text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, thank you for the fact that the President of the Commission has given some thought to the foundations of our European project and for having also written down precisely what the difficulties we are in today are, and for the fact that the answer can only be to provide concrete proof that we can do so in projects. And I want to support or put it into practice in a few places.  Against populists only helps if we regain credibility. And, firstly, credibility is gained by proving that you are following your own rules and your own right. That is why, colleagues from the Socialist Group, it is also a matter of keeping agreements on the issue of the Stability Pact and not changing them every week. Credibility also means standing by what we have agreed together and what the rules say. That is also the responsibility of the Commission.  Secondly, take positions towards populists, not always swim with them when any moods come, but have their own positions. This gives you credibility. TTIP, CETA and others: do we always give in to sentiments, or is it not our job to ensure that things that are recognized as correct are enforced? The latter is the case.  And thirdly, solutions need to be made, not meetings. And solutions must be concrete, practical. What answer do we provide to people for the problem of security needs? What are we really doing to ensure that data exchange between security agencies happens? What do we do on entry, exit? What are we doing when it is externalborders strengthened? What are we doing about a common defence policy? We do not need large models, but, as correctly described, very concrete steps; rather two, but the right one, rather than constantly just describing the things.  Last but not least, if you want to have growth in Europe, you not only have to take money into your hands, but you have to create the conditions for companies to start businesses, and that's where it's happening at every corner of Europe. There is a huge need for action. Incidentally, it is not so difficult to get that: fewer rules and not every detail.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Europe must remain a means whereby European citizens can keep control of their lives in a globalised world, and for this we need a roadmap with better European solutions. With your speech you have made a remarkable contribution in this direction, and the European Parliament supports the adoption of very clear position exactly with this purpose. We would now like the European Council to deliver at the upcoming Bratislava summit, but let me tell you that, at the heart of this roadmap, we should have a strong social pillar, making sure that all European citizens can count on a common set of social standards on working conditions and social protection. This social pillar should entail powerful instruments to deliver on the social standards. We believe that the European Union must become, again, an engine for upward economic and social convergence and, as the law has delivered on cohesion policies, I believe that you should also deliver on completing the economic and monetary union.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the President-in-The Mr Juncker, I certainly do not want to be outrageous or rude, but you are old, you are tired and you are exhausted. You stand for this EU that is currently failing, and what are you doing? You keep repeating your phrases. Unfortunately, nothing new can be expected of you than the tedious management of the often self-inflicted problems, even if you have presented at least some good approaches today. I see the EU in a serious crisis. We still have the euro crisis and its strong economic impact. We have the devastating youth unemployment in southern Europe, the migration crisis, Brexit, terrorism – and the EU still has no satisfactory answers to these problems. You say that you want to explain politics better. You don't have to explain it better, you have to make better policies. The EU must now be reformed, and fundamentally, if we want this EU not to fail in the future, if we really want to give our children answers for a future. Then I do not believe that Mr Verhofstadt of the so-called Liberals is the right person to represent us as a Parliament – or at least I would have liked to have voted on whether he should be the negotiator for Brexit. He stands for centralism in this House like no other. They reject a Europe a la carte. I believe that an a la carte Europe could be precisely the solution for the future.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Mr Juncker, yesterday, Business Europe, the confederation of the great European employers, presented its specifications for the next European Summit.  It is not necessary to be a wizard to guess that, in the conclusions of the summit, all the demands of the great European capital will be there, as is the case at all European summits and councils, as happened here today with your speech. This is the nature of the European Union and its institutions; these, not others, are the interests it defends. For peoples, for those who stand up for their right to the future, employment, wages and income and their sovereignty, for these there are threats and blackmail. Take the unqualified sanctions process against Portugal.  Saving Europe, yes, is urgent, but for this it is necessary to defeat the European Union, because the Europe of Juncker and Barroso, Goldman Sachs and LuxLeaks will never be the Europe of workers and peoples, of those who make a living selling their workforce. This is the crystal clear, raw truth like fists that will one day burst in your face.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the EU is not perfect. President Juncker accepts that and I welcome some of the initiatives that he mentioned in order to tackle challenges such as those in the areas of job creation, connectivity and social justice. President Juncker also said that the EU should empower citizens and embrace solidarity. Well, the people of Scotland voted in June to remain in the European Union to constructively continue to work on collective challenges. Cross-party efforts are being made right now in Scotland to identify all possible means of protecting Scotland’s position, particularly with access to the single market. The Scottish Government is working hard to persuade the UK Government to recognise the democratic will of the people of Scotland in formulating its negotiating position, if it ever gets round to that. I hope that the Commission and the Council, and this Parliament, will be open to imaginatively finding a way to reflect the democratic will of people in Scotland. That would be solidarity.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a year ago, Mr Juncker, you said that the European Union lacked Europe and lacked the Union. Today he should be even more convinced. You spoke to us today of an ideal Europe, of solidarity, of responding to the needs of our citizens. It is a pity, however, that it is a model of Europe that is still too far removed from the present one.  European policies have proved effective in bailing out banks, but not as effective in managing migratory flows or ensuring economic growth for all Member States. The European Union is now perceived as a European power system where technocrats, lobbies and wealthy elites condition decision-making processes and, in this way, impose austerity measures, diminish the role of popular sovereignty and democracy, dismantle the achievements of the welfare state, promote wild liberalisations and deregulation of the labour market, lead to poverty and ultimately increase social inequalities.  If the social and economic progress of present and future generations, the rights of the people, the commons do not become the absolute protagonists of European policies, the citizens will continue to say no to this European Union.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is yet another farce, the umpteenth words in the wind: 3 000 deaths in the Mediterranean Sea of this European Union of peace, 26 million unemployed and, for some phenomenon in here, Europe's enemy are populists and nationalists. You should go to a good doctor, but to a good specialist!  Ordinary people outside this building believe that the danger to 500 million Europeans is Islamic terrorism, which you are helping and funding: with every boat that arrives in Italy, it is millions of euros that end up in the pockets of Islamic nationalists and terrorists. You are fuelling it with the crazy sanctions against Russia, which are costing billions of euros and millions of jobs; you are financing it by giving money to Turkey, which in return gives us nothing; you are fuelling popular anger by taking it up with legitimately elected governments, such as the Hungarian government and the Polish government, to which I give all my free respect; you are keeping a wrong and criminal currency like the euro alive.  I think this is the last vain speech that you, Mr President, will make in this building, because the citizens fortunately can no longer do so and are populistally and nationalistic as they wake up.

name: Martin Sonneborn (NI).
text: Thank you, Boss! The EU has changed. When I took up my mandate, I wanted to fight for a strong core Europe with 27 satellite states. This number has now been reduced. After Brexit and the impending exclusion of the Hungarians, I would like to campaign for the Door to Be shown to the Irish as well. A government that refuses to accept tax payments from Apple could give the impression that it is about a Europe of corporations, not citizens. That is why I appeal to the Irish Government: Dear Mr President of Ireland, if you still believe that Apple will create some jobs in Ireland, forget it. Apple only ever had one job, but he is dead. He will not come back, so please take my advice: take the money and run. EUR 13 billion will buy you many iPhones. This will generate more tax income for Ireland, then you can buy even more iPhones. It is a win-win-win situation. Think it over with a good bottle of whiskey - sl'inte.  A small request, Mr Juncker: could you please encourage your Digital Commissioner Oettinger to log into the German landline every 90 minutes with his mobile phone? This would significantly enhance the negotiations on roaming and performance protection law in Brussels.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Sonneborn, for your speech. The fact that you recognise me as your boss also honours me beyond measure. I didn't even know I was the boss of such a talented person.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There was no official optimism in today's State of the Union speech, because there is no basis for optimism. Today's Zeitgeist climate will not be conducive to celebrating the next anniversary of the Treaties of Rome. Europe is filled with fear and human fears are always fertile soil for populism and xenophobia. That is the reality today. It is xenophobia and populism that dictate the agenda, the tone of public debate and manage people's emotions. It has been possible to combine all threats with open borders, immigration, reluctance to strangers. Nigel Farage was an undoubted pioneer in this field, but he is now very well cloned in many countries, so this political season the key to the European soul will be security, transformed in all varieties, from border security to labour market security.  It is necessary to take up this challenge, to take on a confrontation, because if in the human imagination there is a national state of security, then we will be in a lost position, and this is an illusion, because there is no national response to modern challenges. I think the topic of the Bratislava Summit has been well chosen. Instead of going and demonstrating differences, divisions or helplessness, we need to find a common denominator, which is a common response to security needs. In this case, the common denominator is not the lowest common denominator.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – You are talking about populism, and President Juncker has not said a word about the family, about the rights of the family, and yet it is the family crisis and the birth crisis that is at the source of the decades-long immigration crisis. You are populists. Is it why you are afraid to talk about the family, that family is a mutual duty, and that populists cannot talk about it?

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – President Juncker himself chose the text of his speech, and I believe that he has chosen the tone and text of the speech in the climate that we have in Europe today.

name: Sergei Stanishev (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to acknowledge that President Juncker has the difficult mission of leading the Commission in times when the unthinkable becomes possible and is actually happening. Mr Juncker, Brexit or the lack of solidarity on tackling the refugee and migration crisis are just the symptoms, but in order to help the European Union and create perspective, you need to address the root causes and therein the fact that, in the five years of the Barroso Commission, social Europe fell victim to an austerity—only policy. When you were elected as President of the Commission, you promised to change that. You said that Europe should have social triple—A standards, but this is not a reality yet. What the socialist family is expecting from you and from the Commission is for you to have a clear road map which will balance the freedom of economy and initiative with clear social standards across the European Union.  I would urge you one more time to seriously address the issue of youth in the European Union. Our family proposed a clear plan, a European youth plan, with four clear pillars: employment with much more money for that for the Youth Guarantee – and I did not hear your commitment – culture, education and child protection. If you start fighting for that and making it a reality, then there is a good chance that Europe will return confidence to the citizens.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur For the next twelve months everyone will have everything they want. More social, but not a word about austerity or about flexibility in the application of the Pact for Growth and Stability. The Internet is going to visit, the rapid withdrawal of Britain, and let us immediately develop the capital market outside London. And the fight against social dumping, thus supposedly reducing social inequalities. Yes, in a particular country – yes, but among European countries it will be even greater social inequality, because the younger generation from poorer countries will move where they can get this Quality of Life in Europe, and that will be a problem for the European Union.  About protection. Yes, a new fund that perhaps does not tell how he will work, and there is a signal to NATO countries that, in this case, we will be planning military operations without the US and without Britain in the future, which I think is not right, all the more so because, in your speech, Mr President of the Commission, I did not hear a single word about Russia. Yes, except for the payment of refunds for the loss of the Russian market for milk. But Russia's aggression in Ukraine, the crime issue – as if there were no this aggressor just outside the borders of the European Union.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, let us then talk about the state of the Union, but let us talk about the concrete, and not continue to make lists of generalities. Germany has been in breach of the 6% limit on external surpluses since 2007 and has already been warned in 2013. Germany ignored it and what they did was increase the surpluses to record levels. However, we all know that there will never be sanctions for Germany. Why? Because Germany is Germany.  France had a budget deficit of 3.5% in 2015 and will continue to breach the deficit limit in 2016, and we all know that there will be no sanctions for France. Why? Because France is France. Portugal has undergone one of the most painful adjustment processes in the entire European Union and, according to the European Commission, will reduce the deficit to below the legal limit. However, we are all still discussing a shameful process of sanctions for Portugal, particularly in terms of cuts in European funds. Why, Mr President? Because Portugal is Portugal.  This is the state of the Union that you ignored in your speech. But tell me something, Mr President, aren't you ashamed?

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The State of the Union is under all criticism, despite what you say, Mr Juncker. We are seeing a Union that is cracking at an ever-increasing pace and losing more and more confidence in the electorate. After all, there was the greatest lack of confidence in England, as we now know after the elections. I would like to take this opportunity here and now to congratulate the English people who are now freeing themselves from the increasingly onerous yoke of the European Union. I look forward to Sweden's continued good relations with the UK. Mr Juncker is now in favour of defence cooperation, i.e. a joint military force. As you know, Sweden has always been neutral as a country. It has also meant that we have been able to take on the role of credible negotiator during several crises. This is now looking to end as we are now to be forced into military cooperation. The incomprehension shown in the face of the problems will erode the confidence of the electorate even more. At the moment, the EU can be likened to a sick patient who can only be offered pain relief at the moment.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Commission, even today, in the person of its President, qualifies its condition as existential. I would go so far as to say that it is even catastrophic.  The British have said: good bye, we are leaving this European Union. Today or in the course of this week, the Poles are to be condemned by a majority decision of this House. There is a call from Luxembourg for the exclusion of Hungarians. All I can say is: how absurd is what is manifesting itself here? Recall, a few years earlier, when friendship reigned on this continent, when we looked to each other in peace and freedom in a good future! Today, much has changed with the course of centralization. A false monetary policy with the euro and refugee policy has brought strife and strife across this continent. I appeal to you: understand the signs of the British referendum correctly! Hear this alarm call: away from centralisation, away from the dictates of Brussels, back to the rule of law, to subsidiarity, to sovereignty and thus to more proportional development on this continent!

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Madam President, finally the first foundations of a defence Europe are in sight. This is to be welcomed. But let us not forget, as you rightly pointed out, Mr President of the Commission, that military means are a mere tool in the service of a foreign policy. You have rightly given the example of Syria, and I will mention two others. What is our foreign policy vis-à-vis Russia? The Minsk agreement was not negotiated by the Union, it was negotiated by two Member States and, beyond Ukraine, the situation in the Caucasus, the threats to the Baltic States, Russia's gas diplomacy, are non-subjects for the Union. It is extravagant that a quarter of a century after the end of the Cold War, we are unable to speak with one voice with Moscow.  Second example, Libya. It has once again become the first gateway for migrants and a territory of retreat for Islamist militias. In an effort to re-establish the country, the United States, Qatar, the UAE, Turkey, Egypt are firing at booing and dia with some member states. Where is Europe? Offshore, at sea. Of course, for humanitarian actions, that is good, but it condemns her to be subjected to the decisions taken by others upstream. Without a common policy, we will have additional resources to continue to do nothing together.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to single out just one aspect of the speech. The citizens of the Union have a right to safety. This is internal security and external security. That is why, Mr Juncker, you have my support for your proposals for better cooperation between the secret services, including for a fund on defence policy, including for the start of structured and permanent cooperation in this area. But all this should lead to greater efficiency and not to a pointless additional upgrade. That is why these desired activities can only really be tackled if the Member States are prepared to make additional funds available. The security of our external border, the control over who comes in and who comes out – yes, we have all neglected that a little bit, and we need to do more. But one thing must also be clear: this is not the solution to our refugee crisis. At most, it helps us to defuse our EU crisis in the accommodation and distribution of refugees. The refugee crisis will only be resolved if the much-vaunted values of our Union are taken seriously by all governments and if we use an effective development policy to tackle the causes of flight and displacement. To do this, however, you also have to pay into the funds that have been created.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Juncker, Europe is worse off than it was a year ago. The attacks in France, in Germany, in Belgium, brexit, mafias, which continue to choose which refugees are passing by. Populism grows, unemployment grows, skepticism grows, the feeling that the system is not working grows. Institutions work. The Commission works, Parliament works, but what doesn't really work is solidarity between states. Without solidarity there is no Europe, even if there are European institutions. Solidarity is the vaccine against nationalist interests. Solidarity is what we learned from the war. Solidarity is, as you said, Mr Juncker, and Mr Weber , a European way of life, but also a model of European life enjoyed by all citizens equally and not one more and less. Solidarity is for all countries to fulfil their commitment to the deficit and their budgetary commitment; but solidarity is also that some partners do not seek to sanction others. Solidarity is for the South to understand that Putin is a threat, but solidarity is also that the East understands that mass immigration is a common problem. Solidarity is that the single market means a single economy and not twenty-eight economies. Solidarity is one for twenty-seven and twenty-seven for one: Europe. Solidarity is Europe, and Europe is the only possible future for Europeans. That is why I congratulate you on your speech and tell you to count on my support and that of my country, Spain. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Pons, do you think it is fair that the Spanish Government is announcing further cuts for next year to comply with the European Union? Do you think these measures will no longer harm the most disadvantaged classes of the Spanish state?

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Madam President, I believe that Spain, like all the countries of the Union, has to fulfil its commitments. I think if we're a unique economy, we have to behave loyally to each other. I do not believe that Spain should be sanctioned, but I do believe that Spain should live up to it and not miss what has been committed to its partners. To have a word is to be a good partner and Spain is.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Mistrust, that is, the state of the Union, the loss of European identity. Many Europeans have forgotten about it or don't even know her. For? Because too many politicians and leaders have forgotten what European values are, and because we have not consistently reacted to the violation of rights and values outside or within our borders, because we do not offer, as you said, a social Europe. Our vision must be based on people and in no way can it contain secret TI-type agreements that lower the standard of Europeans. We must not allow ourselves to be completely taken over by the issue of security, while neglecting to care about the privacy of Europeans. The Union's solidarity corps, Mr Juncker, this is a wonderful idea for the inclusion of young people and for helping people in need. With such ideas, the Union will once again straighten its backbone.  We need optimism, pessimism doesn't solve problems. And we need the awareness of all of us, in leadership positions, that the coming months are crucial and that we will be held accountable if Europe succumbs to populism and nationalism.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President of the Commission, your speech was clear and very propitious at this historic moment: your words give us a glimpse of a light after a long crisis. We come from a dry no to our project for Union on the part of an important state, from which we expect responsibility and demand responsibility. We see, day after day, increasing our citizens' distrust of this Europe. As you yourself acknowledge, we are asking you and the Commission, but above all the Council, for a decisive qualitative leap forward: we need ambition, concreteness and defined objectives. Urgent action is needed on a number of priorities: security, immigration, work and the protection of savings.  On security, we need a clear decision: well the European border police, which needs to be further strengthened, Mr President, but we need our own army and, above all, a truly common foreign policy. This action is necessary only and exclusively to continue to maintain many years of peace, which are the main result of 60 years of our being together. Unemployment, particularly among young people, in Europe has exceeded 20% and in my country it is close to 40%. The investment plan is giving its first results: well the strengthening you have announced, perhaps let us triple it, Mr President! We stimulate investment, thus restarting growth and employment. The protection of savings must be guaranteed. Do we believe with bail-in that we have really protected all citizens, or just the state budget? Europe, as you said, needs concreteness and quick responses to give to its citizens: we need neither forwards, nor directors, nor three-way summits. Mr Juncker, Commissioners, this is the time to act forcefully and decisively.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: Mr President, you started by saying, 'I am going to make positive proposals'. That is very important to us in our group. There is no point in some sort of collective depression to lapse after Brexit. We have to move forward. We must make full use of our powers to provide concrete answers to the challenges we face. You yourself said: 'Europe is not social enough'. You will not be surprised if our whole group agrees with you. We also ask you for solutions to social dumping and youth unemployment. Your attention to youth is extremely important. Young people support the European project, but it also supports a different economy and that is a bit of my criticism. You have given a long laundry list of many good projects, but I would also like you to draw a lot of attention to the transition in our economy. Another industry is possible. New jobs are possible. But it has to be a different economy. So if we are going to invest extra, then those investments have to be based on that transition economy.

name: József Szájer (PPE).
text: – Dear Madam President McGuinness, President Juncker spoke emphatically about security. The People's Party welcomes the fact that it has become an independent Commissioner for Internal Security. It is time for Parliament to follow this. On behalf of the People's Party Group, I propose that Parliament set up an independent committee on internal security. The complex issues of internal security and terrorism are only present in one dimension in this Parliament, in the context of human rights. Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. As a Hungarian European politician, I speak about the issue of the immigration crisis. Our position is clear and humane. It is not the trouble that needs to be brought into Europe, it is the local help for those in trouble. And especially for them to get home as soon as possible. Illegal immigration must be stopped. External European borders must be protected. Definitely, just like Hungary does. We do not consider it fair that those who are illegally allowed in or invited by others should be shared according to a mandatory quota. The Hungarian people will have the opportunity to express their views in the form of a referendum. Other countries should not be afraid to ask their citizens about immigration, to get honest answers. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Madam President, I do not know how this structure was built, that it did not come upon us at these moments when, on behalf of the People's Party, the Fidesz member spoke of humane conduct. How can you look Mr Juncker in the eye of his own party family while running a campaign in Hungary – with public money – in which, for example, in government publications, a photograph of Mr Juncker is posted on the waiting room of the ruined airport of the Brussels terrorist attack, as if it were Mr Juncker and Mr Schulz's fault that there had otherwise been a bombing there. In Hungary, they are campaigning against the European Union, and here he is talking about humane behaviour.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Madam President, I did not hear any question.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: Madam President, let me quote a French poet who says: "There is no love, there is only proof of love." After Brexit, Mr President of the Commission, I fear that your declaration of love for Europe will not be enough, we will need proof. How many years have citizens been waiting for the European social pillar? It is not surprising that they no longer believe in it and, therefore, how can we be pleased to have blocked 80% of European legislation? So yes, Europe expects action. In this case, we lack budgetary evidence and this lack of resources contributes to immobility. What is expected is consistency between words and actions, what is expected is a fit between political announcements and budgetary resources, starting with a real revision of the multi-year financial framework and another budget for 2017.  What we expect is that every new political decision, like the one you announced today and which we share, on security, borders and defence, will be accompanied by new budgetary resources. What we reject are budget cuts that strip research, that is, the investment of tomorrow, to dress up today's investment.  What we are waiting for is the funding of the youth guarantee that you have quoted, but for which the Commission has indicated zero euro commitments in the 2017 budget.  And what we are waiting for, Mr President, and Mr President of the Council for that matter, is an initiative to establish new own resources, not an umpteenth committee, but a proposal and negotiation with every parliament in each Member State.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr President of the European Commission, I would like to congratulate you on your speech, in which you were those who are the key points of the European Union's priorities and, in particular, the concrete measures that are necessary.  There is, however, one question I have to ask, which is this: you are very concerned about populism and even Euroscepticism; however, what we see in the news, the rumors and behind the scenes of the European institutions is that there is talk of the possibility of suspending and cutting the structural funds to Portugal and Spain.  Now, countries that have made enormous sacrifices and are fully available to meet the targets should not be sanctioned in this way.  If the Commission considered that the Portuguese State should not be sanctioned, it should also consider that the Portuguese people, businesses, citizens and also universities should not be penalised for such suspension of funds. This will only increase, in Portugal and Spain, the populism and strength of those who are against integration and the European project.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Union is not in good shape, but that must not be a cause for schadenfreude. Some colleagues cannot stop celebrating their schadenfreude here. We were not elected to be destructive. Our task is to solve problems. We must see the difficulties as challenges. Europe has grown every time it has overcome its difficulties.  However, we should not only keep an eye on the obvious problems – the refugee crisis, recession, unemployment, the institutional crisis – but we must also look forward. I think it is very positive, President Juncker, that you have given wide scope to shaping the digital future. The digital future can only be managed at European level, and the Digital Single Market is our most important project – it secures jobs. With regard to the data protection package, we have also seen that we, as Europeans, can set global standards.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had on the work of the rapporteur for her excellent work President Juncker, you have met our expectations with your description of the state of affairs and your specific action plan, because you have mentioned the urgent matters by their name. Our problem is the way in which some politicians deal with the global challenges, with the concerns and fears of the people and with the joint decisions of the European Union, is the insincerity of too many state law firms towards the citizens – let us deal with the moods instead of kneeling before them – is populism that leads to nationalism and the loss of credibility of the European Union. The Bratislava Summit must be a signal of solidarity. It must mean a reversal. Now we must go through all the Member States of the European Union: for the Security and Defence Union, for more tax justice, for the doubling of the investment plan, for the digital single market, for the distribution of refugees, for the protection of the external border and for the common migration and asylum policy.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Madam President, there are multiple problems facing Europe, and Brexit is of course one of them. It will be the mother of all divorce cases, and if done too hastily will be a disaster for both sides. The list of issues that need to be addressed and solved is huge and every day we discover new ones that were never mentioned by the Leave campaign in the national referendum in Britain. The British Government has not triggered Article 50 because it still has no clue on what it wants to do about most of these issues. The big one, of course, is whether it wants to try to secure a place remaining in the single European market – but then, of course, it has to accept all the common rules for the common market – or whether it wants to leave entirely and face a tariff barrier and a regulatory barrier to our main export market. It is an unpalatable choice, and whichever way the government goes on this has huge implications for Britain and Europe, but it will also see people who voted ‘leave’ complain, rightly, that this is not what they were told, and not what they voted for. Brexit is not a settled issue, neither at European level nor at national level, where calls for a rethink continue to grow.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – I am grateful to Mr Corbett for giving way, and I pay tribute to his own esprit européen within this House consistently and over the years. I very much join his condemnation of a deeply dishonest leave campaign that made a number of promises that now simply cannot be fulfilled and will unravel over the years. But would he agree with me that we really must ensure a common UK approach within this, which must respect and represent the interests of London, Gibraltar, Scotland and Northern Ireland, and also that the timescale on this must give us the flexibility to work out the plurality of views within the UK in order to reach some sort of common position to present to our European friends?

name: Richard Corbett (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I agree entirely that this situation has thrown up a multitude of problems that were never properly explored before the decision took place, and certainly never pointed to by those who wished to drag Britain out of the European Union. We have to make the best of a terrible situation, working together, all parts of the UK and of Europe, and at some point when people see the reality of what Brexit really entails rather than the promises that were made – that it would solve every problem, that it would be wonderful, that it would be paradise – there will be many in Britain who will say that they want to think again about this.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I will repeat the words of our leader, Mr. Manfred Weber, who said, "Stop cheap populism against Brussels." The obligation of us politicians is to deliver positive news about the European Union and this, as Mr Juncker said, I want to thank you for this speech. Let's not just speak engagedly here in Strasbourg, that's how we speak in national parliaments and thank you for that. We all have to help together. The fact is that maybe Europe is a bit shaken up after Brexit, but it is certainly not at risk. Therefore, we must restore trust and the European Union cannot do it alone.  I am in favour of a common foreign and European policy, but it cannot be solved only in Berlin, only in Paris, it must be dealt with in both Madrid and Lisbon and Athens, but also in Zagreb. I would like to remind you that our colleague Andrej Plenković will become the new Croatian Prime Minister and I am sure that Croatia will also contribute to the new common foreign policy of the European Union and I think that as a new member we will be engaged in helping just one more sentence.  Thank you also for wanting workers to be paid the same in the same place and have the same salary. This is our European solidarity. In this way, we will prove that we respect the principle of European solidarity that we stand for so much and that you said were mentioned 16 times in the European treaties.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we, the protagonists of Today's life in Europe, are certainly not heroes, and perhaps we have a greater task than ourselves, yet our choices and strength will depend on an historic judgment. In a few years' time, it will be assessed whether Europe, at the height of its most serious crisis, has been reborn or whether it has embarked on the path of dissolution inexorable. You did very well, Mr Juncker, to remind us of this. Our responsibility today is not linked to the daily life of the news, to our political life, but is linked to this appointment, to this passage with history.  We say no, therefore, to any wait-and-see, President and President-in-Office of the Council, towards Brexit and towards the indispensable change of course of many European policies, starting with the economic one, where it is now clear that the pact is not the cornerstone, but a real expansionary budgetary policy, a fiscal capacity of the Union. And let me say to Mr Beazley that we are not going to be able to do anything about it. Weber, above all, but also others – that when the pact is applied intelligently it does not lose credibility, if anything it increases it vis-à-vis the citizens.  I would just like to say two points, Mr Weber, by title: fiscal fairness – the first step towards a fierce fight against evasion and avoidance – and social equity. There is a proposal on the table, that of insurance for the unemployed, put forward by Padoan: it becomes a point of European social policy, to show that we – and you believe in all this, I have confidence in your conviction – are concerned with the right to dignity of the weakest citizens. So let us adopt this Padoan proposal, it is feasible, it is financially sustainable and let us make it a star of European policy.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President of the Commission, you were right to say that many things in Europe at the moment are not converged as they should, and that we lack the necessary solidarity in many areas. Even if we, our group, are right to say: 'Have a courageous agenda, move forward, set targets for a courageous Europe, for an upright Europe', we know that you cannot do everything. Many things are blocked nationally.  You are talking about smart rules. I would like to repeat a proposal made by my group five years ago in the debate on the Stability and Growth Pact. It must make a difference whether a country effectively combats youth unemployment or keeps a water head from administration. It must make a difference whether a country effectively invests in modern technologies, in the energy transition, or finances the Stone Age. It must make a difference whether a country helps to offer refugees a new home in solidarity, or whether it refuses and, on the other hand, does not move a hand for it. I believe that there is a lot of potential for creativity here. We need to change our fiscal rules so that the Commission can also lead intelligently. That is the petitum of our group, and here we are waiting for proposals.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Madam President. Loss of European values, growing national selfishness, unclear course and unresolved continuing crises: that could be the summary of today's Europe; a bleak but changing picture in our hands, because only with a shared effort will we save the Union's project. Because the economic crisis, the refugee and migration crisis, the security crisis are only in response to a common solution, and the time has come for the European Commission with Mr Juncker at the forefront of those who are not in a position to support and are blocking Community initiatives. We will be uncomfortable, we will be able to criticize and demand more forcefulness; we will demand the social pillar, a fairer monetary and fiscal policy, rights for workers. We will oppose the blocking of funds for Spain and Portugal, but we will do so by cooperating with you if you fulfil your commitments and collect our proposals. Let us not let the hope of the European dream disappear. Let us not fail to believe that it is possible to change Europe.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). Madam President, in order to solve the problems, we must take concrete initiatives. I propose two: Firstly, we must clarify our relationship with Turkey, which I consider an important country, with which we must develop our cooperation, but we cannot believe that Turkey will join the European Union. As long as we let the pendulum hover, so will Brexit-style momentum in other European countries that find the prospect of joining the European Union unthinkable in a country with so many undemocratic characteristics. Secondly, we must make a significant increase in the European budget, which we have unfortunately reduced in recent years, in order to finance the digitisation of the European economy, research, innovation and an important pan-European programme in favour of youth employment. I think we can. The crucial question is whether we really want to.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President. Mr President, you said this: we are no better off than we were a year ago. And since this state-of-the-Union debate began with President Barroso in 2009, with the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, there is no worse symptom of the deterioration of the European Union — even worse than brexit and non-compliance with commitments of cohesion and solidarity — than divorce and the distance between speeches and facts. Your speeches deserve applause in this House. But the facts deserve the disapproach, discouragement and mass disaffection of the citizens represented in this European Parliament. And the reason is simple: ricketic growth, which shows the inadequacies of the Juncker plan; massive youth unemployment, showing the shortcomings of the Youth Guarantee, absent from his speech; non-compliance with solidarity commitments is shown by the threat of the fine to Spain and Portugal, which would only increase disaffection in two countries that had and maintain a great European vocation; and, of course, the threat to a commitment to shared responsibility in the face of the ill-called refugee crisis posed by Hungary's referendum. The problem is not a lack of ideas, but of will and leadership, that Europe does not miss its last chance before it is too late in the 2019 elections.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Mr Juncker mentioned the terrible murder of Arkadiusz Jozwik. Hate crime is despicable. Six people have been arrested for this murder. But, Mr Juncker, you did not mention the hundreds and hundreds of local people from Harlow in Essex who stand united to condemn this crime. The vast majority of British people want a calm and peaceful negotiation for their future relationship with Europe. There are deep trade links between the UK and the rest of the EU; if we are forced to rip the UK out of the single market without a long-term plan, there will be economic consequences across all of Europe. Negotiators on both sides of the English Channel need to take time to get this right. Finally, Mrs Georgieva, you would be great in the UN.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the State of the Union report, above all, shows only a hint of self-criticism, but a complete lack of sufficient measures to deal with the crisis. More precisely, a crisis of several affecting the European Union at once. I base this claim on conflicting views and an ineffective solution to the migration crisis, a situation where the majority of UK citizens do not see a good future in the common Union, but also on the growing inequalities between the EU's north and south.  But none of these crises can be fatal. But this implies an effort and an ability to understand the nature of the mistakes that these crises have created. And it also assumes the sincerity to admit that these mistakes were caused by specific individuals. It must be clear who specifically reacted late and who made mistakes. Given the situation, the President of the Commission should consider, with all due respect, whether he is capable of taking the European Union out of the crisis or whether he should resign.

name: Julia Reda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the State of the Union is analogue, the State of the Union is corporate. Two years ago, Mr Juncker, I actually voted for you because you promised us, as your top priority, a copyright reform that would tear down national borders, that would mobilise the European digital potential and that would make everything clearer and easier to understand. Today, the Commission is presenting the exact opposite. You are barely touching the national differences in copyright laws. Instead you are standing here today and telling us that publishers need to be paid for linking to their articles. No, just no. All that this will do is make it more difficult for European tech companies to actually compete on a global level. It will stifle freedom of expression online and it will lead to fewer links to European publications and less media diversity. Finally, this proposal has already been rejected by Parliament numerous times.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, what Mr Juncker said to us in his speech is nothing more than a repetition of already known analyses, literary positions, and unworkable objectives. How is it possible, for example, to reunite Cyprus when Turkey does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus and the European Union tolerates this situation? How can the European Union be decisively involved in the Syrian crisis when its foreign policy is identical to that of the United States? How can European standards and the European way of life be maintained when all the countries of Europe, especially Greece, have been overwhelmed by millions of Muslims, who proudly and resolutely proclaim that they will enforce Islamic Sharia law throughout Europe? How can youth unemployment be tackled when Mr Juncker himself said that talented young people should come from third countries? Finally, how is it possible that Mr. Younger is proud of FRODEX? Has he not been informed by the Italian coast guard, and especially by the Greek coast guard, that all FRODEX can do is pretend to be the traffic warden of those who want to enter these two countries illegally? Yes, there must be a change in Europe but it must be done on the basis and on the basis of serving the interests of its peoples and not on the basis of the obsessions and ideologies of the european Union's leadership circle.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the European Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to express my sincere thanks for the debate, including for what has been said about the Commission. I have not ignored the negative, but for reasons of time I cannot now respond to all the points that have been raised – because arguments have not always been. I would like to thank the large groups in this House for their broad support. I would just like to say a word about Turkey, because this could not be dealt with in my speech. We are still in intensive negotiations with Turkey on the visa issue. I would like to make it clear once again that visa liberalisation can only take place if all the preconditions mentioned are met by Turkey, although I call on us to be a little more patient on a number of points, because it is necessary to resolve the most difficult issues in Turkey. I am convinced that this will happen, but it will not necessarily be possible within the timeframe set for this purpose. But without a reform of, for example, the anti-terrorism law, it will not be possible to seriously consider visa liberalisation with regard to Turkey on a specific date. I am glad that almost everyone has spoken out in favour of strengthening social rights in the European Union. You know what consultation procedures are currently under way on the fundamental pillar of social workers' rights. We will await the outcome of these consultations and then present our proposals. I am also grateful that our reference to the need to double the resources of the European Investment Fund has met with broad support. The Council and Parliament must do their own thing in order to reach decisions on this. The same goes for everything to do with the digital agenda. Here, too, we must work closely together. Once again, thank you very much, Mr President, for the debate. (Applause)

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). You've confessed to the worst state of the Union, Mr. Younger. Your European way of life, unemployment, poverty, tax evasion, the uprooting of farmers, the dead ends of young people with unpaid work and immigration will certainly get worse, both in Greece and everywhere. The Union is not in danger, you said. But the people are in danger. Victims of megather competition for energy and markets. In fact, you are giving a joint headquarters for interventions in the Middle East and Africa. Young people as mercenary volunteers for your victims, refugees, those trapped in Greece. You are proposing more exploitation, cheaper workers, more funds and profits for the bees, as well as old and new social democracy (Hollande, Renzi, and, now, Tsipras) are calling for more flexibility in the Stability Pact to strengthen the bees, rather than wage and pension increases, since they are also tearing their peoples as much as Merkel, Schaeuble and Brexit May. The vision of all of you is the nightmare of the people. The European Union is not improving. Capitalism only guarantees unemployment, poverty and wars. Rot can't be cured. Upset.

name: Marcel de Graaff (ENF).
text: Mr President, this European Commission is not a good one because it exposes its citizens to the terror of Islam and of hundreds of thousands of migrants from Muslim countries who despise our culture. Because she supports bad regimes such as neo-Nazis in Ukraine, the dictatorship in Iran, the anti-Semitic Palestinian Authority and the Sultan of Ankara. Because it is killing the economies of southern Europe, plunging millions of people into unemployment and thereby making the citizens of northern Europe pay for the costs. This Union is not good and its administrative elite is no good. I repeat, therefore, that Mr Juncker must resign. If he does not, I ask him to at least promote the following: no visa liberalisation for Turkey, Ukraine and other rogue states, no more taking in migrants in the EU and sending the current migrants back, not bringing powers to Brussels and restoring national borders and powers, but above all de-Islamising the EU.

name: Nigel Farage (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I was told again and again in the Brexit debate that there would not be a European army, that there would not be an independent military force in the European Union. Well, here it is. Here it is. And the most interesting comment was not Mr Juncker’s when he talked about ‘parallel command structures’; it was Mr Verhofstadt’s, when he basically said ‘go away America, we can do this on our own’.  You cannot run these two structures in parallel with each other without one competing against the other. And once you have got an independent military force, then the argument becomes stronger to start using it. I remember, Mr Verhofstadt, back at the time of Libya and elsewhere you were itching for the EU to militarily start getting involved, and for a project that prides itself on being about peace and reconciliation, I think what is being proposed today is potentially very dangerous and I wonder, if you put it to referendums around the European Union, whether people would endorse it. I do not think so.

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to add something to Turkey. I am currently speaking almost daily with colleagues from Turkey, but also from Ukraine. I believe that one thing is still very important: we must recognise that democratic developments in countries like this can never be achieved from outside. However, our commitments to continue to assist the democrats in these countries in their commitment to the rule of law and democracy, in Ukraine and Turkey, we must not give up this commitment. Mr Farage, you are making us nationalists? I must tell you that the first thing I was very sad about was the decision that the British want to leave the European Union. You are the one who persuades the British that tomorrow's challenges could be answered by going back to yesterday. Let me tell you one thing: this road back to yesterday has never gone well. The future of the European Union, the future on this continent, will be won by those who dare to have this future together, because the better future on this continent has just begun with the fact that we have dared to do what we have done together. I actually find it sad that, as a German, I have to say this to a British nationalist. (Applause from the left)

name: Gabriele Zimmer (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Two comments: I do not believe that citizens feel safer when the EU behaves like a half-strong macker. So I think here: joint headquarters, joint defence fund. I believe that many citizens are more likely to feel that they are involved in military conflicts much more quickly. I would ask you to think about this. My second comment is PNR. You yourself spoke of the need to protect privacy. What is your position on the Advocate General's announcement that the EU's PNR agreement with Canada is contrary to the fundamental rights of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights? Do you also say here: we are not renegotiating with Canada?

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, very briefly, Rebecca Harms was shocked by the words used by Mr Farage. Well I am not shocked by them. Mr Farage is like an alcoholic who complains that another guy is drinking a pint in a pub, to give a good example that he can understand. That it is his problem. It is, on the one hand, ridiculous. But on the other it is not ridiculous because the reality is that, for nationalists and populists, it is not about Brexit, it is not about the interests of British citizens and certainly not about British industry: it is about destroying Europe. The real agenda is about destroying the European Union. That is also the reason why Mr Farage continues to sit here in this House. It is completely ridiculous that we are being attacked because we want European defence, when the US President himself is saying that we need to take responsibility on our own continent and it cannot always be the American army that will do it. OK, I understand, Mr Farage, that you are critical of the operation in Libya. I understand too that you were apparently a good friend of all autocrats in the world, including Mr Putin and Mr Gaddafi. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Verhofstadt, does it not concern you, as someone who calls for closer military cooperation within the European Union, that there are three traditionally neutral Member States within the European Union – notably the Republic of Ireland, Sweden and Austria? What does that say for those countries’ neutrality?

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I do not see any contradictions in this. I do not see any contradiction between European defence and the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. I see this, on the contrary, as a development of a European pillar of NATO. It is absolutely necessary to regain control of our own neighbourhood as soon as possible.

name: Syed Kamall (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it is quite nice to be able to speak after Guy Verhofstadt in this House for once. Since we overtook his Group at the European elections I have not had the chance. But, Guy, I am not saying that this House is a cause of nationalism. However, if you continue to ignore the concerns of citizens, if you continue to focus on EU integration rather than on creating jobs, if you continue to press on regardless, you will drive voters into the arms of those whom you call populists. Yes, the UK will leave the European Union, but it is not as though there is some gain for any of us. We need each other to be prosperous, and the UK and the EU will continue to cooperate. The EU and the UK both need policies to provide security, to deliver jobs and to offer opportunities for citizens in all the countries represented here today. I am afraid, however, that what we heard today was not a State of the Union. It was the same old mantras: it was a state of the reunion.

name: Gianni Pittella (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I honestly remain grounded when I hear Mr Farage and Mrs Le Pen say 'now help us achieve Brexit'. They have been determined, convinced, tenacious in calling for Brexit – and Mr Syley has said that he is not going to be able to do that. Le Pen la Frexit – and then they are not capable and they catch it with the devil, Mr Le Pen said. Verhofstadt, but you are the devils! You are the devils because you have deceived the British people with your lies, you have led them to a decision that will hurt the British people and that will hurt the European Union.  Secondly, poverty, income redistribution, iniquity, social dumping and sustainable growth are our priorities. Thank you, Mr Juncker, because they are also the European Commission's priorities.  Thirdly, you introduced the Capital Market Union this morning. Now we have the Market Union, the Banking Union, to complete, the Capital Market Union. We must work to make the Political Union, the political union of Europe. This is a great challenge. You'll say, "but Pittella's dreaming." We must dream in order to achieve the best things and we must have the strength that comes from being united: the European Commission and the European Parliament, as Delors said, hand in hand. If we go together we can also win by realizing our dreams!

name: Manfred Weber (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his work and for I liked the serious tone, the factual tone, in the discussion today, because people expect answers from us on the matter. And what we can see today is that Jean-Claude Juncker, with his programme and the entire Commission with the great backing of this House, can now start this work. The two institutions , the European Commission and the European Parliament, are capable of delivering. That is the first important point after these three hours of debate. The second point remains: are the Member States now able to move? The debate between North and South on the euro issue, the debate between East and West on migration, and a few days ago, another one came up with the idea of applying for the exclusion of a Member State. Don't be angry with me, but sometimes it sounds more like kindergarten and not serious politics that are being made there. That is why the Council must finally come up with common answers to the tasks of our time. Then we would convince people. And the third – on our question of dealing with populists and extremists from the left and right: I would like to start by saying on Brexit: do not be angry with me – I am politically with those who say that the effect across Europe is such that, according to the polls conducted neutrally, we now have as high approval ratings for the European idea in many, many states of the European Union as we have not been for a long time – in Germany. , my own country, as has not been in the polls since 1977 – because people across Europe see that berlin does not have a problem, people see that it is not Paris that has a problem, people see that it is not Rome that has a problem, but people see that London has a big problem, namely how to deal with the situation. We are experiencing strife, we are experiencing disunity, and even the protagonists of the exit, the upper supporters of the exit, have disappeared. Farage resigns, Johnston is no longer heard. Farage even says: the 350 million we save - that was a lie. That is the reality we are in. And that is why we should now approach the Brexit debate in a really positive way. If a country wants to go out, it is not only the British who say: Brexit means Brexit, but then we Europeans too would have to say: Brexit is Brexit. It will be a difficult road for Britain, but in reality Farage will have to answer to his children in the future what a bitter result he will have for his country. In this debate, therefore, I am campaigning for our principles to be upheld, as Jean-Claude Juncker has done. We stand by this Europe, and the Brexit debate will show that this Europe is right! (Applause) (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Weber, Mr Coburn really wants to ask you a question. And because he is one of those who will leave at some point, I would ask you to accept that.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Weber, I do not know if you have visited Paris recently. I had not been there for some considerable time but, when I went through the streets of Paris changing trains, I was shocked by the number of people sleeping in major boulevards in Paris. If you do not think that is a problem, I do not know what is. And as for young people, young people are supporting Brexit in the UK and I think more and more people in France and other countries are also doing that. Do you agree with me?

name: Manfred Weber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. In fact, it is not worth giving populists more speaking time through such requests, quite frankly. Perhaps this needs to be reconsidered for the future. However, the speech clearly shows how populists and extremists work. They distort the truth, and they simplify. We live in a world where we have complex issues ahead of us, and that is why we must continue along the path of seriousness.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Weber, I would like to thank Mr Weber for No one in this House is obliged to accept such an issue. You would have always had the right to say: no, I have no desire to answer the question. But you can see that the question is being asked and the answer is not wanted. Colleagues in this House should also reflect on this. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. – In the State of the Union debate, Jean-Claude Juncker identified three main priorities for next year and again drew attention to the importance of the issue of refugees, a real challenge to the ability to affirm the civilisationvalues that Europe is demanding. In his speech, the President of the European Commission set out the following roadmap for next year: to safeguard the European social model by rejecting dogmatic interpretations of the Stability and Growth Pact and the Fiscal Treaty; ensuring the safety of European citizens by establishing new defence mechanisms, naturally articulated with NATO, but of European character; and promote the implementation of trade agreements between the European Union and other countries or regions in order to decisively influence the regulation of globalisation.  It is now important to move from words to deeds. In view of this speech by the President of the European Commission, and after the removal of sanctions, it is absurd to continue to consider the suspension of Community funds to be channelled to Portugal and Spain. I am sure that the European Socialist Group will be at the front line in combating this possibility, which would do nothing more than weaken the European project.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. – Loss of European values, growing national selfishness, unclear course and unresolved continuing crises: that could be the summary of today's Europe. A bleak but changing picture in our hands, because only with a shared effort will we save the Union's project. There is no worse symptom of the union's deterioration than the distance between speeches and facts. The problem is not a lack of ideas, but a lack of will and leadership. The economic crisis, the refugee crisis and the security crisis are only in response with a common solution. The time has come for the European Commission, with Mr Juncker at the forefront, to raise its faces with those who are not in a willingness to support and are blocking Community initiatives. We will be uncomfortable, we will be able to criticize and demand more forcefulness. We will demand the social pillar, fairer monetary and fiscal policy and rights for workers. We will oppose the blockade of funds for Spain and Portugal. But we will do so by cooperating with you if you fulfill your commitments and collect our proposals. Let us not let the hope of the European dream disappear. Let us not fail to believe that it is possible to change Europe.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – I underline the importance of the annual State of the Union debate and congratulate President Juncker on his speech.  I could not agree more that we need more solidarity at all levels. But let me highlight what i said about migration policy: we need to act specifically to protect unaccompanied children arriving on our shores. At least 90,000 were in 2015. This year alone, according to Europol, more than 10 000 people have been reported missing on our continent. But let's be clear: we have many thousands trapped in Greece. Let's not forget these kids either.  I fully agree that we need a coordinated European approach to the conflict in Syria. But if it is certain that this is the only way we will start to deal with the problems at their origin, it seems to me unbelievable that a new fund will solve something. How much of the promised have we already raised for the Trust Fund for Africa? How much of what we have promised in the ill-fated agreement with Turkey have we managed to hoard? Little, very little.  Mr President, national governments are required to honor their commitments, but I do not believe that the European Commission can resign from its role by just launching proposals for the table.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the Commission's positive agenda, as presented by the President of the Commission. Europe is the sum of its parts. Populism and nationalism do not take us any further. We have big and difficult tasks ahead of us, but this is nothing new! What is new is that everything that Europe has 'brought' and achieved is simply dismissed as insignificant. But our common values of peace, freedom, democracy, and the rule of law are worth continuing to fight for – just as words and weapons have been fighting for for centuries. Over the last 60 years, we have managed to set up a unique peace and solidarity project in an unprecedented effort. I hope that we will continue to manage to turn great difficulties into small and small ones into very small ones!

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – The European Union is in a severe crisis. Crisis in every aspect: economic, political, social and, in particular, identity crisis. Today, the European Union must make a choice about continuing the policy of federalisation or will Europe turn to the original idea of a union of strong nations.  Since the REFERENDUM in Britain, it has been clear that the policy of stripping national sovereignty, seizing competence from national states is not in the interests of citizens and they do not want this to continue. Confirmation of this is the growing popularity of parties that are anti-federalists.  The European Union has distanced itself from its citizens. For this reason, it needs a new direction. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said more Europe and more union needed. I believe and believe that more Europe means stronger national states that aim for prosperity and a better life for their peoples.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The world is getting bigger and the European Union is getting smaller, demographically and economically," Jean Claude Juncker said today in his State of the Union address. What's the recipe for this? More Europe in Europe. The EC, the executive body, would become a political body, a quasi-government. Federica Mogherini – European Minister of Foreign Affairs, also taking over the powers of the Defence Ministers of the Member States. The EU's main defence objective would be to create a common headquarters parallel to NATO's command structures, and countries such as Poland and Romania, instead of strengthening their armies, would consider how to transfer equipment and personnel to a single European pool.  The litmus test of elite intentions is the diagnosis of external threats. More than 60 soldiers have been killed in Ukraine in the last 10 weeks. Juncker's speech did not even say a single word about the ongoing Russian aggression. The ideas of deepening cfsp integration are simply a tool for implementing a political plan, a plan of domination, the creation of a federalist body imitating its structure as a nation state. Affirmative words addressed to the Polish people are accompanied by unacceptable pressure on Polish government. It is difficult not to mention the incorrect assumptions of the EU's demographic policy.  Juncker's speech indicates that Brexit has not caused reflection in the european Union's mainstream elites. Instead of reforming Europe, we have a deepening of negative trends. This is the road to the collapse of the Union.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, in his State of the Union address in Strasbourg today (14.09.2016), stressed that Brexit is not a threat to the EU. But the consequences of the UK leaving the EU cannot be predicted. New rules for EU-UK cooperation will have to be set, so the EU institutions are looking forward to a letter confirming the Decision of the British people to leave the Community.  Almost three months have passed since the referendum and there is no official response from the British government. What will the EU budget look like in the future, by which time the British will pay a contribution? There are many questions. Only those countries that respect all EU freedoms can have access to the single market, and the UK has the greatest reservations about this. Member States do not cooperate enough and too often national interests are placed above the good of the whole Union, which is the guarantor of peace, which many citizens seem to have forgotten.  President Juncker also praised the NEW EC proposal on copyright reform published today. In this context, I am afraid that, instead of modernising the 15-year legal framework, the Commission has proposed to protect the analogue industry from digital innovation. Not only will this be tragic for these industries in the long term, but it will become a disaster for freedom of expression on the internet and will block the ability of European start-ups to innovate.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today's debate was needed more than ever. Europe is in a deep crisis of image and this is making extremism grow. Citizens of the various European countries look at Europe through the prism of their lives. I thank Giani Pittella for reminding her speech of the need for Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia to be in Schengen. This is why measures are needed to increase social cohesion, safety and quality of life. Mr Juncker, the Commission is often seen as the 'guilty man' by citizens who cannot give their children to school, by young people who do not have a job, by pensioners who cannot live on small pensions, by SMEs who are crushed by multinationals. The misunderstanding of the Commission's role also comes from poor communication. You are right, Europe needs to be better explained! As parliamentarians, we want to support the Commission. Help us support you! Be more transparent! Take Parliament's resolutions into account and focus on social cohesion investments. The EFSI has not achieved its aim and therefore you need to change the spending rules, also taking into account underdeveloped regions with little administrative capacity to write projects. Let's stick together through projects for people. That's the only way we're going to be a power in the world.

text: in writing. – Loss of European values, growing national selfishness, unclear course and unresolved continuing crises: that could be the summary of today's Europe.
