name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - Looking at the current situation in the EU, a clear conclusion is imposed that we need deep EU reform and closer cooperation between Member States. On the occasion of the open debate following European Commission leader Juncker's State of the Union report, I wonder if Brexit could be a prelude to the break-up of the EU? When I listen and watch the statements of some Euro-MEP members, it seems as if all this was already seen twenty-five years ago when Yugoslavia was falling apart.  In order to avoid such a scenario, the union reform should be urgently approached to lead to its better connectivity and closer cooperation between member states. If this does not happen, the disintegration of the EU is more likely than the success of the European project. Personally, I don't want that kind of breakup scenario. Quite the opposite! I want the strengthening of common European defence systems to be discussed as recently as a few days ago.  I want, as at the recent meeting of the Visegrad Group, to discuss better interconnection and cooperation between member states. There is a need to discuss a new Confederate or federal model for the functioning of the EU. That's how I see the future of the Union. In this sense, it is necessary to decisively change the way the European Parliament works and politically function, as well as other common institutions, if we want the European project to succeed.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is a good sign that President Juncker’s speech brought the EU out of Brexit depression. The EU clearly has capacity and resolve to continue, and even strengthen itself. Expanding the Strategic Investments Fund is to be supported. Especially relevant is the understanding that the EU cannot remain a soft power in international politics. The EU is deplorably absent in Syrian peace efforts and therefore needs its own strategy for solving Middle Eastern conflicts. We need to concentrate on healing the roots of both the Middle Eastern conflicts as well as migration from Africa. Restoring support and trust of EU citizens means concentrating on basics – that is completing the single market in deeds, not in declarations, bringing to a conclusion international free trade agreements and starting to treat Member States’ meeting of their commitments without making any exceptions.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The future of the European Union is decided by young people, their level of education, their preparation for life in an intercultural society and the possibility of access to the labour market. Supporting these objectives requires appropriate policies and guidelines, which we must ensure effective implementation and adequate financial security. I therefore ask the Commission to consider changes to the Stability and Growth Pact as regards the exclusion of expenditure on education, research and innovation from the calculation of the allowable deficit level. This practice is already being applied in relation to expenditure resulting from unexpected events and should be extended to include the above-mention expenditure in order to encourage Member States to invest in young people and build a knowledge-based economy.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: writing – In recent years, Europe has faced a large number of crises. From the financial and economic crisis, which have had negative impacts on growth and employment, to the threat to the euro, to the migration crisis and the threat of terrorism. Difficult times, in which people have existential problems and fear for their future, bring about the rise of populism and extremism. Populists are telling people that 'the EU wants to replace nation states', that 'Brussels cannot solve things', that they are the only ones with solutions. Try asking them: What solutions? They can't offer anything concrete. In the European Union, despite a difficult period, 8 million new jobs have been created. More than 9 million young people have participated in the Youth Initiative programme in the last 3 years. In Slovakia, this project was very successful. More than 80% of young people who participated in the project still retained their jobs after the end of the programme. It is therefore necessary to continue with this programme. The people of the EU must feel that the Union can protect them not only against terrorism, but also in the area of employment and social security. What path do we have to take in the EU? Let us do together things that, as the EU, we can do more cheaply and efficiently, or which individual countries cannot manage on their own.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. "Everyone is as big as they feel," says the saying. Let us be clear, then, that Europe is the world's largest economy and the world's most powerful economic and political power. Let's behave like this. The EU economy is growing faster this year than the United States. In almost all Member States, public debt and budget deficits have been caught on a short leash. Today, President Juncker announced that a new investment programme will be launched, at the end of which we expect more than 5 million Jobs in Europe. Talking about Europe's strong decline is a political hysteria. True, there are challenges, from the Russian security threat to the British exit. As the Commission is calling for, we need a common EU army. It's not like we only rely on the United States when it comes to our security. There cannot be a scenario where Europeans do not feel safe in their own country.  We also need to start brutal economic development that allows all Europeans to live well, better than their parents. Thirdly, a swift solution to the refugee crisis cannot be awaiting. EU visas, border guards and a common refugee policy are the solution, not separate solutions from Member States. But let us remember that Europe is not small and not powerless. Europe still gives more than a fifth of the world's economic output, despite being only 7% of the world's population. Let us behave accordingly when we talk about the EU situation.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – What is happening in europe's neighbourhood will inevitably have an impact on the INTERNAL SECURITY of the EU, so both must be dealt with very seriously. The problem of foreign fighters, terrorist financing and radicalisation must be addressed. The EU's borders must be controlled, as the EU must be able to monitor the crossing of its borders, register all entrants and also share this information among themselves. Strengthening Europol is extremely important. Eu defence policy needs to move forward – a clear plan is needed. It is necessary to strengthen cooperation between EU Member States on EU defence policy, including permanent structured defence cooperation, increase cooperation between the EU and NATO, simplify and make arms policy and the market more transparent. It is extremely important that EU Member States also have an obligation to allocate 2% of GDP to defence spending.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. - Many things still need to be improved, but recent developments have shown that defence and security are one of the weakest links in the common European policy structure. Border protection and data sharing are key to detecting terrorists, which is why Juncker's advocacy of linking national defences and intelligence sharing, as well as strengthening the EU's capacity to fight terrorism and other dangers, was indeed expected today and gained additional momentum.  I support the specific figures, primarily the increase of "his" investment fund by an additional 200 billion euros. I think this is a step in the right direction, but I always stress that the criteria for allocating funds from this fund must not only be the preparedness of projects, but also the general financial situation in the country and the threat of an economic crisis. We must not allow most of the funds to end up in the most developed member states.  Juncker also highlighted how ready the European Commission is to set aside for example for the Youth Guarantee and also announced an ambitious investment plan for Africa, as problems affecting the EU arise largely elsewhere, because they are not solved there. If we have 70 years of peace in the European Union, then this is something that certainly benefits not only individuals but also economies and the future to come.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I would like to thank President Juncker for the concrete messages especially when it comes to security and border control. I am pleased by the commitment of the Commission to send at least 200 extra Frontex border guards and 50 vehicles to help with the protection of the Bulgarian-Turkish border as of October, which is also the EU’s external border. The Bulgarian authorities have put daily efforts ‎into protecting the southern border of the country and coping alone with the increased migrant flow pressure in the last two years. But shared interests in the EU mean shared responsibilities. As long as it is in everyone’s interest to know who is crossing our borders and to make sure this only happens legally, Bulgaria’s efforts must be supported. ‎This support must have concrete practical dimensions. The Bulgarian Government will present to the Commission a list of specific demands for equipment, vehicles and personnel. I would like to call for a swift approval of the necessity because it has become clear that without joint efforts by all EU states, a lasting solution cannot be found.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. – On 24 June, with the referendum in the UK, the European Union entered a crucial stage for the future.  I want to be clear: I do not want to dismantle Europe and isolate our countries into a grotesque nationalism. On the contrary, I want to save what can still be saved in a Europe of solidarity and cooperation nations in all areas.  I expected that, during this time, there would be an avalanche of proposals to reform the Union and debate them. Apart from the proposal put forward by President Schulz, which I welcome, I have only seen closed-door meetings between various Heads of State, following which only evasive statements have been made public. Unfortunately, political leaders lose sight of the fact that Brexit and, in general, Euroscepticism were generated precisely by the fracture between the political system and citizens. The state of the Union is worse now than June 23rd! Precisely because nothing was done! To continue to ignore people's grievances is not a solution to bring Europe out of the crisis! In order to continue to exist, the European Union needs deep structural reform!

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – An analysis of the state of the EU today needs a long—range critical review of events over the last twenty years or so. The current angst cannot be blamed uniquely on the 2008 crisis from which the EU still has not freed itself. Its roots go back to the after—effects of policies adopted in the 1990s under the call for enlargement and deepening of the Union. That vision was unfortunately also driven by huge soft power that was frequently misunderstood and misused. Consequently, and not just because of the 2008 crisis, the European Union is now seriously unbalanced – politically, economically, territorially and socially. Unsurprisingly, the Council has become the real powerhouse of the Union, even if there stalemate is frequently the order of the day. The way forward is not through further projects for institutional change, conducted by ‘stealth’ or by ‘convention’, which are then used to justify wider changes. The way forward is through consolidation of existing structures and policies, guided politically and not market—based, also premised on the need to promote real social justice within the Union. In the current situation, consolidation – though vital – would still be a tough and complex project.

name: Algirdas Saudargas (PPE)
text: Writing. – Ahead of the annual speech by The Head of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, we will speculate on whether we will hear proposals to address the problems that are plaguing Europe, or perhaps the speech will be just a talk of 'everyday matters'. The end result is somewhere in the middle. I believe that too much attention has been paid to current EU affairs: tax policy, the development of the telecommunications market, talk of the importance of reducing investment or unemployment. Of course, the President of the EC has sought to outline his work, but it is worth looking at the future on the other side. Would the state not lose all other jobs if it lost one fifth of its economy? Perhaps the comparison is also made through the images, but that is the state we are talking about after Brexit. This is not only an economic challenge, but also a political challenge: after all, the UK wants to turn more states or a significant number of their citizens. It seems that Mr. Juncker sought a balance between national states and supranational institutions in his message: he said that the eu's goal of unification was not the United States, stressed the importance of voluntary solidarity in the refugee crisis, but at the same time spoke of the need for greater integration in areas that have survived mainly national competences. How surprised it was to call for the Commission not to criticise the work of the Commission and not to look for its role in the challenges. I believe that it is precisely the question-raising and answering, and not the fear of responsibility, that can help solve Europe's problems.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – Juncker's speech did not bring up revolutionary ideas. It was conducted in a relatively conciliatory spirit and was much less mentoring towards the sensitive subject of the refugee crisis than in the past. The other points were quite predictable and ranged within the existing topics discussed. It is a question of what is actually feasible in the foreseeable future. In this category I am considering the creation of a European army, a European Foreign Minister or a significant strengthening of the European budget. The question is also what will be part of the EU's social pillar and what the real results of the fight against tax evasion will be.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Europe is not built with propaganda and demagoguery, nor with repression. Europe is building itself by putting an end to adjustment policies and cuts, not threatening to withdraw funds, making debt payable by those responsible for it (banks and large companies) and ending the dictatorship of the euro.  While selling the protection of the European lifestyle, the Spanish minister announced a decree with cuts to obey Europe, knowing that these cuts will bring more destruction of employment. There was talk of youth, although in Galicia more than 100,000 young people were forced to emigrate, and those who find work in the country are mostly poor workers.  Cuts increase precariouss and poverty. If VAT rises on products that have reduced rates, this will condemn thousands of people to hunger. Youth deserves better: decent work, quality and free public services; deserves not to have to drop out of school because families cannot afford it.  Milk doesn't need alms, it needs regulation. There was no talk of the fishing sector, but it needs a fair distribution of the right to fish and fair prices. I agree that we need a better Europe, but for that we must overthrow this European Union.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: writing – I appreciate the speech by The President of the Commission p. Juncker because he clearly and clearly named the CURRENT PROBLEMS of the EU. He recalled that we must not forget the fundamental principles of the functioning of the EU – solidarity, the single market and the freedom of movement of citizens, goods and services. Today, when populists and Eurosceptics criticise the EU's problems, they exploit people's fears, they do not tell people what the EU has done for the people since its inception. Being European means opposing the death penalty, being in favour of protecting personal data and privacy, being in favour of equal pay conditions and social standards. Being European means fighting for the steel industry, which, from my point of view as a resident of Košice, is a very important agenda. Europe cannot be a continent of unemployed young people. That is why the EU supports the Youth Guarantee programme, through which more than 9 million young people have found work, traineeships or trained. The President of the Commission also commented on Brexit, saying that we regret the decision of the British people, but we respect and believe that this does not jeopardise the integrity of the Union. We want to re-establish relations with Britain so that – if they want to have access to the single market – they also accept the freedom of movement of EU citizens. Finally, he recalled the collective responsibility of all those who should explain more and better the functioning of the Union.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing – On the one hand, we are facing major projects such as investments in innovation, small and medium-sized enterprises and important trade agreements, on the other hand, the need for greater cooperation between the secret services and armies to maintain our security. We can only meet these challenges in Europe-wide unity and consensus.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. Mr. Yuger has admitted that the crisis is deepening. And he's right. But he forgot to say that the reason for this is because he continues to support the same neoliberal policies and insists on the hard measures of the Stability Pact. There has been an assumption that unemployment rates, particularly among young people, are particularly high. How young people are doomed to live in greater poverty than their parents. How social dumping is a serious problem in Europe. But how will the real economy be boosted when, instead of promoting investment to create new quality jobs, the Commission proposes to finance the further staticisation of the EU by setting up a permanent high-level headquarters and a European Defence Fund? Solidarity cannot exist with the measures you are proposing to strengthen borders and fortress Europe, but with a refugee policy based on humanism. The only solution to an exit from the crisis is a policy towards a Europe of solidarity, peace, democracy and social justice.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – As a left-wing socialist politician, it is clear to me that the key to solving the problems that are currently straining the Union is to return to the fundamental value of integration and, at the same time, to solidarity. Today, this represents concretely decisive political, institutional and financial steps for the success of the long-running project 'Social Europe', as the President of the Commission referred to in his speech, calling for the building of the 'social pillar' of the EU. Swift and effective action in this area can also serve to regain the trust and support of the European citizen. In the context of this endeavour, I believe that the most urgent task of the UNION today, while promising the most close-to-the-citizens, is to provide all our fellow Europeans with quality, nutritious food on a regular basis in all Member States, including those belonging to the most disadvantaged groups in society.  Humanly, morally and politically, millions of people, including children, are starving en masse on a daily basis on the world's richest continent, which produces long-term surplus food. Aware that the European Union already has essentially all the means at its disposal to end this shameful situation, I expect the European Commission to draw up and present to the leaders of the Member States as soon as possible its proposals for a specific legal, institutional, financial and tax framework for a common European solution. Europe is able and therefore obliged to provide food for all its citizens! (Europe can, and must feed all Europeans!)

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. In front of the European Parliament, President Juncker proposes beautiful tools to improve society. But just yesterday, the European Commission supported TTIP and CETA at all costs, torpedoed free roaming, slowed down the implementation of a real fight against social dumping or the creation of legislation on tax evasion. This schizophrenia destabilizes institutions and creates mistrust of the citizen. Let us hope that this time Juncker will keep his word and that the Commission will make the public interest his top priority.  Europe must be the solution against deregulation and not its accomplice, Europe must establish security and not create instability, Brexit must be an opportunity as long as the institutions question themselves and simplify its rules of operation. Europe sometimes perceived as the problem has everything to be the solution.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: Writing. – In his regular annual address to the European Parliament on the state of the EU, European Commission President Juncker sought to overcome the plight in which the community has found itself after a number of crises and challenges in recent months in a way that focused on a few chosen tasks.  The common denominator of his speech was a call for more solidarity, unity, social justice, responsibility for his own security and concern for the future of the young generation. I am not sure that he has rightly avoided the crisis in relations with Russia, the disunity in the assessments of the EU's strategy of relations with Turkey and the situation in Syria and the Middle East as a whole.  I support his idea of the need for a strong EU foreign minister to sit at the negotiating table when it comes to the hottest international negotiations. I also think that sufficient attention should be paid to the idea of closer EU integration in defence and security.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. – Thank you to The President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, for the State of the Union address! Many things are tearing Europe apart right now, even though, at the same time, European countries need each other more than they have in a long time.  However, the EU cannot act if its members sit in the stands. That is why every Member State and the state leadership must also take responsibility for the development of Europe. There is not much need for new openings, but a focus must be on implementing and promoting decisions that have already been taken. In particular, the European economy and growth must be strengthened and common security must be strengthened. The themes highlighted in the speech, such as digitalisation, international trade and accelerating investment, are important for work and growth.  Faith in the European Union's ability to respond to challenges will be eroded if the EU does not even try to comply with the rules and principles that have been decided together. Over the years, a culture of action seems to have developed, in which agreements concluded together have been stretched according to current needs. Even now, several Member States are struggling with their finances, but the Commission has overlooked the stretching of deficit rules. Member States have also been prepared to be flexible, even though the debts and government deficits of other Members of the Union have increased beyond the agreed limits. However, slipping out of the rules always backfires sooner or later.  It is time for the EU to return to its roots and do less, but better. Member States must be activated to work together again and to assume their responsibility for the fact that the decisions taken together are also implemented. It will benefit both the European Union and the Member States themselves. The EU will continue to be needed in the future.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – In the state of the EU speech, we have not heard a single sentence this time about a subject that directly reaches 40 million EU citizens. The claim that "Europe cannot become a crucible" that kills identities has pleased me. And yet Jean-Claude Juncker made no reference to national and linguistic minorities in Europe.  I agree that the Treaty of Lisbon needs to be amended in order to have an EU foreign minister, but we also need a European Commissioner with the issue of national and linguistic minorities in their portfolio. We need the political will of the Commission to achieve a legislative framework for harmonising the rights of ethnic minorities. "We need to listen to the citizens and we need to do this more intensively," Juncker said. However, the ICE proposed by the UDMR under the umbrella of FUEN – Minority Safe Pack – was rejected by the Commission. "History will not hold us back, but it will hold back our mistakes," he concluded his speech. True prefect. My conviction and 40 million other EU citizens is that the stubbornness with which the EU ignores the issue of European national and linguistic minorities is a mistake of historical significance.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I wrote to President Schulz on 4 February this year on a most important matter and I have not received the courtesy of an acknowledgment or a reply. I know from conversations with colleagues from across the political Groups that this is not an isolated case. Can I ask one of the ushers to take this letter and, in front of 751 witnesses, to see that it is delivered to President Schulz’s office?

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would just like to point out that the Nobel Peace Prize winner Shimon Peres suffered a stroke yesterday and is struggling between life and death. I think it is right that the European Parliament should send its thoughts in the hope that it will regain its strength and life.

name: Președintele. –
text: We all hope so.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, thank you very much to all the people and colleagues who have collaborated in this Resolution. It is time for this Parliament to take sides in favour of European social dialogue and for the European Union to lead the improvement of the working conditions of millions of fishing workers around the world, so that their right to decent work, social protection, living wages and fair rest times is recognized. States should not delay the adoption of ILO Conventions, without which economic globalization opens the door to an infinite erosion of workers' and workers' rights. I am sure that we will get a large majority today for fisheries workers, because without labour and social rights there is no democracy. I look forward to your favorable vote.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs once again for their excellent shared work on this report, which has had the ambition to strongly relaunch cooperation and partnership with what is perhaps our most important partner on the southern shore today and the one that is most consistent with our values and principles. But the greatest thanks must certainly go to the Tunisian people and to the extraordinary efforts that their civil society has made over the years. They have certainly deserved the Nobel Peace Prize, and it is our job to deserve the Nobel Prize for solidarity and foresight.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Just before the vote, an unacceptable incident occurred during the State of the Union debate. Russia's ambassador to the European Union, Mr Czyzov, was in the Chamber of The European Parliament, not in the gallery for diplomats. The European Parliament is not a Russian Dum, and Russian diplomats should not come here and talk to Members during our debate. This is unacceptable and I ask that there be no such situation in the future.

name: Guillaume Balas
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I want to talk about the vote on the report that has just taken place, and I am the rapporteur. I just wanted to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the long and arduous but excellent work we have done and say just one thing: through the voice of its Parliament, Europe says it wants social progress, so now Europe must do what it takes to achieve it.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I want to respond very briefly to what Mr Czarnecki said. We have set ourselves rules here: diplomats from other countries are allowed to participate in our deliberations, they are allowed to observe them – two diplomats per embassy. We are an open house. We have nothing to hide in our debates. I think it is right that the Russian ambassador should look at the lively debate here in the House. On Sunday are in Russia Duma elections. I think it would be nice if the Duma were to become as lively a house as this European Parliament.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, we are likely to reject the proposals for technical standards that the European Commission has submitted to us because it has not listened to this Parliament's requests. On the other hand, we want to reaffirm our commitment to the protection of retail investors and, therefore, to refuse to question the content of Level 2. That is the meaning of the oral amendment that I ask you to support.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, consider Switzerland – Helvetia – a prosperous, peaceful, successful country with a high level of democratic satisfaction, with the highest standard of living in the world, according to the UN, and with an amicable relationship with its neighbours in the EU. Switzerland is a partner and friend of the European Union, duplicating on a bilateral basis some of the obligations that we have to undertake as EU Member States but retaining the right to make its own laws. That seems to me a useful model for countries that are in this part of the world but outside the jurisdiction of EU institutions. There is nothing that precludes us working together as sovereign countries. Obviously, Britain is not going to copy completely what Switzerland does. We are going to be much more engaged, for example, as a member of NATO, in the defence of Europe. However, the idea of being part of the common market but outside a political union, supporting our friends and allies as they pursue closer integration but standing aside from it – surely that is a useful model that can be profitably extended not just to Britain but also to other European countries.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU-Switzerland relations are very important for both sides, especially from an economic and political point of view. Since Croatia's accession to the EU, as a result of the enlargement of the internal market, the importance of the EU-Switzerland partnership has grown even more.  Also considering that around 1 million EU citizens live in Switzerland and a very large number of them cross the border daily for work reasons, I have decided to vote in favour to ensure the free movement of persons between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative consent procedure (single vote) report. The protocol would force Switzerland to gradually open its borders to Croatia over a 10-year period. The Swiss people voted to reject mass immigration in a referendum in 2014. So to respect the wishes of the Swiss people, UKIP voted against the EU’s forcing them to open their borders to Croatia.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report tried to remedy an issue that has been ongoing since the Swiss ‘Against Mass Immigration’ referendum in 2014 and the introduction of a new Article 121a into the Constitution, which states that Switzerland regulates immigration, that residence permit restrictions and quotas may be introduced on the basis of Switzerland’s overall economic interests, and that businesses are obliged to give Swiss nationals priority when hiring staff. According to the EU, Article 121a is not compatible with the agreement on the free movement of persons. This means that a solution needs to be found. The protocol agreed provides for a seven-year transition period in which Switzerland and Croatia can maintain limits on the emigration of their citizens to each other’s countries. The quotas are progressive in that Switzerland may gradually open its borders year by year to Croatian workers. I voted in favour of the report from a technical point of view in order to ensure that Croatia will be included in the bilateral agreement between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. It is clear that Croatia and Switzerland, politically, economically and culturally, will benefit from the signing of this Protocol III. Free movement is a crucial element that cannot be separated from participation in the internal market.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the protocol amending the EU-Switzerland agreement on the free movement of persons. Following the rejection of accession to the EEA Agreement in 1992, the EU and Switzerland signed a number of bilateral agreements. The agreement on the free movement of persons gave citizens of the contracting parties the right to enter, live and work in each other’s territories by reciprocally abolishing  most of the restrictions. This agreement is the only one that did not automatically extend to new EU members, and a protocol thus needs to be signed whenever new countries become part of the EU. Protocol III was initiated after the accession of Croatia in July 2013. The Swiss referendum of 9 February 2014 “Against mass immigration” sparked a reaction by the EU, with the suspension of bilateral negotiations on several subjects. On 4 March 2016 Protocol III was signed. Under the Protocol, for a period of seven years from its entry into force, Switzerland may limit the access of Croatian citizens to the labour market. During the last two years of this transition period, the restrictions must be accepted by the Switzerland-EU Joint Committee. I fully  welcome this decision of the European Parliament.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this protocol. In principle, we are opposed to the notion of free movement, which is the main cause of social dumping, which encourages forced mobility and erases the notion of belonging to a country. We are all the more opposed to this agreement since Switzerland voted in February 2014 to introduce immigration quotas in order to control the entry of foreigners into its territory. The European Union has obviously been quick to judge and condemn this referendum, working by all means in its possession to have this vote annulled/invalidated. This agreement is just one more interference in Swiss affairs, we can only oppose it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Swiss people recently voted in a referendum to end the ‘free movement of persons’ (a standard euphemism for unlimited immigration). Consequently, as a sovereign democratic nation state, their will should be respected. Unlimited immigration is not a requirement of trade, or indeed of free and fair trade. It is a political principle of the European Union, which it seeks to impose upon third countries. I do not believe in that principle, and therefore I cannot support the Protocol which extends this provision to Croatia. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation because Switzerland enjoys, to the same extent as the Member States of the Union, the internal market and its enlargements. There is no doubt that Croatia and Switzerland stand to gain from the signing of the current Protocol III, politically, economically and culturally, by taking advantage of a wider internal market where free movement is an essential element.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the recommendation on the protocol to the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons.  When Croatia joined the EU in 2013, Protocol 1 on the free movement of persons was launched. However, following the anti-immigration referendum in Switzerland in 2014, the protocol was suspended. However, in 2016, the EU and Switzerland signed Protocol 3 under which the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons also applies to Croatia. I support Protocol 3 because I believe that it will benefit both sides with economic, political and cultural benefits.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative consent procedure (single vote) report. The protocol would force Switzerland to gradually open its borders to Croatia over a 10-year period. The Swiss people voted to reject mass immigration in a referendum in 2014. So to respect the wishes of the Swiss people, UKIP voted against the EU’s forcing them to open their borders to Croatia.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. We are fundamentally opposed to this "free movement" constantly promoted by The Euroglobalists: not to mention the migration problems, it is this dogma that is the main cause of social dumping, encouraging forced "mobility" and erasing the very notion of belonging to a country. We are all the more opposed to this agreement since Switzerland voted in February 2014 to introduce immigration quotas in order to control the entry of foreigners into its territory. The European Union has, of course, been quick to judge and condemn this referendum, working by all means in its possession to have this vote annulled or invalidated. This agreement is just one more interference in Swiss affairs, I can only oppose it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which approves the protocol between the European Community and Switzerland on the free movement of persons concerning Croatia's participation following its accession to the Union. The protocol provides that, for a period of 7 years, Switzerland will be able to limit the entry of Croatian nationals into its labour market.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is Switzerland's main trading partner, which is switzerland's fourth largest economic partner. The close relations that exist have developed systematically since the Confederation refused to join the European Economic Area in 1992, a factor which led the two parties to conclude a series of bilateral agreements on specific issues. The agreement on the free movement of persons, signed within the framework of the first group of bilateral agreements, gave citizens of both parties the right to enter, live and work in their territories, abolishing most of the restrictions.  In order to benefit from these rights, however, you must have an employment or service contract or have sufficient financial means and adequate insurance. The Jazłowiecka report, which I supported today with my vote, approves the conclusion of a protocol amending the original agreement and allowing Croatia to accede to it. This is a technical measure that will allow the Balkan country, which joined the EU in July 2013, to make full use of the possibilities offered by its entry into the EU area.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the extension to Croatia of the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the free movement of persons. An agreement that was blocked by the Swiss popular initiative "Against Mass Immigration" approved in a referendum in 2014, incompatible with it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. The signing of this Agreement is a logical consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU. I agree with the rapporteur that both Croatia and the Helvetic Confederation will benefit from the signing of this third protocol in the political, economic, social and cultural spheres thanks to an internal market in which free movement is a fundamental element.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report relates to the protocol to the EC-Switzerland agreement on the free movement of persons, aimed at taking account of Croatia's accession to the EU. The agreement on the free movement of persons, signed in 2000 under Bilateral Agreement I and entered into force on 1 June 2002, was signed between Switzerland and the EU-15. This is the only agreement not to have been made automatically applicable to the new Member States, which is why it must be extended after each new accession. The protocol is being re-examined following Croatia's accession to the EU. I remain opposed to the principle of full free movement and, moreover, following the Swiss vote against immigration quotas in 2014, the EU hastened to condemn it. I am therefore afraid that this agreement is still an interference in Swiss affairs, out of fact prudence, I voted against the protocol.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 9 February 2014, Switzerland approved by referendum the popular initiative "Against mass immigration", which states that Switzerland can manage immigration independently. Following the Swiss referendum, the EU reacted by suspending negotiations with Switzerland on many agreements and threatening to cut its huge funds as a participant in European research programmes. The EU demonstrates, once again, that it is a deeply undemocratic construction, which in no way respects the will of the people, even if it is officially expressed through a regular popular referendum. For these reasons, I do not intend to support this text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution granting the European Parliament its approval for the conclusion of the Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other hand, on the free movement of persons, concerning the participation of the Republic of Croatia as a result of its accession to the European Union.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it endorsed the conclusion of the Protocol to the AGREEMENT between the EU and the Swiss Confederation on the Free Movement of Persons on the Status of a Contracting Party for the Republic of Croatia which acceded to the EU. Due to its geographical and cultural proximity, and in particular the political and economic importance, the EU and its 28 Member States are Switzerland's most important partners. With a wide range of agreements, the EU has closer ties with Switzerland than with any other country outside the European Economic Area (EEA). Switzerland is the EU's fourth largest trading partner (after the United States, China and Russia) and the EU is Switzerland's largest trading partner. More than one million EU citizens live in Switzerland and another 230 000 cross the border every day to work. Some 430 000 Swiss citizens live in the EU. Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia have further expanded the single market (now almost 505 million people) to join the EU, making it an even more important partner for Switzerland.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given its geographical and cultural proximity, in particular its political and economic importance, the Union is Switzerland's most important economic partner. Accordingly, the Union has developed closer relations with Switzerland through a number of agreements than with any country other than the European Economic Area (EEA). Switzerland is the EU's 4th largest trading partner after the United States, China and Russia, and the EU is Switzerland's most important trading partner. Following the rejection of Switzerland's accession to the EEA Agreement in 1992 and mutual awareness of the crucial role of cooperation, a series of bilateral agreements (e.g. the so-called Bilateral I Package) were concluded. These concerned, inter alia, the free movement of persons, land and air transport, agriculture, research and technical barriers to trade and public procurement and entered into force on 1 June 2002. As Switzerland, like the EU Member States, has access to and benefits from the internal market and its enlargement, benefiting politically, economically and culturally from a wider internal market where free movement, including that of Hungarian citizens, is a key element, the restriction of which by Switzerland is unacceptable. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation in line with the rapporteur's opinion, which is also of relevance to Brexit.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this agreement, which will be of political, economic and cultural benefit for both Croatia and Switzerland. Freedom of movement is a key element, and Protocol III includes a transitional period of 7 years in which Switzerland can restrict access by Croatian citizens to its labour market (quotas, priority of local workers, control of working conditions and wages). During the last two years of this transition period, all restrictions must be accepted by the Joint Committee of Switzerland and the EU.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This protocol sets, among other things, the rules for the movement of people between the European Union and Switzerland following Croatia's accession to the Union. I am fundamentally opposed to the free movement of people whom I consider to be one of the main causes of social dumping. On the other hand, I remember the attitude of the Union's leaders towards Switzerland in its referendum on immigration, a particularly outrageous attitude leading to unacceptable interference in Switzerland's internal affairs. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is right that the Republic of Croatia, now that it is fully part of the European Union, should also participate in the trade agreements that the EU signs with foreign states. We consider this to be a due act.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession, the European Union must update its agreement with Switzerland on the free movement of people. As a reminder, under this agreement signed in June 2002, nationals of both parties can enter, stay, settle and study in the other party's space as easily as a national resident.  This new protocol gives Switzerland, for a period of seven years, the possibility of limiting the access of Croatian nationals to its labour market. A safeguard clause even provides that, at the end of this period, Switzerland can, again for three years, unilaterally limit the number of residence permits allowing Croats to come to work there.  Opposed to the free movement of individuals which is the main cause of social dumping, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to its geographical and cultural proximity and, in particular, its political and economic importance, the EU and the 28 Member States are Switzerland's most important partner. The EU has closer links with Switzerland than with any other state outside the European Economic Area (EEA) through a wide range of agreements. While Switzerland is the EU's fourth largest trading partner, after the United States, China and Russia, the EU is Switzerland's largest trading partner. More than one million EU citizens live in Switzerland, and another 230,000 cross the border every day to go to work. Around 430,000 Swiss citizens live in the EU. With the accession of Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia to the EU, the internal market expanded further, reaching almost 505 million citizens and becoming even more important to our Swiss partner. In view of the extremely important bilateral relations between the EU and Switzerland, I considered this Protocol important, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Protocol on the Free Movement of Persons was signed in 2000 by Switzerland and the European Union of the 15 Member States, and will enter into force in 2002. After each episode of enlargement of the Union in 2004 (accession to the EU of the 10 new Member States), respectively in 2007 (accession of Romania and Bulgaria), the EU-Switzerland agreement was amended, coming into force as Protocol II. With Croatia's entry into the European Union in 2013, Protocol III between the EU and Switzerland was initiated, extending the Agreement on the free movement of persons to Croatia. I voted in favour of this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament, as I agree with the text adopted by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because I believe that Switzerland, in addition to its geographical and cultural proximity, is a partner of fundamental economic and political importance to the EU.  In fact, thanks to the large number of agreements concluded with Switzerland, the EU has closer links with the country in question than with any other country outside the European Economic Area (EEA). Switzerland is Europe's fourth largest economic partner, after the United States, China and Russia. More than 1 million European citizens live in Switzerland and more than 230,000 Europeans cross the border daily for work purposes. The number of Swiss citizens residing on European soil, on the other hand, amounts to about 430,000.  With the accession of Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia to the EU, the internal market has expanded. Switzerland, like the EU Member States, benefits greatly from the enlargement of the European internal market. Both Croatia and Switzerland will therefore, with the signing of the current Protocol III, be the beneficiaries of a wider internal market in which freedom of movement plays a top role.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report tried to remedy an issue that has been ongoing since the Swiss ‘Against Mass Immigration’ referendum in 2014 and the introduction of a new Article 121a into the Constitution, which states that Switzerland regulates immigration, that residence permit restrictions and quotas may be introduced on the basis of Switzerland’s overall economic interests, and that businesses are obliged to give Swiss nationals priority when hiring staff. According to the EU, Article 121a is not compatible with the agreement on the free movement of persons. This means that a solution needs to be found. The protocol agreed provides for a seven-year transition period in which Switzerland and Croatia can maintain limits on the emigration of their citizens to each other’s countries. The quotas are progressive in that Switzerland may gradually open its borders year by year to Croatian workers. I voted in favour of the report from a technical point of view in order to ensure that Croatia will be included in the bilateral agreement between the EU and Switzerland.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative consent procedure (single vote) report. The protocol would force Switzerland to gradually open its borders to Croatia over a 10-year period. The Swiss people voted to reject mass immigration in a referendum in 2014. So to respect the wishes of the Swiss people, UKIP voted against the EU’s forcing them to open their borders to Croatia.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree to give my consent to the present agreement between the EU and Switzerland on the free movement of persons, in order to take into account the latest accession, that of Croatia, to the EU. Since its signature in 2000, the agreement has been extended twice to take into consideration the enlargements of 2004 and 2007.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote, Parliament is giving the green light to Croatia's integration into the Protocol on the Agreement between the EU and Switzerland on the free movement of persons. This is a necessary act of practice because of accession. I voted in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Because of its geographical and cultural proximity, the European Union, with its Member States, is Switzerland's most important partner; the Union has closer links with Switzerland than with any other country not belonging to the European Economic Area (EEA).  With the entry of Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia into the Union, the internal market has expanded further, reaching almost 505 million people and becoming even more important to our Swiss partner. Protocol III, initiated precisely by Croatia's accession to the Union, opens the door to Croatian citizens, as well as Swiss citizens, by extending the agreement on the free movement of persons to Croatia. I am convinced that both Croatia and Switzerland can only benefit politically and economically from this openness. Freedom of movement is the cornerstone of EU citizenship, and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the agreement.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that both Croatia and Switzerland will benefit from the signing of this Protocol III, since they will derive political, economic and cultural benefits from the enlarged internal market, for which freedom of movement is vital.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the recommendation on the Agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation on the free movement of persons on the participation of the Republic of Croatia after its accession to the European Union. This agreement is another step in Croatia's effort to integrate smoothly and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of extending the EU-Switzerland agreement on the free movement of persons to Croatia. Given recent developments, and given the uncertainty caused by the 'Against mass immigration' referendum passed in February 2014 by the Swiss Confederation, I hope that the success of Protocol III will help to create a renewed spirit of cooperation between the European Union and Switzerland.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote on the Protocol to the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the free movement of persons (accession of Croatia) and noted no objections.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. The protocol would force Switzerland to gradually open its borders to Croatia over a 10-year period. The Swiss people voted to reject mass immigration in a referendum in 2014. So to respect the wishes of the Swiss people, UKIP voted against the EU forcing them to open their borders to Croatia.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Protocol because it guarantees both the Swiss Confederation and Croatia a progressive adaptation to the agreement on the free movement of persons, through the introduction of limits on access to the labour market. Switzerland will be able to maintain the limits that still apply to employed and self-employed persons with residence permits of four months to one year and lasting one year or more, restrictions which may also be applied by Croatia. Restrictions on access are determined for each of the seven years of application of the Protocol, will be progressive, so as to gradually open up the labour market and will have the right, both countries, to maintain controls on working conditions and pay for nationals of the other Contracting Party.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – Switzerland is the EU’s 4th largest trading partner, right after the United States, China and Russia, with over one million EU citizens who live in Switzerland, and another 230 000 who cross the border daily to go to work. I agree with the scope of the report to build further on the 20 principal agreements and over 120 bilateral agreements since 2000 provided for in the acquis communautaire to facilitate movement and the provision of services in the territory of the contracting parties. I understand that quantitative limits should be set for each year of the Protocol’s seven-year implementation with quotas for each year.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a technical agreement to assimilate the situation in Croatia, the last Member State to join the Union, to the same status as the other States of the Union with regard to the movement of persons with Switzerland. Parliament should be consulted for the conclusion of such international agreements and this resolution gives consent to Croatia's accession. Because it is a technical improvement in equaling the rights of the citizens of Croatia with that of the rest of the citizens of the Union, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the United States, China and Russia, Switzerland is the EU's fourth largest trading partner and the EU is its largest economic partner. More than one million EU citizens live in Switzerland, and another 230,000 cross the border every day to go to work. Around 430,000 Swiss citizens live in the EU. The objective of that agreement was to establish between the Union and Switzerland rules equivalent to those laid down in the acquis communautaire, allowing entry, residence, work, establishment as a worker, education, introducing the right to social security and granting living, employment and working conditions identical to those guaranteed to their own nationals. I voted for a larger internal market, in which free movement is an essential element, but also for the economic and cultural benefits that can be brought.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given its geographical and cultural proximity, in particular its political and economic importance, the Union of 28 Member States is switzerland's most important partner. Accordingly, the Union has developed closer relations with Switzerland through a number of agreements than with any country other than the European Economic Area (EEA). Following the rejection of Switzerland's accession to the EEA Agreement in 1992 and mutual awareness of the crucial role of cooperation, a series of bilateral agreements were concluded. These concerned, inter alia, the free movement of persons, land and air transport, agriculture, research and technical barriers to trade and public procurement and entered into force on 1 June 2002. As Switzerland, like the EU Member States, has access to and benefits from the internal market and its enlargement, benefiting politically, economically and culturally from a wider internal market where free movement is a key element, the restriction of which by Switzerland is unacceptable. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation in line with the rapporteur's opinion.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I fully agree with the rapporteur's position. I believe that cooperation between The Member States (including Croatia) and Switzerland is benefiting both sides. The signing of the Protocol by Switzerland and Croatia will improve the free movement of persons. This aspect is a key point of this document, which is why I fully support it, as the issue of guaranteeing the free movement of persons is very important for citizens. I voted IN FAVOUR.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union and Switzerland benefit from a number of bilateral agreements on a number of issues, including free movement of persons, overland transport, air transport, agriculture and research, as well as technical barriers to trade and public procurement. Following the accession of Croatia to the European Union, these EU agreements had to be amended in order to take the 28th Member State into account. For this reason I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given, on the one hand, that Switzerland is the fourth largest trading partner of the European Union after the United States, China and Russia, and, on the other hand, that, after the accession of Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia to the EU, the internal market has expanded further, becoming even more important for the Swiss partner, I support the rapporteur's position to support this protocol to the agreement and to recommend its approval.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report presents the European Parliament's recommendation on the protocol to update the agreement between the European Union and Switzerland following Croatia's accession to the Union and deals with possible compensation to the EU's partner country as soon as it expands its market to a new member.  The rapporteur recommends supporting the Commission's proposal for this negotiation.  Considering that this technical report stems from Croatia's accession to the Union, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. The protocol would force Switzerland to gradually open its borders to Croatia over a 10-year period. The Swiss people voted to reject mass immigration in a referendum in 2014. So to respect the wishes of the Swiss people, UKIP voted against the EU forcing them to open their borders to Croatia.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text for the conclusion of a protocol to the agreement between the European Community and its Member States and Switzerland on the free movement of persons in order to take account of Croatia's accession. It seems to me that it is quite normal for the agreements with partner countries to take into account the accession of the new members of the European Union.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the agreement because I believe that the EU and Switzerland have stable political and economic relations and are linked by geographical and cultural proximity. In fact, more than a million EU citizens live in Switzerland and more than 230,000 cross the border daily to get to work. An important point in the agreement is the establishment between the Union and Switzerland of rules equivalent to those between Member States on access to employment and social security.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The agreement on the free movement of persons, signed in 2000 as part of the 'bilateral agreement I' between the EU and Switzerland, gave nationals of both parties rights equivalent to those provided for by the EU acquis. This agreement must be renewed with each new accession.  In principle, we are opposed to the notion of free movement. We are all the more opposed to this agreement since Switzerland voted in February 2014 to introduce immigration quotas in order to control the entry of foreigners into its territory. So I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In February 2014, in Switzerland, a majority voted for the state to be able to autonomously regulate immigration and residence permits, giving priority to Swiss citizens when hiring staff. This, to me, is the decision of a sovereign state. However, it appears to be contrary to the agreement that Switzerland has signed with the EU on the free movement of persons and needs to be reviewed.  This report voted on Croatia's accession to this agreement as part of the EU and the rejection of this report would not solve this problem, but only a legal vacuum. I therefore supported the report because Croatia would also benefit from free movement, but what are the procedures and substance of the agreement and whether it is valid or should not be considered at another level.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy of free movement of persons has failed and with tragic results, as demonstrated by the ease with which the various terrorists move from one end of Europe to the other.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given its geographical and cultural proximity, in particular its political and economic importance, the Union of 28 Member States is switzerland's most important partner. As Switzerland, like the EU Member States, has access to and benefits from the internal market and its enlargement, benefiting politically, economically and culturally from a wider internal market where free movement, including that of Hungarian citizens, is a key element, the restriction of which by Switzerland is unacceptable. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation in line with the rapporteur's opinion, which is also of relevance to Brexit.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. For its geographical and cultural proximity, and in particular because of its political and economic importance, the Union, with its 28 Member States, is Switzerland's most important partner. Some 430 000 Swiss citizens reside in the Union. With the accession of Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia to the Union, the internal market has expanded to almost 505 million people and become even more important to our Swiss partner. A number of bilateral agreements (the so-called Bilateral Agreements) were negotiated, after which the second package of agreements (Bilateral Agreements II) was negotiated and signed in June 2002 and signed in 2004. For all these reasons, it is appropriate to support this Protocol to the Agreement and recommend its approval.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Switzerland, like the EU Member States, benefits from the internal market and its enlargements, as highlighted in Switzerland's analysis of the consequences of the cessation of bilateral agreements. There is no doubt that both Croatia and Switzerland will benefit from the signing of this Protocol III, which will give them political, economic and cultural advantages, thanks to a wider internal market which has free movement as its fundamental element.  I voted for it.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: we are opposed to the notion of free movement, which is the main cause of social dumping, which encourages forced mobility and erases the notion of belonging to a country.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The negotiation of the initial agreement between the EU and Switzerland on the free movement of persons, signed in 2000, was supported by a number of reasons, including the fact that more than 100,000 Portuguese emigrants work in Switzerland, including many thousands of seasonal workers. The inclusion of Croatia in this agreement, which provides for a period of 7 years in which, mutually, one and another country (Switzerland and Croatia) can limit the movement of people and goods, is only the consequence of croatia's accession to the EU. This does not change the position of approval that this agreement deserved for us at the outset, under the same arguments for facilitating the fixation, based on issues relating to the rights of workers from other countries and their families. We voted for it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the first series of bilateral agreements between the EU and Switzerland entered into force in June 2002. They are part of an agreement on the free movement of persons. The new phase, called Protocol III, was launched by Croatia's accession to the European Union in 2013, which was initially blocked by Switzerland as a direct result of the Swiss referendum against mass immigration. The European Union has responded to this development by suspending negotiations with Switzerland on a number of other agreements. On 4 March 2016, Switzerland and the European Union finally signed Protocol III extending the agreement on the free movement of persons to Croatia. Protocol III contains seven years of transitional period during which Switzerland may restrict access to the labour market for Croatian citizens.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because the EU is once again demonstrating that it is undemocratic and does not respect the will of the citizens.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the Protocol to the EC-Switzerland Agreement on the free movement of persons (accession of Croatia), because the policy of free movement of persons has failed, and with tragic results, as demonstrated by the ease with which the various terrorists move from one end of Europe to the other.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is beyond doubt that both Croatia and Switzerland will benefit politically, culturally and economically from the signature of Protocol III. Free movement is a crucial element and can hence not be separated from internal market participation. I therefore voted in favour of the protocol.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the conclusion of a Protocol to the EC-Switzerland Agreement to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. Keep in mind that because of its geographical and cultural proximity, and in particular because of its political and economic importance, the EU is Switzerland's most important partner. Similarly, more than one million Union citizens live in Switzerland, another 230,000 cross the border every day to go to work and some 430,000 Swiss citizens reside in the Union.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Protocol to the EC-Switzerland Agreement on the free movement of persons on the occasion of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. It is an important technical update following Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Due to their geographical proximity and cultural ing, the Member States of the European Union are switzerland's most important political and economic partner. More than one million Community citizens live in Switzerland and another 230 000 cross its borders every day on their way to work, while around 430 000 Swiss citizens have chosen the Territory of the Union to live and work. The report on the Protocol to the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons refers this time to the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU in 2013. MEPs supported the signing of this protocol, which is part of the standard procedure applicable to any enlargement of the European Union. This act will be politically, economically and culturally beneficial for both Croatia, the European Union and Switzerland, which will benefit from greater access to the internal market, based on the free movement of persons.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to indicate Parliament’s support for this protocol, which would extend the free movement accord between the EEA and the Swiss Confederacy to Croatia. As this agreement is linked to the fundamental principle of free movement of persons, this agreement will pave the way for the re-entry of Switzerland’s participation in the Erasmus+ programme. This will allow students from the UK to enjoy the possibility of participating in an exchange with Swiss universities.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the extension to Croatia of the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the free movement of persons. An agreement that was blocked by the Swiss popular initiative "Against Mass Immigration" approved in a referendum in 2014, incompatible with it.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision concerning the signing of the Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other part, on the free movement of persons concerning the participation of the Republic of Croatia as a Contracting Party following its accession to the European Union. The European Union of 28 Member States is Switzerland's most important partner because of its geographical proximity and cultural proximity, in particular because of its political and economic importance.  Although Switzerland is the EU's fourth largest trading partner after the United States, China and Russia, the EU is Switzerland's largest partner. More than one million EU citizens live in Switzerland and another 230,000 cross the border every day on their way to work. Around 430,000 Swiss citizens live in the EU. With the accession of Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia, the internal market, which covers almost 505 million people, has been expanded and has therefore become even more important for our Swiss partner. In my opinion, Switzerland can only benefit from the enlargement of the EU's internal market, which is why the signing of this Protocol is politically, economically and culturally beneficial for both Croatia and Switzerland.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – We voted in favour of the Report since both Croatia and Switzerland will benefit from the signing of this Protocol III, as they will derive political, economic and cultural benefits from the enlarged internal market, for which freedom of movement is vital.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this protocol to the Agreement between the EU and Switzerland in relation to the free movement of people following the accession of Croatia. This agreement gives the citizens of both the EU and Switzerland the right to enter, live and work in the respective territories by mutually abolishing the majority of restrictions. However to do so an employment or service contract or sufficient financial resources are necessary.  This agreement does not automatically extend to new Member States once they join and so must be amended by a protocol. There is a transitional period of seven years, with the possibility of a further three years, from the time the protocol comes into force in which access for Croatian citizens can be limited but this period also applies to Swiss citizens entering Croatia. Both Croatia and Switzerland will benefit from access to a larger internal market to which free movement is integral.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this protocol as it ensures the full participation of Croatia within the European Union following its accession in 2013.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the report on a protocol to the agreement between the European Community and its Member States and Switzerland on the free movement of persons with a view to the accession of the Republic of Croatia after its accession to the EU. ALFA believes that referendums are an important means of democracy and that it follows that the results must also be respected. When a country's political and economic situation changes, its citizens must be able to adapt their laws to the new situation. If Switzerland decides that migration from the EU becomes too much, then contracts must be renegotiated. It is acceptable that this could result in a Europe of different speeds. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to discord and strife in Europe.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. The protocol would force Switzerland to gradually open its borders to Croatia over a 10-year period. The Swiss people voted to reject mass immigration in a referendum in 2014. So to respect the wishes of the Swiss people, UKIP voted against the EU forcing them to open their borders to Croatia.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on Protocol III extending the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other, on the free movement of persons in Croatia. This agreement was initiated with Croatia's accession in 2013 and includes a transitional period of 7 years, with a safeguard clause for Switzerland for a further three years. During this period, Switzerland may limit its citizens' access to the labour market and, during the last 2 years of this period, the restrictions will be accepted by a Switzerland-EU Joint Committee. The free movement of persons is the engine of the development of the European Community bloc at all levels.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a Recommendation on the Draft Council Decision on the Conclusion of the Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other, on the free movement of persons in connection with the participation of the Republic of Croatia as a Contracting Party following its accession to the European Union (14381/2013 – C8-0120/2016 - 20 13/0321 (NLE)), as this addresses the issue of the free flow of people, i.e. access to the labour market after Croatia's entry into the EU where Croatian citizens should acquire the same rights as citizens of other Member States.  It is also necessary to take into account the possibility that in the next seven years, i.e. after that another three years, Switzerland can restrict Croatian citizens' access to the labour market. The question remains as to how the new federal constitution article restricting immigration under the 2014 referendum will be resolved, where international treaties must not be opposed to its provisions.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it because I am opposed to this protocol of free movement. In principle, we are opposed to the notion of free movement, which is the main cause of social dumping, which encourages forced mobility and erases the notion of belonging to a country. We are all the more opposed to this agreement since Switzerland voted in February 2014 to introduce immigration quotas in order to control the entry of foreigners into its territory. The European Union has obviously been quick to judge and condemn this referendum, working by all means in its possession to have this vote annulled/invalidated. This agreement is just one more interference in Swiss affairs, we can only oppose it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP have voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. The protocol would force Switzerland to gradually open its borders to Croatia over a 10—year period. The Swiss people voted to reject mass immigration in a referendum in 2014. So to respect the wishes of the Swiss people, UKIP voted against the EU forcing them to open their borders to Croatia.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of ratifying the protocol to the agreement between the European Union and Switzerland on the free movement of people. This agreement will allow Croats to enjoy the same right to freedom of movement as any European national, following Croatia's accession to the European Union. The agreement allows Switzerland to re-enter the Horizon 2020 programme, which it was suspended from following its refusal to ratify the protocol in 2014. This is a decision that satisfies me and is in the direction of a closer union. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.
