name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The Protocol on the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons, which officially entered into force in 2002, has been extended to new Member States. With the accession of Bulgaria and Romania in January 2007, the agreement has once again been amended, thus entering into force as Protocol II. Following Protocol II, it is Protocol III ratified between the EU and Switzerland, which provides for an extension to the agreement on the free movement of persons to Croatia.  Under this procedure, nationals of the Contracting Parties are given the right to enter, live and work in their territories by abolishing the majority of restrictions. The aim of the agreement is to make Community rules equivalent within countries, but also to facilitate the provision of services within them. I therefore welcome the conclusion of the protocol.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I am opposed to The European 'free movement' which encourages forced mobility and social dumping. I congratulate Switzerland for having dared to vote in 2014 to introduce immigration quotas, which allows it to limit the number of entries into its territory.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the protocol to the agreement between the European Union and Switzerland on the free movement of people following Croatia's accession.  I am opposed to Schengen, which is the main cause of social dumping, which encourages forced mobility and erases the notion of belonging to a country. I am all the more opposed to this agreement since Switzerland voted in February 2014 to introduce immigration quotas in order to control the entry of foreigners into its territory. The Union was, of course, quick to judge and condemn this referendum, working by all means in its possession to have this vote annulled/invalidated. This agreement is just one more interference in Swiss affairs.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)

The European Union has obviously been quick to judge and condemn this referendum, working by all means to have this vote annulled/invalidated. This agreement is just one more interference in Swiss affairs. So I voted AGAINST this indefensible text.

text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which extends the free movement of persons between Switzerland and the EU to Croatia as a new member of the European Union.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. The agreement is intended to ensure that, after accession to the EU, Croats in Switzerland (and vice versa) can live and work (if they have an employment contract). In my opinion, such an agreement should be a matter for Switzerland and Croatia, and other countries and the EU should not be talking about it. If Switzerland and Croatia ratify the agreement, I do not object to its validity, which is why I abstained. But the agreement may run counter to switzerland's constitution, which, following a recent referendum, establishes Switzerland's sovereignty over immigration. So I would leave it up to Switzerland whether and how the agreement with Croatia imagines, I do not want to make decisions for the Swiss and Croats.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU, given its political and economic importance, is Switzerland's most important partner. As part of its European policy, Switzerland has always strained to strengthen relations with the EU, as demonstrated by the fact that since 2000 20 major agreements have been concluded and more than 120 bilateral agreements confirmed by Swiss citizens in seven referendums.  Switzerland and the EU signed a memorandum of understanding on 4 March 2016. Protocol III extending the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons to Croatia. Given the broader internal market whose key element is free movement, I believe that Croatia and Switzerland will benefit from the signing of Protocol III, so I supported this recommendation.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament gave its consent to the conclusion of the Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other, to give Croatian citizens access to Switzerland’s labour market. It is a formal but necessary step for the equality of EU Member States.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The approval of the Protocol to the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons concluded between the EU and Switzerland extends this Agreement to the citizens of the Republic of Croatia. According to the agreed rules, Switzerland may restrict access to the labour market for Croatian citizens during a transitional period of the next seven years for categories of residence for a period of more than four months and less than one year and for a period of one year or more. At the end of the transitional period, Switzerland may extend this period by a protection clause, i.e. for a further 3 years. I support the draft Protocol because it is in the interests of both countries and is in line with the agreements concluded between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote of the Recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other part, on the free movement of persons, with regard to the participation of the Republic of Croatia as a Contracting Party after its accession to the European Union, because that recommendation is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Indeed, it tends to develop, once again, the notion of free movement, which is one of the main causes of social dumping organised by the European Union. Even though Switzerland voted in 2014 on several texts to control entries into its territory, the Union sits on this national referendum to impose its vision. Beyond these considerations, the text positions itself favourably for forced mobility and fights the notion of belonging to a country. We can only oppose it.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – As the EU’s newest member, I see no reason for the Republic of Croatia not being able to enjoy the same benefits as those of its European counterparts, especially the free movement of persons. Therefore, I voted in favour on the Protocol between the European Community and its Member States and the Swiss Confederation regarding the participation of Croatia as a Contracting Party, as both the EU and Switzerland will continue benefiting from free movement.  Certainly, Switzerland has the right to prioritise employment opportunities for its citizens but it is also in the country’s benefit to open gradually its labour market to Croatian workers and likewise with Swiss workers in Croatia.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Conclusion of a protocol to the agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other, on the free movement of persons with a view to the accession of the Republic of Croatia: I took a negative view of this draft decision.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the Protocol to the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons, which had to be legally adjusted after Croatia's accession to the EU.  The purpose of this agreement was to create rules in the EU and Switzerland equivalent to those laid down in the Community acquis allowing entry, residence, work, self-employment, study, social security and the same conditions of residence, employment and employment as nationals of that State. In addition, the purpose of the agreement was also to facilitate the provision of services within the territory of the parties to the agreement. The agreement was subject to certain transitional provisions, gradually allowing all EU and Swiss citizens to exercise their right of free movement.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. We are naturally opposed to the notion of free movement, which is the main cause of social dumping, which encourages forced mobility and erases the notion of belonging to a country. We are all the more opposed to this agreement since Switzerland voted in February 2014 to introduce immigration quotas in order to control the entry of foreigners into its territory. The European Union has obviously been quick to judge and condemn this referendum, working by all means to have this vote annulled/invalidated. This agreement is just one more interference in Swiss affairs, so we can only oppose it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal is the legal instrument necessary for the conclusion of a Protocol to the Agreement on the free movement of persons between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.  The proposed Protocol incorporates the Republic of Croatia as a Contracting Party to the Agreement and states that the European Union must provide the version of the Agreement which is authentic in the new official language of the EU.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is important that Croatia, the newest Member State, is included in existing conventions and agreements and is an equal partner in our European Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is beyond doubt that both Croatia and Switzerland will politically, culturally and economically benefit from the signature of the present Protocol III. Free movement is a crucial element and can hence not be separated from internal market participation. That is why I voted in favour of this protocol.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons was signed in 2000 by Switzerland and the then 15 Member States of the Union. This Agreement does not automatically extend to the new Member States following the enlargement of the Union on 1 May 2004 and has therefore been amended by means of a Protocol and extended to the 10 new Member States. In accordance with the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the EU on 1 January 2007, the Agreement was amended again with the entry into force of Protocol II in 2009. Protocol III was drawn up with the entry of Croatia into the Union in 2013. However, this was initially blocked by Switzerland as a result of the 'anti-mass immigration' referendum on 9 February 2014, to which the Union responded. Then, on 4 March 2016, Switzerland and the Union finally signed Protocol III, which extends the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons to Croatia. The Council adopted a draft decision on the conclusion of the Protocol, but this requires the agreement of the European Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs recommends that Parliament agree with the conclusion of the Protocol. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. In principle, we are opposed to the notion of free movement, which is the main cause of social dumping, which encourages forced mobility and erases the notion of belonging to a country.  We are all the more opposed to this since Switzerland voted in February 2014 to introduce immigration quotas in order to control the entry of foreigners into its territory. The European Union has obviously been quick to judge and condemn this referendum, working by all means in its possession to have this vote annulled/invalidated.  This agreement is just one more interference in Swiss affairs. Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Switzerland is the EU's most important partner, given its geographical and cultural proximity, and especially its political and economic importance.  After Switzerland rejected joining the EEA Agreement and being mutually aware of the vital importance of cooperation, a number of bilateral agreements were negotiated covering the free movement of persons, land and air transport, agriculture and research, as well as technical barriers to trade and public procurement. This Protocol to the Agreement on the free movement of persons provides that, for a period of seven years from the entry into force of the Protocol, Switzerland may limit croatian citizens' access to the labour market (quotas, priority for local workers, control of working conditions and wages). During the last two years of this transitional period, the restrictions should be approved by the EU-Switzerland Joint Committee. I believe that the EU, as well as Switzerland, benefits from the internal market and its enlargements, and that both Croatia and Switzerland will benefit from the signing of this Protocol III, which will give them political, economic and cultural advantages, thanks to a wider internal market which has free movement as a fundamental element.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. In principle, I am opposed to the notion of free movement, which is the main cause of social dumping, which encourages forced mobility and erases the notion of belonging to a country. We are all the more opposed to this agreement since Switzerland voted in February 2014 to introduce immigration quotas in order to control the entry of foreigners into its territory. The European Union has obviously been quick to judge and condemn this referendum, working by all means in its possession to have this vote annulled/invalidated. This agreement is just one more interference in Swiss affairs, I can only oppose it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to give the consent of the European Parliament to this enactment which would extend the free movement accord between the EEA and the Swiss Confederacy to Croatia. As this agreement is linked to the fundamental principle of free movement of persons, this agreement will pave the way for the re-entry of Switzerland’s participation in the Erasmus+ programme. This will allow students from the UK to enjoy the possibility of participating in an exchange with Swiss universities.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to give Parliament's approval to Croatia's accession to the Protocol of the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons between the European Union and Switzerland. Since Croatia joined the European Union only from 1 July 2013, it was not a party to this protocol, whereas as a Member State it has a full place in it. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the draft resolution, primarily because it is important that we EU citizens support and make use of the free movement offered by the Union. Switzerland, like the EU Member States, benefits from the internal market and its expansion. The agreement will facilitate the provision of services and will be able to control the organised labour market in Switzerland and Croatia.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The free movement of persons given to the citizens of the European Union and Switzerland to live and work in each other’s territories is regulated by this protocol. I voted for this report that will take into consideration the accession of Croatia.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report tried to remedy an issue that has been ongoing since the Swiss ‘Against Mass Immigration’ referendum in 2014 and the introduction of a new Article, 121a, into its constitution, which states that Switzerland regulates immigration, that residence permit restrictions and quotas may be introduced based on Switzerland’s overall economic interests, and that businesses are obliged to give Swiss nationals priority when hiring staff. According to the EU, Article 121a is not compatible with the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons. This means that a solution needs to be found. The protocol agreed provides for a seven—year transition period in which Switzerland and Croatia can maintain limits on the emigration of their citizens to each other’s countries. The quotas are progressive so that Switzerland may gradually open its borders year by year to Croatian workers. I voted in favour of the report from a technical point of view in order to ensure Croatia will be included in the bilateral agreement between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have abstained from voting on the protocol to the EC-Switzerland Agreement on the free movement of persons on the occasion of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The conclusion of the Protocol is the result of Croatia's accession to the EU. This will benefit both parties on both internal market and free movement issues.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. The protocol would force Switzerland to gradually open its borders to Croatia over a 10—year period. The Swiss people voted to reject mass immigration in a referendum in 2014. So to respect the wishes of the Swiss people, UKIP voted against the EU forcing them to open their borders to Croatia.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ladies and gentlemen, I can only thank the rapporteur for her work and agree on the final text. The free movement of persons remains a fundamental pillar of the Union and we must all fight to protect this right.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – With Croatia entering the European Union in 2013, Protocol III was initiated and after a series of actions between the EU and Switzerland, on 4 March 2016, the two parties signed Protocol III extending the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons to Croatia. I believe the free movement of persons is an important for the smooth functioning of the internal market and the EU’s relation with EEA countries. This is why I fully support this protocol.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I welcome the conclusion of the Protocol extending the Free Movement of Persons Agreement between Switzerland and the EU to Croatia. The agreement between the European Union and Switzerland was supplemented twice after the entry of new member states into the EU. This, Ill. The Protocol was reached following EU intervention and finally ensured equal status for Croatian citizens with all other EU citizens.  The compromise reached ensures that Switzerland can limit the entry of Croatian citizens into its labour market for a period of 7 years because Switzerland retains its interests, firstly to employ its citizens and thereby increase its national GDP, secondly not to create pressure on its employment system by entering a larger amount of labour from Croatia and thirdly that if it does not have its own qualified personnel to fill it with personnel from Croatia. These measures may also be extended by an additional three years.  This Protocol shows the reasons why it is good that Croatia is a member of the European Union. The European Union protects the rights of its citizens regardless of which member they come from. Not reaching an agreement would mean terminating and ceasing the financing of certain joint projects implemented by the EU with Switzerland, such as those in the field of scientific cooperation within Horizon 2020 or infrastructure improvements.  For this reason, I supported this Recommendation of the European Parliament.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. In principle, I am strongly opposed to the notion of free movement, which is the main cause of social dumping, encourages forced mobility and erases the notion of belonging to a country.  This agreement outrages me all the more since Switzerland voted in a referendum in February 2014 to introduce immigration quotas, in order to control the entry of foreigners into its territory. The European Union has, of course, been quick to judge and condemn this referendum, working by all means in its possession to have this vote annulled or invalidated.  This agreement is just one more interference in Swiss affairs, I can only vote against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The EU and its 28 Member States are Switzerland's most important partner in terms of proximity both geographically and culturally, especially given their political and economic importance. The EU is also, in view of many agreements, more connected to Switzerland than to any other country outside the European Economic Area. While Switzerland is the EU's fourth largest trading partner, second only to the United States, China and Russia, the EU is Switzerland's largest trading partner. More than 1 million EU citizens live in Switzerland and 230,000 people cross the border every day for work. There are approximately 430,000 Swiss citizens living in the EU. With the accession of Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia to the EU, the internal market has expanded to cover almost 505 million people, making switzerland as our partner even more significant.  Since Switzerland refused to join the Agreement on the European Economic Area in 1992, and as both sides are aware of the crucial importance of cooperation, a number of bilateral agreements have been concluded (so-called Bilateral Agreements I). Almost 3 years after accession, I support its adoption and agree with the rapporteur's recommendations. All Member States must enjoy equal treatment and equal redress.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that Parliament has approved the rapporteur's recommendation on the conclusion of the Protocol, which will undoubtedly bring numerous political, economic and cultural benefits to Croatia and Switzerland.  Switzerland, like the EU Member States, benefits from the internal market and, of course, free movement is an integral part of it.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Switzerland is the EU's fourth largest economic partner, shortly after the US, China and Russia, while the EU is switzerland's main trading partner. More than 1 million EU citizens live in Switzerland and more than 230 000 cross the border daily to work. Around 430 000 Swiss citizens live in the EU. In 2000, the agreement on the free movement of persons between Switzerland and the EU-15 was signed. As a result, the agreement was extended to the 10 new Member States (Protocol I to the Agreement which entered into force in April 2006).  With Croatia, the European Union in 2013, Protocol III was launched and after a series of actions between the EU and Switzerland, on 4 March 2016, the two parties signed Protocol III extending the agreement on the free movement of persons to Croatia. This Protocol III requires the consent of the European Parliament. I voted in favour of approving this protocol with the conviction that the free movement of persons, although adequately supported by security and public order measures, is one of the most important achievements of these first 60 years of European integration.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other part, on the free movement of persons to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union has been signed subject to its conclusion at a later date. The Protocol should now be concluded on behalf of the European Union and its Member States. The Council may adopt the act only after receiving parliament's consent.  Following a referendum held in February 2014, a new article was introduced into the Swiss Federal Constitution. The most important provisions of this Article state that Switzerland regulates immigration on its own, can impose restrictions on residence permits and quotas, and that companies are obliged to give priority to Swiss citizens when hiring staff. According to the initiative, no treaty or international agreement may violate the newly introduced Article.  Switzerland and eu Member States benefit from comparable benefits from the internal market and both Croatia and Switzerland will undoubtedly benefit from the signing of the current Protocol, in which the free movement of persons is an essential element. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical text, which is part of adjustments related to Croatia's accession to the European Union. I have thereby approved the conclusion of a protocol between the European Union and Switzerland to extend the existing free movement agreement between the two parties to Croatian nationals.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union and Switzerland are important partners and maintain close ties thanks to a wide range of agreements.  The Agreement on the free movement of persons, concluded under bilateral agreements I, granted the citizens of the Contracting Parties the right of entry, residence and access to employment in their territories by mutually abolishing most restrictions. Croatia's accession to the EU in 2013 gave way to the conclusion of Protocol III with a view to extending the Agreement on free movement. However, the process was blocked due to the referendum "against mass emigration" in February 2014. On 4 March 2016, Protocol III was finally signed, providing for rules allowing Switzerland to establish limits on croatian citizens' access to the labour market. I believe that both Croatia and Switzerland will benefit from the signing of this Protocol III, which will give them political, economic and cultural advantages, thanks to a wider internal market which has free movement as a fundamental element.  I therefore vote in favour of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. The protocol would force Switzerland to gradually open its borders to Croatia over a 10—year period. The Swiss people voted to reject mass immigration in a referendum in 2014. So to respect the wishes of the Swiss people, UKIP voted against the EU forcing them to open their borders to Croatia.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that this is another positive step in the process of European integration.  This protocol allows, on the established dates, to deepen the spirit of unity and cohesion of the European peoples, in particular between Croatia and Switzerland. Switzerland will maintain progressive annual quotas so that it can gradually open up its labour market to Croatian workers. Croatia should be entitled to introduce the same quantitative limits for Swiss nationals during the same periods.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Simple revision of the protocol on the free movement of persons with Switzerland, taking into account the accession of Croatia.  Switzerland is expected to limit access to the labour market for Croatian citizens (quotas, priority for local workers, control of working conditions and wages) for a period of seven years.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution granting the European Parliament its approval for the conclusion of the Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other hand, on the free movement of persons, concerning the participation of the Republic of Croatia as a result of its accession to the European Union.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and Switzerland, on the other, signed an agreement on the free movement of persons on 21 June 1999. This free movement agreement came into force on 1 June 2002. Since then, this agreement has been adapted according to the enlargements of the European Union to take account of the new Member States. The agreement now remains to take account of Croatia's recent accession on 1 July 2013. By voting in favour of this report, Parliament gives its approval to the conclusion of the protocol.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The Free Movement of Persons Agreement between Switzerland and the European Union was signed in 2000 and entered into force in 2002. Subsequently, in April 2006, this Agreement was extended to the 10 new Member States in accordance with Protocol I of the Agreement. Under the accession of Bulgaria and Romania in 2007, the Agreement was once again amended, with the recent entry of Croatia in 2013, discussions on what has now been called Protocol III have begun. Finally, and after some procedural issues have been overcome, the two sides signed in March 2016 the now-designated Protocol III, thus extending the Free Movement of Persons Agreement to Croatia. In view of the view that this is a procedure of markedly technical content, following the membership of a new Member State to the European Union, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of a protocol between the Union and the Swiss Confederation. This protocol extends the existing free movement agreement between the two parties to Croatian nationals, following Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the extension to Croatia of the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the free movement of persons. An agreement that was blocked by the Swiss popular initiative "Against Mass Immigration" approved in a referendum in 2014, incompatible with it.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I have agreed to the Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and Switzerland on the free movement of persons and its transfer to the new Member State of Croatia. The agreement on the free movement of persons between the EU and Switzerland was adopted in 2000 and has since been extended to the newly added Member States in the EU's enlargement rounds, after both parties confirm this.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a technical agreement to assimilate the situation in Croatia, the last Member State to join the Union, to the same status as the other States of the Union with regard to the movement of persons with Switzerland. Parliament should be consulted for the conclusion of such international agreements and this resolution gives consent to Croatia's accession. Because it is a technical improvement in equaling the rights of the citizens of Croatia with that of the rest of the citizens of the Union, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to give the consent of the European Parliament to this enactment which would extend the free movement accord between the EEA and the Swiss Confederacy to Croatia. As this agreement is linked to the fundamental principle of free movement of persons, it will pave the way for the re-entry of Switzerland’s participation in the Erasmus+ programme. This will allowing students from the UK to enjoy the possibility of participating in an exchange with Swiss universities.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing – I voted in favour. Croatia's accession to the EU did not automatically extend to Croatia the agreement on the free movement of persons signed in the framework of bilateral agreements between the EU and Switzerland, which gave the citizens of the Contracting Parties the right to enter, live and work in the territories concerned by removing most of the restrictions between them. It was necessary to activate Protocol III (similar to the Agreement), which provides that, for a period of 7 years from the entry into force of this Protocol, Switzerland may restrict access to the labour market for Croatian citizens (quotas, preference for local workers, control of working conditions and wages). During the last two years of this transitional period, these restrictions must be agreed by the Switzerland-EU Joint Committee.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Switzerland has special relations with the EU based on a number of bilateral agreements. As interdepended economic, political and cultural relations have long shown to be beneficial to both sides, I also support Croatia's accession to this agreement. Since Switzerland refused accession to the European Economic Community in 1992, a number of bilateral agreements have been negotiated with the EU. This agreement on the free movement of persons has given the citizens of the Contracting Parties the right to enter, live and work in both territories, with most restrictions removed. Two Protocols were annexed to the Agreement by the accession of the new Member States in 2004 and 2007, which also established quotas, the labour market access regime, restrictions as well as safeguard clauses. Following Croatia's accession to the EU, it was necessary to negotiate a third protocol in a row so that Croatian citizens could also benefit from free movement. Although the protocol contains a protective clause allowing Switzerland to restrict croatian citizens' access to the labour market for a maximum of 10 years, I believe that, ultimately, the agreement will be beneficial for both countries.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the report on a protocol to the agreement between the European Community and its Member States and Switzerland on the free movement of persons with a view to the accession of the Republic of Croatia after its accession to the EU. ALFA believes that referendums are an important means of democracy and that it follows that the results must also be respected. When a country's political and economic situation changes, its citizens must be able to adapt their laws to the new situation. If Switzerland decides that migration from the EU becomes too much, then contracts must be renegotiated. It is acceptable that this could result in a Europe of different speeds.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ Switzerland, as a non-Member State of the European Union, is obliged to allow the free movement of European Union citizens on its territory in exchange for access to the common market. This also applies to the new Member States, including those that will join the European Union in the future. This model can serve as a basis for resolving relations with Great Britain in the future.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The EU-15 signed a bilateral agreement with Switzerland at the time to allow participation in the single market. The agreement was then amended through several protocols each time the EU was extended to include a new Member State. The same procedure is now being followed for the last member state, so that Croatia and Switzerland open up their (labour) market to each other. As in the past, the conclusion of that Protocol III requires parliament's approval. The N-VA delegation agreed to this purely technical adjustment following Croatia's accession, as Switzerland is the EU's fourth largest trading partner after the United States, China and Russia, while the EU is the largest trading partner for Switzerland. In other words, it is extremely important that the EU as a trading bloc is given a straightforward shape.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained from the European Parliament's resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a protocol to the agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other, on the free movement of persons with a view to the accession of the Republic of Croatia as a contracting party following its accession to the European Union. I am opposed to the extension of the EU to include other Member States, so that I cannot, in any case, agree to the adaptation of the various international treaties to Croatia's accession.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is Switzerland's most important partner in terms of proximity both geographically and culturally, especially given their political and economic importance. The agreement on the free movement of persons, signed as part of bilateral agreement I, lifted most of the restrictions, thus recognising their citizens' right to enter, reside and work on the territory of another signatory state.  Switzerland and the European Union signed a memorandum of understanding on 4 March 2016. Protocol III extending the Agreement on freedom of movement of persons to Croatia.  I support the recommendation on the draft Decision of the Council on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other hand, on the free movement of persons in connection with the participation of the Republic of Croatia as a Contracting Party after its accession to the European Union and I support the granting of consent for the conclusion of the protocol.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other part, on the free movement of persons with regard to the participation of the Republic of Croatia as a Contracting Party to the Agreement following its accession to the European Union.  With the accession of Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria to the European Union, the internal market has expanded. The 2002 agreement gave EU and Swiss citizens the right to enter, live and work in their territories, and this agreement established rules between the Union and Switzerland equivalent to those of the Acquis communaut the Union, namely the facilitation of entry, residence, work, self-employment and study, and the introduction of the right to social security and the provision of the same living, employment and working conditions as citizens.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy of the free movement of persons has failed, and with tragic results. A typical example is the ease with which the various terrorists move undisturbed from one end of Europe to the other.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's consent to The 3rd Framework Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons concluded in 2000 under the Bilateral Agreement between the EU and its Member States and the Swiss Confederation, supplementing the Agreement governing the free movement of persons. To sign a protocol. I have taken into account the fact that the content and scope of most of the many agreements between the two parties are automatically aligned with the EU's expansion, but the agreement on the free movement and employment of persons is not, and therefore a new Additional Protocol is needed as a result of croatia's accession. Switzerland is now almost a part of the single internal market in practice, and the EU, Croatia and Switzerland all have an important interest in its continued smooth functioning in the movement and employment of its citizens. In order to ensure gradation in this context, the seven-year transitional period laid down in the draft complies with similar provisions in the past. However, with a view to the forthcoming developments, as a member of the relevant EP delegation, I must bear in mind that the regrettable result of the 2014 Swiss anti-immigration referendum is contrary to the agreement with the EU and that, in the absence of a mutually sound legal solution, the entire legal basis of our relations with Switzerland may be terminated.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The first series of bilateral agreements between the EU and Switzerland entered into force in June 2002, including the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons. They were subsequently amended by Protocol I and Protocol II. Protocol III was initiated with Croatia's entry into the European Union in 2013 and recently signed. It provides for a transitional period of seven years. There is no doubt that, politically, economically and culturally, both Croatia and Switzerland will benefit from the signing of this protocol. Free movement is an essential element and therefore cannot be separated from participation in the internal market.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement with Switzerland.  Because of its geographical and cultural proximity, and in particular its economic and political weight, the Union, together with its 28 Member States, is Switzerland's most important partner. In comparison, the EU has closer ties with Switzerland than any other country outside the European Economic Area (EEA), thanks to a wide range of agreements. While Switzerland is the EU's fourth largest trading partner, just after the United States, China and Russia, the EU is Switzerland's largest trading partner. More than one million European citizens live in Switzerland, and another 230,000 cross the border every day to work. Some 430,000 Swiss citizens live in the EU. With the accession of Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia, the internal market has expanded further to include almost 505 million people and become even more important for our Swiss partner.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States and the Swiss Confederation, regarding the free movement of persons following Croatia’s accession to the European Union in 2013. According to this protocol, Switzerland will be able to limit the access of Croatian citizens to its labour market in terms of quotas, priority to local workers, and control of working conditions and wages for period of seven years, extendable to three more years, a limit that Croatia is also entitled to apply to Swiss nationals in Croatia. Given the importance of the EU internal market for Switzerland, and the partnership with Switzerland for the EU, I am certain that this protocol will bring political, economic and cultural benefits to both Croatia and Switzerland.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I voted to conclude the Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States and the Swiss Confederation on the Free Movement of Persons in connection with the participation of the Republic of Croatia as a Contracting Party following its accession to the European Union. I believe that the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons, signed as part of bilateral agreement I, has lifted most of the restrictions by both sides. I welcome the fact that it is doubt that both Croatia and Switzerland will benefit from the signing of the current Protocol III from a political, economic and cultural point of view.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a protocol to the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the free movement of persons (accession of Croatia) as the EU's internal market has expanded with the accession of Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia, and it has covered almost 505 million people, making it even more important for Switzerland.  Both Croatia and Switzerland will undoubtedly gain political, economic and cultural terms by signing the current Protocol and extending the internal market, where free movement is essential.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the extension to Croatia of the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the free movement of persons. An agreement that was blocked by the Swiss popular initiative "Against Mass Immigration" approved in a referendum in 2014, incompatible with it.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the report on a protocol to the agreement between the European Community and its Member States and Switzerland on the free movement of persons with a view to the accession of the Republic of Croatia after its accession to the EU. ALFA believes that referendums are an important means of democracy and that it follows that the results must also be respected. When a country's political and economic situation changes, its citizens must be able to adapt their laws to the new situation. If Switzerland decides that migration from the EU becomes too much, then contracts must be renegotiated. It is acceptable that this could result in a Europe of different speeds.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Swiss referendum "against mass immigration" resulted in changes to switzerland's constitution, while violating the agreement on the free movement of persons. Following Croatia's accession to the EU, negotiations have drawn up a protocol that contains some temporary restrictions on the labour market and quantitative limits for Croatian citizens, but is a good step towards the realisation of the EU's fundamental freedoms. That is why I voted in favour of Protocol III.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. We are opposed in principle to the notion of free movement, which is the main cause of social dumping, which encourages forced mobility and erases the notion of belonging to a country. We are all the more opposed to this agreement since Switzerland voted in February 2014 to introduce immigration quotas in order to control the entry of foreigners into its territory. The European Union has obviously been quick to judge and condemn this referendum, working by all means in its possession to have this vote annulled/invalidated. This agreement is just one more interference in Swiss affairs. I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given its geographical and cultural proximity, in particular its political and economic importance, the Union of 28 Member States is switzerland's most important partner. Accordingly, the Union has developed closer relations with Switzerland through a number of agreements than with any country other than the European Economic Area (EEA). I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the extension to Croatia of the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the free movement of persons. An agreement that was blocked by the Swiss popular initiative "Against Mass Immigration" approved in a referendum in 2014, incompatible with it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ As strong defenders of the principle of free movement, the Greens-EFA Group fully supports the Protocol extending the corresponding agreement between the EU and Switzerland to Croatia, thus I voted for.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This decision extends to Croatia as a member of the Union by this decision on the free movement of persons signed in 2000. By this decision the European Parliament ratifies this protocol and I consider it necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'Again, an agreement between the EU and a third country (in this case Switzerland) must be adapted to the changed situation caused by Croatia's accession to the Union. I voted in favour of this recommendation, which ensures that Croats enjoy the same rights of free movement of people when travelling to Switzerland as the rest of the EU citizens.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The negotiation of the initial agreement, signed in 2000, was supported by the particular interest that more than 100,000 Portuguese emigrants work in Switzerland, including many thousands of seasonal workers. The inclusion of Croatia, with a period of 7 years in which, mutually, one country and another may limit the movement of people and goods, is only a consequence of their entry into the EU context. This does not change the approval that this agreement deserved for us at the outset, under the same arguments for facilitating the right-making of workers from other countries and their families.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Protocol III would mean that Croatian nationals would have to be granted freedom of movement. However, since the majority of the Swiss population voted against mass immigration in 2014, I rejected this draft decision.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. In the wake of the successful Swiss referendum "Against Mass Immigration" on 9 February 2014, the Swiss government was commissioned by the Sovereign to renegotiate the current rules on the free movement of persons between Switzerland and the EU. The report to be voted on takes the position of the EU, which is not interested in tightening up the rules, and seeks to ignore the changed situation in Switzerland. Its adoption amounts to a disregard for the federal vote, which is why rejection was required here.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In the year 2000 an agreement on the free movement of persons between Switzerland and the EU-15 was signed. Coming into force in 2002, this agreement has since then been extended. It was applied to the 10 new Member States, only to be amended yet again after the accession of Bulgaria and Romania. Now it has to be extended once again for the newest member of the European Union, Croatia. Switzerland and the EU have an undeniably strong tie in several aspects, which both parties benefit from. With this in mind, we have to apply the principle of non-discrimination, including equal treatment, and therefore vote in favour of this protocol. From political, to economic, to cultural aspects, the signing of Protocol III will enable Croatia and Switzerland to profit in those areas, and will additionally expand the internal market, where the free movement is essential.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to give the consent of the European Parliament to this enactment which would extend the free movement accord between the EEA and the Swiss Confederacy to Croatia. As this agreement is linked to the fundamental principle of free movement of persons, this agreement will pave the way for the re-entry of Switzerland’s participation in the Erasmus+ programme. This will allow students from the UK to enjoy the possibility of participating in exchanges with Swiss universities.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ In the context of Croatia's accession to the European Union in 2013, it is necessary to amend a number of bilateral or multilateral agreements that have already been concluded and into which the enlargement of the European Union needs to be recorded. This is also the case with the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons between the European Union and Switzerland. Mrs Jazłowiecka's report was aimed at concluding a protocol that would take account of croatia's accession. In this case, I voted in favour of concluding the protocol, although at present the situation regarding the free movement of persons between the EU and Switzerland is uncertain in view of the results of the 2014 popular vote 'against mass immigration'. I therefore hope that Switzerland will be able to stabilise the situation as soon as possible and that free movement between it and the EU will not be disrupted as a result of the popular vote.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other part, on the free movement of persons with regard to the participation of the Republic of Croatia as a Contracting Party to the Agreement following its accession to the European Union. The internal market and its enlargement bring similar benefits to both Switzerland and EU Member States, as Switzerland has repeatedly emphasised. This is also confirmed by the Swiss analyses of the consequences of the suspension of the implementation of bilateral agreements.  Croatia and Switzerland will undoubtedly gain political, economic and cultural terms by signing the current Protocol III and extending the internal market, where free movement is essential.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to approve the trilateral social summit for growth and employment and at the same time to repeal Decision 2003/174 EC. Considering that the Council and the European Commission have formally committed themselves to always inviting a representative of the Employment and Social Affairs Commission to participate in the trilateral summits, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This ‘summit’ is a talking shop for high-level EU officials, lobbyists and European NGOs to discuss employment and economic issues. It is just another waste of taxpayers’ money that will achieve nothing.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The Tripartite Social Summit (TSS) for Growth and Employment was a meeting with the Council Presidency, the Commission and the social partners (10 trade unionists and 10 business). It took place at least once a year before the spring European Council. The whole idea was to have an exchange of views on employment, social policy, health and consumer affairs before the Council meeting. Parliament was not mentioned but the Chair of the Committee on Employment, and Social Affairs (EMPL) was always invited to the summit. This vote was to give consent to the Council recommendation and re-ratify the decision. Parliament has adopted a report calling for the EMPL Chair to be formally invited. This report was adopted after the Council decision and is not reflected in that draft decision. The EMPL Committee and its Chair were not happy about the decision and only supported the draft decision once a letter from the Presidency of the Council and the President of the Commission outlined that the EMPL Chair would be invited to all TSSs. After that was done the Committee gave consent. My GUE/NGL colleague Thomas Handel, Chair of the EMPL Committee, supported the decision. I voted in favour.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. As co-legislator, it is essential that the European Parliament, represented by the chairman of its Employment and Social Affairs Committee, be systematically invited to the tripartite social summit for growth and employment.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the Tripartite Social Summit (TSS) for Growth and Employment. The legal framework for the TSS needs to be updated following the institutionalisation of the European Council and its President brought about by the Lisbon Treaty.  The main issue in the Council decision on the TSS was the institutionalisation of the standing practice of inviting the Chair of Parliament’s Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) to the TSS. In its interim report, adopted after the Council decision, Parliament called for this to be institutionalised. Unfortunately, the Council text did not refer to an invitation to be sent to the Chair of the EMPL Committee. The Dutch Presidency and the rapporteur worked on a solution to have an official letter from the Council/Commission to the President of the European Parliament confirming the practice of inviting the Chair of the EMPL Committee to attend the TSS. The outcome of the UK referendum postponed the formal letter. The Slovak Presidency ensured that the agreement would be adhered to and the letter sent to Parliament’s President. I look forward to Parliament’s involvement in the TSS.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This social dialogue at the summit is presented as essential to strengthen the legitimacy of economic governance with a strengthened "social pillar". However, it only involves partners who are all the more dependent on the institutions because they are an integral part of the system. The ultra-liberal line of these discussions is obvious and strongly encourages structural reforms. In addition, the Schengen area is considered untouchable, and the integration of migrants held for a chance for Europe.  Not only is the 'social dialogue' rigged, and the desire to relaunch the process at Member State level is a simple formulation of principle, but this social guarantee of the ESD serves to legitimise the governance that is required, without any consideration for national and democratic institutions, starting with national parliaments.  I therefore voted against this report, which institutionalizes a new undemocratic structure.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against approval of the Council decision. I have concerns that this may place too much emphasis upon the role of lobbyists, and too little upon the citizens of the nation states within the European Union.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I call for integrated European policies for growth and jobs. This summit is a promising start.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the recommendation for the Tripartite Social Summit on Growth and Employment and repealing Decision 2003/174/EC. In the light of the institutional developments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and the emergence of the office of President of the European Council, it was revised in 2003. Council Decision setting up the Tripartite Social Summit. The aim of the Tripartite Summit on Growth and Employment is to ensure, in accordance with the Treaty and with due regard to the powers of the Union's institutions and bodies, continuous coordination between the Council, the Commission and the social partners.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Triparti veiled Social Summit for Growth and Jobs is responsible for ensuring continuous coordination between the Council, the Commission and the social partners, in accordance with the Treaty and with due regard to the competences of the EU institutions and bodies. At European level, it gives the social partners the opportunity to contribute to the eu's growth and jobs strategy through their social dialogue. To this end, the Summit will rely on the work of the Council, the Commission and the social partners and on the negotiations between them in the various conciliation for a on economic, social and employment issues. Following the institutional change brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon to establish the Presidency of the European Council, the 2003 Decision establishing the Tripartite Social Summit on Growth and Jobs should be reviewed.  In order to maintain the logic of the Treaty and the institutional context of the Triparti ve multilateral Social Summit for Growth and Jobs, the roles and responsibilities conferred by the 2003 Council Decision on the Presidency-in-Office of the Council should be transferred to the newly created Presidency of the European Council. I supported the proposal because it means reforming the EU's platform for social dialogue in a form adapted to the Treaty of Lisbon. The Forum can give peripheral countries a chance to finally take action against the pay gap between the centre and the periphery and other forms of employment colonisation.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This ‘summit’ is a talking shop for high—level EU officials, lobbyists and European NGOs to discuss employment and economic issues. It is just another waste of taxpayers’ money that will achieve nothing.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. It is out of the question to endorse this desire to institutionalize a new undemocratic structure. This so-called "social dialogue at the top" is presented as essential to strengthen the legitimacy of economic governance with a strengthened "social pillar". However, it only involves partners who are all the more dependent on the institutions because they are an integral part of the system. The ultra-liberal line of these discussions is obvious and strongly encourages the "structural reforms" dictated by the Commission.  Moreover, the Schengen area is considered untouchable, and the integration of migrants as a 'chance for Europe'. Not only is the 'social dialogue' rigged - and the desire to relaunch the process at Member State level a simple formulation of principle - but, in addition, this social guarantee of the ESD serves to legitimise the 'governance' of technocrats, without any consideration for national and democratic institutions, starting with national parliaments.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report on a draft Council decision to comply with the institutional changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon made it necessary to update the organisation of the trilateral social summit for growth and jobs. The Council presented its own proposal in February 2014, forwarding it to Parliament before the adoption of an autonomous resolution of the same in April of the same year. Having asked the Commission and the Council to include a provision, which was then accepted, allowing the chairman of the EP's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs to take part in the trilateral summit, I decided to vote in favour of the Sógor report. The new measures will ensure parliament's regular participation in the summit with the participation of the Chairman of the EMPL Committee.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this recommendation on the TSS, because it implies the completion of a long process in which while the Council's relationship with Parliament has not been as efficient and sincere as it should be, the result is positive, both for the Dialogue of the Commission and the Council with social partners and for the position of the European Parliament in the TSS. However, it should be noted that the Council has acted during this procedure, without respecting Parliament's deadlines.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This summit, established in 2003, meets at least once a year, before the Spring European Council to discuss social issues and employment. These discussions are now part of the EU 2020 strategy. The question is how ESDs for Inclusive Growth can contribute to economic governance. This social dialogue actually involves only partners who are an integral part of the system and the line of this ultraliberal discussion must in fact promote the structural reforms desired by the Union which we denounce. Worse, the Schengen area is seen as untouchable and the integration of migrants as an opportunity for Europe. This governance is imposed without regard for national democratic institutions and in reality serves only as a social guarantor without actually being. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trilateral Social Summit for Growth and Jobs is part of the European Semester process, which is a symbol of the total lack of democracy and transparency in EU governance. In view of the fact that the amendments proposed by the Council will not in any way increase the democratic nature of this instrument, which serves only to validate the Commission's unilateral decisions in a self-referential manner, I voted against the measure.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of a Recommendation on the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment.  This is a forum for dialogue between the Union institutions and the European social partners, which seeks to promote continued exchange and ensure that the social partners contribute to the Union's economic and social strategy. The previous 2003 decision was to be amended by a Council decision with the consent of the European Parliament. In 2014 Parliament approved only one interim report. Finally, the situation could be unblocked and that decision repealed.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported Parliament's decision on the tripartite social summit on growth and employment. One of the EU's objectives is to build a highly competitive social market economy that achieves full employment and social progress. Therefore, when defining and implementing its policies and actions, the Union must take into account their social dimension, in particular those relating to the promotion of a high level of employment, the guarantee of adequate social protection, the fight against social exclusion, a high level of education, training and the protection of human health. In its conclusions of 2013, the European Council noted that the social dimension of Economic and Monetary Union should be strengthened and underlined the crucial role of social partners and social dialogue in this regard. The Commission examined the promotion of social dialogue at national and EU level and concluded that the summit was an opportunity to involve the social partners in the European Semester process.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Within the exercise of the power of memoranda of understanding under the special legislative procedure, the European Parliament has taken a position on the Draft Council Decision on the Triparti veparti board summit on Growth and Jobs and repealing Decision 2003/174/EC. The change essentially concerned technical and procedural issues.  This is based on the Tripartite Social Summit on Growth and Jobs, established by Council Decision 2003/174/EC of 6 March 2003, which formaled the practice of high-level informal meetings organised since 1997, first under the European Employment Strategy and then in the Framework of the Lisbon Strategy. In 2003, the Commission presented the relevant proposal for a decision in order to institutionalise the practice of high-level consultations between the EU institutions and the EU social partners. However, following the institutional change brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon to establish the Presidency of the European Council, the 2003 Decision establishing the Tripartite Social Summit on Growth and Jobs had to be revised. (Article 352 TSI provided the legal basis for the adoption of the Council decision.)

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this Recommendation on a tripartum social summit for growth and jobs and I think it is of u unathase that the European Parliament, represented by the Chair of the EMPL Committee, is invited to the summit on a regular basis.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Tripartite Social Summit (TSS) was established by Council Decision 2003/174/EC of 6 March 2003, which formalised the practice, which has been established since 1997, of holding high-level informal meetings within the framework of the European Employment Strategy and, subsequently, the Lisbon Strategy.  The institutions participating in the Social Summit must do more and act in a more integrated way to ensure growth and employment in the European Union. Growth and employment must be of quality, because there is no possibility of maintaining European welfare and democracy by competing downwards, with wage devaluation and in a deflationary environment. We must support sustainable growth, based on innovation, solidarity and inclusiveness: they are innovation, high quality, efficient services and valuable products that make the European market strong. This awareness must not abandon us, especially in times of economic difficulty.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Established in 2003, the tripartite social summit for growth and employment takes place once a year and brings together the President of the European Council, the President of the Commission and the rotating Presidency of the Council. The text envisages the association of the social partners recognised by the institutions and the chairman of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs at the summit.  Involving only officials dependent on the European institutions, this social dialogue is a vast sham: it actually serves to strengthen the legitimacy of anti-democratic European institutions whose representatives are not elected by direct universal suffrage. But above all, this summit is an opportunity to define the method required to impose ultra-liberal structural reforms on Member States. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment (TSS) was established by Decision 2003/174/EC, which formalised the practice of holding informal summits since 1997 within the framework of the European Employment Strategy. This Decision has been proposed to institutionalise the practice of high-level consultation between the EU institutions and the EU social partners. The proposal meant the abolition of the former Standing Committee on Employment, which was established in 1970 and reformed in 1999. I voted in favour of this proposal, which will allow the social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of social dialogue, to the various components of the Union's strategy for growth and jobs.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. This report is the European Parliament's approval of the revision of the Council's decision 2003/174/EC institutionalising a tripartite summit for growth and employment. The aim of the revision is to adapt the 2003 decision to current legislative, social and economic developments. The tripartite summit for growth and jobs brings together the Council, the Commission and the social partners. The aim of this summit is to maintain an ongoing dialogue between the European institutions and the social partners. This ensures a European strategy for growth and employment that is more in line with the realities on the ground. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU Council decision rewriting the functioning of the trilateral social summit for growth and jobs in order to allow better consultation between the European Council, the EU Council, the Commission and the social partners and to enable them to contribute, within the framework of the social dialogue, to the various aspects of the Union's growth and employment strategy. Since its inception (in accordance with Decision 2003/174/EC repealed by the one in question), the Summit has played a key role in high-level consultation, contributing positively to the development of the social dialogue at Union level within the framework of the Lisbon Strategy during the period 2000-2010 and within the Framework of the Europe 2020 Strategy. The tasks and composition of the Summit have been adapted to take account of the institutional changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the creation of the function of President of the European Council referred to in Article 15 TEU.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The Tripartite Social Summit (TSS) for Growth and Employment was a meeting with the Council Presidency, the Commission and the social partners (10 trade unionists and 10 business). It took place at least once a year before the spring European Council. The whole idea was to have an exchange of views on employment, social policy, health and consumer affairs before the Council meeting. Parliament was not mentioned but the Chair of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) was always invited to the summit. This vote was to give consent to the Council recommendation and re-ratify the decision. Parliament has adopted a report calling for the EMPL Chair to be formally invited. This report was adopted after the Council decision and is not reflected in that draft decision. The EMPL Committee and its Chair were not happy about the decision and only supported the draft decision once a letter from the Presidency of the Council and the President of the Commission outlined that the EMPL Chair would be invited to all TSSs. After that was done the committee gave consent. My GUE/NGL colleague Thomas Handel, Chair of the EMPL Committee, supported the decision. I voted in favour.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This ‘summit’ is a talking shop for high—level EU officials, lobbyists and European NGOs to discuss employment and economic issues. It is just another waste of taxpayers’ money that will achieve nothing.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it confirmed the practice of inviting the Chair of Parliament’s Employment and Social Committee to the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment. This factor was still missing in the draft Council decision which laid out the basis of the new setup of this Summit, following the changes brought about by the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the report, the European Parliament approves the draft Council decision on the trilateral social summit for growth and employment. The favourable position for approval was supported by the Council's commitment to invite a representative of the EP (and in particular the Employment and Social Affairs Commission) to each summit meeting. I voted in favour without delay.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Tripartite Social Summit (TSS) was established in 2003 to institutionalise the practice of holding high-level informal meetings between the heads of the European institutions and representatives of companies and workers within the framework of the European Employment Strategy. I believe, however, that an agreement between the European institutions is appropriate to allow the chairman of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) to attend these summits as well. I felt that I was voting in favour of the Council's decision because I believe it was necessary to update the way in which the summit was held in order to take account of the institutional changes brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon. I hope that the new structure of the summit will make a positive contribution to the development of social dialogue at Eu ropean Union level for the benefit of European citizens and workers.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Sogor report concerns the European Parliament's consent to the reconstitution of the tripartite social summit on growth and jobs as a result of the amendments brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon. However, this reconstitution is not only a technical issue of consensus, but also has political dimensions. It continues to exclude the European Parliament from the whole process and limits its role to informal and consultative, reinforcing the democratic deficit. The implementation of the Treaty of Lisbon has also completely dismantled the social dialogue since, with the stricter budgetary discipline adopted, the labour market has been deregulated, industrial relations have been dissolved and insurance conquests have been destroyed.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The recommendation on the draft Council decision establishing a tripartite social summit on growth and jobs is directly linked to efforts to tackle the problems faced by thousands of citizens as a result of the crisis that has plagued Europe for almost eight years. As such actions are aimed at tackling the problem through development, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the trilateral social summit for growth and employment since it allows for a simultaneous and continuous confrontation between the European Council, the Commission, Parliament and the social partners. The current socio-economic situation in the Union as a whole has been more magma for years now, and it is therefore essential to provide for methods of consultation between those parties which, more than anyone else, must ensure optimum resolution for the citizens. It is precisely from this point of view of social dialogue that new tactics and strategies can be found which are functional to constant growth and full employment.  All too often, in fact, there has been a disconnect between the European decision-making bodies and the social partners to the point of clashes or deadlocks, thereby also helping to strengthen anti-European sentiments. The legitimate Euroscepticism that has emerged, however, has only complicated the working tables by preventing rapid and effective deliberations.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote on the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Jobs (CST), established by Council Decision 2003/174/EC, formalised the practice of holding, since 1997, informal high-level meetings under the European Employment Strategy and, subsequently, the Lisbon Strategy. Following the institutional changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, the 2003 Council decision establishing the Tripartite Social Summit needed to be revised. The Treaty of Lisbon entailed significant institutional changes, which justify the revision of the decision, namely: - Institutionalised the European Council and created the post of President of the European Council; - Recognised the role of cst as an integral part of the EU's social dialogue; - Repealed Article 202 of the EC Treaty, which was the legal basis for adopting the 2003 decision (the functions of the Council are now defined by Article 16 of the EU Treaty and the comitology principles are set out in Articles 290 and 291 TFEU). I voted in favour of this Recommendation, which adapts the institutional changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, also reviewing the policy framework, replacing the Lisbon Strategy with the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This ‘summit’ is a talking shop for high—level EU officials, lobbyists and European NGOs to discuss employment and economic issues. It is just another waste of taxpayers’ money that will achieve nothing.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – I agree with the conclusion of the report which is to support the outcome of this Summit. Fruit may be reaped by getting employers and trade unions to dialogue together for lasting solutions in employment.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a proposal to improve this European social dialogue system, especially with regard to Parliament's participation in the meetings. Parliament should be consulted in the review of the functioning of the tripartite social summit, and the condition of this consultation has been the participation of the President of the European Parliament's Employment Committee in the meetings.
