Once agreement has been reached with the Commission and Council on this point, it is guaranteed to participate in the summit. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the trilateral social summit is a key opportunity to involve the social partners in the Process of the European Semester. I am convinced that the widest possible representativeness and the legitimacy and effectiveness of consultation with the social partners are of the utmost importance and that only in this way can social dialogue in the European Union find new impetus. I believe that it is important to strengthen and exploit synergies and complementarity between the various bodies in order to coordinate the European Union's economic and social strategy more coherently.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I support the document, the main purpose of which is to regulate the issue of calls made to the President of the Committee on Employment to attend every tripartite social summit. I am very pleased that all the EU institutions have the same opinion and are positive about the document described above. I, too, as a member of Parliament, voted in favour. The presence of the President will certainly improve the work and benefit the trilogue.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation as I believe that European Parliament’s role as co-legislator in the tripartite social summit for growth and employment is crucially important, and Parliament should be represented by the Chair of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on a regular basis.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of approving the draft Council Decision on a tripartite social summit for growth and employment and repealing Decision 2003/174/EC.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The tripartite summit is a forum for the European institutions to establish a constructive dialogue with employers' and trade union representatives. This report proposes the Approval of the European Parliament to the new regulations governing the tripartite summit, which includes the participation of the Chairman of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Considering that this report promotes better representation of the European Parliament at the tripartite social summit, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This ‘summit’ is a talking shop for high—level EU officials, lobbyists and European NGOs to discuss employment and economic issues. It is just another waste of taxpayers’ money that will achieve nothing.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Through this vote, we gave our approval to the Council's draft decision to adapt the 2003 Council decision on the organisation of high-level informal meetings in tripartite social summits. This adaptation must be made in order to meet the new requirements introduced by the Lisbon Treaty. If the missions of the tripartite social summit for growth and employment remain broadly the same, it is mainly its composition that will be changed.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Established in 2003, this summit meets at least once a year, before the Spring European Council to discuss social issues and employment. The ESD brings together a trio of presidents: the President of the European Council, the President of the European Commission, and the rotating Presidency of the Council. We cannot support this social dialogue, which is based on the ultra-liberal principles long defended by the European Union. So I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the Trilogue on Social Affairs, as I believe that the European Parliament should be an equal participant in it. It is important, in addition to the Council and the Commission, that we also have a representative of this important meeting with social partners from all over Europe. For this reason, I voted in favour so that the Chair of the Committee on Social Affairs could be an official representative of the EP.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against because I believe that this session does not really promote the interests of workers.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Within the exercise of the power of memoranda of understanding under the special legislative procedure, the European Parliament has taken a position on the Draft Council Decision on the Triparti veparti board summit on Growth and Jobs and repealing Decision 2003/174/EC. The change essentially concerned technical and procedural issues. This is based on the Tripartite Social Summit on Growth and Jobs, established by Council Decision 2003/174/EC of 6 March 2003, which formaled the practice of high-level informal meetings organised since 1997, first under the European Employment Strategy and then in the Framework of the Lisbon Strategy. In 2003, the Commission presented the relevant proposal for a decision in order to institutionalise the practice of high-level consultations between the EU institutions and the EU social partners. However, following the institutional change brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon to establish the Presidency of the European Council, the 2003 Decision establishing the Tripartite Social Summit on Growth and Jobs had to be revised. (Article 352 TSI provided the legal basis for the adoption of the Council decision.) I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the need to update the legal framework of the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment (OSH) due to the changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty, the European Commission presented a new Council decision on which the OSH could be based.  The proposal is to adapt the 2003 Council decision to the institutional changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty. It is also reviewing the overall policy framework, replacing the Lisbon strategy, the Europe 2020 Strategy and specifying how OSH for growth and employment should contribute to global governance.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission does not intend, at this stage, to use the opportunity provided by this review to carry out a thorough reform of the functioning of the Tripartite Social Summit. The summit has always been regarded by the social partners as a privileged forum for discussing social and employment issues at the highest level. It is also an opportunity for representatives of the EU institutions participating in the CST to hear the views and proposals of both sides of the spectrum of social dialogue, allowing them to then convey these views to the members of the European Council. I agree with a proposal adapting the existing decision to the institutional changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, while reflecting the positive results of the recent practical experience gained under the CST.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: we must refuse to endorse the institutionalization of a new undemocratic structure.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The participation of workers in all the decisions that affect them, in a sense of defense of their class interests, obviously deserves our support. While there are also reservations about the character and scope of an instrument such as the Tripartite Social Summit (joining the Presidency of the European Council, the Council of the European Union, the European Commission, 10 employers' representatives and 10 workers' representatives), in the context in which its launch and implementation has been considered, it has also received our positive attention. As a consequence of the Treaty of Lisbon, the composition of the Summit has been amended. By not changing the level of representation of workers and their relative weight, we do not oppose and agree with the recommendation made.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because the changes proposed by the Council will not increase democracy.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation because the tripartite session is now based on the Treaty of Lisbon with which I am opposed;

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As co-legislator, it is essential that Parliament, represented by the Chair of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) is invited to the Tripartite Social Summit (TSS) for Growth and Employment on a regular basis. The PPE rapporteur, Mr Sógor, the shadows and the EMPL coordinators proposed that consent be given to the Council position only on the condition that the Chair of the EMPL Committee is invited to the TSS on a regular basis. Respective assurances should be given by the Council and the Commission prior to the plenary vote. In the meantime Parliament received a letter from the Council and the Commission confirming that the EMPL Chair will be invited to the TSS also in the future, thereby satisfying Parliament’s demands. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Jobs. The European Social Summit is held twice a year in the run-up to the Spring and Autumn European Councils. The Social Summit will be attended by the Heads of Government and Labour Ministers of the Member States of the current Trio Presidency, the European Commission and the European social partners. I consider this summit to be an important forum in the active EU social partner dialogue.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision as it aims to enable social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of their social dialogue, to the various components of the European Union’s strategy for growth and jobs.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The tripartite social summit (SST) includes the presidency of the European Council, the presidency of the Commission, and the presidency-in-office of the Council. Established in 2003, it meets at least once a year, before the Spring European Council, to discuss social issues and employment. It combines social partners "recognized by institutions" and is, in a way, the moral guarantor of economic governance.  By choosing the social partners, fully committed to the relevance of the system's choices, this summit leaves European decision-makers free to act in favour of globalism. This is particularly the case in migration, where the Schengen area is considered untouchable and migrants are considered a "chance for Europe".  The proposal itself aims to revise the Council's 2003/174/EC decision, which institutionalizes the tripartite social summit, to facilitate its contribution to global governance. Patriotic MEPs cannot endorse this institution, whose functioning leaves no room for national and democratic institutions, starting with national parliaments and which aims above all to "rigg" social dialogue. So I voted against this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this recommendation on the TSS, because it implies the completion of a long process in which while the Council's relationship with Parliament has not been as efficient and sincere as it should be, the result is positive, both for the Dialogue of the Commission and the Council with social partners and for the position of the European Parliament in the TSS. However, it should be noted that the Council has acted during this procedure, without respecting Parliament's deadlines.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision, as it aims to enable the social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of their social dialogue, to the various components of the European Union’s strategy for growth and jobs.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – The report was of a technocratic nature, and concerned the institutionalisation of social dialogue through the Treaty of Lisbon. The Treaty now names the President of the Council as coordinator. Despite our clear disagreement with the Treaty of Lisbon, we believe that the tripartite social dialogue must be institutionalised. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment (TSS) was set up in 2003 and formalised the practice of holding high—level, informal meetings in the framework of the European Employment Strategy, and subsequently the Lisbon Strategy. The Commission proposed the formalisation to institutionalise the practice of high-level consultation between the EU institutions and EU social partners. The TSS has been a separate event from the European Council meetings ever since and has broadly fulfilled its aim of facilitating high—level exchange of views between the Commission, the EU Presidency and the EU social partners on employment and social aspects of the Lisbon Strategy.  Following the creation of the role of President of the European Council by the Lisbon Treaty, the decision establishing the TSS needs to be revised to transfer the role and responsibilities of the rotating Presidency of the Council to the newly created role of President of the European Council. In addition, the overall policy framework needs to be revised, replacing the Lisbon Strategy with the Europe 2020 Strategy and specifying how the TSS for Growth and Employment contributes to the overall governance.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this protocol because it revised the procedure of the summit to bring it in line with the changes introduced in the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This ‘summit’ is a talking shop for high—level EU officials, lobbyists and European NGOs to discuss employment and economic issues. It is just another waste of taxpayers’ money that will achieve nothing.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report to strengthen social dialogue between the institutions of the European Union and the European social partners for job creation and inclusive development, as well as to reduce the adverse impact of the migration and refugee crisis on labour markets.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Tripartum Social Summit for Growth and Jobs and the repeal of Decision No 100/2013. 2003/174/EC as this gives consent to the council's draft decision. It is of utmost importance to react in the right way to the consequences of the migrant and refugee crisis on the labour market and to the challenges posed by the increasing digitisation of society. It is essential to include in this type of discussion so-called social partners who can directly contribute to the European economic and social strategy, and therefore I support this Recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report analyses the 'social dialogue at the top', which is presented as essential to strengthen the legitimacy of economic governance and a strengthened 'social pillar'. However, it only involves partners who are all the more dependent on the institutions because they are an integral part of the system. The ultra-liberal line of these discussions is obvious and strongly encourages structural reforms. In addition, the Schengen area is considered untouchable, and the integration of migrants held for a chance for Europe.  Not only is the 'social dialogue' rigged, and the desire to relaunch the process at Member State level is a simple formulation of principle, but this social guarantee of the ESD serves to legitimise the governance that is required, without any consideration for national and democratic institutions, starting with national parliaments. Of course, I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This ‘summit’ is a talking shop for high—level EU officials, lobbyists and European NGOs to discuss employment and economic issues. It is just another waste of taxpayers’ money that will achieve nothing.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on a proposal that aims to revise the 2003 Council Decision to comply with the changes that were introduced by the Lisbon Treaty. It was a necessary and logical step to align the institutional framework to fit the current context.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for my colleague Csaba Sogor's report validating the regulation of the tripartite social summit for growth and jobs. It is a once-a-month summit that provides a platform for exchange between the European institutions and representatives of employers' and trade union unions. This regulation provides for the presence of the chairman of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, a welcome development. My commitment to employment leads me to welcome this initiative which promotes the european Union's action to promote its social dimension. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The legal framework for the three-year social summit for growth and jobs (TSS) ensures joint action between the European Council, Parliament, the Commission and the social partners. In particular, the participants exchanged views on three issues, such as: experience in implementing country-specific recommendations; the impact of the migration crisis and refugees on the labour market; the challenges related to digitalisation. These are issues of central importance even more than in the day, given the need, which can no longer be extended, to promote and support growth and employment throughout the EU.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision as it aims at enabling the social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of their social dialogue, to the various components of the European Union’s strategy for growth and jobs.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The long-standing problem I have repeatedly voiced is the pay gap between peripheral and central countries and colonial aspirations. The proposal is eligible because it provides at least a negotiating platform in a format adapted to the Treaty of Lisbon. At the same time, it should be noted that, although the summit system has been in place since 2003, it has so long yielded no tangible results for underpaid workers in the labour sector and, in particular, in peripheral countries. The policy framework needs to be fully reviewed, the Lisbon Strategy replaced by the Europe 2020 strategy, and how the Tripartitised Social Summit for Growth and Jobs can contribute to the overall management of the strategy.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I am hostile to the false social dialogue it endorses, which is just an illusion of concealing the EU's ultraliberalism.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)

For these various reasons, I objected to this aberrant relation.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment (TSS) which is a forum for dialogue between the Union institutions at the level of Presidents and the European social partners at the level of management bodies. It aims to promote continued exchange between the social partners and the institutions of the Union, as well as to ensure that the social partners contribute to the Union's economic and social strategy.  The last summit was on 16 March 2016 on "Intense collaboration for job creation and inclusive growth".

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a proposal to improve this European social dialogue system, especially with regard to Parliament's participation in the meetings. Parliament should be consulted in the review of the functioning of the tripartite social summit, and the condition of this consultation has been the participation of the President of the European Parliament's Employment Committee in the meetings. Once agreement has been reached with the Commission and Council on this point, it is guaranteed to participate in the summit. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to update this legal framework in keeping with the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the Council's decision to set up a new tripartite body to include trade unions and industrialists' unions. I consider this to be corporatism, that is, an attempt to replace democracy with a union government. I consider this a waste of taxpayers' money. It's just going to be another chat.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The legal framework for the Three-Way Social Summit for Growth and Employment (TSS) needs to be updated due to changes brought about by the Lisbon Treaty. Therefore, the Commission presented a new Council decision on which the new TSS should be based. In its report, Parliament called for the introduction of the practice of inviting the chair of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee (EMPL) to TSS committees.  I think the proposed practice is good. I therefore supported this recommendation of the Council decision.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament to give its consent to the draft Council decision on the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment. This formalised the practice of holding high—level, informal meetings in the framework of the European Employment Strategy, and subsequently the Lisbon Strategy. Dialogue with social partners has to be at the highest possible level.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Tripartite Social Meeting (TSS) was set up by a Council decision in March 2003. Its role is to facilitate the exchange of views between the Commission, the EU Presidency and the EU's social partners on employment and social issues. The Council decision presented reflects the institutional changes to the Treaty of Lisbon and the practical results of the work of the Tripartite Social Meeting since its inception. It defines tasks and membership, the organisation of an activity and the provision of information. I support the proposal.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained when voting on the recommendation on the draft Council Decision establishing a tripartite social summit on growth and jobs and repealing Decision 2003/174/EC, because this recommendation is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. It concerns the approval of the institution of the tripartite social summit, composed of the President of the European Council, the President of the European Commission and the President of the Council of Europe. It meets to discuss social and employment issues as part of the EU 2020 Strategy for Inclusive Growth. The composition could change: it is planned to involve the social partners recognised by the institutions, and to integrate the chairman of the employment committee. In addition, the text provides that all participatory bodies can assist in the design of the agenda. Finally, the priorities set should then be submitted for approval by the European Parliament.  This summit involves only partners who are an integral part of the system, whose independence is questionable. The text shows an ultraliberalism encouraging structural reforms. Moreover, the integration of migrants is seen as an opportunity for Europe, which I disapprove of.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union has reached impressive economic, political, and social levels but different reports suggest that there is still much more we need to accomplish in order to be an even stronger Union. For the European Union’s progress, we need to figure out the uncertainties and fill the gaps so we can move on. I voted in favour of the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment. I agree with President Juncker’s views that highlight the importance of advancing towards a fair and truly European labour market through social dialogue and the deepening of economic and monetary union.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support this Parliament's recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. It calls for agreement on the establishment of a Tripartite Social Summit, with reference to the functioning of the European Union. Through this Social Summit, the EU is attracting more powers. That is why I abstained.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the preliminary report prepared by the EP on the tripartite Social Summit on Growth and Employment. In the light of the institutional developments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and the emergence of the office of President of the European Council, it is necessary to revise the Council Decision setting up the Tripartite Social Summit.

The ultra-liberal line of these discussions is obvious and strongly encourages structural reforms. In addition, the Schengen area is considered untouchable, and the integration of migrants held for a chance for Europe.  Not only is the 'social dialogue' distorted, and the desire to relaunch the process at Member State level is a simple formulation of principle, but this social guarantee of the ESD serves to legitimise the lack of consideration for national and democratic institutions, starting with national parliaments. Having to refuse the institutionalization of a new undemocratic structure, I objected to this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The tripartite Summit for Growth and Jobs is to ensure, in accordance with the Treaty and while respecting the competences of the Institutions and bodies of the Union, the existence of permanent consultation between the Council, the Commission and the social partners. It will enable the social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of social dialogue, to the different components of the EU's growth and employment strategy.  To this end, it relies on the work and discussions between the Council, the Commission and the social partners, which take place upstream in the various conciliation bodies on economic, social and employment issues. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this legislative resolution as it will institutionalise the practice of high-level consultation between the EU institutions and the EU social partners related to jobs and growth in the European Union.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Social Europe exists. Nevertheless, the Union's competence in this area is limited by treaties which do not give it the right to legislate on wages, the right to strike, social security, or to intervene in general contractual relations between employees and employers. Holding such a summit is a way for European leaders to take into account the aspirations of social partners and for social partners to contribute to the EU's economic and social strategy.  It is obvious that a growth strategy only makes sense if it is accompanied by a social strategy. With this in mind, I certainly support the establishment of tripartite social summits for growth and employment, elements of the inter-professional dialogue, the initiative of which helps to move towards the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: In writing , the Summit Tripartite Social Meeting for Growth and Jobs (TSS) was formally set up by the Council Decision of 6 March 2003. It aims to exchange views at the highest level on employment and social affairs aspects of the Lisbon Strategy and later on the 2020 strategy. Until the Treaty of Lisbon entered into force, the meetings were co-chaired by the Presidency of the Council and the President of the Commission. The Treaty of Lisbon has brought about a number of institutional changes, which require a revision of the 2003 Decision. Institutionalise the European Council and create the post of President of the European Council; recognised the role of the tripartite social meeting dialogue as part of the EU social dialogue and repealed Article 202 of the EC Treaty, which constituted the legal basis for the adoption of the 2003 Decision. The revision now provides that TSS meetings are attended by the President of the European Council, the Presidency of the Council and two successive Presidencies, the Commission and the social partners, ministers from the three Presidencies and the Commissioner responsible for employment and social affairs. It establishes the regularity of the twice-yearly meeting, always before the Spring and Autumn European Councils.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment since it is essential that the European Parliament, represented by the Chair of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, is invited to the summit on a regular basis.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Tripartit social summit on Growth and Jobs was established by Council Decision 2003/174/EC of 6 March 2003. The Council, on a proposal from the Commission, adopted a draft decision repealing that Decision and new legislation on the Triparti veparti board for Growth and Jobs. In adopting the draft, the Council must obtain Parliament's consent. In its report, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs recommends that Parliament agree with the Council's draft decision. I voted accordingly.

The ultra-liberal line of these discussions is obvious and strongly encourages structural reforms. In addition, the Schengen area is considered untouchable, and the integration of migrants held for a chance for Europe.  Not only is the 'social dialogue' rigged, and the desire to relaunch the process at Member State level is a simple formulation of principle, but this social guarantee of the ESD serves to legitimise the governance that is required, without any consideration for national and democratic institutions, starting with national parliaments. Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Jobs was set up following the Lisbon European Council in March 2000 with the aim of promoting high-level consultation with the European social partners. Since it was established under Council Decision 2003/174/EC, the Summit has fulfilled its key role of ensuring high-level consultation. It has contributed positively to the development of social dialogue at Union level, within the framework of the Lisbon Strategy, over the period 2000-2010, as well as within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy.  The tasks and composition of the Summit should be adapted to take account of the institutional changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the creation of the role of President of the European Council, as provided for in Article 15 OF the ETU.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This social dialogue at the summit is presented as essential to strengthen the legitimacy of economic governance with a strengthened "social pillar". However, it only involves partners who are all the more dependent on the institutions because they are an integral part of the system. The ultra-liberal line of these discussions is obvious and strongly encourages structural reforms. In addition, the Schengen area is considered untouchable, and the integration of migrants held for a chance for Europe.  Not only is the 'social dialogue' rigged, and the desire to relaunch the process at Member State level is a simple formulation of principle, but this social guarantee of the ESD serves to legitimise the governance that is required, without any consideration for national and democratic institutions, starting with national parliaments. So I'm voting against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision as it aims at enabling the social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of their social dialogue, to the various components of the European Union’s strategy for growth and jobs.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation. The revision of the Decision is necessary because previous strategies are being replaced by the European 2020 strategy and previous legislation must also be adapted to the implementation of the new strategies.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this recommendation regarding the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment that amongst other matters, considers the impact of the migration and refugee crisis on the labour market and the digitalisation challenges faced by the labour market.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 3 of the Treaty provides that one of the objectives of the European Union is to develop a highly competitive social market economy that aims at full employment and social progress. In defining and implementing its policies and actions, the Union must take into account their social dimension, namely the requirements for promoting a high level of employment, ensuring adequate social protection, combating social exclusion, and requirements for a high level of education, training and protection of human health. The Union has established a tripartite social summit for development and employment, recognised as an integral part of social dialogue at EU level. It will enable the social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of their social dialogue, to the various components of the Union's strategy for growth and jobs.  The Summit shall consist of the highest-level representatives of the President of the European Council, the Presidency of the Council and the two successive Presidencies, the Commission and the social partners. The Summit shall meet at least twice a year before the European Council's spring and autumn sessions respectively.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The Tripartite Social Summit (TSS) for Growth and Employment was a meeting with the Council Presidency, the Commission and the social partners (10 trade unionists and 10 business). It took place at least once a year before the spring European Council. The whole idea was to have an exchange of views on employment, social policy, health and consumer affairs before the Council meeting. Parliament was not mentioned but the Chair of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) was always invited to the Summit. This vote was to give consent to the Council recommendation and re-ratify the decision. Parliament has adopted a report calling for the EMPL Chair to be formally invited. This report was adopted after the Council decision and is not reflected in that draft decision. The EMPL Committee and the Chair were not happy about the decision and only supported the draft decision once a letter from the Presidency of the Council and the President of the Commission outlined that the EMPL Chair would be invited to all TSSs. After that was done the Committee gave consent. My GUE/NGL colleague Thomas Handel, Chair of the EMPL Committee, supported the decision. I voted in favour.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. If I had been able to vote on the tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Jobs, I would have abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Due to the institutional changes in the changes resulting from the Treaty of Lisbon, it is also important to review the practice of high-level consultations between the EU institutions and the EU social partners. The summit will take place twice a year, as it is already de facto. The summit will provide an opportunity for the social partners to contribute to the different parts of the Union's strategy for growth and jobs.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This ‘summit’ is a talking shop for high—level EU officials, lobbyists and European NGOs to discuss employment and economic issues. It is just another waste of taxpayers’ money that will achieve nothing.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I support the proposal for a Council Decision on the Tripartum Social Summit for Growth and Jobs. I consider that the set task of the Summit is positive and that its objectives including the adoption of growth strategies, high levels of employment, social integration and protection and the creation of conditions for quality education, training and protection of human health can only be achieved through the professional coordination and joint work of the Council, the Commission and the social partners, in accordance with the Treaty and taking into account the powers of the Union institutions and bodies.  The exchange of knowledge and experience between the Council, the Commission and the social partners and their coordination in economic and social matters is a prerequisite and basis for working towards their common objectives enabling social partners to contribute at European level, in the context of their social dialogues, to various components of the Union's growth and job creation strategy.  I also consider the proposed structure of the organization, representation and schedule and rhythm of the Summit to be correct, as the set goals can only be achieved through regular session and equal discussion of authorized representatives of both parties (workers and employers) of all delegates.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This social dialogue at the summit is presented as essential to strengthen the legitimacy of economic governance with a strengthened "social pillar". However, it only involves partners who are all the more dependent on the institutions because they are an integral part of the system. The ultra-liberal line of these discussions is obvious and strongly encourages structural reforms. In addition, the Schengen area is considered untouchable, and the integration of migrants held for a chance for Europe.  Not only is the 'social dialogue' rigged, and the desire to relaunch the process at Member State level is a simple formulation of principle, but this social guarantee of the ESD serves to legitimise the governance that is required, without any consideration for national and democratic institutions, starting with national parliaments. I am, of course, voting against this text.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The purpose of the Tripartum Social Summit for Growth and Employment is to ensure, in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and taking into account the powers of the Union institutions and bodies, the coherence of the Commission, the Council and the social partners. It enables social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of social dialogue, to the creation of a Union strategy for growth and job creation.  I supported MPs' recommendation aimed at revising the Council decisions of 2003 to ensure compliance with the changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty. In addition, it is necessary to revise the overall framework of the organisation and align its work with the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Commission presented its proposal on an updated plan for the organisation of the Tripartite Social Summit (TSS) on 31 October 2013. However, the Council decided on this proposal separately, notwithstanding the opinion adopted by the European Parliament's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. I strongly support Parliament's position, which calls for an adaptation of the report on the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Jobs in the area concerning the President of the EMPL, who should be invited to the TSS at regular intervals. The Council should therefore take into account this proposal by the European Parliament, as its adoption is subject to the agreement of the entire Legislative Proposal of the Commission by the European Parliament.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with my group in supporting and voting in favour of the text presented.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The trilateral social summit for growth and employment ensures continuous consultation between the European Council, the Council, the Commission and the social partners. The summit enables the European social partners to contribute, within the framework of the social dialogue, to the various aspects of the Union's strategy for growth and employment. The social dialogue is a pillar of that social market economy which we, as the PPE, want to help achieve in Europe. I voted in favour of approving the draft Council decision.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Tripartite Social Summit is a meeting of representatives of the European social partners, the European Commission and the Council. It takes place on the eve of the European Council in the autumn and spring to discuss employment-related and social aspects of the European Agenda for Growth and Jobs.  In 2013, The Commission has submitted a proposal to update this instrument to take account of changes in the EU legal and institutional framework over the last ten years (Article 15 OF THE EU HERE AND ARTICLE 152 TFEU). In April 2014, Parliament adopted a resolution requesting a more regular invite of the Chair of the Committee on Employment to participate in each tripartite social summit.  The next summit will take place in October 2016. In accordance with Article 99, the committee responsible has six months from that date to issue a recommendation. In this resolution, Parliament approves the original 2014 proposal. There is general agreement among all institutions that the Chair of the Committee on Employment should be invited to attend the trilogue meetings of the Social Summit. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment is a forum created in 2003 that brings together the European institutions as well as European social partners (trade union and employer representatives). I voted in favour of this technical procedure which validates the new regulation of this summit, as part of the application of the Lisbon Treaty. For example, the new regulation provides for the European Parliament to be systematically represented in this forum with the presence of the Chairman of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative, consent procedure (single vote) report. This ‘summit’ is a talking shop for high—level EU officials, lobbyists and European NGOs to discuss employment and economic issues. It is just another waste of taxpayers’ money that will achieve nothing.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft decision on the revision of the 2003 Council decision in the framework of the Tripartite Social Summit. The main changes concern roles and members. As regards the tasks, it will have to ensure, in accordance with the Treaty and with due respect for the competences of the Union institutions and bodies, that there is concertation between the Council, the Commission and the social partners, and will have to enable the social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of social dialogue, to the various components of the Union's strategy for growth and jobs. As regards members, the main amendments concern the inclusion at the Summit. It will be composed of the President of the European Council, the Presidency of the Council, the following two presidencies, the Commission and the social partners.  In view of the above and the other amendments proposed for the Summit, I voted in favour of this Recommendation.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of a Recommendation on the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment.  This is a forum for dialogue between the Union institutions and the European social partners, which seeks to promote continued exchange and ensure that the social partners contribute to the Union's economic and social strategy. The previous 2003 decision was to be amended by a Council decision with the consent of the European Parliament. In 2014 Parliament approved only one interim report. Finally, the situation could be unblocked and that decision repealed.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's decision to revise the 2003 decision to institutionalize a tripartite social summit for growth and jobs. This revision was necessary, in particular, in order to comply with the institutional changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty. The missions of this tripartite social summit remain broadly the same. The tripartite social summit will now be composed of the President of the European Council, representatives at the highest level of the Council's current Presidency, the next two presidencies, the Commission and the social partners. I would like to take this opportunity to remind you that it is essential that this tripartite social summit be followed by action. Like the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude JUNCKER, I am convinced that a strong European social dialogue will benefit the future of Europe.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the Council's request for approval (as well as its provisional resolution of 15 April 2014) on the proposal for a Council decision on the holding of a Tripartite Social Summit (CST) for Growth and Jobs, I voted in favour of this draft decision. The now adopted proposal aims to revise the 2003 Council decision in order to comply with the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon – in particular in interinstitutional terms and the functioning of the Union itself – and the overall policy framework should also be revised, replacing the Lisbon Strategy with the Europe 2020 strategy and specifying how cst for growth and jobs contributes to global governance. After being adopted at first reading, Parliament proposed some amendments, in particular on the involvement of the social partners. Subsequently, the European Parliament's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs adopted the report on the draft Council decision on the CST, recommending that the European Parliament, in plenary, also give its consent, which today was done by a large majority and with the favourable vote of my political group.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which represents the Approval of the European Parliament in the Council's draft decision. The original proposal aims to adapt the 2003 Council decision to comply with the institutional changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty. The text also aims to revise the overall strategic framework, replacing the Lisbon Strategy with the Europe 2020 strategy and also specifying how the tripartite social summit for growth and jobs should contribute to global governance.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this recommendation on the TSS, because it implies the completion of a long process in which while the Council's relationship with Parliament has not been as efficient and sincere as it should be, the result is positive, both for the Dialogue of the Commission and the Council with social partners and for the position of the European Parliament in the TSS. However, it should be noted that the Council has acted during this procedure, without respecting Parliament's deadlines.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a proposal to improve this European social dialogue system, especially with regard to Parliament's participation in the meetings. Parliament should be consulted in the review of the functioning of the tripartite social summit, and the condition of this consultation has been the participation of the President of the European Parliament's Employment Committee in the meetings. Once agreement has been reached with the Commission and Council on this point, it is guaranteed to participate in the summit. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision, as it aims to enable the social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of their social dialogue, to the various components of the Union’s strategy for growth and jobs.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing – In line with the position of the EKR, I welcome the fact that the possibility of expressing representatives of the European Parliament at this tripartite summit is increasing. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting the resolution tabled.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Council Decision of March 2003 established the so-called 'Green Paper'. Tripartite Social Summit, which aims to act as a forum for discussion between the EU institutions and representatives of employees and employers, that is, the social partners. At the same time, the summit is part of a dialogue across different sectors of industry, thus providing the social partners with the space to contribute regularly to the development of the EU's economic and social strategy. The summit is always held once a year before the European Council and is attended by the European institutions, represented by the Council and Commission presidency triathlons, and the social partners, represented by 10 employees' representatives and 10 employers' representatives. The adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon requires an update of the operation of this summit. As there was finally agreement with the Council that the President of the EP Committee on Employment and Social Affairs would also be able to attend the tripartite summit, I agreed with the report that was tabled. In fact, I believe that the European Parliament, as co-legislator, is an essential article in the process of this dialogue with the social partners. This, too, is the way to put more pressure on the creation of more socially balanced EU policies.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ EU—level social dialogue plays an essential role in the smooth functioning of our social market economy; it has benefits for employers and workers alike, as well as for the economy and society as a whole. This is why I am grateful that this House adopted my report on the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment. In the current process of strengthening economic governance – if we want to ensure real ownership of policies and to ensure effective implementation of our decisions – it is critical to involve the social partners in policy debates and decision-making processes. Beside the macroeconomic dialogue, the tripartite social summit is one of the key opportunities for improving the involvement of the social partners in the coordination of economic and employment policies at EU level. This is why it is of utmost importance that the social partners have the possibility to negotiate with EU leaders at the highest levels within a stable consultation framework. This is an essential condition to ensure a coherent, fair and efficient decision—making process.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The legal framework of the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment, established by the EU Council decision in March 2006, had to be updated as a result of the changes that have taken place with the Treaty of Lisbon. Parliament's interim report on this subject called for the institutionalisation of the practice to be taken to the Tripartite Social Summit by the Chair of the Parliamentary Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Parliament considers that the Chair of this committee should also have a legal basis for regular invitations to the Tripartite Social Summit and access to information and materials. The President of the European Commission and the President of the Council of the EU have thus addressed a letter to Parliament about a month ago expressing their agreement to the continued visit of the Chair of that committee at the summit, while hoping for a swift agreement on this by Parliament. I also supported this decision and the continued involvement of the Chair of the Parliamentary Committee in this matter, as it is good that Parliament is also aware of the work of the Tripartite Social Summit.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing \u2012 Tripartite negotiations have an important role in the construction of work and wage relations. However, as always, I am advocating the principle of subsidiarity in this case, namely that agreements should be established in a direct dialogue between employees' representatives and the employer. Any representation of a higher level necessarily entails distortions and approximations, the implementation of which in specific cases may be rather counterproductive.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I agree with the draft Council decision on the basis that, following the institutional change introduced by the Lisbon Treaty establishing the function of President of the European Council, the Council Decision of 2003 establishing the Tripartum Social Summit should be revised. Since 2003, the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment has been a separate event from european council meetings, which has largely met its objective of facilitating the change of opinion at the highest level between the Commission, the EU Presidency and the EU's social partners on employment and social aspects of the Lisbon Strategy.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the EU Parliament resolution on the draft Council decision on a tripartite social summit for growth and jobs and the repeal of Decision 2003/174/EC. This is an institutional adjustment to the EU's organisational order, as a result of the Treaty of Lisbon. The task of the Tripartite Summit for Growth and Jobs is to ensure continuous consultation between the Council, the Commission and the social partners, in accordance with the Treaty and with due regard to the competences of the Union institutions and bodies. The Summit will allow the social partners at European level to contribute to the various components of the Union's strategy for growth and employment through the social dialogue. It is based on the work and discussions that are taking place in advance between the Council, the Commission and the social partners in the various conciliation bodies on economic, social and employment issues. The EU should have no role in these issues. In any case, it is not at all a political task to "concert" state/political and private/civil society organisations. In a liberal state order, these levels remain separate. I am concerned about the overwhelming support for such projects.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Since 2003, the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment has been a separate event since the European Council meetings, which largely met its objective of facilitating the change of opinion at the highest level between the Commission, the EU Presidency and the EU's social partners on employment and social aspects of the European Union. Following the changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty, the Council Decision 2003 establishing the Tripartum Social Summit was to be revised. The European Parliament gives its consent in a specific legislative procedure for the Council's draft decision on the Tripartum Social Summit for Growth and Employment and for the repeal of Decision No 1009/2013. 2003/174/EC.  I support the recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the Tripartum Social Summit for Growth and Jobs and the repeal of Decision No 1009/2013. 2003/174/EC to make the decision as precise as possible and I support giving consent to the council's draft decision.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment and repealing Decision 2003/174/EC.  The Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment was established in 2003 by Decision 2003/174/EC, formalising the practice of informal high-level meetings. Thanks to the Treaty of Lisbon, which institutionalised the European Council and recognised the role of the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment as part of the EU's social dialogue.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report was of a technocratic nature, and concerned the institutionalisation of social dialogue through the Treaty of Lisbon. The Treaty now names the President of the Council as coordinator. Despite our clear disagreement with the Treaty of Lisbon, we believe that the tripartite social dialogue must be institutionalised. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The tripartite social summit on growth and employment does not substantially promote the interests of workers. It is also based on the Treaty of Lisbon, with which we are opposed.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Tripartit social summit on Growth and Jobs was established by Council Decision 2003/174/EC of 6 March 2003. This is to institutionalise the practice of high-level consultations between the EU institutions and the EU social partners. The Summit was predominantly tasked with helping to facilitate the exchange of views at the highest level between the Commission, the EU Presidency and the EU social partners on the employment and social aspects of the Lisbon Strategy (until 2010 and the Europe 2020 strategy thereafter). The Treaty of Lisbon has undergone significant institutional changes and a revision of the decision has therefore been justified. The review has been ongoing since 2013, in this case the European Parliament gave the Green Light to the European Council in the form of an approval. The changes will make the Summit more efficient and will now allow the Chairman of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs to participate as a permanent invitee. In this way, we strengthen representative democracy, which is why I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Growth and employment are two closely related and interdependent concepts. Aware of this, the European institutions have initiated consultations with the social partners in the trilateral format 'employers – trade unions – institutions', in order to boost the ECONOMIC development of the EU. Within this format, the representation of the European Union was assumed by the Commission and the Council as decision-making forums. However, in the context of the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon, the role of the European Parliament, as the main forum for the representation of European citizens, must be respected. The Council's position was adopted, but before Parliament expressed its position, which does not exactly reflect the normal procedure. That is why the compromise decision was reached for the Chair of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) to participate in these consultations. It is a salutary formula, which is likely to recognise, even in part, the importance of the European Parliament's participation in this dialogue. I think it is a step forward, which can contribute to the success of the much-needed tripartite social summit in the current European context.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the Council's draft decision on a tripartite social summit for growth and employment and repealing the 2003/174/EC decision, according to the experts on the matter.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Tripartite Social Summit (TSS) for Growth and Employment, which is a forum for dialogue between the EU institutions at president level and the European social partners at top management level. The report seeks to revise the TSS so it complies with the institutional changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty, particularly by replacing the Lisbon Strategy with the Europe 2020 Strategy. This revision is an opportunity to push for a coherent process of consultation of the social partners, whose contribution in terms of expertise is very valuable, to render the Summit more representative of the European institutions but also of European cross-industry organisations, namely SMEs, but also to ensure that the agenda for the Summit is determined jointly and on equal partnership by all partners.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The task of the Tripartum Social Summit for Growth and Jobs is to ensure uninterrupted alignment between the Council, the Commission and the social partners, as well as the coordination of their strategies for high-quality and sustainable employment. It will enable social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of their social dialogue and their expertise, to various components of the Union's growth and job creation strategy. This is crucial for all Member States, especially those for whom unemployment is one of the most pressing problems in the country. Therefore, I supported this resolution.  In April 2014, the European Parliament adopted this resolution, which included a request for the Chair of the Employment Committee to be invited to the Tripartum Social Summit for Growth and Employment. The next summit will take place in October this year. This resolution supports the European Parliament's position in 2014, and the general agreement of all institutions is to invite the Chair of the Employment Committee to the next Summit.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Employment, as it is designed to ensure a continuous exchange between the EU's social partners and institutions and to ensure that the social partners contribute to the EU's economic and social strategy. It will enable the social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of social dialogue, to the various elements of an integrated economic and social strategy, including aspects of sustainable development.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this recommendation on the TSS, because it implies the completion of a long process in which while the Council's relationship with Parliament has not been as efficient and sincere as it should be, the result is positive, both for the Dialogue of the Commission and the Council with social partners and for the position of the European Parliament in the TSS. However, it should be noted that the Council has acted during this procedure, without respecting Parliament's deadlines.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The Tripartite Summit is a meeting of representatives of the social partners with the European Commission and the Council. The resolution provides for updating the rules of the Summit through legal and institutional exchanges between the EU. I am in favour of the proposal.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Tripartite Social Summit on Growth and Jobs was established by Council Decision 2003/174/EC of 6 March 2003, which formaled the practice of high-level informal meetings held since 1997, first under the European Employment Strategy and then in the Framework of the Lisbon Strategy. I supported this proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I am voting in favour of this recommendation on the TSS, because it implies the completion of a lengthy process in which while the Council's relationship with Parliament has not been as efficient and sincere as it should be, the result is positive, both for the Commission and the Council's dialogue with social partners, and for the European Parliament's position on the TSS. However, it should be noted that the Council has acted during this procedure, without respecting Parliament's deadlines.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for, as the Chair of Parliament’s Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) should have the right to participate fully at the Tripartite Social Summit.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This social dialogue at the summit is presented as essential to strengthen the legitimacy of economic governance with a strengthened "social pillar". However, it only involves partners who are all the more dependent on the institutions because they are an integral part of the system. The ultra-liberal line of these discussions is obvious and strongly encourages structural reforms. In addition, the Schengen area is considered untouchable, and the integration of migrants held for a chance for Europe.  Not only is the 'social dialogue' rigged, and the desire to relaunch the process at Member State level is a simple formulation of principle, but this social bond serves to legitimise the governance that is required, without any consideration for national and democratic institutions, starting with national parliaments. I voted against it.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The Tripartite Social Summit (CST) for Growth and Employment was established in 2003 with the aim of institutionalizing the practice of holding high-level consultations between the different Community institutions and the Union's social partners. In 2013, the Commission presented a proposal to adjust the organisation of this summit to the new situation of the Union, strengthening it as an indispensable part of social dialogue. The CST has broadly fulfilled its task, which is to facilitate the exchange of views at the highest level between the various actors on employment and the social aspects envisaged in the Europe 2020 Strategy. Considering the european social dialogue to be essential, I voted in a favourable direction.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I approved the report on the tripartiete social summit for growth and employment.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The participation of workers in all the decisions that affect them, in a sense of defense of their class interests, deserves our support. The Tripartite Social Summit, together with the presidency of the European Council, the Council of the European Union, the Commission, 10 employers' representatives and 10 workers' representatives, has also received our positive attention. As a consequence of the Treaty of Lisbon, the composition of the Summit has been amended. If there is no change in the level of representation between employers and workers, we agree with the recommendation presented.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. It calls for agreement on the establishment of a tripartite social summit, with reference to the functioning of the European Union. It consists of the European social partners, the European Commission and the Trio Presidency. However, as the EU has more competences to take on through this Social Summit, I abstained.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the trilateral social summit for growth and jobs. In particular, the report establishes the Trilateral Social Summit, a forum for discussion between the institutions of the European Union (EU) and representatives of employers and employees. The summit is part of the interprofessional dialogue and aims to provide continuous exchange between the social partners and the EU institutions and to ensure that the social partners contribute to the European Union's economic and social strategy

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision as it aims at enabling the social partners at European level to contribute, in the context of their social dialogue, to the various components of the European Union’s strategy for growth and jobs.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Tripartite Social Summit is a meeting of representatives of the European social partners, the European Commission and the EU Presidency, whose function is to enable the exchange of views on employment and social aspects of the Lisbon Strategy. The report regulates inviting the Chair of the Committee on Employment to attend the trilogue meetings, taking into account the need to share proposals and increasing the ability of larger groups to address and address social problems.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The Tripartite Social Summit (CST) for Growth and Employment was established in 2003 by Council Decision. The Commission proposed the 2003 Decision to institutionalise the practice of holding high-level consultations between the EU institutions and the EU's social partners. The Tripartite Social Summit, composed of the Trio of Presidencies, the social partners and the European Commission, meets before the spring and autumn summits of Heads of State and Government and sets its position for these summits. My vote on this report is in favour, as I consider good European social dialogue essential in order to promote the European Semester process, now complemented by the European social dimension.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this recommendation on the Tripartite Meeting for Growth and Jobs. I think it is right that a grouping composed of representatives of the Commission, the European Council and delegations of the social partners has the opportunity to discuss together the problems of European social policy. However, I think that it is effective and desirable for the President of the European Parliament's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs to participate in the negotiations – this is also addressed by the recommendation tabled, which also seeks to comply with the institutional changes brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Sogor report because I agree with the need for the European Parliament to be invited to participate regularly in the Tripartite Social Summit for Growth and Jobs, alongside the European Commission and the Council. The European Parliament's participation in this summit is crucial in that it is part of the inter-trade dialogue and has the task of providing continuous exchange between the social partners and the EU institutions and ensuring that the social partners contribute to the EU's economic and social strategy, areas to which Parliament has contributed constructively in its capacity as co-legislator.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a tripartite social summit for growth and employment.  I believe that a constant exchange between the EU's social partners and institutions is essential for the development of a successful EU economic and social strategy in terms of sustainable development.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The overall objective of the Directive is to provide a coherent and uniform framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels, with the emphasis on rationalising the use of resources for the development of technical standards and adapting them to scientific and technical progress through the use of standards prepared by international organisations. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP have decided to abstain on this second reading because the UK has an exception.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this subject. While the report aims to improve and homogenize the level of safety and regulation of safety and environmental requirements for vessels sailing in European waters, very similar regulations already exist in France.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a uniform application of common technical requirements for inland navigation vessels in the European Union. This is, in my view, fundamental in order to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency of inland navigation within the European area.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendations on the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the technical requirements for inland waterway vessels. At first reading, Parliament supported a uniform application of common technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union in view of ensuring a high—level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation through CESNI (the European Committee for drawing up of common standards in the field of inland navigation). Parliament and the Council agreed on the overall aim of the Directive but diverged on how to adapt the annexes to the technical standards.  After the trilogue negotiations, a compromise solution was reached on 17 March 2016. In April, Parliament’s Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) approved the compromise solution. Following the Committee’s approval, the Chair of the TRAN Committee, in his letter to the Committee of Permanent Representatives, indicated that he would recommend to the Plenary that it approve the Council’s position at first reading without amendments. I welcome the decision of the Council to adopt its first reading position confirming the agreement of 17 March 2016.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to improve and homogenize the level of safety and regulation of safety and environmental requirements for vessels sailing on European waterways. This technical report is not revolutionary or scandalous and does not affect France, where many similar regulations are already applied for the subject areas. But opposed to the principle, on the problematic basis, aimed at standardising regulation at European level, I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This was approved without a vote. However, I wish to place on record that I have concerns that there is no need for this matter to be subject to legislation across 28 different countries. The UK should be quite capable of taking these decisions for itself.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the technical requirements for Inland Waterway vessels. In order to ensure consistency with other EU legislation, in particular Directive 2014/94/EU on the deployment of alternative fuels infrastructure, Parliament called for delegated acts to lay down technical requirements for liquefied natural gas-powered vessels.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided to abstain on this second reading because the UK has an exception.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report, which aims to homogenize safety and environmental regulations for boats sailing on European waterways: this is only a technical report which is not revolutionary or scandalous and does not affect France, where many regulations are already applied compatible with those required by this report. However, the very principle of uniformity of regulation across the Union remains problematic.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text to provide for a harmonised and coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland shipping vessels, because I believe it is necessary to ensure a high level of safety for workers in the shipping industry and, more broadly, the efficiency of inland navigation. In particular, MEPs voted in favour of rapidly adapting standards to scientific and technical progress, taking into account the standards developed by international organisations. They therefore called for a periodic review of the directive after three years in order to assess the mechanisms for cooperation with the relevant international organisations, which appears to be the most responsible decision.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Belet report approving the Council's position at first reading on requirements for inland waterway vessels. This is a technical measure which pushes for the uniform application of technical requirements, with a view to ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in inland waterway transport, taking into account the standards laid down by international organisations such as the European Committee for the Development of Standards for Inland Navigation (CESNI). The text also calls for a regular review of the directive every three years, with the aim of assessing the mechanisms for cooperation with the international organisations involved.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the previous phase of commissions, we voted in favour of this technical regulation on inland water navigation. The aim is to establish a harmonised technical framework to ensure the same level of safety for all vessels operating in the Union and to facilitate their adaptation to scientific and technical progress taking into account the guidelines of CESNI (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards) and other international bodies. Following the ordinary legislative process of the Union, the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading was declared approved without a vote.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. We agree with the adoption of common technical standards for inland boating vessels. They offer more and better guarantees to users by raising the safety standard and technical conditions that these vessels must meet, including also the environmental aspect. We also congratulate Parliament's negotiators for defending the prerogatives of the chamber in this area throughout the process and for defending the Council's exclusive decision-making power in this area.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation on technical requirements for inland shipping vessels aims to improve and homogenize the level of safety and regulation of safety and environmental requirements for vessels operating on European waterways.  This report, which is essentially technical, has little to do with France with often similar regulations already applied to it, but nevertheless the recommendation aims to standardise European regulations in this area. As a result, I have decided to abstain.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While it is a partly shareable text, there are still unclear passages that could open up critical issues. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
