text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive which aims to harmonise technical standards for vessels sailing in inland waterways.  Parliament and Council agreed on the overall objective of the Directive, which is to establish a harmonised and coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland watering vessels. The two institutions supported streamlining the use of resources to develop technical standards and adapt them to scientific and technical progress through the use of standards developed by international organizations such as CESNI. Basically, the rule seeks to order the technical requirements established by the Commission for The Navigation of the Rhine, the main inland waterway in Europe, with the requirements for other waterways.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it approved an agreement with the Council on a future directive laying down technical requirements for inland waterway vessels. The overall objective of the Directive is to establish a coherent and coherent framework to ensure a uniform level of safety for inland waterway vessels. The use of resources must also be streamlined in order to develop technical standards and adapt them to scientific and technical progress through standards developed by international organisations, in particular CESNI.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report outlines provisions that already exist in state regulations. As such, I have no complaints on the merits. On the other hand, it is a question of standardising all regulations at European level, which for me is nonsense. So I abstained.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 At first reading, Parliament advocated the need for uniform application of common technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union in order to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency in inland waterway transport.  We in this House have also spoken in favour of rapidly adapting the rules to scientific and technical progress, taking into account the rules laid down by international organisations, in particular the European Committee for the Development of Standards for Inland Navigation (CESNI), to be set up under the aegis of the Central Commission for Navigation on the Rhine. In addition, Parliament has requested a regular review of the directive every three years in order to assess the mechanisms for cooperation with the international organisations involved.  Today, confirming our demands, we are requesting that the proposal be approved in a manner consistent with the negotiating agreement reached between Parliament and the Council on 17 March 2016 as approved by the TRAN Committee on 7 April last.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because I consider the uniform application of common technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union to be of great importance. My choice was therefore dictated by the desire to guarantee a high level of safety and efficiency to inland waterway transport. The aim of the directive is to provide a coherent and uniform framework in order to ensure a common safety standard for inland waterway vessels. Of undoubted importance is the rationalization of the use of resources for the development of technical standards and the adaptation to the considerable scientific and technical progress made, also in relation to the standards prepared by the various international organizations.  In this respect, the European Committee for the Development of Standards for Inland Navigation (CESNI) plays an important role. CESNI is an international body which, however, includes only the Member States and Switzerland. It is therefore essential to achieve the adaptation of technical standards by adopting delegated acts.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided to abstain on this second reading because the UK has an exception.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree that there should be progress towards a single uniform set of technical standards through CESNI (the European Committee for drawing up common standards in the field of inland navigation). This would provide legal certainty and timely adaptations to technical progress, thus ensuring high safety standards on all EU waterways, innovation and that safety in the sector is not hampered. I believe that the Commission should be delegated the power for updating the reference to the most recent version of the CESNI standard and setting the date of application and adopt legal acts accordingly.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The cooperation mechanism with the European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards (CESNI) should be reviewed within five years. That is why I voted in favour of Mr Belet's report.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the directive laying down technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union, at first reading we supported a uniform application of common technical requirements, with a view to harmonising and ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in inland waterway transport.  We have also come out in favour of rationalising the use of resources for the development of technical standards and adapting them to scientific and technical progress, using standards already drawn up by international organisations, such as CESNI. We have also called for a regular review of the directive every three years in order to assess the mechanisms for cooperation with the international organisations involved. With today's vote, the European Parliament is reaffirming its institutional prerogatives with regard to the adaptation of technical standards in the inland waterway sector.  I therefore voted in favour, because I believe that it is in the interests of the citizens of the European Union that no new technical standards should be introduced without going through the European Parliament.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and support the uniform application of the common technical specifications for inland waterway vessels in the European Union, with a view to ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the recommendation for the adoption of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the adoption of technical specifications for inland waterway vessels is an attempt to improve and correct the rules relating to the maritime sector and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mr Belet's recommendation for second reading on technical requirements for inland waterway vessels. I believe that the adoption of the directive is a positive development in the shipping sector and represents a step forward in the integration of the technical standards required by the European Union. Indeed, the issue of navigation certificates on the basis of compliance with the technical requirements laid down in Article 22 of the directive will ensure a new level of safety and efficiency, as well as the achievement of a uniform set of technical requirements within the EU States, thanks to the work carried out by CESNI.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote on technical requirements for inland waterway vessels and noted no objections.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided to abstain on this second reading because the UK has an exemption.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on technical requirements for inland waterway vessels as I am in favour of a uniform application of maritime technical requirements within the European Union to ensure an ever higher level of safety and efficiency.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – I support a uniform application of common technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union in view of ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation. The report is also in favour of a swift adaptation of standards to scientific and technical progress, taking into account standards developed by international organisations, which I support.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a good compromise in the field of inland navigation, aimed at improving the technical requirements for this type of transport. This improvement will result in the safety of both workers and end-users of such forms of transport in the Union. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – The purpose of the revision of Directive 2006/87/EC is to standardise technical standards for inland waterway transport, taking into account the requirements of the European Commission for the Development of Inland Waterway Standards (CESNI). CESNI was set up to help standardise standards for the European inland waterway sector. Thanks to the edification, inland waterway transport would be characterised by an adequate degree of safety and efficiency, taking into account scientific and technical developments in the sector. The review will result in a higher degree of legal certainty and timely adjustments to technical progress and will contribute to compliance with stringent safety standards across the Union, without limiting innovation and safety. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the directive on the technical requirements applicable to inland waterway vessels. I believe that it is important both to adopt technical standards in a timely manner and to provide a harmonised and coherent framework for the EU legal system and the rules of the Central Commission for the Navigation of the River (CCD). I believe that taking all measures to improve the functioning of the sector is a very good initiative, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the technical requirements for vessels should be applied and regularly updated for all EU Member States. This would significantly contribute to more efficient, dynamic and safe transport on inland waterways throughout the EU and would also facilitate the introduction and use of new innovative technologies, including in respect of technical standards in the inland waterway sector. For this reason I voted in favour of the report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to develop a set of common and uniform technical standards developed by the European Committee on the Development of Standards in the Field of Indoor Navigation (CESNI). Supporting the objectives of this exercise of harmonization and updating the rules, necessary for the performance and reliability of sailing boats in Europe, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided to abstain on this second reading because the UK has an exception.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the revision of Directive 2006/87/EC is to standardise technical standards for inland waterway transport, taking into account the requirements of the European Commission for the Development of Inland Waterway Standards (CESNI). CESNI was set up to help standardise standards for the European inland waterway sector. Against this background, inland waterway transport would be characterised by an adequate degree of safety and efficiency, taking into account scientific and technical developments in the sector. The move would therefore lead to a higher degree of legal certainty and allow for appropriate adjustments in a timely manner to technical progress, as well as contribute to compliance with stringent safety standards throughout the Union, without hindering innovation and safety. In view of the importance of the safety and efficiency of inland waterway transport and the essential elements of professional and technical development such as competitiveness and modern inland waterway transport, I agree with the review efforts and therefore, as a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this recommendation because it provides a coherent and uniform framework to rationalise the use of resources and ensure a high level of safety for inland waterway vessels. A structured investment in this type of navigation also allows better cooperation between Member States and trade that promotes economic growth. These reasons led me to vote in favour of the recommendation.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The purpose of the revision of Directive 2006/87/EC is to standardise technical standards for inland waterway transport, taking into account the requirements of the European Commission for the Development of Inland Waterway Standards (CESNI). CESNI was set up to help standardise standards for the European inland waterway sector. Against this background, inland waterway transport would be characterised by an adequate degree of safety and efficiency, taking into account scientific and technical developments in the sector. The move would therefore lead to a higher degree of legal certainty and allow for appropriate adaptations in a timely manner to technical progress and contribute to compliance with stringent safety standards throughout the Union, without hampering innovation and safety. In view of the importance of the safety and efficiency of inland waterway transport and the essential elements of professional and technical development such as competitiveness and modern inland waterway transport, I agree with the review efforts and therefore, as a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to improve and homogenize the level of safety and regulation of safety and environmental requirements for vessels sailing on European waterways. Being opposed to the principle of harmonisation, although the practical scope of this report is limited in France, I abstained on this text.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The uniform application of common technical specifications for inland waterway vessels in the European Union is supported, with a view to ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the revision of Directive 2006/87/EC is to standardise technical standards for inland waterway transport, taking into account the requirements of the European Commission for the Development of Inland Waterway Standards (CESNI). CESNI was set up to help standardise standards for the European inland waterway sector. Against this background, inland waterway transport would be characterised by an adequate degree of safety and efficiency, taking into account scientific and technical developments in the sector. The move would therefore lead to a higher degree of legal certainty and allow for appropriate adaptations in a timely manner to technical progress and contribute to compliance with stringent safety standards throughout the Union, without hampering innovation and safety. In view of the importance of the safety and efficiency of inland waterway transport and the essential elements of professional and technical development such as competitiveness and modern inland waterway transport, I agree with the review efforts and therefore, as a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. CESNI (European Committee for the Development of Common Standards in the Field of Inland Navigation) was established to facilitate the harmonisation of technical standards applied in the inland navigation sector throughout Europe. The aim of the revision of Directive 2006/87/EC is to enable progress towards a single uniform set of technical standards through CESNI. This would provide greater legal certainty and ensure that appropriate adaptations to technical progress can be introduced on time, in order to ensure that the high levels of security in all waterways in the Union are maintained and that innovation and security in the sector are not hindered.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament supported, at first reading, a uniform application of the common technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union in order to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency of inland navigation.  It was also in favour of a rapid adaptation of standards to scientific and technical progress, taking into account the standards developed by international organisations, in particular the CESNI (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards).  Parliament and the Council agreed on the general objective of the Directive, which is to provide a harmonised and coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: a technical report that has little problem with France, where many similar regulations are already being applied for the targeted areas.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a second reading of a proposal for a Directive defining the technical requirements for inland waterway vessels. It is an eminently technical document, which aims to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency of inland navigation. The text also aims at rapidly adapting standards to scientific and technical progress, taking into account the standards developed by international organisations, notably cesni (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards). The promotion of fuel alternatives is also properly addressed (notably the shift to LPG). We voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Inland navigation in individual Member States is of fundamental importance to the European Union and it is very important that we continue to work to continuously increase the high level of safety and efficiency of inland navigation, including, but not least, the scientific and technological progress that has been made in this area in recent years. After lengthy negotiations, the European Parliament and the Council agreed on a coherent and harmonised framework to ensure an equivalent level of safety for ships used in inland navigation.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of technical specifications for inland waterway vessels as it supports the uniform application of common technical specifications for inland waterway vessels in the European Union, with a view to ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement reached between Parliament and the Council focuses in particular on the need for legislative clarity, better regulation, safeguarding of Parliament’s institutional prerogatives, in particular for the update of the technical standards in the inland waterway sector, in order to take into account scientific and technical progress in the field of inland navigation, and introducing a safety clause in order to safeguard EU interests. I supported the agreement between the Council and Parliament.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the revision of Directive 2006/87/EC is to standardise technical standards for inland waterway transport, taking into account the requirements of the European Commission for the Development of Inland Waterway Standards (CESNI). CESNI was set up to help standardise standards for the European inland waterway sector. Against this background, inland waterway transport would be characterised by an adequate degree of safety and efficiency, taking into account scientific and technical developments in the sector. The move would therefore lead to a higher degree of legal certainty and allow for appropriate adaptations in a timely manner to technical progress and contribute to compliance with stringent safety standards throughout the Union, without hampering innovation and safety. As a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported my fellow Member Belet's report on technical requirements for inland water vessels. The Council position shall decide amending Directive 2009/100/EC and repealing Directive 2006/87/EC. Parliament and the Council agreed on the overall objective of the Directive, which would be to create a harmonised and coherent framework for domestic vessels with a aim of ensuring the same level of safety. Both institutions supported the quantification of the use of resources in order to develop technical standards and align them with scientific and technical progress. During the negotiations, parliament's priorities at first reading included uniform application of technical requirements and ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in domestic shipping.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Recommendation with a view to the uniform application of common technical requirements relating to inland watering vessels in the EU, in order to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation, as well as to streamline the use of resources to develop technical standards and adapt them to scientific and technical progress through the use of standards developed by international organisations.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on 'Technical rules for inland waterway vessels' – it is an important update of existing legislation to guarantee the safety of inland waterway transport.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour colleagues, I welcome the close cooperation between the River Commissions, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and the European Institutions in order to increase efficiency and much needed legal clarity for the inland navigation sector, which mainly consists of SMEs. I fully support the coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels across Europe. We would urge the UK to ensure that all aspects of our standards follow best practice in this area including on inspections.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the previous phase of commissions, we voted in favour of this technical regulation on inland water navigation. The aim is to establish a harmonised technical framework to ensure the same level of safety for all vessels operating in the Union and to facilitate their adaptation to scientific and technical progress taking into account the guidelines of CESNI (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards) and other international bodies. Following the ordinary legislative process of the Union, the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading was declared approved without a vote.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I support the need to ensure the coherence and development of EU legislation, in particular with Directive 2014/94/EU on the installation of alternative fuel infrastructure. Although Parliament and the Council have so far agreed with the overall objective of the Directive to ensure a harmonised and coherent framework that ensures the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels, it is necessary for these two institutions to continue to support and streamline the use of resources. As a member of the TRAN committee, I believe that the development of technical standards and their adaptation to scientific and technical progress is a comprehensive process, which depends both on international standards and on national technical requirements.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour welcomes the close cooperation between the River Commissions, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and the European institutions in order to increase efficiency and provide much-needed legal clarity for the inland navigation sector, which mainly consists of SMEs. We fully support the coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels all around Europe. We would urge the UK to ensure that all aspects of our standards follow best practice in this area, including on inspections.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – We voted in favour of the report which was purely technical since all the institutions agreed to the final text which ensures a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report along with the majority of my colleagues. The proposal seeks to adopt a uniform set of technical standards for inland navigation vessels that would: (i) provide more legal certainty; (ii) ensure that technical adaptations can be introduced within a reasonable time; (iii) ensure that high safety standards on all EU inland waterways are maintained; and (v) promote innovation in the sector, all of which would greatly benefit individuals who use waterways, especially workers. In addition to that, harmonisation of this regulation across the EU will help prevent distortions of competition.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it ensures that safety standards on EU waterways are maintained while also supporting innovation in the inland waterway sector.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this directive is to streamline the decision-making process of technical standards for inland waterway vessels and to have a harmonised framework. The main point of the negotiations between the institutions was setting up the report in a way that would not impede further interventions by Parliament once a new standard was adopted. It is important that Parliament not be sidelined, which is why I supported this report.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided to abstain on this second reading because the UK has an exemption.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the European Parliament's decision to support the uniform application of common technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union. They aim to ensure a high and consistent level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation. The European Parliament has successfully negotiated the maintenance of its institutional powers to update technical standards in the inland waterway sector and introduce the safety clause in order to protect the interests of the EU.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive from the European Parliament and the Council establishing technical rules for inland navigation vessels, amending Directive 2009/100/EC and repealing Directive 2006/87/EC, as I believe that the negotiating teams of the European Parliament and the Council have found a compromise to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation. Both sides strongly support the rationalisation of the use of funds with a view to developing technical standards and adapting them to scientific and technological progress using standards developed by international organisations, in particular CESNI (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards).

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to improve and homogenize the level of safety and regulation of safety and environmental requirements for vessels sailing on European waterways.  This text is not revolutionary or scandalous and does not affect France, where many similar regulations are already applied for the subject areas. But the principle of standardising regulation at European level is on the merits problematic. So I abstained.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Diane James and the UKIP MEPs decided to abstain on this second reading because the UK has an exception.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Belet report on the technical requirements for inland navigation offices. The main purpose of this text is to standardize and simplify technical standards. From now on, the standards will be set by an international body set up in 2015 (the European Committee for the Development of Standards in the Field of Domestic Navigation) and will be taken up by the Union through delegated acts.  I welcome this report, which makes it possible to clarify the legislation in force for our citizens. This text was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ At first reading Parliament supported a uniform application of common technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union in view of ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation. It was also in favour of a swift adaptation of standards to scientific and technical progress taking into account standards developed by international organisations, in particular by CESNI (European Committee for drawing up standards in inland navigation) to be established within the auspices of the Central Commission for the navigation on the Rhine. Parliament also requested a periodic three-year review of the Directive to assess the mechanisms of cooperation with the international organisations concerned. In order to ensure coherence with other pieces of EU legislation, in particular with Directive 2014/94/EU on the deployment of alternative fuels, Parliament called for the adoption of delegated acts to introduce technical requirements for vessels powered by liquefied natural gas (LNG).

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this report. The aim of the Recommendation is to establish a single and coherent legal framework to ensure an equal level of safety for inland waterway vessels. The EP and Council negotiating teams also agreed on the dynamic adaptation of technical standards. This will be done through the adoption of delegated acts.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour welcomes the close cooperation between the River Commissions, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and the European Institutions in order to increase efficiency and much needed legal clarity for the inland navigation sector, which mainly consists of SMEs. We fully support the coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels all around Europe. We would urge the UK to ensure that all aspects of our standards follow best practice in this area including on inspections.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the revision of Directive 2006/87/EC is to standardise technical standards for inland waterway transport, taking into account the requirements of the European Commission for the Development of Inland Waterway Standards (CESNI). CESNI was set up to help standardise standards for the European inland waterway sector. Against this background, inland waterway transport would be characterised by an adequate degree of safety and efficiency, taking into account scientific and technical developments in the sector. The move would therefore lead to a higher degree of legal certainty and allow for appropriate adaptations in a timely manner to technical progress and contribute to compliance with stringent safety standards throughout the Union, without hampering innovation and safety. In view of the importance of the safety and efficiency of inland waterway transport and the essential elements of professional and technical development such as competitiveness and modern inland waterway transport, I agree with the review efforts and therefore, as a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – I support the uniform application of common technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union with a view to ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency of navigation. I also support a rapid adaptation of standards developed by international organisations, in particular cesni (European Committee for the Preparation of Standards for Inland Navigation), which should be established under the auspices of the Central Commission for Rhine Navigation.  In the interests of safety and in order to ensure a level playing field, progress needs to be made towards a single set of technical standards. This will provide certainty and ensure that the requirements can be introduced within an acceptable time frame so as to maintain high safety rules for all European inland waterways and not hinder the development of the sector.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on the technical requirements for inland navigation vessels. This text aims to improve and homogenize the level of safety and regulation in terms of safety and environmental requirements for boats sailing on European waterways.  It is a technical report that is not revolutionary or scandalous and does not affect France, where many similar regulations are already applied for the subject areas. But the principle of standardising regulation at European level is on the merits problematic.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the European Parliament's decision to provide a coherent and uniform framework for a level of safety for inland waterway vessels. With regard to the technical requirements for inland waterway vessels, they are laid down in Directive 2006/87/EC, which lays down the conditions necessary for the issue of certificates allowing navigation for inland waters of the Union, including the Rhine. It also ensures that such certificates are issued on the basis of technical requirements which guarantee a total level of safety. Parliament also called for a regular review of the directive every three years in order to assess the mechanisms for cooperation with the international organisations involved.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to improve and homogenize the level of safety and safety and environmental regulations for boats sailing on European waterways.  It is a technical report, which is not revolutionary or scandalous, and which also has little impact on France, where many similar regulations are already being applied in these areas. But the principle of standardising regulation at European level is on the merits problematic. I therefore abstained on this subject.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a good compromise in the field of inland navigation, aimed at improving the technical requirements for this type of transport. This improvement will result in the safety of both workers and end-users of such forms of transport in the Union. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that encouraged technical progress with high safety standards for inland navigation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. At first reading, Parliament supported the uniform application of common technical rules for INA vessels in the EU with a view to ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation. He also advocated the urgent adaptation of standards to scientific and technological progress, taking into account standards developed by international organisations, in particular CESNI.  CESNI was set up to facilitate the harmonisation of technical standards applied in the inland navigation sector in Europe. It is therefore important that the applicable CESNI technical standards set out in this Directive are updated to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency. The aim of the revision of Directive 2006/87/EC is to allow for the uniform application of common technical standards for inland navigation vessels in the European Union, which will allow for greater legal certainty and ensure that appropriate technical adjustments are made and high safety standards are maintained in waterways. The powers to adopt acts should be delegated to the Commission, in accordance with Article 290 of the TFEU and I therefore supported this recommendation.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of proposal is to adopt a uniform set of technical standards for inland navigation vessels. I agree that it would provide: more legal certainty; ensure that technical adaptations to technical progress can be introduced within a reasonable time; ensure that high safety standards on all EU inland waterways are maintained; promote innovation in the sector.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The submitted proposal for a directive monitors the creation of a common and uniform set of technical standards for inland vessels, setting requirements for stability, safe distance, watertightness, equipment, assemblies and transports of containers and governing specific requirements for passenger ships. The Commission shall have the right to further regulate these conditions by delegated and implementing acts. The proposal aims to ensure maximum safety on inland waterways and the maintenance of safety standards, taking into account the scope for further innovation in this area.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained when voting on the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down technical specifications for inland waterway vessels, amending Directive 2009/100/EC and repealing Directive 2006/87/EC because that recommendation is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text.  This text aims to improve the safety and regulation of navigation on European waterways, which we agree with. But it also aims to homogenize regulation, depriving nations as usual even more of their sovereignty, which we oppose.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the proposal for the establishment of technical requirements for inland boating vessels. The important thing is that we have managed to establish a harmonised and coherent framework that guarantees the same level of safety for inland watering vessels.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this proposal which ensures a high level of safety and efficiency of inland waterway transport in the EU. In addition, it advocates the rapid adaptation of standards to scientific and technical progress. It is necessary and necessary to provide a harmonised and coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The aim is to create a single and coherent framework for inland navigation. This will increase security. I therefore support this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the recommendation drawn up by the EP for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down technical requirements for inland waterway vessels.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to improve and homogenize the level of safety and safety and environmental regulations for vessels sailing on European waterways. It is a technical report which is not revolutionary or scandalous and which, moreover, has little impact on France, where many similar regulations are already being applied in these areas. But the principle of standardising regulation at European level is on the merits problematic. So I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to harmonisation at Union level, and in order to avoid distortions of competition and unequal levels of safety, the same technical requirements should be applied to the entire union inland waterway network and to update them regularly. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This legislative resolution aims to prove greater legal certainty and ensure high safety standards on all EU waterways whilst not hampering innovation; therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing — Inland waterway vessels wishing to obtain a Union certificate to sail on European inland waterways shall comply with the uniform technical requirements developed by the European Inland Navigation Standards Committee (CESNI) under the auspices of the Central Commission for Navigation on the Rhil. Technical standards developed to provide a harmonised and coherent framework to ensure an equivalent level of safety in the case of inland navigation will be incorporated into EU law. The proposal passed its first reading, the key being the agreement on Parliament's rights as co-legislator. Parliament could not support the use of a dynamic reference to the automatic adaptation of the Annex to the Directive to the European standard developed under CESNI. This dynamic message would give the Council exclusive decision-making power, bypassing Parliament's prerogatives as co-legislator. I support the proposal with my vote.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which aims in first instance to achieve harmonisation of the technical requirements for inland waterway vessels at EU level. The same technical requirements for vessels should be applied, and regularly updated, for the entirety of the Union’s inland waterways. This would contribute significantly to more efficient, dynamic and safe transport on inland waterways throughout the EU and would also facilitate the use of new and innovative technologies.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council a directive laying down technical requirements for inland water vessels, amending Directive 2009/100/EC and repealing Directive 2006/87/EC. Parliament has adopted its position on the proposal at first reading. Parliament and the Council agreed on the overall purpose of the Directive, but there were disagreements between them as to the adaptation of the Annexes to technical standards. The negotiating team of Parliament and the Council reached an agreement on the matter on 17 March 2016. The Council adopted its position at first reading in accordance with this Agreement. In its report, the Committee on Transport and Tourism recommends that Parliament agree with this position and thus make the draft directive final. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to improve and homogenize the level of safety and regulation of safety and environmental requirements for vessels sailing on European waterways. It is not revolutionary or scandalous and does not affect France, where many similar regulations are already applied for the targeted areas. However, the principle of standardising regulation at European level is questionable and justifies our abstention.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. On 15 April 2014, the EP gave its first reading a uniform application of the common technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union with the purpose of ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency of inland navigation.  Parliament and the Council agreed to provide a harmonised and coherent framework in order to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels. Both institutions agree to rationalise the use of resources to develop technical standards and adapt them to scientific and technical progress, using standards developed by international organisations, in particular CESNI. This Recommendation deals with the text resulting from the negotiations between Parliament and the Council and was adopted by the TRAN Committee in April 2016. This recommendation deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This technical report is not revolutionary or scandalous and does not affect France, where many similar regulations are already being applied for the targeted areas. But the principle of standardising regulation at European level is on the merits problematic. So I abstain.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour welcomes the close cooperation between the River Commissions, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and the European Institutions in order to increase efficiency and much needed legal clarity for the inland navigation sector, which mainly consists of SMEs. We fully support the coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels all around Europe. We would urge the UK to ensure that all aspects of our standards follow best practice in this area including on inspections.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading for the adoption of a directive setting out the technical requirements for inland shipping vessels. Early negotiations for the second reading have already taken place between Parliament and the Council, which allowed the Tran Committee to approve a text on 7 April. In view of these early negotiations, the Council's position at first reading was appropriate.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the vote and adoption of this report, as the safety and smooth operation of domestic shipping requires due attention. Thus, a harmonised and uniform framework will be established to allow for an equal level of safety in the navigation of member states' inland waters.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Common technical requirements are needed to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation for inland waterway vessels. I have voted for this report that aims at providing a harmonised and coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterways vessels.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim of the negotiations on the Directive is to harmonise the technical conditions of inland waterway vessels in the EU in order to ensure the safety and efficiency of vehicles. It is also important that the technical status of ships complies with the rules of the European Committee for the Preparation of Standards for Inland Navigation.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided to abstain on this second reading because the UK has an exception.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I can only appreciate and thank my colleague Ivo Belet for the work he has done and for his excellent contribution to the preparation of this final document.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I supported the Council Position Recommendation at first reading with a view to adopting a directive from the European Parliament and the Council establishing technical rules for inland navigation vessels.  In the procedure so far, the European Parliament has requested to ensure greater safety of inland navigation through technical rules. It was then pointed out that the existence of different legal frameworks and deadlines for decision-making procedures hardly maintains the equivalency of the certificate for navigation are in accordance with Directive 2006/87/EC and certificates issued under the article of the revised Convention on Navigation on the Rhine River. This new document ensures the legal certainty of licence holders and certificate holders and removes a potentially negative impact on the safety of inland water navigation within the EU.  The single legislative framework will also affect the simpler application of regulations and certification of Croatian river shippers, which is important for further development and strengthening of river traffic on Croatian rivers.  Now that this significant legal step has been made, it would also be a good idea to consider adapting the agreed standards to scientific and technological progress as soon as possible, taking into account the standards developed by other international organizations.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to improve and homogenize the level of safety and regulation of safety and environmental requirements for vessels sailing on European waterways.  It is a technical text that is not revolutionary or scandalous and does not affect France, where many similar regulations are already applied for the subject areas. But the principle of standardising regulation at European level is on the merits problematic. In these circumstances, I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. At first reading, Parliament supported the uniform application of common technical rules for inland navigation vessels in the European Union with a view to ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation. He also advocated the urgent adaptation of standards to scientific and technological progress, taking into account standards developed by international organisations, in particular CESNI (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards) to be established under the auspices of the Central Commission for Navigation of the Rhine.  Parliament also requested a periodic three-year revision of the Directive to assess cooperation mechanisms with the international organisations in matter. In order to ensure consistency with other EU legislation, in particular Directive 2014/94/EU on the establishment of alternative fuels infrastructure, Parliament called for delegated acts to introduce technical rules for lng-powered vessels, which is why I support the rapporteur's position to accept the Council's position at first reading.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. At first reading, Parliament supported the uniform application of common technical rules for inland navigation vessels in the EU with a view to ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency. He also advocated the immediate adaptation of scientific and technological progress standards, taking into account standards developed by international organisations. Parliament also requested a periodic three-year revision of the Directive to assess cooperation mechanisms with the international organisations in matter.  I supported the recommendation for a second reading, as the Directive aims to establish a coherent and coherent framework that will guarantee an equal level of safety for inland navigation vessels.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the technical requirements for inland navigation vessels. This report is part of the revision of the 2006/87/EC Directive, which aims to allow for the standardisation of technical standards developed by the European Committee for the Development of Standards in the Field of Indoor Navigation (CESNI). The simplification of standards for operators in the sector is necessary, and legal certainty must be increased, without hindering the potential of technical and technological developments.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The revision of Directive 2006/87/EC aims to establish a uniform application of the common technical requirements for inland navigation in the European Union, ensuring a high level of efficiency and safety in this area.  The review also points to the rationalisation of the use of resources, adapting the Directive to technical and scientific progress and respecting the standards developed by international organisations such as the CESNI (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards). I voted in favour of this draft resolution, between others, for two reasons: first, because, from a substantial point of view or, if we want, material, I agree with the creation of a harmonised, coherent and current technical framework on the subject under discussion; then, and that is no less, because from a legislative or perhaps adjective procedural perspective, I consider the European Parliament's participation in this matter to be very relevant.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided to abstain on this second reading because the UK has an exception.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. Parliament supported a uniform application of common technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union in order to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency of inland navigation. It was also in favour of rapidly adapting standards to scientific and technical progress, taking into account the standards developed by international organisations, notably the CESNI (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards). However, Parliament called for a periodic review of the Directive at three-year intervals to assess cooperation mechanisms with the relevant international organisations, and called for delegated acts to be adopted for the introduction of technical requirements for liquefied natural gas vessels.  In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of its application.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Uniform application of common technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union is necessary in order to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive which aims to harmonise technical standards for vessels sailing in inland waterways.  Parliament and Council agreed on the overall objective of the Directive, which is to establish a harmonised and coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland watering vessels. The two institutions supported streamlining the use of resources to develop technical standards and adapt them to scientific and technical progress through the use of standards developed by international organizations such as CESNI. Basically, the rule seeks to order the technical requirements established by the Commission for The Navigation of the Rhine, the main inland waterway in Europe, with the requirements for other waterways.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the directive containing the technical requirements for inland navigation vessels, as it provides for a harmonised and coherent framework to ensure a high and uniform level of safety for inland navigation vessels.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union (EU) considers it necessary to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency of inland navigation within the EU itself and, as such, supported, at first reading, the adoption of a Directive capable of establishing a homogeneous application of common technical requirements for this type of vessel, as well as an adaptation of the rules to scientific and technical progress, in line with the standards used by international organisations in this sector. In the name of consistency with other legislative acts, the European Parliament has proposed the adoption of delegated acts for the inclusion of technical standards for natural gas-powered vessels.  After the agreement between the European Parliament and the Council on the ultimate end of this Directive – which will allow for the rationalisation of the use of resources – it is important to maintain the adaptation of technical standards by the adoption of delegated acts, and I therefore voted in favour of this proposal for a recommendation for second reading with a view to the final adoption of this Directive.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the previous phase of commissions, we voted in favour of this technical regulation on inland water navigation. The aim is to establish a harmonised technical framework to ensure the same level of safety for all vessels operating in the Union and to facilitate their adaptation to scientific and technical progress taking into account the guidelines of CESNI (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards) and other international bodies. Following the ordinary legislative process of the Union, the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading was declared approved without a vote.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this legislation to harmonize technical requirements for inland waterway vessels. Coherent transport policy delivers benefits for manufacturers, consumers and the environment. Of special importance is the increase in safety which can be expected from such harmonisation, as well as the promotion of new technologies to provide more efficient, cleaner transport. I welcome the oversight powers for the European Parliament which were negotiated by my colleagues and which will ensure democratic scrutiny when this legislation is updated in the future.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Directive of the European Parliament and the Council establishing technical rules for inland waterway vessels, as it allows for the path to uniform standards.  This would create more legal certainty, ensure compliance with high safety standards on all EU inland waterways and would not hinder innovation in this sector.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a good compromise in the field of inland navigation, aimed at improving the technical requirements for this type of transport. This improvement will result in the safety of both workers and end-users of such forms of transport in the Union. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased that Parliament and the Council have agreed on the general objective of the Directive, which is to provide a harmonised and coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels. We are all in favour of streamlining the use of resources to develop technical standards and adapt them to scientific and technical progress, using standards developed by international organisations, in particular the European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards.  I am pleased that the negotiations have reached their conclusion and the Directive can therefore be adopted.  For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour welcomes the close cooperation between the River Commissions, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and the European institutions in order to increase efficiency and provide much-needed legal clarity for the inland navigation sector, which mainly consists of SMEs. We fully support the coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels all around Europe. We would urge the UK to ensure that all aspects of our standards follow best practice in this area, including on inspections.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Although the inland waterway sector is relatively small, it still accounts for 140 billion kilometres of traffic in a significant way in the EU transport system. I see very positively that, compared to other land modes of transport, inland waterway transport is energy efficient, safe, almost free of congestion and quiet. Unfortunately, less stringent emission limits and long engine lifespans are significantly underwritten by the lack of progress in reducing air pollutants. From the point of view of eu inland waterway infrastructure, I consider interconnection with other modes of transport to be insufficient, so I support the construction and completion of missing links, the removal of major problem points, the introduction of innovative technology, the improvement of intermodal connections and the development of smart infrastructure. I supported the resolution because I believe that harmonising the rules will ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels. I also expect the proposed directive, on the basis of the measures taken, to improve research, development and innovation in the inland transport sector for the greening of the fleet of vessels, which is low compared to other modes of transport.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \u2012 Shipping is gaining importance. Although the construction of waterways is difficult and permanently changes the landscape, modern technologies are still reducing environmental impacts. In the context of ambitious plans for the construction of new lines, it is also necessary to redefine the minimum technical requirements for the competence of river vessels participating in European inland waterway transport.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I accept the Council's position at first reading without modification. The Council's position at first reading reflects the compromise agreed by the Negotiating Teams of the Council and Parliament. The consensual text of the negotiations was approved by the Transport and Tourism Committee on 7 April 2016.  I believe that the new Directive will make a significant contribution to more efficient, dynamic and safer transport of inland waterways within and outside the European Union.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The draft EU Parliament legislative resolution on the technical requirements for inland waterway vessels was approved without a vote. However, had there been a vote I would have voted against the resolution. It aims to harmonise technical standards under the banner of ‘efficiency’ and safety. Should the peoples of each Member State desire to adopt such regulations then it should be done through their own individual democratic institutions. Furthermore, by adopting a common safety standard we ignore the natural economic progress that must take place in each society in order for it to be able to implement and support such standards.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. At first reading, Parliament supported the uniform application of common technical rules for inland navigation vessels in the European Union with a view to ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in internal ploving, and both institutions supported the rationalisation of the use of funds with a view to developing technical standards and adapting them to scientific and technological progress using standards developed by international organisations. However, the Council and Parliament have differing views on how to align annexes with these technical standards. Parliament and the Council's negotiating teams reached an agreement on the matter on 17 March 2016. Following legal and linguistic verification, the Council adopted its position at first reading confirming the agreement of 17 March 2016.  To this end, I support the recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive from the European Parliament and the Council establishing technical rules for inland navigation vessels, amending Directive 2009/100/EC and repealing Directive 2006/87/EC.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on technical regulations for inland waterway vessels.  At first reading, we supported the uniform application of common technical rules for inland waterway vessels in the EU, with the aim of ensuring a level of safety and efficiency of inland navigation. After successful negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council, the text without amendments is thus before us on the first reading text.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The uniform application of common technical specifications for inland waterway vessels in the European Union is supported, with a view to ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I see the uniform application of technical requirements for inland watertight vessels in the European Union as a good example of closer integration. I therefore voted in favour of this recommendation at second reading. The European Parliament supported the recommendation at first reading, with the aim of ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in domestic shipping and with the condition that the Directive will be reviewed every three years. The agreement between the EP and the Council clarifies legal clarity (e.g. by designating clear geographical boundaries), reduces administrative burdens and guarantees the European Parliament's institutional prerogatives, in particular in updating technical standards. I believe that these uniform requirements make a significant contribution to efficient, dynamic and safe inland water transport and facilitate the use of new and innovative technologies.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Inland waterways are an increasingly important means of transport within the European Union, mainly due to the low price for freight transport and the reduced potential for pollution.  However, there are a number of obstacles to the full operation of these transport routes. These include insufficient harmonisation of national regulations and various river portions. In this respect, the European Commission has come up with a proposal for the establishment of common technical standards for river craft used by the various Member States. The proposal aims to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency, rapidly adapt standards to scientific and technical progress and regular regulatory review. It is also envisaged to install infrastructure for alternative fuels, including liquefied gas. An important component that was reached as a result of the institutional negotiations was Parliament's prerogative to take decisions on up-to-date technical standards in the field of inland waterways. This is an important gain, which is why I support the adoption of this recommendation in its current form.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text of my colleague and friend Ivo Belet. Parliament and the Council agreed on the general objective of the directive, which is to provide a harmonised and coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland shipping vessels. Both institutions supported streamlining the use of resources for the development of technical standards and adapting them to scientific and technical progress using standards developed by international organizations, in particular by CESNI.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement on the Directive laying down technical requirements for inland waterway vessels. The text allows the European Commission to regularly review the technical requirements for inland vessels, which will provide the necessary legal certainty to the sector to ensure that we can benefit from innovations and maintain the highest level of safety. Such assessment by the Commission will be completed in light of the most recent technical innovations, it will prevent any distortion of competition and will set up a harmonised level of safety standards over the whole of the EU’s inland waterways.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I supported the setting of technical rules for inland navigation vessels, as this Regulation maintains the adaptation of technical standards by adopting delegated acts, which is very important so that the Council does not have exclusive decision-making power, i.e. that the European Parliament does not circumvent it as a co-icon. I agree with the need to urgently adapt the technical rules to scientific and technological progress standards and consider that uniform application of common technical rules for inland navigation vessels in the European Union can achieve a high level of safety and efficiency in inland navigation.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for technical regulations for inland waterway vessels in order to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency of inland navigation. It is also a case of adapting standards rapidly to scientific and technical progress, taking into account standards developed by international organisations, in particular the European Committee for the Preparation of Inland Navigation Standards (CESNI).

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the previous phase of commissions, we voted in favour of this technical regulation on inland water navigation. The aim is to establish a harmonised technical framework to ensure the same level of safety for all vessels operating in the Union and to facilitate their adaptation to scientific and technical progress taking into account the guidelines of CESNI (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards) and other international bodies. Following the ordinary legislative process of the Union, the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading was declared approved without a vote.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 At first reading, Parliament supported the uniform application of technical requirements for inland waterway vessels in the European Union with a aim of ensuring a high level of safety and efficiency in domestic shipping. It also welcomed the rapid adaptation of standards to scientific and technical progress. Parliament also requested a periodic review of the Directive every three years in order to assess cooperation with the international organisations concerned. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – In the previous committee phase, we voted in favour of this technical regulation on inland water navigation. The aim is to establish a harmonised technical framework to ensure the same level of safety for all vessels operating in the Union and to facilitate their adaptation to scientific and technical progress taking into account the guidelines of CESNI (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards) and other international bodies. Following the ordinary legislative process of the Union, the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading was declared approved without a vote.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Voted for as generally welcome proposal to harmonise standards for technical requirements for inland waterway navigation to strengthen legal certainty and a common high level of safety. However, I emphasise that the founded Committee for the development of technical standards should ensure the possibility of participation for all relevant stakeholders as well as NGOs. Besides, our aim was to integrate a link to Article 16 and Article 36 of the TEN-T Guidelines (Reg. No 1315/2013) in order to establish a connection between the development of environmental performance of inland waterway transport and the already adopted priorities regarding existing inland waterway infrastructure.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The revision of this directive is intended to move towards a uniform battery of technical standards to ensure better safety standards in inland navigation. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a second reading of a proposal for a Directive defining the technical requirements for inland waterway vessels. It is an eminently technical document, which aims to ensure a high level of safety and efficiency of inland navigation.  The text also seeks a rapid adaptation of standards to scientific and technical progress, taking into account the standards developed by international organisations, in particular cesni (European Committee for the Development of Inland Navigation Standards).  The promotion of fuel alternatives is also promoted (notably the transition to LPG). The group proposes to vote in favour, which can be followed.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The recommendation (the unchanged adoption of the Council's position) aims to establish a single and coherent framework to ensure an equal level of safety for inland waterway vessels. The EP and Council negotiating teams also agreed on the dynamic adaptation of technical standards, which will take place through the adoption of delegated acts. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour welcomes the close cooperation between the River Commissions, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and the European Institutions in order to increase efficiency and much needed legal clarity for the inland navigation sector, which mainly consists of SMEs. We fully support the coherent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels all around Europe. We would urge the UK to ensure that all aspects of our standards follow best practice in this area including on inspections.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a report aimed at improving and homogenizing the level of safety and regulation of safety and environmental requirements for vessels sailing on European waterways. This report is technical and does little to affect France, where many similar regulations are already being applied for the targeted areas. But the principle of standardising regulation at European level is on the merits problematic. I chose abstention.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the need for the EP and the Council to adopt a directive on technical requirements for inland waterway vessels. The current Directive was established in 1982 and was amended later in 2006. Since then, however, there have been significant changes in the technical level of inland waterway vessels. The problem is whether the technical requirements for these ships are to be determined by individual Member States or whether such requirements would be defined by the European Union.  In view of the cross-border nature of inland waterway transport and the need to maintain a high level of safety, technical standards should be set at Union level. This would provide a greater guarantee of maintaining high safety standards on all inland waterways in the European Union.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ Mr Belet's report concerned the adoption of a new directive, which aims in particular at simplifying the decision-making process with regard to the adoption of technical standards for inland waterway ships, while at the same time providing a harmonised framework of technical standards for the EU and the CCNR (Central Commission for Navigation on the Rhine). The first edition of these harmonised standards was prepared by the recently established Standards Committee in November 2015. Since I believe that, in such a highly technical area, it is necessary to have certain common standards within the European Union and, at the same time, these standards should be aligned with the regime given by the commissions for individual areas, I voted in favour of adopting this directive.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on technical regulations for inland waterway vessels and the amendment of Directive 2009/100/EC and the repeal of Directive 2006/87/EC. I support the establishment of a harmonised and consistent framework to ensure the same level of safety for inland waterway vessels.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this new economic agreement between the European Union and the South African countries because it greatly harms European orange and citrus producers and, in particular, Valencians, who are the largest producers in Europe. The decision to extend the period in which South African orange will be able to enter Europe until the end of November is a blow to our producers, because during that time the imported orange will be matched with the orange we produce ourselves. One more blow to orange producers, who are suffering unfair competition from countries like Morocco– where orange is produced without our standards, neither social nor environmental – and the pressure of large distribution chains, which pay them a miserable price. One more blow that fuels Euroscepticism. I don't know how I'm going to be able to explain this to my constituents. Frankly, it gives us the impression that the European Union does not work for European agricultural producers.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted 'no' to this agreement because, once again, the European Union's foreign policy is against Community agricultural policy, especially against our producers, in this case citrus. I come from Spain, from southern Spain, from Andalusia, where citrus fruits, as in Valencia, as Mr Sebastio said, are very important, and there has not been the slightest sensitivity. In addition, I have to report here, before this House, that the sector was absolutely not sure of the latest agreements: the six-week extension of the period, which coincides with Spanish production; in addition, the radical elimination of all tariffs. It's all been done with its back to the agricultural sector. We can't keep doing international politics. This agreement has laudable aspects, but seriously hurt agricultural policy and our producers, certainly not with my vote.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, in the next ten years the countries of Africa, the Pacific and the Caribbean will liberalise 80% of their trade with the European Union. This is possible under a Partnership Agreement concluded in 2012. The agreement, however, is not complete and not perfect.  The Union must be more ambitious and continue negotiations to include services, investment, intellectual property, public procurement or sustainable development. This is to the advantage of these countries, in Africa, the Caribbean, the Pacific, and it is all the more important now that we are facing the refugee crisis. Diversifying the economies of these countries will lead to economic and political stability, the safety of citizens and the stability of all: and those regions, and Of Europe.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this agreement because it will seriously harm small and medium-sized agriculture, both in the European Union, especially in the field of wine and fruit in the southern countries and in the countries of Africa.  I have also voted against it because we are dealing with an agreement against the interests of all the popular classes.
