This is an agreement for large Western companies – they are the ones that profit from exports and imports, because behind the oil imported by the EU from Angola, behind the diamonds imported from Botswana, or behind coal, precious stones, metals and fish imported from Namibia are the interests of large multinationals. In 2013, the European Union imported EUR 31 billion, exported EUR 33 billion, a positive balance of 2 billion, to which we should add up the profits of large companies supplying cheap raw materials and with extremely low production costs.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted against this agreement, I voted against the agreement between the European Union and certain countries of southern Africa, including South Africa, because it would be yet another blow to our agriculture, to agriculture in Europe, and especially to Southern Europe, to our citrus fruits, to oranges – I must quote – from my region, which have the healthiest organoleptic qualities.  I am against it because I want to say enough is enough: no more trade agreements that expose the agricultural sector to unfair competition from tonnes of non-European products that arrive on our markets without even being traced, subjected to inadequate phytosanitary controls and at rock-bottom prices. I say no more to agriculture as a bargaining chip in European trade policy and I say no more monopoly and no more blows from the Commission, which enters into agreements without a minimum impact assessment that these agreements will have on local markets, which is quite different from considering the general market of the European Union. If the European Commission does not do this, it will soon be our farmers who will mourn the damage of bad choices.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I and my colleagues in the 5-Star Movement have also voted against this agreement, an agreement which the Commission claims is an agreement to help Africa, but which is in fact a fully-fledted trade treaty, which will lead to an opening of 86% of the African market, an untenable opening for Africa, which will cause eur 3.5 billion in lost customs duties to be lost and at the same time the first consequence for us will be an invasion of South African oranges in the very period of our harvest.  Furthermore, there is no chapter on sustainable development in the Treaty and civil society has not been included in the wording. This agreement will easily increase regional disintegration by pitting South Africa against smaller states. Finally, we are forcing our partners to make forced marches towards ratification in October, without their Members having had time to read the text they are signing. Furthermore, if they do not sign, we will punish them with prohibitive customs duties – a very good example of democracy, but that is what we have always done with Africa.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 12 June 2002, the Council authorised the opening of negotiations for the EPA with the Group of States Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland (BLMNS) and South Africa (SADC). The trade agreement offers asymmetric access to the EU market and THE SADC countries, enabling them to protect sensitive sectors from liberalisation; it also provides a large number of safeguard measures and a protection clause for the fledgling industry. While I recognise the need to promote the economic and industrial development of these countries, I disapprove of such asymmetricality between the two markets, especially in a context of severe crisis for the European economy, which would harm EU operators. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We abstained on this vote. Despite our abstention, we note with concern the EU tendency to bully poor countries in trade ‘partnerships’. We hope that the EU will behave more fairly towards its trade partners in the future.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The EU signed an Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) in June 2016 with the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Economic Partnership Agreements (EPA) group, which includes Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland. EPAs, created in 2000, are trade agreements that were meant to safeguard African Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries’ preferential access to EU markets. EPAs are changing this preferential access from non-reciprocal to reciprocal access, meaning that ACP countries are required to open their markets to EU imports and, furthermore, require liberalisation in other areas such as investment and services. This will have serious negative consequences for local populations in the SADC and the strong opposition from these states and civil society mean negotiations have lasted more than a decade.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. Although this is probably the "least worst" of the three economic partnership agreements, I voted against this agreement: The attitude of the European Commission in the negotiations was undignified: by the very admission of the ACP presidents, it has multiplied 'excessive demands' and has weakened the 'regional integration' of the African continent. It blackmailed the ratification of the agreements by threatening to suspend the trade preferences of non-LDC countries in the region on 1 October 2016. The SADC EPA, by opening the markets of LDC countries more than the existing "Everything but Arms" regime, would result in immediate economic losses for Lesotho and Mozambique, which are already the most fragile countries in the region.  The SADC EPA is exclusively commercial, devoid of any ambition in terms of development assistance. It also contradicts the EU's policy of promoting human rights in the region, particularly in Swaziland. The SADC's provisions in this area are lower than those contained in previous EPAs (for example, the CARIFORUM APE).

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) between the EU and the SADC EPA States. On 11 June 2016, the EU and six members – Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland – of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) signed the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA). Angola is the only country that is not part of the EPA, but as provided for in a clause of the Agreement, may join in the future. The objectives of the agreement are: a) eradication of poverty through a trade partnership; b) promotion of regional integration; c) gradual integration of the SADC EPA States into the world economy; d) to improve the SADC EPA States’ capacity in trade policy; e) to support conditions for increasing investments and f) strengthening existing relations between the parties on the basis of solidarity and mutual interest. It is important to stress that on market access, the EPA will give the SADC countries duty-free access to the EU market. Although South Africa will not receive duty free access, an improved offer will be proposed. Overall, I welcome the EPA which will liberalise 86% of trade with the EU in 20 years.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed economic partnership agreement is asymmetrical, with a customs duty-free basis for imports from the CDAA (South Africa, Namibia, Mozambique, Botswana, Lesotho, Swaziland...). One of the subjects is the "white sugar" produced in this area which already competes strongly with European production, Mozambique being a major producer, very competitive, whose exports to the EU are increasing very strongly. So I voted AGAINST this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I have some concerns over this Partnership Agreement because of its impact on poorer countries, and the potential for them to be exploited.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation because this partnership agreement is a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the CDAA-EU EPA States - which have strong political significance - as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the recommendation on the conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and the SADC EPA States. In 2013, the EU imported goods for EUR 31 billion from the SADC EPA group. In 2005, the Commission adopted a plan to improve the use of goods in the SADC. It is clear that the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPAs) enables substantial positive developments and contributes to sustainable economic growth in the South African Development Community Group (SADC) and EU countries. I support the flexibility and protection provisions included in the agreement, in particular those relating to trade and sustainable development, which can help to secure a mutually beneficial agreement.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote. Despite our abstention, we note with concern the EU tendency to bully poor countries in trade ‘partnerships’. We hope that the EU will behave more fairly towards its trade partners in the future.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I am voting against this new free trade agreement with the Southern African Development Community states - the CDAA includes South Africa, Namibia, Mozambique and Botswana. One of the risks is that sugar imports will increase sharply in the European Union, to the detriment of our producers.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) aims to promote trade, regional integration and the gradual integration of ACP countries into the global economy and to encourage their sustainable development. This purely trade agreement, a remnant of a bilateral relationship of another time, is in complete contradiction with European commitments on development policies and objectives.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. In this legislative resolution, Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of the Agreement with the AAE States of the Community for the Development of Southern Africa (Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland). This Agreement seeks to increase cooperation with this region of Africa. It contains provisions to promote trade and development, the promotion of regional integration, and contains clauses for respect for values and follow-up to the implementation of the Agreement. However, this agreement poses a threat to the Spanish agricultural sector, in particular the citrícola, due to the unfair competition it allows and the lack of reciprocity. I share the objectives of promoting interregional cooperation and helping the economic growth of southern Africa, but not without transparency, at the expense of the Spanish agricultural sector and without taking into account its demands and its possible impact, or providing for countervailing measures.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the economic agreement between the Union and the countries of Southern Africa. The instrument offers few real advantages for African countries, as it replaces the logic of non-reciprocity that has existed so far in the EPA, with one of reciprocity. That is, it forces the least developed countries to open their markets to European products and thus further increase competition, which has serious repercussions in some sectors such as agriculture. In addition, regrettable pressure has been exerted on African countries to speed up the signing of the agreement.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 Agreeing to the general framework described in the Agreement. We abstained in this report because we do not yet understand why the date has been extended to allow imports of oranges into the European market until November. In the previous situation, the date of 15 September was much better suited to the reality and needs of European citrus producers. This extension poses a completely free problem. That is why we abstained in this vote.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation relates to an economic partnership agreement between the UNION and the CDAA EPA states such as South Africa, Lesotho, Mozambique... The EU imports 31 billion goods from this area and exports 33 billion. This agreement guarantees these countries duty-free access to the EU market. Countries in the zone will liberalise 86% of their trade with the EU, but sensitive sectors (fishing, agriculture) and emerging industries will remain protected. However, for example, the EU does not protect sugar imports from Mozambique, which is detrimental to us.  This agreement is therefore asymmetrical. So I decided to vote against this recommendation, which is just an additional free trade agreement.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 My commitment to the European Parliament has always been for the benefit of farmers in my country. The Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and the SADC states, which includes 15 African states including South Africa, will severely penalise our producers, especially in the citrus fruit sector. As has already happened, this European Union is incapable of protecting the economies of the Member States by opening the door to products of dubious quality, which are often harmful to the health of our citizens, and by abolishing the duties that protect the agriculture of our territories. For these reasons, I did not intend to support the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I recognize that this agreement is a major step in contributing to the sustainable economic development of Community countries for southern African development, facilitating their integration into the world economy, diversifying their economic structures, strengthening cooperation and intensifying their own regional integration dynamics. However, I abstained in the vote because of excessive concessions granted to South Africa's citrus exports that could adversely affect Spanish producers. The Ministry of Agriculture of Mr. Rajoy's Government has not done its job in defence of Mediterranean citrus fruits, but the Spanish Socialist delegation has succeeded in getting the Commission committed to protecting our producers, carrying out monthly monitoring of exports and also of citrus sales from South Africa to Europe, applying the safeguard clause should these exports or sales have a negative impact on the production of our regions and putting countervailing measures for producers if necessary.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has been approved by Parliament for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Community of South Africa, of the other part, the Community of Development (SADC). The SADC has 15 members. Seven of them opened negotiations with the EU on the EPA as part of the SADC EPA Group – Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland and South Africa. South Africa initially participated as an observer and played an auxiliary role, but officially joined the negotiations in 2007. The EU-SADC EPA is based on the South African Customs Union (PAMS), the world's oldest customs union. Mozambique and Angola intended to extend already strong economic and trade ties with the South African Customs Union by joining this group. Eight other SADC Member States (Democratic Republic of Congo, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Seychelles, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe) participate in other regional EMU 2007.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This economic partnership agreement is asymmetrical with a customs duty-free agreement for imports from these countries. So I voted against this additional free trade agreement.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft resolution deals with the approval of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Southern African Development Community. As a reminder, the Member States of the Union exports 33 billion euros and imports 31 billion euros of goods from this area.  This agreement, negotiated in a deliberately asymmetrical manner, guarantees duty-free access to the EU market for these countries but also gives them the opportunity to protect their strategic sectors as well as their emerging industries.  I opposed this agreement, which does not protect our beef industry from sugar imports from Mozambique. Already destabilized by the fall in the price of raw materials, this sector must now face the multiplication of tariff concessions and the abolition of import quotas granted under free trade agreements. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2000, when the Cotonou Partnership Agreement was concluded, there was a need for fundamental changes in long-standing non-reciprocal trade preferences that had regulated economic and political relations between the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) group of States and the European Union for almost 40 years. The main reason for this was that the impact of these unilateral preferences had been disappointing: firstly, the share of ACP trade on the EU market was constantly decreasing, and most countries failed to use these preferences to diversify their economic structures. Although this development-oriented regional trade agreement currently contains only provisions on trade in goods, development and trade cooperation and provisions on sustainable development, it makes it possible to negotiate additional provisions on services, investment, intellectual property, public procurement and improved provisions on sustainable development. I voted in favour of this report, considering it essential to promote trade and development between the EU and the States Parties to the SADC EPAs.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the SADC states belonging to the EPA, on the other. In 2000, the Cotonou Agreement called for fundamental changes in the continuous non-reciprocal trade preferences that had governed, for many years, economic and political relations between the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States and the European Union. The impact of these trade preferences has been unsatisfactory, resulting, in some cases, even in incompatible with WTO rules. The European Union and the ACP countries had agreed to negotiate reciprocal trade agreements known as economic partnership agreements (EPA). These agreements can be an instrument of development and sustainable economic growth, but supporting the economies of the SADC states belonging to the EPA (Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland) would be to the disadvantage of the Mediterranean countries of Europe, particularly southern Italian agriculture, which would suffer yet another blow.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The EU signed an Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) in June 2016 with the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Economic Partnership Agreements (EPA) group, which includes Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland. EPAs, created in 2000, are trade agreements that were meant to safeguard African Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries’ preferential access to EU markets. EPAs are changing this preferential access from non-reciprocal to reciprocal access, meaning that ACP countries are required to open their markets to EU imports and, furthermore, require liberalisation in other areas such as investment and services. This will have serious negative consequences for local populations in the SADC and the strong opposition from these states and civil society mean negotiations have lasted more than a decade.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote. Despite our abstention, we note with concern the EU tendency to bully poor countries in trade ‘partnerships’. We hope that the EU will behave more fairly towards its trade partners in the future.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to this Economic and Partnership Agreement as it is the first agreement with Africa as a continent, rather than unilateral concessions. It was a long process but should be considered a success for the EU and could pave the way for other such agreements in the near future.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 12 June 2002, the Council authorised the opening of negotiations for the EPA (Partnership Agreement) with countries in the SADC region (southern African countries). From a trade point of view, the agreement offers asymmetrical access to the EU market and THE SADC countries, so as to enable them to protect their sensitive sectors from liberalisation. However, this puts at risk certain European productions – particularly Mediterranean ones – and, furthermore, the method used by the Commission to conclude this type of agreement does not guarantee a democratic process for our African partners and imposes an un equitable distribution of well-being and economic development between the different states of the region, which have distinct characteristics and growth times. I have therefore chosen to vote against.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that this EPA has the potential to deliver fundamental positive changes and contribute to sustainable economic growth and the strengthening of intra-regional trade and integration.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly reject the Economic Partnership Agreement between the Commission and the countries of the Southern African Development Community.  Although I cannot deny that a fundamental first step has been taken towards the progress of trade relations with sub-Saharan Africa, I believe that the enhancement of local products to strengthen their competitiveness is the essence of my activity.  I cannot deny that the issue that puzzles me most is the opening up of our market to their oranges: I would not do my duty if I did not protect our excellence. And then it is not good to always sacrifice agri-food products on the altar of free trade and the export of technology.  I hope that in the future it will be possible to reach agreements that are beneficial to both sides and thus seize the opportunity to promote the progressive integration of African states into the world economy, while also helping to eradicate poverty.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote on the Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and the SADC EPA States and noted no objections.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote. Despite our abstention, we note with concern the EU tendency to bully poor countries in trade ‘partnerships’. We hope that the EU will behave more fairly towards its trade partners in the future.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the trade agreement signed between the European Union and the southern African development community. The objectives of the agreement are to contribute to poverty reduction, the promotion of regional integration and the gradual integration of African countries into the global economy.  The adoption of this economic agreement is a great step in trade relations with Africa because, for the first time, it is not based on a relationship of unilateral concessions, but on a genuine agreement on a regional basis, which will also involve other countries in the future.  Furthermore, although this regional agreement is mainly oriented towards the development of trade relations in terms of trade in goods and cooperation in sustainable development, it also leaves room for negotiation on further provisions relating to services, investment and intellectual property. The trade agreement is therefore part of a broader strategy that the SADC states are called upon to implement through national policies that facilitate trade, development and structural reforms.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – I agree to commit parties to facilitate regional trade by boosting customs cooperation and by implementing reforms, in particular by simplifying procedures and regulations in the SADC region, facilitating transit and fighting fraud. I believe that this EPA has the potential to bring fundamental positive change and contribute to sustainable economic growth and deepened intra-regional trade and integration. Moreover the trade and partnership agreement can only be a small part of a larger strategy. The SADC states should conduct trade and development-friendly domestic policies and pursue structural reforms.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this SADC EU-STATE Economic Partnership Agreement because it is an agreement that will go against the interests of the popular classes: it is tailor-made for large Western companies, which profit from exports and imports into these States (oil imported from Angola , diamonds imported from Botswana, coal, precious stones, metals and fish imported from Namibia, sugar from Swaziland...). According to the Union's own data, in 2013 it imported 31 billion and exported 33,000 to these countries. Positive balance at 2 billion, to which we must add the profit of large companies that supply cheap raw materials, with extremely low production costs in account of misery wages. So we see that it does not contribute to development, but to looting. And, as always, this agreement will seriously harm small and medium-sized agriculture, both in the Union, especially in the peoples of southern Europe in wine and fruit, and in sadc countries.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union, its Member States and the States of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) belonging to the EPA marks an important step forward in trade relations and development cooperation with Africa. Indeed, despite relatively positive data on African growth, poverty, inequality and instability still plague the African continent and suffer from international trade relations to the detriment of local economies.  The Economic Partnership Agreement introduces a chapter dedicated to regional integration and safeguarding sustainable trade and development in the SADC States. For example, the EU has been flexible, allowing the EPA-affiliated SADC States to maintain existing export duties, to apply new export taxes in the case of specific revenue needs, and to exclude sensitive products from liberalisation, to promote fledgling industries and to protect the environment. For this reason, I voted in favour of this resolution.  Furthermore, my vote in favour is intended to keep a high focus on monitoring the phytosanitary risk from CBS phytopathy present in citrus growing in the SADC countries, which has so far been monitored through enhanced surveillance of orange cargoes from the African region.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – Economic Partnership Agreements (GMP) are a system of trade and development agreements between African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the EU. The aim is to support the regional and global trade integration of the GCSEs. The GMP is another significant step towards deepening regional integration if the effectiveness of the monitoring is adequate and the necessary monitoring measures are taken. Furthermore, it is essential to involve civil society as a partner in economic processes, which can be facilitated by an adequate allocation of available resources. It will be particularly important to control the contribution to sustainable fair trade within the GMP. I voted in favour of parliament giving its consent to the draft Council Decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the countries of the Southern African Development Community (sadc EPA countries), on the other.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I fully support the EU-South African Development Community (SADC) Economic Partnership Agreement covered by the Economic Partnership Agreement. As it stands, this agreement deals with trade in goods, development cooperation and trade and sustainable development provisions. One of the reasons I voted in favour is that this agreement does not have to end only on these provisions, it gives the opportunity to negotiate future provisions on services, investment, intellectual property, public procurement.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The deepening of Europe’s partnership with the SADC EPA states is important, as it improves regional integration and assists the region to integrate into the global market. This agreement also includes novel features such as geographical indications. I am in favour of duty-free and quote-free access for Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia and Swaziland while also offering South Africa the opportunity of new market access. However, I strongly believe that civil society should be involved in the monitoring and scrutiny of such agreements.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the final, long overdue, agreement on this economic partnership with Southern African Development Community Countries, many of which are long-standing friends and allies of the UK. It’s vital for their current and future prosperity that they continue to have full access to the EU market.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Eu ropean Union – Southern African Development Community (SADC) Partnership Agreement, together with the agreements with the West African and Southern African region on which the European Parliament is due to give its opinion in the near future, are an important sign of the European Union's renewed interest in the African continent. Trade relations with these macro-regions are all the more significant at a time when one of the greatest challenges for European Member States is precisely the considerable increase in migratory flows from this continent. From this point of view, despite the fact that this is an agreement providing for an asymmetrical opening of the two markets, in favour of the SADC countries, its structure raises some concerns about human rights and sustainable development. In particular, I take a negative view of the failure to introduce a monitoring mechanism capable of ensuring and verifying that the clauses contained in the agreement are actually being fulfilled, particularly in the field of human rights; This instrument would also have ensured greater coherence between European trade policy and development cooperation policy. Because of these concerns, I abstained in connection with Parliament's decision to give its assent to the conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the acceding SADC states.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report presents the European Parliament's recommendation on the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Commission and the Southern African Development Community (ACAC) states including Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland.  The agreement aims to contribute to the eradication of poverty through a trade partnership, to encourage the gradual integration of the CDAA EPA states into the global economy and to support conditions conducive to increased investment.  The European Parliament's report considers that the new agreement is fully compatible with the provisions of the Southern African Customs Union and will not create internal distortions in these trade.  Considering that the Economic Partnership Agreement is a key tool to support the economic development of the Union's partners and to foster conditions conducive to growth, innovation and employment, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote. Despite our abstention, we note with concern the EU tendency to bully poor countries in trade ‘partnerships’. We hope that the EU will behave more fairly towards its trade partners in the future.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this vote, we approved the conclusion of an Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the CDAA EPA states, on the other, Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland and South Africa. Such an agreement will strengthen our trade relations to promote the development and growth of both parties.  It seemed to me then particularly important that the agreement contained a protocol on geographical indications so that the European Union could protect its denominations, particularly for the trade in spirits wines and beverages.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I abstained in the context of this report because, while I am obviously in favour of better access for the countries of the APE CDAA to the Union market to provide them with opportunities and work for their development and growth, I am wary of the collateral effects that could destabilize small producers within the Union who would see their products competed locally.  I am also concerned about the nature of the development desired for the CDAA EPA countries. This type of agreement often leads to a specialisation of agriculture, with monocultures sensitive to market volatility and climatic accidents.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The EU-SADEC agreement is the first economic partnership agreement signed between the European Union and a group of ACP countries, Botswana, Lesotho, Swaziland, Namibia, South Africa and Mozambique.  Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs), intended to replace previous trade preference agreements that expired in 2007, are more ambitious than conventional trade agreements. Under the terms of the agreement, the six states, all members of the Southern African Development Community (SADC), will benefit from "positive discrimination", i.e. duty-free and quota-free access to the European single market for their exports.  Protection measures have been added at the request of the European Parliament to ensure that this cooperation will really benefit Africans.  This agreement contains an appointment clause providing for the mandatory revision of any EPA after 5 years and its possible modification. This should enable us to assess the impact of the removal of tariffs, country by country, by also measuring the impact of progress and, if necessary, making adjustments and improvements, in a spirit of mutual trust.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the CDAA EPA States on the other.  The EU imports 31 billion goods from this area and exports 33 billion. Countries in the zone will liberalise 86% of their trade with the EU, but sensitive sectors (fishing, agriculture) and emerging industries remain protected.  This economic partnership agreement is asymmetrical with customs deductibles for imports from these countries. So I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Lambsdorff's report as I believe that the conclusion of an Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Countries of the South African Development Community. The asymmetric nature of the agreement creates "positive discrimination" for THE CAAOR partners by providing them with duty-free access to the EU market, while reciprocally removing barriers to "all trade" and ensuring compatibility with the JTO, promoting regional integration, economic cooperation and good governance.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The terms of the development cooperation to be concluded with the EPA States of the CAMA also provide for financial support from the EU.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Economic Partnership Agreements (GMP) are a system of trade and development agreements between African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the EU. The aim is to support the regional, global and trade integration of THECS countries. The GMP is another significant step towards deepening regional integration if the effectiveness of the monitoring is adequate and the necessary monitoring measures are taken. Furthermore, it is essential to involve civil society as a partner in economic processes, which can be facilitated by an adequate allocation of available resources. It will be particularly important to control the contribution to sustainable fair trade within the GMP. In view of this, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's agreement to the draft Council Decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of an Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the countries of the Southern African Development Community (sadc EPA countries), of the other part, acceding to the Economic Partnership Agreement.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I express my rejection of the ratification of this Agreement, not because I oppose its laudable objectives of helping south Africa's economic development, but because its processing has suffered from certain elements which I consider essential to make a sound decision. In particular, no impact study has been carried out on the consequences of the agreement on the Community market, in the specific case of enlargement for another month and a half, until 30 November each year, of the tariff-free export period of South African oranges. That extension coincides with the start of the southern Union marketing year.  The European citrus sector already has several years of difficulties trying to ensure the profitability of its producers. The new concession to exports of South African oranges also joins the unease of the sector by the European Commission's passivity in dealing with the threat posed by the 'black spot' disease affecting south-country citrus fruits. The Commission is not only not addressing this concern, but has also recently relaxed on-the-spot checks.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and six countries of the Southern African Development Community (SADC), including Mozambique, provides for measures to progressively open up the market, allowing these countries to liberalise 86 % of their trade with the EU (74 % in the case of Mozambique) over a ten-year period, excluding sensitive agricultural and fisheries products. This regional trade agreement currently only covers trade in goods, development cooperation and provisions on trade and sustainable development. It nevertheless leaves the door open for the negotiation of new provisions on services, investments, intellectual property rights, public procurement and enhanced provisions on sustainable development.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: this economic partnership agreement is asymmetrical, with a customs duty-free basis for imports from these countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are facing the culmination – for the countries of Southern Africa – of a long process of blackmail. A process in which the European Union has done everything to impose on the states of the region, against its will and despite its resistance, free trade agreements, which it has called "Economic Partnership Agreements" (EPAs). An EU option that highlights its neocolonist intent and is based on a supposed (false) obligation under the Cotonou Agreement. The aim of the EPAs was to go beyond what has been achieved in the WTO on trade liberalisation and deregulation. To this end, a whole arsenal of pressure has been brought together, including the instrumentalisation of the European Development Fund, in addition to pure and hard blackmail. It is noted that some countries resisted blackmail (case of Angola). All to serve the interests of the major European economic and financial groups: opening up markets, selling goods and services, exploiting raw materials and imposing an export-oriented production model, helping to level the playing field for workers' wages, rights and living conditions. Obviously we voted against it.  This is not a vote against "trade", but a vote for another policy, which promotes effective independence, sovereignty, cooperation, solidarity, development and social justice.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: In writing ‒ the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the SADC-EPA states was signed on 10 June in Botswana and its main contribution is the emergence of duty-free, non-tariff access to the European Union market for Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia and Swaziland. All relevant measures should help to develop sustainable development in the African countries concerned. However, it is very important that civil society, which guards respect for human rights and labour standards in partner countries, is also involved in this process. The European Commission will therefore have to provide clear guarantees on respect for human rights and freedoms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against: once again our producers are being penalised.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation as the terms of the development cooperation to be concluded with the EPA States of the CAMA also provide for financial support from the EU.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D)
text: Writing. Today, the SPÖ delegation voted against the EU Economic Partnership Agreement with the Member States of the South African Development Community (SADC EPA). The real aim of such agreements should be to grant African countries preferential access to the European market. However, this agreement does not focus on the support and development opportunities of the African countries, but on the very liberal economic agenda and various vested interests. For us, SADC does not meet our social democratic goals in the areas of development, climate change and migration.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to welcome the SADC EPA which will provide duty-free, quota-free access to the EU market for Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia and Swaziland, and will offer South Africa new market access in addition to what it already enjoys. I welcome the fact that the agreement contains a relatively comprehensive sustainable development chapter. I would like to highlight the importance of involving civil society in the monitoring and scrutiny of such agreements, to ensure that fundamental human rights and labour standards are being upheld in partner countries. It is essential to understand the best way to protect and monitor fundamental principles in the Economic Partnership Agreement and implement the sustainable development chapter effectively. I therefore support the call for a strong commitment from the Commission for the inclusion of civil society in monitoring implementation of the agreement.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Economic Partnership Agreements (GMP) are a system of trade and development agreements between African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the EU. The aim is to support the regional, global and trade integration of the GCSEs. The GMP is another significant step towards deepening regional integration if the effectiveness of the monitoring is adequate and the necessary follow-up measures are taken. Furthermore, it is essential to involve civil society as a partner in economic processes, which can be facilitated by an adequate allocation of available resources. It will be particularly important to control the contribution to sustainable fair trade within the GMP. In view of these, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's agreement on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of an Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the countries of the Southern African Development Community (sadc EPA countries), of the other part.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council Decision on the conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the Union and the Southern African Development Community (SADC). At the heart of the agreement is the South African Customs Union (SACU), the world's oldest cooperation system of this type. The Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) is intended to promote trade and development in SADC member countries, as the EU has authorised SADC EPA countries to be exempt from existing export duties and to impose new export taxes in exceptional circumstances, in case of specific revenue needs, to promote young industries or for environmental purposes. This EPA can bring about fundamental positive changes and contribute to sustainable economic development and trade and integration in the deepened region. However, SADC States should pursue a trade-friendly and development-friendly domestic policy and seek structural reforms, and the Union should provide support in capacity building and trade.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against the Agreement bearing in mind that while it is vital to continue to support developing countries to achieve a level of economic development that will enable them to reduce poverty and social inequalities, it is also important to protect European producers. Trade can and must play an important role in achieving these important objectives, but always maintaining the balance between aid to developing countries and the protection of EU producers.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this recommendation report by Mr Lambsdorff. This agreement, which is a trade and development partnership between the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States and the European Union, aims to support trade, regional integration and to foster sustainable development. These are very important issues and it is something that we should support, but it is also important that the report underlines that domestic development policies and structural reforms are needed in these countries and that this agreement will not do anything in a vacuum. For this reason, I also supported the call from my colleagues that it is important that we strengthen the monitoring process to this agreement.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on the Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and the countries of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) required very careful consideration of the assessment of the real benefits and mutual benefits between the parties.  The agreement will allow Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia and Swaziland free access to the European market through the elimination of quotas and customs duties, while South Africa, already a bilateral partner of the EU, will see freedom of access for its goods and agricultural products facilitated. After the Tunisian oil affair, we are witnessing yet another severe blow to our farms and in particular to the small citrus producers in Mediterranean Europe, who are already subject to unfair competition from countries such as Morocco and who will now have to suffer the invasion of cheap oranges on the European market without adequate plant health controls. My vote against the text is therefore also a firm no to the policy of selling off our agriculture without, however, adequate impact assessment. With regard to goods from the EU and destined for South Africa, I believe that a good agreement could have taken into account, in addition to wines and food products, our protected designation olive oil, which is not mentioned in the text.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As coordinator of my ECR Group for the EU-ACP delegation, I voted in favour of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and the SADC EPA countries. Members of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) are Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland. The agreement itself has now been ready for signature for more than 15 years, and the step adopted today is long overdue. The Economic Partnership Agreement can and must set standards for new, genuine cooperation with Africa on an equal footing.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the economic agreement between the Union and the countries of Southern Africa. The instrument offers few real advantages for African countries, as it replaces the logic of non-reciprocity that has existed so far in the EPA, with one of reciprocity. That is, it forces the least developed countries to open their markets to European products and thus further increase competition, which has serious repercussions in some sectors such as agriculture. In addition, regrettable pressure has been exerted on African countries to speed up the signing of the agreement.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I express my rejection of the ratification of this Agreement, not because I oppose its laudable objectives of helping the economic development of South Africa, but because its processing has suffered from certain elements which I consider essential to make a sound decision. In particular, no impact study has been carried out on the impact of the Agreement on the Community market in the specific case of enlargement by an additional month and a half, until 30 November each year, of the tariff-free export period of South African oranges. This extension coincides with the start of the marketing year in the southern European Union.  The European citrus sector already has several years of difficulties trying to ensure the profitability of its producers. The new concession to exports of South African oranges also joins the sector's unease over the European Commission's passivity in dealing with the threat posed by black spot disease, which affects the country's citrus fruits. The Commission is not only not addressing this concern, but has also recently relaxed on-the-spot checks.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Countries of the South African Development Community (SADC) covered by the Economic Partnership Agreement, on the other.  The Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) on trade and development between the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries and the European Union are, in principle, aimed at promoting trade, regional integration and the gradual integration of ACP States into the world economy and promoting their sustainable development. The agreement with sadc countries can be an important step towards further regional integration, provided that further steps are taken to promote technical capacity, for example with regard to rules of origin and trade facilitation. In my opinion, this agreement can bring about positive changes and contribute to sustainable economic growth and the development of intra-regional trade and deepen intra-regional integration.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. "We Swedish Social Democrats welcome the fact that the stated goal of the ECONOMIC PARTNERSHIP Agreement between the EU and the sadc states of the contracting (EPA SADC) is to contribute to sustainable development and long-term poverty reduction. The fact that epa sadc is an asymmetric agreement that should take into account the different circumstances of the Contracting Parties and enable them to protect sensitive sectors is of paramount importance to us, together with the reference to the fundamental principles of the Cotonou Agreement on human rights. We can see that epa sadc thus has the opportunity to contribute positively in the long term to the countries' social and economic development, which is why we chose to support the agreement. However, we would like to stress that the abolition of customs duties is not automatically a guarantee of positive development. In order for the agreement's intended benefits to benefit the population and to contribute to the promotion of regional integration, proper monitoring of both the implementation of the agreement and its longer-term consequences in the region is required. It is therefore crucial to put in place instruments and procedures to ensure proper follow-up in the Contracting Countries. The European Commission must now keep its promise that compliance with the sustainability chapter and respect for human rights will be carefully assessed and that civil society will play an extremely active role in this follow-up process.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – We voted against the report since this agreement contains a number of problematic provisions which undermine the development of African countries, such as disproportionate competition for the agricultural sector, reduced real benefits from their access to the European market, and loss of tax revenues.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the SADC EPA. I agree that this agreement has the potential to bring positive change and to contribute to sustainable economic growth and deepened intra-regional trade between the European Union and the Southern African Developing Countries. On top of this there should be the establishment of a sustainable development dialogue and relevant participative processes for monitoring. I support that while enhancing the development prospects of the region, we are laying the foundation for an economic partnership that is lasting and mutually beneficial. This trade agreement creates new opportunities for the economic development of African partner countries and also offers European businesses new opportunities.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Economic Partnership Agreement because it marks an important step in the establishment of a trading relationship between the EU and the African continent as a whole. The EPA will be instrumental in tackling poverty in the region, supporting regional integration and permitting the integration of the SADC EPA states into the global economy.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I express my rejection of the ratification of this Agreement, not because I oppose its laudable objectives of helping the economic development of South Africa, but because its processing has suffered from certain elements which I consider essential to make a sound decision. In particular, no impact study has been carried out on the impact of the Agreement on the Community market in the specific case of enlargement by an additional month and a half, until 30 November each year, of the tariff-free south African orange export period. This extension coincides with the start of the marketing year in the southern European Union. The European citrus sector already has several years of difficulties trying to ensure the profitability of its producers. The new concession to exports of South African oranges also joins the sector's unease over the European Commission's passivity in dealing with the threat posed by black spot disease, which affects the country's citrus fruits. The Commission is not only not addressing this concern, but has also recently relaxed on-the-spot checks.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote. Despite our abstention, we note with concern the EU tendency to bully poor countries in trade ‘partnerships’. We hope that the EU will behave more fairly towards its trade partners in the future.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this agreement between the EU and the STATES Parties to the SADC EPA, which provides duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia and Swaziland. This agreement gives South Africa an extra opportunity for new market access. This agreement ensures that fundamental human rights and labour standards are respected.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Recommendation on the Draft Council Decision on the Conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the SADC EPA states, on the other hand, because it certainly has the potential to bring profound positive change, contribute to sustainable economic growth and deepen interregional trade and integration.  Seven SADC countries (the EU-South African Development Community Economic Partnership Agreement) have started negotiations on the Economic Partnership Agreement: Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swazi and South Africa and it is these countries that need to steer domestic policy towards trade and development and implement structural reforms.  While this Agreement contains many development measures, it also contains safeguards that allow these partner countries to protect sensitive sectors from European competitors, such as domestic industry, agricultural markets and food security.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This economic partnership agreement is asymmetrical, with a customs duty-free basis for imports from these countries. One of the main points is the 'white sugar' produced in this area which already competes strongly with European production, Mozambique being a major producer, very competitive, and whose exports to the EU are increasing sharply. So I voted against this additional free trade agreement.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We abstained on this vote. Despite our abstention, we note with concern the EU tendency to bully poor countries in trade ‘partnerships’. We hope that the EU will behave more fairly towards its trade partners in the future.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution to open the EU market to SADC countries, which include South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Lesotho, Swaziland and Mozambique. This agreement will bring about sustainable development and regional integration in this region whilst allowing the EU to obtain wider access to the Southern African Customs Union. I believe this arrangement is a stepping stone to a lasting and mutually beneficial economic partnership.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Alexander Graf Lambsdorff's report on the economic partnership agreement between the Union and the African member states of the CDAA EPA. This is the first real regional agreement between Africa and the European Union and is an important step in the future trade relations between the two regions. A programme that I consider complete insofar as it provides support for investment, improved state capacity in trade policy and the promotion of regional integration. Despite the difficulties facing this region, I think it is important to take concrete actions that look to the future. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D)
text: Writing. Today, the SPÖ-EU delegation voted against the EU Economic Partnership Agreement with the Member States of the South African Development Community (SADC EPA Group). The real aim of such agreements should be to grant African countries preferential access to the European market. However, this agreement does not focus on the support and development aid of the African countries, but on the very liberal economic agenda and the self-interests of the European Commission. For us, SADC does not meet our social democratic goals in the areas of development, climate change and migration.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The ratification of the AGREEMENT between the EU and its Member States with the EPA States of the CAMA reflects the deepening of relations between the EU and Africa and reaffirms the Union's commitment to the objective of creating a sustainable development environment for the African continent with characteristics of open economies.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report contains some acceptable approaches, it does not link the EU's economic concessions to the return of migrants by the countries concerned. It should also be noted that the combination of economically extremely different states can lead to significant conflicts between the objectives and interests of those states. For these reasons, I am voting against this report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 14 September 2016, in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, we voted on a draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the SADC EPA states, on the other (Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland) on behalf of the European Union. Personally, I am not a big supporter of these economic partnership agreements, the existence of which dates back to the Cotonou Agreement of 2000. The current EPA contains various very problematic provisions that will certainly not help the development of African countries, especially in the agricultural sector. The terms of the agreement will result in a loss of tax collection in these countries. Moreover, the process of finaliseing the agreement has been very hasty, and many least developed countries have been forced to sign and ratify it as quickly as possible. For these reasons, I voted against this proposal.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Economic Partnership Agreements (GMP) are a system of trade and development agreements between African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the EU. They are intended to support the regional and global trade integration of THECS countries. The GMP is another significant step towards deepening regional integration if the effectiveness of the monitoring is adequate and the necessary follow-up measures are taken. Furthermore, it is essential to involve civil society as a partner in economic processes, which can be facilitated by an adequate allocation of available resources. It will be particularly important to control the contribution to sustainable fair trade within the GMP. In view of this, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's agreement to the draft Council Decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of an Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the countries of the Southern African Development Community (sadc EPA countries), of the other part, acceding to the Economic Partnership Agreement.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report since I believe that the Economic Partnership Agreements do not help ACP countries, but on the contrary make their economic situation or their development worse. Indeed through the EPA, ACP countries will be obliged to open their markets to EU imports, investments and services. Last but not least, the EPA process has been rushed and some countries were forced to sign and ratify them. I cannot support this kind of trade agreement.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Changes are needed in trade between the EU and third countries, and access to markets in developing countries at all prices is impermissible. The policy so far has primarily served the interests of multinationals, whose power continues to grow as markets expand. The ever-widening market is bringing uncertainty to economies, worsening the situation of people living on work and salaries. The report is ineligible because trade agreements would be needed, the cornerstone of which is to increase the population retention capacity of the area. This means transfer of technological knowledge rather than mutual market opening, which can actually help developing countries to catch up.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – The 15-member Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and the 15-member SADC States represents a development-oriented regional economic agreement that includes not only trade in goods, development cooperation and trade and sustainable development provisions, but also provisions on services, investment, intellectual property, public procurement and better conditions for sustainable development. However, I believe that this scenario could have serious consequences for certain strategic production sectors for our country.  The agreement provides, in fact, for the extension of the reduced tariff period, for the citrus fruit sector, until now scheduled from 1 June to 16 October – the date on which customs duties are reintroduced at the rate of 16% – and now lasts until 30 November, with an expected decrease of 1.8% per year, until the total exemption by 2025. An more month and a half during which the production of blonde oranges is in danger of being subjected to aggressive and harmful competition. For these reasons, considering this agreement to be disadvantageous to Southern Europe and Mediterranean agriculture, I voted against Mr Lambsdorff's report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it supports the signing of a new free trade agreement, this time with South Africa and neighbouring countries. However, free trade agreements are dangerous for the European economy, especially for its agriculture.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) replace previous trade agreements with the world's poorest countries. These agreements (Cotonou, Lomé) gave these countries trade preferences to enter the European market and sell their products and goods, while protecting their markets from ours. They had to make the transition pending a comprehensive agreement within the WTO. As this one did not come, free trade advocates saw it as an opportunity to open up to African markets. Under the pretext of keeping trade preferences granted to African countries, the European Union seeks to claim the same rights to enter their market. This carries several dangers: for local productions, European competition risks destroying entire sectors; The EPA requires further liberalisation, privatisation; loss of customs revenue will limit tax revenues; And the southern African economic zone includes countries with too different levels of development. We are therefore going from an unbalanced trade relationship in favour of developing countries, to an equal trade relationship between unequal partners, which I refuse to protect the development of these countries.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the economic partnership agreement between the UNION and the CDAA EPA states.  This draft legislative resolution deals with the approval of the economic partnership agreement between the European Union and the CDAA states - South Africa, Namibia, Mozambique, Botswana, Lesotho, Swaziland, etc. The EU imports 31 billion goods from this area and exports 33 billion. This agreement guarantees these countries duty-free access to the EU market. Countries in the zone will liberalise 86% of their trade with the EU, but sensitive sectors (fishing, agriculture) and emerging industries remain protected.  On the other hand, the EU is not doing the same because it does not protect its sugar sector from a country in particular, Mozambique, which is very competitive and which is increasingly exporting to the EU.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This economic partnership agreement is asymmetrical, with a customs deductible for imports from these countries. One of the subjects is the 'white sugar' produced in this area, which already competes strongly with European production, Mozambique being a large and highly competitive producer whose exports to the EU are increasing sharply. From then on, I voted against this umpteenth free trade agreement.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I abstained in this report on the Economic Partnership Agreement (EAA), which has already been signed and is in the process of ratification by all African partners, will provide these countries with access to new markets. It responds quite satisfactorily to the objective of giving as much coherence as possible to the Union's policies, coordinating our trade policies, with those of development, fisheries and agricultural policy. By signing the Agreement, all participants undertake to act in accordance with international standards in social and environmental matters. The Agreement provides for a number of flexibilities and asymmetric time limits to enable southern African countries to gradually and partially open up to Union exports.  But the lack of an independent human rights clause, which does not contribute to regional integration, which many national parliaments have not participated in in the negotiation process makes this agreement incomplete. And while the Agreement includes a commitment to foster dialogue with civil society, unfortunately it does not incorporate a formally structured mechanism for its follow-up, and we do not cease our efforts to demand the full inclusion of civil society in the process.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this SADC EU-STATE Economic Partnership Agreement because it is an agreement that will go against the interests of the popular classes: it is tailor-made for large Western companies, which profit from exports and imports into these States (oil imported from Angola , diamonds imported from Botswana, coal, precious stones, metals and fish imported from Namibia, sugar from Swaziland...). According to the Union's own data, in 2013 it imported 31 billion and exported 33,000 to these countries. Positive balance at 2 billion, to which we must add the profit of large companies that supply cheap raw materials, with extremely low production costs in account of misery wages. So we see that it does not contribute to development, but to looting. And, as always, this agreement will seriously harm small and medium-sized agriculture, both in the Union, especially in the peoples of southern Europe in wine and fruit, and in sadc countries.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I support the easing of trade with the countries of Southern Africa – South Africa, Botswana, Namibia, Swazi, and others. I also support the elimination of EU export subsidies for exports to these countries.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The economic partnership between the EU and sadc EPA countries is a major step in supporting international trade relations, regional integration of African countries and the gradual integration of ACP countries into the world economy, and the EU is one of the largest trading partners of the SADC EPA Group.  The EU-SADC EPA Economic Partnership Agreement will not only provide unrestricted access to their products to the EU market, but will also act as a development instrument. The conclusion of the Agreement will contribute to the sustainable development and eradication of poverty, to improving the capacity of SADC EPA states in trade policy and to support favourable conditions for increasing investment. One of the key objectives of the Agreement is to strengthen relations between the EU and sadc on the basis of solidarity and mutual interest.  Despite the fact that the Agreement focuses on commodity exchange, development cooperation and trade, it opens up new opportunities for negotiations on further investments, services, public procurement, intellectual property and sustainable development provisions. I supported this Agreement because I believe it represents a significant step in the relationship with the countries of the African continent and contributes to the sustainable development of the economy of the countries of Africa.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I share the purpose of proposal is to conclude the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the SADC EPA States, of the other part. The Agreement contains provisions that will give the possibility to partner countries to benefit from preferential market access to the EU.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I support the conclusion of economic partnership agreements with Botswana, Lesoth, Mozambique, Namibia, Swazily and South Africa. These countries are at different levels of economic and social development. By integrating into development cooperation and trade, we will enable them to participate in the world economy. This, on the one hand, will also help the EU; This will create the conditions for strengthening their sustainable development. The agreement also creates space for other areas of cooperation in the future.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision concerning the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the EPA States of the CAMA, on the other, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 13/9/2016, and because this recommendation is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  It deals with the economic partnership agreement between the European Union and the following CDAA states (South Africa, Namibia, Mozambique, Botswana, Lesotho, Swaziland...). It is an agreement on trade in goods and voluntaryly asymmetrical development cooperation. This text guarantees these countries duty-free access to the EU market even though reciprocity is not true. In particular, white sugar is a problem, as the sugar produced in this area already competes strongly with European production.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union holds many functions but economics is the main one. I voted in favour of the conclusion of the EU and the SADC EPA States to set an economic partnership, for such activity shows signs of the following: bringing fundamental positive change, contributing to sustainable economic growth, and strengthening intra-regional trade and integration. Trade has proven to be an effective tool in enhancing employment opportunities, and, therefore, the African countries that form part of the SADC EPA could really benefit their economies and GDPs by deepening economic ties with Europe. However, there is a need to emphasise the importance of trade by the African states in a sustainable manner that can comply with EU regulations.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. I refused to support the European Parliament's ratification of the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) between the European Union and six southern African states. Negotiated under the Barroso Commission, it is symptomatic of the ideological blindness of European negotiators, even when it comes to trade agreements with developing states, some of which are among the 'least developed countries'.  Indeed, such an agreement will inevitably generate significant budgetary losses for the signatory countries, notably Lesotho and Mozambique, which have hithert enjoyed full access, without tariffs, to the European market, without consideration in terms of opening their own markets. With the EPA, the six African states will be forced to open their markets, especially agricultural, to more than 80%. In the minds of negotiators, the exclusively commercial EPA is an alibi to avoid the problems of cooperation in economic, social and political development. The European right believes that there is no alternative to the EPA, justifying the Commission's shameful pressure on African parliaments to hasten their ratification. While it is true that the current system was no longer in line with WTO rules, the Commission had a moral duty to negotiate an agreement that was less unfavourable to Africa.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report contains reasonable approaches, there is no link between the EU's economic concessions and the withdrawal of migrants by the SADC EPA countries. I cannot therefore agree with this recommendation.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the EP's report on the conclusion of the EU-South Africa Development Community (SADC) Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA). This agreement will ensure substantial positive developments and contribute to sustainable economic growth, as well as the development of intra-African trade and integration. However, a trade and partnership agreement can only be a small part of a larger strategy. SADC states should pursue trade and development-friendly internal policies, as well as continue structural reforms.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This economic partnership agreement is asymmetrical, with a customs deductible for imports from these countries. One of the subjects is the 'white sugar' produced in this area, which already competes strongly with European production, Mozambique being a major and highly competitive producer, whose exports to the EU are increasing very strongly. Therefore, I voted against this additional free trade agreement.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal implements the Partnership Agreement between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, signed at Cotonon on 23 June 2000 ('ACP-EC Partnership Agreement'), which calls for the conclusion of WTO-compatible Economic Partnership Agreements. The Agreement contains provisions on cooperation, trade in goods, trade and sustainable development, customs and trade facilitation, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, dispute resolution, geographical indications and rules of origin.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Southern African Development Community (SADC) EPA Group aims to combat poverty through an asymmetric trade partnership, promote regional integration and facilitate greater cooperation between all parties. Therefore, I voted in favour of this resolution and the agreement.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
