text: in writing – In July 2014, following negotiations between the EC and the Southern African Development Community (SADC), both parties initialled the text of the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA). The Southern African Development Community includes the African states of Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland, South Africa and Angola, which is not part of the EPA on the basis of its willingness not to accede to the agreement. This development-focused regional trade agreement currently only includes provisions on trade in goods, development cooperation and sustainable development, but also leaves open the possibility of negotiating further provisions on services, investment and others. The agreement is asymmetrical in nature, which introduces so-called positive discrimination against SADC-EPA partner countries. This model guarantees them duty-free access to the EU market, while at the same time mutually removing barriers to virtually any trade, guaranteeing compatibility with the WTO and others. Trade relations between SADC-EPA countries and the EU are based on a contractual agreement, i.e. SADC-EPA countries will liberalise 86% of trade with the EU over 10 years, with the exception of sensitive agricultural products, according to agreed provisions. I consider the adoption of this Treaty to be an important step in the Union's trade relationship with Africa, which is based for the first time on a regional agreement and not on a unilateral one, which may lead to the conclusion of further Economic Partnership Agreements. I am therefore voting in favour in favour.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and the SADC EPA States, which reflects the ongoing commitments of the EU towards Africa by engaging in a range of efforts, amongst them economic and trade cooperation. The SADC EPA agreement with Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia and Swaziland is also orientated towards development, supporting economic diversification in these African states, promoting democracy and sustainable development, as well as strengthening regional integration in southern Africa. Undoubtedly, this agreement benefits both sides and offers a window of opportunity for both the EU and Africa to further strengthen their economic, political and social ties.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, which sets a new institutional basis for enhancing trade and cooperation between the EU and Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland and South Africa. I welcome in particular the fact that the agreement includes a chapter on trade and sustainable development and the Commission’s commitment before the vote to actively encourage and support the involvement of civil society in the monitoring and scrutiny of the implementation of the agreement.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 7 of the 15 members of the South African Development Community (SADC) started negotiations with the EU with a view to the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) of Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland and South Africa. This is the SADC EPA group. At the end of 2007, Botswana, Lesotho, Swaziland, Mozambique and Namibia concluded a temporary interregionational EPA with the EU. The provisional EPA also includes a clause a way for Angola and/or South Africa to join quickly if they want to. The agreement was signed by Botswana, Lesotho, Swaziland and Mozambique in June 2009. Although Namibia had corked the agreement more than nine years earlier, it ultimately decided not to sign it. Both sides decided to continue negotiations on a comprehensive regional EPA, including services, investments and trade-related rules. The EU concluded negotiations on 15 July 2014 with six members of the SADC EPA Group (Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, Mozambique, South Africa and Swaziland). Angola ultimately did not cork the agreement, but due to its special accession clause, it could join it in the future. This year, the Council adopted a draft decision on the conclusion of the Corked Economic Partnership Agreement, but this requires the agreement of parliament. In its report, the Committee on International Trade recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The subject of this draft legislative resolution is the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Southern African Development Community States, CDAA (South Africa, Namibia, Mozambique, Botswana, Lesotho, Swaziland).  This agreement guarantees duty-free access to the EU market for these countries, liberalising 86% of trade but retaining protection over sensitive fisheries and agriculture sectors, and some other emerging industries. However, the EU is not asking for protection of its sugar sector, which will find itself in competition with Mozambique in particular. We oppose this asymmetric agreement, which could harm our white sugar production.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The Economic Partnership Agreements establishing trade and development partnerships between the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States, on the one hand, and the European Union, on the other, aim to foster trade, regional integration and the progressive integration of acp states into the world economy, as well as the sustainable development of these States. In 2014, the Union concluded negotiations on an EPA on trade in goods with six of the fifteen countries of the Southern African Development Community (SADC): Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland and South Africa.  The SADC-EU Economic Partnership Agreement has the potential to trigger fundamental positive change, contribute to sustainable economic growth and deepen intra-regional trade and integration. I endorse the rapporteur's position on the guarantees and flexibility mechanisms provided for in the agreement, in particular on trade and sustainable development, which can contribute to the agreement being mutually beneficial and favouring development, ensuring the coherence of development policies, provided that it is properly implemented and monitored.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This economic partnership agreement is asymmetrical, with customs-free imports from these countries. One of the subjects is the 'white sugar' produced in this area, which already competes strongly with European production, Mozambique being a major and highly competitive producer, whose exports to the EU are increasing very strongly. I therefore vote against this additional free trade agreement.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as the EU-SADC EPA can represent an important element of the EU strategy for Africa by contributing to economic and sustainable development in the region. We have received reassurances from the Commission concerning strengthening of the monitoring structures and civil society involvement in the implementation phase. Labour MEPs will follow the implementation of the deal very closely to ensure that civil society is properly involved.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation on the economic partnership agreement between the European Union and the states of the APE CDAA (Southern African Development Community). The aim of this agreement is to promote trade and growth on the side of both the European Union and its trading partners.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The reason why I have decided to speak out against this agreement is because I wish to express my opposition to a method which, increasingly, is the background to the negotiation of trade agreements with third countries.  Although I recognise the need to establish trade links with developing countries, I find it unacceptable that the agri-food sector, the backbone of the Mediterranean European economy, should be sacrificed on time when defining such partnerships.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the conclusion of the Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Southern African Development Community. I believe that a consensus has been put on the table that not only contributes to sustainable economic development, but can also contribute to structural reforms. I would stress that, even in this case, I consider it essential to establish a system that allows the results of the agreement to be continuously tracked and assessed.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Southern African Development Community (SADC) consists in 15 members out of which only seven have started negotiating an Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) with the European Union. I voted in favour of this report, giving my consent for the SADC-EU Economic Partnership Agreement.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Partnership Agreement between the EU and its Member States, of the one part, and the SADC EPA States, of the other part, will contribute to sustainable economic growth as well as to enhancing internal regional trade and integration. SouthEr's exports to the EU consist of Angola oil (23%), Botswana diamonds (11%), precious stones, metals and fish from Namibia and Swaziland sugar.  THE SADC countries should consider exploiting the EPA's potential beyond trade in goods and include trade in services in the future. The asymmetric nature of the agreement creates "positive discrimination" of THE SADC EPA partners, guaranteeing them duty-free access to the EU market, removing barriers to trade between the parties to the agreement and promoting regional integration, economic cooperation and good governance. I support the agreement provided that sensitive EU agricultural and fishery products will not be affected by this. I believe that in the face of a crisis for the sector, the market should not be liberalised. We must not question the livelihoods and livelihoods of millions in this sensitive European industry.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. The EU signed an Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) in June 2016 with the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Economic Partnership Agreements (EPA) group, which includes Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland.  EPAs, created in 2000, are trade agreements that were meant to safeguard African Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries’ preferential access to EU markets. EPAs are changing this preferential access from non-reciprocal to reciprocal access, meaning that ACP countries are required to open their markets to EU imports and furthermore, require liberalisation in other areas such as investment and services. This will have serious negative consequences for local populations in the SADC and the strong opposition from these states and civil society mean negotiations have lasted more than a decade.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. If I had taken part in the votes, I would have opposed this report. The report contains sensible approaches, but there is no link between the EU's economic concession sedation and the withdrawal of migrants by SADC EPA states.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Negotiations between the EU and the seven SADC Member States angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland and south Africa have been concluded and are ready for the conclusion of the agreement. The agreement ensures duty and quota-free access to the EU market and complies with WTO rules. The agreement should contribute to sustainable economic growth and to deepening interregional trade. At the same time, it is important that sadc countries implement national policies and reforms conducive to trade and development.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote. Despite our abstention, we note with concern the EU tendency to bully poor countries in trade ‘partnerships’. We hope that the EU will behave more fairly towards its trade partners in the future.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Let me make it clear that I am fully convinced (in this very particular historical period) that the only way the EU can go is to open up and partnership with third countries and not to close with the construction of physical or regulatory barriers. I therefore welcome the report and vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal of the International Trade Committee on Economic Partnership between EU Member States and the South African Development Community (SADC). The importance of cooperation with countries in African, Caribbean and Pacific countries (ACP) is of utmost importance, especially as the EU does not own the raw materials and products possessed by these countries, and they are needed as resources that are important for the production of some products in the EU.  Also, this Agreement opens up the possibility for ACP growth and development through various benefits when importing their products in the EU. This will reduce unemployment and poverty in ACP countries and create an opportunity for progress. What I would like to point out is that when importing products, SADC member states introduce stronger controls on product surveillance and verification, especially for Xylelle fastidiose in agriculture, which came from these countries and destroyed the olive groves of Italy and France and caused enormous damage, but also created fears that it would spread to other EU member states.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This economic partnership agreement is asymmetrical, with customs-free imports from the countries concerned. The most important problem is the white sugar produced in this region, which already competes strongly with European production, Mozambique being a large and highly competitive producer whose exports to the EU are increasing very strongly. I therefore decide to vote against this additional free trade agreement.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the SADC EPA currently covers only provisions on commodity exchange, development cooperation and trade and sustainable development. Further negotiations on services, investment, intellectual property, public procurement and improved sustainable development provisions are encouraged.  As the Agreement and further cooperation between Member States and SADC EPA countries have the potential to bring positive change, contribute to sustainable economic growth and deepen interregional trade and integration, I supported the Recommendation.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion of the EU-SADC EPA, signed in Botswana on 10 June. This agreement is the next step in deepening relations between the European Union and the states of Southern Africa. Although I welcome the benefits of duty-free and unlimited access quotas for SADC EPA states, I must express my opposition to some aspects of these agreements. As a member of the S&D faction, I stress the importance of involving civil society in the monitoring and control of agreements in order to ensure that human rights and labour standards are not violated. Here, however, this mechanism is underintegrated, and this should change. However, despite some shortcomings, I support this agreement as it is the basis not only for deepening mutual partnership, but will also lead to improved regional integration and help the region to integrate into the global market. I also consider it positive that the EPA complies with WTO rules compared to previous agreements.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has been called upon to give its assent to the Economic Partnership Agreement with the Southern African Development Community, which comprises 6 countries: Botswana, Lesotho, Swaziland, Mozambique, Namibia and South Africa. I voted against the adoption of this agreement because I believe that, for the umpteenth time, the Italian citrus fruit sector is being heavily penalised.  Suffice it to say that, although free access for South African oranges is already granted throughout the country between 1 June and 15 October, with the introduction of this agreement, entry would be extended until 30 November. What is more, with a progressive reduction in taxation, until completely abolished in 2025.  Rejecting this partnership agreement does not mean wanting to force Europe to adopt an autarkic business model, but, if anything, it means emphasising the need to activate measures to enhance local products in order to strengthen their competitiveness. Policies to protect European products, on the other hand, have been sacrificed because of a vision of international trade without a principle of defending southern European production, as has already happened with Tunisian oil and Moroccan tomatoes.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The asymmetric nature of this agreement leads to so-called positive discrimination against the Partners of the South African Development Community under the Economic Partnership Agreement, as it ensures free access to the EU market, while at the same time removing barriers to almost all trade, and guarantees compliance with WTO rules, thereby promoting regional integration, economic cooperation and good governance. The EU will offer a duty-free quota to the five countries of the South African Development Community, a continuation of current practice.  However, instead of granting unilateral preferences, trade relations between the Countries of the South African Development Community under the Economic Partnership Agreement and the EU have been given the character of contractual arrangements. Under the provisions on the gradual opening up of the market, the Countries of the South African Development Community will liberalise 86 % of trade with the EU (Mozambique 74 %) under the Economic Partnership Agreement within 10 years, excluding sensitive agricultural products and sensitive fishery products.  While this development-oriented regional trade agreement currently covers only trade in goods, development cooperation and trade and sustainable development provisions, it also leaves open the possibility to negotiate further provisions on services, investment, intellectual property, public procurement and more detailed provisions on sustainable development. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved the conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) signed on 11 June 2016 between the European Union and the six Southern African Development Community (ACAC) states including Namibia, Mozambique, Botswana, Swaziland, Lesotho and South Africa. The overall objectives of this trade agreement, which provides preferential access to the European Union market to these countries, is to eradicate poverty in the region, promote regional integration, increase investment and gradually integrate CDAA countries into the global economy and value chains.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. During the last 14 years, the European Commission has initiated negotiations with several countries on the African continent for the establishment of Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) with the aim of evolving towards the establishment of reciprocal trade preferences. One of the fruits of the above-mentioned negotiations is the understanding of six countries of the Southern African Development Community (SADC), also called the SADC EPA group, in 2014. The understanding led to the conclusion of an EPA, which would highlight the objective of eradicating poverty through the establishment of trade partnerships, the promotion of regional integration, investment and the gradual integration of SADC countries into the global economy. The negotiated agreement presupposes access to markets of asymmetric magnitude, in order to better respect the interests of each of the countries encompassed, and makes a strong reference to respect for human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law. Therefore, as a regional agreement to promote good trade relations with Africa, a continent which today, more than ever, plays an important role in the global geopolitical and economic context, I voted in favour.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. Today, the SPÖ delegation voted against the EU Economic Partnership Agreement with the Member States of the South African Development Community (SADC EPA). The real aim of such agreements should be to grant African countries preferential access to the European market. However, this agreement does not focus on the support and development aid of the African countries, but on the very liberal economic agenda and the self-interests of the European Commission. For us, SADC does not meet our social democratic goals in the areas of development, climate change and migration.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained on this vote. Despite our abstention, we note with concern the EU tendency to bully poor countries in trade ‘partnerships’. We hope that the EU will behave more fairly towards its trade partners in the future.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, the Union concluded negotiations on an EPA (Economic Partnership Agreement) in the field of trade in goods with six of the fifteen countries of the Southern African Development Community: Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland and South Africa. The rapporteur recommends the adoption of the SADC-EU Economic Partnership Agreement. This EPA has the potential to trigger fundamental positive change, contribute to sustainable economic growth and deepen intra-regional trade and integration. However, the trade and partnership agreement can only be a small part of a broader strategy. SADC States should implement national policies conducive to trade and development and carry out structural reforms. Another element to be taken into account is a regulatory framework that attracts investment. These countries should also consider using the potential of the EPA, going beyond trade in goods and including services in the future. The EU should provide capacity building and trade assistance support, and Parliament should monitor implementation and present issues where necessary. Appropriate control structures should be set up to maximise the impact of the agreement.  I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The asymmetric nature of the agreement establishes positive discrimination in favour of SADC EPA partners, ensuring duty-free access to the EU market and, at the same time, mutually removing barriers to almost all trade, ensuring WTO compatibility and promoting regional integration, economic cooperation and good governance.  This agreement has the potential to trigger fundamental positive changes, contribute to sustainable economic growth and deepen intra-regional trade and integration.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I recognize that this agreement is a major step in contributing to the sustainable economic development of Community countries for southern African development, facilitating their integration into the world economy, diversifying their economic structures, strengthening cooperation and intensifying their own regional integration dynamics. However, I have had to vote against this agreement because of the excessive concessions granted to South Africa's citrus exports that could adversely affect Valencian producers. The Ministry of Agriculture of Mr. Rajoy's Government has not done its job in defence of Mediterranean citrus fruits, but the Spanish Socialist delegation has succeeded in getting the Commission committed to protecting our producers, carrying out monthly monitoring of exports and also of citrus sales from South Africa to Europe, applying the safeguard clause should these exports or sales have a negative impact on the production of our regions and putting countervailing measures for producers if necessary.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. In order to comply with WTO decisions, the European Union has been negotiating Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) with ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific) since 2002. Among other things, these agreements aim to reverse the trade preference given to these countries. The agreement with the Southern African Development Community (SADC) led to difficult negotiations and was signed on 16 June 2016, under pressure from the European Commission. This agreement includes progress, such as the introduction of a chapter on sustainable development, although not binding. But that is not enough. By favouring a primarily commercial logic, at the expense of a logic of development assistance, which these countries need, this agreement remains too unbalanced. It also does not promote regional integration or the participation of civil society in its implementation, particularly with regard to human rights and governance. In view of these imbalances, I opposed this agreement.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the proposal for a Recommendation on the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union (EU) and six countries of the Southern African Development Community (SADC): Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland.  One of the main objectives of concluding this agreement is to liberalise 86% of these countries' trade with the EU for a period of ten years. This regional agreement will address trade in goods, development cooperation and some trade-related matters related to sustainable development. Outside the agreement are agricultural products and fishery products, which are most sensitive, although the possibility of negotiating a wider scope for the Agreement, capable of including aspects related to services, investments, intellectual property rights and public procurement, among others, is open. The Union is the largest regional trading partner of these countries, guaranteeing them, under this agreement, access to the European market, free of quotas and customs duties, so I believe that there is every interest in deepening trade relations with these countries, in which Mozambique is integrated.  To that extent, I voted in favour.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the economic agreement between the Union and the countries of Southern Africa. The instrument offers few real advantages for African countries, as it replaces the logic of non-reciprocity that has existed so far in the EPA, with one of reciprocity. That is, it forces the least developed countries to open their markets to European products and thus further increase competition, which has serious repercussions in some sectors such as agriculture. In addition, regrettable pressure has been exerted on African countries to speed up the signing of the agreement.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) between the EU and the SADC EPA countries, as this is an important step in trade relations with the continent of Africa. SADC countries include Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Swaziland. The agreement pursues objectives such as contributing to the eradication of poverty through a trade partnership, promoting the regional integration of sadC countries into the world economy, improving the performance of SADC EPA countries in trade policy or strengthening relations between the parties on the basis of solidarity and mutual interest. It is also worth mentioning a special safeguard clause in the agriculture of the SADC countries in order to avoid concerns about the negative impact of the agreement on them.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this agreement because I am convinced of its relevance to the economies and populations of the southern African countries that are part of it and who agreed with it.  I understand it's the best deal possible right now. However, it is essential to invest in ways of printing a sustainable social, environmental and economic growth logic that has the appropriate monitoring and monitoring measures. With regard to the agricultural chapter, it is essential that health control measures are sufficient and effective to prevent the spread of diseases. It is also important to ensure that the agreed quotas do not pose an increased risk of imbalance in the internal market with serious consequences on prices and the disposal of European production.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Economic Partnership Agreement with six southern African countries, including Mozambique, because it is a development-oriented agreement.  The trade agreement is reciprocal and therefore compatible with World Trade Organisation rules, but is of an asymmetric and gradual nature. Southern African countries can protect their sensitive sectors from European competitors and the agreement also includes a number of safeguards for national industries, agricultural markets and food security in these partner countries.  The agreement includes relatively flexible rules of origin and there is also a chapter dedicated to sustainable development with commitments in the field of labour and environmental legislation. As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development, I have advocated effective monitoring of the agreement, with the involvement of civil society, as well as a mobilisation of adequate resources to strengthen technical capacity building and cover some adaptation costs that an economic transition like this will entail. In a state, provided that the agreement is properly implemented and monitored, the guarantees and flexibility mechanisms provided for in the agreement should contribute to sustainable development.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because the EU—SADC EPA can represent an important element of the EU strategy for Africa by contributing to economic and sustainable development in the region. We have received reassurances by the Commission concerning the strengthening of the monitoring structures and civil society involvement in the implementation phase. SADC EPA includes a trade and sustainable development (TSD) chapter. The agreement is based on Cotonou Agreement’s provisions on human rights, democracy and good governance.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in favour. Although this EU-SADC-EPA regional trade agreement (Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namíbia, South Africa and Swaziland) with a focus on development currently includes only provisions on trade in goods, development cooperation and trade and sustainable development, it also leaves open the possibility to negotiate further provisions on services, investment, intellectual property, public procurement and better provisions on sustainable development. The agreement introduces so-called positive discrimination against SADC-EPA partner countries, which guarantees them duty-free access to the EU market, while at the same time mutually removing barriers to virtually any trade, guaranteeing wto compatibility while promoting regional integration, economic cooperation and good governance.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Six EPA countries within the SADC group have a total population of approximately 100 million, and according to World Bank data in 2014, their GDP was EUR 410 billion. I am therefore glad that the EPA not only prevented the break-up of the world's oldest existing customs union by amending the market access regulation, but also defined a comprehensive list of areas in which partners will work together to strengthen sustainable development. I supported the resolution because I believe that, thanks to this agreement, positive changes will also be made at partnership level, and the agreement will contribute to sustainable economic growth and deepening trade between regions and their mutual integration. Although this agreement only includes provisions on trade in goods, development cooperation and trade and sustainable development, I believe that both parties will also negotiate further provisions on services, investment, intellectual property, public procurement and better provisions on sustainable development in the coming periods. I believe that, despite the positives of the agreement, it will be essential that the SADC-EPA states proceed urgently to implement national trade policies supporting the development and implementation of structural reforms.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ states in south Africa have not insignificant resources of natural raw materials, and some of them have also achieved significant economic growth in recent years. It is in the european Union's interest to develop and maintain stability in the region, not only with regard to tackling the migration crisis, but also for the economic potential of these countries.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I accept this Recommendation because I consider that the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the SADC EPA countries, on the other hand, is of great importance as it has the potential to contribute to sustainable economic growth and the deepening of interregional trade. The EU-SADC agreement is based on the South African Customs Union, the oldest union in the world. SADC countries must steer domestic policy towards trade and development.  Also, these countries must be aware of their potential and not limit themselves not only to commodity exchanges, but also to expand to service activities. Sadc EPA partner countries are a diverse group and so among them we can find the least developed countries and middle-income countries. It is important to promote deep business links to support the African private sector. The full potential of the agreement requires the introduction of a quality monitoring mechanism and the European Parliament will be tasked with overseeing implementation and assisting on disputed issues.  The EPA improves regional integration in different ways thanks to the opportunities it provides in terms of rules of origin and regional cumulation. It is also important to improve regional trade by fostering customs cooperation and the implementation of reforms, in particular by harmonising procedures and regulations in the SADC region to facilitate transit.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained from the European Parliament's resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion – on behalf of the European Union – of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the SADC EPA countries, on the other. Like the so-called free trade agreements, this Economic Partnership Agreement is a miracle bag of mixed content. Although it is actually a question of unhindered trade, the EU has negotiated with the SADC EPA countries that, in exceptional cases, they may exempt existing export duties from the new regime under the agreement and introduce new export taxes if there is a special revenue requirement to protect emerging industries or the environment. At the same time, it is largely within the WHO's regulatory framework and has included, for example, a most-favoured-nation clause that applies only to customs duties and fees. At the same time, however, the agreement also pursues development and regional inclusive objectives. It is therefore not only a product of trade policy, but also affects security policy interests.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒SADC (South African Development Agency) consists of 15 countries and seven of them (Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swazi and South Africa) have started negotiations on an Economic Partnership Agreement with the European Union. The EU-SADC agreement is based on the South African Customs Union (SACU), which is the oldest customs union in the world.  This regional trade agreement focuses on development and currently covers provisions on commodity exchange, development cooperation and sustainable development. However, it leaves room to negotiate further provisions on services, investment, intellectual property and public procurement. I support the Recommendation on the Draft Council Decision on the Conclusion of the Economic Partnership between the European Union and sadc countries, as I believe that this agreement will lead to greater regional integration, contribute to sustainable economic growth and increase trade and investment.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Countries of the South African Development Community (SADC), which implement the EPA, on the other.  The Economic Partnership Agreement, which covers only trade in goods, development cooperation and trade and sustainable development provisions, leaves the door open to negotiating additional provisions, provides for positive discrimination for the partner countries that are members of the SADC and provides them with duty-free access to the EU market.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to this Recommendation, the terms of the development cooperation to be concluded with the EPA States of the CAMA also provide for financial support from the EU.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I was unable to support the Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Southern African Development Community (SADC) because it could be detrimental to the weakest economic operators in Africa in its current form. Although the draft draft has the support of all negotiators at the level of the government, it will act as a full free trade agreement in its future practical effect, because of the economic predominance of the EU, and poses a real risk of market disadvantages for local small business and craftsmen who are still weak. I believe that the EU-SADC agreement should also be treated with caution because it would be the first in a series of similar partnership agreements with countries in the world's poorest regions, for which unbalanced regulation could set an unfavourable precedent.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Africa is a continent of growth. New companies are being created every day, and dependence on exports of unprocessed natural resources is steadily declining. The Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) is a unique instrument that brings the two continents closer not only politically or humanely, but above all economically. The agreement contains a number of 'safeguards' for SADC countries that could be used if there was a threat to domestic industry. In addition, the agreement includes pro-development provisions, such as m.in elimination of export subsidies or a clause protecting new industries. It should be borne in mind that the agreement represents an important step towards strengthening trade relations with Africa. For the first time, the Union will base our relations not on unilateral concessions, but on a joint partnership agreement.  I have chosen to vote in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation and I believe that the unequivocal adoption by the European Parliament of this agreement will send a positive signal to the conclusion of the negotiations on the remaining Economic Partnership Agreements with African countries.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the ECONOMIC PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENT between the EU and the SADC countries, because this agreement will enable us to support the development of these partners as a country in a sustainable way. However, this EPA alone does not create the conditions for the development of states, but provides eu support for this development in a way that rewards the economic development of these countries, while creating conditions for growth for countries in a way acceptable to wto rules.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union supports free trade worldwide, expressed through the conclusion of economic partnership agreements with various countries and regions of the world. These regions include the Southern Africa Cooperation and Development Area (SADC), comprising countries that already have a strengthened cooperation relationship with the EU, such as South Africa, and others aspiring to this status, such as Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia and Swaziland. The current agreement, signed in June 2015, gives all these countries free, duty-free access to the European market, encouraging the sustainable development of those countries. Unfortunately, the agreement does not contain formal mechanisms to monitor its implementation, although such mechanisms are included in EU agreements. In this regard, the role of civil society is essential in order to monitor the achievement of the aims of the agreement, in particular in the field of ensuring fundamental rights and labour standards. Fortunately, the agreement can be revised after 5 years, which is a reason for optimism. However, it would be useful to include verification mechanisms in the agreement as early as now, if possible. In any case, however, this is an important step forward for the protection of products of protected origin, and beyond. I support the adoption of the report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against the Lambsdorff report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the economic partnership agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the APE CDAA states on the other. We felt that it was unacceptable to the parties concerned and crossed our red lines.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs), which are trade partnerships between the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and the EU aimed at contributing to the integration of SADC group into the world economy and to its sustainable development. Through this agreement, these states will continue to enjoy free, or in the case of South Africa, preferential access to the EU market, within a WTO-compatible legal framework. Given that the EU is the largest trading partner of the region, I believe that these partnerships offer new opportunities for the economic development of African partner countries, but also present a promising opportunity for European businesses alike to grow. However, these EPAs will only have a long-term impact if they are part of the SADC states’ larger strategy to improve their trade and development-friendly policies, and pursue structural reforms.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. I opposed the ratification of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Southern African Development Community (SADC EPA). The agreement with South Africa, Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia and Swaziland, the first of three agreements with Africa currently being adopted, poses three main problems.  Firstly, the negotiating methods used by the European Commission, which threatened to suspend the trade preferences of non-LDC countries in the region on 1 October 2016, cast doubt on the genuine adherence of our African partners to the content of this agreement.  Moreover, the SADC EPA, by opening up the markets of LDC countries beyond the existing one, would cause immediate economic losses for Lesotho and Mozambique, which are already the most fragile countries in the region.  Finally, the SADC EPA is exclusively commercial, devoid of any ambition in terms of development aid. It is at odds with the EU's policy of promoting human rights in the region, particularly in Swaziland. The PROVISIONS of the CFDC in this area are less than those contained in previous agreements.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The Economic Partnership Agreements (EPA), i.e. trade and development partnerships between African, Caribbean and Pacific states (ACP) and the European Union, aim to support trade, regional integration and the gradual integration of ACP countries into the world economy, while fostering their sustainable development, which is why I supported this report. The Economic Partnership Agreement will provide BLMNS countries with a single access regime that implies tariff-free and quota-free access to the EU market. SADC EPA has many developmental aspects. Under several safeguards, EPA countries will preserve some political space to protect their domestic industry, agricultural markets and ensure food security. However, during implementation, it will be extremely important to closely monitor the real developments and, if problems actually arise, react swiftly within the institutions of the Economic Partnership Agreement. It is also very important to stress that this agreement can be a driver of further regional integration and opens the door to some future provisions on services, investment, intellectual property, public procurement and improved provisions on sustainable development.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for an ECONOMIC PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENT between the EU and the Countries of the South African Development Community (SADC) implementing the EPA, as I believe that this agreement has the potential to bring about fundamentally positive change and contribute to sustainable economic growth and deepening trade and integration within the region. However, the Trade and Partnership Agreement can only be a small part of a broader strategy.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the economic agreement between the Union and the countries of Southern Africa. The instrument offers few real advantages for African countries, as it replaces the logic of non-reciprocity that has existed so far in the EPA, with one of reciprocity. That is, it forces the least developed countries to open their markets to European products and thus further increase competition, which has serious repercussions in some sectors such as agriculture. In addition, regrettable pressure has been exerted on African countries to speed up the signing of the agreement.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have always been in favour of free trade, and will continue to be in favour of free and fair trade. However, I cannot vote in favour of trade deals that will be hugely detrimental to the farmers in my constituency, in particular orange producers. In this specific case, the orange from South Africa will invade our markets in huge numbers without the sanitary checks and strict rules EU farmers are subject to. These South African oranges will enter EU markets even before the European producers start harvesting their oranges. The European Union should have made a detailed analysis on the potential negative effects on the agriculture sector.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EU Economic Partnership Agreement with sadc countries is a document aimed at improving trade between the two parties. It will allow for the mutual removal of barriers, free access to the EU market, which will enable integration into the world economy. I support the proposed resolution because the EU should ensure a significant contribution to the development of African countries. Our aim should be to liberalise economic elements such as investment, structural reforms and trade in services.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Cotonu Partnership Agreement, when it was established in 2000, called for fundamental changes in the long-standing non-reciprocal trade preferences that have dominated economic and political relations between the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACCS) group and the European Union for almost 40 years. I voted in favour of the proposal that has now been put on the agenda.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against the economic agreement between the Union and the countries of Southern Africa. The instrument offers few real advantages for African countries, as it replaces the logic of non-reciprocity that has existed so far in the EPA, with one of reciprocity. That is, it forces the least developed countries to open their markets to European products and thus further increase competition, which has serious repercussions in some sectors such as agriculture. In addition, regrettable pressure has been exerted on African countries to speed up the signing of the agreement.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as the Greens/EFA Group rejects the EU-SADC EPA, as it continues to believe that Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) are not the right means to foster regional integration, sustainable development and respect for human rights in the ACP region. The EU-SADC EPA singles out six economically very different countries from the 15 SADC member countries. This is likely to bring about the disruption of the still precarious regional integration and regional trade. Cheap imports of European products and inputs might well wipe out infant industry and manufacturing potential.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I express my rejection of the ratification of this Agreement, not because I oppose its laudable objectives of helping south Africa's economic development, but because its processing has suffered from certain elements which I consider essential to make a sound decision. In particular, no impact study has been carried out on the consequences of the agreement on the Community market, in the specific case of enlargement for another month and a half, until 30 November each year, of the tariff-free export period of South African oranges. That extension coincides with the start of the southern Union marketing year.  The European citrus sector already has several years of difficulties trying to ensure the profitability of its producers. The new concession to exports of South African oranges also joins the unease of the sector by the European Commission's passivity in dealing with the threat posed by the 'black spot' disease affecting south-country citrus fruits. The Commission is not only not addressing this concern, but has also recently relaxed on-the-spot checks.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this recommendation because the Economic Partnership Agreement between the SADC countries (the southern African states) and the EU has the potential for fundamental improvements. It will contribute to sustainable economic growth and strengthen interregional trade and integration. However, the trade and partnership agreement can only be a small part of a broader strategy. The SADC countries must promote trade and development in their domestic policies and implement structural reforms. In addition, a regulatory framework is needed that attracts investment.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Currently, all States that have not signed an EPA benefit from the EU's 'Generalised System of Preferences' (GSP) or the 'Everything but Arms' (TMA) initiative. However, for countries that signed an interim EPA in 2007, in order to avoid market disruption and allow sufficient time to sign and ratify the agreement, the EU adopted a Regulation on Market Access (AMR), Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, from 1 January 2008, which allowed the early implementation of epas. It was subsequently decided that the AMR [free access to the EU] treatment would end on 1 October 2014 for countries that had not concluded a regional agreement or had not taken the necessary measures to implement their interim EPAs. The EU wants trade liberalisation, from which its large financial and economic groups seek to ensure market opening, sell goods and services, exploit raw materials and impose an export-oriented production model in their interests.  Another policy is needed to promote effective independence, sovereignty, cooperation, solidarity, development and social justice.   For the above, I vote against.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report contains some reasonable approaches, there is no link between the EU's economic concessions and the return of migrants by the countries concerned. Moreover, merging economically extremely different states (South Africa, Angola, Lesotho...) would lead to significant conflicts of interest. There could also be negative effects on European agriculture, and I have therefore rejected the report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report in line with the ETUC and some of my S&D colleagues’ position, as this new free trade agreement with Africa will require African countries to open their market not only on goods but also on services, investments and intellectual property, which might weaken their economic development. As a supporter of the Alternative Trade Mandate I have worked to promote the view that trade must always put people and planet ahead of profit. Many studies (South Centre, ILO, etc.) show the negative impact that these kinds of agreements can have on sustainable development. The EPA in the current form would jeopardise food security and have an adverse impact on the agricultural sector of the SADC countries. In the long term, the EPA could impede industrialisation. The Agreement will also lead to a loss of government tariff revenue that is used for measures such as to finance social protection. In view of this concern, I urge my colleagues in Parliament to engage in negotiations that put the respect of labour rights, the Agenda 2030, the growth and development of SADC countries, food security, social protection and the environment at the top of our priorities.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Free Trade Agreement with Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland and South Africa is one of the EU's well-known trade agreements with third countries that initiate the opening of the respective markets to large business groups. It is a blow to both the poor producers and small and medium-sized farmers of these states, as well as the EU Member States, such as Greece. The agreement for at least a five-year trade with these countries abolishes the protection of important Greek PDOs and PGEs, such as feta cheese and Kalamata olives. Small farmers and farmers in our country are given a free shot, since it is added to a series of EU and SYRIZA-ANEL government agreements, such as CETA and the revised Greek Food Code, according to the OECD, which abolish the protection of a range of Greek traditional (yogurt, feta cheese and more). However, in any case, indications of geographical origin cannot prevent the path promoted by the definitive integration of poor farmers and the strengthening of business groups by trade agreements serving it. The only way out is the struggle of small and medium-sized farming with the working class against the EU and its governments, a conflict with the interests of capital, the policy of the CAP and the trade agreements it dictates.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This economic partnership agreement is asymmetrical, with a customs deductible for imports from these countries. One of the subjects is the 'white sugar' produced in this area, which already competes strongly with European production, Mozambique being a large and highly competitive producer whose exports to the EU are increasing very strongly. I voted against this agreement.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported mr Lambsdorff's report on the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the countries of the so-called SADC-EPA. Unlike previous agreements concluded with African countries, this agreement is not based on non-reciprocal preferences, which have proved ineffective. On the contrary, it is based on asymmetrical but at the same time reciprocal rules, positive discrimination against these countries, duty-free access to the European market and vice versa, as well as guarantees compatibility with World Trade Organisation rules.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Countries of the South African Development Community (SADC) implementing the EPA, of the other part. While the current regional trade agreement is focused on development cooperation and trade and includes provisions on sustainable development, it leaves open the door for negotiations on additional provisions on services, investment, intellectual property, public procurement and strengthened provisions on sustainable development.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We have discussed a great deal this morning about the European Union's ability to work, and I think that if we enforce the meaning of the motion for a resolution, the European Union's ability to work will be a little better. For among friends it is important to express one's opinion to each other, it must also be allowed to point out mistakes to each other, and it is also important among friends to insist on compliance with contracts. We are asking for nothing more and no less with the resolution that has been adopted today, and I expect it to be implemented. And that can increase the ability to work, that can be unity and, if you like, the future viability of the European Union.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, I voted against this resolution because it is an inadmissible interference with the internal affairs of a sovereign state such as Poland. The edified tone, the tone with which some of my colleagues try to tell Polish citizens and the Polish nation how to arrange their country, is absolutely inadmissible and unjustified. And this is one of the reasons in European countries there are growing doubts about the common sense of the European Union's ruling parties in Brussels.  Clearly, the European Union needs reform and this reform must be right in the direction of much more sovereignty, subsidiarity and much more rights for national governments to line up their own country and their own countries. Otherwise, what was also commented on at the Council meeting will happen, namely: an increase in mistrust in the European institutions. Poland is a sovereign state and must be able to dispose of its own internal order.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against this resolution, even though I am a strong opponent of the current government. But any outside pressure strengthens people's support for their own government, and this resolution will help the ruling PiS become more popular. That is why I voted against it. I would also like to point out that if we say that the current Law and Justice government is a bad government, then imagine how bad previous governments must have been, that people preferred to choose Law and Justice.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Parliament deals with democracy in Poland, wants to see how democracy works in Poland, and the context of this work is completely grotesque. In Austria, presidential elections cannot be held for many months because it is not possible to count votes correctly. In Ireland, people who were in a minority were publicly humiliated during the referendum on changing the natural definition of the family in the name of minority rights. In France, the largest party in parliament has a half percent representation, and in all this the president of our parliament limits our debate and why? In the name of what democratic principle? Because he has the support of exactly the political forces that elected him as president, and that is a sufficiently democratic mandate.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, Parliament adopted a resolution on developments in Poland. The resolution, tabled in cross-border agreement, underlined the importance of ensuring the rule of law and the rule of law in all Member States. I voted in favour of the resolution and agree with the concerns expressed by the text. On the other hand, I voted against a number of additional proposals on, among other things, migration and abortion. For example, although I share the conclusion that Poland needs to take greater responsibility on the issue of Europe's common migration challenge, the theme of resolution processing was legal certainty in Poland. Adding further comments would risk weakening Parliament's message.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. Recent events in Poland, in particular the dispute concerning the composition and functioning of the Constitutional Court and the failure to publish the judgments of the Constitutional Court, have raised concerns about guarantees regarding respect for the rule of law. This report expresses its concern about the recent and rapid legislative developments that have taken place without proper consultation and therefore urges the Commission to carry out an assessment of the legislation adopted with regard to its compatibility with primary and secondary EU law and with the values on which the Union is founded, with particular reference to the Law on Public Media , on the police, the penal code and the public prosecutor's office, the civil service and the fight against terrorism. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non—binding motion for a resolution. We do not support the EU’s power through the rule of law mechanism to interfere in the democratic processes within Member States. Whilst we take no position on the reforms instituted by the Polish Government, they are exercising a democratic mandate from a free and fair general election. Any issues regarding their compliance with the constitution is a matter for the Polish institutions. We remain concerned at the possible extension of the use of the rule of law mechanism to other Member States. Furthermore, the legal basis for the EU's is questionable. Under Protocol No. 30 Poland is not bound by the Charter unless they are recognised in Polish law. As such we voted against.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. Three motions for a resolution on recent developments in Poland were presented. This is a common practice in the European Parliament, when a government appears to be rather conservative and above all less subject to the technocrats in Brussels, European leaders are undertaking a series of pressure measures such as plenary debates, resolutions and others. The resolution of the major political groups is an attack on Poland's national sovereignty and that is why I opposed it. Once again, the EU is interfering in the internal affairs of the Member States. On the other hand, I supported the text proposed by the Conservatives and the text drafted by my group, the ENL.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ On the joint motion for a resolution on recent developments in Poland, I and my Sinn Féin colleagues voted in favour. The resolution identifies huge concerns in relation to civil liberties, adherence to democratic necessities and environmental and constitutional malpractice. The resolution also places a large focus on strict adherence to both the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights. For those reasons we supported the resolution.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. Yesterday the pluralism of the media, today women's rights, tomorrow freedom... We are witnessing a permanent coup d'etat, with a serious attack on the balance of power marked by the paralysis of the Constitutional Court. Considering that there is a systemic threat to the rule of law and fundamental rights in Poland, the Commission has initiated a dialogue with the Government to put an end to this worrying situation. The Polish authorities have until 27 October to respond satisfactorily to the Commission's recommendations.  In this context, we have adopted a resolution to support the Commission's approach to the Polish Government. In addition to the constitutional crisis, we are concerned about reforms that could undermine fundamental rights. Because the European Union is based on common values, we call on the European Commission, the guardian of the treaties, to be intransigent and to uphold fundamental rights in that country.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This is a motion for a resolution on recent developments in Poland and its impact on the fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Applicants consider that any attempt to intervene in areas which they consider to be the exclusive competence of the Member States or relating to Poland's internal affairs is unjustified. I voted against this motion because I agree with the broad majority of Parliament and I also think it is important for the European Parliament to express its concerns and express its concerns about recent developments in Poland. The principles of the rule of law and the independence of the courts must continue to be upheld in Poland. I therefore also welcome the Commission's intention to have a 'constructive and productive' dialogue with the Polish Government in order to quickly find concrete solutions to the 'systemic threats to the rule of law'.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The change of majority in Poland has led to a crisis between the Constitutional Court and the legitimately elected Polish government. This crisis and the conservative options of the new government provoked the intervention of Brussels in defiance of the most basic notions of sovereignty and respect for the verdict of the ballot box. The joint resolution on the situation in Poland is a full-standing attack on Poland's national sovereignty. I voted against this unacceptable text. The EU does not have to interfere in the internal affairs of the Member States.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The text of the joint motion for a resolution completely fails to take into account Polish sovereignty and their own democratic right to take decisions, even if we happen to disagree with them.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation considering that the current Polish government systematically threatens the rule of law. The current constitutional crisis, the government's control of the public media and the politicization of the national administration only contribute to isolating the country and harming Polish citizens.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential that all Member States of the European Union can share basic principles such as respect for the rule of law and a clear understanding of the separation of powers within each State. When one of the countries that are part of the European Union calls these principles into question, it is important that it, as a whole, take a stand. This resolution seeks to draw the attention of the Polish government and, above all, to contribute to the solution of a situation that has served to extremely position between the European Commission and the government of that country. As I believe that respect for the rule of law and the separation of powers are fundamental guarantees of a modern democratic state, and as I believe that this resolution is a clear attempt to protect these values in Poland, I will vote in favour of it. I hope that with this signal the Polish Government will realise that it is essential to implement the Commission's recommendations.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the events of recent years in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights as set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The suspension of the activities of the Constitutional Court in Poland and the refusal of the country's government to publish its decisions are dangerous for democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law. There is also a great deal of concern among Polish citizens about the restriction of democracy within the country. I therefore welcome the Commission's determination to find a quick solution to the threat to Polish democracy.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding motion for a resolution. We do not support the EU’s power through the rule of law mechanism to interfere in the democratic processes within Member States. Whilst we take no position on the reforms instituted by the Polish Government, they are exercising a democratic mandate from a free and fair general election. Any issues regarding their compliance with the constitution is a matter for the Polish institutions. We remain concerned at the possible extension of the use of the rule of law mechanism to other Member States.  Furthermore, the legal basis for the EU’s intervention is questionable. Under Protocol No 30, Poland is not bound by the Charter unless they are recognised in Polish law. As such, we voted against.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this resolution, which first of all reminds us of the fundamental importance of the values enshrined in Article 2 of the EU Treaty, including respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law within the Union. The paralysis of the Constitutional Court or changes to public media and police laws make the situation in Poland extremely worrying. This concern is further reinforced by the Polish government's lack of cooperation with the European Commission. It must be firmly reaffirmed that democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are non-negotiable values within the Union. The Polish government must now cooperate with the Commission, whose recommendations it must respect.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent events in Poland have seriously jeopardised the rule of law within the country. The controversy concerning the composition and functioning of the Constitutional Court, the non-publication of its judgments, the amendments already adopted and those recently proposed to the Polish Media Act, the Police Act, the recent amendments to the Code of Criminal Procedure and the Law on public prosecutors' office are all pieces of a framework in which the fundamental principles of the constitutional order are being undermined.  The joint motion for a resolution adopted today by Parliament, and supported by me, reiterates the position already expressed on 13 April 2016. Poland must make every effort to ensure full respect for fundamental rights, firstly by overcoming the paralysis of the Constitutional Court and then by intervening in the legislation passed, following the opinion of the Venice Commission and the Recommendation of the European Commission. The EU will not accept political and legislative decisions contrary to the founding values of the Eu ropean Union.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation of human rights in Poland, because it stresses the importance of defending fundamental rights as fundamental to a European country which must comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. In addition, our group added four amendments to the final resolution highlighting the need for protection of the rights of women and sexual minorities.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. What are we getting into here? The internal affairs of a sovereign and democratic state that is a member of the European Union and which scrupulously respects its legislative framework and fundamental rights! As the alternative resolution of our colleagues in the ECR group has said, the existence of civic movements to ban abortion is perfectly legitimate, contrary to what the major left-wing lesson-givers in this Parliament want us to believe. Ditto for other alleged violations of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. They are the same lecturers who want to throw overboard one of the founding principles of the Maastricht Treaty, namely that of subsidiarity.  However, Article 5 of the EU Treaty clearly states that "in areas outside its exclusive jurisdiction, the Union intervenes only if, and to the extent that, the objectives of the proposed action cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States." It's clear, clear and precise. Why do we so often forget this principle which, if properly applied, would prevent so many of our fellow citizens from turning their backs on Europe?

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. We would like to highlight here our vote in favour of the six amendments that have fallen and which criticized the restrictive laws on abortion, against anti-Muslim rhetoric, asylum, freedom of expression around debates on historical events and other aspects that only highlight our concern about decisions that may be the exclusive competence of the Polish institutions but which degrade fundamental freedoms and rights in that country and , therefore, throughout the Union.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The change of majority in Poland has led to a crisis between the Constitutional Court and the legitimately elected Polish government. This crisis and the conservative options of the new government led to the intervention of Brussels, in defiance of the most basic notions of sovereignty and respect for the verdict of the ballot box. The joint resolution on the situation in Poland is a full-standing attack on Poland's national sovereignty. This text is unacceptable. We believe that the EU does not have to interfere in the internal affairs of the Member States. That is why the ENL Group has tabled its own resolution, as has the ECR group. The ENF and ECR resolutions tend to protect the sovereignty of the Polish state - The joint resolution is a model for the future of relations between the Commission and the Member States.  Of course, we voted against this joint resolution, which is as liberticidal as it is dangerous for the future of relations between the Member States. The sovereign vote of the European peoples must be respected, or the Union will be renamed the European Prison.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with what is contained in this joint resolution. The European Union does not have the right to interfere in matters which are the exclusive competence of the Member States. That is why I voted against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the degrading state of law and the quality of democracy in Poland. The European Commission has been investigating the recent reforms of the Polish Constitutional Court and state control over the public media for months. The Commission has also found a lack of cooperation on the part of the Polish authorities and will therefore continue with the next phase of the gradual process envisaged by the mechanism.  Finally, another really worrying issue is the absolute abortion ban planned by the Government that is incompatible with reproductive autonomy rights. In addition, the Venice Commission has raised questions about the use of listening practices and control of citizens' communications included in the new Police Law.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution condemning Poland because it concerns matters of subsidiarity and can be interpreted as a political attack, thus counterproductive and harms the Polish people and the credibility of the European institutions. Resolving the internal political dispute surrounding the Polish Constitutional Court is not AN EU competence and, moreover, the rule of law mechanism is not included in the EU Treaties, so the procedure or the penalty to be imposed on Poland at the end is legally incomprehensible. The existing EU treaties do not give the Commission the power to launch such a measure, and there is therefore a risk that the mechanism based on the accountability of undefined concepts serves purely for political purposes and not for the interests of EU citizens. I do not consider it fortunate that, in the current growing anti-EU mood, Parliament and the Commission should intervene in the internal affairs of a sovereign Member State, rather than looking for reasonable solutions to the challenges facing europe as a whole, so I voted against the adoption of this resolution.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this statement on recent developments in Poland. The political situation in Poland is worrying, and the composition and functioning of the Constitutional Court, as well as the non-disclosure of judgments issued by the Constitutional Tribunal, as well as initiatives to introduce a complete ban on abortion, new amendments to the Public Media Act, the Law on Police, the Law on the Office of the Chief Prosecutor and the Criminal Procedure Act are particularly contentious.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The change of majority in Poland is causing an institutional crisis between the Constitutional Court and the Polish government, whose conservative options have been strongly criticised by the European Union, in defiance of the basic principles of democracy. This joint motion for a resolution is indeed an attack in good standing against Poland's sovereignty. We believe that the European Union does not have to interfere in the internal affairs of its Member States. That is why I voted against this unacceptable text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent events in Poland concerning disputes over the composition and functioning of the Constitutional Court have given rise to concerns about guarantees of respect for the rule of law. There have been a number of discussions with the Polish authorities, but the issues threatening the rule of law have not been fully resolved, leading the Commission to believe that there is a systemic threat to democracy in Poland. In this regard, the European Commission has made concrete recommendations to the Polish authorities on how to address its problems as a matter of urgency. There are also concerns about respect for freedom of expression and the freedom and pluralism of the media. All this leads the European institutions to intervene in order to resolve satisfactorily the problems created, bearing in mind that the principle of separation of powers and that of the independence of the legal system is at the heart of the democratic system and must not be undermined. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the resolution tabled by the PPE Group, together with S&D, ALDE, GUE/NGL and Verts/ALE.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
