text: in writing. \u2012 Recent events in Poland, referring here to the disputes over the composition and functioning of the Constitutional Court in that country, as well as to the worrying aspect of the non-publication of decisions taken by this Court, impart the guarantees of respect for the rule of law.  It should be stressed from the top of the way that the principle of separation of powers in the state and that of the independence of the judiciary is at the heart of the democratic system and must not be undermined in any way. The Polish Government has not only made no progress in resolving the constitutional crisis, but also raises a number of concerns about respect for freedom of expression and the freedom and pluralism of the media. Recently, a number of amendments to Polish media legislation relating to the governance, editorial independence and institutional autonomy of public media services have been adopted. I am therefore voting on this resolution to invite the Polish Government to cooperate with the Commission on the principle of sincere cooperation in order to find a compromise that would resolve the ongoing constitutional crisis and to quickly identify concrete solutions to systemic threats to the rule of law.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Since the Eurosceptic PiS party came to power in Poland, the Polish government has implemented highly controversial reforms. The reform of the Constitutional Court and the reform of the public media have provoked strong reactions on the international and European scene. The European Commission, as guardian of the treaties, has therefore decided to analyse the consequences of recent developments in Poland on fundamental rights and the rule of law. We must ensure that all Member States respect the treaties. The European values enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on the European Union are respect for fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law. It is our duty to ensure that these values are respected within the European Union. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution 'Recent developments in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights', because in recent years the EU has been forced to deal with several emergencies. One of the dangers to the future of the Union is those countries where nationalists and populists have embarked, as some say, on a 'cultural counter-revolution'.  The Ventotene Summit sought to relaunch the European project. Despite the noble attempt of Renzi, Merkel and Hollande, the reality is that Europe is increasingly exposed to cases such as Poland's. whose government led by nationalist Beata Szydlo refused to validate the appointment of five judges of the Constitutional Court. To complete the disturbing picture, the new majority has adopted new laws giving parliament control over the media and prosecutors. This is unacceptable to an EU country!  This has provoked just protests from our European partners. It is time for the EU to make its voice heard and prevent blatantly undemocratic behaviour from being carried out by Poland as well as by any EU country.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ On the joint motion for a resolution on recent developments in Poland, I and my Sinn Féin colleagues voted in favour. The resolution identifies huge concerns in relation to civil liberties, adherence to democratic necessities and environmental and constitutional malpractice. The resolution also places a large focus on strict adherence to both the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights. For those reasons we supported the resolution.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding motion for a resolution. We do not support the EU’s power through the rule of law mechanism to interfere in the democratic processes within Member States. Whilst we take no position on the reforms instituted by the Polish Government, they are exercising a democratic mandate from a free and fair general election. Any issues regarding their compliance with the constitution is a matter for the Polish institutions. We remain concerned at the possible extension of the use of the rule of law mechanism to other Member States.  Furthermore, the legal basis for the EU’s intervention is questionable. Under Protocol No 30, Poland is not bound by the Charter unless they are recognised in Polish law. As such, we voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution in order to stress the fundamental importance of guaranteeing that the common European values listed in Article 2 of the TEU and those in the Polish Constitution are upheld in full and that fundamental rights as laid down in the Charter of Fundamental Rights are guaranteed. I am concerned that the paralysis of the Constitutional Tribunal is endangering democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law in Poland. Another matter of concern and regret is that so far no compromise solution has been found and that the Venice Commission’s recommendations of 11 March 2016 have not been implemented. I welcome the Commission’s determination to pursue a constructive and productive dialogue with the Polish Government with a view to finding swift and concrete solutions to the systemic threats to the rule of law.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution highlights how the situation of fundamental rights in Poland continues to be seriously worrying. In particular, the paralysis of the Constitutional Court is seriously endangering democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law. Despite the constant attempt by the European institutions to influence a return to normality, the situation does not seem to be improving at all, but, on the contrary, it seems to be constantly turning to the worst. I certainly voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We welcome the Commission's intention to seek a constructive and productive dialogue with the Polish Government

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following recent developments in Poland and serious violations of the rule of law and the principles of the European institutions, I support the resolution proposed by Mrs Weber and Mrs González Peñas as it emphasises the importance of respect for the fundamental rights of citizens and the values of the European Union. Contrary to what is said in the motion for a resolution tabled by my colleagues from the ENF and the ECR, I think it is appropriate to reiterate the importance of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Indeed, it is important to remember that as a member of the European Union, Poland is obliged to respect the right to a fair trial, the freedom and pluralism of the media and the independence of the judiciary.  In line with the report, I therefore call on the Polish Government to cooperate with the Commission in the name of the democratic values on which the EU is founded.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The joint resolution, which is a full-standing attack on Poland's sovereignty and the verdict of the ballot box, is unacceptable. I therefore vote against the joint resolution. On the contrary, the ENF and ECR resolutions tend to protect Polish sovereignty and, therefore, I vote for the ENF resolution and I vote for the ECR resolution.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the EPP motion for resolution on the recent developments in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights as laid down in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and I fully back the procedure initiated by the European Commission.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is no longer the first time that Parliament has spoken on the situation in Poland.  Since the inauguration of the current government, we have witnessed the degradation of the rule of law in this Member State. It is clear that with each new election it is possible – and even likely – a change in state policies. However, what is manifestly happening is a change in the very nature of the State, which cannot be tolerated. We cannot tolerate the violation of freedom of the press, we cannot tolerate the violation of the right to privacy and the unprecedented embarrassment of freedom, we cannot tolerate the independence of the judiciary and we cannot tolerate the violation of women's rights. All this is at stake in Poland. It is clear that we need a constructive approach and the Union must promote a productive dialogue with national authorities. But it is clear that the home of European citizens, including the Polish people, cannot remain indifferent and has a duty to exercise its powers, defending our common values.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because we must not allow the rule of law to be flouted in Europe and for the independence of the courts not to be guaranteed. These values are central elements of our democracy and must not be curtailed. The violations committed by the current Polish Government are unacceptable, and I hope that the Polish Government will find a solution within the three-month deadline set by the European Commission on 27 July, based on a compromise with all the parties represented in the Polish Parliament.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding motion for a resolution. We do not support the EU’s power through the rule of law mechanism to interfere in the democratic processes within Member States. Whilst we take no position on the reforms instituted by the Polish Government, they are exercising a democratic mandate from a free and fair general election. Any issues regarding their compliance with the constitution is a matter for the Polish institutions. We remain concerned at the possible extension of the use of the rule of law mechanism to other Member States.  Furthermore, the legal basis for the EU’s interference is questionable. Under Protocol No 30, Poland is not bound by the Charter unless they are recognised in Polish law. As such, we voted against.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is of fundamental importance to guarantee that the common European values listed in Article 2 of the TEU and in the Polish Constitution are upheld in full and that fundamental rights as laid down in the Charter of Fundamental Rights are guaranteed. There are no ifs and buts.  A country is in paralysis if the Constitutional Tribunal is not functioning properly. This endangers democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law. But dialogue needs to be impartial, evidence-based and cooperative while also respecting the competences of the EU and its Member States. I join the rapporteur in urging the Commission to carry out an assessment of the legislation adopted as regards its compatibility with primary and secondary EU law and with the values on which the Union is founded.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I share a deep concern about the situation of fundamental rights in Poland which, as in other States of the Union, has seen a strong regression. Growing xenophobia, attacks on the rights of women and LGTBi people, or the imposition of ultra-conservative profiles in different instances of the State, are realities that call into question the union's self-proclaimed democratic and plural character. However, this resolution puts European authorities who do not look after them in States where their political interests do not allow them to do so as guarantor of these freedoms. In addition, it presents women's rights as something dissociated from other fundamental rights, which have in their indivisibility a basic pillar. As is often the case, the right to dispose of one's own body becomes an accessory and second-order element. For all this, I have decided to abstain.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent events in Poland over the dispute over the composition and functioning of the Constitutional Court have raised concerns about guarantees of respect for the rule of law. I voted for the resolution because I believe it is necessary to support and protect the fundamental rights on which the European Union is founded, especially in view of the lack of progress on the part of the Polish Government in resolving the constitutional crisis.  I am also convinced that it is only through intensive dialogue with the Polish authorities that we can help to resolve the legal issues that threaten its state. Europe and its institutions must defend and promote the rights on which they were built, without giving in to authoritarian drifts that call fundamental freedoms into question. Every day we are targeted by populism and nationalism, and only by reaffirming the rightness and validity of our principles will we be able to foil the threat and revive the dream of the founding fathers.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The current composition of the Constitutional Tribunal, and its non-publication of judgments, and the new Amendments to the Act on Public Media among others, has prompted us as Members of Parliament to vote on a resolution to address these issues. The Commission has also opened a dialogue with the Polish Government under the Rule of Law Framework in order to ensure full respect for the rule of law but the Polish authorities still have not taken the necessary steps towards a resolution. Politicians’ objectives should not be to go against the fundamental values and rights of the EU and individuals, and that is why I voted in favour of this report. As I have done in the past, I have voted against all clauses relating to abortion, as I strongly believe that, under the Treaty, such an issue should remain a Member State competence.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution refers to the political situation in Poland and the violations of European fundamental rights. The resolution considers that the measures taken by the Polish Government and the President of the Republic of Poland with regard to the Constitutional Court represent a major risk to constitutional democracy. Considering that the Constitutional Court has been established as one of the central elements guaranteeing the balance of the powers of constitutional democracy and the rule of law in Poland and that these attacks on Polish constitutional democracy also undermine the fundamental rights of European citizens, especially those of women, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding motion for a resolution. We do not support the EU’s power through the rule of law mechanism to interfere in the democratic processes within Member States. Whilst we take no position on the reforms instituted by the Polish Government, they are exercising a democratic mandate from a free and fair general election. Any issues regarding their compliance with the constitution is a matter for the Polish institutions. We remain concerned at the possible extension of the use of the rule of law mechanism to other Member States.  Furthermore, the legal basis for the EU’s interference is questionable. Under Protocol No 30, Poland is not bound by the Charter unless they are recognised in Polish law. As such, we voted against.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This non-binding resolution on recent developments in Poland and the consequences on fundamental rights enshrined in the European Union's Charter of Fundamental Rights is a balanced text that allows the European Parliament to express its concerns about systemic threats to the rule of law in Poland. I supported this text, which mainly calls on the European Commission and the Polish Government to continue a constructive dialogue to ensure that the Constitutional Court in Poland clearly responds to the principle of judicial independence, a fundamental principle in Europe.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. Through this text, MEPs deplore the lack of cooperation of the Polish authorities with the Commission in the framework of the procedure opened under the rule of law. We also wanted to respond to other reforms (or reform projects) that threaten to violate fundamental rights, particularly public media laws, the police and civil service law, and the issue of abortion, where women, doctors and health care workers would face up to five years in prison. Through this resolution, we call on the Commission to carry out an assessment of the compliance of these laws with European law and the values of the Union. We also appeal to European public opinion. It is the integrity of the European Union that is at stake here.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution, expressing concern about recent developments in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights. The text stresses that it is of fundamental importance to ensure that the European values enshrined in the EU Treaty and the Polish constitution are respected in their entirety and that fundamental rights are guaranteed. The situation in Poland is worrying, particularly with regard to the paralysis of the Constitutional Court, which jeopardizes democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law in that country. Parliament welcomes the Commission's determination to pursue a constructive and productive dialogue with the Polish Government, with a view to finding quick and concrete solutions to threats to the rule of law. Parliament calls on the Polish government to cooperate with the Commission under the principle of fair cooperation enshrined in the Treaty. Finally, the resolution calls on the Commission, as guardian of the treaties, to monitor the follow-up given by the Polish authorities to the recommendations. I abstained from voting on any amendment tabled in plenary so as not to take the risk of losing the support of the majority of members on the text.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – I voted against the resolution condemning Poland because it concerns matters of subsidiarity and can be interpreted as a political attack, so it is counterproductive and harms the Polish people and the credibility of the European institutions. Resolving the internal political dispute surrounding the Polish Constitutional Court is not AN EU competence and, moreover, the rule of law mechanism is not included in the EU Treaties, so the procedure or the penalty to be imposed on Poland at the end is legally incomprehensible. The existing EU treaties do not give the Commission the power to launch such a measure, and there is therefore a risk that the mechanism based on the accountability of undefined concepts serves purely for political purposes and not for the interests of EU citizens. I do not consider it fortunate that, in the current growing anti-EU mood, Parliament and the Commission should intervene in the internal affairs of a sovereign Member State, rather than looking for reasonable solutions to the challenges facing europe as a whole, so I voted against the decision as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the joint resolution and for the alternative resolutions presented by ECR and ENF. This resolution is part of the crisis between the Polish Constitutional Court and the government. It is marked by unacceptable interference by the European Union in the internal affairs of a sovereign state, in contrast to the alternative ecR and ENF resolutions.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must respect the popular sovereignty and will of the Polish people and can only take actions to support and coordinate the Member States. Issues of public morality and family law do not fall within the competence of the Union.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "The reason I chose not to vote on the issues of abortion was because there was a very clear majority who would not vote through the resolution if these passages were included. Instead, we now had a very broad resolution focusing on constitutional affairs in Poland and the worrying developments in these. Abortion laws are of high relevance and should be discussed in another forum.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Polish government must cooperate with the European Commission and reach a compromise with the other Polish parties to resolve the constitutional crisis that endangers democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law in the country.  Recent events in Poland, such as the paralysis of the Constitutional Court (TC), endanger democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law in the country.  Issues relating to women's rights are also a cause for concern.  I welcome the European Commission's determination to pursue a constructive and productive dialogue with the Polish government with a view to finding rapid and concrete solutions to systemic threats to the rule of law.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Against the joint resolution: the Commission and the European Parliament appear to be the support of the government of judges under the guise of the rule of law.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are aware of the seriousness of the situation in Poland and its most recent developments, resulting from the rise to power of ultraconservative and reactionary forces. Attacks on the rights, freedoms and guarantees of citizens and workers have different expressions, such as political persecution and anti-communist laws, such as that prohibiting communist symbols in that country. A situation that this resolution, lucidly, omits. We do not turn off the emergence of far-right and Nazi-fascist forces from the reactionary, racist, xenophobic and undemocratic nature of the EU and its policies. This resolution is wounded by hypocrisy. One thing is just criticism and concern scares about attacks on democracy, freedom and the rights of peoples. It is another thing for the EU to become a judge and a paladin of democracy and human rights. Something intolerable, when today is well in sight its true anti-democratic and antisocial nature, as well as the way in which it disrespects and affronts human rights. It is up to each people to decide what measures and struggles to defeat those who attack their rights. Parliament is responsible for expressing solidarity with those fighting for democracy in Poland. Because we stand in solidarity with this struggle and because we defend the democratic rights and sovereignty of the Polish people, we abstained in this resolution.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The latest political developments in Poland, particularly in the area of the composition and effective functioning of the Constitutional Court, but also with regard to the publication and publication of decisions of the Constitutional Court, as well as the total ban on abortion, up to new laws that threaten media freedom, increase the powers of the police to represent an unimaginable and unjustifiable interference with the rule of law, as well as a threat to the fundamental freedoms of citizens and their way of life. Following the steps in question, the European Commission has opened a dialogue with the Polish Government to ensure that the rule of law is respected. The Polish authorities have unsatisfactoryly explained the threat to the rule of law and therefore the European Commission is forced to activate the mechanism and move to the second phase in support of the legal framework when it issues specific recommendations to the Polish authorities to address the problems associated with the protection of the rule of law.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution as the European Union should not interfere in Poland's internal affairs.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I totally vote against the reports on recent developments in Poland and their impact on the fundamental rights set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The EU must respect the popular sovereignty and will of the Polish people and can only take action to support and coordinate the Member States. Issues of public morality and family law do not fall within the competence of the Union.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that procedural safeguards and material conditions set in the Police Act for implementing secret surveillance are not sufficient to prevent its excessive use and unjustified interference with privacy and data protection of individuals. The issues that threaten the rule of law in Poland have not been satisfactorily resolved and I therefore believe there is a systematic threat to the rule of law in Poland. This is why I welcome the fact that, on 27 July 2016, the Commission activated the second stage of the Rule of Law Framework by making concrete recommendations to the Polish authorities on how to address its concerns. We are not prepared to accept political decisions which go against the fundamental values of the European Union.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, considering that the EU is based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights, values which are common to all Member States and which must therefore be respected. Despite intensive exchanges of views with the Polish authorities, the issues threatening the rule of law in Poland have not been resolved satisfactorily, so the Commission believes that there is a systemic threat to the rule of law in Poland and, in line with this situation, has made a number of concrete recommendations to the Polish authorities on how to respond to the institution's concerns Urgency.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on recent developments in Poland and their impact on the fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union because I believe that recent events deserve the utmost attention from the EU institutions. Given that the EU is founded on respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and democracy and aspires to a plural and non-discriminatory society, it is essential that the new Member States also aspire to continuously improve their democratic standards. I strongly support the EP's call for the Polish Government to cooperate with the Commission as provided for in the Treaties and to maintain its ambition to modernise and make Polish society even more open. It would be appropriate for the Polish parties to resolve this situation of constitutional crisis and to do their utmost to maintain the rule of law, protect the independence of judges and freedom of the press and protect individual and women's rights in particular. I am convinced that all these issues can soon be resolved through a constructive and fruitful dialogue between the Commission and the Polish Government and that the future of the citizens of that country will be a future of democracy and freedom.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution on 'Current developments in Poland and its impact on the fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union'. Why? I, too, take a critical view of some developments in Poland, but also in other EU countries. At the same time, I distance myself from the creeping arrogance of individual politicians, parties, and states to publicly brand the actions of others – without sufficient objectivity and balance. Such a development is neither fair nor in line with the spirit of the EU. Europe works like a family , which is why we need more "WE" than "you..."

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I strongly oppose the ENF Group's request. The right to a free judiciary and free media is not a purely national issue, but a European one. As the European Union, we must ensure that human rights are respected and acted in the same way in each of our Member States.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The Law and Justice party won the presidency of the Republic in August 2015 (Andrzej Duda) and the parliamentary elections in October 2015. This new government, because it is conservative, is attacked by the Eurocrats on two points: on public television, where a reform aims not to renew the mandates of the leaders of public television and radio. It is an exaggeration to speak of control over the media: it is simply a renewal of the governing bodies, as is also the case in France in case of alternation. on the Constitutional Court, the attack on Poland is even less justified: the new government has appointed some judges to this court. But the former ruling European party had itself appointed new judges to the Constitutional Court in May 2015. He wanted to maintain control of this institution, even in the event of an electoral defeat, without the European Commission and Parliament being outraged. The resolution they present therefore supports the government of judges and the media against the government elected by the people. Together with the Patriotic Members, we voted against this resolution and presented a counter-project in favour of Poland.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. After Hungary, Poland! Decidedly, as soon as a government does not please technocrats and high priests of good thinking, it is declared anti-democratic and must be punished. And never mind if he was democratically elected by a majority of citizens.  "The Commission is convinced of a systemic threat to the rule of law in Poland," we are told? Ah, she knows a thing or two about democracy and moral behaviour, the Commission, a cenacle of appointed officials who go to pay their address books to multinationals once their mandate is over! But when you ask ordinary Poles, you don't feel any concern about their individual freedoms. When you ask them about the Constitutional Court, you get the impression that the Tribunal did not behave with the previous government as the independent institution you describe. This explains this. Brecht said that when the people vote badly, the people must be dissolved. You are working on it in Europe through your massive immigration policies. But flute! I forgot! Aggravating circumstance: Poles do not want to be dissolved. That is why they elected this government! Definitely, they've got it all wrong!

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation of human rights in Poland, because it stresses the importance of defending fundamental rights as fundamental to a European country which must comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. In addition, our group added four amendments to the final resolution highlighting the need for protection of the rights of women and sexual minorities.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted a second resolution to support the Commission in its formal dialogue with the Polish government this year. It concerns policies pursued by the government of the day, which threaten the rule of law and fundamental rights in Poland. Voted by a large majority, this resolution allows MEPs to express their concerns about the constitutional crisis and other reforms, including the media, freedom of expression, privacy, and women's rights. The latter could be threatened by a draft law restricting access to abortion. The European Commission, the guardian of the Treaties, must continue to assess the policies and reforms being carried out by the Polish government, and their adequacy with the Union's values, which are non-negotiable. It can do so as part of the rule of law process it has initiated by sending an opinion and then recommendations to the Polish government. It is due to act by 27 October; the European Parliament will remain attentive to developments in this dialogue and the policy pursued by the Polish government.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Our position sends messages in two directions at the same time: a message to the Polish Government that we condemn and oppose its reactionary policies, racism and xenophobia, Islamophobia and inhuman anti-immigrant policy, anti-democratic over-concentration of powers, the worrying changes it promotes affecting individual rights, the right to privacy and freedom of expression. At the same time, we stress that the EU should show a similar annoyance at the violation of labour and social rights both in Poland and throughout the Union. At the same time, institutional anti-unionism in Poland and other Member States, as well as the exploitation of the situation of fundamental rights in Member States with a view to intervention in their internal affairs, should also be denounced. In any case, it is the peoples themselves, and not any third party, who will halt their countries' progress towards authoritarianism and deep preservation.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Joint Motion for Resolution regarding the recent developments in Poland. Unfortunately it seems that the current government in Poland is undermining their democratic institutions, thus threatening the rule of law. This runs counter to the fundamental principles of the EU. The ongoing constitutional crisis, the government’s control of the public media, and the politicisation of the national administration are only contributing to isolating the country and damaging citizens’ rights. It is therefore important that the current government restore the rule of law.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it raises concerns over the threat posed to the rule of law in Poland. I fully agree with its calls on the Polish government to comply with the articles contained in the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the ECHR with respect to democracy and respect for human rights.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding motion for a resolution. We do not support the EU’s power through the rule of law mechanism to interfere in the democratic processes within Member States. Whilst we take no position on the reforms instituted by the Polish Government, they are exercising a democratic mandate from a free and fair general election. Any issues regarding their compliance with the constitution is a matter for the Polish institutions. We remain concerned at the possible extension of the use of the rule of law mechanism to other Member States.  Furthermore, the legal basis for the EU’s interference is questionable. Under Protocol No 30, Poland is not bound by the Charter unless they are recognised in Polish law. As such, we voted against.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I have decided to support the resolution on Poland, which I consider to be measured. In view of the situation in Poland, we cannot remain silent and must instead encourage dialogue between the authorities and the European Commission, the guardian of the Treaties. Europe is a territory that has experienced terrible conflicts, dictatorships, totalitarian powers but has also defended the principles of democracy and the rule of law and disseminated values that are now universal. Observers in Poland are concerned about the paralysis of the Constitutional Court, whose decisions are not published in the Official Journal and whose members are prosecuted when they express their disagreements with the current government.  We are quick to judge the policies carried out in third countries, but yet today in Poland, certain laws on media freedom and the separation of powers threaten the stability and cohesion of the country.  I do not want to prejudge the outcome of the dialogue which is being conducted at the highest level, but I believe that the European Parliament has a duty to support the Commission's action when it comes to enforcing our common values and principles.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution submitted following statements by the Council and the Commission in accordance with Article 123(2) of the REGULATION. Rules of procedure on recent developments in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (2016/2774 (RSP)), as the situation in Poland has not improved in relation to the recent debate in spring this year.  This is a problem of several legislative proposals that are not in line with some of the EU's core values and principles. It is about the Public Media Act, the Police Act, the Criminal Procedure Act, the Public Administration Act, the Counterterrorism Act and other solutions that intrude on the independence of the media, the impartiality of public administration, the right to privacy, the right to a fair trial, the right to freedom of expression and other aspects of restricting human rights. Especially under the rule of law, the still unresolved situation around the Constitutional Court is dangerous.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The joint resolution on the situation in Poland is a full-standing attack on Poland's national sovereignty. This text is unacceptable. We believe that the EU does not have to interfere in the internal affairs of the Member States. That is why the ENL Group has tabled its own resolution, as has the ECR group. The ENF and ECR resolutions tend to protect the sovereignty of the Polish state The joint resolution is a model for the future of relations between the Commission and the Member States. The Commission and the European Parliament appear to be the support of the government of judges under the guise of the rule of law. This pervasive legalism from which the EU draws a discourse of normalization of states is in fact a prison discourse, which will one day be opposite to us.

name: Diane James (EFDD)

Under Protocol No 30, Poland is not bound by the Charter unless they are recognised in Polish law. As such, we voted against. Furthermore the legal basis for the EU's is questionable. Under Protocol No. 30 Poland is not bound by the Charter unless they are recognised in Polish law. As such we voted against.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution with my vote, because it is important that fundamental rights anchored in the Charter of Fundamental Rights are preserved in Poland and in the Union in general. I believe that this decision will allow us to have a productive discussion with the Polish Government and find a common solution.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: Written. 'The PvdA-Euro delegation considers it important to protect democracy and the rule of law in all EU Member States. That is why we support today's joint resolution on the situation in Poland. The government in Poland is breaking fundamental principles of a functioning democratic rule of law by, for example, reducing the independence of the Constitutional Court. This is contrary to European treaties and that is why we also support the European Commission, which has started legal proceedings against them. However, we cannot support the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL and the Verts/ALE group, even though we agree with the points raised on the substance, such as LGBT rights, women's rights and the protection of refugees. We believe that a European Parliament resolution on the rule of law in a Member State should focus on laws that the government has actually adopted. However, there are no legislative proposals on these issues in Poland. That is why we are abstaining on these amendments. Of course, we are closely following developments in Poland in the area of abortion and minority rights. If the Government adopts laws in this area that are contrary to European values, we will fully support any action taken by the EU.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Poland. The aim of this text is to draw up an overview of the situation on respect for human rights. On the other hand, I voted against the amendments leading to interference in Polish internal politics. Despite the disagreements that the European Union may have with the Polish government, it is necessary to maintain a constructive dialogue in order to find solutions that will be in everyone's interest.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution on the situation in Poland which essentially reminds the Polish Government that the EU is based on values ratified by the Polish people on the occasion of the 2003 referendum and operates on the basis of mutual belief that Member States respect democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The paralysis of the Constitutional Court and the refusal of the Polish Government to publish all its decisions jeopardise democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law in that country.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The decision to Polish in the EU was a political decision. It also had a civilisational dimension, guaranteeing poland security and the possibility of development. It can be said that this was an epochal decision. This decision also entailed the adoption of standards previously adopted and in force in the Community. These include the fundamental principles of the democratic rule of law. I have no doubt that these fundamental principles are being violated in Poland today. The tridivision of power is destroyed. The executive usurps the powers of the judiciary, starting with the Constitutional Court. This also applies to the sub-sub-subpoy of the public prosecutor's office and the judiciary. Action in the area of the media and the civil service is also unacceptable. Weakening the position of local government and limiting the powers of its bodies are actions contrary to the principle of subsidiarity contained in the Constitution of the Republic of Poland and to the European Charter of Local Self-Government, which Poland ratified Polish in 1994. We are members of the EU and these are our institutions, and the EC is the guardian of the treaties on which the Community is based. I therefore voted in favour of the document. This is a very sad day for me, because today, through the actions of the Government of PiS, Poland opens up a very short list of EU countries where democracy and the rule of law are at stake.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution. Poland has a democratically legitimate government, which must not be unfairly criticised by the European side. Such behaviour only leads to further antagonisms and will not enhance the EU in Poland. A better approach would be to approach each other diplomatically.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The rule of law has been essential to Poland’s success and we need to fight to ensure its protection. I fully support the Commission’s efforts to work with the Polish Government, even if these have so far received an uncooperative response. I voted in favour of the resolution as it urges the Polish Government to change course and ensure that the rule of law is respected.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 14 September 2016, we voted on the motion for a resolution on recent developments in Poland and its impact on fundamental rights, as set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. As I said on the vote on the last resolution relating to the current constitutional crisis in Poland. Personally, I am mostly strongly opposed to any interference by the European Union in internal political processes taking place not only in any Member State, but also outside the EU. However, here the escapades of the newly formed Polish Government reached such a critical threshold that this time I had to agree with the progress of the European institutions. Developments after the summer do not indicate that the Polish government is trying to resolve the situation amicablely. On the contrary, it shows that it does not intend to refrain from constantly trampling on its own constitutional and democratic principles. The current paralysis of the Constitutional Court clearly threatens democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law in the country. Constitutional democracy, the independence of courts and judges, fundamental rights, including freedom of the media and the right of a woman to decide freely on her own body, are universal principles that must always be recognised and supported by all EU Member States. I therefore supported the appeal to the Polish Government to resolve this constitutional crisis within three months and to find a compromise in line with the Recommendations of the European Commission.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution condemning Poland because it concerns matters of subsidiarity and can be interpreted as a political attack, thus counterproductive and harms the Polish people and the credibility of the European institutions. Resolving the internal political dispute surrounding the Polish Constitutional Court is not AN EU competence and, moreover, the rule of law mechanism is not included in the EU Treaties, so the procedure or the penalty to be imposed on Poland at the end is legally incomprehensible. The existing EU treaties do not give the Commission the power to launch such a measure, and there is therefore a risk that the mechanism based on the accountability of undefined concepts serves purely for political purposes and not for the interests of EU citizens. I do not consider it fortunate that, in the current growing anti-EU mood, Parliament and the Commission should intervene in the internal affairs of a sovereign Member State, rather than looking for reasonable solutions to the challenges facing europe as a whole, so I voted against the decision as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. With this resolution, the European Parliament reminds the Government of Poland of the values on which the European Union is founded: respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. These values are common to the Member States in a society characterised by pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men and were approved by the Polish people in the 2003 referendum. We are concerned not only about the constitutional crisis caused by the paralysis of the Constitutional Court and the Polish Government's refusal to publish all the judgments, but also by some recent legislative developments that are affected by the rights to freedom of expression, the independence of the media, privacy and, above all, fundamental human rights, including women's rights. It is imperative for us that the common European values listed in Article 2 TEU and the Polish Constitution are unconditionally respected. We therefore call on the Polish authorities to cooperate with the Commission in finding a way out of the current situation as soon as possible.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is built on a common set of values, enshrined in the EU treaty. These values are freedom, the rule of law and human rights. These values have made the Union, and the decision of Poland’s conservative Law and Justice government to change the way in which judges are appointed to the country’s Constitutional Tribunal represents a real threat to the EU’s common set of values (in particular the rule of law in Poland). In addition to that, the government’s decision to change the organisation and functioning of the Polish state threatens freedom of speech and transparency. To address these fundamental issues, the Polish Government should work with the EU. This is particularly important at a time when Europe’s institutions are being challenged by Eurosceptic parties and populist movements across the continent. Poland has become an immensely important test for the EU and the Union should prove that it is ever closer and united by our common set of values.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it seriously undermines Poland's sovereignty. Some amendments, which wanted to impose immigration and multiculturalism on this courageous country, were fortunately rejected with the support of the ENL group.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Since the ultra-conservative GOVERNMENT of the PIS came to power, Poland has embarked on a real purge of existing checks and balances, similar to what has been done in Hungary. Many journalists from the public media have been thanked, the heads of the main state administrations changed to supporters of the government, and the Constitutional Court is subject to a reform seeking to put it in step. At the end of July, the Commission sent Poland an official letter on respect for the rule of law denouncing the shenanigans against the Constitutional Court. This resolution supports the Commission's letter and is concerned about other movements, including the media law, changes in the police and administration, and changes to the penal code to facilitate prosecution. I support this text while calling for stronger measures to ensure that constitutional balances are not changed according to majorities. The maneuvers of populist forces in Poland and Hungary to lock down powers while maintaining democratic suffrage must be fought, otherwise they will become an example for all the continent's apprentice autocrats.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the joint resolution on Poland. The change of majority in Poland led to a crisis between the Constitutional Court and the legitimately elected Polish government. This crisis and the political options of the new government have led to the intervention of Brussels in defiance of the most basic notions of sovereignty and respect for the verdict of the ballot box. The joint resolution on the situation in Poland is a full-standing attack on Poland's national sovereignty. This text is unacceptable. The EU does not have to interfere in the internal affairs of the Member States. That is why the ENL group has tabled its own resolution.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The joint resolution on the situation in Poland is a full-standing attack on Poland's national sovereignty. The EU does not have to interfere in the internal affairs of the Member States. That is why the ENL Group has tabled its own resolution, as has the ECR group. Both resolutions are aimed at protecting Poland's sovereignty, which is why I voted for them but against the joint resolution, which aims to define a model of the future relations between the Commission and the Member States.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I share a deep concern about the situation of fundamental rights in Poland which, as in other States of the Union, has seen a strong regression. Growing xenophobia, attacks on the rights of women and LGTBi people, or the imposition of ultra-conservative profiles in different instances of the State, are realities that call into question the union's self-proclaimed democratic and plural character. However, this resolution puts European authorities who do not look after them in States where their political interests do not allow them to do so as guarantor of these freedoms. In addition, it presents women's rights as something dissociated from other fundamental rights, which have in their indivisibility a basic pillar. As is often the case, the right to dispose of one's own body becomes an accessory and second-order element. For all this, I have decided to abstain.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution that supports the Commission in its stance on Poland’s constitutional crisis.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the claim that the changes to the Polish Constitutional Court 'threaten democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law in Poland'. I do not agree with the urgent call on the Commission to assess the compliance of recent Polish laws with the 'values of the Union', namely the Law on public media, the Public Service Act, the Anti-Terrorism Act and others. It is a call for protectorate supervision that violates the principle of the sovereignty of the Polish Parliament.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union functions on the basis of a presumption of mutual trust that Member States respect democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, as recorded in the European Convention on Human Rights and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Recent developments in Poland, in particular the dispute over the composition and functioning of the Constitutional Court and the non-disclosure of Constitutional Court rulings have raised concerns about respect for the rule of law.  In his report after his visit to Poland, the Commissioner for Human Rights of the Council of Europe concluded that the recently adopted amendments to the Criminal Procedure Act and the Law on Prosecution jeopardise the right to a fair trial in criminal proceedings, the presumption of innocence and the right to defend themselves. This resolution calls on the Polish Government to cooperate with the Commission on the basis of the principle of loyal cooperation, as set out in the Treaty and to find a compromise to resolve the current constitutional crisis, so I supported the proposal for this resolution.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We can not keep silence when some Member States breach the rule of law. On my point of view EU structures, politicians and mass media have to pay attention to situation in Poland and other EU countries. The Copenhagen criteria should be fulfilled not only before accession into EU, but always.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, matters of public morality and family law are entrusted to the exclusive competence of the Member States of the Union. In the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, Poland stressed the exclusive competence of the Member States to carry out legislative activities in the fields of public morality, family law, the protection of human dignity and respect for human physical and moral integrity. The application of the Charter vis-à-vis Poland thus has legitimate restrictions. Poland is not bound by the principles of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union if these principles are not recognised in the framework of Poland's legislation or practices. With the resolution, MEPs confirmed that they respect the rights of the Republic of Poland as a sovereign state and recognise that the areas of legal relations to which the Republic of Poland has not committed to joining the EU are an internal matter for it. The EP pointed out that the new internal legislation of the Republic of Poland (Anti-Terrorism Act, Code of Criminal Procedure, Public Prosecutions Act, Public Service Broadcasting Act...) should not apply to the EU institutions, given the principle of subsidiarity. The objectives and tasks of these laws can be better achieved by the Polish authorities. I supported the motion for a resolution because it is based on respect for applicable law in the Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on recent developments in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights, as set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, because this proposal is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the joint resolution.  The European Union, following the change of majority in Poland and the resulting constitutional crisis, has largely interfered in the internal affairs of the country, going against the sovereignty of one of its Member States. We strongly condemn this interference. That is why our group has tabled its own resolution.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we discussed a motion for a resolution highlighting recent developments in Poland. I am referring to the situation, for example, around the filling of judges' posts at the Constitutional Court. In the resolution, we call on the Commission to act objectively and impartially in order to fulfil its role as guardian of the Treaties exactly as defined by the EU's founding treaties. In protecting the fundamental values on which the EU is founded, it is necessary to proceed objectively and measure all by the same metre. The motion for a resolution tabled seems to me to be balanced, drawing Poland's attention to some problematic issues, but at the same time strongly asking the Commission how exactly to proceed. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is to prevent interference with Poland's sovereignty. I can only support that, because the Commission is the executive body of the Union and not a political body.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The joint resolution on the situation in Poland is a full-standing attack on Poland's national sovereignty. We believe that the EU does not have to interfere in the internal affairs of the Member States. That is why the ENL Group has tabled its own resolution, as has the ECR group. Both resolutions are aimed at protecting Poland's sovereignty, which is why I voted for them but against the joint resolution, which aims to define a model of the future relations between the Commission and the Member States.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential to ensure that the common European values set out in Article 2 OF the ET and in the Polish Constitution are fully respected and that fundamental rights, as defined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, are safeguarded. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this cross-party resolution on the situation in Poland as it stresses the importance of protecting and promoting European values.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of this resolution on the situation in Poland and its impact on fundamental rights. While the constitutional crisis remains unresolved and the commission's dialogue under the Rule of Law Mechanism is still ongoing, it was crucial that Parliament position itself and send a clear message to the Polish authorities. It was therefore crucial that the text should receive the votes required to become parliament's position. It is with the awareness of this need that I have chosen to vote for the text as supported by the majority of political groups. If I essentially agree with the amendments to the text tabled by other groups, I have chosen to follow my group by abstaining on most of these amendments. Knowing that the Polish authorities will have to respond next month to the Commission's recommendation under the Rule of Law Mechanism, Parliament had to be able to agree on a common position before that date while remaining sufficiently committed to the Polish government.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on recent developments in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights as laid down in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, since I agree with the text. However, I have never supported, and I have voted against, any references to abortion and to women’s sexual and reproductive health rights, which, in my opinion, are strictly a competence of the Member States.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the subject, the ENF and ECR political groups submitted separate motions for resolutions, while the PPE, S&D, ALDE, GUE/NGL and Verts/ALE Groups tabled a joint motion for a resolution. I voted in favour of the five-party joint motion.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. These are resolutions following The interference of Brussels in Polish domestic politics. Indeed, the change of majority has led to a crisis between the Constitutional Court and the newly elected government. We vehemently oppose the joint resolution, which is a clear attack on Poland's sovereignty and which once again highlights the EU's scandalous interference in the internal affairs of the Member States. However, we support the two alternative proposals tabled by the ENF and ECR groups respectively.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. While the resolutions defended by the ENL or ECR groups are respectful of Poland's sovereignty, the joint resolution is absolutely not, and I strongly oppose them.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on recent developments in Poland and their impact on the fundamental rights enshrined in the European Union's Charter of Fundamental Rights. In particular, the text recommends that European leaders, in the current context of Brexit and the rise of extremism in Europe, consider ways to reform the European Union in order to better respect the principle of subsidiarity and bring citizens closer to the decision-making process.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in Poland is of great concern, as recent developments risk undermining the fundamental values underlying the European Union. In particular, the paralysis of the Constitutional Court, disputes over its operation and pressure from the Polish Government towards public information services threaten democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law itself. Unfortunately, the dialogue carried out by the Commission and the Polish Government authorities in an attempt to resolve the situation has not shown any significant progress or produced the desired results.  Similarly, the Venice Commission has established that the fundamental rights of Polish citizens are not adequately protected by the new law on police forces promoted by the Warsaw Executive. For these reasons, the Commission has formalised its recommendations to the Polish authorities, with the intention of remedying the crisis as soon as possible, given the systematic threats to the rule of law in the country. The European Parliament, as a direct expression of the peoples of Europe, cannot accept any political choice that is clearly at odds with the values underlying the Union itself.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against the motion for a resolution regarding the recent development in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – On the joint motion for a resolution on recent developments in Poland, I and my Sinn Féin colleagues voted in favour. The resolution identifies huge concerns in relation to civil liberties, adherence to democratic necessities and environmental and constitutional malpractice. The resolution also places a large focus on strict adherence to both the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention of Human Rights. For those reasons we supported the resolution.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This is intended to legitimise an interference with Poland's sovereignty. I would have rejected this in the vote, because the Commission is the executive body of the Union and not a political body.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Against the backdrop of recent complex events, the resolution calls on Poland to respect European principles and to comply with democratic legislation. It is important to end Poland's constitutional crisis, to ensure freedom of the press and media and to engage in dialogue with opposition leaders.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding motion for a resolution. We do not support the EU’s power through the rule of law mechanism to interfere in the democratic processes within Member States. Whilst we take no position on the reforms instituted by the Polish Government, they are exercising a democratic mandate from a free and fair general election. Any issues regarding their compliance with the constitution is a matter for the Polish institutions. We remain concerned at the possible extension of the use of the rule of law mechanism to other Member States.  Furthermore, the legal basis for the EU’s interference is questionable. Under Protocol No 30, Poland is not bound by the Charter unless they are recognised in Polish law. As such, we voted against.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I do not consider that human rights, democracy and the rule of law in Poland are at risk. It is true that the Polish government has made some changes, but the information placed in the international media is not based on reliable data and does not reflect the actual situation. As regards Chapters 3, 4 and 5 on the state of fundamental civil rights - freedom of assembly, freedom of speech and media freedom, there have been no significant legal changes in this regard, as the exercise of freedom of assembly before and after the last parliamentary elections has not changed.  Poland's largest association of journalists supported the changes to the Media Act, saying they were much needed and enabled media pluralism. Comparative analysis shows that the legal changes introduced in this area are similar to solutions that exist in Western European countries such as Italy, Spain or France. When we talk about women's rights and reproductive health, Poland has excellent laws, and the data shows that maternal mortality in Poland is among the lowest in the world, precisely because of good legal regulation.  There are problems with the functioning of the Constitutional Court, but Poland is able to solve them on its own without interference from external factors. Poland is an independent state, its government was elected by the people in democratic elections, it has its legitimacy and legitimacy and we must respect that.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The change of majority in Poland brought with it a crisis between the Constitutional Court and the legitimately elected Polish government. This crisis and the conservative options of the new government led to the intervention of Brussels, in defiance of the most basic notions of sovereignty and respect for the verdict of the ballot box. The joint resolution on the situation in Poland is a full-standing attack on Poland's national sovereignty. This text is unacceptable and I therefore vote against it. The EU does not have to interfere in the internal affairs of the Member States. That is why the ENL Group has tabled its own resolution, as has the ECR Group, and I support these alternative motions for resolution.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I share the concern expressed in the resolution regarding the reforms promoted by the Polish Government. The Law on Public Media, the amendment of the Police Act, the law amending the Criminal Code and the Law on Public Prosecutors' Rights, the amendment of the Civil Service Act and the Anti-Terrorism Act risk creating a regulatory framework incompatible with primary and secondary EU law, with the values on which the Union is founded and with the Polish Constitution itself. Respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights is at great risk. Further concern, in this context, is the paralysis of the Constitutional Court determined by the Warsaw Government itself, thus preventing any constitutional control of the new legislation. I also share the regret at the Polish Government's refusal to reach a compromise solution with the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, based on the principles of loyal cooperation and subsidiarity, and on the recommendations drawn up by the Venice Commission. I therefore join in the appeal to the Polish Government to find a solution soon that guarantees full respect for the rule of law and fundamental freedoms.

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: Written. 'The PvdA-Euro delegation considers it important to protect democracy and the rule of law in all EU Member States. That is why we support today's joint resolution on the situation in Poland. The government in Poland is breaking fundamental principles of a functioning democratic rule of law by, for example, reducing the independence of the Constitutional Court. This is contrary to European treaties and that is why we also support the European Commission, which has started legal proceedings against them. However, we cannot support the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL and the Verts/ALE Group. Even if we agree on the content of the points raised, such as LGBT rights, women's rights and the protection of refugees. We believe that a European Parliament resolution on the rule of law in a Member State should focus on laws that the government has actually adopted. However, there are no legislative proposals in Poland on these issues. That is why we are abstaining from these amendments. Of course, we are closely following developments in Poland in the area of abortion and minority rights. If the Government adopts laws in this area that are contrary to European values, we will fully support any action taken by the EU.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution to reiterate the importance of the Polish Government being aware of the urgency of resolving the constitutional crisis in which the country is currently in. The aim of this text is not to sue the government but to encourage it to engage in more dialogue with the European Commission in order to find a way out of the various breaches of the rule of law found in Poland over the recent period. It must be remembered that Poland, through the voice of its sovereign people, decided in 2003 to join the European Union, it is to belong to a set of states that share common fundamental values and principles.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding motion for a resolution. We do not support the EU’s power through the rule of law mechanism to interfere in the democratic processes within Member States. Whilst we take no position on the reforms instituted by the Polish Government, they are exercising a democratic mandate from a free and fair general election. Any issues regarding their compliance with the constitution is a matter for the Polish institutions. We remain concerned at the possible extension of the use of the rule of law mechanism to other Member States.  Furthermore, the legal basis for the EU’s interference is questionable. Under Protocol No 30, Poland is not bound by the Charter unless they are recognised in Polish law. As such, we voted against.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. Belonging to the European Union implies a foundation of fundamental values based on the rule of law and democracy. If a single Member State violates these principles, it undermines the integrity of the Whole Union. That is why the Commission has initiated a dialogue with the authorities in Poland, where the balance of power is being put at risk by the paralysis of the Constitutional Court and the liberticidal reforms of the conservative government. MEPs support the Commission's approach to finding a solution to this constitutional crisis. They are concerned about this systemic threat to the rule of law, which undermines the protection of fundamental rights, including media freedom and pluralism, as well as women's rights. If I support the objective of this text, I would have liked it to be more ambitious on the need to adopt sanctions in the event that the Polish government persists in its refusal to cooperate. It is the credibility of the Union that is at question. Above all, all this reinforces the need for a European Pact for the Rule of Law, in order to ensure that European values are respected on a daily basis in all the Member States of the Union.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the EU is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, and that these values are common to the Member States, it is essential to ensure that the common European values set out in Article 2 OF the ETS and the Polish Constitution are fully respected and that fundamental rights are fully respected and that fundamental rights are fully respected and that fundamental rights are fully , as defined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, are safeguarded.  This reiterates the position on the situation in Poland, in particular with regard to the paralysis of the Constitutional Court, which endangers democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law in Poland. Among other concerns expressed is the fact that, to date, no compromise solution has been found and that the Recommendations of the Venice Commission have not been implemented; it is also regretted that the Polish Government refuses to publish all judgments of the Constitutional Court. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential to ensure that European values are fully respected and that fundamental rights, as defined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, are safeguarded. The situation in Poland, in particular as regards the paralysis of the Constitutional Court, endangers democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law. Poland shall take into account the recommendations made with regard to: the media law, ensuring the provision of independent, impartial and reliable content; the law amending the law of the police, taking into account their disproportionate interference with the right to respect for private life; the law amending the Criminal Code, taking into account the need to respect the EU acquis on procedural rights and the fundamental right to a fair trial; the law amending the law on civil service, taking into account the serious risk of politicisation of the Polish administration; the law on combating terrorism, taking into account the right to freedom of expression; and other issues of concern, as they may constitute violations of EU law and fundamental human rights, including women's rights.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the degrading state of law and the quality of democracy in Poland. The European Commission has been investigating the recent reforms of the Polish Constitutional Court and state control over the public media for months. The Commission has also found a lack of cooperation on the part of the Polish authorities and will therefore continue with the next phase of the gradual process envisaged by the mechanism.  Finally, another really worrying issue is the absolute abortion ban planned by the Government that is incompatible with reproductive autonomy rights. In addition, the Venice Commission has raised questions about the use of listening practices and control of citizens' communications included in the new Police Law.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the situation in Poland, because the constitutional crisis that this Member State is going through, as well as the responses to it, are worrying to say the least. The Polish government must immediately follow the recommendations of the Venice Commission and the European Commission in order to comply with the values of the European Union, to which Poland has subscribed. The European Union must do everything in its power to uphold democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. I am particularly concerned and I am outraged that the independence of the media, freedom of expression, the right to privacy and justice are threatened by the attitude of the Polish authorities.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. Since coming to power in October 2015, the conservative Polish government has been pursuing a reform programme that has provoked multiple opinions from the Venice Commission since the beginning of 2016 and has led the European Commission to question this government and the European Parliament to adopt a resolution on 13 April 2016, as the measures taken pose a threat to the rule of law in Poland. The paralysis of the Constitutional Court violates the principle of separation of powers and allows the government to introduce new laws that deliberately threaten the rights to privacy, freedom of expression, the right to a fair trial, women's rights and the impartiality of the civil service. The adopted motion for resolution supports the Commission's initiative, which adopted an opinion and made a recommendation under the rule of law framework. The proposal also calls on the Polish government to cooperate in finding appropriate solutions to strengthen the rule of law in Poland. The preservation of the rule of law and the rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights are an absolute necessity, so I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which once again reflects the European Union's concerns about systemic threats to the rule of law in Poland and the actions of the current Polish government. This resolution focuses on recent and rapid changes in legislation taking place in areas such as the public media, or the status of the civil service, without proper consultation with the Constitutional Court, which is also plagued by many difficulties related to its bias. The aim of this resolution is to recall Parliament's support in the constructive and productive dialogue launched by the European Commission in order to reach solutions in a spirit of cooperation between the European institutions and the Polish Government.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation of human rights in Poland, because it stresses the importance of defending fundamental rights as fundamental to a European country which must comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. In addition, our group added four amendments to the final resolution highlighting the need for protection of the rights of women and sexual minorities.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote on this motion carries the following reservations: I am not convinced that when the European Parliament is seeking to censure the actions of governments of our Member States, we are following comparable methods of assessment and applying ‘principles’ to situations in a transparent and fair manner.  In most situations of national crisis and controversy, especially in polarised democracies, the partisan clash of political formations can be huge and intimately influenced by the subterranean strategies being followed by vested interests.
