Assessing rights and wrongs in such situations can be extremely difficult even for objective observers within the national context (should they exist). Doing so from within this Parliament is even more complex and liable to error. Our deliberations here are also subject – though we may try to believe otherwise – to political calculations and manipulations, extraneous to the national situation about which we try to reach a judgement. Frankly in the case of Poland, though ideologically I disagree with the approaches and beliefs of its present government, I doubt whether sufficient weight has been given to the anti-democratic  distortions of the previous government which have led to what one could all the ‘over’-reactions of the present one.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I share a deep concern about the situation of fundamental rights in Poland which, as in other States of the Union, has seen a strong regression. Growing xenophobia, attacks on the rights of women and LGTBi people, or the imposition of ultra-conservative profiles in different instances of the State, are realities that call into question the union's self-proclaimed democratic and plural character. However, this resolution puts European authorities who do not look after them in States where their political interests do not allow them to do so as guarantor of these freedoms. In addition, it presents women's rights as something dissociated from other fundamental rights, which have in their indivisibility a basic pillar. As is often the case, the right to dispose of one's own body becomes an accessory and second-order element. For all this, I have decided to abstain.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the latest developments in Poland and its impact on fundamental rights. I am sorry that we must once again return to the situation in Poland, which I consider to be an advanced democratic country. However, the situation has not improved. Although the recent amendment to Poland's Constitutional Court Act, after pressure from the public and the international community, abandoned some of the original controversial proposals, such as the possibility of parliament dismissing constitutional judges, shortcomings remain. The need for an 11-member quorum with a simultaneous number of twelve constitutional judges or the abandonment of the possibility of priority hearing of complaints cannot be accepted in terms of the effective functioning of the constitutional tribunal. Nor does the government's resusion to publish a constitutional court decision have no place in the rule of law. The Constitutional Court should not be the subject of political games. I hoped that public pressure would lead the Polish government to self-reflection. It's the other way around. In the meantime, other controversial regulations on the edge of constitutionality have been adopted, such as an amendment to the Police Act or anti-terrorism legislation, which is now under review before a crippled constitutional court. I myself have experienced a totalitarian period of one political party rule and the trampling of the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary. I therefore hope that the one-colour government of the Law and Justice party will soon exchange a sense of power intoxication for respect for democracy, human rights and the rule of law. At least the citizens of Poland deserve it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the European Commission cannot enter into the sovereignty of the Member States of the European Union. However, they undertook to comply with commonly agreed and agreed rules through their accession. This concerns, in particular, the independence of the courts and freedom of speech and the press and respect for democratic procedures in the exercise of state authority. Poland has moved away from these principles in recent months, but I believe that there will soon be a correction.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution on recent developments in Poland and its impact on fundamental rights, as set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. In my opinion, the resolution adopted by the European Parliament represents a factual and rational assessment of the developments so far in Poland. On the basis of the conclusions reached by the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe and others, the European Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, has decided to enter into an informal dialogue with the Polish Government, which, I hope, will result in concrete solutions that would eliminate objective threats to the rule of law in Poland, such as preventing the proper functioning of the Constitutional Court. The EU operates on the basis of the presumption of mutual trust that Member States act in accordance with democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights enshrined, for example, in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. It is right that the European Commission is monitoring compliance with the values to which EU countries, including Poland, have committed their membership. Poland must not lose its hard-won democracy and freedom.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. With this resolution, the EU is strengthening the unwritten principle of selective tolerance.  If Greece, France, Germany, Spain, Portugal or Italy permanently violate existing Community law, for example in asylum, euro and budgetary policy, then the European Commission is keeping an eye on it. However, if a Conservative government is democratically elected to office in a Member State and implements its electoral programme, the EU Commissioners will arrive in droves and look for pretexts to denounce conservative governments down to the last detail. Poland should set an example: those who do not meet the ideas of the left-liberal EU officials will be punished. This resolution is intended to contribute to this. That is why I voted against. And one more wish: let the Polish PiS government stand firm and put Mr Tusk, Mr Juncker and Mr Timmermans in a friendly and determined manner. If there could indeed have been infringements, then only the ECJ has the power to decide. But not the ideologically acting EU Commission.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The European Parliament recalls that the European Union is based on values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights. The division of power and the independence of the judiciary are at the heart of the democratic system and must not be compromised.  Recent developments in Poland, such as the dispute over the composition and functioning of the Constitutional Court and the non-disclosure of Constitutional Court rulings, raise concerns about respect for the rule of law. Effective, impartial and professional public administration is a feature of democratic government, and poland's new Public Administration Act jeopardised this principle. I support the proposal for a resolution on recent developments in Poland, as I think it is essential to establish full respect for common European values as well as fundamental rights. I believe that Poland needs to be given all assistance in finding solutions to strengthen the rule of law.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a joint resolution on the latest developments in Poland and their impact on the fundamental rights of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  On 27 July 2016, the European Commission issued a recommendation to Poland in the context of the rule of law procedure. The main concerns concerned the appointment of members of the Constitutional Court, amendments to the Constitutional Court law and the effectiveness of the assessment of the constitutionality of the new legislation. Poland must lift the controversial legislative decisions within three months.  I support the resolution, which welcomes the Commission's strong intention to pursue a constructive and fruitful dialogue with the Polish Government in order to find a swift and concrete solution to these systemic threats to the rule of law.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the resolution tabled we abstained. Our position sends messages in two directions at the same time: It sends a message to the Polish Government that we condemn and oppose its reactionary policies, racism and xenophobia, Islamophobia and inhuman anti-immigrant policy, anti-democratic over-concentration of powers, the worrying changes it promotes affecting individual rights, the right to privacy and freedom of expression. At the same time, however, we support hypocrisy and selectivity from the dominant circles of the EU who are not bothered by the violation of labour and social rights, who do not denounce institutional anti-communism in Poland, who use the situation of fundamental rights in Member States to intervene in their internal affairs. In any case, however, it is the peoples themselves who will halt their countries' progress towards authoritarianism and deep preservation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must respect the popular sovereignty and will of the Polish people and can only take actions to support and coordinate the Member States and any attempt to interfere in the exclusive competences of the States is considered to be devoid of legitimacy. Issues of public morality and family law do not fall within the competence of the Union.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a decision because I consider it to be a major breakthrough in relations between the European Union and its Member States, through the functioning of the democratic rule of law, the control of European democratic principles and the rule of law and possible sanctions for infringements. I consider it perfectly justified and well founded by EU law that the steps taken by the new Polish Government towards the downsizing or restriction of democratic institutions, in particular the curtailment of the powers of the Constitutional Court, should be examined by the Commission, discussed with the Polish Government and, if necessary, proposed sanctions. I am convinced that, with today's decision, the EP can also contribute to solving the constitutional crisis in Poland. In considering my vote, as a Hungarian opposition Member, I could not ignore the important lesson that, if the Commission and the European Parliament had acted with similar consistency in the past against the Hungarian Government, which had long violated European democratic standards in a similar or even more serious way, the state of democracy in my country might not have worsened to the present situation.

name: Paul Tang (S&D)
text: Written. 'The PvdA-Euro delegation considers it important to protect democracy and the rule of law in all EU Member States. That is why we support today's joint resolution on the situation in Poland. The government in Poland is breaking fundamental principles of a functioning democratic rule of law by, for example, reducing the independence of the Constitutional Court. This is contrary to European treaties and that is why we also support the European Commission, which has started legal proceedings against them. However, we cannot support the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL and the Verts/ALE group, even though we agree with the points raised on the substance, such as LGBT rights, women's rights and the protection of refugees. We believe that a European Parliament resolution on the rule of law in a Member State should focus on laws that the government has actually adopted. However, there are no legislative proposals on these issues in Poland. That is why we are abstaining on these amendments.  Of course, we are closely following developments in Poland in the area of abortion and minority rights. If the Government adopts laws in this area that are contrary to European values, we will fully support any action taken by the EU.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Disputes in recent months over worrying political developments in Poland have been an event of maximum interest for the European institutions. The involvement of government authorities in the functioning of the Constitutional Tribunal, including the obstruction of binding decisions, constitutes a flagrant violation of the democratic spirit of the European Union.  Attempts to introduce an abortion ban, to amend the Public Media Act, the Police Law, the Law of the Prosecutor General and the Code of Criminal Procedure are measures that can only raise our awareness towards the defence of the fundamental values of the Union.  The dialogue between the Polish European and national institutions did not lead to any notable results, although the Venice Commission itself issued critical views on the new national legislation. In these circumstances, in July, the Commission activated the second stage of the Rule of Law Monitoring Framework, making new recommendations to the Polish authorities. I believe that it is time for the European Parliament to give a signal of the defence of the fundamental rights of European citizens in all Member States. This resolution is only a first step in this, but it is a measure that is self-evident. I support the adoption of the current resolution, so that Polish democracy can be saved.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have, of course, voted in favour of this resolution, which is based on four precepts: is of the opinion that any attempt to interfere in the exclusive competences of the Member States, including in the internal affairs of Poland, is unfounded; solemnly reaffirms its commitment to the principles of national identity and sovereignty, which form an indivisible whole with the principle of freedom; recalls that the Commission is not a political body, but the executive body of the Union and must therefore strictly respect the treaties, including Article 5 of the Treaty on the European Union and Articles 3 to 6 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union; its President is responsible for forwarding this resolution to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the recent developments in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights as laid down in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which calls on the Polish Government to solve its constitutional crisis within the three-month deadline set by the European Commission in late July.  While I fully respect Poland’s sovereignty and its democratically elected government, the decision of its government to refuse to seat five judges appointed to the Constitutional Tribunal by the previous government is highly worrying and seriously threatens the rule of law. It is essential that the Polish Government finds a compromise regarding this matter, and demonstrates its firm commitment to the rule of law and democracy.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Commission's many attempts at dialogue have been unsuccessful. The situation in Poland remains very worrying and the rule of law is at risk.  I, together with the majority of my colleagues in the European Parliament, support the Commission in the proceedings and express my determination that Article 7 should be activated if things do not change; this would lead, in an unprecedented way, to the suspension of Poland's voting rights in the Council. We also wanted to draw the Commission's attention to other reforms under way that threaten to undermine fundamental rights, and whose compliance with European law must be assessed. Thus the law on public media, on the police, on the fight against terrorism or other bills infringing on women's rights, contradict Poland's adherence to European values.  The European Commission must guarantee the rule of law and it is its duty to do all it can to ensure that it is respected.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the latest developments in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights enshued in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, because Declaration No 61 of the Republic of Poland, as regards the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, stresses that the Charter does not in any way prejudice the right of Member States to perform legislative functions in the areas of public morality, family law and the protection of human dignity and respect for human and mental integrity.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Regretfully, the European Union has to deal with the human rights issues of some Member States. I support the indignation reflected in the resolution and also raise concerns that the political leadership of an EU Member State shows little respect to basic principles of the Union. European institutions should be provided with better tools to influence individual Member States’ policies in order to protect democracy and human rights.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation of human rights in Poland, because it stresses the importance of defending fundamental rights as fundamental to a European country which must comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. In addition, our group added four amendments to the final resolution highlighting the need for protection of the rights of women and sexual minorities.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in the vote on this report on Poland because I feel there are differences of attitude in Europe depending on the political majorities in place in different Member States. In particular I would mention Amendment 2, referring to problems of other countries with regard the rule of law and respect for democratic principles, which reads: ‘whereas other countries have had a deteriorating rule of law situation that would need to be investigated by the Commission, considering that the rule of law represents a common standard that should be respected and applied equally by all Member States’. In particular, I would like to see the same attitude on the part of the Commission with regard the independence of the Spanish Constitutional Court and the independence of the media in Spain.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The change of majority in Poland has led to a crisis between the Constitutional Court and the legitimately elected Polish government. This crisis and the conservative options of the new government triggered the intervention of Brussels, in defiance of the most basic notions of sovereignty and respect for the verdict of the ballot box.  The joint resolution on the situation in Poland is a full-standing attack on Poland's national sovereignty. This text is unacceptable. We believe that the EU does not have to interfere in the internal affairs of the Member States.  The Commission and the European Parliament appear to be the support of the government of judges under the guise of the rule of law. This pervasive legalism, from which the EU draws a discourse of normalization of states, is in fact a prison discourse that will one day be opposed to us.  I voted AGAINST the joint resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is based on the values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. These values are common in the Member States, in a society of pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men. By my vote, I supported the group's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation of human rights in Poland, because it stresses the importance of defending fundamental rights as fundamental to a European country which must comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. In addition, our group added four amendments to the final resolution highlighting the need for protection of the rights of women and sexual minorities.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Seek to establish a constructive and effective dialogue with the Polish Government with a view to finding concrete solutions quickly.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on recent events in Poland. According to poland's Constitutional Court, the provisions of several laws passed in Poland are unconstitutional. Freedom of expression and assembly has narrowed in the country and the spirit of the EU Treaty has been blatantly violated. I believe that the observations of the Venice Commission and the EUROPEAN Commission are heading in the right direction, and Poland, in cooperation with the EU, must correct the mistakes made and return to the policies of a Member State under the EU Treaty for the sake of democracy, the people and Poland itself.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this European Parliament resolution, which is concerned about the evolution of democracy and respect for fundamental rights in Poland. Questioning the separation of powers, freedom of the press by a muzzle of the media, undermining the presumption of innocence under the pretext of fighting terrorism, to name but a few examples, are all violations of rights that are unacceptable in Poland, Hungary but also in many other European countries. The resolution adopted, however, is relatively timid in many respects; I particularly regret that the GUE/NGL amendments on the right to abortion were not voted on, in particular because of the abstention of my Social Democrat colleagues. On 21 September, the Polish Parliament is due to debate a new law which, if passed, would effectively prohibit any voluntary termination of pregnancy in Poland. The European Parliament should have voted strongly on this point in support of Polish women After Hungary, this resolution on Poland demonstrates the need for a tool to prohibit any regression of fundamental rights within the EU. There's an emergency.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The situation in Poland results from the rise to power of ultraconservative and reactionary forces. Well beyond the conditioning of the action of the Constitutional Court, freedoms, rights and guarantees of citizens and workers are attacked.  Political persecution and the prohibition of communist symbols in that country are of this serious expression. We do not turn off the emergence of these and other far-right and Nazi-fascist forces of the reactionary, racist, xenophobic and undemocratic nature of the Policies of the European Union itself and a continued strategy of crushing the sovereignty of peoples. Situations and policies that we strongly condemn and systematically denounce. This resolution is wounded by hypocrisy. Fair criticisms and concerns about attacks on democracy, freedom and the rights of peoples are not compatible with gross interference in sovereign countries, because sovereignty is also a democratic right.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution states that intervention in national affairs, which are exclusively the competence of a Member State, is unjustified. The principle of identity and national sovereignty cannot be negotiated. It is also pointed out that the Commission is not a political body, but an executive body. I have therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on recent developments in Poland and their impact on the fundamental rights enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Due to the alarming political developments in Poland, relating to the functioning of the Constitutional Court and the failure to publish its judgments and, above all, the initiative to introduce an absolute ban on abortion are worrying elements that undermine respect for the rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Although the Commission has opened a dialogue with the Polish Government to ensure respect for the rule of law, no progress has been made in this direction.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. Motion for a resolution B8-0977/2016 amounts to unilateral and unqualified EU interference in Poland's internal affairs and must therefore be rejected. B8-0865/2016 and B8-0978/2016, on the other hand, underline Poland's right to the sovereign shaping of its internal relations and do not see the Constitution or fundamental rights being violated, as claimed by the EU, which is why consent was called for here.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am deeply concerned with the ongoing constitutional crisis in Poland, and the Polish government’s continued assault on the country’s democratic institutions. Moreover, the current government’s reactionary position on women’s rights, and on women’s rights to sexual and reproductive health in particular, is a grave concern, which I believe must be addressed specifically by the European Parliament and EU institutions.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Once again this year we have witnessed a buffoon. The European Parliament is dealing with a fictitious crisis of democracy in Poland. Meanwhile, the EU is experiencing its biggest ever crisis. I am astonished by the arrogance and conceit that pour out of the text of the resolution. I have the impression that only a short dedication is missing here: "For ourselves – with admiration, which we owe ourselves."  This resolution does not solve any of Europe's real problems. On the contrary, it is a model example of the EU hypocrisy that led the UK to decide on Brexit. The resolution brightly encroaches on the internal competences of a Member State, closes its eyes to the growing threat of terrorism in Europe and wants to block citizens' initiatives – although it is the Polish government that accuses it of human rights violations. The height of hypocrisy is the allegation of the destruction of the Białowieża Forest, when the obligation to take action stems from EU directives.  Dear! No one will thank you for this document, apart from the Polish opposition. The naivety with which you are fighting the fictional crisis of Polish democracy would be ridiculous if it were not for the fact that it is so painful. I come to mind a story about a certain nudity, on which it is written: "Here rests the Stranger who did good and bad things. He did good things – he did bad things, bad things – he did well." Your business closes exactly in these words.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this resolution because I consider it to be a balanced and constructive description of the situation in Poland. From my point of view, this whole situation is not about Poland as such, but it is a debate with Poland and the Polish Government, respectively. Poland itself initiated this debate through disputes with the Venice Commission, and today it must face the consequences. I believe that, in the current situation, the European Union must defend not only European law, but also the very foundations of Poland's constitutionality.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ by joint resolution of five political groups, the European Parliament has once again responded to political and legislative developments in Poland for several times. In addition to the recent debate on tightening abortion rules, he also addressed changes to the criminal code, changes to media law, the judiciary and a new anti-terrorism law. However, from my point of view, the report on the situation in Poland is unfortunate. It deals with topics falling within the competence of a Member State in a number of provisions, and I am opposed to the European Union interfering in these exclusive competences. Moreover, we are at a time when, in order to preserve the European Union, we need to find what unites us, not divides us, to focus on common themes such as job creation and security, among other issues.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As an MEP of the Polish delegation, I decided to support the motion for a resolution (B8-0865/2016) because I agree with the counter-argument presented by the Polish side. Because the EU cannot interfere with the exclusive competences of the Member States; Polish government did not submit any inconspicuous legislative proposals, Poland did not sign the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. I consider it inappropriate to interfere in the internal affairs of the Republic of Poland with such oppressive interference. As an MEP of the Polish delegation, I decided to vote against the motion for a resolution (B8-0977/2016) on the fact that the allegations made to the Polish side are out of step with the facts.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The next resolution on Polish adopted by the European Parliament demonstrates how much the EU needs reforms, especially as regards the extent to which the EU institutions can interfere in the policies of sovereignly elected governments. Fortunately, the attempt to draw european public attention to Poland's alleged violation of the rule of law standards has failed, as evidenced by the extremely low turnout during the debate on this issue.  Nevertheless, this topic still occupies the minds of the most important EU politicians! Today, we are facing huge challenges that could threaten not only the existence of the European Union, but also the security of our continent, and the attention of Europeans is directed towards substitute topics. Brexit was a warning that the current structure and course of action of the EU does not give citizens of the Member States confidence that these challenges can be overcome. Seeking excuses for its own ineffectiveness in criticizing the actions of the Government of the Republic of Poland is a dead end in which European elites are waithing more and more. None of the allegations that this resolution makes against Poland are covered in reality, and the interpretation of many facts is biased and takes into account only one unfavourable point of view for our country.  Of course, having regard to the above arguments, I voted against this unjust, fact-free and politically motivated resolution.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on recent developments in Poland because I agree that the European Parliament's position is necessary by urging the Polish government to change course and to ensure that European rule of law standards are fully respected. The conflict over the composition and functioning of the Constitutional Court and the non-publication of judgments handed down by the Constitutional Court and the initiative to introduce a total ban on abortion is of particular concern. The resolution tabled is not intended to ostracize the Polish people, but rather to urge the Polish executive to cooperate with the European Commission to realign its political programme with the founding principles of the EU which are common to all its Member States giving it three months to implement them in full.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the latest developments in Poland and their impact on fundamental rights in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  The EU operates on the basis of a presumption of mutual trust that Member States respect democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, as enshrined in the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  In the face of the above, I agree with the Commission's call to pursue a constructive and fruitful dialogue with the Polish Government in order to find a swift and concrete solution to recent events.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to argue the reasons for my vote to abstain on this report, not because I do not appreciate the efforts made in particular by the rapporteur, Mr Castaldo, but because I think that we need to change literally with regard to the European Union's policy in relation to the Tunisian people.  In other words, we have often smuggled into 'support' the Tunisian people what is in fact a free trade policy that facilitates European multinationals and Tunisian multinationals and certainly not the Tunisian people, certainly not small tunisian and southern European farmers.  That is why we have also been highly critical of the issue of increasing oil quotas, as well as the free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia. In particular, I believe that the European Union's concrete support should relate to the issue of debt affecting the Tunisian Government and people.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, five years after the Arab Spring, The transition of Tunisia to democracy is a worthy example for other countries to follow. Tunisia is home to more than a million displaced Libyans who have fled violence and conflict in Libya. That is why it is justified to launch a Marshall Plan for Tunisia, precisely to strengthen democracy in this country. Only a stable country with a strengthened democracy can ensure stability, both in Tunisia and in the region. This report also proposes the creation of an independent authority to oversee public procurement and the functioning of the administration. If such an instrument works, it will bring transparency, fairness, efficiency and, obviously, call on investors. The report also proposes the creation of a point of contact with Tunisia by Eurojust. So right now we only have good things. Let's see them in practice.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this is an extremely important measure because of the political as well as the economic nature of the agreement, because it is aimed at the only country of complete democracy, a Muslim country that has faced a thousand drawbacks since the reform begun with the Bourguiba Revolution to date.  There is still the possibility of applying the Tunisian model throughout North Africa. , and that Tunisia in particular can be regarded as a partner of the European Union, a great integrated partner, precisely because of the democratic path it has managed to take in recent decades.  And thanks to Italian-Tunisian relations, which I believe must also become a model for the European Union, we have had the opportunity to establish the best conditions for three hundred and sixty-degree cooperation with that north African country.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, I voted for this report because Tunisia is not only the homeland of the Arab Spring, but also the only Arab country in which democracy is successfully consolidated. Today, Tunisia is a democratic state whose constitution guarantees the rule of law and protects the fundamental rights and freedoms of citizens. A major sign of the successful democratisation of the country is the existence of a well-developed and stable civil society.  Despite the progress made, today the country faces a difficult socio-economic situation. And instability in the region and the danger of terrorist attacks negatively affect tourism and the fragile Tunisian economy. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to work to increase Tunisia's capacity in terms of its stability, democracy, good governance, the fight against corruption and economic development. Last but not least, we need to deepen our cooperation in the fight against terrorism, because this is a common challenge for both Tunisia and Europe. And at the same time, to create a common strategy for joint deradicalisation programmes as the best prevention against terrorism.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia has managed to emerge from the Arab spring as an example of a functioning democracy and is laboriously trying to complete its democratic transition. At the same time, it can be an example to other countries in the North African region, often characterised by unstable and repressive regimes, and an excellent ally for the EU.  I therefore consider it very important to support Tunisia, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non—binding initiative. We do not support the development and practice of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, we remain concerned that the Global Security Strategy foresees an increased capability for the EU to project power in the near neighbourhood, which would include Tunisia. As such, we voted against. Following the vote by the UK to leave the EU, we support friendly and cordial relations between Tunisia and the UK.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I chose to vote against the report on relations with Tunisia in the current regional context. First of all, I think it is essential to remember that foreign policy remains a competence of states and not of the Union. Each state is thus free to conduct its own foreign policy and to deal with its relations with third countries. This report, however innocuous as it is in its proposals, once again calls for EU intervention, whose action in recent years has been detrimental to the region.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. Tunisia is a successful example in the Arab world and its consolidation is essential for the stability of the entire region. It is crucial that Tunisia's democratic transition is consolidated and supported politically and economically. Terrorist attacks have had a devastating effect on the economy and unemployment, especially among young people, remains high. The critical nature of Tunisia's problems requires support from Tunisian institutions, including the justice sector and internal security reforms.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the EU relations with Tunisia in the current regional context. Tunisia is currently facing a difficult socio-economic situation and threats to security deriving mostly from the situation in Libya. The European Parliament renews its commitment to the Tunisian people and the democratisation process that began in 2011 and emphasises the need to support the People’s Representative Assembly (PRA) given the fragile regional context. It welcomes the establishment of an EU-Tunisia Joint Parliamentary Committee and the Commission proposal for a macro-financial assistance of EUR 500 million. The EU has also started negotiations on an ambitious trade agreement with Tunisia. This agreement has not only a trade dimension, but also contributes to extending European standards in the field of environment, consumer protection and worker rights to Tunisia. With regard to security, the report calls on the Tunisian Government to set up a strategy to deal with returning foreign fighters and welcomes the launch, in November 2015, of the European Union programme of support for security sector reform in Tunisia.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context, because I consider Tunisia to be a successful example of the countries of the Arab world and that its consolidation is of the utmost importance for the whole region.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU has no rights in the field of foreign affairs. Moreover, the EU's action since the so-called 'Arab Spring' has been deleterious throughout the area. Tunisia is a convalescent country, not yet stabilized after the seizure of power of the so-called moderate Islamists, whose action has allowed this oasis of development within an area in crisis to lose little or no ten years of economic effort. I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the report contains many positives about future relations with Tunisia and correctly identifies the need to act against human trafficking, I am concerned that it is somewhat too EU—centric, particularly in the context of Brexit.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the peaceful democratic transition in Tunisia sets an example in the Arab world and its consolidation is crucial for the stability of the whole region and, therefore, for security in Europe. We need to stabilize this region through our regular exchanges with this country.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on the European Union's relations with Tunisia deserves my vote in favour, because, as I have advocated in this Parliament, this was the country where the Arab Spring began and is so far the only successful example of this historic event. The consolidation of Tunisian democracy is essential for the stabilisation of the entire region, and this report is careful to emphasise the need for vigorous support from the European Union.  A consolidation of Tunisian democracy that take into account respect for human rights and also the care to involve civil society organisations is something that I consider extremely important, and its inclusion in this report has also contributed to my vote in favour.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context. The cause of the mass demonstrations by the population in 2011 was the lack of jobs and opportunities. At the same time, instability in Libya and its side effects pose a serious threat to Tunisia and the stability of the region as a whole. Tunisia has now accepted more than a million displaced Libyans who have fled instability and violence in Libya. In view of these reasons, I agree with the need for the reforms necessary for social and economic well-being in Tunisia and the need for the EU and the Member States to concentrate and better coordinate large technical and financial resources in order to provide concrete support to Tunisia.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non—binding initiative. We do not support the development and practice of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, we remain concerned that the Global Security Strategy foresees an increased capability for the EU to project power in the near neighbourhood, which would include Tunisia. As such, we voted against. Following the vote by the UK to leave the EU, we support friendly and cordial relations between Tunisia and the UK.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report on tunisia relations, which reiterates the essential importance of supporting the democratic transition process in the country. To this end, the report details a wide range of areas where the Union can intervene to help a country whose economy has been hard hit by terrorism. The report envisages a real Marshall Plan to support democratic consolidation and promote socio-economic investment that brings jobs and social progress. In this regard, the report underlines its full support for the negotiations that have begun to conclude an ambitious free trade agreement.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Castaldo report on the European Union's relations with Tunisia. It is a balanced text which, starting from an analysis of the current regional context, starting with the recent terrorist attacks, defines the characteristics and proposes new paths for the democratic consolidation taking place in the country.  The text focuses in particular on political and institutional reforms, social and economic development, security, mobility and education. The main demands on the Tunisian Government concern the need for technical support for civil society groups, the reform of the criminal code and the judiciary and a general strengthening of the process of decentralisation and régionalisation.  The report calls on Europe to step up aid to Tunisia, a positive example of stability in the Arab world, by strengthening the European Neighbourhood Instrument. Only by increasing its commitment to the Maghreb country will the Union be able to ensure a lasting affirmation of democracy after the end of the Ben Ali regime.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report ultimately did not include our group's amendments on debt (in favour of an audit, restructuring and forgiveness by the debt) and the agreement to readmission of migrants (the practice of which is a violation of human rights), this is a positive report as regards the Union's support for the process of democratisation of the country. However, we do not support the inclusion of a section in favour of the opaque Free Trade Agreement (ZLCAP) which, like all of its kind, by the asymmetry of the parties, would end up harming the weakest in terms of terms of trade, both economically and environmentally, as the manifesto signed by 29 Tunisian and French civil society organizations points out. In addition, the effects of liberalization on certain Spanish products, such as olive trees, must be analysed. Finally, we understand that agreements of this kind, due to their great social, economic, labor and environmental implications, should be the product of extensive informed debate in the companies involved prior to their subscription. I voted abstention.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I support this motion for a resolution, which seems to me to be a correct expression, based also on an objective assessment of the situation, of Tunisia's strong support for the European institutions for its democratic commitment to a real openness of its institutional, social and political structures. It is also an expression of the issues on which we can contribute more than words: experience, means and concrete instruments of cooperation in critical areas such as innovation, security, etc.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Since the European Union is as unfit as it is tasteless for foreign affairs issues, we voted against it. Indeed, we believe that the European Union should not intervene more in the Maghreb than it already does, often badly.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite some interesting ideas, this text on the EU's relations with Tunisia has several critical points, so I preferred to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which aims to promote relations between the Union and Tunisia in the current regional context. Tunisia is a case of democratic success in the Arab world and its consolidation is of paramount importance to the stability of the entire region. The Union must continue to support Tunisia's socio-economic, political and security transition. We welcome the efforts of the Tunisian Government and encourage the Union to support the reform of the country's judicial sector and rule of law, the reform of the penal code and call for increased aid to Tunisia through the European Neighbourhood Instrument, among other issues. We also underline the importance of respect for human rights and the development of monitoring mechanisms in respect for fundamental freedoms, gender equality and strengthening the role of civil society organizations.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been in Parliament's advocacy on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context. Under the European Neighbourhood Policy, the European Union considers Tunisia to be one of the priority countries. The process of peaceful democratic transition in Tunisia is a successful example in the Arab world, and its consolidation is essential for the stability of the whole region and has direct consequences for European security. 2015 The Tunisian Quartet of National Dialogue has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for its crucial contribution to tunisia's development of pluralistic democracy. Tunisia is currently in a difficult socio-economic situation and is also facing security problems, particularly as a result of the situation in Libya. These circumstances and the terrorist attacks carried out in the country have a significant negative impact on tourism, tunisia's most important economic sector. Parliament therefore urges the EU and the Member States to mobilise and better coordinate large technical and financial resources in order to provide concrete support to Tunisia. Stresses also that, without measures to strengthen tunisia's capacity and stability, democracy, good governance, the fight against corruption, economic development and employment in the region, any prospects for reform will be jeopardised. Parliament therefore calls for a genuine and comprehensive partnership between the EU and Tunisia.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament has traditionally had good relations with Tunisia, which are only improving year after year.  This country is a kind of bright example in North Africa, which shows that it is possible to benefit from good bilateral relations with the European Union. The EU also offers assistance in reforming certain sectors, as well as opening the door to its market for Tunisian products.  What is particularly important for them is that we also provide them with technical assistance in the area of regional funds and share experience in reducing disparities between regions.  Regional cooperation between countries in the region is also being strengthened. Tunisia is such a fine example of a practice where the EU helps to improve the economic and social situation. This significantly reduces migration tendencies, as well as the rise of radical political cells that could pose a security threat in the future.  Therefore, my support and my vote on this report.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. While I am in favour of European countries stepping up their aid to African and North African countries, I am strongly opposed to any attempt by the EU to intervene on foreign affairs, especially since its initiatives have not been successful so far. So I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The provision of economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the most widely used instruments by the EU in its neighbourhood and partnership relations with third countries. This has often produced positive results for citizens on both sides and increased the range of influence of soft power in the European Union.  Tunisia is today one of the few (or perhaps the only) Arab country in which the so-called 'Arab Spring' has arrived at a modern democracy, looking to the West and the development of the rule of law. A friendly democracy, which we must support by enabling it to develop under appropriate conditions, gradually, and gradually to become part of the common free trade area. Its strategic position, territorial proximity and key role in the fight against Islamic terrorism today justify a European 'Marshall Plan' to support its economy, strengthen democratic institutions and ties with the West: only with a stable Tunisia on our side can we weaken Libyan terrorists and Mediterranean migrant traffickers.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to deepen the cooperation relations between the European Union and Tunisia within the framework of the neighbourhood policy. On the one hand, the European Union has no diplomatic legitimacy as foreign policy is the responsibility of the Member States. On the other hand, it should be remembered that the European Union has contributed, with the support of Western countries, to the political destabilising of this region, which is currently facing internal unrest and the Islamist threat. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the Tunisian revolution of 2011, the EU has provided political, financial and technical support for Tunisia's democratic transition. All this has been achieved taking into account the fact that the peaceful democratic transition process in this country is an example of success in the Arab world, and its consolidation is of paramount importance for the stability of the region and has direct consequences for security in Europe. At the same time, I believe that the EU and the Member States must maintain their commitment to working with the Tunisian people and their government to promote common interests, including trade, tourism, culture and security, which is why I have said in favour of this report.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The current peaceful democratic process in Tunisia is an example of stabilization in the region. The European Union supports this process politically and financially. For example, it will provide 500 million euros in macro-financial assistance to Tunisia in order to promote the country's economic and social development. It is true that instability in the region and terrorist attacks are hampering the country's economic recovery process, particularly with regard to tourism. With this in mind, it is appropriate to start negotiations for a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia, which is favourable to both sides. Many economic, social, political and institutional reforms have yet to be undertaken in Tunisia. We must support Tunisia's democratic transition. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the dossier on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context, because Tunisia has managed to establish a constitutional system of government within a few years, guaranteeing fundamental rights for the entire population. Today the country is led by an executive elected in a free and transparent way.  Tunisia is a hope in the Arab Mediterranean context. This hope was also underlined by the award of the 2015 Nobel Peace Prize to the Tunisian Quartet of National Dialogue for its decisive contribution to the construction of pluralistic democracy. There are, of course, still many problems, the country has repeatedly been the target of attacks and terrorist attacks that have mainly compromised the tourism sector. It is therefore necessary for Europe to be able to take all the necessary steps to support this delicate phase of transition for the country.  It is up to Europe, through concrete acts, to show solidarity and determination by encouraging the country from which the Arab spring began and which certainly represents a model for all those who want to try to promote peace and democracy in the Middle East, North Africa and the rest of the world.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. While it contained many good elements, drawing attention to both the progress Tunisia has made towards a democratic transition, such as peaceful transition over the summer despite a split in Nidaa Tounes, and issues that must be addressed, such as the criminalisation of homosexuality and the fact that the death penalty remains as a possible penalty for certain offences (though it hasn’t been used since 1991), references to EU military missions meant I could not support it.  The report called for the intensification of the EUNAVOR MED mission, whose mission is to ‘identify, capture and dispose of vessels’ carrying refugees in the Mediterranean. As Sinn Féin disagrees with this military mission, I could not support the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding initiative. We do not support the development and practice of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, we remain concerned that the Global Security Strategy foresees an increased capability for the EU to project power in the near neighbourhood, which would include Tunisia. As such, we voted against. Following the vote by the UK to leave the EU, we support friendly and cordial relations between Tunisia and the UK.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is important within the context of the current regional turmoil to support Tunisia and the People’s Representative Assembly for the process of democratisation of the country within this volatile regional context. The European Parliament is urging the EU and Member States, amongst other things, to mobilise and better coordinate substantial technical and financial resources to support Tunisia.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report of mine stems from the awareness, on the one hand, of the specific ities of Tunisia's transition and new democratic life after 23 years of dictatorship. On the other hand, the growing importance of its support and defence in an increasingly deteriorated regional context.  Tunisia's recent democratic achievements constitute an extremely fragile architecture that needs and deserves protection, primarily from us Europeans who, in addition to being its immediate neighbours, are also the reference point for its development and its present and future aspirations. In addition to economic aid, such as the proposal to convert Tunisian debt into investment projects, we must encourage social inclusion, visa facilitation, especially for artists, students, professors, as well as all forms of partnership in the field of culture and creativity. Encouragement, however sincere, is no longer enough. We now need concrete action.  Tunisia's stability is our stability. Its prosperity is our prosperity. Tunisian civil society has earned the Nobel Peace Prize, and it is up to the European Union to win that of solidarity and foresight. My vote was undoubtedly in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, in which the EP renews its commitment to the Tunisian people and to the political transition process that began in 2011.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on EU-Tunisia relations was a step towards more effective communication between the two sides, as well as a thorough analysis of the requirements that exist. I believe that, despite the important and intractable issues we have to deal with, such reports work positively and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the European Union's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context. I express my full support for the Assembly of Representatives of the Tunisian people with regard to the democratisation process undertaken for the well-being of Tunisia itself and for granting stability in an extremely precarious context. However, it is crucial that this House speeds up the reform path as the country urgently needs new legislation containing more balanced gender policies and the abolition of the death penalty. In this respect, I recognise the importance of the new parliamentary committee set up between Europe and Tunisia, which, through regular meetings, will make it possible to initiate a profound dialogue in any aspect of common interest.  Given the chaotic situation in North Africa at the moment, concern arises about instability in neighbouring Libya and the many Tunisian fighters joining the Islamic State, so I hope that two strategies will be developed. The first concerns a social inclusion programme to prevent terrorist organisations from recruiting new affiliates by exploiting poverty and degradation, as they have unfortunately been able to do in other areas. The second, on the other hand, is in terms of cooperation between the European and Tunisian intelligence agencies, considering terrorism to be a common challenge, and therefore to be eradicated together.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on EU relations with Tunisia in the current regional context and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Tunisia is a key partner of the European Union in the European Neighbourhood Policy, but also in the fight against terrorism, in resolving the refugee crisis and stabilising the region, especially with regard to Libya. I would remind you that there are more than one million displaced Libyans in Tunisia who are without access to basic infrastructure because they are mostly in former refugee camps. I am also concerned about the fragile situation of the Tunisian economy, which is heavily based on tourism and foreign investment, as the high level of unemployment is exploited by radical organisations such as the Islamic State to recruit young people. Any approach to EU-Tunisia relations must take this into account. I agree with the priorities set out in the report, but I follow in particular the recommendations for the abolition of the death penalty, eradication of torture in detained citizens, decriminalisation of homosexuality, respect for freedom of expression and the press, the conclusion of a free trade agreement with a macro-financial assistance programme, promotion of public administration reforms and the fight against corruption, enhanced security cooperation and the prioritisation of youth and youth employment support programmes. From the foregoing, I support the report.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding initiative. We do not support the development and practice of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, we remain concerned that the Global Security Strategy foresees an increased capability for the EU to project power in the near neighbourhood, which would include Tunisia. As such, we voted against. Following the vote by the UK to leave the EU, we support friendly and cordial relations between Tunisia and the UK.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU's relations with Tunisia because I believe that tunisia's strategic geographical position makes it one of the priority countries within the framework of the EU's European Neighbourhood Policy and, furthermore, the process of democratic transition that has taken place peacefully in Tunisia in recent years is a positive example in the Arab world of fundamental importance for the stability of the entire region and consequently for security in Europe.  The difficult security situation that the country is experiencing, deriving mainly from the problems affecting Libya, have penalised it above all in the field of tourism, a fundamental element for the Tunisian economy, which depends to a large extent on foreign investments that can only be guaranteed through a progressive development of democracy in the country. The EU and its Member States must continue to work with the Tunisian people and government to promote trade and tourism policies by better coordinating technical and financial resources in support of the country.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The EU can facilitate Tunisia’s democratic process through the creation of an enabling environment with the necessary structures for civil society organisations to be included in the decision-making process. There should be a commitment to the Tunisian people and the political transition process that began in 2011 which, while it consolidates its democratic process, implements the reforms needed to achieve social and economic prosperity and guarantees its security;  the EU and the Member States are urged to mobilise and better coordinate substantial technical and financial resources in order to provide concrete support for Tunisia, not excluding a real ‘Marshall Plan’ as advocated by the report.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report reaffirms the Union's support for the democratic consolidation process in Tunisia and underlines the problems that could jeopardize it: debt, unemployment, security, rule of law, etc. In general, the report has a more progressive approach than the European Parliament usually employs to deal with relations with other countries. However, there are some elements that I do not agree with and which made me finally unable to support the report, and as a result I abstained from the final vote: one of the main problems was that the report supports the EUNAVFOR mission, and that on the other hand, it talks about deepening the negotiations of the free trade agreement to which our delegation opposes , while the text seeks to give it an approach focused on the environment and consumer protection, I cannot vote in favour of the document supporting free trade, which also commends the macro-financial support of EUR 500 million without denouncing its neoliberal conditions, nor does it make any reference to a necessary audit of Tunisia's odious debt.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia is a key country under the EU's European Neighbourhood Policy and remains a successful model of democratic transition after the Arab Spring. I voted in favour of this resolution because I intend to support the action of the EU and its Member States in favour of Tunisia, which is suffering the consequences of Libyan instability and terrorist attacks and must be supported by the EU through financial and technical resources.  I am convinced that supporting Tunisia's stability, democracy, the fight against corruption and economic development also supports priorities in common with the EU, such as trade and culture, security and the tourism sector. Initiatives such as the establishment of an EU-Tunisia Joint Parliamentary Committee contribute to the process of economic and administrative reforms taking place in the country and encourage us to continue along the path of progress made in many areas, such as compliance with international standards on freedom of association.  This resolution reiterates that cooperation between the EU and Tunisia must continue in the light of full respect for human rights and calls on Tunisia to reform the Law on the State of Emergency, the Use of Torture and the Death Penalty, freedom of the press and the media.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia is one of the priority countries in the EU's European Neighbourhood Policy. Tunisia's peaceful democratic transition process is an example of success in the Arab world, and its consolidation is a priority for the stability of the entire region and has direct consequences for security in Europe. The economy of Tunisia is dependent on foreign investment, tourism, which is severely affected by these circumstances and by terrorist attacks against the country, but also on the export of products to the EU. Its economy can only thrive if democracy continues to develop. I voted for cooperation between Member States and Tunisian authorities to combat organised forms of illegal immigration, but also to continue support for the sustainable development of the economy in this country.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. Tunisia is one of the European Union's priority countries under the European Neighbourhood Policy. The process of peaceful democratic transformation in Tunisia sets a successful example in the Arab world, so its strengthening is crucial for the stability of the whole region and even for the security of Europe. Tunisia is currently in a difficult socio-economic situation and is also facing security problems due to the conditions in Libya. Tourism, which is an essential component of the Tunisian economy, is severely affected by these circumstances and terrorist attacks on the country. The Tunisian economy depends to a large extent on foreign investment, tourism and exports of goods to the EU, but an economy can only flourish if democracy can develop. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a genuine partnership that takes into account the interests of the population on both sides of the Mediterranean and which is particularly concerned with reducing social and territorial disparities in Tunisia. The European Union and its Member States must continue to commit to working with the people and government of Tunisia in order to promote common interests, including trade, investment, tourism, culture and security.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the EU's efforts to strengthen cooperation with Tunisia, the first country to hold the Arab Spring, where the first democratic elections were held (2014). I voted in favour because this cooperation can bring a great deal of benefits to Member States in the areas of trade, investment, culture and security.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia’s consolidation is paramount for stability in the region. The critical nature of the problems affecting Tunisia demands better support to contribute to capacity-building for the Tunisian institutions, justice sector and security reforms. I am in favour of this report as I believe that the democratic transition in Tunisia is to be supported both politically and economically.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In line with the work the UK government is already doing with its Tunisian counterpart on business promotion, culture, tourism and security, I support this report’s emphasis on the value of the EU’s developing partnership with Tunisia and its commitment to promoting common interests.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report calls on the European Union and Member States to better coordinate their technical and financial resources to support Tunisia. The report expresses its support for the democratization process by emphasizing the need to support the Assembly of People's Representatives (PRA). Considering that the Union has a role to play in supporting its economic and political partners in their process of development, growth and democratisation, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding initiative. We do not support the development and practice of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, we remain concerned that the Global Security Strategy foresees an increased capability for the EU to project power in the near neighbourhood, which would include Tunisia. As such, we voted against. Following the vote by the UK to leave the EU, we support friendly and cordial relations between Tunisia and the UK.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the relations between the European Union and Tunisia in the current regional context in order to encourage Tunisia in its democratic transition process at a time when economic difficulties and security challenges remain significant. I am particularly in favour of the European Union accompanying Tunisia in the fight against terrorism, including through the Europol agency. Like the European Union, Tunisia is experiencing a significant number of departures to terrorist organizations. We must improve our cooperation in the face of the rise of terrorism in all regions of the world.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I support the democratisation process and the economic reforms under way in Tunisia. Following the Arab spring, I believe that the European Union must play a key role in this process in promoting the country's economy, security and better job prospects for Tunisian citizens. That is why I support the establishment of a joint parliamentary committee of Members of the European Parliament and Tunisian MePs to initiate a structured political dialogue on civil rights, the rule of law and economic progress.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is essential that the EU supports the democratic transition process in Tunisia. Consolidating this process is more crucial than ever for the stability of the entire region. Tunisia faces major challenges, including the economic downturn, rising unemployment and terrorist attacks that discourage tourists. At the same time, Tunisia has received more than 1.8 million refugees (nearly 20% of its population) from Libya. In this context, Tunisia's transition to democracy is remarkable and I believe that the EU must stand by it. I therefore support the plan to lend Tunisia EUR 500 million to help it reduce its external debt, consolidate its democratic mechanisms and develop all sectors of economic and social life. I call on Tunisia to sign the Memorandum of Understanding with the Commission committing it to structural reforms and sound management of public finances. Tunisia must ensure effective democratic mechanisms, the rule of law and respect for human rights.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Tunisia's situation justifies the implementation of a genuine "Marshall Plan" to support democratic consolidation and economic development. Over the past year, the European Union has adopted and implemented several initiatives to support Tunisia's young democracy. We have adopted an emergency plan to import 70,000 tonnes of duty-free olive oil from Tunisia to help this key sector of a Tunisian economy hard hit by terrorist attacks. The EU has also provided 500 million euros in macro-financial assistance. Finally, Tunisia and the EU have launched negotiations for a trade agreement aimed at increasing trade between their territories. These initiatives are moving in the right direction. Europeans need a stable and prosperous Tunisia. That is why we must continue to stand with Tunisians in the long term, intensify economic and cultural exchanges and make Tunisia a privileged partner of the Union in the Mediterranean region.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a situation report with a proposal to deepen EU-Tunisia cooperation within the framework of the neighbourhood policy. It should be remembered that the EU has no vocation or right to interfere in the field of foreign affairs. Moreover, the EU's action since the "Arab Spring" has proved harmful throughout the area concerned. Tunisia is a convalescent country, unstabilized since the seizure of power by the so-called "moderate" Islamists. Through their fault, this oasis of development, in an area in crisis, has lost ten years of economic efforts. Although the report seems innocuous, it nevertheless remains in favour of EU intervention that is particularly damaging to France, of which Tunisia is part of the natural zone of influence. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on EU-Tunisia relations. The democratic transition in Tunisia over the past five years has been given as an example of optimism by other Arab Spring countries. In December 2014, Tunisia became the first of these nations to successfully complete its transition to democracy and hold its first ever democratic presidential elections.  Tunisia is ahead of its neighbours and has strong trade links with Europe, and the international community supports the process as a model for stability and democracy in the region. My colleague Castaldo's report assesses how the EU's relations with Tunisia have evolved since the dawn of the Arab Spring. Noting the fact that Tunisia is a priority country for the European Union, it encourages increased EU support.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report provides for high financial support for Tunisia from the EU.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The peaceful democratic transition process in Tunisia is an example of success in the Arab world and its consolidation is fundamental to the stability of the entire region and, as a direct consequence, to Europe's security.  Tunisia is currently facing a difficult socio-economic situation, as well as security challenges that result mainly from the situation in Libya, and is heavily dependent on foreign investment, tourism and the export of products to the EU.  I therefore agree with the mobilisation and better coordination by the Union and the Member States of considerable technical and financial resources, with a view to providing concrete support to Tunisia.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: proponent of EU intervention particularly damaging to France, of which Tunisia is part of the natural zone of influence.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report addresses eu-Tunisia relations in the current regional context, focusing on the following aspects: political and institutional reforms, economic and social development, security and defence policy, mobility, research, education and culture. The unstable situation that exists today in Tunisia is inseparable from the policy of aggression that major European powers have carried out in the region and whose crass example is that of Libya. Tunisia's instability has naturally contributed to tunisia's situation, with terrorist attacks and problems on its borders.  With the hope that it is necessary to fight terrorism, arguments are made to a "technocratic" government to limit the civil and political rights of Tunisians. Secular and democratic associations have already ended in Tunisia, for example, and the mobility of the population has been limited. Popular leaders have already been murdered. All of this is inseparable from the progressive alignment with EU security and defence policies and guidelines. The aim of this report is, fundamentally, to deepen this alignment. Pressure stemming from the deregulation of trade between the EU and Tunisia is a significant example, while issues such as the need to cancel the country's debt are avoided. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of strengthening the European Union's relations with Tunisia, a strategic partner in the Mediterranean of Europe and, in particular, of Italy. I therefore hope that the process of democratization of the country, as well as the necessary economic and social reforms, will be speeded up. I think it is laudable that, despite a complex internal situation within the country, the Tunisian Government has considered new methods of speeding up key priority policies. It will be these changes in favour of the establishment of the rule of law that will increasingly reduce economic stagnation and the lack of prospects among young Tunisians, the main causes of the call of extremist and terrorist groups.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Tunisia is a successful example in the Arab world and its consolidation is fundamental to the stability of the whole region. It is important that the transition to democracy in Tunisia is supported both politically and economically. Terrorist attacks have had a devastating impact on the economy. Unemployment, especially among young people, remains high. Tunisia must continue to support and build independent control bodies, the judiciary and promote security reforms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
