text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because I do not fully agree with the report, despite some positive aspects such as the commitment against Islamic terrorism and the strengthening of economic support for Tunisia's social and productive development.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context as there is high financial support for Tunisia from the EU.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia represents a successful example in the Arab world and its consolidation is paramount for the stability of the entire region. It is crucial that the democratic transition in Tunisia be consolidated and supported politically and economically. The terrorist attacks have had a devastating effect on the economy, and unemployment, especially among young people, remains high. The critical nature of the problems affecting Tunisia demands more and better support to contribute to capacity building for the Tunisian institutions, justice sector and security reforms. I support the call for the continuation of technical and capacity-building support for civil-society groups, the launching a programme in support of reform of the judicial sector and the rule of law, a reform of the penal code, a stronger process of decentralisation and the empowerment of the regions by means of further local autonomy, as well as an increase in EU aid to Tunisia through the European Neighbourhood Instrument, and the coordination of international aid to Tunisia.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In agreement with the rapporteur, I voted in favour of the report on relations with Tunisia. Tunisia should be one of the european neighbourhood policy's top priority countries. The process of peaceful democratic transformation sets a successful example in the Arab world, which is why tunisia is of great importance for the security of the whole region and for the security of Europe. Deep cooperation is needed, in particular, in the fight against terrorism, as Tunisia has also been hit by numerous terrorist attacks in the past year, and the Islamic State is recruiting many young people in the country.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report considering that the peaceful process of transition to democracy in Tunisia represents an example of success in the Arab world and that its consolidation is vital for the stability of the whole region and for EU security. To assist its consolidation, the EU and Member States must better mobilisation and coordinate a significant volume of technical and financial resources in order to provide Tunisia with specific support.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia is a key country in EU foreign policy; Tunisia was the only country that came out of the ‘Arab Spring’ as a democracy and this democratic transition can serve as an example across North Africa and the Muslim world. Given this, and the current economic crisis in the country, the consolidation of stability in Tunisia is of paramount importance. Tunisia needs significant EU support to make necessary political and economic reforms, and I support the report in welcoming the Commission’s macro-financial aid to Tunisia. I also agree with the report that cooperation with Tunisia and technical support to the country is needed in the area of defence and security, especially given the chaotic situation in Libya.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The stability and development of our southern Mediterranean neighbours are strategic objectives of great importance. Tunisia, which is the first country to experience regime change following the Arab revolutions, has always been a major political and commercial partner for the European Union. Strengthening economic cooperation must go hand in hand with concrete support for democratic reforms and security cooperation in the region.  The report we have adopted today reminds Europe of its responsibility as a democratic actor: the diplomatic attraction we can have is indeed of great importance, in order to accompany Tunisian society and institutions towards cooperation that can make it easier to manage the major crises of our time, such as the fight against terrorism, the management of migratory flows and environmental sustainability.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context because I believe it is essential to support the small Maghreb country in the process of democratic transition following the Arab spring of 2011. Tunisia is the only country in the Arab world on track for the peaceful construction of the rule of law and is a positive example of democracy following the popular uprisings which have had a dramatic outcome in the rest of the Maghreb and the Middle East.  It is therefore vital, for the survival of the still fragile internal balance, undermined by the terrorist threat and a serious economic crisis, to support the efforts of young democracy, to guarantee respect for fundamental rights and to protect their stability and security, with consequent positive effects on the whole neighbourhood.  As tunisia's economy depends to a large extent on foreign investment, tourism and the export of products to the EU, it is important that European Neighbourhood Policy funds primarily provide assistance to small and medium-sized enterprises, which are essential for the development of the country's economic fabric, and that they support the dissemination of know-how, the training of professionals and skills at work.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context. The report makes it clear that the EU must play a more active role in Tunisia's economic, political and social development if it takes seriously its promise to combat the causes of flight and promote good neighbourliness with African states.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I am aware of the European Union's special responsibility towards its neighbouring countries and therefore support European-Tunisian relations. It is important to strengthen democratic structures in Tunisia, in particular parliamentary structures, in order to avoid drifting into chaotic conditions.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Tunisia represents a successful example in the Arab world and its consolidation is paramount for the stability of the entire region. It is crucial that the democratic transition in Tunisia be consolidated and supported politically and economically. The terrorist attacks have had a devastating effect on the economy, and unemployment, especially among young people, remains high. The critical nature of the problems affecting Tunisia demands more and better support to contribute to capacity building for the Tunisian institutions, justice sector and security reforms.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report ultimately did not include our group's amendments on debt (in favour of an audit, restructuring and forgiveness by the debt) and the agreement to readmission of migrants (the practice of which is a violation of human rights), this is a positive report as regards the Union's support for the process of democratisation of the country. However, we do not support the inclusion of a section in favour of the opaque Free Trade Agreement (ZLCAP) which, like all of its kind, by the asymmetry of the parties, would end up harming the weakest in terms of terms of trade, both economically and environmentally, as the manifesto signed by 29 Tunisian and French civil society organizations points out. In addition, the effects of liberalization on certain Spanish products, such as olive trees, must be analysed. Finally, we understand that agreements of this kind, due to their great social, economic, labor and environmental implications, should be the product of extensive informed debate in the companies involved prior to their subscription. I voted abstention.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report, which urges Tunisia to go further in its political reforms in ways such as abolishing discrimination based on gender, supporting the inclusion of young people and reforming penal law with a view to upholding fundamental freedoms such as the freedom of expression.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The European Parliament renews its commitment to the Tunisian people and the political transition process that began in 2011. However it is important to stress that reforms are needed to achieve social and economic prosperity and security. The EU and the Member States are urged to mobilise and better coordinate substantial technical and financial resources in order to provide concrete support for Tunisia because without measures to strengthen Tunisia’s absorption capacity and stability, democracy, good governance, the fight against corruption, economic development and employment in the region, any prospect of reform will be put at risk.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report contains several positive points. It assigns responsibilities and asks the EU for any relationship with Tunisia to work. However, we are critical of some very important points in the report. One concerns the readmission agreement, and the second concerns the free trade agreement. Our firm position is contrary to these agreements knowing what measures are being imposed on the States and in particular on the peoples. That is why we have held a position of abstention in the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The peaceful democratic transition process in Tunisia represents a successful example in the Arab world and its consolidation is paramount for the stability of the entire region. It is imperative for Tunisia to implement adequate reforms aimed at boosting employment and developing sustainable and inclusive growth. While the increased democratisation of the People’s Representative Assembly (PRA) is encouraging, there is room for other measures to enhance public administration, democratic transition and development in general in the country. I strongly support the provisions of the motion which call for the abolition of the death penalty and the decriminalisation of homosexuality. Equally, freedom of expression should be defended in the press and media as well as freedom of expression online. I welcome the launch of the EU programme of support for security sector reform in Tunisia. The promotion of logical objectives, rather than mere support by policy instruments, within a clear strategic vision focusing on prevention, is essential to the development of a clear and coherent security policy which would aid in combating the spread of fundamentalist extremism.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it highlights the importance of providing support to the Tunisian People’s Representative Assembly (PRA) in strengthening the country’s democratic structures and protecting itself from a security spill over from instability in Libya.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on the EU's relationship with Tunisia has few weaknesses. It would have made sense to include in the text issues of the repatriation of Tunisian migrants. It remains to be seen whether useful uses can be found for the aid money planned by the EU. Apart from these issues, it is important to have clear support for Tunisia. There are few functioning democratic and constitutional elements in the Arab countries. Tunisia is very important as a positive example for the region, and so I was happy to vote in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to discord and strife in Europe.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding initiative. We do not support the development and practice of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, we remain concerned that the Global Security Strategy foresees an increased capability for the EU to project power in the near neighbourhood, which would include Tunisia. As such, we voted against. Following the vote by the UK to leave the EU, we support friendly and cordial relations between Tunisia and the UK.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report to support the strengthening of the stability of the entire region of Tunisia. This country is a real success in the Arab perimeter and therefore the support provided would restore the stability of the country at all levels. Following the adverse events of recent times, it is essential that it receives social, economic and political support, especially in the event of the devastating effects on the economy, that of high youth unemployment, justice and security reforms. Respect for fundamental human rights and the development of monitoring mechanisms on fundamental freedoms, gender equality and other human rights issues are also essential and paramount.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the EU-Tunisia Relations Report in the current regional context (2015/2273(INI)), as I support the EU's efforts, actions and activities towards Tunisia with a view to helping its weak economy and fragile democratic structure.  It is important to help Tunisia and its citizens and improve partnership relations, as it is an important country that has succeeded in implementing the transition to a democratic social order, but which is burdened with terrorist threats that have particularly set tourism back as one of the most important economic branches, and is a country located in the immediate neighbourhood of a still politically and security-unstable Libya that poses a potential threat to the environment.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Eu action since the so-called 'Arab Spring' has been deleterious across the area. Tunisia is a convalescent country, not yet stabilized after the seizure of power of the so-called moderate Islamists, whose action has allowed this oasis of development within an area in crisis to lose little or no ten years of economic effort. While the report is innocuous in its substance as in its proposals, it nevertheless remains in favour of an untimely EU intervention.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non—binding initiative. We do not support the development and practice of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, we remain concerned that the Global Security Strategy foresees an increased capability for the EU to project power in the near neighbourhood, which would include Tunisia. As such, we voted against.  Following the vote by the UK to leave the EU, we support friendly and cordial relations between Tunisia and the UK.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution because Tunisia represents a priority country in our Neighbourhood Policy and is a crucial partner in our fight against terrorism. As Tunisia is currently facing difficult socio-economic and security challenges, I found it necessary to continue deepening our bilateral relations and supporting them in their process of democratisation. The financial assistance and the proposed deep and comprehensive free trade agreement will positively influence development in Tunisia in the short and long run, which in turn will be beneficial for Europe as well.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report of my colleague Fabio Massimo Castaldo. The text calls on Member States and the European Commission to provide financial and technical assistance to Tunisia. As Tunisia is one of the most important countries in the European Neighbourhood Policy, I think it is in everyone's interest for the country to regain stability and security. I am satisfied with this positioning, which is in line with the interests of Tunisians but also of Europeans. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on EU relations with Tunisia in the current regional context, as it addresses a number of issues. The process of democratisation, the respect of fundamental human rights, the open market economy, the freedom of the press and the media, are only some of the very important issues that the report is trying to address. It is important that in times of crisis we strengthen our ties with our neighbouring countries, and even more important that we make sure the values and the ideas in place are in accordance with the respect of human rights.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from this report. It deals with EU-Tunisia relations at various levels. Emphasis is placed on building democracy and civil society in the country, which is to be done, inter alia, through EU financial assistance. In the long term, this is certainly worthy of support, such as the EU's plan to promote the fight against corruption and terrorism in Tunisia in particular. However, it is to be rejected that mobility partnerships and visa facilitation should be promoted here, which is a kind of migration facilitation, at least for the time being.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it urges Tunisia to go further in its political reforms such as abolishing discrimination based on gender, supporting the inclusion of young people and reforming penal law with a view to upholding fundamental freedoms such as freedom of expression. It further underlines which economic development challenges face Tunisia and welcomes steps taken to modernise and liberalise the economy.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on the EU's relationship with Tunisia has few weaknesses. For example, it would have made sense to include in the text issues of the repatriation of Tunisian migrants. It remains to be seen whether useful uses can be found for the aid money planned by the EU. Apart from these issues, it is important to have clear support for Tunisia. There are few functioning democratic and constitutional elements in the Arab countries. Tunisia is very important as a positive example for the region, and so I was happy to vote in favour of the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 14 September 2016, at the Plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, we voted on a report on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context. It should be noted that the Maghrebu states are crucial for the EU to address some of today's problems, such as the so-called migration crisis, so close monitoring of their current developments and developing very broad cooperation with them. But virtually all Maghrebu states have been plagued by serious problems in recent years. I am therefore very glad that the rapporteur has managed to include in the report on Tunisia mentions of some controversial issues and steps, such as the issue of public debt, the death penalty and the new anti-terrorism law, the fight against regional disparities, the social system, etc. , I have decided to support the report in the vote.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report draws attention to the European support for Tunisia in its democratic process, but underlines also the essential steps that Tunisia should undertake for this process within the topics of debt, unemployment, security, rule of law, etc. I voted in favour of this report since there are some good amendments: freezing of Ben-Ali’s assets, stopping the torture in prisons, action against the death penalty, fighting against discrepancies between regions. I truly believe that these kinds of recommendations to Tunisia could help the country in its democratic process.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The report rightly points out that instability in Libya and its spill-over effects are a serious threat to the stability of Tunisia and the whole region, as Tunisia is currently sheltering one million displaced Libyans. At the same time, the material coyly hides the fact that the situation in Libya is a consequence of the fact that some EU Member States have also attacked Libya without UN authorisation, trampling on international law. In large part, this is also the result of a flare-up of terrorism. Due to the serious shortcomings of the report, it cannot be supported in its entirety, only in detail, because some of its elements, such as the fight against people smuggling, are being fought.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on relations between the European Union and Tunisia in the current regional context. I believe that a deeper partnership between the European Union and Tunisia is needed in order to improve the situation in terms of stability, democracy, good governance, anti-corruption, economic development and employment in the region.  I welcome the establishment of a Joint Parliamentary Committee between the European Union and Tunisia to play a key role, enabling representatives of both parties to meet regularly and develop a structured political dialogue on democracy, human rights, the rule of law and other topics of common interest.  Political dialogue between the European Union and Tunisia in the field of counter-terrorism is also of great importance. Terrorism is a common challenge that requires a common response and cooperation between the two countries in the field of security and counter-terrorism is making progress, in particular with the launch of an ambitious agenda to support security sector reform. I also support the UN-led process of peace and political reconciliation in Libya as important for stabilising the wider region and enhancing security and the reform process in Tunisia.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on Tunisia because I believe that the EU does not have to have a diplomatic role.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report paints a picture of all the dangers facing the Tunisian revolution: slowing economy, debt burden, social frustration, instability, terrorism. Five years after launching the Arab Spring in January 2011, real progress on human rights and democracy is still fragile in the face of the economic and social slump. The report also calls on the EU to take strong action to help Tunisia and to go beyond some trade facilities or loans linked to IMF conditions, which are more than questionable. One of the highlights of this report is precisely the demand for the conversion of Tunisian debt into development projects, a point which I had also asked in the Committee on International Trade and which had been the subject of amendments to the aid plan on my part. I welcome the fact that the plenary has supported this idea and also calls for the release of Ben Ali's frozen assets. The funds must be released quickly and thus follow the recent call of economists for a "Marshall" plan for Tunisia in order to support this young democracy and the aspirations of its youth.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context. It is worth recalling the principled position that the EU has no rights in the field of foreign affairs. Moreover, the EU's action since the so-called 'Arab Spring' has been deleterious throughout the area. Tunisia is a convalescent country, not yet stabilized after the seizure of power of the so-called moderate Islamists, whose action has allowed this oasis of development within an area in crisis to lose little or no ten years of economic effort. Although the report is innocuous in its substance as in its proposals, it nevertheless remains in favour of EU intervention that is particularly damaging to France, of which Tunisia is part of the natural zone of influence.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union, although supranational in structure, has no foreign policy rights. Moreover, the EU's action since the so-called 'Arab Spring' has been deleterious throughout the area. Tunisia is a convalescent country, not yet stabilized after the seizure of power by the so-called moderate Islamists and to which the EU, through its action, imposes a halt in its economic efforts. Although the report is innocuous, both in substance and in its proposals, it nevertheless remains in favour of EU intervention that is particularly damaging to France, of which Tunisia is part of the natural zone of influence. I therefore voted against this report and the idea that the EU should have a diplomatic role.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to promote relations between the Union and Tunisia in the current regional context. Tunisia is a case of democratic success in the Arab world and its consolidation is of paramount importance to the stability of the entire region. At the moment a new government has just started its journey, with a very young prime minister, which has as its main objectives the fight against corruption and economic recovery. The text emphasizes the need to support Tunisia's socio-economic, political and security transition.  Our group stressed: the importance of respect for human rights and the development of monitoring mechanisms in respect for fundamental freedoms, gender equality and other human rights issues, that the Free Trade Agreement should contribute to tunisia's stability and which should be a progressive and asymmetrical agreement, from which the economies and societies of Tunisia and the Union can benefit , and finally, strengthening the role of civil society organizations.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report reaffirms the Union's support for the democratic consolidation process in Tunisia and underlines the problems that could jeopardize it: debt, unemployment, security, rule of law, etc. In general, the report has a more progressive approach than the European Parliament usually employs to deal with relations with other countries. However, there are some elements that I do not agree with and which made me finally unable to support the report, and as a result I abstained from the final vote: one of the main problems was that the report supports the EUNAVFOR mission, and that on the other hand, it talks about deepening the negotiations of the free trade agreement to which our delegation opposes , while the text seeks to give it an approach focused on the environment and consumer protection, I cannot vote in favour of the document supporting free trade, which also commends the macro-financial support of EUR 500 million without denouncing its neoliberal conditions, nor does it make any reference to a necessary audit of Tunisia's odious debt.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Tunisia was the country where five years ago, the so-called "Arab Spring" began. The democratic transition began in January 2011, being the only one in the so-called "Arab Spring" in which the process culminated in the adoption of a constitution and the holding of democratic and transparent presidential and legislative elections. However, the Tunisian economy has suffered since 2011 from continued domestic turmoil, regional instability and the weak international environment, mainly from the Union, which is its main trading partner. The current fear is that the economic situation will derail political achievements.  Last April, the EU-Tunisia Association Council was held, where the Union stressed the importance of Tunisia implementing the pending structural reforms. In the European Parliament we have begun to work by taking a first step in this direction, through the establishment of the EU-Tunisia Joint Parliamentary Committee. I give my positive vote for the adoption of this report, because I believe that both Spain and Europe should consider Tunisia a priority partner in the strategic region of the Maghreb and we must accompany it in political reforms, economic development and the fight against terrorism.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on the EU's relationship with Tunisia has few weaknesses. It would have made sense to include in the text issues of the repatriation of Tunisian migrants. It remains to be seen whether useful uses can be found for the aid money planned by the EU. Apart from these issues, it is important to have clear support for Tunisia. There are few functioning democratic and constitutional elements in the Arab countries. Tunisia is very important as a positive example for the region, and so I was happy to vote in favour of the report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which promotes the process of democratisation, particularly in the current context of the instability of neighbouring states such as Libya.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the call for member states to release 'substantial funds' to help Tunisia. I stand by the principle of Trade, not Aid, that is, it is better to have free trade with Tunisia than to send him charity. Nor do I agree with the call for the promotion of 'gender-balanced policies', Tunisia must achieve gender equality on its own, and I consider gender-balanced quota policies to be wrong policies that will not help Tunisia and have nothing to do with equality before the law.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The process of consolidating the democratic process in Tunisia is one of the key factors for establishing the stability of the entire region and therefore the security of Europe. Without EU technical and financial support within the Framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy, Tunisia's stability, democracy and economic development will be at risk. Measures to increase absorption capacity and a comprehensive partnership between Tunisia and the EU are needed to ensure social and economic prosperity in the region. In the form of imminent instability in Libya, Tunisia needs strong support. In order to better support the process of democratic consolidation in Tunisia, improvements are needed in mobilising and coordinating the technical and material support of EU Member States. The objective of strengthening democracy and stability in the currently unstable regional context can also be achieved by supporting the Assembly of National Representatives.  Measures, such as the EU-Tunisia Mobility Partnership signed in March 2014, a new vis policy and the conclusion of readmission agreements, will improve existing cooperation between the EU and Tunisia. In line with the forthcoming claims, I support this report, as I believe that deepening relations with Tunisia will greatly contribute to the progress of democracy, respect for human rights, the rule of law and all other issues of common interest.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The peaceful democratic transition process in Tunisia represents the only successful example in the Arab world and its consolidation is paramount for the stability of the entire region. That is why for the EU it is very important to support democratic processes in this country.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ despite the strong progress in democratising society, Tunisia is currently facing major social and economic challenges. Terrorist attacks, conditioned by the situation in Tunisia's neighbours, in particular Libya, negatively affect tourism, make foreign investment and the overall economic operation of the country more difficult. This, of course, has implications for high unemployment, especially among young people, and persistent socioeconomic disparities. Tunisia is an important partner for the EU in the fight against terrorism and also in the fight against illegal immigration. In cooperation with this country, many of the problems of the Countries of Africa can be solved, which also affect the situation in Europe. I support the proposal for the EU to facilitate democratisation processes and political reforms in the country and to provide it with €500 million in macro-financial assistance for economic and social development, which will help create employment and stem migration flows to Europe.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 First of all I refer to my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 13/9/2016. Furthermore, I stress that I voted against the report on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context, which is a follow-up to both the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of exceptional autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia, as well as the resolution on macro-economic aid to Tunisia, because with these actions the European Union itself is methodically pooring Greek farmers and leading to a dramatic fall in olive oil prices in Greece resulting in the consequent income loss of greek olive growers from the memorandum and harsh austerity measures.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. The EU has no rights in the field of foreign affairs. Eu action since the so-called "Arab Spring" has been deleterious throughout the area. Tunisia is a country in reconstruction and the EU, through its action, prevents the development of its economic efforts and actions. Although the report is not, in its proposals, truly reprehensible, it nevertheless remains in favour of EU intervention that is particularly damaging to France, of which Tunisia is part of the natural zone of influence.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on the EU’s relations with Tunisia in the current regional context. Tunisia has proven to be a worthy representation to its Arab neighbours in the context of a peaceful democratic transition and stability within its borders amid terrorist attacks and collateral damage from the situation in Libya. Hence, I consider EU relations with an African country like Tunisia, that is working hard on its democratic elements, important so as to be able to promote common interests, such as trade, investment, tourism, culture, and society. Tunisia now has a constitution that protects press independence, among other rights, which can help Europe to consider the country a key partner in the EU’s fight to tackle terrorism. Collaboration between Europe and the African state can positively contribute to a more thorough and consolidated democracy in Tunisia.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. In the European Parliament, we are committed to renewing our commitment to the people of Tunisia and to their political transition process initiated in 2011. My support for the resolution in which we call on the Union to support its Government in the face of the challenges and threats facing the country in consolidating the democratic process, implementing the necessary reforms for the sake of its social and economic prosperity, and ensuring its security. In the motion for a resolution we have supported, we express our support for political and institutional reforms, which will advance a path of democratic consolidation, as well as to implement economic and social development measures as soon as possible.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. By voting in favour of the Castaldo report, the European Parliament has once again demonstrated the value it places on the unwavering partnership between the European Union and Tunisia, both the cradle and the best symbol of the Arab Spring. In full line with the positions I have always defended as rapporteur of the Socialist Group for TRADE relations between the EU and Tunisia, the report sets an ambitious course for stabilizing the country's political and economic situation. Parliament gives frank support to the negotiations for a comprehensive and comprehensive free trade agreement, provided that they involve civil society very closely and are conducted in an atmosphere of maximum transparency. Business as usual does not have to be: the agreement must be progressive and asymmetrical so that Tunisia retains the full freedom to sanctified the sectors it does not wish to open to liberalisation. Furthermore, the Castaldo report makes two proposals which I fully support: the efforts of European governments must be multiplied to recover the assets misappropriated under Ben Ali, and urgent measures must be taken to ease the Tunisian debt burden.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. It is important to build democracy and civil society in Tunisia, but to achieve this objective by the wrong means. Financial support, mobility partnerships and visa facilitation are not suitable for combating terrorism. I therefore reject this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP report on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context. I agree with the provisions set out in the report on tunisia's importance in the fight against terrorism and the calls for increased opportunities for education, social and economic development, so that Tunisian youth become more resilient to the vilion of extremist groups. The report discusses tunisia's most important political reforms, their course, economic and social development, security and defence issues and sets out guidelines for cooperation in the areas of mobility, research, education and culture.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. It is worth remembering, unfortunately all too often, a basic principle: the EU has no rights in the field of foreign affairs. Moreover, the EU's action since the so-called 'Arab Spring' has been deleterious throughout the area. Tunisia is a convalescent country, not yet stabilized after the seizure of power by the so-called moderate Islamists and to which the EU, through its action, imposes a halt in its economic efforts. Although the report is innocuous in its substance as in its proposals, it nevertheless remains in favour of EU intervention that is particularly damaging to France, of which Tunisia is part of the natural zone of influence. I therefore voted against this report and the idea that the EU should have a diplomatic role.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. 'u2012 Tunisia is one of the priority countries under the European Neighbourhood Policy of the Union. The process of peaceful democratic transition in Tunisia is an example of success in the Arab world and its consolidation is fundamental for the stability of the whole region and, as a direct consequence, for Europe's security.  Tunisia's serious social and economic situation and tunisia's historic democratic transition require a much more ambitious EU-Tunisia partnership, which is not limited to the measures traditionally adopted. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report in which Parliament calls on the Union to continue its support of the Tunisian people and People’s Representative Assembly (PRA) on their path of democratisation in an exceedingly complex and challenging regional context.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The consolidation of the democratic transition process in Tunisia is extremely important for stability in the region and for security in Europe. But Tunisia has also been hit unusually hard by terrorist attacks in recent years. The country also served as a recruiting ground for IS. In this context, the Tunisian economy, which is heavily dependent on foreign investment, tourism and the export of products to the EU, has been hit hard. This economic stagnation must be broken. Over the past year, the EU has taken urgent trade measures to support the Tunisian economy. But in order to strengthen democracy and get the economy back on track, it is appropriate for Tunisia to implement structural reforms. That is why the EU supports the country in its efforts to modernise and liberalise its economy, although it will also need to reform the labour market and tailor education to the needs of the labour market. In order to realise its broader political and social ambitions, it is desirable to reform the judiciary, to deradicalise, to reintroduce the death penalty and to guarantee freedom of the press and association.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The initiative appeals to the EU and the Member States to better mobilise and coordinate technical and financial resources to support Tunisia. It expresses support for the democratic process in the country. It stresses that the difficult task of strengthening stability in an unstable regional context requires the support of the Assembly of People's Representatives (PRA) while deepening democracy. The report stresses the need for reforms in a number of areas and the call for respect for human rights, for the abolition of the death penalty and for the guarantee of fundamental civil liberties. The security situation in the country and region, which is significantly destabilised by the impact of the situation in Libya, remains worrying. A worryingly high number of young Tunisians are hired by the terrorist group Islamic State and others. The tendency of young people to join extremist groups is due to economic stagnation, which creates hopeless among the young. The EU and Tunisia signed the Tunisia Mobility Partnership in March 2014, the report calls for its swift implementation; recommends that Member States show solidarity with Tunisia by making it easier for entrepreneurs, teachers, students, researchers, artists, etc. to show solidarity with Tunisia by making it easier for entrepreneurs, teachers, students, researchers, artists, etc. to demonstrate their solidarity with Tunisia.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on EU relations with Tunisia in the current regional context because Tunisia represents a successful example in the Arab world and its consolidation is paramount for the stability of the entire region. It is crucial that the democratic transition in Tunisia be consolidated and supported politically and economically. The terrorist attacks have had a devastating effect on the economy, and unemployment, especially among young people, remains high. The critical nature of the problems affecting Tunisia demands more and better support to contribute to capacity building for the Tunisian institutions, justice sector and security reforms.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the process of peaceful, democratic transformation, Tunisia, which is a successful example to the Arab world, is in a difficult socio-economic situation and also faces security problems. The Motion for a Resolution of the Committee on Foreign Affairs reviews how the EU can support the democratic transition in Tunisia, which is in serious difficulties, in the areas of political reforms and institutions, economic and social development, security and defence, and mobility, research, education and culture. I supported the adoption of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. We are voting against this situation report, which proposes deepening cooperation between the EU and Tunisia within the framework of the neighbourhood policy. Our main objection is that the EU has no rights in the field of foreign affairs, especially after the decisions taken during the 'Arab Spring' which have had negative consequences. Moreover, Tunisia is still an unstable state where the strong presence of islamist political groups, known as moderates, has considerably weakened the national economic structure.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. 'u2012 Tunisia is one of the priority countries under the European Neighbourhood Policy of the Union. Its process of peaceful democratic transition is an example of success in the Arab world and its consolidation is fundamental for the stability of the whole region and, as a direct consequence, for europe's security. Tunisia is currently facing a difficult socio-economic situation, as well as security challenges, which are mainly the result of the situation in Libya. The Tunisian economy relies heavily on foreign investment, tourism and exports of goods to the EU, and the economy can only prosper if democracy can continue to develop. I advocate the deepening of the EU-Tunisia partnership with more ambition, which is not limited to the measures traditionally adopted, so as to allow greater absorption capacity for Tunisia and to give stability to democracy, good governance, the fight against corruption, economic development and employment in the region.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU has no rights in the field of foreign affairs. Moreover, the EU's action since the so-called 'Arab Spring' has been deleterious throughout the area. Tunisia is a convalescent country, not yet stabilized after the seizure of power of the so-called moderate Islamists, whose action has allowed this oasis of development within an area in crisis to lose little or no ten years of economic effort. Although the report is innocuous in its substance as in its proposals, it nevertheless remains in favour of EU intervention that is particularly damaging to France, of which Tunisia is part of the natural zone of influence. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which urges Tunisia to go further in its political reforms such as abolishing discrimination based on gender, supporting the inclusion of young people, and reforming penal law with a view to upholding fundamental freedoms such as freedom of expression.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on the vote of this report on the European Union's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context. Indeed, this text sets out provisions that call on the Commission to develop circular migration schemes that can open up safe and legal routes for migrants. I am consistently opposed to the irresponsible policy of migrant quotas, which is a call for air to illegal immigration.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering tunisia's courageous path towards a democratic and pluralistic political system; the great commitment made by civil society to this end; and the major economic and security challenges that threaten its success; We are voting in favour of this report. Indeed, its content and holistic vision consistently respond to the broad spectrum of objectives set by European foreign policy in support of the country and, more generally, Africa.  The attacks on the country have, in fact, undermined its largest economic voice, tourism. The resulting economic failure has further aggravated Tunisia's social situation, increasing its inequalities and increasing the risk of radicalisation among the most fragile fringes. Added to the complicated scenario is the great test of sustained solidarity with Libya's nearly two million refugees. The report is consistent with all the measures, voted on by the European Parliament, aimed at mitigating the causes of migration, such as the negotiations for a comprehensive and in-depth free trade agreement, financial assistance measures and trade facilitation. The report, in our favour, promotes cooperation for sustainable development and security.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union plays an important role in strengthening democracy in the countries where it is most needed. In the case of Tunisia, we have witnessed significant progress in recent years. The country's already struggling economy has been hit hard by terrorist attacks in 2015 and 2016, which have resulted in the loss of a substantial portion of one of its most significant tourism revenues. I believe that, in order for the democratisation process to continue to be sustainable, we must come to Tunisia's aid. Against this background, I supported the report. I would like to point out that I consider the establishment of the EU-Tunisia Joint Parliamentary Committee to be a great idea, which will allow regular monitoring of the results achieved.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that reaffirms its pledge to the Tunisian people and the political transition process that began in 2011 and stresses the need for a more ambitious EU-Tunisia partnership.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – Against the backdrop of instability in North Africa and the Middle East, Tunisia is a rare example of a country continuing its democratic development. I believe that if the EU wants to contribute to the establishment of peace in the Arab world, then one of the things it needs to do is promote the development of countries like Tunisia and help make this country a role model for the rest of the region.  One of the most effective methods by which the EU can help mitigate the situation in the Southern Mediterranean countries is the provision of logistical and financial assistance. This help will serve to restore security and the country's economy, creating jobs for the many unemployed young people who, in the impasse, have become a natural target of radical influences proclaimed by organizations like Islamic State.  An important clarification to be made is that my support for providing assistance to Tunisia must be distinguished from the conclusion of a trade agreement, which would have a negative effect on the livelihoods of the European farmer.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The building of democracy and civil society in Tunisia is right, but this objective is to be achieved by the wrong means. Financial support, mobility partnerships and visa facilitation are not suitable for combating terrorism. I would have opposed this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Tunisia's security and socio-economic situation are complex, but the country has made progress towards a democratisation process. The report welcomes the provision of financial assistance to Tunisia and the opening of negotiations on a comprehensive free trade agreement. It is good that there has been increased cooperation in the fight against terrorism between the EU and Tunisia. It is also important to cooperate more closely with Europol.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The report we voted on represents a renewed commitment to Tunisia following the election of Youssef Chahed's new government. The process of transitioning to democracy in Tunisia is an example of success in the Arab world and its continuity depends in large part on the stability of the region.  Despite this, we must continue to work together to advance the country's social and economic development and to promote investment. That is why I congratulate the Commission on its proposal to devote aid of around EUR 500 million and the conversion of Tunisian debt into local investment projects. I voted in favour of the report with the hope that democracy and development in Tunisia will continue to take centre control.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is a successful example in the Arab world and its stability is of the utmost importance for the stability of the whole region. It is very important that the democratic transition in Tunisia is consolidated and supported politically and economically. Terrorist attacks have had disastrous consequences for the economy and unemployment, particularly among young people, which remains high. Given the critical nature of the problems affecting Tunisia, more and better support is needed to contribute to capacity building for institutions in Tunisia, in the field of justice as well as security reforms. I voted in favour of the report calling for a genuine comprehensive and in-depth partnership between the EU and Tunisia. Without measures to strengthen Tunisia's absorption capacity and stability, democracy, good governance, the fight against corruption, economic growth and employment in the region, any prospect of reform will be put at risk.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding initiative. We do not support the development and practice of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, we remain concerned that the Global Security Strategy foresees an increased capability for the EU to project power in the near neighbourhood, which would include Tunisia. As such, we voted against. Following the vote by the UK to leave the EU, we support friendly and cordial relations between Tunisia and the UK.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In addition to reiterating my vote in favour of this text and thanking the rapporteur for the excellent compromise work he has been able to do, I am publicly thanking the Tunisian Government and citizens for what they have done in recent years. I hope that Tunisia will also serve as an example and a model for other Countries in North Africa which are still experiencing difficulties as a result of bad policies and deplorable events.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as I believe that the relations of the EU with neighbouring countries are of utmost importance for the stability and security of the bloc – both internally and externally. In this report the Parliament urges the European Union and the Member States to mobilise and better coordinate substantial technical and financial resources to support Tunisia. Parliament also expresses deep concern about the immediate security spillover in Tunisia originating from instability in Libya. It welcomes the EU and Tunisia Mobility Partnership signed in March 2014 and calls for its rapid implementation, and calls for a new visa policy towards Tunisia and for the conclusion of a readmission agreement.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. —Tunisia is one of the most developed countries in North Africa, which thanks to its political and economic achievements can set an example for other countries from the same region. The EU has been fostering good relations with Tunisia for a long time, and this resolution only reaffirms this. The resolution adopts many views indicating a tendency to improve relations with Tunisia and proposes increasing financial assistance in order to successfully implement the reforms envisaged for the period 2016-2020 as soon as possible.  As many Lebanese have fled to Tunisia fleeing the chaos that has emerged in their country, I support the proposal to urgently mobilise funds for Tunisia to stabilise the political situation as soon as possible, which is ultimately a condition for realising reforms. I also consider it a positive proposal to change some laws that do not respect human dignity, i.e. are aimed at discrimination.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a situation report with a proposal to deepen EU-Tunisia cooperation within the framework of the neighbourhood policy. On principle, I would like to point out that the EU has no rights in the field of foreign affairs. Moreover, the EU's action since the so-called 'Arab Spring' has proved harmful throughout the area. Tunisia is a convalescent country, not yet stabilized after the seizure of power of the so-called moderate Islamists, whose action has allowed this oasis of development within an area in crisis to lose little or no ten years of economic effort. Although the report is innocuous in its substance as in its proposals, it nevertheless remains in favour of EU intervention that is particularly damaging to France, of which Tunisia is a historical partner. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia is an example of success in the Arab world and its consolidation is of primary importance for the stability of the whole region. It is essential that its democratic transition is strengthened and supported, politically and economically. Terrorist attacks have had a devastating effect on the economy, particularly targeting the tourism sector, and unemployment remains very high, especially among young people. In this context, there is a need for greater and better support for strengthening the capacities of Tunisian institutions, the judicial system and security reforms. The EU can do a great deal in this regard, accompanying the reform process, launching projects to support civil society, increasing aid provided through the European Neighbourhood Instrument and coordinating international aid. At the same time, the Union must promote respect for human rights, through the development of monitoring mechanisms that guarantee, in particular, fundamental freedoms and gender equality. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported Castald's report because Tunisia is a successful example of a peaceful democratic transition that is important for the stability of the entire region and the security of Europe. The Tunisian economy, its growth and further development of democracy depend largely on foreign investment, tourism and product exports in the EU.  Therefore, the EU and the Member States are encouraged to mobilise and better coordinate resources to provide financial assistance to Tunisia. It calls on the Council to swiftly implement the aid programme for Tunisia, focusing on security assistance to protect tourism infrastructure and combat terrorist threats. It welcomes the stronger political dialogue between the EU and Tunisia and stresses the importance of protecting human rights.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. In 2011, Tunisia became the birthplace of the Arab Spring, which heralded its transition to a democratic state. The country has faced many challenges and threats in its efforts to consolidate and ensure that the necessary reforms are implemented and implemented. Yet it is now a successful example for other Arab countries, and its consolidation is essential for the stability of the entire region. In this context, it is necessary to support the National People's Assembly (PRA), which should continue to strive to increase its capacities and thus improve its capacity to fulfil its legislative role. Despite the ongoing social and economic complications, I see Tunisia as having a high potential for closer relations with the EU. For this reason, it is important to continue to support the country so that it can complete its transition to democracy altogether. Member States should therefore participate fully and provide Tunisia with technical and financial resources. Tunisia should then use this support in particular to build the capacities of civic associations, reform the judiciary and the rule of law, to continue the process of decentralisation and to strengthen the regions.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We must adequately support Tunisia, and all the countries of North Africa, so that it can continue its process of democratisation and ensure the fight against Islamist terrorism. This part of the world is of vital importance to Europe, to our security and to our economy. The Mediteranno is the cradle of our civilisation and we must look more closely at this regional context. Support for Tunisia must not, however, be achieved through unholy measures such as the additional quotas for olive oil imported duty-free into the EU. Relations between the EU and Tunisia must be based on mutual and non-asymmetric advantage.  With regard to this point, I believe that, without affecting the agricultural sector in particular, it would be more useful to invest in cooperation in the tourism and cultural sector. Beyond this important aspect, I believe that the report is balanced and that it carefully monitors the state of bilateral relations. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of its approval.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which underlines the importance for the European Union of maintaining a privileged relationship with Tunisia, including providing the country with technical and financial resources to cope with the economic, political and security difficulties it faces.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European project is not limited to solidarity between Member States, but also includes solidarity between the Union and neighbouring countries, especially those experiencing periods of greatest grace. Tunisia, precisely one of those neighbours and partners, has been making efforts towards a peaceful transition to a democratic political regime, but is currently experiencing a period of greatest external security difficulty, not only because of its geographical proximity to unstable Libya, but also because it has been the target of several terrorist attacks in recent years.  At the same time, Tunisia's external security challenges are obviously related to economic-financial challenges, as the Tunisian economy is largely dependent on tourism and foreign investment. This situation poses serious risks to the process of consolidating democracy in that Mediterranean State and, reflexively, its relationship with the Union.  Understanding what has just been set out in both the premises and conclusions, this report proposes a technical and financial aid package for Tunisia.  In that sense, my vote could not fail to be in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding initiative. We do not support the development and practice of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, we remain concerned that the Global Security Strategy foresees an increased capability for the EU to project power in the near neighbourhood, which would include Tunisia. As such, we voted against. Following the vote by the UK to leave the EU, we support friendly and cordial relations between Tunisia and the UK.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that Tunisia is one of the priority countries under the European Neighbourhood Policy of the Union, tunisia highlights the challenges and threats facing the country in consolidating its democratic process, in particular in carrying out the necessary reforms in the field of social and economic development and in ensuring its security, and makes a call for a genuine and in-depth partnership between the European Union and Tunisia. Participants in the Deauville Partnership believe that the situation in Tunisia justifies the launch of a genuine 'Marshall Plan', with adequate funding to support the consolidation of the democratic transition and foster investment and development in all sectors of economic and social life in the country. The EU welcomes the good cooperation between Tunisia and its neighbours, demonstrated by the signing of a trade agreement, and stresses the importance of respecting human rights in the implementation of the European Neighbourhood Policy. The Union also stresses that the relaunch of the political integration process within the Arab Maghreb Union could be particularly timely in order to ensure security and strengthen cooperation throughout the region.  In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At noon, the EP reiterated its support for Tunisia. And for good reason; Since the Arab Spring, born on its land, Tunisia has been the subject of political instability and terrorist reality. The 2015 attacks at the Bardo Museum and the seaside resort of Sousse, as well as the March 2016 attacks at the National Guard post in Ben Gerdane, are still remembered. It is crucial that Europe stands with this fragile but courageous country in the fight against terrorism. The European aid, about 500 million euros, is to be considered in this context and gives a "breath of fresh air" to the Tunisian population. The latter is directly affected by the absence of tourists, a key sector in Tunisia, which accounts for more than 7% of the national GDP. In adopting the Castaldo report, MEPs also highlighted the leading role played by civil society in the adoption of social reforms. The awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize in 2015 to the Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet crowned the efforts of an entire country.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Tunisia is one of the priority countries under the EU's European Neighbourhood Policy and a good example in the process of peaceful democratic transition. It is an example of success in the Arab world and its consolidation is fundamental for the stability of the whole region and for the security of Europe.  We must continue to stress the importance of respect for human rights and the need to create mechanisms to monitor respect for fundamental freedoms and strengthen the role of civil organisations.  Free trade agreements should contribute to tunisia's stability.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which aims to promote relations between the Union and Tunisia in the current regional context. Tunisia is a case of democratic success in the Arab world and its consolidation is of paramount importance to the stability of the entire region. The Union must continue to support Tunisia's socio-economic, political and security transition. We welcome the efforts of the Tunisian Government and encourage the Union to support the reform of the country's judicial sector and rule of law, the reform of the penal code and call for increased aid to Tunisia through the European Neighbourhood Instrument, among other issues. We also underline the importance of respect for human rights and the development of monitoring mechanisms in respect for fundamental freedoms, gender equality and strengthening the role of civil society organizations.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The peaceful democratic transition underway in Tunisia today must be seen as an example in the Arab world. However, I am concerned about the impact of the new anti-terrorism legislation on fundamental rights. The fight against terrorism is important and requires an adequate response, but it cannot be contrary to these rights.  With regard to the economic and social development of this country, I welcome the Commission's proposal to provide macro-financial assistance of EUR 500 million. I also believe that it is necessary to convert Tunisian debt into strategic investment projects. There are many other elements in the text that I can quite agree with, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this report, the European Parliament calls on the European Union and the Member States to mobilise and coordinate substantial technical and financial resources to support Tunisia in consolidating its democratic process by carrying out the necessary political reforms, particularly in terms of the security and economic and social development of tunisia. I am in favour of providing this extraordinary aid by establishing an in-depth partnership with the European Union, which will certainly strengthen Tunisia's stability in a volatile regional context, where measures are needed to combat corruption and to implement an effective rule of law, promote political stability and good governance. I endorse the reform suggestions put forward by the rapporteur, which are bolder than those traditionally adopted, because it is only through the implementation of more ambitious solutions that Tunisia will be able to foster investment and promote its political, economic and social development, generating jobs and improving the quality of its public services, with a view to achieving sustainable and inclusive growth.  For all that is set out, my vote was in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which identifies the opportunities and challenges of EU-Tunisia relations in a particularly complex and unstable regional context. This text paints a picture of Euro-Tunisian relations, showing the progress of democratic reforms, economic and trade relations, and cooperation on security and migration. In less than a year, Parliament has repeatedly reiterated its desire to step up and increase its support for Tunisia, with the adoption of exceptional measures and the granting of new macro-financial assistance. Five years after the events of the Arab Spring, Tunisia is emerging as the only successful transition model and raises hope for democrats around the world. With this in mind, the Union must provide unwavering support to Tunisia and meet the demands of the privileged partnership that binds us together.  It is essential that the Union broadens the areas of cooperation and deepens those that already exist! There are many challenges that could undermine this process. Terrorism and economic and social imbalances are two examples. These challenges require responses built together, within the framework of ever closer cooperation between the Union and Tunisia.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report ultimately did not include our group's amendments on debt (in favour of an audit, restructuring and forgiveness by the debt) and the agreement to readmission of migrants (the practice of which is a violation of human rights), this is a positive report as regards the Union's support for the process of democratisation of the country. However, we do not support the inclusion of a section in favour of the opaque Free Trade Agreement (ZLCAP) which, like all of its kind, by the asymmetry of the parties, would end up harming the weakest in terms of terms of trade, both economically and environmentally, as the manifesto signed by 29 Tunisian and French civil society organizations points out. In addition, the effects of liberalization on certain Spanish products, such as olive trees, must be analysed. Finally, we understand that agreements of this kind, due to their great social, economic, labor and environmental implications, should be the product of extensive informed debate in the companies involved prior to their subscription. I voted abstention.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on EU relations with Tunisia, as it gives Tunisia's fledgling democracy support for the stabilisation of the country. It also calls for the rapid implementation of the EU-Tunisia Mobility Partnership, which will include new visa guidelines for Tunisia.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report reaffirms the Union's support for the democratic consolidation process in Tunisia and underlines the problems that could jeopardize it: debt, unemployment, security, rule of law, etc. In general, the report has a more progressive approach than the European Parliament usually employs to deal with relations with other countries. However, there are some elements that I do not agree with and which made me finally unable to support the report, and as a result I abstained from the final vote: one of the main problems was that the report supports the EUNAVFOR mission, and that on the other hand, it talks about deepening the negotiations of the free trade agreement to which our delegation opposes , while the text seeks to give it an approach focused on the environment and consumer protection, I cannot vote in favour of the document supporting free trade, which also commends the macro-financial support of EUR 500 million without denouncing its neoliberal conditions, nor does it make any reference to a necessary audit of Tunisia's odious debt.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report, which urges Tunisia to go further in its political reforms in ways such as abolishing discrimination based on gender, supporting the inclusion of young people and reforming penal law with a view to upholding fundamental freedoms such as the freedom of expression.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in favour. I support and appreciate the evolving partnership with Tunisia as a model country for democracy and stability in the Middle East and North Africa. The EU is to continue to work with the Tunisian Government to promote common interests, including trade, investment, culture and security.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The partnership relations between the European Union (EU) and Tunisia are legally supported by the Association Agreement, which entered into force in 1998. I consider this to be particularly important because terrorism, which hit Tunisia and Europe hard in 2015 and 2016, requires a more united, holistic response aimed at eliminating the root causes of this phenomenon. In view of Tunisia's ambitious reforms and projects, I supported the draft legislative resolution because I believe that, thanks to the proposals and measures adopted, we will be able to intensify cooperation with Tunisia. I believe that the willingness and determination to deepen the EU-Tunisia partnership is a good signal for the implementation of reforms concerning young people, job creation, social progress, investment and reducing regional disparities. I believe that the EU's macro-financial assistance will strengthen Tunisia's economic stabilisation and its programme of fundamental reforms.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The report on relations with Tunisia was hardly expected.  After 2011, when President Ben Ali was deposed, there has unfortunately not been much talk about Tunisia in the EU. Since then, there has been a major political transformation in this country, but Tunisia is still plagued by major challenges - from terrorism to political fragmentation and socioeconomic inequalities.  In this context, therefore, the EU should give more power and help this unique process of democratisation in the Arab world. This is why this report represents an opportunity for the EU to once again pay some attention to Tunisia and to show future deeper and more effective cooperation between them.  The report reiterates the EU's past commitments to assist Tunisians in the political transition, calls on the EU to increase its assistance to Tunisia, including financial assistance to civil society, and stresses the need to respect human rights in the process of reforming the country.  Because I believe that good EU cooperation with the neighbourhood regions is needed and that the report is well prepared, I supported it.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on the EU's relationship with Tunisia has few weaknesses. It would have made sense to include in the text issues of the repatriation of Tunisian migrants. It remains to be seen whether useful uses can be found for the aid money planned by the EU. Apart from these issues, it is important to have clear support for Tunisia. There are few functioning democratic and constitutional elements in the Arab countries. Tunisia is very important as a positive example for the region, and so I was happy to vote in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ Tunisia is an example among the countries of North Africa and the Middle East of the successful story of the transformation of the political regime and society as a whole towards democracy. It is in the vital interest of the European Union for Tunisia to support economically and politically, thus increasing the chances of stabilising the situation in the region.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the REPORT on EU-Tunisia relations in the current regional context, because I consider Tunisia to be one of the priority countries related to the European neighbourhood policy. Tunisia is a country where tourism is a key sector for the economy, and today it is hit hard by different circumstances, the most prominent of which is terrorism.  Tunisia has suffered several terrorist attacks and is an important partner of the European Union in the fight against terrorism. Tunisia faces security risks and is in a difficult socio-economic situation stemming mainly from Libya. Good partnerships should be developed in which the population on both sides of the Mediterranean should be taken into account. Strong support from the European Union is needed to ensure stability and deepen democracy in an already fragile region.  The Tunisian economy depends on foreign investment and exports of products in the EU, and it can only grow with the further development of democracy. The EU and Tunisia must continue to work together to succeed in promoting some of their common interests, such as trade, investment, tourism, culture and security.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. What is the point of the much-praised Mediterranean Union when this mechanism, created specifically for states such as Tunisia, fails completely? It is true that the EU acts as a mediator in its Member States in the event of international crises. But the appearance is deceptive. The EU does not add value in the case of the Arab Spring, and the bilateral dependencies between Arab and European states are too great. Nevertheless, this resolution calls for Another half a billion euros of taxpayers' money to be transferred to Tunisia in addition to the existing EU transfers. I reject that.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Tunisia is considered one of the priority countries under the European Neighbourhood Policy and is also seen in the Arab world as a successful example of a peaceful and democratic transition, which is crucial for the stability of the entire region and thus for the security of Europe. Currently, Tunisia is in a difficult economic-social situation and faces security risks due to the situation in Libya.  A key branch of the Tunisian economy is tourism that has been hit hard by neighbourhood circumstances and terrorist attacks. Tunisia remains an important partner of the European Union in the fight against terrorism, but it is worrying that Daesh is recruiting many young Tunisians because of the economic stagnation that attracts young people to extremist organisations. I support the report on relations between the European Union and Tunisia, as I believe that the guidelines in it are well stated and are a good guideline for political and institutional reforms, as well as economic and social development.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on EU-Tunisia relations in the current regional context.  I support the call for the EU and the Member States to mobilise and better coordinate significant technical and financial resources to provide concrete support to Tunisia.  Tunisia, which is one of the EU's priority countries under the European Neighbourhood Policy, is a sample example of a peaceful democratic transition in the Arab world, making its consolidation crucial for the stability of the whole region. In the light of the migrant and refugee crisis, the stability of the whole region is all the more important for the European Union.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
