text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's report on the EU's relations with Tunisia in the current regional context, as Tunisia is one of the EU's important partners in the Mediterranean region and its latest developments give some hope that this state will be stabilised and further developed. The EU is also interested in these developments, which is why I welcome the EP's now reaffirming its support for Tunisia and calling for greater support from the Member States and eu institutions and agencies, whether in terms of supporting civil society, greater cooperation on trade or, last but not least, cooperation and support for Tunisia in its fight against terrorism and the consequences of the unstable situation, particularly in Libya. A stable and prosperous Tunisia is an EU concern.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report has positive points. It also assigns responsibilities and underlines that there must be reforms, particularly in the areas of justice, civil liberties, the rights of special groups of the population, etc. in order to strengthen the relationship with the EU. However, there are problematic reports that we cannot ignore. The promotion of the free trade agreement with Tunisia is particularly negative. The Free Trade Agreements fully serve the intended benefits of the EU's dominant circles. They create interdependence - economic as well as political - with partners and promote extreme competition and investment for the benefit of large capital and at the expense of the interests of society and peoples.  For these reasons we have abstained.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report provides for high financial support for Tunisia from the EU. The Union should be primarily interested in tackling the problems of its Member States.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, fully agreeing with the positive perception and support reflected there from it in terms of building democracy in Tunisia and its stabilising role within the region. I consider it important that further development of the political and economic relations with the European Union and its Member States will continue to help Tunisia in its fight against terrorism and the effects of economic hardship and unemployment, in particular with regard to the development of judicial and security institutions. I am convinced that a resolution of the European Parliament with such clear support can also contribute to the fulfillment of these positive developments in Tunisia.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Tunisia's peaceful democratic transition over the last 5 years is a good example in the Arab world and their consolidation is essential for the stability of the region as a whole, with direct consequences for security in Europe. Unfortunately, Tunisia is currently in a very difficult economic and social situation and the Tunisian economy is heavily dependent on foreign investment, tourism and exports of products to the Union. In the current crisis situation, it is necessary to set up a fund to support democratic transition, investment and development in all sectors of economic and social life in a holistic way. In particular, money is needed to create new jobs and maintain high-quality public services that are widely available. The European Parliament's report rightly draws attention to the need for the Union to be involved in helping this young democracy. I have therefore chosen to support the European Parliament resolution.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. Tunisia has always been one of the priority countries under the EU's European Neighbourhood Policy. The report highlights the need to strengthen the EU-Tunisia partnership and direct it towards more ambitious actions. Cooperation between the Arab country and its neighbours and the process of democratic transition, which was a positive example of the Arab spring, are praised. Tunisia's socio-economic situation is certainly still difficult and the country faces fundamental challenges in terms of political reforms, socio-economic development, security and defence.  In view of the challenges and threats facing Tunisia, in order to consolidate the democratic process and to implement the necessary reforms, I believe that improving the coordination of EU-Tunisia relations is essential. I voted in favour because the report urges the Eu ropean Union to establish a genuine and solid partnership.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The peaceful democratic transition process in Tunisia represents a successful example in the Arab world and its consolidation is paramount for the stability of the entire region and, as a direct consequence, for the security of Europe. However, Tunisia currently faces a difficult socio-economic situation but also security challenges mostly deriving from the situation in Libya. Furthermore, tourism, which represents a key element of the Tunisian economy, is severely affected by these circumstances and by the terrorist attacks which have targeted the country. Consequently the EU and its Member States must remain committed to working with the people of Tunisia and their government to promote common interests, including in trade, investment, tourism, culture and security.  The report in question is a good and balanced text, divided into four parts: Political Reforms and Institutions; Economic and Social Development; Security and Defence; and Mobility, Research, Education and Culture. The report reemphasises the need to support Tunisia and calls for many actions such as the launch of a programme in support of the reform of the judicial sector and the rule of law and the increase of EU aid to Tunisia through the European Neighbourhood Instrument. I support this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this text, which renews our commitment to the Tunisian people and the political transition process begun in 2011. We highlight the challenges and threats facing the country as it seeks to consolidate the democratic process, implement the necessary reforms in the interests of its social and economic prosperity, and ensure its security. The UNION and the Member States must mobilise and better coordinate substantial technical and financial resources to provide concrete assistance to Tunisia.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ We cannot stress enough that the consolidation of the peaceful democratic transition process in Tunisia is paramount for the stability of the entire region. Unfortunately, the ongoing terrorist threat and economic crisis in Tunisia have stalled the implementation of essential political, economic and social reforms. This is why I voted in favour of the report on EU relations with Tunisia in the current regional context, as I agree that we must step up our financial support and technical assistance to help ensure that Tunisia achieves tangible results in terms of growth and employment, the fight against corruption, a thorough security infrastructure and the reform of certain of its controversial societal laws.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the REPORT on EU-Tunisia relations in the current regional context, as the Tunisian economy depends on foreign investment, tourism and product exports in the EU. In view of Tunisia's strategic development plan for the period 2016-2020 and as Tunisia is one of the priority countries under neighbourhood policy, I express my support for the democratisation process and underline the need for social and economic reforms and the initiative for the Tunisian Strategic Development Plan.  I welcome the stronger political dialogue between the EU and Tunisia in the fight against terrorism and call on the Tunisian authorities to work closely together to combat irregular immigration. Unemployment, in particular graduates, needs to be reduced and thorough reforms should be initiated to boost growth and quality employment.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on EU-Tunisia relations in the current regional context.  Tunisia is currently facing difficult social and economic conditions, as well as security challenges, most of which are due to the situation in Libya. This situation and the terrorist attacks in Tunisia are very damaging to tourism. The Tunisian economy depends to a large extent on foreign investment, tourism and exports of products to the EU, and the economy can only thrive if democracy is further developing.  The European Union and its Member States must continue their efforts to work with the Tunisian people and the Government in order to promote common interests, including trade, investment, tourism, culture and security.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report ultimately did not include our group's amendments on debt (in favour of an audit, restructuring and forgiveness by the debt) and the agreement to readmission of migrants (the practice of which is a violation of human rights), this is a positive report as regards the Union's support for the process of democratisation of the country. However, we do not support the inclusion of a section in favour of the opaque Free Trade Agreement (ZLCAP) which, like all of its kind, by the asymmetry of the parties, would end up harming the weakest in terms of terms of trade, both economically and environmentally, as the manifesto signed by 29 Tunisian and French civil society organizations points out. In addition, the effects of liberalization on certain Spanish products, such as olive trees, must be analysed. Finally, we understand that agreements of this kind, due to their great social, economic, labor and environmental implications, should be the product of extensive informed debate in the companies involved prior to their subscription. I voted abstention.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a situation report with a proposal to deepen EU-Tunisia cooperation within the framework of the neighbourhood policy.  It is worth recalling a position in principle, namely that the EU has no rights in the field of foreign affairs. Moreover, THE EU's action since the so-called "Arab Spring" has been deleterious throughout the region. Tunisia is a convalescent country, not yet stabilized after the seizure of power of a so-called moderate Islamic government whose action has allowed this oasis of development within an area in crisis to lose little or no ten years of economic effort. Although the report is innocuous in its substance as in its proposals, it nevertheless remains in favour of EU intervention that is particularly damaging to France, of which Tunisia is part of the natural zone of influence.  I voted AGAINST.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution in the vote because Tunisia is an important partner of the EU in the Framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. In the context of political transition, the progressive democratisation of the state, the government's support for freedom of expression and civic issues, it is important to maintain and strengthen the current partnership. It supports the development of innovation, participation in joint research projects and enhanced cooperation on education, culture, the promotion of entrepreneurship and women's activities. The European Union will support efforts to ensure the security of the citizens of the Member States and of the population living in conflict-threatened regions of the Middle East.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently in a difficult socio-economic situation and is facing security problems due to the conditions in Libya. The Tunisian economy is heavily dependent on foreign investment, tourism and exports of products to the EU. An economy can only flourish if democracy can evolve. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Although the report ultimately did not include our group's debt amendments (in favour of an audit, restructuring and forgiveness by the debt group) and the agreement to readmission of migrants (the practice of which is a violation of human rights), this is a positive report as regards the Union's support for the country's process of democratisation. However, we do not support the inclusion of a section in favour of the opaque Free Trade Agreement (ZLCAP) which, like all of its kind, by the asymmetry of the parties, would end up harming the weakest in terms of terms of trade, both economically and environmentally, as the manifesto signed by 29 Tunisian and French civil society organizations points out. In addition, the effects of liberalization on certain Spanish products, such as olive trees, must be analysed. Finally, we understand that agreements of this kind, due to their great social, economic, labor and environmental implications, should be the product of extensive informed debate in the companies involved prior to their subscription. I voted abstention.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for, as I welcome this sound and comprehensive report, which is long overdue: the remarkable political transformation and efforts of the Tunisian people since the overthrow of Ben Ali in 2011 have regrettably fallen off the EU/EP radar. Tunisia faces mighty challenges – from terrorism to deep and persistent socio-economic inequalities and political fragility. The EU should substantially step up its efforts in support of this unique, effective democratisation process in the Arab world. It should remain vigilant to ensure that human rights and the rule of law are upheld in the challenging security and political context. Support to Tunisian youth, women and civil society should be a priority for the EU.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the establishment of an EU-Tunisia Joint Parliamentary Committee, which will play an extremely important role in the regular meeting and development of a structured political dialogue on democracy, human rights, the rule of law and any topic of mutual interest.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In this report, the European Parliament urges the Union and its Member States to better mobilise and coordinate technical and financial resources to support Tunisia, while providing express support to the process of democratisation in the Arab country, taking into account, in particular, the challenge of strengthening stability, while deepening democratisation , in a volatile regional context. Given that Tunisia was the country where the so-called "Arab Spring" began - which brought about the beginning of the democratic transition - and, in fact, the only one where this phenomenon culminated in the adoption of a consensus building (which came to enshrine such relevant aspects as freedom of conscience, equal rights of women and the civil character of the State) and the holding of democratic and transparent presidential and legislative elections , I share the need to reiterate European support for Tunisia, so I voted in the affirmative.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report in order to send an important signal: let us improve political dialogue with our neighbour Tunisia and strengthen our cooperation, in the areas of trade, tourism, culture and last but not least the fight against terrorism. We believe that a more ambitious partnership is possible. Europe can only be prosperous and safe if it goes well in its neighbouring countries. That is what we want to achieve with this report. Politically, we call for Tunisia to take action against torture, to abolish the death penalty and to repeal the law criminalising homosexuality. Economically, I think it is very important that Tunisia strives to modernise and liberalise the economy in order to create more jobs and provide opportunities and perspectives for young Tunisians. That is very important for my third priority, which is the fight against terror. I am concerned about the Tunisian youth who are joining Daesh and other terrorist groups. We must work with Tunisia to ensure inclusion so that young people are not attracted as foreign fighters. We must work together to develop a strategy to deal with returned combatants, ...

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The unstable situation that exists today in Tunisia is a reflection of the policy of aggression that major European powers have been engaged in in the region and whose crass example is libya. Tunisia's instability has naturally contributed to tunisia's situation, with terrorist attacks and problems on its borders. Citing the need to fight terrorism, arguments are made to a technocratic government to limit the civil and political rights of Tunisians. Secular and democratic associations have already ended in Tunisia, for example, and the mobility of the population has been limited. Popular leaders have already been murdered.  We do not deny the need to help Tunisia. We want to avoid the neocolonial policies that this EU has already accustomed us to.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I have rejected the report because this report talks about a mobility partnership and visa facilitation.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU's relations with Tunisia in order to strengthen transnational ties, support its ongoing democratisation process and call for greater protection of human rights. This choice will also make it possible to ensure greater economic stability for Tunisia, strengthen the role of civil society organisations and give greater impetus to research, education and culture.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that urges Tunisia to go further in its political reforms such as abolishing discrimination based on gender, supporting the inclusion of young people and reforming penal law with a view to upholding fundamental freedoms such as freedom of expression. It further underlines economic development challenges facing Tunisia and welcomes steps taken to modernise and liberalise the economy. Importantly, the report includes Tunisia’s security challenges that spill over from Libya and encourages Tunisia to abolish the death penalty. Lastly, the report calls for a new visa policy (visa liberalisation) towards Tunisia and the opening up of safe and legal routes for migration to decrease irregular migration.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The text tabled describes the political and institutional framework as it exists today but also underlines the reforms that need to be made. It raises the issues of economic and social development and explains the importance of education, culture and mobility in EU-Tunisia relations.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The report unfolds the EU's reactionary – unpopular policy and the aspirations of monopolies, in the region of North Africa that is critical to their interests. Eu-EU monopolies seek to strengthen - regain their positions in the region, centred on Tunisia. These objectives are supported by the report, calling for a rapid conclusion of the EES with the EU, which will allow business groups to enter the markets, increase the mobility of cheap labour and scientific resources. At the same time, the always convenient pretext of 'tackling terrorism', preventing 'migration flows', promotes an increase in EU military aggression and imperialist interventions. The report promotes Tunisia's close cooperation with all EU repressive mechanisms and its participation in its military naval operation, EUNAVFOR MED in the name of 'fighting radicalisation'. The fact that the author of this reactionary report is an MEP for grillo's 5-star Italian party shows that such parties, which appear to be 'Eurosceptic', express particular interests of parts of the capital that feel 'thrown' at existing associations within the EU, but serve with commitment the same objectives: to ensure the profitability of monopolistic groups through the break-up of workers' rights.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ the resolution on relations between the European Union and Tunisia continues the trend of European Union support for Tunisia, which, as the only country in the region, has mastered a democratic birth and is therefore a positive example for the other countries of the Arab Spring. Thanks to this democratic transition, Tunisia is thriving more than its neighbouring countries and also has stronger trade relations with Europe. However, despite all the positives, Islamic radicalisation is beginning to emerge in this country, which is causing considerable problems. That is why the European Parliament has proposed an even greater deepening of relations, which could help Tunisia in successful democratic reforms. At the same time, the resolution proposed financial support to help Tunisia fight unemployment, corruption or support Tunisia's efforts against desertification. I therefore supported the report.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Castaldo report because I believe that, despite the serious social and economic situation in Tunisia, tunisia's historic democratic transition requires a much more ambitious EU-Tunisia partnership, which is not limited to the measures traditionally adopted. I would therefore stress the resolution's call for the mobilisation of the Union and the Member States to improve the coordination of technical and financial resources with a view to providing concrete support to the country through a genuine full and in-depth partnership between the EU and Tunisia. I would also like to point out the proposal to set up an EU-Tunisia Joint Parliamentary Committee, which will play a central role, allowing Members of the European Parliament and Tunisian Members to meet regularly and develop a structured political dialogue on democracy, human rights, the rule of law and issues of common interest.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. Tunisia is currently facing security challenges and a difficult social and economic situation, largely due to the situation in Libya. This situation and terrorist attacks are detrimental to tourism and foreign investment.  Given that the democratic process has been consolidated, the EU can improve its political dialogue with Tunisia by taking more account of the interests and priorities of this important partner, thus maintaining the objective of stability, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to explain why I voted in favour of this report, which is a first step in the Union's fight against social dumping.  Of course, I believe that this is only a first step and that a great deal still to be done in this direction in the fight against social dumping, which, as we know, is the result of unbridled globalisation which allows capital a free movement which is linked to an increasingly radical process of deregulation, while systematically eroding the rights of workers and workers.  I believe that we must stop this race to the bottom with regard to labour rights, and I think that this must be done both by setting European labour standards, and therefore, let us say, by supplementing national legislation upwards, and by establishing a minimum citizenship income at European level, as we will be discussing tomorrow here in this House.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the deterioration of working conditions and social rights due to social dumping is the fundamental problem of the European Union. An erosion that has been constant for decades, which precarizes and impoverishes European workers. Europe has the tools to combat this practice, but we find that the directives that are adopted, as in transport, do not apply, or are undermined, as is the case with the legislation of posted workers. As the report asks, we demand the same rights for any worker in the same place in the Union; inspections, fines and sanctions to the last responsible; to fight against mailbox companies and fictitious subcontract chains; to strengthen collective bargaining and social dialogue. Because the laws and fundamental principles of this deeply devalued European Union demand it. Refusing to act, the European Union denies itself any possibility of a democratic Europe.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, loopholes in EU legislation and the weakening of collective agreements have led to the exploitation of workers by unscrupulous employers and unfair competition. Too often, such practices have wrongly fuelled local frustration, xenophobia and hatred towards migrant workers, contributing in our case to the Brexit vote. Many of my constituents felt their livelihoods and living standards were being threatened by the undercutting of wages and poor labour rules. It is time to address these loopholes, particularly for posted workers and agency workers.  That is why this report is so important and I supported it. It is time to ensure the equal pay for equal work in the same place applies for all workers across Europe. If we do not tackle this issue now, the consequences for the EU could be disastrous in the long term and I fear that it could threaten the very existence of this crucial union.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against this resolution, of course, because it creates a new instrument that has not yet been known. There is no formal concept of 'social dumping' and under this phrase any instrument can be created to combat freedom of employment. Dag The report openly states that a worker is not allowed to sell his social privilege for money. This limits the freedom of workers and, of course, employers. Ms. Forenza even said that it is necessary to take care of workers' rights, but I am not allowed to sell these rights, so Mrs. Forenza knows better than the employee what is good for him. Mrs López Bermejo even said that, as for Hitler, we should increase control, increase inspection. More control, less freedom— that's what you've been trying to do for a long time. Even under Stalin, there were different laws in different countries, and you want to unify everything. And this, unfortunately, is unacceptable, which is why I voted against it.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Union, if it is to be a union of states, should protect the single market and not jointly liquidate the market. The hunt for so-called social dumping among our countries is nothing more than excluding the competitiveness of countries that first suffered from Soviet domination for decades, separated them from the free world, and now cannot even increase their competitive advantages by reducing labour costs. This is not why we are taking part in the European Community to control our economy. We have entered the European Union in the belief that we can operate in the common market and that we will never give up the possibility of genuine competitiveness, that we will not give up on promoting the competitiveness of our companies.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I was happy to support this report on social dumping. Today, once again in this Parliament, President Juncker spoke of the same pay for the same work in the same place. I was pleased to hear him reiterate his view that equal pay for equal work in the same place is a focus for this Commission. I believe many European citizens will share that view. This is a crucial issue for the EU.  I was also pleased to support the proposal of introducing national minimum wages across Member States. We have a minimum wage in Ireland and I support the proposal that all Member States, in line with their national traditions and their practices, introduce a minimum wage. While I understand minimum wages are a Member State competence, we still know that decent wages across the EU will help to ensure social cohesion, and social cohesion is the antidote to social dumping. Social dumping undermines the EU in a most insidious way.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. "The report highlights several problematic aspects of wage competition and makes proposals that I can support. At the same time, it blackmails foreign workers and proposes measures that I cannot support. Many of them would transfer power from the social partners and from the Member States to the EU, and that goes against the principle of subsidiarity. That is why I choose to vote against several of the measures in the proposal, including a national minimum wage, which would undermine the Swedish model. It should not be forgotten that free movement of labour is fundamentally positive. In the meantime, the line advocated in the report leads to a situation in which this is impossible. All in all, it is a report in which I support the approach, but i cannot support the end product. That is why I choose to abstain.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfair competition between companies is a huge problem, as European workers have neither the same obligations nor the same social rights. The report proposes a number of solutions to this problem, focusing in particular on improving control and inspection instruments, modernising the registration of work services through the production of a single digital document for the transfer of social rights for each European worker and, finally, the production of a 'blacklist' containing all companies that have committed infringements in the field of worker protection. In order to guarantee all European workers high-level social protection within the EU, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The fight against social dumping, which could be defined as the downing race in socio-labor and wage standards within the Union, has been a priority of the Socialist Group since the last parliamentary term, as it results in the abuse of workers and erodes national social protection systems.  With this report, the Socialists wanted to improve labour controls and inspections in the Union, increase sanctions for companies that do not respect the rules, improve cooperation between national authorities in order to improve the fight against social security fraud, false self-employment and fictitious enterprises. We also call on the Commission to set up a Europe Road Transport Agency and to review the Workers' Displacement Directive.  In short, I voted in favour of this report because it is a huge step forward in upward social convergence in the Union and in the struggle to equate social rights with economic freedoms. Only by guaranteeing the principle of equal pay for equal work and fair competition can we really protect workers and SMEs, which are the real engine for creating jobs in the Union.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non—binding, own-initiative report. Social dumping is, of course, a huge problem with cheap labour being brought over from other countries by companies to undercut wages and avoid employing local workers. It also covers issues like companies finding cheaper alternatives elsewhere and moving operations abroad.  However, this report went on to call for more EU action, legislation, monitoring of legislation and data collection. On top of that, there isn’t an official legal definition of ‘social dumping’ in EU law, so this report is about an issue the EU can’t even define properly. The EU can never tackle social dumping, as the free movement of people is the perfect enabler for it to occur. Also, the EU’s Posted Workers Directive actually enables employers to bring cheap labour over to undercut the local community. The only way to stop social dumping is to leave the EU and get back control of immigration.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker keeps talking about his intention to fight social dumping. His speech is all the more astounding given that the European Union is the main culprit in this situation. The aim of this report on social dumping would be to fill the legislative and regulatory loopholes that promote the development of current unfair competition within the internal market. The solutions presented are totally unacceptable: labour control and inspection at European level, a desire to standardise social security systems and a series of harmonisations at all levels. I have, of course, opposed this text.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this very good own-initiative report, which proposes solutions to harmonise social rights upwards across the EU. The draft report recommended several measures to fill the regulatory and legislative gaps. These included strengthening labour inspections at national level and the creation of a EU-level body to combat abusive practices; an obligation for companies to have one official address to combat letterbox companies; blacklisting companies responsible for serious offences including the use of undeclared work; and a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to ensure real equal treatment of workers and fair competition. More than 700 amendments were tabled, mainly by conservatives, and the resulting compromise amendments have weakened the report, in particular by blocking all concrete proposals in relation to the PWD. Despite this it is still a very progressive and valuable report that comes at a crucial time in the lead-up to the revision of the PWD.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on social dumping in the European Union. It is essential to point out that unreported work, like fake self-employment, can lead to distortions of competition, causing long-term damage to social security systems. This promotes both the increase in the number of precarious jobs and a deterioration in levels of protection for workers: the fight against these abuses is essential to preserve free movement within the internal market.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on social dumping in the EU. The European Union was planned by its architects as a democratic space endowed with a strong economy and a high level of social protection. However, the harmonisation of social rights was often neglected and this resulted in situations of unfair economic and social competition, which also represent an obstacle to maintaining a high level of social standards in the Member States. The EU authorities have become aware of this issue and the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, made a solemn commitment to fight against ‘social dumping’. In his 2015 State of the Union address, he also stated he wishes to avoid ‘abuses and risks of social dumping’. Therefore, I welcome this report which proposes to strengthen controls and inspections, at both national and European level, in application of existing legislation. It is important to modernise the registration of employment benefits and develop a single digital document guaranteeing social rights for every European worker, as well as to adopt measures in order to ensure social convergence in the European Union.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report concerns a vital issue, social dumping. As such, the European Parliament has a strong position and is making an important effort to build a more social Europe. With this report, which I voted in favour of, an effort is being made to reach a balanced agreement between all the parties concerned and the political groups. The Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats is aware of the great importance of the issue of social dumping and has demonstrated its commitment to combating the phenomenon in order to ensure that all Union workers enjoy the same high levels of social protection and rights.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This report deals with the problem of social dumping and calls, among other things, for improved cooperation between the Member States' bodies responsible for labour inspectorates. In addition, an EU-wide list of companies, including letterbox companies responsible for serious breaches of European labour and social legislation, will be drawn up and a European social security card will be introduced. Social dumping, unemployment and low wages increase the risk of poverty and social exclusion. I strongly support the plan to combat social dumping in the EU and to reform the Posting of Workers Directive. Improvements are absolutely necessary here. In Belgium, too, many jobs are lost every year, particularly in the construction sector, as a result of the use of underpaid and socially poorly protected posted workers.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The fight against social dumping is one of the great promises made by Jean-Claude Juncker. On 15 July 2014, he promised to "fight against social dumping" during the current Parliament, a wish he reiterated in his State of the Union address in 2015. The announced objective of this report is to close the legislative and regulatory loopholes that promote the development of current unfair competition within the internal market. For this the solution is simple: more Europe! The issue of the revision of the Detached Workers Directive is over the top of the ass it will be the subject of a separate report. On the whole, even if it is paved with good intentions, it is nevertheless Europeanist as possible, and so full of good feelings that it loses all credibility. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for further EU harmonisation. At a time when Britain is leaving the European Union, it cannot be in our interests to have such harmonisation. In particular, when countries have massively different purchasing power, the suggestion of harmonisation of minimum income could lead to significant problems – either leading to a lowest common denominator, or to a situation which would be completely unsustainable in the poorest Member States.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the report on social dumping in the European Union. As the scale of abuse and social dumping grows in Europe, support for the internal market and the competitiveness of businesses, especially SMEs, undermines the rights of European workers and undermines confidence in European integration, and social convergence is therefore essential in the agriculture, construction, food and food, transport, care and household services sectors. I therefore support further action that is necessary to ensure social convergence in the European Union.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is about social dumping in the European Union and essentially says that undeclared employment and spoaning self-employment can lead to distortions of competition, which can lead to long-term damage to social security systems, an increase in precarious jobs and a deterioration in the protection of workers and the quality of employment in general. The growing trend of outsourcing and subcontracting may allow abuse or circumvention of existing labour and social legislation. It is therefore essential to address these abuses in order to maintain freedom of movement and solidarity within the Union in the internal market. On the basis of the fore said, the report should be supported, but I consider some comments to be justified in the interests of clarity. The free movement of goods, services and capital between countries where there is a 10-tenfold difference in average wages between countries (Denmark-Bugaria) or even only four times (Germany-Hungary) leads to social dumping, and no regulation helps this, but can only slightly reduce glaring cases. The report emphasises the need for upward social convergence, while the Union is experiencing the opposite, the middle classes are slipping, 100% due to huge wage differences, made worse by the pressures created by immigrants and cheap (Chinese) imports, which also push wages downwards.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE)
text: Writing. The Austrian delegation of the EPP voted in favour of G. Balas' own-initiative report on social dumping in the European Union, as social dumping is unfortunately a reality in Europe that has a negative impact on the development of the European labour market. The Member States and the institutions are called upon to recognise and combat the three main manifestations of social dumping, i.e. economic, financial and social. There must be no class differences in Europe based on the origin of workers, which are reflected in pay and social benefits.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE)
text: Written. I voted today in favour of the own-initiative report on social dumping. Yes, there are a few places where I think the text could be better – I think that the Commission's proposal on sole proprietorships is a good idea for entrepreneurs – but it is an expression on my part that fair competition and fair working conditions are needed, for example for aviation and lorry drivers. We need to get better control of registers across the authorities in Europe so that we do not see cheating and deception with shell companies. Freedom of movement is a good that should not be abused.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current context presents a number of conditions which seriously undermine the level of social protection underlying the whole project of European integration. The Balas report, which I strongly supported, addresses the issue of social dumping in the Union, strongly highlighting the damage caused by exacerbated competition between economic operators. Excessive competition leads not only to a reduction in expenditure associated with labour costs but also to a weakening of social norms and the same rights that should be guaranteed to employees on the continent.  Reversing this downward race must be a priority, which is why we must first improve controls and inspections at all levels, increasing the human and financial resources made available to the authorities. Reforms are needed to modernise the registration of work benefits, urgent action in the transport sector, a single digital document on the transfer of social rights for every European worker, as well as measures such as the creation of a European list of companies guilty of serious infringements. Only by resolving the asymmetry between the reality of the internal market and social rights will it be possible to create real upward social convergence.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because it is a progressive report denouncing the unfair economic and social competition that social dumping practices entail. Dumping promotes a reduction in labour costs and entails less social protection for workers, which in turn results in a decrease in the available resources of the State to protect its own citizens. The report proposes harmonisation of social rights and includes positive measures such as strengthening labour inspection at national level and creating a Body at Union level to combat abusive practices; the development of a single digital document that guarantees the social rights of all workers; the obligation for companies to have an official direction to combat the existence of phantom companies; a revision of the Displaced Workers Directive to ensure fair competition, with particular emphasis on the transport sector and the adoption of a social protocol ensuring the predominance of social rights over economic freedoms, as well as the introduction of minimum wages that can be extended at Union level in some sectors.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported the basic lines of this report because I share that strengthening the internal market must be parallel to harmonisation of social rights in it. Otherwise we will attend cases of social dumping that are leading to practices that we have repeatedly denounced in sectors such as transport and construction, which alter competition and are degrading basic aspects of working conditions such as wage purchasing capacity and, in particular, worker safety. To stop this threat is also key for citizens to perceive the usefulness of the European project. I agree on the need to activate the Commission's commitment in this area.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is an unfair and ill project supported by the European institutions. The free movement of workers and the huge differences in labour costs between Member States have turned relocation and dumping into social scourges that are exterminating entire economic sectors in Italy, such as construction or road transport.  Our territories and our workers are victims of the unfair manoeuvres of foreign temporary agencies and multinationals, which are slaughtering our productive fabric, leaving Italian workers in a desert of unemployment and social problems. The rules of the single market must be rewritten, this time for the benefit of our people. For all these reasons, I did not intend to support the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The fight against social dumping, which could be defined as the downing race in socio-labor and wage standards within the Union, is a priority of the Socialist Group as it results in abuse of workers and erodes national social protection systems.  With this report, the Socialists wanted to improve labour controls and inspections in the Union, increase sanctions for companies that do not respect the rules, improve cooperation between national authorities to improve the fight against social security fraud, false self-employment and fictitious enterprises. We also call on the Commission to set up a Europe Road Transport Agency and to review the Workers' Displacement Directive.  In short, I voted in favour of this report because it is a huge step forward in upward social convergence in the Union and in the struggle to equate social rights with economic freedoms. Only if we guarantee the principle of equal pay for equal work and fair competition can we really protect workers and SMEs, which are the real engine for creating jobs in the Union.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been advocated by Parliament on social dumping in the EU. The report talks about the fact that the competitive advantage of companies in our single European union market, if it is obtained by unfair practices or the cost of exploiting workers, should be absolutely intolerable. This practice gives birth to poverty and exclusion in certain Member States, confrontation in the European Union and divides eu unity. Unfair practices and exploitation of workers must be tackled by a number of measures: strengthening labour inspectorates, including in cross-border cases, combating the shadow economy, illegal employment, bogus self-employment, tax avoidance and all other things that undermine the trust of EU Member States and threaten our single market and the free movement of workers.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Fidesz-KDNP delegation in the European Parliament voted unanimously and decisively against the EP report on social dumping. The document sees, inter alia, a threat to EU citizens legally employed in another Member State in the context of the free movement of services, in particular workers from Central and Eastern Europe. Instead of defining the concept of 'social dumping', the report sought to define the posting of legally employed workers to another EU country as social dumping. Under existing EU legislation, the report seeks to blur the status of legally posted workers to another Member State, as well as of cross-border service providers, typically hauliers, including the situation of undeclared workers and workers in the domestic, nursing and care sectors (in particular home care), which is unacceptable. As is well known, the proportion of posted workers in the EU is less than 1% of the EU labour market. The question arises as to why the European Commission forced the start of a review of the legislation in relation to posted workers when the deadline for transposition had not yet expired. It is also a well-known fact that western European businesses are much more capital-strong, while in Central and Eastern Europe, lower wage costs are one of the main elements of competitiveness. The difference between the two could be limited, but the legislation on posted workers would be lifted, the review of which would be reasonable and equitable only with sufficient experience.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. – With the desire to improve the definition of 'social dumping', which should not, of course, be mixed with dumping in the areas of trade policy and the labour sector, I supported the report on social dumping in the EU.  The fact is that social rights vary considerably across the EU, as the legislation is governed by national law. Thus, of course, there are big differences, and companies are, of course, taking advantage of the internal market and serving the legislation that best suits them in this area.  If we also want a normal functioning internal market in the area of free movement of labour, we must strive for the homogenisation of the social rights and obligations of workers, as well as special cases such as offshore workers, posted workers to another country, carriers, etc. Therefore, my support for the rapporteur's proposal to adopt a protocol on social policy that would ensure the priority of social rights over economic freedoms.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Labour and social policy legislation is still a matter for the Member States. In the absence of harmonisation mechanisms and with very different social systems, the single market and the free movement of workers can give rise to practices, such as social dumping, to develop. These are forms of unfair competition between companies and indirectly between workers, aimed at trying to use from time to time the most convenient regulations among those existing in the different Member States.  We are faced with a problem not only social, but also political, which requires a European solution aimed at protecting its citizens. I therefore welcome this report, which addresses the different facets of the phenomenon, highlighting the need for an initiative to address the issue of unfair competition between European companies and the resulting abusive practices that jeopardise the rights of citizens as workers.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this EU Social Dumping Report. The phenomenon of social dumping stems from the practice of disloyal economic and social competition and represents a "race to the bottom" in relation to social conditions in Europe, damaging the high level of social protection in the EU. Increased competition between economic operators encourages them to reduce labour cost spending, leading to a weakening of social standards in force in different Member States of the Union. This report shows that we are aware of the gravity of the problem from social dumping and is an expression of our engagement in the fight against social dumping and to ensure that all workers in Europe enjoy a high level of social protection and rights.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic side on the social side is often prevalent in the EU: this leads to imbalances, especially territorial imbalances, in which a different level of protection of state-to-state rights leads to the exploitation of low-skilled labour, internal migration of the same labour force and a risk of double regime of internal social and security standards, with the result that internal differences and mistrust between EU citizens increase and generate social envy.  We must stress the specific fragility of the social protection of certain employees, such as 'workers of the sea', victims of the use, by many shipowners, of flags of convenience, which allow employers to escape social obligations. These practices have a negative impact on safety standards and contribute to the reduction in the number of qualified European seafarers and the loss of their know-how. This is not acceptable to the world's leading political reality in promoting living standards and individual rights: social rights must be promoted and not just stated by the Commission. A duty of care must be introduced for the most important European companies, with regard to the activities of their subsidiaries and subcontractors.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to combat social dumping within the European Union by advocating for the harmonisation of social protection systems and social rights in the Member States. But the convergence of upward wages that they are calling for is an illusion in a generalized free trade system. Companies are moving to Member States with low-tax labour laws. In addition, the European Directive on the Secondment of Workers, which allows companies to relocate locally by hiring underpaid Eastern European employees subject to the social charges of their home countries, exacerbates competition between employees in different Member States. The employment will therefore be returned to those who have the least wage demand in terms of working time and remuneration. In this report, however, they pretend to address the effects they cherish. They deplore the fraud of seconded workers when they are at the origin of this infamous directive, which we propose to abolish. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, having regard to the provisions on the harmonisation of social policies at EU level, as well as those relating to the creation of protectionist measures in the Member States and the introduction of limitations and barriers on the free movement of services and workers. I can agree with the provisions on efforts to ensure that all workers are protected and have access to fair working conditions, but I cannot agree with measures that undermine the competences of the Member States, in particular as regards wage setting, social security, the tax system and specific labour market reforms.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report to combat social dumping in Europe. This is a strong signal that the European Parliament wants to give with this report. This vote is a major step towards Europe of social convergence, an essential bulwark against the deregulated market between European workers. In particular, the European Parliament has adopted concrete proposals, including: the fight against so-called 'letterboxes' by ensuring that companies established in an EU Member State have a real activity; the introduction of a threshold of 60% of the national average wage as a benchmark for setting the minimum wage within Member States; Extending joint and joint and solidarity liability on the subcontracting chain; the possibility for the competent authorities to suspend the provision of services in the event of serious violations of the law on the secondment of workers; registration of declarations of secondment in a European register to facilitate consultation and coordination between Member States; the Commission's request to assess the impact of the social contribution differential for employers and employees between Member States.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I believe that the particular situation of some new Member States, which switched to a market economy in 1990, has not been taken into account. A definition of social dumping is being slased as a wide range of abusive practices which allow, inter alia, the development of unfair competition by unlawfully minimising operating and personnel costs. In a unified economic environment, that definition is correct and does not raise any objection. There is, however, an economic development gap between the old and new Member States, which, moreover, largely explains the small operating costs in those States, but also lower staff costs. I believe that the rapporteur should have taken this into account and given a full view of the state of the European economy. Naturally, I agree to fight against social dumping, as it often consists of illegal practices, such as undeclared work or abusive practices. However, for an economy as complex and diverse as that of the European Union, I believe that it should not be confused with the social dumping of some Member States in eastern Europe.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The fight against social dumping, which could be defined as the downing race in socio-labor and wage standards within the Union, is a priority of the Socialist Group as it results in abuse of workers and erodes national social protection systems.  With this report, the Socialists wanted to improve labour controls and inspections in the Union, increase sanctions for companies that do not respect the rules, improve cooperation between national authorities to improve the fight against social security fraud, false self-employment and fictitious enterprises. We also call on the Commission to set up a Europe Road Transport Agency and to review the Workers' Displacement Directive.  In short, I voted in favour of this report because it is a huge step forward in upward social convergence in the Union and in the struggle to equate social rights with economic freedoms. Only if we guarantee the principle of equal pay for equal work and fair competition can we really protect workers and SMEs, which are the real engine for creating jobs in the Union.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. We have finally voted on a text that clearly defines the term social dumping. We must be able in the Union to fight together against unfair social competition. Our citizens are the first victims of social dumping. To solve this problem, we need to bring the social policies of the Member States together. This convergence must be upwards. It is inconceivable that the most successful social systems would be undermined in this process. We are also looking forward very soon to a revision of the Directive on the Detachment of Workers, which has already been the subject of a proposal by the European Commission in March 2016. I voted in favour of this initiative report on social dumping.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the problem of social dumping is topical and requires urgent and targeted measures. One of the fundamental principles of EU policies is social cohesion. This is reflected in the urgent need to bring wages closer together with a view to better and effective social protection for all workers.  In the present Union, there are still considerable differences in both working conditions and pay. Unfair competition reduces operating and labour costs, resulting in genuine violations of workers' rights, leading to their exploitation. We need to harmonise social rights for which, in many cases, the Member States still have competence. In line with the rapporteur, I would like to see increased controls and inspections in accordance with current legislation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this very good own-initiative report, which proposes solutions to harmonise social rights upwards across the EU. The draft report recommended several measures to fill the regulatory and legislative gaps. These included strengthening labour inspections at national level and the creation of a EU-level body to combat abusive practices; an obligation for companies to have one official address to combat letterbox companies; blacklisting companies responsible for serious offences including the use of undeclared work; and a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to ensure real equal treatment of workers and fair competition. More than 700 amendments were tabled, mainly by conservatives, and the resulting compromise amendments have weakened the report, in particular by blocking all concrete proposals in relation to the PWD. Despite this it is still a very progressive and valuable report that comes at a crucial time in the lead-up to the revision of the PWD.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. Social dumping is, of course, a huge problem with cheap labour being brought over from other countries by companies to undercut wages and avoid employing local workers. It also covers issues like companies finding cheaper alternatives elsewhere and moving operations abroad.  However, this report went on to call for more EU action, legislation, monitoring of legislation and data collection. On top of that, there isn’t an official legal definition of ‘social dumping’ in EU law, so this report is about an issue the EU can’t even define properly. The EU can never tackle social dumping, as the free movement of people is the perfect enabler for it to occur. Also, the EU’s Posted Workers Directive actually enables employers to bring cheap labour over to undercut the local community. The only way to stop social dumping is to leave the EU and get back control of immigration.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The fight against social dumping is one of the great promises made by Jean-Claude Juncker. On 15 July 2014, he promised to "fight against social dumping" during the current Parliament, a wish he reiterated in his State of the Union address in 2015. Social competence remains one of the exclusive competences of Member States, which is why there are now great differences between social rights and the social obligations of countries. According to the rapporteur, and the EU, this asymmetry is an obstacle to the harmonisation of living and working conditions in the EU. Worse, this situation leads to the weakening of social standards, degrades all the rights of employees and diminishes the financial resources necessary for the various social protection systems. Unfortunately, the solutions advocated by the Balas report do not seem to us to be seriously fighting this scourge, having come straight from the Euro-federalist ideological matrix, in particular the crazy idea of the creation of a European agency of labour inspectors. Considering the text as insufficient as it is crossed by the wrong directions, we voted against it.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that increasing worker mobility within the Single Market is positive. It stimulates the EU’s economic development, as well as enhancing social and cultural cohesion. These workers play a part in addressing the mismatch between available employee skills and the needs of the marketplace.  I believe that we must protect the Internal Market, but there must also be safeguards to prevent abuse. When there are shortcomings in European legislation we should work to address them. But this cannot be done in a vacuum. We need proper enforcement of these rules through controls which are able to detect and prevent abuse, abuse of all kinds, be it tax avoidance, unfair competition or undeclared work. We should cooperate together with Member States to ensure that all European workers’ rights are respected.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report highlights the distortions linked to the internal market as currently conceived. There are no social rights and treatments for workers throughout the Union, which leads to dumping to the detriment of them. Competition between economic operators is in fact passed on to labour costs, leading to a damaging race to the bottom of standards. The report recommends measures aimed at filling regulatory gaps in the fight against unfair competition and instead promoting the portability of workers' social rights. I certainly voted in favour of this report.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Social dumping resulting in unfair competition, illegal practices and disregard of social and labour standards is, of course, negative and we should do our best to fight against it. We need to make sure that the current rules are fully enforced and that there is no room for social dumping in the EU. However, there is a certain misuse of the term in the present report which relates to the fact that there are differences in labour costs among the EU Member States. The report, in this respect, calls for protectionist measures to be adopted and that is why I voted against it. Free movement of labour, together with competitive advantages of respective Member States need to be preserved, as they are at the very basis of the European Union.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Social and economic inequalities in Europe jeopardise the achievement of the Europe 2020 poverty and employment targets. The growing trend towards undeclared work, outsourcing and subcontracting, as well as the consequent increase in precarious employment and the deterioration in levels of protection for workers, are among the primary causes of this disparity.  Social dumping and other forms of unfair competition are preventing the achievement of working conditions and social standards guaranteed at European level. I therefore welcome the report's emphasis on the supremacy of fundamental rights and the desire to intensify the social dialogue against dumping practices.  I believe that the creation of a European corps of labour inspectors to investigate unfair competition practices and cases of social dumping can be an effective measure.  In addition, it should be noted that women are often the most affected by social dumping and un declared work, especially in domestic and care work. I very much hope that the Commission, in cooperation with its Member States, will launch a detailed and timely analysis of the situation of women who are victims of such practices.  On the basis of these comments, I have decided to support the report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress that social issues, and in particular the issue of unfair social competition, are of great concern to our Fellow Europeans. This underlines the importance of the European Parliament articulating a strong and clear discourse, which will help to build a Europe that is more social and, by extension, more friendly to our citizens.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on social dumping in the European Union. The issue of social dumping is particularly important and has taken on great proportions in recent years. Although the market has experienced particular growth, the same cannot be said for the protection of social rights, particularly in the light of policies pursued in specific countries, with the aim of attracting businesses to the detriment of citizens' interests. As this report focuses on prospects for tackling the phenomenon, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this very important, and at the same time controversial, subject in order to give a positive signal to the fight for the social rights of workers. I congratulate my colleague Danuta Jazlowiecka on her excellent work on this report. Indeed, I am pleased that a final compromise with the Group of the Party of European Socialists has made it possible to propose, for the first time at European level, a definition of 'social dumping', understood as intentionally abusive practices and circumvention of existing European and national legislation to the detriment of workers.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on Social dumping in the EU and noted no objections.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. If I am in favour of the standard of living of people in the poorest EU countries joining that of the developed countries fairly quickly, I deny any EU competence in this area. Violating sovereignty will never bring prosperity. These utopian good intentions actually mask sinister objective assets. So I'm voting against it.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe has been defined by its creators as a democratic space, with good economic performance and high-level social protection. Priority has been given to the construction and strengthening of the internal market and there is no such harmonisation with regard to social rights. There is, in fact, an asymmetry between the reality of a virtually completed internal market and very heterogeneous social rights. This paradox calls into question the very principle of fair competition between undertakings and the promotion of a social market economy by the Union. This situation of unfair economic and social competition also represents an obstacle to maintaining high-level social protection in Europe. I support this report, which advocates the need for increased controls and inspections, both at national and European level, in application of existing legislation. I advocate the creation of a single digital document containing the social rights of all European workers. I would like to comment on the need to revise the Posting of Workers Directive in order to pave the way for the change of its current legal basis, as well as regulations on the coordination of social security systems.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because we need to tackle the issue of social dumping at European level. The cornerstone of our internal market is the social market economy. The principle of 'equal pay for equal work in the same place' should be taken into account across the EU. To this end, we must make use of the means at our disposal and, through better controls and greater cross-border cooperation, prevent circumventions of social standards while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. Social dumping is of course a huge problem with cheap labour being brought over from other countries by companies to undercut wages and avoid employing local workers. It also covers issues like companies finding cheaper alternatives elsewhere and moving operations abroad. However this report went on to call for more EU action, legislation, monitoring of legislation and data collection. On top of that there isn’t an official legal definition of ‘social dumping’ in EU law, so this report is about an issue the EU can’t even define properly. The EU can never tackle social dumping as the free movement of people is the perfect enabler for it to occur. Also the EU’s Posted Workers Directive actually enables employers to bring cheap labour over to undercut the local community. The only way to stop social dumping is to leave the EU and get back control of immigration.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 'Social dumping', a term which at present does not have a legally recognised and universally accepted definition, yet we are all aware of the proliferation of illegal practices that allow the development of unfair competition, thus creating an asymmetry between the reality of an evolving internal market and very heterogeneous social rights, which weakens adherence to the principle of the internal market and weakens confidence in the construction of Europe.  Rather than hiding behind protectionist policies, by taking unilateral decisions in the social field, states would do better to cooperate with each other, strengthening controls in order, above all, to avoid the use by certain economic actors of illegal practices such as undeclared work or abusive practices such as false self-employment, which can lead to serious distortions of the market, to the detriment of companies that work honestly. , in particular SMEs and all those sectors most affected, such as agriculture, construction and the food sector. I believe in the need to achieve social convergence in the EU, for a fairer labour market in order to achieve strong and sustainable competitiveness in all Member States.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The report favours the establishment of wage floors in the form of a national minimum wage, where applicable, with due respect for the practices of each Member State.  Such debate should be undertaken in full concordance with the social partners with the objective of gradually attaining at least 60% of the respective national average wage, if possible, so as to avoid excessive wage disparities.  It is evident that a pay gap still exists and, despite existing EU legislation and soft-law recommendations, progress in this area is extremely limited. The situation is exacerbated by social dumping which doesn’t help.  This accentuates a wider gender pension gap that puts elderly women at greater risk of poverty than elderly men. I support specific recommendations the report makes to the Member States as part of the European Semester, to incorporate opinions on social issues with a view to enhancing worker protection through convergence

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report not only clearly positions itself on a problem, that of social dumping, which the right and other European institutions even refuse to name, but requires measures with which I very much agree: the better implementation of existing labour regulations, the strengthening of sanctions and inspections and the extension of responsibility to the subcontracting chain , coordination of social security systems, equal rights between workers in the same place etc. I see with skepticism that the constitutional architecture of treaties, especially when the Union does not intend to be integrated into the European Social Charter or even the ECHR, allows us to overcome the current subordination of labour rules to the 'market freedoms' used by large groups to force workers to compete with each other and, in this regard, I consider insufficient proposals such as that of the 'Social Pillar' or the current reform of the directive on posted workers who please to the rapporteur. Nevertheless, considering it a step in the right direction, I voted in favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution is a step forward for the Europe of social convergence, which seeks to affirm its desire for social progress, and which reduces differences and therefore contrasts and discrimination between workers practising in different European nations. I voted in favour of this resolution, because I consider the measures proposed by the European Parliament to be appropriate, including greater control and coordination between and by The Member States with regard to companies that are responsible for serious violations of labour social legislation and workers' fundamental rights, in the fight against social dumping in the transport sector, which is particularly fragmented at European level, including through the creation of a European Agency for Rail and Rail Transport. in the protection of women who are particularly affected by social dumping.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on this report because, instead of defining the concept of 'social dumping', the report sought to define the posting of legally employed workers to another EU Country as social dumping. Under existing EU legislation, the report seeks to combine the status of legally posted workers to another Member State, as well as those providing cross-border services, typically hauliers, with, inter alia, the situation of undeclared workers and workers in the domestic, nursing and care sectors (in particular home care). Furthermore, in many cases, the report goes beyond the limits of subsidiarity and aims, inter alia, at guaranteeing an EU 'minimum civilian income' and has a say in national pay policy.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On social dumping in the EU, I have decided to abstain. I have reservations about the content of the project. The political faction to which I belong has tabled numerous amendments to ensure that it complies with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. What raises my concerns and concerns is that it is to undermine the competences of the Member States in terms of wages, social security, tax systems and concrete labour market reforms. Because I belong to a faction that cares about preserving the sovereignty of each Member State, I have decided to abstain.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Social Dumping in Europe is unacceptable. We need to have a strong voice in helping to build a more Social Europe. We need to safeguard each and every person working in member countries and ensure that they are all treated equally. This also helps to generate more support from European Citizens. I strongly agree and support this report, as we need to fight against social dumping practices and ensure that all workers in Europe enjoy high levels of social protection and rights.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support this report and its calls for initiatives at an EU level that would undermine the competence and effectiveness of national governments’ efforts in their own labour markets. I am a strong supporter of protecting all workers from unfair working conditions but national governments are much better placed to develop labour market policies addressing their own specific needs.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The structural labour reforms required by Europe have resulted in contract insecurity and a reduction in social security in some Member States. In addition, the "sell-off" of social protections for the benefit of more advantageous economic treatments, exploitation through violated working and rest hours, downward competitiveness with China and other third countries, but also the growing trend towards the use of vouchers in Italy instead of regular employment contracts, or even recourse to caporalato, lead to an increase in precarious , forms of enslaveability, a lack of security in the workplace and reduced contribution income for the Member States. I welcome the proposal to penalise those who use social dumping to make greater profits, but we need more widespread and stringent controls. Finally, I very much welcome the proposal to combat the fall in the employment rate caused by the economic and financial crisis with a paradigm shift that puts 'income' at the forefront of 'work' and which pursues the objective of guaranteeing a 'minimum citizenship income' throughout the European Union that guarantees a free and dignified existence. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The heterogeneity of national and European social and labour regulations mean that social dumping is still a reality within the European Union today.
