As is the case in the context of trade relations with our partners, we must combat this phenomenon in order to prevent the serious distortions of the market with which we are having an issue and to ensure equal treatment and non-discrimination for all European workers. As the report states, the European Commission and the Member States must ensure that controls are strengthened in order to better implement existing legislation, as well as encourage greater coordination between and by Member States in order to combat the deterioration in levels of worker protection and the quality of work in general, very often caused precisely by abuses and eluments of existing legislation by certain economic actors. The illegal reduction of operating and labour costs results in unfair competition, as well as the violation of workers' rights, which harms companies that work honestly and, in particular, small and medium-sized enterprises, which are very important protagonists of the European production system. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on the principle of social dumping in the European Union. In particular, the rapporteur considers social dumping to be an illegal practice, responsible for unfair competition between European workers. According to the report, clear conditions are needed for all workers in all EU Member States. Supporting these objectives I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. Social dumping is of course a huge problem with cheap labour being brought over from other countries by companies to undercut wages and avoid employing local workers. It also covers issues like companies finding cheaper alternatives elsewhere and moving operations abroad. However this report went on to call for more EU action, legislation, monitoring of legislation and data collection. On top of that there isn’t an official legal definition of ‘social dumping’ in EU law, so this report is about an issue the EU can’t even define properly. The EU can never tackle social dumping as the free movement of people is the perfect enabler for it to occur. Also the EU’s Posted Workers Directive actually enables employers to bring cheap labour over to undercut the local community. The only way to stop social dumping is to leave the EU and get back control of immigration.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on social dumping in the European Union. It seems to me necessary for the European Parliament to make its recommendations in order to prevent abusive practices and social dumping, which take advantage of the weaknesses of European legislation and particularly undermine certain sectors of our economies. We must do everything possible to ensure fair competition in Europe and, in order to do so, Member States should, in particular, strengthen labour inspection structures.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I wanted to support this report on social dumping in the European Union. This text proposes for the first time a definition of social dumping, which will serve as the basis for future negotiations in this area. In this text, it is also alluded to an assessment of the economic and social impact of the social contribution differential between Member States, which I find particularly interesting and important. Finally, I am pleased that initiatives are being put in place to protect the internal market by combating unfair practices and social fraud. In my opinion, it is essential to work towards a harmonisation of social policies in the Union in order to move forward in the construction of a social Europe.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Social dumping occurs when an employer takes on cheaper labour than the resources available on the domestic market. This practice must be restricted because it has a negative impact on the social fabric, particularly affecting the weakest sections of employees. I supported this report because it is committed to improving, both at European and national level, controls and legislation for the development of a sustainable and competitive economy while respecting workers' rights and social progress.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. The glaring lack of social harmonisation has been jeopardising the European project for too long. My colleague Guillaume Balas' report crystallizes the balance of power on key issues such as the introduction of a 60% threshold for the national average wage as a benchmark for setting the minimum wage in Member States, the fight against dummy self-employment and a new proposal for a revision of the Detachment Directive. It is an essential report, which lays down the principle of upward social convergence, which must now be followed up.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it sets out concrete measures to be implemented to combat social dumping in many sectors of activity in Europe, starting with the construction and transport sectors. The free movement of workers is undoubtedly a European added value, but the shortcomings and inaccuracies of the Directive on the secondment of workers have led to all too frequent violations of European and national laws (non-reporting in the country of origin, remuneration well below the minimum wage, exceeding maximum working hours, etc.) and has led to numerous bankruptcies and redundancies in Europe. We need workers' mobility, but this mobility must be properly controlled and competition must be fair. The EU must therefore develop a real control capacity, facilitate the work of our inspectors on the ground and harmonize sanctions. This approach is the best shield to strengthen the free movement of workers.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. On 15 July 2014, President Juncker promised to "fight against social dumping" during the current Parliament, a wish he reiterated in his State of the Union address in 2015. The aim of this text is to fill the legal loopholes that promote unfair competition between Member States. The solutions envisaged are: the creation of a pan-European labour inspectorate, the creation of a single digital working paper and the revision of the Directive on the Detachment of Workers. We cannot support this text, which advocates the maintenance of the fundamental principles of the European Union (particularly the free movement of workers) even though these are the cause of social dumping. The ENF Group also proposed an alternative resolution, recalling the principle of state sovereignty against any attempt at pan-European harmonisation. I of course voted against the text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support my colleague Balazs's report on social dumping in the EU, as I do not think it represents a real situation in the EU. The aim of this report is to define our institution's position on a series of forthcoming European Commission proposals on the posting of workers, the review of Regulation 883/2004 and the creation of a European Pillar of Social Rights.  The report contains a number of positive points and while I can agree and explicitly support the drive to ensure equal rights for workers, I cannot support initiatives that undermine the competences of member states.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote against. It is at least ironic that the Union wants to appear as a protector of workers when its policies are responsible for the current unacceptable situation.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Fidesz-KDNP delegation in the European Parliament voted unanimously and decisively against the EP report on social dumping. The document sees, inter alia, a threat to EU citizens legally employed in another Member State in the context of the free movement of services, in particular workers from Central and Eastern Europe. Instead of defining the concept of 'social dumping', the report sought to define the posting of legally employed workers to another EU country as social dumping. Under existing EU legislation, the report seeks to blur the status of legally posted workers to another Member State, as well as those providing cross-border services, typically hauliers, including undeclared workers and those working in the domestic, nursing and care sectors (in particular home care). As is well known, the proportion of posted workers in the EU is less than 1% of the EU labour market. The question arises as to why the European Commission forced the start of a review of the legislation in relation to posted workers when the deadline for transposition had not yet expired. It is also a well-known fact that western European businesses are much more capital-strong, while in Central and Eastern Europe, lower wage costs are one of the main elements of competitiveness. The difference between the two could be limited, but the legislation on posted workers would be lifted, the review of which would be reasonable and equitable only with sufficient experience.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe has been defined as a democratic space, with an effective economy and high-level social protection. However, if market liberalization is not linked to the harmonisation of social rights, the principle of fair competition between enterprises and the promotion of a social market economy can be jeopardized. The multiplication of abusive practices as well as unfair social competition weaken adherence to the principle of the internal market and undermine confidence in European construction. The European Parliament expresses a commitment to 'combat social dumping', filling legislative and regulatory gaps that favour the development of unfair competition currently existing in the internal market, such as strengthening controls and inspections, both at national and European level, among others.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. 'Due to misunderstandings, I inadvertently missed voting in the vote on the whole text. This is an issue that is of great importance and deserves more attention at national level in each Member State. However, I firmly believe that decisions that affect people should be taken so directly at a level as close to those affected by the decisions as possible. It is for this reason that I intended to vote against the text.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Social rights in the EU have not been harmonised and, with the exception of some principles enshrined in the Treaty and some directives, it was agreed that Member States would continue to be socially competent.  There is, in fact, an asymmetry between the reality of a virtually completed internal market and very heterogeneous social rights. These situations of unfair economic and social competition also represent an obstacle to maintaining high-level social protection in Europe. I therefore agree with the proposals made for this report.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: the ENF Group has prepared an alternative resolution that recalls the illogicality of the Union's strategy of wanting to expand at all costs, giving itself ever more responsibilities.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report addresses the issue of "social dumping" in the EU in a logic of combating the phenomenon, the relevance of which is unquestionable, particularly in the face of so-called austerity policies, which have promoted labour precariousity, unemployment, increased poverty and exclusion and the reduction of labour and civil rights. The report emphasises the need to strengthen inspection, even at the level of cross-border cooperation, as a way of combating "social dumping". It advocates the strengthening of means and staff, along with the strengthening of collective contracting and negotiation, the recovery of social rights and income, the promotion of work with rights, the limitation of the posting of workers, among other measures. The report contains positive aspects, contrary to the existence of dumping. But it also contains negative aspects: concerns about the single market of people and goods, its promotion and defence. Provisions that go in the opposite direction to what was required in this context.  There is no goodness in the single market – it is at the heart of the policies that have led to the dumping of societies in the EU and the disfigurement of labour as a structuring factor for the development of states. These inconsistencies of principles and contradictions justify our abstention. It would be desirable for the report to clearly break the causes of social dumping in the EU.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because, despite efforts to ensure an adequate level of social protection for all workers, the competence of member states' national legislation on pay, social security, taxation and labour market reform cannot be reduced.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the phenomenon of social dumping is based on unfair competition practices. This is a long-term negative phenomenon with regard to social conditions in Europe, which is damaging a high level of social protection in the European Union. Increased competition between economic operators forces them to continuously reduce labour costs. This leads to a weakening of the social standards in force in the various Member States of the European Union and gradually undermines all the rights of European workers. This asymmetry between economic freedoms and social rights gives way to the feeling that Europe is undermining individuals and communities instead of protecting them. It follows that the spread of unfair practices and unfair competition undermines the stability of the European Union's internal market and undermines confidence in building a common Europe. The situation that has arisen is often not assisted by individual Member States with their unilateral decision-making in the social sphere.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against: in this report many words and few final results.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on social dumping in the European Union;

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. – I voted against this own-initiative report as it does not add any additional value to existing laws. Calling for more numerous initiatives at the European level will not solve the extensive problems of unemployment in some Member States. Whilst I agree that workers should be protected from unfair working conditions, I strongly believe that individual governments are best placed to create legislation for their own work markets. A ‘one-size-fits-all’ approach does not work.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The phenomenon of social dumping arises from practices of unfair economic and social competition and represents a ‘race to the bottom’ in relation to social conditions in Europe, damaging high level of social protection in the EU. Increased competition between economic operators encourages them to reduce spending related to labour costs; this is leading to a weakening of the social standards in force in the various Member States of the Union, is gradually undermining all the rights enjoyed by European employees and, finally, is reducing the financial resources necessary for the various social protection systems. This asymmetry between economic freedoms and social rights is fuelling the feeling that Europe weakens both individuals and communities, instead of protecting them. Thus, the proliferation of abusive practices and unfair social competition weakens adherence to the principle of the internal market and undermines confidence in the construction of Europe. These phenomena encourage protectionist tendencies by the Member States and unilateral decision-taking by them in the social field. Through this report we show that we are very aware of the gravity of this issue and that we engage in fighting against social dumping practices and in ensuring that all workers in Europe enjoy high levels of social protection and rights.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Fidesz-KDNP delegation in the European Parliament voted unanimously and decisively against the EP report on social dumping. The document sees, inter alia, a threat to EU citizens legally employed in another Member State in the context of the free movement of services, in particular workers from Central and Eastern Europe. Instead of defining the concept of 'social dumping', the report sought to define the posting of legally employed workers to another EU country as social dumping. Under existing EU legislation, the report seeks to blur the status of legally posted workers to another Member State, as well as those providing cross-border services, typically hauliers, including undeclared workers and those working in the domestic, nursing and care sectors (in particular home care). As is well known, the proportion of posted workers in the EU is less than 1% of the EU labour market. The question arises as to why the European Commission forced the start of a review of the legislation in relation to posted workers when the deadline for transposition had not yet expired. It is also a well-known fact that western European businesses are much more capital-strong, while in Central and Eastern Europe, lower wage costs are one of the main elements of competitiveness. The difference between the two could be limited, but the legislation on posted workers would be lifted, the review of which would be reasonable and equitable only with sufficient experience.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report in finding that the European Union was built, first, through the liberalisation of economic trade between Member States. However, there was no harmonisation of social rights and, with the exception of some principles set out in the Treaty and in some Directives, Member States retain competence in social matters. There is therefore an asymmetry between the reality of an internal market in the process of completion and very heterogeneous social rights. This paradox creates competition between companies, as it does not have European workers or the same obligations or social rights. In this regard, on 15 July 2014, the President of the Commission made a commitment to 'combat social dumping' before the European Parliament during the current parliamentary term. Therefore, from the European institutions we must continue to work and legislate for greater harmonisation in social matters.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. The fight against social dumping, which could be defined as the downing race in socio-labor and wage standards within the Union, has been a priority of the Socialist Group since the last parliamentary term, as it results in the abuse of workers and erodes national social protection systems.  With this report, the Socialists wanted to improve labour controls and inspections in the Union, increase sanctions for companies that do not respect the rules, improve cooperation between national authorities in order to improve the fight against social security fraud, false self-employment and fictitious enterprises. We also call on the Commission to set up a Europe Road Transport Agency and to review the Workers' Displacement Directive.  In short, I voted in favour of this report because it is a huge step forward in upward social convergence in the Union and in the struggle to equate social rights with economic freedoms. Only by guaranteeing the principle of equal pay for equal work and fair competition can we really protect workers and SMEs, which are the real engine for creating jobs in the Union.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The issue of social dumping is very high on the political agenda on many Member States; one example being during the Brexit campaign. Social dumping is a real threat to many ordinary Europeans and it might risk the integrity of the internal market and the European project if no action is taken. Thus I fully support that a report has been many on this topic and I think that it in a good way highlights the issues at hand. The report rightly notes that increased cooperation and controls are needed to close regulation gaps and that better inspections of malpractices are needed. This report is a step in the right direction, but more action will be needed to reassure our citizens that we are tackling the problem of social dumping.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – The fight against social dumping, which could be defined as the downing race in socio-labor and wage standards within the Union, has been a priority of the Socialist Group since the last parliamentary term as it results in the abuse of workers and erodes national social protection systems. With this report, the Socialists wanted to improve labour controls and inspections in the Union, increase sanctions for companies that do not respect the rules, improve cooperation between national authorities in order to improve the fight against social security fraud, false self-employment and fictitious enterprises. We also call on the Commission to set up a Europe Road Transport Agency and to review the Workers' Displacement Directive. In short, I voted in favour of this report because it is a huge step forward in upward social convergence in the Union and in the struggle to equate social rights with economic freedoms. Only if we guarantee the principle of equal pay for equal work and fair competition can we really protect workers and SMEs, which are the real engine for creating jobs in the Union.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's approval of the text on social dumping in plenary is an act of responsibility and commitment that Parliament has enshrined with regard to workers' rights. Drawing a red line against abuses in the labour market and the risks of exploitation and loss of economic and contractual guarantees is unacceptable. That is why I supported this report, which calls for a revision of the current Posting of Workers Directive, making compliance with fair and non-discriminatory working conditions, a strong fight against unfair competition, increased controls on suspicious subcontracting companies, and also making the proposal for a minimum wage a priority. I fully believe in what is a battle pursued with obstinacy by the S&D Group in Parliament: the protection of social rights is the best investment that Europe can make for the future of its citizens.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted strongly in favour of the EP own-initiative resolution on social dumping in the European Union because I shared from the outset the need to send a strong signal to the European Commission to reflect in depth on the social consequences of labour markets without fundamental rules, affecting a large number of workers in Europe. This issue is the subject of a major clash in Europe, between workers between themselves and between Member States, with deep divisions between them. The EEA has identified a large majority of concrete proposals: the creation of a blacklist of companies responsible for serious breaches of existing labour social legislation, the creation of a European road transport agency to ensure compliance with the rules, the introduction of a threshold of 60% of the national average wage as a reference for setting the minimum wage within the EU. , the extension of joint corporate responsibility, to name but a few. The time has come to respond and find solutions to this problem, while respecting existing legislation and the need to review some of it, such as the Posting of Workers Directive, which is a priority of the Group of the European People's Party (S&D) in the EP.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on social dumping in the European Union because, as important as the issue is and as much as cross-border coordination makes sense, Europe cannot regulate everything at its political level. We need to encourage the Member States to cooperate better, not to completely skip and patronise them on social issues. What is clear is that the EU's internal market must not be a market for social dumping!

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Social dumping is illegal and is prosecuted by national courts. I am therefore in favour of the report 'Social dumping in the EU', but I am against over-regulation on the part of the EU. It is also important to continue to guarantee the right to free choice of job and freedom of movement within the EU.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour colleagues and I voted in favour of an important report to fight social dumping (the race to the bottom on social rights and wages) in Europe. My colleagues and I have long been calling for a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to fight social dumping effectively and ensure fair competition. We need to codify the principle of ‘equal pay for equal work in the same place’, and to that end it is pleasing that Commission President Juncker reaffirmed his commitment to this principle in his recent State of the European Union address.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. You'll never make it! Mr Balas' report addresses a real problem: unfair competition based on abuse, circumvention or violation of regulations. However, from recital B, the red line is drawn: under no circumstances can the free movement of workers, the freedom of establishment and the free provision of services be called into question. However, the direct causes of the explosion of dumping are: - European legislation (including the 'services' and 'detachment' directives), putting European workers in savage competition against each other; Enlargement to countries where living and wage standards are well below those in Western Europe; The unbridled race for cost-competitiveness due to globalization. The national minimum wage that you are proposing would probably improve, at the margins and within the same country, some individual situations, but it would not change the wage gap between countries. Your other proposals are similar. It's like using a fresh cloth to lower the fever of a septicaemia patient!

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because it is a progressive report denouncing the unfair economic and social competition that social dumping practices entail. Dumping promotes a reduction in labour costs and entails less social protection for workers, which in turn results in a decrease in the available resources of the State to protect its own citizens. The report proposes harmonisation of social rights and includes positive measures such as strengthening labour inspection at national level and creating a Body at Union level to combat abusive practices; the development of a single digital document that guarantees the social rights of all workers; the obligation for companies to have an official direction to combat the existence of phantom companies; a revision of the Displaced Workers Directive to ensure fair competition, with particular emphasis on the transport sector and the adoption of a social protocol ensuring the predominance of social rights over economic freedoms, as well as the introduction of minimum wages that can be extended at Union level in some sectors.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today the EPLP voted in favour of an important report to fight social dumping (the race to the bottom on social rights and wages) in Europe. The European Parliament Labour party have long been calling for a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to fight social dumping effectively and ensure fair competition. We need to codify the principle of ‘equal pay for equal work in the same place’.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it defines for the first time the concept of social dumping and recalls the principle of 'equal work, equal pay', which should guide the next revision of the legislation on seconded workers. It is crucial that Europe gives itself the means to restore equity and effectively combat social dumping, which threatens our jobs and businesses, particularly in the construction and transport sectors. Social Europe must be a response to the Euroscepticism that is winning over our fellow citizens.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. In the face of a deregulated market between workers and among nations, Europe must act. That is why I enthusiastically supported the report of my colleague Guillaume Balas to affirm my desire for social progress. This requires a number of concrete measures: combating so-called mailbox companies by ensuring that companies established in an EU Member State have a real activity; Putting in place a blacklist of companies Create a European Road Transport Agency to monitor compliance; introduce a threshold of 60% of the national average wage as a benchmark for setting the minimum wage within Member States; Extend joint and joint responsibility on the subcontracting chain; give the competent authorities the opportunity to suspend the provision of services in the event of serious violations of the law on the secondment of workers; or take into account the new proposal to revise the Detachment Directive. It is now up to the European Commission and heads of state to take responsibility for ending social dumping.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. The fight against social dumping, which could be defined as the downing race in socio-labor and wage standards within the Union, has been a priority of the Socialist Group since the last parliamentary term, as it results in the abuse of workers and erodes national social protection systems.  With this report, the Socialists wanted to improve labour controls and inspections in the Union, increase sanctions for companies that do not respect the rules, improve cooperation between national authorities in order to improve the fight against social security fraud, false self-employment and fictitious enterprises. We also call on the Commission to set up a Europe Road Transport Agency and to review the Workers' Displacement Directive.  In short, I voted in favour of this report because it is a huge step forward in upward social convergence in the Union and in the struggle to equate social rights with economic freedoms. Only by guaranteeing the principle of equal pay for equal work and fair competition can we really protect workers and SMEs, which are the real engine for creating jobs in the Union.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report even though we think it could have had more positive elements. The vote in favour of a report with this title was a political act, because parliament itself now accepts the existence of a security in employment, and the dissolution of industrial relations. We have clear positions against the dismantling of the social fabric as a result of the neoliberal policies imposed by the Stability Pact and the European Semester. The report made a first attempt at the definition of social dumping, which the conservative and neoliberal forces in Parliament have tried to reject. For us it is clear that insecurity at work, the reduction of workers covered by collective agreements, the increase in reduced-term contracts, the impoverishment of workers and chronic unemployment, especially among young people, are social dumping. Even if these are not mentioned in the report, an important first attempt has been made, which we will continue in Parliament.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because recognises the growth in inequality and unemployment in Europe as a result of the economic and financial crisis and notes the importance of high-level working conditions in the creation of a robust economy. Furthermore I support the report’s proposal for a definition of the term ‘social dumping’ to include illegal practices and law avoidance.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report calls for far-reaching regulations to prevent "social dumping" across Europe. ALFA supports adequate working and safety conditions for all workers. However, the report goes far too far in many areas and calls for a full-scale expansion of the welfare state. For example, it calls for a minimum wage of 60% of the average income. In addition, the report calls on the Commission to consider an unconditional basic income in a regulatory way. For these reasons, I cannot vote in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to discord and strife in Europe.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. Social dumping is of course a huge problem with cheap labour being brought over from other countries by companies to undercut wages and avoid employing local workers. It also covers issues like companies finding cheaper alternatives elsewhere and moving operations abroad. However this report went on to call for more EU action, legislation, monitoring of legislation and data collection. On top of that there isn’t an official legal definition of ‘social dumping’ in EU law, so this report is about an issue the EU can’t even define properly. The EU can never tackle social dumping as the free movement of people is the perfect enabler for it to occur. Also the EU’s Posted Workers Directive actually enables employers to bring cheap labour over to undercut the local community. The only way to stop social dumping is to leave the EU and get back control of immigration.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The truth about the detachment of foreign workers must be re-established. Contrary to popular belief, the recruitment of a seconded worker costs the equivalent or even more expensive to a French employer than a local worker. The reason is simple: the Smic and collective agreements also apply to the seconded worker, but it must be added the secondment allowance and the various expenses incurred by the seconded worker (travel, accommodation, food). It is therefore not the principle of detachment that is problematic and which is also welcome when an employer does not find a local worker to carry out certain tasks - harvesting, harvesting in agriculture - but the exploitation by unscrupulous companies of the grey areas of European legislation. The report on social dumping which I support reminds us that any European measure or legislation that creates unfair competition between Member States and affects employment and the quality of employment in a country is unacceptable. Our priority is to protect our businesses and arm them from global competition. The revision of the directive on the secondment of workers, which has already been too late, is an absolute urgency to combat, for example, "mailbox" companies.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in support of building a united social Europe. I support the joint effort to combat social dumping, ensuring a high level of social protection and equal rights enjoyed by all workers in Europe. The phenomenon of social dumping is present in the wake of unfair economic and social competition practices and represents a high deterioration of social protection in the EU. This unfair competition undermines the rights of European workers by reducing labour costs, social standards, implicitly the cost of living.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on social dumping in the European Union, because I think it is necessary to protect competitiveness in Europe and to enable competitively priced companies across the union as a whole and to facilitate workers' free movement from one Member State to another.  The disproportionate development of the internal market and social protection systems lead to unfair competition in the internal market, causing workers' rights to be weakened and workers exploited. Disloyal economic and social competition also leads to political effects that weaken the idea of European unity. Therefore, I consider it necessary to continue concrete measures in order to achieve social convergence within the European Union.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The announced objective of this report is to close legislative and regulatory gaps that promote the development of current unfair competition within the internal market. For this the solution is simple: "more EU!" On the whole, if this report is paved with good intentions, it is only more Euro-euro, and so full of good feelings that it loses all political credibility. So I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Diane James MEP and her colleagues voted against this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. Social dumping is of course a huge problem with cheap labour being brought over from other countries by companies to undercut wages and avoid employing local workers. It also covers issues like companies finding cheaper alternatives elsewhere and moving operations abroad. However this report went on to call for more EU action, legislation, monitoring of legislation and data collection. On top of that there isn’t an official legal definition of ‘social dumping’ in EU law, so this report is about an issue the EU can’t even define properly. The EU can never tackle social dumping as the free movement of people is the perfect enabler for it to occur. Also the EU’s Posted Workers Directive actually enables employers to bring cheap labour over to undercut the local community. The only way to stop social dumping is to leave the EU and get back control of immigration..

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on social dumping in the European Union. If it is not a legislative report, the text at least has the merit of clearly defining what social dumping is, whereas a number of countries, particularly in the East, dispute its very existence. This text laid out the terms of the debate to be held in the coming months during the revision of the Detached Workers Directive, which will help to reduce abuses and combat social dumping. I therefore welcome its adoption.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on social dumping in the EU. Unfortunately, there is a de facto asymmetry between the reality of a European internal market that tends to be completed and the existence of very heterogeneous social rights. The report includes measures such as strengthening, both at national and European level, controls and inspections in the context of the implementation of existing legislation and stresses the need for reforms on modernising the registration of labour benefits and the need to establish a single digital document for the transfer of the social rights of all European workers.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. Unfortunately, the harmonisation of the internal market has not had a positive impact on workers' rights on the same scale. The rapporteur notes that companies and European workers compete with each other, who do not have equal social obligations or social rights. The report deals with social dumping and its consequences (unfair competition, distortions of competition, damage to the social system, etc.) in the major sectors of the Union. I support his proposals on how to remedy such situations, such as central registers and single documents.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on social dumping in the EU at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, as the report's title already shows that it is going against the EU's biggest achievement, the single market. The report introduces a common definition of 'social dumping', which has not been the case so far at European Union level. The introduction of the definition of social dumping is a distortion of competition and a desire to restrict the free movement of services, goods and people within the EU. This is against the interests of Latvia and of the Union as a whole. The report also highlights the very counter-oversuded directive on the posting of workers, which provides that a worker from Latvia who leaves for a month to Germany receives the German minimum wage. However, this report requires that employees be paid equally for equal work, which would be detrimental to companies from less wealthy countries. Social safeguards between the Member States of the European Union, such as the same minimum wages, vary so drastically that the introduction of a minimum wage into the EU is not yet unrealistic.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of an important report to fight social dumping in Europe. The European Parliament Labour Party have long been calling for a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to fight social dumping effectively and ensure fair competition. We need to codify the principle of ‘equal pay for equal work in the same place’.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE)
text: Writing. Social dumping is a serious problem, especially in the transport sector.  Unfair conditions of competition, such as competition from low-wage countries, letterbox companies and bogus self-employment dominate everyday life. Here we need much more control of existing laws by the Member States. It is true that high-quality employment in Europe should be our common objective, but there is a European internal market and in this country all EU citizens can offer their services. It only becomes problematic when a service is permanently exported in a particular Member State in which the company is not established and the socially more favourable law of the country of origin is accordingly applied. That is why the distinction between the freedom to provide services and the freedom of establishment is essential here. I believe that there is sufficient legislation, but that compliance with it is not sufficiently monitored. That is why it is important to strengthen existing structures such as TISPOL and Euro Contréle Route. These support the implementation of the current road transport legislation and also ensure a level playing field through coordinating controls. All Member States should cooperate more closely, monitor more closely and exchange more information; this will lead to the recognising of and addressing social dumping.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report calls for far-reaching regulations to prevent social dumping across Europe. ALFA supports adequate working and safety conditions for all workers. However, the report goes far too far in many areas and calls for a full-scale expansion of the welfare state. For example, it calls for a minimum wage of 60% of the average income. In addition, the report calls on the Commission to consider an unconditional basic income in a regulatory way. For these reasons, I cannot vote in favour of the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 14 September 2016, we voted in plenary in Strasbourg on a report on social dumping in the EU. The report is based on the fact that there is considerable asymmetry between the reality of the EU's increasingly developed internal market and the insufficient protection of social rights in the EU. Unfair competition is not only an obstacle to maintaining a high level of social protection in the EU, but above all encourages economic operators to reduce their labour costs, thus gradually undermining social standards and reducing the funds necessary to ensure a high level of social protection. This asymmetry between economic freedoms and social rights also has a significant political impact, as it rightly encourages the sense that the EU is weakening individuals and entire communities, instead of protecting them. From my point of view, the only solution to this overall dismal, largely neglected and completely overlooked area by European elites is at least partial harmonisation of social rights across the EU in order to create a more social Europe. This is the only way to prevent the much-discussed social tourism and the escape of people from Eastern Europe to the Western one. Although the original report was significantly weakened during the negotiations, it contains a fairly solid list of concrete steps to prevent social dumping in the future and strengthen social protection in the EU, which is why I supported it.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Fidesz-KDNP delegation in the European Parliament voted unanimously and decisively against the EP report on social dumping. The document sees, inter alia, a threat to EU citizens legally employed in another Member State in the context of the free movement of services, in particular workers from Central and Eastern Europe. Instead of defining the concept of 'social dumping', the report sought to define the posting of legally employed workers to another EU country as social dumping. Under existing EU legislation, the report seeks to blur the status of legally posted workers to another Member State, as well as those providing cross-border services, typically hauliers, including undeclared workers and those working in the domestic, nursing and care sectors (in particular home care). As is well known, the proportion of posted workers in the EU is less than 1% of the EU labour market. The question arises as to why the European Commission forced the start of a review of the legislation in relation to posted workers when the deadline for transposition had not yet expired. It is also a well-known fact that western European businesses are much more capital-strong, while in Central and Eastern Europe, lower wage costs are one of the main elements of competitiveness. The difference between the two could be limited, but the legislation on posted workers would be lifted, the review of which would be reasonable and equitable only with sufficient experience.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Within the European Union, there is asymmetry regarding the internal market and social rights. This asymmetry weakens the internal market, encourages protectionism and unilateral social decisions from EU Member States. It is then crucial to have a harmonisation of social rights within the EU. The report recommends some initiatives against social dumping: measures to guarantee the social rights of every worker, blacklisting companies which use undeclared work, social protection in the transport sector. For all these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The practice of social dumping not only brings the principle of the internal market and the competitiveness of companies to its knees, but also undermines workers' rights, resulting in long-term damage to social security systems, an increase in precarious employment and a deterioration in levels of worker protection and the quality of work in general.  We call for strong action on the part of the Member States both in the area of preventing and combating social fraud and in the field of cross-border cooperation. A concrete request from today's vote concerns the companies of convenience and the desire expressed by this House to establish an EU-wide list of companies guilty of serious breaches of EU social and labour legislation that are denied access to public procurement, public subsidies and EU funds for a legal period. We voted in favour of the principle that each company should have only one head office and carry out a 'genuine' activity in the Member State of formation.  With this vote, we remember that labour law and high social standards are essential to rebalance economies, support incomes and encourage productive investment.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This report has been the subject of several debates, which have come into an agreed text, after several compromises. The aim of the report is to create a system that is capable of promoting an efficient economy and a high level of social protection. Workers in Europe do not have the same rights and obligations, which causes unfair economic and social competition between companies. For these reasons, the report presents the measures necessary to fill the legislative and regulatory shortcomings that, to date, favour unfair competition.  As a first step, the aim is to strengthen controls on the implementation of today's policies by increasing and training the human and financial resources responsible for enforcing the rules. It also calls for modernisation of reforms on the registration of labour benefits and the creation of a digital document on social rights that will be made available to all European workers. In the light of the above, I am voting in favour of the report on social dumping in the European Union.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it does not really have the will to fight social dumping. The proof: he accepts the system of "detached workers"!

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report on the fight against social dumping was based on the many abuses in the transport or construction sector to propose solutions to enforce national labour rights, including by attacking the system of seconded workers. This was already too much for the Eastern countries and the Liberals, who sought to divert the report from this European system of circumventing national labour rights. However, they have not been able to empty it of its contents. The report proposes three areas of action to tackle this problem: strengthening controls between and by Member States; Bridging regulatory loopholes to enforce labour law at all levels (European and national); promote equal treatment and non-discrimination among workers. In addition to these directions, it proposes three concrete measures: the creation of a European road transport agency to monitor drifts in this sector, which is heavily affected by social dumping; Establishing a blacklist that prevents fraudulent companies from accessing certain markets; introduction of a minimum wage equivalent to at least 60% of the national average wage. I have, of course, supported these proposals.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on social dumping in the European Union. The announced aim of this report is to close legislative and regulatory loopholes that promote the development of unfair competition within the internal market. For this the solution is simple: more Europe! The proposed solutions range from the creation of a European labour inspection agency to the registration of work benefits on a 'single digital document', through the revision of the 'detached workers' directive and better coordination of social security systems. The ENL Group has prepared an alternative motion which recalls the illogicality of the Union's strategy of wanting to expand at all costs, taking on ever more responsibilities, trampling on the sovereignty of the Member States, all in order to promote free movement and too often irregular immigration. We insist on the failure of the internal market and call on the Commission to stop any attempt to coordinate national wage-setting or collective bargaining mechanisms. We also call for it to enable Member States to combat the phenomenon of foreign temporary agencies and to combat abuses linked to the use of outsourcing.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The fight against social dumping, which could be defined as the downing race in socio-labor and wage standards within the Union, has been a priority of the Socialist Group since the last parliamentary term, as it results in the abuse of workers and erodes national social protection systems.  With this report, the Socialists wanted to improve labour controls and inspections in the Union, increase sanctions for companies that do not respect the rules, improve cooperation between national authorities in order to improve the fight against social security fraud, false self-employment and fictitious enterprises. We also call on the Commission to set up a Europe Road Transport Agency and to review the Workers' Displacement Directive.  In short, I voted in favour of this report because it is a huge step forward in upward social convergence in the Union and in the struggle to equate social rights with economic freedoms. Only by guaranteeing the principle of equal pay for equal work and fair competition can we really protect workers and SMEs, which are the real engine for creating jobs in the Union.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. With this report, the Socialists wanted to improve labour controls and inspections in the Union, increase sanctions for companies that do not respect the rules, improve cooperation between national authorities to improve the fight against social security fraud, false self-employment and fictitious enterprises. We also call on the Commission to set up a Europe Road Transport Agency and to review the Workers' Displacement Directive.  In short, I voted in favour of this report because it is a huge step forward in upward social convergence in the Union and in the struggle to equate social rights with economic freedoms. Only if we guarantee the principle of equal pay for equal work and fair competition can we really protect workers and SMEs, which are the real engine for creating jobs in the Union.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. The fight against social dumping, which could be defined as the downing race in socio-labor and wage standards within the Union, has been a priority of the Socialist Group since the last parliamentary term, as it results in the abuse of workers and erodes national social protection systems.  With this report, the Socialists wanted to improve labour controls and inspections in the Union, increase sanctions for companies that do not respect the rules, improve cooperation between national authorities in order to improve the fight against social security fraud, false self-employment and fictitious enterprises. We also call on the Commission to set up a Europe Road Transport Agency and to review the Workers' Displacement Directive.  In short, I voted in favour of this report because it is a huge step forward in upward social convergence in the Union and in the struggle to equate social rights with economic freedoms. Only by guaranteeing the principle of equal pay for equal work and fair competition can we really protect workers and SMEs, which are the real engine for creating jobs in the Union.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This is a comprehensive report by the European Parliament which aims to strengthen controls and coordination by and between Member States, eliminate legislative gaps with a view to ensuring compliance with Union legislation on social and labour matters, and defending the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination, therefore combating upward social convergence. The report describes a set of measures covering virtually the entire set of Union legislation.  I agree and share the need to carry out all those reforms necessary to combat fraud and social dumping, such as strengthening labour inspections. That is why I give my positive vote for the adoption of this report, which helps to ensure compliance with European legislation on social and labour matters, and respects at all times the principles of equal treatment and non-discrimination.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report calls for far-reaching regulations to prevent "social dumping" across Europe. ALFA supports adequate working and safety conditions for all workers. However, the report goes far too far in many areas and calls for a full-scale expansion of the welfare state. For example, it calls for a minimum wage of 60% of the average income. In addition, the report calls on the Commission to consider an unconditional basic income in a regulatory way. For these reasons, I cannot vote in favour of the report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims to combat social dumping in Europe.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I consider the term 'social dumping' to be a code name in the old Member States used purely to suppress cheaper competition from the eastern EU countries. I do not agree with the call for a mandatory minimum wage in the Czech Republic at the level of 60% of the average wage, i.e. CZK 16,000. With such a high minimum wage, it would not be worth employing people without qualifications or experience in some regions. Labour law should remain with the Member States. I do not agree with the call for stricter controls on long-distance drivers. Nor do I agree with the proposal to establish a new office, the European Road Transport Agency. I do not agree with the call for the liberalisation of so-called cabotage. I take the view that a lorry with free space should have the right to carry other goods. It would relieve the crowded roads and save oil.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The issue of undeclared work and bogus self-employment poses a major challenge for harmonising social rights within the EU. The non-compliance that exists within member states' markets can adversely affect social security systems and reduce affiliation to the principle of the internal market. Lower efficiency and coherence of social provisions encourages Member States to take unilateral decisions on social policy.  Some of the consequences of undeclared work and fraudulent employment are distortions of competition and protection of workers, an increase in the number of precarious jobs and the overall quality of job implementation. They cause long-term damage to Member States' social security systems and therefore need to be addressed. Job allocation and subcontracting create the conditions for circumventing or abusing the laws present related to work and social policy.  In order to maintain freedom of movement in the internal market, the Union must dedicate itself to tackling this problem. The EU needs to strengthen the principles of loyal competition within social policy and focus on promoting a social market economy. Growing competition between employers encourages them to optimise costs and therefore causes breaches of current social standards in the Member States.  Avoiding work charges, bogus self-employment and other breaches of existing justice systems must be addressed, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the idea to intensify the fight against the use by certain economic actors of illegal practices such as undeclared work or of abusive practices such as bogus self-employment  and other social dumping examples. But at the same time, some countries should avoid unjustified protection measures of their labour market.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Any dumping is contrary to the values and objectives of the European Union. The area of social affairs is a priority within the competence of the Member States, so the protection of employees and the social policy that comes with it are regulated differently from country to country. This disparity is being made by Union citizens when they benefit from the free movement of persons and capital, in which employees enjoy different levels of social protection and social security, as well as different employee benefits. Social dumping by targeting labour costs reduces the protection of workers' rights. It also creates an environment for unfair practices in competition. This ultimately negatively affects the internal market. I support the proposal for the Commission to create a European pillar of social rights that sets minimum social rights so as not to reduce the existing social and labour protection afforded to employees in individual Member States. However, this framework must be developed in cooperation with individual Member States and must take into account the possibilities of individual countries. It must therefore be set up in such a way that it is also feasible.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the elimination of social dumping in the European Union for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 13/9/2016 and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This text, despite its good intentions, attempts to give the EU ever more responsibility and to remove a little more sovereignty over the Member States. It promotes free movement and too often irregular immigration, which we oppose. The internal market is a failure and we urge the Commission to stop any attempt to coordinate national wage-setting or collective bargaining mechanisms. We are also in favour of it allowing Member States to combat the phenomenon of foreign temporary agencies and to combat abuses linked to the use of unseated subcontracting.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. – As much as we try to tackle discrimination, we cannot avoid having such situations arising at moments affecting people in the workforce. Maybe we cannot stop discrimination from happening, but as a Union, we can certainly take measures to counter the impact it has on people. Hence, my reason to vote in favour of establishing a general framework for equal treatment in employment and occupation is that I support the Commission and the Member States focusing not only on legislation but also on creating a working culture and securing the well-being for everyone. Europe is a diverse continent, and sometimes religion has become ground for discrimination.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we discussed a report on social dumping in the EU. The report points out that one of the guiding principles of EU policy is social cohesion, which means a constant and ongoing convergence of wages and protection and social security for all workers. Unfortunately, however, it is clear that significant differences in working conditions and wages remain in the Union, which is one of the reasons why workers are leaving for another country. We also pointed out in the debate that there is always a gender pay gap and, despite all efforts, little progress has been made in this area. This situation of social dumping can only worsen. It should also be borne in mind that the gender pay gap also leads to pension disparities, which is one of the main reasons why women in old age are at greater risk of poverty than men. The report draws attention to all these negative social phenomena, and I supported it in the vote.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, although there is still much way to go, presents itself as a first step in combating social dumping.  The report presents very positive aspects, such as the need for enhanced inspection, also in cross-border cooperation, as a way of combating social dumping, as well as promoting working conditions, measures to support women affected by social dumping and urgent measures in the transport sector, which are often genuine areas of non-social law.  For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My support for the report in which we from Parliament are proposing measures to end so-called social dumping and which seek to fill the legislative and regulatory gaps that favour the development of unfair competition currently existing in the internal market. We must strengthen controls and inspections, guarantee social rights for all European workers and, in general, foster a social shift that defends those rights.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union has allowed two fractures to settle in the 'big market': shameless tax dumping and social dumping that reduces working conditions, promotes violations of social rights and inevitably increases tensions between national workers. That is why the report of my colleague Guillaume Balas was essential to the debate: the European Parliament, through him, clearly expresses its determination to thwart all anti-social and anti-competitive practices from below. Convergence from the top is assumed, with minimum wages at 60% of the national average wage; Corporate responsibility, when the arrangements are complex, is reinforced with joint and joint responsibility throughout the subcontracting chain, the wage-earning disguised as self-employment is also targeted. Finally, safety nets, such as the suspension of activities or the prohibition of responding to public contracts, are provided in case of serious violations of social labour legislation. These milestones, won by a firm negotiation with right-wing groups, allow us to approach with ambition the revision of the directive on the detachment of workers. I voted for this report without reservation.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Undoubtedly priority should be given to building and strengthening the internal market and the fact that there is an asymmetry between the reality of an internal market and social rights, which are even heterogeneous, should not be overlooked. This situation causes a great deal of competition between businesses since there are not the same rights and social obligations to all European citizens. There are therefore many phenomena of unfair economic and social competition and this competition is an obstacle to maintaining social protection in Europe and mutual respect. Such a development promotes and fuels the feeling of a Europe that undermines individuals and teamwork and certainly does not ensure the protection of its citizens. For the above reasons, I consider it necessary to set up reforms and concrete proposals to ensure and transfer the social rights of all European citizens.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Hell is paved with good intentions, says the old adage. This text is the perfect illustration of this. The Europeanist presentation and the overflow of "good feelings" that flow from this text serve and discredit it. In the face of this report, our ENL group has tabled a more critical alternative resolution. We denounce the EU's enlargement strategy, coupled with its desire for ever greater interference in the affairs of States, in order to promote free movement and immigration. We also note the failure of the internal market and call for the all-powerful Commission to stop any attempt to coordinate national wage-setting or collective bargaining mechanisms. Finally, we want it to enable Member States to combat the phenomenon of foreign temporary agencies and to combat abuses linked to the use of unseated subcontracting. With regard to Mr Balas' report, I voted strongly against it.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. It reports on the strengthening of the position of workers. Combating social dumping is a necessary step in this direction. I can only support that.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. On the whole, even if it is paved with good intentions, this report is nevertheless Europeanist and discredited by too many good feelings precisely. The ENF Group has prepared an alternative resolution which recalls the illogicality of the EU's strategy of wanting to expand at all costs, taking on ever more responsibilities, trampling on the sovereignty of Member States, with a view to promoting deadly free movement and unsustainable immigration. We insist on the failure of the internal market and urge the Commission to stop any attempt to coordinate national wage-setting or collective bargaining mechanisms. We also call for it to enable Member States to combat the phenomenon of foreign temporary agencies and to combat abuses linked to the use of unseated subcontracting. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Undeclared work and false self-employment can cause distortions of competition, resulting in long-term damage to social security systems, increased precarious work and deteriorating levels of protection for workers and the quality of employment in general, and must therefore be tackled. It is crucial to ensure a level playing field across the EU and to eliminate social dumping. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that calls on Member States to increase cooperation to combat cross-border abuses in workers’ rights and protect social rights by combating tax evasion and tax fraud.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Social dumping is an unfair practice that undermines the mobility of European workers and distorts the very philosophy of the Union. We must ensure that the free movement of workers respects the rules of fair and fair competition. The priority is to enforce the rules. We need real control, facilitating the work of our inspectors on the ground and harmonizing sanctions. This approach is the best shield to strengthen the free movement of workers, which is a principle dear to the Liberals and an added value of the European project. Moreover, as the report points out, we must create an unfalsifiable European social security card, a proposal of the MR programme, in order to certify the payment of social security contributions or to set up a European list of companies that have seriously violated our social and labour laws. I would like to support Commissioner Marianne Thyssen in her proposed amendment to the 1996 Worker Detachment Directive. Strengthening the rules is essential to protect companies and workers from fraud and to apply the principle of equal work, equal pay.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: writing – I share the trend that the European Union has been stamping in recent years on strengthening the social rights of European citizens. I believe in the laws of the market economy, but at the same time I believe that the strong social background present in Europe gives the backing to building a certain social protection framework that does not conflict with the principles of the free market. However, it is not possible to overlook the fact that the EU's competences remain limited in dealing with social issues. I believe that, when introducing the so-called European minimum wage, we would already have exceeded the threshold of competences renounced by the Member States in favour of the Union. I therefore consider that setting the minimum wage must remain in the hands of the Member States, just as the decision to introduce the minimum wage itself must be introduced or not. I also believe that an optimal and fair level of such a wage can only be achieved as a result of an open dialogue between governments and the social partners and transparent collective bargaining, which also follows from the principles of the International Labour Organisation Convention on the Setting of the Minimum Wage. In fact, the directive setting the minimum wage at European level would risk the wage thus set not reflecting the real situation of the economies of the various Member States and, conversely, ignoring national conditions which vary considerably from one Member State to another.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on social dumping in the EU, which expresses our engagement in fighting against social dumping practices and ensures that all workers in Europe enjoy high levels of social protection and rights – something which is essential.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is built on a single and common internal market, while the competence in the social field remains with the Member States. The report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs deals with the asymmetry between the internal market and highly heterogeneous social rights. As fierce competition between economic operators encourages companies to reduce labour costs, this asymmetry is causing undesirable competition between companies. This violates the principle of fair competition between companies, the widening of abusive practices and the application of unfair social competition reduces support for the principle of the internal market and undermines confidence in European integration, and encourages Member States to take protectionism and unilateral decisions in the social field.  The report calls for measures aimed at eliminating legislative and regulatory shortcomings that are favourable to the emergence of unfair competition within the internal market. These are the strengthening of checks and inspections resulting from the application of the legislation in force, the modernisation of the register of work carried out and a single digital document ensuring the portability of social rights for all European workers. It proposes drawing up a European list of companies responsible for serious infringements such as the use of undeclared work and the establishment of minimum wages that can be extended to Community level in certain sectors. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. We are opposed to this report, which proposes to close the legislative and regulatory loopholes that promote the development of current unfair competition within the internal market. This is a good intention, but to which a very bad solution is proposed: that of more Europe. It is therefore mentioned the establishment of a European labour inspection agency, a 'single digital document' for the registration of work benefits, and better coordination of social security systems. The idea is therefore to further strengthen the EU's prerogatives over the Member States, to give it more responsibility and, ultimately, to further reduce the sovereignty of states. It goes without saying that we cannot support such proposals.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The issue of social dumping is too often raised without legal basis, leading to incongruities in the achievement of the internal market. As far as transport is concerned, we need legal clarity for carriers and a simplification of the existing regulatory framework.  It is not the fault of cabotage operations, but of the lack of effective control by the competent authorities and of differences in the application of certain provisions, such as the prohibition of regular weekly rest on board the vehicle in Belgium and France.  To do this, we need to review the establishment requirements, avoiding the transfer of activity to other Member States for the deliberate purpose of tax evasion and labour taxation.  We need more clarity in the implementation of existing provisions, in particular in the regulations on cabotage and in access to the profession.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, even if full of good intentions, is nevertheless Europeanist as possible, and so full of good feelings that it loses all credibility. The problem of social dumping in the Union is structural and cannot be solved with a few measures. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of this important report to fight social dumping (the race to the bottom on social rights and wages) in Europe. The European Parliamentary Labour party have long been calling for a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to fight social dumping effectively and ensure fair competition. We need to codify the principle of ‘equal pay for equal work in the same place’.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on social dumping in the European Union. This phenomenon has no place in the European single market and that is why we must work to put an end to it. In particular, I supported the provisions that require companies to have a real head office and all those that pave the way for harmonisation of legislation in the economic field (the establishment of a European transport agency to enforce European road transport legislation, as already exists for aviation and rail).

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcomed the proposal for a European policy to combat social dumping. When it was decided to create the European Union, we thought of a democratic area with an efficient economy and a high level of social protection. The task of protecting the social rights of the peoples of Europe had been delegated to the Member States, which should have harmonised their welfare systems with the aim of avoiding forms of unfair competition. Nevertheless, the problem of social dumping is currently affecting European individuals and communities, in violation of the principles of the Internal Market and the spirit of solidarity of the Union. The interconnection between markets raises the issue of reconciling different systems of social protection, leading to widespread mistrust of the Union's ability to guarantee the rights of its citizens. That is why we need European policies that protect workers and control the activities of companies. We need measures to ensure that companies pay taxes in the countries where profits are made, we need a squeeze on tax havens, as well as a new directive on precarious jobs. In short, a European Pillar of Social Rights must be activated.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on social dumping in the EU that will ensure social convergence in the Union and strengthen controls and inspections both at national and European level, in application of the existing legislation. The report emphasises the fragility of social protection availability for employees.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – Social dumping is one of the current problems facing working Europeans, despite the existence of already adopted European norms. I supported Mr Balazs's report as I consider it necessary to ensure better cross-border cooperation between Member States, namely between inspection services and the electronic exchange of data and information. The establishment of bilateral operational groups authorised to carry out cross-border on-the-spot checks will not only reduce market abuse, but will also allow easier disclosure of letterbox companies.  The difference in social security systems between Member States is one of the main reasons for circumvention of the rules. Increasing inequalities in Europe threatens to achieve the Europe 2020 poverty and employment targets.  The adoption of social instruments aimed at ensuring effective competition will demonstrate that Europe must be an example of the solution to the problem of social dumping. The establishment of a European list of companies responsible for serious infringements, as well as the adoption of the social pillar, will help to ensure a fair European labour market where there is no room for social dumping.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
