text: in writing. \u2012 One of the basic principles of EU policies is social cohesion, which means a constant and ongoing approximation of wages and guaranteed social security protection to all workers, whether at local or remote level. Significant differences in working conditions and wages persist in the Union, with differences in pay levels being the main reason why workers leave their country of origin. It is crucial to ensure a level playing field and fair competition throughout the EU, as well as to eliminate social dumping. Labour inspectorates and/or social partners play a key role in ensuring respect for workers' rights, defining decent remuneration in accordance with The laws and practices of the Member States and providing advice and guidance to employers. The rules on secondment should be clear, proportionate and justified and we stress the need to comply with collective agreements and industrial relations systems in the host country.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on social dumping in the EU, because I do not agree with its basic ideological basis. Various forms of dumping need to be discussed in relation to trade relations with third countries such as China, but not within the EU, where internal market rules apply. Moreover, in a situation where member countries have their social policies at a high level. Moreover, a significant part of the phenomenon mentioned in the report is a violation of laws or other norms for which the term "non-enforcement" should be used. Social dumping is not legally defined (nor is it definable or subjective), and juggling the term is therefore dangerous and easily exploitable, for example, by opponents of the common market and free movement in the EU. I consider fundamental freedoms within the EU to be of untouchable value and it would be very reckless to distort it with political concepts such as social dumping.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this very good own-initiative report, which proposes solutions to harmonise social rights upwards across the EU. The draft report recommended several measures to fill the regulatory and legislative gaps. These included strengthening labour inspections at national level and the creation of a EU-level body to combat abusive practices; an obligation for companies to have one official address to combat letterbox companies; blacklisting companies responsible for serious offences including the use of undeclared work; and a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to ensure real equal treatment of workers and fair competition. More than 700 amendments were tabled, mainly by conservatives, and the resulting compromise amendments have weakened the report, in particular by blocking all concrete proposals in relation to the PWD. Despite this it is still a very progressive and valuable report that comes at a crucial time in the lead-up to the revision of the PWD.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. It reports on the strengthening of the position of workers. Combating social dumping is a necessary step in this direction. I would have supported that.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. The report recommends setting a pan-EU minimum wage that is a threat to small and medium-sized enterprises. Different wage levels favour intra-EU and global competitiveness and are essential for SMEs to promote the EU economy.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. Social dumping is a problem faced by many workers within the Union due to the strong competitive environment in which our companies live.  This report proposes a large group of proposals ranging from labour, tax, transport, etc. These measures aim to strike a balance between working and personal life and to ensure a minimum and fair wage for workers, while seeking to avoid abusive work practices such as the creation by many companies of false self-employed persons or the movement of workers to other countries with also abusive recruitment conditions. This is an important report because it affects broad aspects of the labour and personal sphere. We cannot allow working conditions to continue to deteriorate and to be impassive about it. This report is a step forward and a strong commitment from the European Parliament and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report which calls for an end to social dumping practices and for all workers in Europe to enjoy high levels of social protection and rights. Unfair economic and social competition is an obstacle to maintaining a high level of social protection in Europe. In particular, increased competition between undertakings forces undertakings to reduce costs linked to labour costs. This situation has the effect of weakening the social standards in force in the individual Member States of the Union and gradually lowering the total rights from which European employees can benefit. It is therefore necessary to protect workers from all over Europe against exploitation, discrimination, undeclared work and other forms of social dumping due to the lack of adequate labour legislation at European level.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. Social dumping is of course a huge problem with cheap labour being brought over from other countries by companies to undercut wages and avoid employing local workers. It also covers issues like companies finding cheaper alternatives elsewhere and moving operations abroad. However this report went on to call for more EU action, legislation, monitoring of legislation and data collection. On top of that there isn’t an official legal definition of ‘social dumping’ in EU law, so this report is about an issue the EU can’t even define properly. The EU can never tackle social dumping as the free movement of people is the perfect enabler for it to occur. Also the EU’s Posted Workers Directive actually enables employers to bring cheap labour over to undercut the local community. The only way to stop social dumping is to leave the EU and get back control of immigration.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I congratulate you on your work and contribution to this text. All of us, regardless of political affiliation and considering that one of the fundamental principles of EU policies is social cohesion, must develop rules and instruments that disadvantage and counter the development of unfair competition.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report that sets a common definition of social dumping, as it was necessary to address the lack of a shared definition that has led to misunderstandings and misperceptions in debates across the EU Member States. Hence, the adopted report is of key importance to combat cases of abuse and circumvention of the existing European or national rules. I anticipate better enforcement of existing rules; more strengthened and efficient cooperation between national competent authorities as well as the identification and elimination of existing legal loopholes, which should all result in fairer conditions for workers.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee on social dumping in EU countries. Market development and competition affecting employers leads to a decrease in the price of products and services. To survive and cover costs, employers are forced to reduce the cost of work to employees, and this should not be allowed.  For all EU citizens, an important principle applies, it is the right to equal pay and social protection. We must not allow the understatement of the workforce because human capital is an indispensable resource and worth countering this ruthless market. I am particularly committed to non-working Sundays in all EU Member States, respect for working hours and rest.  I do not support the exploitation of labour, so particular attention should be paid to those sectors where this is most pronounced such as road, air and maritime transport. Greater controls and inspections are needed to combat any unfair and disloyal practices concerning labour rights. I call on all member states to cooperate on this issue.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The announced objective of this report is to close legislative and regulatory gaps that promote the development of current unfair competition within the internal market. For this the solution is simple: more Europe! The proposed solutions range from strengthening controls and inspections (with the creation of a European labour inspection agency) to registering work benefits on a 'single digital document' (again, at European level), revising the 'detached workers' directive and better coordinating social security systems (read 'very soon: a European social security'). All this in order to achieve the "necessary [...] convergence in the European Union." It should be noted that the issue of the revision of the "detached workers" directive is over the top of the air because it will be the subject of a separate report. On the whole, even if it is paved with good intentions, it is nevertheless Europeanist as possible and so full of good feelings that it loses all credibility. I therefore vote against this text and support the alternative proposal put forward by my colleagues in the ENF group, which is much more respectful of the sovereignty of States and therefore of democracy and social protection.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The lack of a real balance between economic freedom and social rights has made it possible to multiply abusive practices and unfair social competition, which contradict the principles on which the European internal market is based and which trigger a generalised 'race to the bottom' of social protection. All this risks seriously undermining the high level of social protection that has historically characterised European countries and, as a result, is undermining citizens' confidence in the European Union, which is increasingly perceived as an entity that weakens individuals and communities, instead of protecting and strengthening them. It is in this context that populist movements and protectionist tendencies are proliferating and, far from proposing effective responses to the problem, they risk aggravating it. The Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D) is more than aware of the seriousness of the problem and this report is a clear expression of our commitment to combating social dumping. It is essential that the European Parliament takes a firm stand and makes its voice heard in the construction of a more social Europe, a Europe that consequently manages to deserve and win the support of all its citizens. That is why I supported this report.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Greater competition between companies usually results in a reduction in costs associated with labour costs. This undermines workers' rights and reduces the funding needed to ensure social protection. I therefore supported MeP Balas's report, as it calls for ensuring a level playing field and for strengthening the fight against violations of workers' social rights.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Social dumping is a phenomenon closely linked to an increasing competitive environment. Individual economic operators shall endeave to reduce as far as possible their labour costs and resort to unfair competition practices. This is unacceptable to me as a Social Democrat. It is necessary to set the limits of their behaviour for the subjects concerned. Actions that deliberately harm workers' rights and undermine social norms cannot be tolerated. For these serious reasons, I welcome the report adopted on social dumping in the European Union, which brings with it important measures to combat these unfair practices. This provision provides, inter a view, for a definition of social dumping, calls for increased controls and inspections and encourages the creation of a legal framework for the protection of carers and domestic workers. At the same time, it is crucial that the EU and the Member States strengthen their cooperation in the exchange of information on the social security of posted workers in order to better enforce existing legislation.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report addresses issues such as the role of labour inspections and equal pay for equal work in the same workplace. It aims at the general definition of 'social dumping', especially in the transport sector. The report also aims to present a wide range of policy recommendations in order to promote better social convergence at EU level. There have been many important objections to the draft text from the outset and a number of amendments have been tabled to adapt the text to comply with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. Measures to protect all workers and ensure their access to fair working conditions can be supported, but actions to undermine the competences of the Member States cannot be supported. This is particularly important in terms of wage setting, social security, tax systems and specific labour market reforms. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report, which is part of the dynamics of building a social Europe. Europe can only be strong if the Member States are part of a social harmonisation process. This text deals specifically with social dumping in the European Union, a practice which severely penalises the internal market. Some European companies are illegally reducing their costs, leading to discrimination and unfair competition within the European Union itself. Above all, it is the workers who are the main victims of these abuses, their working conditions being often difficult to control and verify. National authorities are therefore invited to cooperate more in combating these practices and, for example, so-called "letterbox" companies (responsible for violations of European social law) must be clearly identified in order to be punished.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite being one of the most ambitious regulatory blocks on social rights, the European legal system does not exhaust the range of competences in this area and should also be supported by the legal systems of the Member States. The discrepancy in the exercise of Member States' powers in the context of the consecration and protection of social rights leads, however, to an asymmetry in the European project, which, despite having a virtually completed internal market, has a catalogue of heterogeneous social rights.  It is well known that this dystonia contributes to the creation of sprains to the principle of competition between undertakings and to the promotion of a social market economy, creating incentives to reduce expenditure associated with the cost of labour and thereby weakening the social standards in force in the Union.  The rapporteur therefore recommends increasing control and inspections of working conditions at national and European level, while also suggesting the creation of a single digital document, which aggregates the social rights of all European workers, and the fight against 'front companies'. Fighting for the correction of this asymmetry between economic freedoms and social rights, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding, own-initiative report. Social dumping is of course a huge problem with cheap labour being brought over from other countries by companies to undercut wages and avoid employing local workers. It also covers issues like companies finding cheaper alternatives elsewhere and moving operations abroad. However this report went on to call for more EU action, legislation, monitoring of legislation and data collection. On top of that there isn’t an official legal definition of ‘social dumping’ in EU law, so this report is about an issue the EU can’t even define properly. The EU can never tackle social dumping as the free movement of people is the perfect enabler for it to occur. Also the EU’s Posted Workers Directive actually enables employers to bring cheap labour over to undercut the local community. The only way to stop social dumping is to leave the EU and get back control of immigration.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that Europe has been defined as a democratic area with good economic performance and high-level social protection, this report stresses that greater priority has been given to the construction and strengthening of the internal market. The rapporteur underlines that social rights have not been the subject of similar harmonisation and that it was agreed that Member States would continue to be socially competent. It also notes a paradox that encourages competition between companies, although European workers do not have the same obligations or the same social rights, insisting on the political repercussions of this asymmetry between economic freedoms and social rights. Following this situation, the rapporteur proposes, first, an increase in controls and inspections, modernising the register of work benefits and the need to create a single digital document containing the social rights of all European workers and, finally, a European list of companies that have committed serious infringements. Finally, the rapporteur calls for the creation of a social protocol guaranteeing the primacy of social rights over economic freedoms and recommends setting minimum wage limits.  In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the EU, social rights have not yet been harmonised, and it has been agreed that Member States would continue to be socially competent. In fact, there is an asymmetry between the reality of a virtually completed internal market and very heterogeneous social rights. This paradox encourages competition between companies, although European workers do not have the same obligations or social rights.  There are several measures that can address legislative and regulatory gaps favouring "social dumping": an increase in controls and inspections, both at national and European level, in application of existing legislation (human and financial resources should be strengthened); the creation of a single digital document containing the social rights of all European workers; combating 'front companies', in particular by imposing new obligations on official addresses; the creation of a European list of companies that have committed serious infringements, such as the use of undeclared work; the adoption of urgent measures in the transport sector, which are often genuine areas of non-social law; the creation of a social protocol ensuring the primacy of social rights over economic freedoms and the setting of minimum wage limits.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The fight against social dumping, which could be defined as the downing race in socio-labor and wage standards within the Union, has been a priority of the Socialist Group since the last parliamentary term, as it results in the abuse of workers and erodes national social protection systems.  With this report, the Socialists wanted to improve labour controls and inspections in the Union, increase sanctions for companies that do not respect the rules, improve cooperation between national authorities in order to improve the fight against social security fraud, false self-employment and fictitious enterprises. We also call on the Commission to set up a Europe Road Transport Agency and to review the Workers' Displacement Directive.  In short, I voted in favour of this report because it is a huge step forward in upward social convergence in the Union and in the struggle to equate social rights with economic freedoms. Only by guaranteeing the principle of equal pay for equal work and fair competition can we really protect workers and SMEs, which are the real engine for creating jobs in the Union.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Today was voted a report on social dumping in Europe. The result of a compromise, it is not perfect, but I have supported it, because it has the merit of producing a definition of social dumping (which, for some, does not exist...) and proposing concrete measures to prevent unfair competition. A positive first step pending the resumption of discussions on the revision of the Detachment of Workers Directive. A thorny but very important issue led by Commissioner Marianne Thyssen, who is facing fierce opposition from Central and Eastern Europe. The protection of social rights and identical rights in Europe is not yet a reality, but any such initiative must be encouraged.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Guillaume Balas' report on social dumping in the European Union. With this report, the European Parliament relays the demand of European citizens for a social Europe. This report makes concrete proposals to combat social dumping, such as the establishment of a blacklist of companies responsible for serious violations of labour laws (including mailbox companies) and temporarily excluded from access to public order and EU funds. It prioritizes the fight for gender equality by urging the Commission to take measures to help women affected by social dumping. The report also sets the first steps for "upward" social convergence by recommending the introduction of a 60% threshold of the national average wage as a benchmark for setting the minimum wage in the Member States. By proposing to remedy distortions of competition in the internal market and to raise the level of protection for workers, it can help restore citizens' confidence in the European project.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. This report draws attention to the dichotomy between what so-called 'economic freedoms' represent and what so-called 'social rights' represent, warning that it usually leads to abusive practices, unfair social competition and subversion of the social market economy, with the subsequent incentive to protectionism of member states and unilateral decision-making in the social field.  Nevertheless, it is certain that there is already a greater awareness and concern on the part of the European authorities about this problem, in the fight against so-called 'social dumping'. To that end, I am in favour of the need to water down some legislative and regulatory edges which may lead to the promotion of unfair competition within the internal market, as well as to the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive and regulations on the coordination of social security systems. Despite the controversy of some proposals concerning the harmonisation of social policies at European level and the introduction of stabilising mechanisms, it was possible to reach compromise solutions between the various political groups to achieve a balanced report, which obtained my vote in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock and proposes ways to combat social dumping within the Union. The proliferation of abusive practices and the increasing use of social dumping are undermining the competitiveness of businesses, especially SMEs, weakening confidence in European integration but, above all, undermining the rights of European workers. This situation can no longer last! Europe must fight social dumping. This text calls for tighter controls and greater coordination between and by Member States. Improving cross-border cooperation between inspection services, or developing a list of European-wide companies engaged in social dumping, are measures that will effectively combat abusive practices and provide greater protection for our market-distorting companies. Europe must be more social and protect businesses and workers from unfair practices within its internal market. With this in mind, the report calls for the establishment of a pillar of social rights to enable upward social convergence and protection of workers.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because it is a progressive report denouncing the unfair economic and social competition that social dumping practices entail. Dumping promotes a reduction in labour costs and entails less social protection for workers, which in turn results in a decrease in the available resources of the State to protect its own citizens. The report proposes harmonisation of social rights and includes positive measures such as strengthening labour inspection at national level and creating a Body at Union level to combat abusive practices; the development of a single digital document that guarantees the social rights of all workers; the obligation for companies to have an official direction to combat the existence of phantom companies; a revision of the Displaced Workers Directive to ensure fair competition, with particular emphasis on the transport sector and the adoption of a social protocol ensuring the predominance of social rights over economic freedoms, as well as the introduction of minimum wages that can be extended at Union level in some sectors.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I abstained on the report on social dumping in Europe because, although I think it is important to combat social dumping, this report touched on many areas that have nothing to do with social dumping and are actually being dealt with in parallel in other Parliament reports or will soon be.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As long as there are huge wage disparities between Member States in the European Union, we will still face a competitive environment that builds on these differences. For this reason too, it is so difficult to agree on the definition of so-called social dumping across Europe. This report, which otherwise describes a number of unacceptable practices towards employees, has not fully come to terms with this either. First and foremost, however, it is a fundamental problem of economic and social convergence. We should therefore pay particular attention to the nature of the problem, rather than pointing out and trying to address one of its symptoms. Unfortunately, the reality is the abuse of the weaker economic situation of people in different parts of Europe. These practices are committed not only by companies at fictitious addresses, but also by some reputable employers from economically stronger countries, as demonstrated, for example, by the testimony of truck drivers that took place some time ago here in the European Parliament.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report not only clearly positions itself on a problem, that of social dumping, which the right and other European institutions even refuse to name, but requires measures with which I very much agree: the better implementation of existing labour regulations, the strengthening of sanctions and inspections and the extension of responsibility to the subcontracting chain , coordination of social security systems, equal rights between workers in the same place etc. I see with skepticism that the constitutional architecture of treaties, especially when the Union does not intend to be integrated into the European Social Charter or even the ECHR, allows us to overcome the current subordination of labour rules to the 'market freedoms' used by large groups to force workers to compete with each other and, in this regard, I consider insufficient proposals such as that of the 'Social Pillar' or the current reform of the directive on posted workers who please to the rapporteur. Nevertheless, considering it a step in the right direction, I voted in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today the European Parliament Labour Party (EPLP) voted in favour of an important report to fight social dumping (the race to the bottom on social rights and wages) in Europe. The EPLP has long been calling for a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to fight social dumping effectively and ensure fair competition. We need to codify the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing – I welcome efforts to improve the position of workers and ensure equal opportunities for access to the labour market. At the same time, however, it is necessary to take into account the specificities of the labour markets of individual Member States and to respect that social security policy falls within the competence of the Member States, which is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ strong safeguards for the protection of the rights of posted workers and prevention of social dumping are laid down in the Posting of Workers Directive (96/71/EC) of 1996, which constitutes a basic set of mandatory rules on employment conditions which must be guaranteed to workers posted to work in another Member State. I regret that 'social dumping' does not have a legally recognised and common definition, which is why, in practice, we often encounter unfair practices and situations that allow unfair competition to develop. I supported the resolution because I expect the reform of the directive to eliminate the shortcomings of social dumping, which contribute to different national solutions and run counter to the fundamental freedoms of the single market. I also consider the reform of the directive to be important because the proposal will create a legal framework for posting workers that is clear, fair and easier to enforce. I believe that, in order to achieve firm and lasting competitiveness in all Member States, posting of workers will not be a source of social dumping, but will facilitate the posting of workers in an environment of fairer competition and respect for the rights of workers who are employed in one Member State and whose employer has temporarily posted to work in another Member State.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Social dumping is currently the biggest problem caused by deliberate exploitative practices. These are numerous cases of abuse of European and national laws with the aim of obtaining benefits at the expense of one of the social security systems.  The Commission and the Member States must escalate their action in this area, ensure effective supervision and better exchange of information between Member States. The report links social dumping to undeclared work, covert employment relationships and cases of posting abuses to other Member States, while at the same time describing a wide range of exploitative practices that arise in relation to national laws and European rules. The sectors most "under the shock" are agriculture, construction, service, transport, health and the like.  It is precisely because of the abuses that take place in the space of several countries at the same time, the Member States need to strengthen cooperation and organise their inspection bodies in such cases so that they cooperate closely with each other in such cases.  Particular attention is also paid to companies which are mailboxes and serve only the purpose of exploiting certain differences between member states' social systems with long-term damage to employees. A specific chapter is also devoted to transport, where such practices occur to the greatest extent possible.  I believe that such exploitative practices must be prevented at the expense of our social systems and employees, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report calls for far-reaching regulations to prevent "social dumping" across Europe. ALFA supports adequate working and safety conditions for all workers. However, the report goes far too far in many areas and calls for a full-scale expansion of the welfare state. For example, it calls for a minimum wage of 60% of the average income. In addition, the report calls on the Commission to consider an unconditional basic income in a regulatory way. For these reasons, I cannot vote in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ I consider any efforts to introduce a single European minimum wage unacceptable. This would be a serious interference with the exclusive competences of the Member States and a distortion of free competition with the inevitable consequence of the collapse of domestic firms, especially small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA is committed to tackling social dumping with conviction. A fairer European labour market is simply a must. Unfortunately, the N-VA cannot support this report because it takes the wrong approach. For example, we are resolutely opting for a euro-federalist course with more European legislation, in areas where EU action is neither desirable nor legitimate. Further objections to the N-VA include the complete rejection of flexible employment contracts, the stigmatisation of robotics and artificial intelligence as major causes of job losses, the rejection of single partnerships, etc.  The N-VA therefore abstained in the vote on this report. However, she deliberately chose not to vote against it in order to signal that the fight against social dumping is paramount to the N-VA. According to the N-VA, this fight must be waged by, for example, the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place, the reduction of the posting period to a maximum of 6 months and the payment of social security contributions in the country of work.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I accept the Report on Social Dumping in the European Union, as I believe that this undermines one of the main principles of EU policy, namely social cohesion. Continuous and permanent harmonisation of wages and guaranteed social protection for all workers is needed. Undeclared work and bogus self-employment can lead to distortions of competition leading to long-term damage to social security systems.  Working conditions that protect physical and mental health are a fundamental right of all workers. It is important to note that there is still a pay gap between women and men which is inadmissible. Social dumping can only further deepen the cash income gap between men and women and leave older women at greater risk of poverty.  Social dumping, be it fissile or environmentally, is contrary to European values. I also believe that social dumping undermines the protection of the rights of EU citizens, and the protection of the rights and free movement of persons is essential for the European project itself.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. The EP complains about distortions of competition caused by social dumping. But the EU is a distortion of competition because competition has been abolished through a common internal market with a common currency between completely different economies. Let us not forget that the real aim of the founding fathers of the EU was to abolish the nation state through a centralised pan-European political union. The internal market was only a first step in this direction. Political union is being driven forward by 'accompanying policies' of the internal market. These include the demands expressed here to combat 'social dumping'. The EP itself notes that there is no definition of 'social dumping', but that 'social dumping' must be combated through community-level policies. That is why I am opposed to this resolution. The AfD stands for the fact that the world of work should enable all citizens to lead a self-determined life in relative prosperity. Because this claim is not necessarily consistent with the objectives of the economy, the state must establish an appropriate regulatory framework. This framework must not restrict too much those who can and want to do a great deal, while at the same time not letting those who are unable to look after themselves fall out of the frame. The political design of the conditions of working life and of all systems that guarantee the unemployed sufficient living conditions is therefore one of the most significant policy areas of modern statehood.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Undeclared work and bogus self-employment distort competition, which harms the social security system, but contributes to the growth of precarious jobs and undermines the level of worker protection. Increasing employment among women is a key objective of the European Union in terms of social dumping.  This also includes improving women's position in the labour market and eliminating gender disparities. It is also important to mention the pay gap between men and women that is still present, which ultimately leads to pension gaps. Human trafficking, especially women, which also exists between EU countries is often associated with a bogus employment contract. I support the social dumping report because I think the guidelines set out there are of high quality and will allow for stronger control and coordination of Member States, as well as address regulatory shortcomings in order to enforce national and European labour and social law.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on social dumping in the European Union. In the social sphere, the European Union has not yet achieved full harmonisation, so we need to unify those policies where possible.  In recent years, we have seen increasing social dumping, which has a negative impact on the competitiveness of enterprises. However, there is still a great deal of ambiguity and confusion in the area of social dumping, as we still do not have a clear and generally accepted definition.  As an alternate member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I support the committee's opinion that Member States should implement fully, effectively and in a non-discriminatory manner all social legislation applicable to the transport sector and to increase the number of actual controls, in particular as regards driving and rest periods.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted today against the report on social dumping in the EU because I believe that it is very dangerous to have a debate on a concept whose definition does not exist in the EU legal order and whose interpretation is still very variable by the participants in the various discussion forums. Moreover, if that concept can serve as a pretext for restricting the fundamental freedoms on which the common market is based, that concept must be rejected. The free movement of people, services, goods and capital is clearly regulated by EU law and any questioning of it is counterproductive and only leads to the break-up of the common market, not to its further development.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report even though we think it could have had more positive elements. The vote in favour of a report with this title was a political act, because Parliament itself now accepts the existence of a security in employment, and the dissolution of industrial relations. We have clear positions against the dismantling of the social fabric as a result of the neoliberal policies imposed by the Stability Pact and the European Semester. The report made a first attempt to define social dumping, which conservative and neoliberal forces in parliament have tried to reject. For us it is clear that insecurity at work, the reduction of workers covered by collective agreements, the increase in reduced-term contracts, the impoverishment of workers and chronic unemployment, especially among young people, are social dumping. Even if these are not mentioned in the report, an important first attempt has been made, which we will continue in Parliament.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 There are hundreds of laws, laws and directives at EU level relating to work, employment, insurance, social cohesion, ensuring the health of workers and protecting them from atypical and flexible forms of employment. In my country, everything that this report is trying to combat and even more is being implemented. I would suggest, as a genuine pragmatist, instead of this report, that we proceed to the adoption of two simple laws: a law that makes it compulsory for everyone to apply labour laws, i.e. institutions, Member States and social partners, and a second that repeals those laws that are unenforceable in practice.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order not to be self-contradictory because of my obligation as Vice-President of the People's Party, in cases where the parliamentary group votes differently from the Hungarian Members in roll call ballots, I will not take part directly in the vote. In other words, I will not press the voting button, but I will put my hand on the voting position previously decided jointly by the PP group. That's how I did it in this case.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it makes the right findings in an area that is important to me personally. The rapporteur notes that, in addition to the efforts for peace and prosperity after The Second World War, 'Europe' was defined by its creators as a democratic area where, in addition to a successful economy, a high level of social protection was provided. In reality, however, while we have made great strides in terms of economic elements, apart from a few principles set out in the Treaty and in some directives, the competence in the social field has remained with the Member States. I share the finding that there is, in practice, asymmetry between the internal market and highly heterogeneous social rights.  I believe that the principle of the reverse between the development of the social system and economic development prevails, which many people have mistaken for: Member States that maintain a quality social system (and not the other way around) are successful economically. I agree that there is competition between companies in an asymmetrical system, which also hinders the maintenance of a high level of social protection in Europe (e.g. fierce competition between economic operators encourages companies to reduce spending). Unfortunately, the gender pay gap is even more burdened by social dumping. I believe that the European minimum wage dreamed up by the Party of European Socialists a decade ago would have a positive impact on social rights!

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The best guarantee of economic development and protection against the crisis is a healthy and fair market generating domestic demand. However, we have not been able to create a fully integrated single market within the European Union for years. Instead, we are multiplying the rules that burden businesses, which are destroying EU competition. The social dumping report contains a number of dangerous provisions which, if implemented, could become a nail in the coffin for EU entrepreneurship and competitiveness.  The mere use of the vague concept of social dumping as a pretext for the introduction of protectionist measures by a growing number of Member States may be objectionable. Proposals for measures purporting to serve social convergence are also being multiplied at EU level– in particular the proposal to amend the Posting of Workers Directive and the announcement of the construction of the European Pillar of Social Rights. In my opinion, social convergence should be a natural process for equalisation of differences in the economic development of the Member States and should not be achieved by imposing harmonised social standards from above. Moreover, such steps are incompatible with the Treaty principle of division of powers and the principle of subsidiarity. I have therefore chosen to vote against Parliament's report and I believe that both the European Commission and the Council will take action to support EU citizens and businesses, not harm them.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted against the resolution. In many respects, this motion for a resolution exceeded the EU's competences. With good attention to this document, I would like to highlight the paragraph on cabotage transport, which made the right line in order to harmonise regulation. However, I felt that there were too many problematic points in the resolution as a whole that I could have voted in favour of it.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Increased competition between economic operators has at times led to a race to the bottom as regards social conditions for European workers. The proliferation of abusive practices and unfair social competition is constantly weakening the principle of the internal market and ultimately undermines the construction of the European project. Moreover, in trying to defend their own market, some Member States have introduced protectionist measures which have further distorted the market. To respond to all these issues, the present report has aimed to bring some clarity with regard to the practice of social dumping, with the final aim of ensuring social rights in a harmonious manner across Europe. It calls for control and inspections to be strengthened, at both national and EU level, and calls for the establishment of a legal framework for the protection of all European workers. In the field of transport, a key achievement is the request for the creation of a European Road Agency, a body which could ensure the coordination of all transport policies, including social aspects, between national authorities and EU institutions.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for my colleague Balas' report. The rapporteur wanted to make concrete proposals, most often made by employers, employees, or experts in the field. He stressed the preponderance of social issues, in particular that of unfair social competition among our fellow Europeans. It thus underlines the importance of a strong and heard word from the European Parliament helping to build a more social Europe and therefore more supported by our peoples. Let us regret, however, the EPP's desire to empty the text somewhat of its essence!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to create the EU internal market, it was necessary to bring together a group of countries that are socially, economically and politically diverse. While it is essential that we ensure a level playing field, fair competition and fair working conditions across this internal market by harmonising the rules when necessary, I do not believe that imposing certain conditions that are not adapted to the specific dynamics and traditions of each Member State will benefit our economy as a whole, as the report advocates. This is particularly true for many of the small businesses across the EU, for whom the imposition of certain inadequate demands could truly damage their competitiveness. This is why I voted against this report, in addition to the fact the practices it describes do not reflect my understanding of social dumping.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. After several months of hard work and negotiations to push the right of the European Parliament to its limits, the adoption by a large majority of the report of my French Socialist colleague Guillaume Balas is a magnificent victory. This initiative report is a signal sent to the European Commission, which is struggling to come up with ambitious proposals to combat social dumping. The European Parliament has demonstrated that a majority of its members support greater social convergence. European citizens have been waiting for it for too long. Today, the responsibility lies with the Commission and the Member States, who cannot ignore this momentum. Tomorrow, if the Commission were to transform the test, it would be necessary to ensure that companies established in the Union have a real activity, a blacklist of companies responsible for serious violations of social labour legislation would be put in place, a minimum wage would be introduced at a threshold of 60% of the national average wage, in terms of secondment of workers joint and solidarity liability on the subcontracting chain would be extended and declarations of compulsory detachment registered in a European register to facilitate consultation and coordination between Member States.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒This report tosses a number of problems in the exercise of employee rights, such as the role of labour inspection, the need for equal pay for equal work in the same place, a level playing field in the same workplace or respect for working hours. Like my ECR colleagues, I will always support efforts to ensure that all workers are protected to the maximum and that everyone is entitled to fair working conditions, but I cannot support something that undermines member states' competence. This is particularly important in terms of wage setting, social security, the tax system and specific labour market reform. The ECR shadow rapporteur has worked constructively in the negotiations, in particular with the EPP and ALDE shadow rapporteurs, to bring this report as close as possible to the ECR's views. Unfortunately, the ECR proposals have not met with approval from the S&D rapporteur, which is why I will not support this report on social dumping in the European Union.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on social dumping in the EU because undeclared work and quasi-self-employment can distort competition, lead to precarious jobs and affect the deteriorating protection of workers and the overall quality of jobs.  In the EU, on the one hand, we have the free movement of people who can travel and work anywhere in the Union and in different forms of employment. On the other hand, we have companies that are in the single market and are placed in a position where they have to ensure competitiveness. We also have countries within the European Union that cannot guarantee the same level of social rights because their budget cannot take it.  We must distinguish between the exploitation of employees, on which some employers make profits because of their own gluttony for higher profits, and between ensuring equal income and equal social status. We need to be aware that social rights cost money and many do not want to see it. The answer to how we can ensure the same social situation would be simple if there was a single European source from which social rights would be financed. Until this is the case, we will continue to face the fact that social rights within the European Union are different.  We need to help businesses and shape our proposals in such a way as to create an environment where differences are minimised.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The commitment of the Commission to establish a pillar of social rights is welcomed.  Social, especially wage disparities between Eastern, Western and Southern parts of the EU are deplorable. Therefore I fully support the recommendation of the report regarding the establishment of wage floors in the form of a national minimum wage and the objective of attaining at least 60% of the respective national average wage.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because it is a progressive report denouncing the unfair economic and social competition that social dumping practices entail. Dumping promotes a reduction in labour costs and entails less social protection for workers, which in turn results in a decrease in the available resources of the State to protect its own citizens. The report proposes harmonisation of social rights and includes positive measures such as strengthening labour inspection at national level and creating a Body at Union level to combat abusive practices; the development of a single digital document that guarantees the social rights of all workers; the obligation for companies to have an official direction to combat the existence of phantom companies; a revision of the Displaced Workers Directive to ensure fair competition, with particular emphasis on the transport sector and the adoption of a social protocol ensuring the predominance of social rights over economic freedoms, as well as the introduction of minimum wages that can be extended at Union level in some sectors.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The report calls for far-reaching regulations to prevent "social dumping" across Europe. ALFA supports adequate working and safety conditions for all workers. However, the report goes far too far in many areas and calls for a full-scale expansion of the welfare state. For example, it calls for a minimum wage of 60% of the average income. In addition, the report calls on the Commission to consider an unconditional basic income in a regulatory way. For these reasons, I cannot vote in favour of the report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In these times of social and economic crisis, is more important than ever that the EU fights against the social dumping that is undermining the standards of our workers. Freedom of labour should not be misused as this will create a backlash against the EU. Minimum wages have to be protected and strengthened, as well as decent working and salary conditions. Without them, the EU will just join a race to the bottom in labour standards. This is why I will vote in favour of this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The proposed resolution concerns the regulation of social rights in the countries of the European Union. Important demands, such as the protection of workers in the labour market or non-discrimination, are worth considering, but the proposal implies excessive interference by senior EU actors in member states' internal regulations. The proposal to harmonise wages, the tax system and social security, which are individual decisions of governments familiar with the specifics of national labour markets, should be called into question. I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the main tenasures of EU policies is social cohesion, which means a continuous and constant approximation of the wages of all workers, local or traveller, and the social security protection granted to them. Workers leave their home countries primarily because of wage differences. Nevertheless, in the final vote, I supported the group's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, because it is a progressive report denouncing the unfair economic and social competition that social dumping practices entail. Dumping promotes a reduction in labour costs and entails less social protection for workers, which in turn results in a decrease in the available resources of the State to protect its own citizens. The report proposes harmonisation of social rights and includes positive measures such as strengthening labour inspection at national level and creating a Body at Union level to combat abusive practices; the development of a single digital document that guarantees the social rights of all workers; the obligation for companies to have an official direction to combat the existence of phantom companies; a revision of the Displaced Workers Directive to ensure fair competition, with particular emphasis on the transport sector and the adoption of a social protocol ensuring the predominance of social rights over economic freedoms, as well as the introduction of minimum wages that can be extended at Union level in some sectors.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Voted for. The title of the report is hiding the biggest problem in situations of intentionally abusive practices and circumvention of existing labour and social legislation. These practices are leading to the exploitation of workers and the violation of their rights. The Commission and Member States need to step up their efforts to ensure the proper implementation of European and national legislation in this field and improve the effectiveness of controls, including by a better exchange of information and by improving cooperation between national labour and social control bodies in cross-border situations.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I call on the Commission to coordinate and strengthen cooperation between national authorities on road transport legislation, including through the exchange of information, and on other actions to support the implementation of legislation and to ensure a level playing field between operators. I welcome the launch of the European Platform against Undeclared Work and the objectives it has set to strengthen cooperation in preventing and deterrence of undeclared work.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. The fight against social dumping, which could be defined as the downing race in socio-labor and wage standards within the Union, has been a priority of the Socialist Group since the last parliamentary term, as it results in the abuse of workers and erodes national social protection systems.  With this report, the Socialists wanted to improve labour controls and inspections in the Union, increase sanctions for companies that do not respect the rules, improve cooperation between national authorities in order to improve the fight against social security fraud, false self-employment and fictitious enterprises. We also call on the Commission to set up a Europe Road Transport Agency and to review the Workers' Displacement Directive.  In short, I voted in favour of this report because it is a huge step forward in upward social convergence in the Union and in the struggle to equate social rights with economic freedoms. Only by guaranteeing the principle of equal pay for equal work and fair competition can we really protect workers and SMEs, which are the real engine for creating jobs in the Union.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today the EPLP voted in favour of an important report to fight social dumping (the race to the bottom on social rights and wages) in Europe. The European Parliament Labour Party has long been calling for a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to fight social dumping effectively and ensure fair competition. We need to codify the principle of ‘equal pay for equal work in the same place’.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'The report on social dumping in the EU falls short in many areas. I voted against it and my group.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I opposed the adoption of the report on social dumping in the European Union. The report as a whole largely interferes with the sovereignty of the Member States and uses simplistic and even erroneous points of view in some places in its explanatory statement. The ground proposal also called for the sustainability of economic and monetary union as a whole to be strengthened, which I cannot support. In addition, the report tackles the rules on restricting cabotage and proposes that they be dismantled. From the point of view of Finland or the majority of EU countries, these are not welcome reforms. The ALDE Group also voted to reject the report as a whole.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to combat "social dumping" in the EU. This phenomenon is relevant, particularly in the light of austerity policies, which have promoted labour precariousing, unemployment, increased poverty and exclusion, which facilitates the reduction of labour and civil rights. The report emphasises the need to strengthen inspection, even at the level of cross-border cooperation, as a way of combating "social dumping".  By combining this strengthening of means and staff with the reference made to the strengthening of collective bargaining, the recovery of social rights (including guaranteed income) and the promotion of work with rights and the limitation of the posting of workers, it is understood that the report has many positive points, contrary to the existence of dumping. Concerns about the "truth" of the single market for people and goods, in the way of defending and promoting it, are, however, contrary to what was required in this context.  There is no goodness in the single market. This inconsistency of principles justifies the abstention in this document, which would be desirable for you to affirm a break with the causes of social dumping in the EU context.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report deals with social dumping and its consequences. It also calls for the fight against bogus self-employment, which in turn distorts competition. In addition, companies that violate labour and social law regulations are to be kept in a register. Since it is crucial to achieve equal competition across Europe, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on social dumping in the European Union. This report was necessary in view of the strong asymmetry within the European Union between economic freedoms and social rights, which has fuelled a feeling that weakens both individuals and the community, rather than ensuring the protection of its population. The increase in abusive practices and the exercise of unfair social competition weaken adherence to the principle of the internal market and weaken confidence in the construction of Europe.  These phenomena are an incentive to withdraw protectionist member states and to take unilateral decisions in the social field. This report is the result of numerous hearings of experts, employers and employee representatives and proposes measures to remedy the legislative and regulatory shortcomings that favour the development of unfair competition currently present in the internal market.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EPLP voted in favour of an important report to fight social dumping (the race to the bottom on social rights and wages) in Europe, sending a strong message to the Commission and Member States. With the adoption of this report, supported by all British Trade Unions, the Socialists and Democrats have won an important battle to protect workers from all over Europe against the exploitation, discrimination and abuse they suffer at the hands of unscrupulous companies and due to the lack of adequate labour legislation at a European level. The European Parliamentary Labour Party has long been calling for a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to fight social dumping effectively and ensure fair competition.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Parliamentary resolution because I recognise that social dumping is an important issue in the EU that needs to be addressed. Especially in the transport sector action needs to be taken. The Commission has already indicated that it is working on this. Setting up a European Road and Transport Agency can help in this regard. I agree that it is very important that fair competition is guaranteed. In order to ensure this, both fraud and tax evasion need to be combated. With regard to the enforcement of adherence to current legislation, I welcome specific measures mentioned in this resolution. The use of technology will play a strong role herein. Member States’ authorities should focus more on an exchange of information on the posting of workers and the companies involved in this. However, we should avoid the misuse of the term ‘social dumping’ for protectionist purposes.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the adoption of the report on social dumping in the EU because I am deeply convinced of the importance of the four fundamental freedoms of the common market and the need to avoid discrimination of any kind when referring to the future of these freedoms. The report makes serious confusions between notions such as black work, freedom of movement for workers, freedom of movement of services and abuses the notion of social dumping, using this vague and insufficiently defined term to justify potential adverse consequences for citizens of some EU Member States.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report addresses the role of labour inspections and equal pay for equal work in the same workplace. It also aims at defining the concepts of 'social dumping', especially in the transport sector. There are many important reservations about the text of the report, the provisions of which do not comply with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. The European Commission's proposal to combat social dumping is incompatible with the rules of the internal market, as it imposes a disproportionate burden on businesses seconding workers and can have long-term negative effects.  Action to protect all workers and ensure their access to fair working conditions should be encouraged, but I cannot support actions to undermine the competences of the Member States. This is particularly important in terms of wage setting, social security, tax systems and specific labour market reforms.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Articulated report on three axes: strengthening controls and coordination by and between Member States; eliminate legislative gaps to ensure compliance with social and labour legislation, ensuring the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination; and achieve upward social convergence. Negotiations have been difficult and sensitive but agreement has been reached with a number of commitments, even if there have been separate votes. With regard to the first axis, Spain shares the need to carry out all necessary measures to combat fraud and social dumping, reinforcing labour inspections. We support the creation of a European platform to combat fraud and the submerged economy and join the actions of information exchange between Member States; Directive 96/71/EC on posted workers has already been transposed. With regard to the second axis, it is in line with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination which is protected in Spain. The third block is being addressed within the EU on different committees. In general, I support the content of the report, taking into account national competences, so I vote in favour.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report treats the violation of labour law and the violation of labour rights as a "distortion" of capitalist competition. The EU and governments treat labour rights not from the point of view of workers' needs, but from the point of view of business interests and monopoly competition. They thus promote the false separation between 'good' companies that supposedly respect labour rights and 'bad' who trample on them, calling on workers to be aligned behind 'good' capitalists, so as not to reduce the competitiveness of the former. Any comments about violations of labour law (false self-employment, undeclared work, non-payment of insurance contributions) end up serving competing business interests. This reflects the EU's so-called 'social model', the 'acquis communautaire', which the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government claims to be a 'protection shield' for workers. The working class in our country and in the other EU Member States already has bitter experience. For this reason, they must resolutely confront their policy of deception by organizing their fight against their real adversary, monopolies and associations, claiming power and ownership of the wealth they produce.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The fight against social dumping is one of the great promises made by Jean-Claude Juncker. However, social competence remains one of the exclusive competences of Member States, which is why there are now great differences between the social rights and social obligations of countries. According to the rapporteur, this asymmetry is an obstacle to the harmonisation of living and working conditions in the EU and leads to the weakening of social standards. The announced objective of this report is to close the legislative and regulatory loopholes that promote the development of current unfair competition within the internal market. The proposed solutions range from strengthening controls and inspections, through the revision of the "detached workers" directive and better coordination of social security systems. Even if it is paved with good intentions, this text is nevertheless Europeanist as possible, and so full of good feelings that it loses all credibility. The ENF Group presented an alternative resolution stressing the failure of the internal market and calling for the Commission to stop any attempt to coordinate national wage-setting mechanisms. We also call for it to allow Member States to combat the phenomenon of foreign temporary agencies. I voted against this report.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided not to support this report. This is parliament's initiative report containing a number of measures which, in my opinion, are not feasible in practice. If we really want to help the real situation in the labour market, we should look at the real needs and not create more nonsensical regulations. Moreover, I also do not agree with the definition of social dumping that appears in the report. In particular, the European Union should promote competitiveness and the freedom to conduct a business. I think these are solutions that would help the labour market.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ the report on social dumping in the European Union was produced on members' own initiative and is intended to express the European Parliament's opinion on social dumping in advance of the European Commission's new legislative proposals. The report touches on various topics, such as labour inspectorates, the principle of equal pay for equal work, while at the same time trying to define social dumping (especially in the field of transport). Unfortunately, however, many parts of this report interfere with the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality, and since this problem was not eliminated during the vote on the report, I decided to vote against it.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The problem of non-compliance with workers' rights is one of the most widely discussed in the EU today. The growing popularity of flexible working arrangements or the forced self-employment of workers, especially in a cross-border context, is conducive to the emergence of pathologies and non-compliance by employers with existing social security or working time rules.  What is different, however, is to criticise and actually combat such abuses and, more differently, to try to include in these practices the objective economic differences that exist between Member States. The concept of 'social dumping' which is the subject of this report is extremely imprecise and should not be used in this discussion. Treating the disparity between the minimum wage or social benefits in Poland and Germany as a form of unfair competition is a misunderstanding. This interpretation, which unfortunately indirectly supports this report, is an extremely dangerous m.in. for Polish companies delegating their employees to provide services throughout the EU and for transport companies that have already fallen victim to it as a result of the extremely restrictive minimum wage rules in force in France and Germany.  I agree with the intentions of the authors of this report, as long as they were sincere, that decent wages and adequate working conditions are unconsuatable and that workers' rights must be protected and enforced. However, I believe that this report is unacceptable in this form, which is why I voted against it by the European Parliament.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Balas report because I believe that it is essential that the European Parliament has a stronger voice in building a fairer Europe so that all European workers can be covered by the same levels of social protection. Despite some attempts to weaken this report, I underline the action of the European Socialist Group which has managed to include the need to ensure a level playing field across the EU to eliminate social dumping. In this context, I would like to note the definition of social dumping presented in the report, which, while recognising the lack of a legally recognised and universally accepted definition of social dumping, notes that the concept covers a wide range of intentionally abusive practices that enable unfair competition to develop by illegally minimising labour and operating costs and lead to violations of the rights and exploitation of workers. I also call on the European Commission to make a recommendation for the 28 Member States that have ratified ILO Convention 81 on labour inspection in order to ensure compliance with labour standards and the protection of workers, including provisions on working time, safety and health.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The rights and social protections of workers within the EU vary from state to state, creating a situation of unfair competition between European companies. In this context, social protection and workers' rights are also being reduced. The exacerbated competition between economic operators leads to a reduction in the costs associated with labour costs, with a consequent deterioration in the rights that European employees can avail themselves of. The report recommends a series of measures aimed at filling the legislative and regulatory gaps that favour the development of unfair competition currently present in the internal market. This document is intended to curb what is a major contradiction in the internal market. It calls for an increase, both at European and national level, in controls and inspections resulting from the application of existing legislation. In this respect, it calls for a strengthening of the human and financial resources made available to the competent authorities responsible for enforcing the rules. The aim is to strengthen this fight by also proposing the creation of a European blacklist of companies guilty of serious infringements such as the use of undeclared work. This is a battle with which I agree, and I have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on social dumping in the European Union.  The concept of social dumping covers a number of cases of deliberately harmful practices and abuses of existing European and national legislation, which leads to unfair competition due to the unlawful reduction of labour costs and operating costs and leads to infringements of workers' rights and their exploitation.  I agree that it is essential to ensure a level playing field and fair competition throughout the EU and to eliminate social dumping.  I believe that labour inspectorates and trade unions play a key role in strengthening workers' rights and defining decent wages in accordance with regulations. It is therefore necessary that Member States increase efficiency and provide adequate human and other resources for their supervisory authorities, including social and/or labour inspectorates, agencies and liaison offices.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I find it misleading for investors to remove credit risk from the calculation of the risk categorisation of insurance products, as consumer information on investment products should be fully comparable in order to promote a level playing field in the market.  Therefore, given that the Delegated Act adopted by the Commission contains gaps in the methodology for calculating future performance scenarios and therefore does not meet the requirement under Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 to provide information that is 'accurate, correct, clear and non-misleading', there is a risk of a conflict with the spirit and purpose of the legislation, which is to provide clear, comparable, comprehensible and non-misleading information on PRIIP to retail investors. This report therefore calls for this delegated regulation not to enter into force, while at the same time asking the Commission to present a new delegated act which takes account of the above risks. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Regulatory Technical Standards laid before the Parliament by the Commission include a provision that we have learnt will result in misleading information about future performance being published in investment prospectuses. The Parliament seeks to correct this by objecting to the delegated legislation but, because in doing so the Commission is called upon to act, we cannot vote in favour of either the oral amendment, or the resolution as a whole, nor can we vote against them because doing so would approve delegated legislation (and moreover that legislation would knowingly mislead investors). Accordingly, UKIP abstained.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion and in favour of the oral amendment. My colleague Matt Carthy is a member of the PRIIPs negotiating team. The file is on Packaged Retail Insurance-based Investment Products and relates to level 2 regulatory technical standards (RTS) developed by the Commission to impose disclosure requirements on costs, risk and future performance scenarios on the banks and financial institutions that market these products to retail investors. While we want to see it implemented as quickly as possible there are problems with the RTS as they currently stand, particularly in relation to the calculation of future performance (the results are overly optimistic). In the interests of consumer protection we support the revision of the RTSs which will require an objection from Parliament. For practical reasons I supported the oral amendment, which ‘Calls on the Commission to consider a proposal postponing the application date of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 without changing any other provision of level 1 in order to ensure a smooth implementation of the requirements set out in the Regulation and the delegated regulation, and avoid the application of level 1 without RTS being in force in advance’.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, in which the Socialist Group played a key role. We will do everything we can to reach agreement on the rules for information for non-professional investors because such information is essential in the current environment. RTSs need to be modified so that issuers of investment products are forced to play cards on the table and finally recognize all the risks they take by selling to non-professional investors. The regulation is due to come into force on January 1, 2017.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
