text: Writing. \u2012 This vote concerns the development of the Commission's delegated regulation supplementing Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1286/2014 on basic information documents concerning packaged investment products for private investors and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP). Protecting private investors through better information on investment products has been one of the group's main objectives since the 2008 crisis. That is why I voted in favour of this regulation and as a group of Socialists and Democrats in the EP we have done everything possible to reach agreement on the rules for informing non-professional investors. The Regulation should enter into force on 1 January 2017, as planned with an improved content.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Regulation (EU) 1286/2014 requires the initiators of packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (a market worth EUR 10 trillion in Europe) to develop "key information documents" for these products. European supervisory authorities have been asked to develop technical regulatory standards on the presentation and content of key information documents. On 30 June 2016, the Commission presented a delegated act containing all the elements to be presented in the key information documents. As soon as it was published, the delegated act was the subject of fierce criticism from all players in the financial markets and investor associations. These new key information documents are accused of being opaque and misleading, especially in relation to the presentation of performance and their calculation. On the other hand, the formulas used on the wafer are not realistic enough and do not place enough emphasis on the risk of loss to the investor, and the presentation of costs is made on assumptions that are too favourable. I therefore voted in favour of the objection, which asks the Commission to represent new technical standards and to delay the entry into force of the regulation.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This matter was not the subject of a roll-call vote. In the interests of transparency and democracy, I would therefore like to confirm that I abstained on this resolution.  I could not vote against (because of the potential for misleading information) but neither could I vote in favour (because I oppose the principle of Commission action in this way).

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the proposal for a proposal for a period of 30 June 2016. The Commission Delegated Regulation supplementing the key information documents of packaged retail investment products and insurance-based investment products (PRIIPs) with regulatory technical standards relating to the submission, content, review and revision of key information documents and the conditions for fulfilling the requirement to submit such documents. It is essential that information on investment products provided to consumers is comparable in order to create a level playing field on the market, regardless of which financial intermediary allows or distributes them. Similarly, excluding credit risk from the calculation of the risk of insurance products by category would mislead investors. I agree with Parliament's objection to the Commission delegated regulation and call on the Commission to present a new delegated act that takes into account these concerns.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulatory Technical Standards laid before the Parliament by the Commission include a provision that we have learnt will result in misleading information about future performance being published in investment prospectuses. The Parliament seeks to correct this by objecting to the delegated legislation but, because in doing so the Commission is called upon to act, we cannot vote in favour of either the oral amendment, or the resolution as a whole, nor can we vote against them because doing so would approve delegated legislation (and moreover that legislation would knowingly mislead investors).  Accordingly UKIP abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. We have rejected the proposals for technical standards that the European Commission has submitted to us because it has not listened to this Parliament's requests. On the other hand, we want to reaffirm our commitment to retail investor protection. Indeed, the main concerns expressed by the European Parliament's negotiating team were that the key information document was not intended, in the first place, to inform investors to make an appropriate investment decision, but to help product initiators sell their products.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution which raises objections to the Commission's delegated regulation supplementing Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 on documents containing key information for pre-assembled retail investment and insurance products. PRIIPs constitute a market worth around EUR 10 000 billion, which is why the relevant legislation needs to be particularly adequate to highlight the risks associated with these products.  Unfortunately, the delegated act adopted by the Commission has many shortcomings in the definition of the methodology for calculating future return scenarios, not providing for the possibility for some PRIIPs, even in cases of negative scenario, to indicate to investors the possible losses of money.  In view of the inadequacy of the proposed measures, Parliament has therefore asked the Commission to propose new regulatory technical standards, which suppliers will have to meet in order to ensure greater transparency and clarity for investors.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to the Commission's delegated act, therefore delaying the entry into force of the new regulation on information that financial firms must make available to the consumer when selling insurance-based investment products. The reason is that the current proposal includes a risk forecasting system that has been identified by independent investigations as being too optimistic, that is, that tends to hide real risk from the consumer. This regulation is part of the Commission's policy of promoting the Capital Market Union as a means of financing for businesses and individuals, favouring the holding of all types of goods by favouring speculative markets.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. In view of the consequences of safe regulation for users of these funds, we agree to ask the Commission for an improvement in its proposal. We play a lot. These retail funds consolidate a market in which 10 billion euros move. Its users move basic own resources for their income and aspire mostly to generate from them income to meet basic needs such as education or mortgage payment, so eliminating the risk categorization calculation of insurance products is the safest way to mislead investors.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Regulation (EU) 1286/2014 (PRIIP Regulation) requires the initiators of packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP) (a market worth EUR 10 trillion in Europe) to develop "key information documents" (KID, key Information Documents) for these products before they are made available to retail investors. A delegated act, proposing technical regulatory standards (RTS) on the presentation and content of AEDPs, was presented by the Commission. These highly criticized standards leave a great deal of room for subjectivity. We voted in favour of the objection put forward by Pervenche Berès, asking the Commission to represent new technical standards and to delay the implementation of the regulation. It should be noted that this is the first time in the history of the European Union that the European Parliament has rejected technical standards of regulation (RTS).

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the objection is balanced and devoid of particular critical issues. I therefore intended to support him with my vote.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it contradicts the Commission's delegated act on packaged retail investment products and key information documents for insurance-based investment products. In Parliament's view, it is essential that information on investment products provided to consumers is comparable in order to create a level playing field on the market, regardless of which financial intermediary allows or distributes them. Meanwhile, excluding credit risk from the calculation of the risk of insurance products by category would mislead investors. The delegated act adopted by the Commission is flawed in forecasting future performance scenarios and therefore does not meet the requirement to provide accurate, correct, clear and non-misleading information in Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014, in particular because, in the case of some PRIIPs, even adverse scenarios, as well as information on products in which investments are regularly incurred during the minimum recommended period, does not indicate that investors may lose money.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Regulation (EU) 1286/2014 requires initiators of packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP) to develop key information documents for these products before they are made available to retail investors. European supervisory authorities have been asked to develop technical regulatory standards (RTS) on the presentation and content of these documents. The delegated act presented by the Commission in June 2016 containing all the elements to be presented in the key information documents was the subject of fierce criticism from all financial market players. These new key information documents are accused of being opaque and misleading, especially in relation to the presentation of performance and their calculation. Indeed, past performance is suppressed in favour of future performance scenarios built around 3 assumptions (unfavourable, moderate, favorable) that leave a lot of room for subjectivity. That is why I voted for the objection put forward by Pervenche Berès, which asks the Commission to represent new technical standards and to delay the implementation of the regulation.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important that consumer information on investment products is comparable in order to promote equal competitive conditions on the market, regardless of the type of financial intermediary that produces or markets them. The lack of detailed guidance in the delegated regulation on documents with essential information on structured and insurance-based individual investment products (PRIIP), which relate to the 'intelligibility alert', which gives rise to a serious risk of inconsistent application of this element, was identified. I believe that there is a risk that the rules laid down in the delegated regulation in its unaltered form will conflict with the spirit and purpose of the legislation, which is to provide individual investors with clear, comparable and intelligible information, which is why I voted in favour of the report, namely in favour of the European Commission presenting a new delegated act.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Commission Delegated Regulation of 30 June 2016 supplementing Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on documents with essential information on structured and insurance-based individual investment products (PRIIPs) contains flaws in the methodology for calculating future performance scenarios, such as the elimination of credit risk from the calculation of the risk category for insurance products that would mislead investors and result in their loss of money. The delegated act, in its form adopted by the Commission, cannot enter into force and the Commission is therefore invited to submit a new delegated act taking into account the abovementioned calculation methodology and the elimination of the risk that the rules laid down by the delegated regulation will conflict with the spirit and purpose of the legislation.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reading and discussion in plenary, I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Commission's delegated regulation of 30 June 2016 supplementing Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council as I believe that consumer information on investment products must be homogeneous and comparable, in order to achieve a level playing field in the market regardless of where they come from. There is no doubt that the credit risk element should be included in the calculation of categories, and indeed this is an essential element of the prospectus.  There is also an urgent need for a definition of the treatment of products that allow multiple options as well as the development of the methodology for calculating future performance scenarios, which must meet the requirement to provide information that is "accurate, correct, clear and not misleading". There is also a need for further standardisation of when comprehensibility reports are used.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion and in favour of the oral amendment. I am a member of the PRIIPs negotiating team. The file is on Packaged Retail Insurance-based Investment Products and relates to level 2 regulatory technical standards (RTS) developed by the Commission to impose disclosure requirements on costs, risk and future performance scenarios on the banks and financial institutions that market these products to retail investors. While we want to see it implemented as quickly as possible there are problems with the RTS as they currently stand, particularly in relation to the calculation of future performance (the results are overly optimistic). In the interests of consumer protection we support the revision of the RTSs which will require an objection from Parliament. For practical reasons I supported the oral amendment, which ‘Calls on the Commission to consider a proposal postponing the application date of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 without changing any other provision of level 1 in order to ensure a smooth implementation of the requirements set out in the Regulation and the delegated regulation, and avoid the application of level 1 without RTS being in force in advance’.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulatory Technical Standards laid before the Parliament by the Commission include a provision that we have learnt will result in misleading information about future performance being published in investment prospectuses. The Parliament seeks to correct this by objecting to the delegated legislation but, because in doing so the Commission is called upon to act, we cannot vote in favour of either the oral amendment, or the resolution as a whole, nor can we vote against them because doing so would approve delegated legislation (and moreover that legislation would knowingly mislead investors).  Accordingly UKIP abstained.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a parliamentary objection motion that seeks to reject the delegated act proposed by the Commission to implement the PRIIPS Regulation on retail and insurance investment products. The technical implementing rules drawn up by the Commission in the delegated act were strongly at odds with the objectives of the Regulation to put investors in a position to invest consciously on the basis of clear, correct and comprehensible information, ensuring maximum transparency and comparability between financial products. That is why I supported the motion to reject it with a vote in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and ask the Commission to consider a proposal to postpone the date of application of Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1286/2014 without changing any other provision of Level 1 in order to ensure the smooth implementation of the requirements set out in the Regulation and the Delegated Regulation, and to avoid the application of Level 1 without the regulatory technical standards (RTS) having entered into force in advance.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour because I believe that information on investment products must be clear and comparable in order to promote a level playing field in the single market and to ensure freedom and full awareness of consumer choices. In the light of what has happened in Italy with collective investment instruments (I am referring to the actual deception that has occurred against those who have purchased subordinated bonds from some credit institutions), it is clear that these need unambiguous legislation capable of making up for the existing shortcomings.  The objections raised in the resolution relate to shortcomings in the method of calculating future returns and to the elimination of credit risk in the calculation of the category of risk represented by the product, these are elements that can be misleading to the investor and must therefore be dispelled.  In accordance with the above, the Commission is required to issue a new delegated act clarifying the treatment of UCITS and obligations to provide accurate, clear and non-misleading information in line with the legislative purpose that led to the creation of the regulation.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution to object Commission Delegated Regulation supplementing Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 on key information documents for packaged retail and insurance based investment products (PRIIPs) and noted no objections.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulatory Technical Standards laid before the Parliament by the Commission include a provision that we have learnt will result in misleading information about future performance being published in investment prospectuses. The Parliament seeks to correct this by objecting to the delegated legislation but, because in doing so the Commission is called upon to act, we cannot vote in favour of either the oral amendment, or the resolution as a whole, nor can we vote against them because doing so would approve delegated legislation (and moreover that legislation would knowingly mislead investors).  Accordingly UKIP abstained.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the importance of consumer information on investment products, and the right to compare such products in order to promote a level playing field in the market, I agree with the rapporteur's objections to the Commission's delegated regulation.  This regulation should provide more accurate, correct, clear information that is easily understandable and not misleading about PRIIPs to retail investors.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – I agree that it is misleading to investors to remove credit risk from the calculation of risk categorisation of insurance products.  The lack of detailed guidance in the delegated regulation on the ‘comprehension alert’ creates a serious risk of inconsistent implementation of this element in the key information document across the single market.  To this effect I support the call to submit a new delegated act which takes account of the above concern.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it objects to the delegated act submitted by the Commission on the information requirements for insurance investments. The Commission's proposal includes serious deficiencies in the calculation of the risks to be indicated to retail investors before purchasing any of these financial products. That is why I share the shortcomings identified by the European Parliament to the Commission's delegated act and I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the Commission Delegated Regulation supplementing Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 on key information documents on retail collective investment products and insurance-based investment products (PRIIPs). I am motivated by my conviction that implementation should be better planned and that Member States should be given the opportunity to extend the implementation of the regulation by one year.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Regulation on key information documents for Packaged Retail and Insurance-based Investment Products (PRIIPs) introduces a key information document or a simple document giving key facts to investors in a clear, comparable and understandable manner, covering not only collective investment schemes but also other ‘packaged’ investment products offered by banks or insurance companies. The protection of retail investors through better information on investment products was one of S&D’s main aims following the 2008 crisis. I believe that retail investors need to be protected, which is why I voted in favour of this regulation for it to be put forward to the Council and governments of Member States.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulatory Technical Standards laid before the Parliament by the Commission include a provision that we have learnt will result in misleading information about future performance being published in investment prospectuses. The Parliament seeks to correct this by objecting to the delegated legislation but, because in doing so the Commission is called upon to act, we cannot vote in favour of either the oral amendment, or the resolution as a whole, nor can we vote against them because doing so would approve delegated legislation (and moreover that legislation would knowingly mislead investors).  Accordingly UKIP abstained.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Regulation (EU) 1286/2014 requires initiators of packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP) (a market worth EUR 10 trillion in Europe) to develop "key information documents" (KID, for Key Information Documents) for these products before they are made available to retail investors. The question now is to regulate the technical standards of AEDPs. To do this, the European Commission has presented a delegated act on the elements to be presented in the AEDs from 1 January 2017. The AEPs as presented, however, are opaque and misleading. We therefore call on the Commission to represent new technical standards and to delay the implementation of the regulation. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection to the delegated act because I agree that this RTS is not yet ready. There's still a lot to improve on. Not only do we need a more precise wording, but also the industry is not ready yet and we should not introduce standards at the legislative level while the industry is not yet able to get it on board. There are still too many challenges that either need clarification or additional action and attention. These concerns were communicated to the Commission but were not taken into account before the adoption of the delegated act. Therefore, I voted in favour of the opposition and postponed the introduction of RTS.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament is right to call for the postponement of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 in order to ensure the smooth implementation of the requirements set out in the Regulation and the Delegated Regulation and to avoid the application of Level 1 without the regulatory technical standards (RTS) enter into force in advance. The lack of detailed guidance under the delegated regulation on 'understanding warning' poses a serious risk of inconsistent application of this element to the key information document in the single market.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report requires that the regulation better protect investors from packaged investment product sellers. So I'm in favour of it. I'm voting for.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. It is essential that consumer information on investment products is comparable in order to promote a level playing field on the market, regardless of the type of financial intermediary that designs or markets them. The very treatment of products offering multiple options still needs to be clarified. The lack of detailed guidance in the delegated regulation on the 'comprehension warning' creates a serious risk of inconsistent application of this element in the key information document throughout the single market. I therefore have some doubts about the regulation produced.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: in this way, we therefore support the objection put forward by Pervenche Berès, which asks the Commission to represent new technical standards and to delay the implementation of the regulation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The retail investment product and insurance-based investment product packages, or PRIIP, include a wide range of investment products that are marketed among non-professional investors (investment funds, life insurance policies with an investment element, structured products and structured deposits). The European Commission's proposal to impose more regulations on the PRIIP sector emerged, even late, as a response to the financial crisis. The suggested reforms are designed to protect retail investors in the financial sector selling inappropriate, high-risk products without providing appropriate information in advance. The Key Information Document (DIF) is a standardized information document that should inform potential investors about potential risks, costs and scenarios of the future performance of associated products. The objection stems from the fact that the delegated act adopted by the European Commission contains errors in the method of calculating future performance scenarios. In particular, it does not show, for some retail investment product packages and insurance-based investment products, that investors may lose money. Furthermore, there is a lack of detailed guidance in the delegated regulation on the 'comprehension warning'. We voted in favour of the objection.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of implementing regulatory technical standards for key information on retail investment and insurance products, because I believe it is essential that consumer information on investment products is comparable in order to promote a level playing field in the market, regardless of what type of financial intermediary produces or markets them.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 My vote is in favour as the European Parliament is right to call for the postponement of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 in order to ensure the smooth implementation of the requirements set out in the Regulation and the Delegated Regulation and to avoid the application of Level 1 without the regulatory technical standards (RTS) having entered into force in advance. The lack of detailed guidance under the delegated regulation on 'understanding warning' poses a serious risk of inconsistent application of this element to the key information document in the single market.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Regulation on key information documents for Packaged Retail and Insurance-based Investment Products (PRIIPs) introduces a key information document or KID (a simple document giving key facts to investors in a clear, comparable and understandable manner) covering not only collective investment schemes but also other ‘packaged’ investment products offered by banks or insurance companies. I consider that revision and improvement of the delegated act is necessary. I support a stronger wording on better information on performance scenarios, in order to avoid misleading the retail investor with over-optimistic scenarios, and the need for a detailed comprehension alert addressed to the investor regarding very risky products.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution bearing in mind that it is essential that the information on investment products provided to consumers be comparable, in order to promote a level playing field on the market regardless of the type of financial intermediary produced or marketed by those products. Therefore, from the European Parliament we must ask the Commission to present a new delegated act which takes into account the reservations mentioned by Parliament.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of objecting to a delegated act relating to documents containing key information for pre-assembled retail investment and insurance products, Proposed by the Commission in the context of the implementation of the directive and PRIIP, since I am in favour of a high standardisation and simplification of consumer information on investment products are comparable in order to promote a level playing field in the market regardless of what type of financial intermediary produces or markets them. It would be misleading for investors to remove credit risk from the calculation of the categorisation of insurance product risk. The delegated act adopted by the Commission contains gaps in the methodology for calculating future performance scenarios and does not ensure that the information is 'accurate, correct, clear and not misleading'. The lack of detailed guidance in the Delegated Regulation on 'Comprehensibility Reports' creates a serious risk of inconsistency in the application of this element in the document containing key information across the market.  The implementation of the regulation is fundamental and requires the utmost attention and adherence to the regulation. I therefore fully agree with the proposal made by the rapporteur, Mrs Berès, to postpone the application of the regulation for a year without making any further changes to the provisions contained in the regulation.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's Delegated Regulation supplementing Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 on Key Information Sheets for Packaged Investment Products for Retail Investors and Insurance Investment Products (PRIIP). It is clear to me that financial market crises are also prevented by providing consumers with fair and comprehensible information. Both transparency and legibility are guaranteed by the new proposal of the PRIIP Regulation. Also for the benefit of families.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I very much welcome the proposed increased transparency of investment products and insurance products (PRIIP). In order to provide retail investors with clear, comparable, comprehensible and irreverent information on PRIIPs, the uneven implementation of PRIIPs should be eliminated throughout Europe.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to the Commission's delegated act, therefore delaying the entry into force of the new regulation on information that financial firms must make available to the consumer when selling insurance-based investment products. The reason is that the current proposal includes a risk forecasting system that has been identified by independent investigations as being too optimistic, that is, that tends to hide real risk from the consumer. This regulation is part of the Commission's policy of promoting the Capital Market Union as a means of financing for businesses and individuals, favouring the holding of all types of goods by favouring speculative markets.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I believe it is important that the information provided to consumers on investment products is comparable in order to ensure equal competitive conditions on the market. It is also important that investors also benefit from information that is 'correct, clear and not misleading', in particular as regards the transparency of risk details for products that periodically cause losses during the recommended minimum holding period.  The establishment of regulatory technical standards on how essential information documents are presented or how they are reviewed and amended, as well as the conditions for their provision, is essential for the establishment of detailed guidelines and for the consistent application of this element in the key information document, in particular in the context of the single market.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report rejects the Commission Regulation because consumer information is essential as the removal of credit risk from the calculation of the risk categorization of insurance products would be misleading to investors and the treatment of multi-choice products still needs clarification, in particular in relation to the explicit exemption of funds. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that calls on the Commission to consider a proposal postponing the application date of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 to ensure a smooth implementation of its requirements and an objection to the Commission’s delegated regulation. This delegated regulation lacks detailed guidance, and if left unchanged there is a risk that the rules set out in the delegated regulation stand to go against the spirit and aim of the legislation, which is to provide clear, comparable, understandable and non-misleading information on PRIIPs to retail investors.  The Commission now needs to submit a new delegated act which will take into account this concern as well as others. One other particularly important concern is that they must ensure that consumer information on investment products is comparable. This is necessary to promote a level playing field in the market, no matter what type of financial intermediary manufactures or markets them.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the objection to the Commission Delegated Regulation because it failed to match what was contained in the primary regulation.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulatory Technical Standards laid before the Parliament by the Commission include a provision that we have learnt will result in misleading information about future performance being published in investment prospectuses. The Parliament seeks to correct this by objecting to the delegated legislation but, because in doing so the Commission is called upon to act, we cannot vote in favour of either the oral amendment, or the resolution as a whole, nor can we vote against them because doing so would approve delegated legislation (and moreover that legislation would knowingly mislead investors).  Accordingly UKIP abstained.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that better information on investment products can really help retail investors and avoid another financial crisis. The Regulation on key information documents for Packaged Retail and Insurance-based Investment Products (PRIIPs) introduced a key information document or KID which is a simple document giving key facts to investors in a clear, comparable and understandable manner, covering not only collective investment schemes but also other investment products offered by banks or insurance companies. In the current environment, I believe that we should do everything possible to reach an agreement on rules for the information of non-professional investors. I believe in openness and transparency. The regulation should enter into force with an improved content on 1 January 2017 as it was planned.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for The European Parliament's Resolution on the Commission Delegated Regulation of 30 June 2016 on the amendment of Regulation (EU) No 30/2017. 1286/2014 Of parliament and the Council on key information documents for packaged investment products for retail investors and investment insurance products by setting regulatory technical standards concerning the presentation, content, review and revision of key information documents and the conditions for meeting the requirements for the submission of those documents, as this raises objections to the Delegated Commission Regulation, and requires it to submit a new delegated act.  I believe that it is necessary to promote equality of conditions on the market to a greater extent and that it is necessary to clarify how products with multiple options are treated. In addition, the delegated act proposed by the Commission contains some shortcomings concerning the methodology for calculating performance situations for the future, and furthermore, some requirements of Regulation (EU) No 1000/2013 have been met. 1286/2014.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I supported the objection of Pervenche Berès, which asks the Commission to represent new technical standards and to delay the implementation of the regulation.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Regulatory Technical Standards laid before the Parliament by the Commission include a provision that we have learnt will result in misleading information about future performance being published in investment prospectuses. The Parliament seeks to correct this by objecting to the delegated legislation but, because in doing so the Commission is called upon, to act we cannot vote in favour of either the oral amendment, or the resolution as a whole, nor can we vote against them because doing so would approve delegated legislation (and moreover that legislation would knowingly mislead investors).  Accordingly UKIP abstained.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Pervenche Berès' report objecting to the European Commission's draft technical measures about the information that a retail investor will be able to use to compare certain financial products. The aim of the measures in this area should be to improve the information to savers about their life insurance accounts. This rejection must lead to a new commission proposal which will, I hope, better protect consumers. I believe that a transparent system is fundamental to a healthy and efficient economy, which is why I welcome Parliament's vote.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation proposed by the Commission, which does not meet the management needs of insurance companies, should be reviewed. In particular in Level 3. We expect an improved proposal from the Commission and the relevant regulatory authority. Until then, it is necessary to suspend the implementation of the proposal, and to wait until a proposal is presented related to the real needs and characteristics of the insurance companies industry.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution. In my opinion, credit risk must be taken into account in the valuation of PRIIP, otherwise it will encourage speculation that has already brought the European economy close to collapse.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the Commission's delegated regulation supplementing the regulation on documents containing key information for pre-assembled retail investment and insurance products. The delegated act previously adopted by the Commission contains gaps in the calculation of performance and therefore does not provide accurate and correct information, as required by legislation. The proposal raises objections to the regulation delegated to the Commission and calls for the submission of a new delegated act that respects the current rules.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this very technical resolution because it has the merit of blocking some of the Commission's unfortunate initiatives.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Commission's Delegated Regulation (EU) 1286/2014 on key information documents relating to packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP). The regulation obliges the initiators of these products, which represent a market of 10 trillion euros in Europe, to develop "key information documents" (KID) before they are made available to retail investors. European supervisory authorities have been asked to develop technical regulatory standards (RTS) on the presentation and content of ADPs. The Commission therefore presented a delegated act containing all the elements to be presented. The delegated act was the subject of fierce criticism from all players in the financial markets and investor associations. In particular, these AEPs are accused of being opaque and misleading, especially in relation to the presentation of performance and their calculation. Indeed, past performance is suppressed in favour of future performance scenarios built around 3 assumptions (unfavourable, moderate, favorable) that leave a lot of room for subjectivity and that do not integrate past crises.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Objection to the technical standards presented by the Commission under the PRIIP regulation on KID made available to retail investors for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP). These standards remove references to past product performance in favour of subjective future performance forecasts. Moreover, the formulas used on the wafer are not pessimistic enough and do not place enough emphasis on the risk of loss to the investor. So I voted for this resolution.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it objects to the delegated act submitted by the Commission on the information requirements for insurance investments. The Commission's proposal includes serious deficiencies in the calculation of the risks to be indicated to retail investors before purchasing any of these financial products. That is why I share the shortcomings identified by the European Parliament to the Commission's delegated act and I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I agree with the commission's call for the regulation to be delayed on 'key information disclosure', which I consider to be confusing and harmful. Forcing investors to publish " key contract information" in addition to their own contracts and advertising leaflets is in itself questionable. Key information can never replace a contract, and mandatory disclosure can discourage customers with faith in the effectiveness of regulation from reading the contract itself. I am in support of any delay in the effectiveness of this harmful regulation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Information on investment products intended for consumers must be comparable to promote a level playing field on the market, and eliminating credit risk from the calculation of the categorisation of investor insurance products can be misleading.  It is necessary to clarify how products with multiple options are treated, in particular as regards the explicit exemption granted to UCITS funds under Regulation (EU) No 1000/2013. 1286/2014. In the Delegated Act adopted by the Commission, there are weaknesses in the methodology for calculating performance scenarios for the future and therefore the requirement of Regulation (EU) No 100/2014 has not been met. 1286/2014 The delegated regulation does not contain detailed guidance on the alert of understanding, which poses a serious risk of inconsistent application of this element in key information documents throughout the single market. If the rules laid down in the Delegated Regulation remain unchanged, they will not provide clear, comparable and understandable information on PRIIPs, so I supported this report.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution. This text is an objection to the technical standards presented by the Commission under the PRIIP regulation on KID made available to retail investors for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP). These standards remove references to past product performance in favour of subjective future performance forecasts. Moreover, the formulas used on the wafer do not place enough emphasis on the risk of loss to the investor, which we find harmful.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution improves investor protection for retail investors by taking into account credit risk in the calculation of the classification of the risk of insurance products. I am in favour of that.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP's report because it is essential that information on investment products provided to consumers is comparable in order to create a level playing field on the market, regardless of which financial intermediary allows or distributes them.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Objection to the technical standards presented by the Commission under the PRIIP regulation on KID made available to retail investors for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP). These standards remove references to past product performance in favour of subjective future performance forecasts. Moreover, the formulas used on the wafer are not pessimistic enough and do not place enough emphasis on the risk of loss to the investor. So I voted for this resolution.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. It is essential that consumer information on investment products is comparable in order to promote a level playing field on the market, regardless of the type of financial intermediary that designs or markets them. The delegated act adopted by the Commission contains errors in the method of calculating future performance scenarios and, therefore does not meet the requirement, provided for in Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014, to provide information that is 'accurate, correct, clear and does not mislead' and, in particular, does not show, for some PRIIP, even in an unfavorable scenario, and even for products that have caused losses regularly during the recommended minimum detention period, that investors may lose money. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution that rejects the delegated regulation as Parliament’s position on this matter was not taken into consideration when the Commission drafted the delegated regulation in question.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Retail investors who wish to make an investment are offered a wide range of packaged retail and insurance-based investment products. The information currently provided to retail investors on these products is not coordinated. As a result, retail investors have frequently made investments without understanding the risks and associated costs, and in some cases have suffered unanticipated losses. In view of these elements, Regulation (EU) 1286/2014 was established and becomes applicable from 31 December 2016. Nevertheless, the delegated act adopted by the Commission still lacks the elements that would provide optimal information to consumers of investment products. That is why we are asking the Commission to submit a new delegated act that takes into account the new concerns of the European Parliament.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls for an agreement to be reached on rules for information for non-professional investors, because such information is critical in the current environment. The regulatory technical standards should be changed so that issuers of investment products are obliged to show their cards and indicate all the risks they sell to non-professional investors. The regulation should enter into force 1 January 2017, as planned, with improved content.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 30 June 2016, the Commission adopted delegated Regulation C(2016)03999 on this subject. The report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs raises a number of concerns about this delegated regulation. According to the report, these run the risk that the rules laid down in the Delegated Regulation go against the spirit and purpose of the legislation, which states that clear, comparable, understandable and non-misleading information on PACKAGE RETAIL investment products or insurance-based investment products should be provided to retail investors. The report therefore recommends that Parliament raise objections to the Commission Delegated Regulation, thereby preventing its entry into force, and to ask the Commission to submit a new delegated act that takes account of those concerns. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Regulation (EU) 1286/2014 (PRIIP Regulation) requires the initiators of packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP) (a market worth EUR 10 trillion in Europe) to develop "key information documents" (KID, key Information Documents) for these products before they are made available to retail investors. This objection, voted unanimously in committee, accuses these new AERs of being opaque and misleading, especially in relation to the presentation of performance and their calculation. Indeed, past performance is suppressed in favour of future performance scenarios built around 3 assumptions (unfavourable, moderate, favorable) that leave a lot of room for subjectivity and that do not integrate past crises. However, the presence of past statistics is the only way to highlight likely losses and gains, and this in an objective way. We therefore support the objection put forward by Pervenche Berès, which asks the Commission to represent new technical standards and to delay the implementation of the regulation.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This objection seems to me to be justified: the delegated act presented by the Commission has been the subject of quite justified criticism. So I'm voting for this report.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the text that complements the regulation on key information documents on packaged retail and insurance-based investment products. This text, which aimed in particular at improving the information of savers, missed its objectives and even introduced a more complicated regime. So I voted against it.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution regarding key information documents for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the motion and in favour of the oral amendment. My colleague Matt Carthy is a member of the PRIIPs negotiating team. The file is on Packaged Retail Insurance-based Investment Products and relates to level 2 regulatory technical standards (RTS) developed by the Commission to impose disclosure requirements on costs, risk and future performance scenarios on the banks and financial institutions that market these products to retail investors. While we want to see it implemented as quickly as possible, there are problems with the RTS as they currently stand, particularly in relation to the calculation of future performance (the results are overly optimistic). In the interests of consumer protection we support the revision of the RTSs which will require an objection from the Parliament. For practical reasons I supported the oral amendment, which ‘Calls on the Commission to consider a proposal postponing the application date of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 without changing any other provision of level 1 in order to ensure a smooth implementation of the requirements set out in the Regulation and the delegated regulation, and avoid the application of level 1 without RTS being in force in advance’.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report improves investor protection for retail investors by taking into account credit risk in the calculation of the classification of the risk of insurance products. I would also have voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the postponement of the entry into force of the Regulation. The legislation runs counter to the original objectives of facilitating the more transparent use of investment products for EU citizens and therefore needs to be further supplemented.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulatory Technical Standards laid before the Parliament by the Commission include a provision that we have learnt will result in misleading information about future performance being published in investment prospectuses. The Parliament seeks to correct this by objecting to the delegated legislation but, because in doing so the Commission is called upon to act, we cannot vote in favour of either the oral amendment, or the resolution as a whole, nor can we vote against them because doing so would approve delegated legislation (and moreover that legislation would knowingly mislead investors).  Accordingly UKIP abstained.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur and thank you all because this vote is the right example of what good European policy should be in defence of citizens and their rights. We must all fight and reiterate in every appropriate forum that information, especially on investment, must be complete, simple and direct.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's objection to the Commission's Delegated Regulation on key information documents for packaged investment products for retail investors and investment insurance products (PRIIPs) by setting regulatory technical standards regarding the presentation, content, review and review of key information documents and the conditions for meeting the requests for the submission of those documents.  The delegated regulation is against the spirit and objective of the Regulation on providing information that requires it to be accurate, correct, clear and not misleading investors. Providing clear, comparable and understandable information on PRIIPs is particularly important for retail investors, and eliminating, for example, credit risk from the calculation of the risk categorisation of insurance products could mislead them.  There are also weaknesses in the methodology for calculating performance scenarios for the future. In the Delegated Regulation, the proposed method will not indicate to investors that they may lose money for some PRIIPs, even in the case of adverse scenarios and products that, as a rule, have already led to losses during the recommended minimum holding period. I support the objection and ask the Commission to submit a proposal that will protect the interest of EU citizens.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Regulation (EU) 1286/2014 (PRIIP Regulation) requires the initiators of packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP) (a market worth EUR 10 trillion in Europe) to develop "key information documents" (KID, key Information Documents) for these products before they are made available to retail investors. These new AERs are accused of being opaque and misleading, especially in relation to the presentation of performance and their calculation. Indeed, past performance is suppressed in favour of future performance scenarios built around 3 assumptions (unfavourable, moderate, favorable) that leave a lot of room for subjectivity and that do not integrate past crises. However, the presence of past statistics is the only way to highlight likely losses and gains, and this in an objective way. On the other hand, the formulas used on the wafer are not pessimistic enough and do not place enough emphasis on the risk of loss to the investor, and the presentation of costs is made on assumptions that are too favourable. I therefore support the objection put forward by Pervenche Berès, which asks the Commission to represent new technical standards and to delay the implementation of the regulation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the European Commission's Delegate Regulation complementing Regulation (EU) 1286/2014 on key information documents relating to detail-based and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP). The purpose of this text is to improve information for savers, particularly with regard to the costs of account units in life insurance systems.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, in the course of their activity, retail investors are increasingly faced with the offer of a wide range of retail investment product packages and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP). Some of these products offer specific investment solutions, adapted to the needs of retail investors, and often combined with insurance contractualization, so they can be highly complex and therefore difficult to understand. In addition, priip information is often provided to retail investors in an uncoordinated manner. Consequently, retail investors often make investments without understanding the risks and costs associated with them, sometimes suffering unforeseen losses.  It is necessary that consumer information on investment products be comparable in order to promote fair competition. The document in this regard is precisely in that sense. Therefore, with the aim of strengthening the protection of retail investors and increasing their confidence in PRIIP, I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulatory Technical Standards laid before the Parliament by the Commission include a provision that we have learnt will result in misleading information about future performance being published in investment prospectuses. The Parliament seeks to correct this by objecting to the delegated legislation but, because in doing so the Commission is called upon to act we cannot vote in favour of either the oral amendment, or the resolution as a whole, nor can we vote against them because doing so would approve delegated legislation (and moreover that legislation would knowingly mislead investors).  Accordingly UKIP abstained.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of considering that it is essential that consumer information on investment products is comparable in order to promote a level playing field on the market, regardless of the type of financial intermediary that designs or markets them. Whereas the fact that eliminating the credit risk of calculating the risk classification of insurance products could mislead investors, as the treatment of products offering multiple options still needs to be clarified, in particular as regards the explicit exemption granted to UCITS funds under Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the European Commission's draft technical measures detailing the pre-contract information that a retail investor can use to compare certain financial products. In my view, consumers cannot be misled by information about financial products. It is essential to ensure maximum consumer protection for these services. Like many of my colleagues, I ask the Commission to formulate a new delegated act and to delay the entry into force of the PRIIP regulation.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The single market's regulatory laws dictate that it is essential to provide consumers with the most complete and accurate information possible with regard to retail and insurance-based investment product packages, enabling adequate comparison and balanced competition on the market, regardless of the type of financial intermediary that develops or markets them. However, the delegated regulation adopted by the European Commission is not fully reliable as to the method of calculating the future performance scenarios of these products, casting doubt on the accuracy, correctness and clarity of the information provided by it. Thus, taking into account that the delegated regulation may contain indetailless and reliable guidelines which make the coherent application of the key information document consistent and take into account the fact that the rules laid down in the Regulation themselves may contradict the spirit and purpose of the legislation in this area - which seeks to make information on this type of investment products clearly available to small investors , strict and objective, I do not consider that the conditions for its implementation are in place, so I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which objects to the entry into force of the delegated regulation.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to the Commission's delegated act, therefore delaying the entry into force of the new regulation on information that financial firms must make available to the consumer when selling insurance-based investment products. The reason is that the current proposal includes a risk forecasting system that has been identified by independent investigations as being too optimistic, that is, that tends to hide real risk from the consumer. This regulation is part of the Commission's policy of promoting the Capital Market Union as a means of financing for businesses and individuals, favouring the holding of all types of goods by favouring speculative markets.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it objects to the delegated act submitted by the Commission on the information requirements for insurance investments. The Commission's proposal includes serious deficiencies in the calculation of the risks to be indicated to retail investors before purchasing any of these financial products. That is why I share the shortcomings identified by the European Parliament to the Commission's delegated act and I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing – I agree that the European Parliament objects to the Commission's delegated regulation. One reason is that, if a delegated act is left unchanged, there is a risk that the rules laid down in the Delegated Regulation will contradict the spirit and objective of the legislation, which is to provide clear, comparable, comprehensible and non-misleading information on PRIIP to retail investors.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the objection to the Commission Delegated Regulation because concerns remain that some important information will not be made available to ordinary investors. We need to reach an agreement with the Commission that will lay down rules on investor information in the current fragile financial environment. Regulatory technical standards should be adapted so that investment product intermediaries are obliged to play with open cards and do not conceal the risks arising from the sale to the investor. Furthermore, the European Parliament notes in its resolution that the delegated act adopted by the Commission contains errors in the methodology for calculating future performance scenarios and does not meet the requirement to provide information that is accurate, true, clear and not misleading. The risk also comes from the lack of detailed guidance on the application of certain elements of the document, and other parts could also lead to contradictory explanations. I am of the opinion that investment products should be as transparent as possible, since every investor has the right to know all the risks arising from their purchase. Therefore, the Commission should reconsider its proposal and clarify the points of contentious issues.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 When choosing financial products, the consumer must be able to compare services from different suppliers, which must be in such form and language as to be able to make an informed choice about the solution that is most advantageous to him.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I agree with the Proposal for a European Parliament Resolution on the Commission Delegated Regulation of 30 June 2016 amending Regulation (EU) No 30/2017. 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, as I think it needs further clarifications in order to be adopted. If this Delegated Regulation remains unchanged, there is a risk that small investors would be left without sufficient information and remain misguided.  The delegated regulation has "no warning of danger" and therefore poses a serious risk to many investors. The information must be made evenly available to all in order to provide consumers with a level playing field in the financial market.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution on the Commission's delegated regulation of 30 June 2016 supplementing Regulation (EU) No. 1286/2014 Of the European Parliament and of the Council on key information sheets for packaged retail investment products and insurance investment products (PRIIP) i have agreed to regulatory technical standards for the presentation, content, review and revision of key information sheets and the conditions for fulfilling the obligation to provide such documents (C(2016)03999 – 2016/2816 (DEA)). This rejects the Commission's proposal on key information sheets and refers it back to the Commission for follow-up. Like most of my colleagues, I consider the rules on key information sheets to be inadequate. In any case, I believe that such brief information cannot provide appropriate information on investment products. They should be abolished because they only lead to unnecessary corporate bureaucracy and do not provide the investor with any significant benefit that could not also be achieved through an adequate liability regime for false advice. The situation is regrettable for companies, which now have to live with a certain degree of legal uncertainty.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament considers that information on investment products intended for consumers must be comparable to promote a level playing field on the market. The Commission delegated regulation does not contain detailed guidance on 'understanding alert', so there is a risk of inconsistent application in key information documents in the single market.  Therefore, Parliament considers it necessary to further standardise when a 'comprehension warning' will be used. I support the objection to the Delegated Regulation of the Commission, as I believe that the rules laid down in the Delegated Regulation will be against the spirit and objective of the legislative act if they remain unchanged. The aim of the act is to provide clear, comparable and understandable information on PRIIPs that will not mislead retail investors.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on a Commission delegated regulation supplementing the Regulation (European Parliament and council on key information documents on packaged retail and insurance investment products (PRIIP) by laying down regulatory technical standards on the display, content, review and revision of key information documents and the conditions for meeting the requirement to transmit such documents.  Information on investment products should be comparable to consumers. This is the only way to promote a level playing field in the market, regardless of which types of financial intermediaries prepare or market them.  With this resolution, we oppose the Commission's delegated regulation and call on it to submit a new proposal.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament is right to call for the postponement of Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 in order to ensure the smooth implementation of the requirements set out in the Regulation and the Delegated Regulation and to avoid the application of Level 1 without the regulatory technical standards (RTS) enter into force in advance. The lack of detailed guidance under the delegated regulation on 'understanding warning' poses a serious risk of inconsistent application of this element to the key information document in the single market.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution objecting to Commission Delegated Regulation C(2016)3999. Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 November 2014 provided for the development of a draft regulatory technical standard on the basis of which a standardised document containing key information could be created to ensure greater transparency for retail investors with regard to RETAIL INVESTMENT PACKAGE products and insurance-based investment products. The aim was to provide retail investors with information on these products in an easy-to-read and comprehensible and comparable form.  However, the Commission Regulation, which is based on draft regulatory technical standards submitted by the EUROPEAN supervisory authorities, did not fully meet expectations. I therefore agree with the launch call on the Commission to submit a new delegated act that takes into account the concerns expressed thereon.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European citizens must be at the heart of the concerns of decision-makers at the level of the European institutions. This also applies to structured and insurance-based individual investment products (PRIIPs), where customer information is extremely important. Unfortunately, the regulatory level so far has not proved sufficient, not ensuring equal competitive conditions on the market, eliminating credit risk from the calculation of the risk category for insurance products, excluding products with multiple options and omitting performance scenarios. It is therefore necessary to further standardise this area in order to provide documents with essential information on these products. The Commission's proposal for a regulation concerns the presentation, content, revision of these documents, as well as the conditions for complying with the requirement to provide such documents. However, the proposal fails to resolve existing problems. In conclusion, the proposal for the European Parliament resolution is to postpone the date of application of the Regulation in order to ensure the smooth implementation of the requirements laid down in the Regulation and the entry into force of the regulatory technical standard. I support this resolution.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the 30.6.2016 Delegate Regulation complementing the European Parliament and Council (EU) Regulation on Key Information Documents on Packaged Retail and Insurance-Based Investment Products (PRIIP) by Technical Regulatory Standards for Presentation, the content, review and revision of key information documents and the conditions to be met in order to meet the obligation to provide these documents.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution objecting to the Commission Delegated Regulation on key information documents for packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIPs). This is because the delegated act as adopted by the Commission contained methodological flaws and therefore fails to provide clear, comparable, understandable and non-misleading information on PRIIPs to retail investors. In order for our internal market to function correctly, it is key that consumer information on investment products be comparable in order to promote a level playing field in the market, no matter what type of financial intermediary manufactures or markets them.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the objection to the adoption of the Commission Delegated Regulation on key information documents for packaged investment products for retail investors and investment insurance products (PRIIPs) by setting regulatory technical standards regarding the presentation, content, review and review of key information documents and the conditions for meeting the requirements for the submission of those documents. In my view, the adoption of this Delegated Commission Regulation should be postponed as it does not ensure legal certainty and a coherent approach. While the European Parliament's Economic and Monetary Policy Committee expressed a clear and reasoned view that the adoption of this Regulation should be postponed, it was not taken into account by the Commission. I therefore hope that the Commission will abandon the amendment of the regulation following the adoption of this complaint and the possible reaction of the Member States through the Council.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 Motion for a resolution on a Commission delegated regulation supplementing Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 18 December 2010 on the protection of the european I supported it because I believe that information for consumers on investment products is comparable in order to promote a level playing field in the market, regardless of which types of financial intermediaries they prepare or market.  Without these changes, there is a risk that the rules in the delegated regulation will be contrary to the spirit and purpose of the legislation to provide clear, comparable, comprehensible and non-diliven information on retail PRIIPs.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to the Commission's delegated act, therefore delaying the entry into force of the new regulation on information that financial firms must make available to the consumer when selling insurance-based investment products. The reason is that the current proposal includes a risk forecasting system that has been identified by independent investigations as being too optimistic, that is, that tends to hide real risk from the consumer. This regulation is part of the Commission's policy of promoting the Capital Market Union as a means of financing for businesses and individuals, favouring the holding of all types of goods by favouring speculative markets.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The PRIIP Regulation requires initiators of retail packaged and insurance-based investment products to develop "key information documents" (KID) for these products before they are made available to retail investors. European supervisory authorities have been asked to develop technical regulatory standards (RTS) on the presentation and content of ADPs, including methods of calculating and presenting risks, remuneration and costs to be included. On 30 June 2016, the Commission presented a delegated act containing all the elements to be presented in the AEDs. As soon as it was published, the delegated act was the subject of fierce criticism from all players in the financial markets and investor associations. These new AERs are accused of being opaque and misleading, especially in relation to the presentation of performance and their calculation. I therefore supported the objection put forward by Pervenche Berès, which asks the Commission to represent new technical standards and to delay the implementation of the regulation.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to promote a level playing field in the market, it is essential that consumer information on investment products is comparable, regardless of the type of financial intermediary that produces or markets these products. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the objection to the Commission's delegated act, therefore delaying the entry into force of the new regulation on the information that financial undertakings must make available to the consumer when selling insurance-based investment products. The reason is that the current proposal includes a risk forecasting system that has been identified by independent investigations as being too optimistic, that is, that tends to hide real risk from the consumer. This regulation is part of the Commission's policy of promoting the Capital Market Union as a means of financing for businesses and individuals, favouring the holding of all types of goods by favouring speculative markets.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Voted in favour of the motion to reject a delegated act under the Packaged Retail and Insurance Based Investment (PRIIPs).

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Changes to the regulatory project on packaged retail investment products and insurance-based investment products need to be made. The technical regulatory standards that entities must meet need to provide maximum transparency and clarity to investors need to be better suited to consumer protection. That is why I thought it necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. This is a parliamentary objection motion that seeks to reject the delegated act proposed by the Commission to implement the PRIIPS regulation on retail and insurance investment products. The technical implementing rules drawn up by the Commission in the delegated act, under very strong pressure from the financial lobbies, were in fact found to be strongly contrary to the objectives of the regulation to put investors in a position to invest consciously on the basis of correct, clear, comprehensible and non-misleading information, ensuring maximum transparency and comparability between financial products.  Given that these technical standards are intended to regulate key elements of the KID, including probabilistic performance scenarios, risk indicators, cost-calculation methodology - this motion rightly calls on the Commission to postpone the date of application of the regulation and rewrite the delegated act from the beginning, taking full account of the objectives of the regulation and the concerns expressed by this Parliament. In the absence of these basic technical standards, in fact, the provisional application of the PRIIPS would risk seriously harming investors by providing them with incomplete and misleading information, thus playing into the hands of lobbies, and would, moreover, allow unelected technocrats to bypass the democratic will of legislators.  That is why I supported this motion with a vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I agreed to this resolution because we in Parliament object to this delegated regulation of the Commission. We ask the Commission to submit a new delegated act.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. What a disavowal! 602 votes to reject the Commission's draft regulation which imposed new technical standards and a new timetable on the financial sector marketing savings products to prepare standardised (and therefore supposedly neutral) key information documents for their customers for each proposed product. Beyond the fact that banks, funds and insurers did not have the time to develop such documents, the issue of their reliability and control of their content was completely unresolved. Leaving traders alone to judge both the risks and possible future performance of their products is to put customers in a situation of potential abuse. It is the meaning of my vote to recall it.
