name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We agree that it is extremely important for investors to have reliable and accurate information and a high degree of transparency. We refuse to completely distort the genesis of this crisis in the back of this notion of transparency.  Transparency helps and is welcome. But it is not believed that it was the lack of transparency that caused the financial crisis. The crisis was provoked by the greed of large institutional investors who had all the information they could, but who still did not want to give up their profits.  The problem was the speculative spiral that involved banking and other financial institutions, which knew they could risk because they knew and know today that they can always rely on governments and central banks to solve this problem. As much regulation as they may invent, there is nothing to erase today the need for public control of the financial system.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution maintains that consumer information on investment products must be comparable in order to promote a level playing field in the market. If credit risks were excluded from the calculation of the classification of the risk of insurance products, this would amount to misleading investors. As credit risks are therefore intended to be included in PRIIP's risk assessment, I voted in favour of the request.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission Delegated Regulation supplementing Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 on documents containing key information for pre-assembled retail investment and insurance products. This regulation was necessary following the 2007-2008 financial crisis. The Regulation obliges those who produce or sell investment products to provide investors with 'documents containing key information' on products. The goal is to help investors understand and compare the main characteristics and risks of such products.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Motion for a resolution on a Commission delegated regulation supplementing Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 on key information documents on packaged retail and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP) was supported. As the resolution states, it is essential that information to consumers on investment products is comparable in order to promote a level playing field in the market, regardless of which types of financial intermediaries prepare or market them. The delegated act adopted by the Commission contains errors in the methodology and there is therefore a serious risk that the implementation of this element in the key information document throughout the Single Market will be inconsistent.  I agree with the call for the Commission to submit a new delegated act.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, first I would like to apologise because I will not be able to be here for the whole debate. The reason is that I need to rush back home because we are finalising the preparations for the meeting in Bratislava. You added this point to the agenda on Monday, therefore I changed my schedule because it was important to present the position but I will not be able to stay here for the debate. News of the closures announced, most recently in Belgium and France, created anxiety and anger in the towns and regions concerned. The recent cases of Caterpillar and Alstom are a reflection of a more widespread phenomenon of mass redundancies across the EU as a result of the changing economic environment, with deep employment and social effects. The recent crisis in the steel and automotive industries, as well as the announced restructuring, show that serious reflection and action is needed in the Member States and at EU level. We need to decide whether we want to let our industrial know—how slip away elsewhere or whether we should take determined action to improve the framework conditions for our industries. Back in June 2013 the European Council recognised the vital importance of a strong European industrial base as an essential building block of the EU’s growth and competitiveness agenda. As you noted in your resolution of 2014, there are several aspects to consider, and I will touch upon them. Like Parliament, the Council has called for an ambitious and active industrial policy. This should include sectoral initiatives to be pursued by the Commission whenever the challenges to competitiveness and the need to maintain a strong industrial base require it. To ensure an active industrial policy, industrial competitiveness needs to be mainstreamed across all relevant policy areas. Infrastructures, including digital ones, must also be developed with a long—term view. Labour markets should enable growth, while safeguarding the social rights of workers. In the area of financing, progress has been made through recent instruments such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments. There is, however, still a need to remove obstacles to – and to promote – new debt and equity financing. The potential of increasingly strategic and targeted lending by the European Investment Bank to innovation and industrial transformation projects, notably in manufacturing and related services, could also be looked into. As local and regional decision makers are responsible for two-thirds of public investment in the EU, their interaction with business and industry is highly relevant. Regions can play a key role in supporting industrial modernisation. This can be done, inter alia, by combining regional policy and industrial policy tools. As recent events show, there is also a need for effective social dialogue involving governments and the social partners. At Union level there has been a growing recognition of the importance of involving the social partners at different levels. The Council has welcomed the steps taken by the Commission to involve the social partners in policies that may have a significant impact on the employment and social situation, but dialogue and policy also need to take into account the financial aspects. To this end the European Union has developed an instrument to support workers’ employability and mitigate the adverse social consequences of restructuring. The European Globalisation Fund (EGF) gives specific one-off support aiming to facilitate the reintegration of redundant workers suffering the shock of serious economic disruption. The EGF is, however, only a tool to manage such difficult situations once they arise. Together we need to engage in efforts to manage the adaptation of the current economic environment, achieving gains in competitiveness, whilst preserving quality employment. There are some excellent signs. Research and innovation are essential for the sustainable development of the European economy. It is in this context that the Presidency, in cooperation with the Commission, is inviting representatives from European and international research, innovation communities and the business sector to a major international conference on the re-industrialisation of the European Union. This event will take place in Bratislava on 26-28 October 2016 and will focus on the fields of nanotechnologies, advanced materials, manufacturing and production technologies, as well as biotechnology. Another key element is the digitalisation of industry, which has a cross-fertilising effect on all sectors. However, we are still lacking coherent development across Europe. The EU, Member States, regions and industry all have a role to play in fostering the digitalisation of business processes and in developing the industrial dimension of the digital agenda. Therefore the Council welcomes the recent Commission communication on digitising European industry. Finally, as the Commission has indicated in its new Skills Agenda, sustained investment in education and training and better alignment of skills and labour market needs are necessary as a way of contributing to employment, growth and competitiveness. These are the different aspects we need to work on if we want to re-industrialise Europe. Parliament and the Commission are working hard towards these goals and so is the Council. Re—industrialisation will be addressed by the Competitiveness Council on 29 September 2016, and I would remind you once again of the conference that we will be hosting in Bratislava. I invite you to attend. Once again I apologise that I have to leave but I am already very late.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the recent announcements by Caterpillar and Alstom about the envisaged closings of major industrial plants in Europe are a hard blow for the affected people and a severe setback for the regions concerned. I thank the European Parliament for organising this debate and for making the link with the vitally important issue of the future of the European industry and the need for industrial competitiveness.  In cases like these, the immediate priority of the Commission is to support those directly affected. It is absolutely necessary to quickly establish a perspective for the workers, their families, as well as the local economy. Europe does not stay on the side—line. We must work together at all political levels to help the workers who have lost their jobs and to assist the regions in overcoming this difficult economic and social situation. First and foremost, companies operating in Europe have the legal and moral responsibility to put social dialogue at the heart of the restructuring processes. Information and consultation of workers is a core feature of our European Social Model. It is absolutely clear that no company is allowed to escape this responsibility towards its workers. Secondly, where redundancies or closing a business are linked largely to developments at global level, we have a Solidarity Fund, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (Fonds Européen d’Ajustement à la Mondialisation), which can provide financial support for the workers and regions affected. EUR 3 million have already been granted in the past years to cover redundant workers from Caterpillar and some related companies in the region. Seeing the context, additional financial support from the European Globalisation Fund can be made available, upon request from the Member States concerned. Financial means from the EGF can be used to support, amongst others, the professional retraining of workers. In addition, the European Regional Fund and the European Social Fund can be put at the service of the conversion of the region and the affected workers.  To respond to the serious situation in Gosselies, we have set up a taskforce, a taskforce which will be an interface for the Belgian authorities with the Commission, and which will assist with any questions arising during the process ahead, for instance related to the legal framework or the use of European funds. While these measures all contribute to our short-term response, this Commission has from the beginning sent a strong signal on the necessity to preserve and improve the competitiveness of our industrial economy over the long term with the Investment Plan for Europe.  In July 2016, EUR 20.4 billion had already been invested in infrastructure projects, innovation and small- and medium-sized enterprises under the European Fund for Strategic Investment. This amount is expected to generate EUR 115 billion in investments. And, as announced this morning by President Juncker in his State of the Union address, the Commission will take this further by doubling the duration of the Fund, and doubling its financial capacity. This should lead to a total of at least EUR 500 billion of private investments by 2020. The Investment Plan also aims at removing barriers to investment and at creating simpler, better and more predictable regulation in the European Union. The industrial dimension is also incorporated into all other major Commission policies: the Single Market Strategy, the Circular Economy package, the Digital Single Market, the Energy Union, the Capital Markets Union, our Research and Development agenda, the Better Regulation agenda, the Trade for All Strategy and the New Skills Agenda for Europe. Indeed, in a fast-changing global economy, skills will, to a large extent, determine Europe’s competitiveness and the capacity to drive innovation. They also help mobilise and attract investment and they are a catalyst in the virtuous circle of job creation and growth. Our skills agenda is an agenda for all: young, old, in education, unemployed, in work or indeed in transition between jobs. Our industry is strong. Nevertheless, worldwide competition is increasing. So we must step up our efforts at all levels to ensure that Europe remains a competitive and attractive environment for manufacturing.

name: Françoise Grossetête
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, unfortunately, once again we are led to talk about this profound crisis of competitiveness and lack of investment for our industry in Europe. The closures of the two Caterpillar sites on one side and Alstom on the other are symptomatic of the industrial depression we are experiencing in Europe. There are more closures than industrial start-ups in Europe. This is an alarming signal and it is what causes and generates a lot of anxiety and anger. And yet, the authorities were aware of the difficult situation of these sites and unfortunately these authorities are panicking at the last minute, seeking a hasty rescue plan. The fundamental problem is the nagging lack of competitiveness of our companies and also the lack of willingness of some Member States to create the right environment. In reality, companies constantly need to restructure to adapt to change, but in order to grow, they must benefit from a favourable fiscal and social environment that is not paralyzed by one or the other.  In the case of Alstom, which I particularly deplore, it seems to me dangerous that a government would propose to another French company that is in debt trouble - SNCF - to place orders urgently. Artificial orders in the end, whereas for years there is not a real rail policy in France. In reality, what is missing in Europe is anticipation. We are constantly talking about industrial policy but who proposes real long-term industrial development strategies for our European companies? This is what is most lacking and, unfortunately, it is the employees who bear the brunt of the inaction of some governments in the face of structural reforms to be carried out and in the face of the social dumping that unfortunately exists in Europe. The closures of these sites are always difficult times for employees. That is why it is essential to accompany them, as you said, Commissioner, in the defence of their social rights. Above all what our European industry needs is stability, fiscal stability, legislative stability, it needs to feel encouraged by long-term strategies.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. Madam President, the announced closure of Caterpillar in Gosselies has plunged more than 6,000 workers into disarray, but also into misunderstanding. Caterpillar is not unique. Every week, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund receives files: Finland, Nokia/Microsoft, more than 8,000 redundancies; Sweden, Ericsson, more than 1,500 redundancies. The list is long, but what is unacceptable is not just a firm business, but how it closes and why it closes. Going back to Caterpillar, it's a group that's setting up its seats where it pays the least. Caterpillar is in Switzerland to avoid paying tax in Europe. Caterpillar is also a beneficiary company that chooses to pay its capital rather than invest in meaningful employment strategies. Caterpillar is also a decision-making centre outside Europe that neglects the role a company must have at the European level. Well, this model is a model that is found with many multinationals at the moment. Finally, Caterpillar is also a direct effect of European austerity, because less public works equals less investment in machinery, whereas it is said that green investment could bring jobs, and I think we should work in that direction. So what to do? First, Commissioner, as you said, we need to help the laid-off workers and the regions that are affected, and I know how willing you are. Second, we need to boost public investment. Third, we must guarantee taxation, where the production of wealth takes place. Fourth, we must fight against the financialization of our economy. Fifth, it is important not to give absolute rights to foreign investors. However, we here in this Parliament are ready to accept agreements with private investments and arbitration courses that would give absolute rights to foreign investors. We absolutely have to stop this mechanism.  Finally, we need to have impact studies on globalisation and not just impact studies on what it brings positive - it is true that there are positive effects - but also on the negative effects. If we defy the negative effects, we will not be able to prepare ourselves to adapt companies and adapt our structure and, therefore, we must be much more sincere about globalisation.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The first thought of an announcement like Caterpillar's always goes out to those involved. The ECR Group and my party, the N-VA, sympathize with the thousands of affected workers and subcontractors. For them, the intention to close is hard. There is a great deal of concern about globalisation. The correct answer is: well-thought-out policy. Some elements are crucial. We must not give in to protectionist tendencies. International competition is just creating more jobs, not fewer. We need job security to take precedence over job security. Continuous technological change requires a rapidly adaptable labour market in order to maintain and improve our prosperity and employment. We must not write anyone off prematurely for the labour market. In order to pay for an ageing population, the labour market position of older workers needs to change dramatically. We can expect the EU to support collective redundancies. But passing the bill to the taxpayer is not a sustainable solution. With a European transfer union, we will not solve unemployment. It is up to the Member States to make a full use of structural reforms that maxim enerti y to promote job creation and entrepreneurship. In my own Member State, Belgium, the federal and Flemish governments are already leading by example. (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. "I heard Mr. Stevens say that the N-VA, his party, stands in solidarity with the workers. The best way to show solidarity is as we did in Belgium a few years ago, when Ford Genk was restructured. There has been national solidarity in Belgium to ensure that workers have access to pre-pension. I note that the N-VA is no longer in favour of this method at all. Today, however, it could be a relief solution to the crisis and social cataclysm that is being experienced in Gosselies and throughout its region. Why does the N-VA object to access to pre-pension for workers who are victims of this restructuring?

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer. Thank you for your question, but you must listen very carefully to my speech. We are opposed to the depreciation of older workers, which is why we are opposed to the idea of early retirement because it does not offer a fundamental solution. We must ensure that older workers can be retrained in such a way that they can find a new job. That's our intention. A early retirement pension is not a solution in itself.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. On the morning of 2 September, Caterpillar announced the closure of its Gosselies site, Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. The announcement is stiff, the blow is brutal, the workers are sounded and the politicians shocked. More than 2,000 workers will be laid off by the company, double by subcontractors. Any business closure, as we know, is done in pain. But this one hurts particularly badly. First, there is the brutality if not the violence of a decision of a faceless capitalism; this decision has not been announced to the government of my country and the American leaders are absent subscribers, even when the Belgian Parliament asks them to come. There is also the injustice of fate. This closure hits a region tragically affected by industrial decline, which has a very high level of unemployment and an extremely worrying lack of attractiveness. Finally, it has been said, there is the budgetary constraint that arises from the Stability Pact and which weighs on the means of action of the Walloon and Brussels governments.  So what to do? First, require Caterpillar to comply scrupulously with all the provisions of the Renault procedure. This means, first of all, requiring credible justifications as to why a company, which makes a profit and has little debt, decides to close a successful site. Secondly, if the decision is confirmed, make every effort to ensure that workers receive fair compensation and a strong prospect of reclassification. You have understood the situation, Commissioner, by meeting with trade unions and politicians and by announcing from the outset the creation of a task force within the Commission's services and your willingness to mobilise all possible means to support efforts to reclassify workers. All of these initiatives need to be taken, but it is not enough. This morning I heard the President of the Commission reaffirm, in his State of the Union address, his desire to build a social Europe and a Europe that protects. I doubt that the workers of Caterpillar or Alstom are now convinced that Europe is protecting them.  I am well aware that we are living in times of great change as a result of globalization and the emergence of an economically multipolar world. And it is good, Commissioner, to have reminded Caterpillar management that social dialogue is part of Europe's DNA. But it would also be better to have, at European level, new instruments such as a strategic investment fund specifically industrial to consolidate or recreate a solid industrial base in Europe and it would be nice to have with the companies that invest in our countries a broader and more contractual code of conduct than the Renault procedure which actually only regulates closures. This is a real challenge for the Juncker Commission, since it intends to put investment and social at the heart of its policy.

name: Thomas Händel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Commission is setting out major objectives for the reindustrialisation of Europe – that is a good thing – but we are currently seeing the opposite: it is not only at Caterpillar that jobs are being destroyed in regions that are already suffering to the highest degree of unemployment. This is often done in companies that are not only profitable, but also in no case suffer from a lack of competitiveness. Of course, it is usually the pure profit interests of companies that destroy jobs. But it is the policy that could fall into the arm of companies with a forward-looking, long-term industrial policy, in this case in the construction sector and in public transport. The Alstom case is not an indication of a long-term employment-ensuring industrial policy, either nationally or European.  We are only reacting and sharing the worst consequences of job destruction with funds from the Globalisation Fund and thus from taxpayers' money. That is a good thing, but not enough. It is finally time to think about involving profitable companies in the social and economic damage caused by job destruction, and now.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Caterpillar, between 2009 and 2015, there was a 50% increase in the dividend per share and a 15% increase in job losses. These figures alone show that the cancer of financialization continues to eat away at the heart of our economy and that, despite the professions of faith following the financial crisis, maximizing short-term profit remains the alpha and omega of multinational policy, and the return of finance and the economy to the service of society, a wishful thinking. The case of Caterpillar is not isolated as industrial employment in Europe has increased from 20% to 15% of the labour force since 2000. And to hear Commissioner Malmstrom, who is a little obsessive about pushing the CETA and TTIP trade agreements, we can expect even more social disruption since she is asking you, Mrs Thyssen, for a strengthening of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, all of this, while the Europeans have set themselves the objective of increasing the share of industry in their GDP to 20%. And we are right because, whether it is energy, mobility, buildings, to take just these three examples, industry has a vital role to play in the transition of our economy to a low energy and resource economy. Europe, ladies and gentlemen, has every interest, for its own competitiveness, in leading this transition, in being a leader rather than a follower. Therefore, beyond the emotion aroused by the arbitrary closure of Caterpillar in Gosselies, we must finally learn from these serial restructurings and adopt the essential elements of an industrial policy. First, it involves the re-eding of finance. And there, a lot remains to be done. As long as the standard of profit is set by financial institutions too big to fail, then our economy will be fully enslaved to finance. Second, a shift in trade policy. We must put an end to these draft trade agreements tailored solely to the interests of shareholders and condition access to the European market on compliance with the social, environmental and fiscal standards of our Union. Third, industry must be put at the service of transition and transition at the service of industry. Indeed, we have ways to put our industry at the forefront of their transition. Let us give ourselves ambitious and binding energy efficiency and resource targets. Let's make the Juncker investment plan, instead of sprinkling a little money everywhere, focus on industry and the ecological transition. Finally, industrial employment is increasingly being replaced by machines. That in itself is not a bad thing, provided that the profits are distributed. In other words, we need to challenge our work organization model, which is to share work and income. This is the inevitable evolution of our societies if we do not want to leave millions of people on the side of the road.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Lamberts, I have listened to you with great interest. Before being Members of Parliament, there were a number of us, together with the presidents of the major public banks, calling for a genuine reinvestment plan using the central bank's monetary facilities, $1 trillion invested in sustainable development and the green economy. Why don't you take that idea again? On the other hand, should we not have European protectionism, at least for reciprocity in openness?

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear colleague, if I do not repeat all the ideas in my speeches, it is usually that in 2 minutes and 30 minutes, you cannot say everything. Now, what is clear is that the massive financing of the economy by the European Central Bank in recent years - and this is continuous financing, so-called quantitative easing - is again something that is dispersed in a totally indiscriminate way. We have been advocating for a very long time to green this quantitative easing, in other words to target investments not on speculation - it is clear that asset markets are exploding because liquidity is being injected into the system - but rather to direct, through the European Investment Bank and other public investment tools, this liquidity towards the investments necessary for the ecological transition of the economy. It makes sense and yet there is still no political will to put that in place. I hope that one day we will have a majority at national and European level to put these policies in place.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the case of Alstom's Belfortaine plant, which is still hoped to find a more favourable outcome than that of the Gandrange and Florange steel mills, is emblematic of the submission of our managers to the dictates of shareholders and pension funds. What a symbol this Belfort factory! Opened in 1879, it was from this factory that the first prototype of our high-speed train came out in 1971, our now famous TGV that the world envy us, a factory that employed up to 9,000 employees. Today, almost only in the tertiary sector is hired, while the dramatic destruction of industrial employment continues: last year, more than 33,000 jobs were lost in our French industries. Without absolve our national leaders of their responsibilities, it must be recognised that it is the European Union that imposes the financialisation of our economies on us, and which, in the name of supposedly free and undistorted competition, forbids us from any protectionism, even if it is European.  It is also the European Union which, claiming to fight monopolies, imposes the separation between network and transport activity in the rail sector. Now we are cutting our companies branch by branch, to better resell them to their competitors. The announcement of the closure of the Belfort plant is thus only the logical continuation of Alstom's skinning with the sale in 2014 of its energy division to the American General Electrics.  The challenge, beyond safeguarding our industrial jobs, is the maintenance of the skills and innovation poles that depend on production sites.  This is why it is imperative that the public authorities help industrial sites that operate temporarily under production, especially when it comes to national flagships. But our ministers still need to work on their files, rather than focusing on their career plans.  It is not surprising, then, that banker Macron did not see anything coming. In between photo shoots for the "people" press, the Minister of the Economy did not want to listen to the calls for help from Alstom's executives and employees. Macron had given his word: "Zero layoffs" and here are 2,000 jobs that are threatened, including nearly 500 in Belfort. Today, more than ever, our industry needs a strategic state that sets long-term goals and truly empowers itself to achieve them.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE).
text: Madam President, February 2013, restructuring of Caterpillar, 1,400 redundancies. Promise of management: a future for the company. Workers make concessions in terms of wages, in terms of flexibility. Result today, thanks: closure of the Gosselies site, dismissal of all staff, and this in defiance of employees, in defiance of social dialogue, in defiance of the political authorities of the country. Unfortunately, in the region, in Europe, this is not the first, nor the last business closure. But this one is nevertheless an example and I will repeat the words of Philippe Maystadt, the former president of the EIB: Caterpillar is the product of a totally deregulated capitalism. This closure requires several responses. In terms of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, we need to be able to move faster, we need to be able to integrate subcontractors who are doubly victims of this type of situation. We need an ambitious recovery plan in industrial terms and I would like to congratulate the Commission on this willingness to boost, to increase the resources of the Investment Fund. We need to find ways at European and national level to really build projects with a future in economic terms, promising projects as well as in terms of energy, mobility or digital. We must also stop being naïve and defend our industry. When China produces at costs defying all competition and well, our companies cannot resist. In international markets, all players must play by the same rules of the game. I take an example: we produce the most environmentally friendly machines at Caterpillar, but we buy Chinese machines that do not meet those standards. Finally, I welcome the Commissioner's willingness to set up a task force. This is important, but I also want the stability pack to be evaluated. To evaluate is also to learn from it. We need to defend our jobs, but we also need to build a forward-looking industrial development and economic development.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Madam President, I am pleased that our Parliament has been reactive in the situation at the Caterpillar industrial sites in Gosselies and Alstom in Belfort. With this debate, we show that this is not a Franco-Belgian debate, but a European issue, that of the establishment of a real European industrial policy. Two months ago, in this same House, we adopted a resolution calling on the Commission to further support the European rail industry and to use the full potential of European funds and the Juncker plan to support public orders. Five months ago, we voted on the techniques of the fourth rail package, strongly encouraged by industry manufacturers, including Alstom, because it allowed for the harmonisation of rules and products within the Union. The votes of the European Parliament must be heard by citizens, institutions and also by businesses. We have a huge challenge in protecting our industry from ever-increasing and sometimes unfair international competition. The Commission must set the rules and limit the entry into our market of foreign groups which benefit from massive subsidies and undermine our industry. But this debate also reflects the failure of a fiscal policy that constrains public investment. We need more flexibility if we want to be able to support our industry, that is a fundamental issue.  Finally, this debate, in essence, is also and above all that of the defence of women, men and entire families who find themselves directly affected. And if governments can act and act, industrial leaders must also take responsibility to take into account the human factor rather than always favouring the logic of profitability.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, just two weeks ago Caterpillar announced that more than 200 jobs will be lost in Northern Ireland from the plant in Monkstown in County Antrim. This announcement, sadly, has been the latest in a series of job losses over the past number of years. Last year we had Caterpillar again, Invista, Sensata, and Michelin, which all announced massive job losses, and in the course of 2014, JTI announced that it would be closing its facility in Ballymena, with 800 job losses.  I know from the situation in Northern Ireland that these are highly skilled and highly motivated workers. The jobs that we are talking about are of both direct and indirect benefit to the local economy, and the cumulative effect of all these redundancies is therefore  considerable. As we have heard, this month there are similar stories from other parts of Europe. At regional, national and European level I believe we need to identify and address the challenges facing the manufacturing sector and equip for the future, with a joined-up approach and a clear positive vision to make the most of future opportunities. That is why my party colleagues and I, and the business community, are calling for a specific manufacturing strategy in Northern Ireland. Unfortunately, our local executive does not appear to be listening.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – I was listening to our colleague Mr Nicholson before on this subject and I would like to ask him: how is it possible to realise re-industrialisation when we are dealing with so many free-trade agreements that offer so many advantages to other countries from the whole world. In the end, it is even cheaper to produce in those countries instead of producing inside the European Union?

name: James Nicholson (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I would like to thank my colleague for his question. He asked a very interesting question, and I understand that at this moment in time the Commissioner is preparing a response directly looking at all the different negotiations and trade deals that they are making. I have asked the Commission this particular point from the Agriculture Committee's point of view: how many deals can we do without totally destroying that which we are producing within the European context? I think the sooner we see that, what not only TTIP, CETA and all the other trade deals that are in the offing – Australia and New Zealand are out there at the moment. So there is many trade deals that are out there to happen, and that is a very worrying thing. But we need to know the effects. How much more can Europe absorb with these trade deals?

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE).
text: Madam President, of course, like all colleagues here, I hope that these two companies will find a positive outcome and, in particular, that Alstom can remain on the Belfort site with a sufficient backlog. We have to face it: for these two companies, there are responsibilities - at least for Alstom - widely shared. France has a great responsibility. For more than ten years, we have been hearing repeated promises in every way, without any coherence, without any vision, and from that point of view, there is a national responsibility. Europe also has a share of responsibility. We have been facing, for many many years, a total lack of economic, industrial and political management claimed on these issues. It's really time for that to change. It is time to act. We must show signs, show that Europe is finally determined to pursue an economic and industrial policy. We must act to avoid suffering. I suggest to you at least that we act in a few directions, a strong symbol that all Heads of State and Government finally advocate a change or addition to the ECB's mandate, that the ECB be in charge not only of growth issues, but also of the vital issue of full employment. This would be an extremely positive political signal. The Commission must realisation that it needs to rethink the rules of competition. The competition today is global. Yes, we will make great European champions and, really, the Commission must not prevent this kind of thing, as has been the case in the past. Thirdly, we need a real investment plan, a power 10 investment plan, which is focused on all sectors of the future and research and which is based on European savings and, why not, as Gérard Deprez said earlier, an industrial investment fund. Finally, we need to defend our business interests. We are no more idiotic or incompetent than the Americans. The U.S. Congress defends the economic interests of Americans. I expect the European institutions to defend the economic interests of europeans and, in particular, refuse to give China market economy status.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I do not believe that our debate should be approached by the social treatment of deindustrialisation, as I have heard, which is exactly the opposite of a European policy of re-industrialisation. We have to ask the right questions, for example, how can we accept That Cater—pillard is laying off at the moment, when its shareholders are going to get one billion four hundred million euros? How could Alstom not have a future, when passenger and freight transport would have to be developed, especially with the locomotives and trains of tomorrow that will be part of the environmental transition. So, as has been said, that the money from the Juncker plan, that the monetary creation of the Central Bank - 80 billion a month - that the European Investment Bank serve the investments of tomorrow for these two companies. Let the necessary funds be released to boost productive investment and employment, training at Cater-pillard, develop intra-European cooperation for railway companies, instead of competition. Why are we not inventing the equivalent of an Airbus from the rail industry? That we protect our operations and our jobs as do other countries, including the United States. Finally, let employees be given the floor and powers in the orientation and management of their companies.

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, it is still incredible that we meet regularly in this Chamber to deal with industrial issues.  Each time, the same observation is made: austerity has completely locked public order and the ability of states both to relocate the economy, to create jobs, to create infrastructure that is necessary for society, as well as for the economy. Each time, we have the same debate about the lack of a European industrial policy that is sorely lacking and about the need for a European industrial policy because there are national policies that are terribly flawed. Alstom in France is now the ball of hypocrites, between the management of Alstom, which deliberately creates scandal to guarantee the intervention of the state, and the state, which pretends to discover a situation.  In 2007, during the Grenelle of the environment in France, we agreed to increase rail freight from 14% to 25%. Rail freight in France has continued to decline. A few years ago, Mrs Royal, Minister of the Environment, killed the ecotax, the EUR 1 billion a year which also financed sustainable development infrastructure and tram infrastructure.  Basically, we are now in a situation where the issue is a European industrial policy, a major investment plan on the sustainable city with trams, a grand plan on rail freight which is an efficient and ecological transport, and then, to return the responsibility to the States. It is unbearable that we do not make more rail freight, it is unbearable that we do not go from road to rail, it is unbearable that we do not make trams in our cities, when they are no longer breathable.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Jadot, I am quite surprised because you are complaining about economic austerity, but you absolutely want to keep the euro single currency. There is a contradiction to me. Once again, the Caterpillar and Alstom cases prove the harmfulness of the Ultraliberal European economic model, which generates social desolation. The closure of the historic site of our industrial flagship Alstom in Belfort has aggravated the deindustrialization of France for twenty-five years. When Alstom was dismantled, following the sale of the energy division in 2014 to the American General Electric, the European politicians UMPS promised wonders for the future. Employees see the result today. With your inept rules of competition, you let our strategic companies be bought back by private foreign groups listed on the stock exchange. With the European Union, this is the great economic sell-off. For the weakening of states, you are committing economic crimes against citizens. Your only Euro-globalist logic is to serve large international investors at the expense of nations. Only a model of national economic patriotism with a long-term strategic vision, as proposed by the National Front in France, can re-industrialize France.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, it is important for me to mention the case of Alstom, whose 480 jobs are at risk in Belfort, in my constituency. The reasons for this social threat are numerous and, among them, the French government's questioning of a contract of 30 trains with the group. By feigning surprise, France shows a lack of vision, and the new promises, which many consider artificial, must in no way undress Peter to dress Paul and set up the sites of Belfort and Reichshoffen against each other. However, Alstom's difficulties are also symptomatic of a European industrial policy that is below expectations, far from the 20% of GDP target. Last June, the European Parliament voted on a resolution on the competitiveness of the railway industry. What's the case? Commissioner, will the Commission start a structured dialogue with the sector? The railway industry accounts for 400,000 jobs at European level. Unfortunately, our companies too often have to fight against highly subsidized, highly subsidized competitors and work in countries that impose binding localization rules. The European Commission must absolutely defend access to public procurement in its negotiations with China, Japan and the United States. If so, stop being naïve and better protect the European market with a reciprocity instrument for public procurement! We will support you. Let us not let the railway, Commissioner, sink like other industries. Finally, let us adopt an ambitious industrial policy.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, as you know, the closure of Caterpillar in Gosselies is more than 6,000 jobs sacrificed to fill the pockets of an American pension fund. This is obviously a brutal and scandalous act that strikes the heart of my region, as unfortunately too many regions in Europe. I really want to express my full support for the workers and their families. I would also like to underline their dignity in the ordeal, as well as that of the trade union organisations. We really would have liked to see the same attitude on the part of Caterpillar officials. Commissioner, this closure is obviously a symbol of everything that is wrong in Europe. I believe that Europe really needs to impose exemplary fines on companies that lay off for stock market reasons, even though they have received for years a whole series of public subsidies. These fines would help laid-off workers, they would also allow public authorities to requalify sites closed by blind capitalism.  It has been said that Europe must reinvest in an industrial policy based on research and innovation, but I reiterate once again the demand to immediately abandon austerity and invest in the real economy to create quality jobs. And, for God's sake, what are we waiting for? The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has already seen too many human tragedies linked to the decline of the industry. However, it will still have to intervene massively to help Caterpillar workers and their subcontractors. And given the scale of the tragedy and the number of workers on the tile in a region that is already being helped by Europe, via the Feder, I think that its co-financing should be increased to 80% to avoid annihilating all the efforts already undertaken. And finally, Europe has to go after tax havens hard because, for more than a decade, Caterpillar has been relocating its profits to Switzerland, all before throwing its workers away. So either, as a matter of urgency, Europe better protects its citizens, strengthens the social dimension and creates fiscal justice, or its future will be behind it, because the citizens will reject it massively and with good reason.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – (Sound missing at start) in home demolitions in Palestine. As MEP, however, I support the workers of the Monkstown plant in Newtownabbey, which had 250 jobs axed, and plants in Belfast and Larne are under threat.  Taking into account profits and shareholders’ dividends, one way of saving these jobs might be to spread production over different plants and limit shareholders’ dividend. So, will shareholders and millionaires receive a little less, or will well-performing industrial infrastructure be destroyed and thousands of families thrown into disarray?  Unfortunately, in a world that caters for greed and not need, greed triumphs. Whatever the concerns regarding the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, there will be no opportunity for my constituents to tap into it because the British Government has control over access to it and it has consistently denied the use of the Globalisation Fund for redundant workers in the North of Ireland.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her 6,000 workers – people, family fathers, family mothers – have been on the streets since Caterpillar closed these plants in Gosselies. Can this just leave us cold? No, it doesn't. Has this closure been fairly completed? No, it is not. And, dear managers, dear managers, dear caterpillar shareholders, you should be ashamed! Therefore, in the short term, we must help the workers concerned. This can be done very concretely through the activation of the European Globalisation Fund. But in the long term – and this is important – we must create a fair and effective framework in Europe in order to safeguard jobs and industrial sites in Europe. I therefore see three concrete approaches: firstly, the fight against this painful tax evasion. Caterpillar draws profits almost untaxed in Switzerland, worked and no longer invested in Belgium. In Europe, the tax is to be paid where the work is done. That is a simple principle; we just have to implement it, and I very much support the Commission, which has put this proposal on the table. Secondly, one question: is it wise that European accounting standards make it almost impossible for public investment in industrial parks, for example, to be made almost impossible? The answer, of course, is no, it kills investment. That is why I have a concrete idea: let us amend the so-called SEC standards so that states, regions, municipalities and cities do not have to write off investments for one year as is now required. After all, we also get jobs in Europe through public investment. Thirdly, how do we ensure that industry remains and grows in Europe? By creating innovative products. This is through investment in research and development. We need a lot of Silicon Valleys in Europe. Only at this level can we compete with low-wage countries. We must also create excellent education and qualifications. We achieve this through clusters of excellence between universities and industry, as in Aachen, and through dual training as a model for the whole of Europe. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which We owe a perspective to the workers in Gosselies and throughout Europe. In this sense: don't talk, but do!

name: Martina Werner (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Two years: 1879 and 1964. Locomotives have been built in Belfort for more than 130 years, and construction machinery has been coming from Grosselies for more than 50 years. Should these two plants actually be closed, European industrial history and know-how will be lost. For employees and their families, the company's decisions are also a real disaster. What is often forgotten in the discussion, however, is that these two individual cases are part of a trend. Between 2008 and 2014, three and a half million jobs were lost in Europe's manufacturing sector. France alone has seen a decline in industrial jobs of more than one million since the turn of the millennium. Aggressive and partly state-backed competition with Chinese and other manufacturers puts high pressure on industries such as the railway industry. In addition, there is the digitisation of manufacturing, which is certainly an opportunity for some, but also threatens industrial jobs elsewhere. Both also drive productivity expectations into the unattainable. The economy is forced to lag behind the market. It puts workers under pressure to perform that makes them sick, and yet we in Europe are gradually losing our industrial base. This has nothing to do with a social, reliable market economy.  The French Government has intervened in the case of Alstom , and that is a good thing. But Paris alone will not be able to change the basic problem. The ruinous game of ever-cheaper production does not stop any Member State alone. In order to change the rules of the game, we need a united European Union. We must clearly formulate our interests in industrial policy in an EU strategy and also defend them with strong trade defence instruments. This is the expectation I have of the EU Commission and the Member States, ladies and gentlemen. The industrial policy of the quiet hand must come to an end at the very latest now.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, commissioner, the negative effects of caterpillar and alstom's decisions will, above all, also have an impact in Italy, my country. It seems that the jobs called into question, on the outskirts of Milan, at an Alstom plant exceed 200. I therefore hope that the Italian Government will also be involved in the attempt to contribute to the resolution of this dispute, because the number of jobs is really enormous for my country too.  On the other hand, the question of the European Union's responsibility in general, with regard to the possibility of relaunching the manufacture of our continent, is absolutely the subject of our debate today. It is clear, as we know and have repeated many times: manufacturing, industry as such, is not one of those competences that we can call direct competences of the European Union, there are other areas in which action is normally taken, but many of these have indirect effects on the revival of manufacturing.  Let us not complain about job losses and then generate an energy policy that is totally contrary to the development of our industry. Let us not complain about the loss of jobs and then wink at China's recognition of market economy status. Let us not complain about the loss of jobs and then have a conception of public budgets in our Member States which is totally contrary to the possibility of a revival of investment by the Member States themselves and by those political actors who, in cooperation with the private parties, can be the breeding ground for a genuine revival of our economy and all the jobs associated with it.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we need to re-industrialise Europe because having a strong industry means having sustainable growth, and because industry is also linked to good wages, better social protection and more stable jobs. But, in order to re-industrialize Europe, the first thing we need to do is protect the industry we already have today. I am sick of meeting in my constituency, in Catalonia, with companies, with business committees, with trade unions, with representatives of workers undergoing restructurings, plant closures by merger processes, such as Alstom," we also have a plant, for having undergone very aggressive labor reform or for the greed to seek unlimited benefits. I know that Commissioner Thyssen shares this sensitivity, but we have to take letters on the issue, and what we need to do is put common rules that protect workers from the restructuring processes we can do and common rules for information and consultation of workers in companies.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think this is a very important discussion, because one of our challenges in making Europe competitive again is reindustrialisation, and our targets for 2020 and beyond are very sensible. Otherwise we will have what former Commissioner Tajani, now an MEP in my group, called an ‘industrial massacre,’ with large—scale carbon leakage and steel industries, etc. leaving Europe and going elsewhere. This is doubly damaging: number one, losing jobs in Europe, and number two, increasing rather than reducing CO2 emissions.  Certainly we have to have learned the lessons from what has happened, we have to look at what we are able to do in the future and, above all, we have to reindustrialise Europe and create a climate for it to happen, especially in relation to COP21 and its implementation. This is a huge opportunity for us: if we are implementing targets in relation to renewable energies, etc., then we can actually also do the fundamentals, the industrial aspects needing the resources here in the European Union.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we said this morning that Europe is at a crossroads. Europe chains crises, and crises chain Europe together. Nationalism and populism are increasing, and so does the discontent of citizens with the European Union. And this has to do with rising inequalities, the wage gap, the loss of rights and, of course, job losses. An industrial policy needs to be relaunched through the European Union as a whole. And if we do not, we will not meet the European Commission's objective of increasing the gross domestic weight of the industry from 15% to 20%. You have to go from words to deeds. We have to bet on new niches of employment and new opportunities. And, of course, we must avoid the social dumping and unfair competition that is also taking place within the States of the European Union themselves, as is the case, for example, with the steel industry. And for that it is necessary to set up a European fund to compensate energy-efficient industries, so that each Member State cannot do what it wants.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, competitiveness in Europe's global market cannot be detached from the need for reindustrialisation. Reindustrialisation is a solution for increasing jobs and ultimately increasing people's quality of life. That is why I propose, Commissioner, that you insist on policies of fair competition, trade defence, investment in research and innovation to increase competitiveness. We do not have to over-regulate, however, because the European Union has the most complicated legislation, and I am frightened by the TTIP agreement when I think about the difference in product standard. We need to simplify regulations and insist on the culture of voluntary compliance because otherwise we cannot develop the industry. And there's another problem that I've raised—a two-year time since I came here. I do not see any trade defence policy towards non-European products, new, against what has happened in the internal market with competition in – I will not nominate external markets – on the textile industry, on the car industry, on the steel industry. Basically, if we are to re-industrialise, we must put an end to this unfair competition and dumping.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, industry in Europe has been facing enormous problems, especially since the recent financial crisis. Hundreds of production plants have been closed in the Union in recent years and thousands of jobs have been lost. Caterpillar and Alstom units and employees have now been added to the list. It should be noted that in Greece, because of the Memorandum and the Troika, thousands of operations were closed, resulting in the creation of armies of unemployed people. We must also recognise that Caterpillar closed despite the fact that the company had met its target of a 36% reduction in production costs. Alstom's plant is due to close after a German company signed major contracts to supply French railways. These are the results of German Europe. A Europe of austerity, which until now, unfortunately, has been served with reverence by the Belgian and French Government. But reindustrialisation of Europe is not done by TTIR-style free trade agreements, by austerity, and by an economy subject to Berlin's orders.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Madam President, what kind of industrial policy do we even have? Do we really have an industrial model? Do we really have the strategy of reindustrialising Europe that we are talking about today? And what kind of industry do we even want? I think a lot of things were left out today. I didn't hear much, and I expected to hear it.  However, I will be concrete because when we react to Alstom, Caterpillar, it is ok, we need to react, we need to express solidarity with these citizens who will be afflicted, but let's think about what we will do tomorrow, the day after tomorrow, so that it is not too late for one industry that is almost destroyed in Europe, and is a great industry. Shipbuilding, which can collect a lot of what is produced in Europe, is installed in one ship and then it becomes a real European product. Let's not destroy shipbuilding. Concrete example, concrete possibility of industrialization or reindustrialization of Europe.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. –Thank you, Madam President. I welcome the debate we had today and I have taken note of your recommendations. I would like to stress once more that our immediate priority now is to support those directly affected. The European Union will continue to show solidarity with the workers and regions affected by major closures, and we are ready to offer our support through the European funds, the legal acquis and any other relevant policy instruments. I can announce that today the Commission has adopted a proposal to prolong the derogation for needs beyond 2017. This prolongation that is foreseen in the regulation on the Globalisation Fund in Article 6(2).  To support job creation we must keep improving the framework conditions for jobs, growth and investment. We do this via the European semester, recommending, clarifying and simplifying rules and regulations, ensuring that tax systems encourage, and not discourage, employment reducing the scale of undeclared work.  We must also act directly to help create jobs by deepening our internal market in all its dimensions. The crucial tool is the Investment Plan for Europe, which has the potential to bring investments back in line with historical trends. Structural reforms in the framework of the so-called third pillar of the investment plan will nurture the economic recovery and can provide further basis for sustainable growth.  There were some reactions on the Stability and Growth Pact. It should first be noted that the closure of the Caterpillar plant in Gosselies and the stability pact are of course two different things. The stability pact is critical to preserve sound public finances in the European Union and to stimulate sustainable economic growth. The rules of the pact should not therefore be holding back investments, as President Junker also said this morning in his ‘State of the Union’,  and here we see a common responsibility for Member States and for the European institutions. There was also something said on the European Parliament’s resolution on the competitiveness of the European rail supply industry. We are aware of this resolution. We know it. We are preparing a draft reply, and I can tell you that we are taking due note of Parliament’s resolution on the competitiveness of the rail supply industry. We welcome the emphasis on our common effort to maintain a thriving industry. There were a lot of remarks on the international trade agreement. I can tell you that Commissioner Malmström is a good negotiator; she is negotiating hard and she has already said that we will not have an agreement on everything. Her aim, and the aim of this agreement must, of course, be to strive for a good thing for Europe, not a bad thing. In so doing, she is taking into account all the social consequences and is acting for the best future for us all. As for the market economy status of China, on which some remarks were made, whatever the final decision will be, one thing is for sure: we will have effective trade defence instruments in place and the tools at our disposal will be sharpened and not weakened. And finally, and this, I will say in French Madam President, if you will allow me... Je dois dire, comme M. Bayet, que vraiment, moi aussi, je veux saluer la réaction pleine de dignité des syndicats et de la direction locale de Gosselies. Les deux sont vraiment déterminés à agir de concert. L'Europe est là pour les aider et pour les soutenir. En fin de compte, cette décision d'entreprise est naturellement peu compréhensible, mais je veux être optimiste. On ne peut pas devenir immédiatement tout à fait pessimiste. On doit aussi se rendre compte que l'an dernier, en région wallonne, on a su créer 9 300 emplois. Cette usine qui est concernée, et ces travailleurs, ont des atouts formidables à faire valoir: leurs compétences, leur jeunesse. C'est une usine moderne, avec un matériel de production de grande qualité. Elle se situe à proximité des grands centres logistiques et de décisions tels que Bruxelles et l'aéroport de Charleroi. Nous devons en être conscients aussi. Je sais que pour les gens qui sont touchés par cette décision, ces considérations ne sont pas une consolation, mais continuons à travailler ensemble pour le futur.

name: La Présidente. –
text: We also thank you, Commissioner. The debate is closed. The vote will take place in the next session. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – European industry has been severely affected by the economic crisis, but also by the relocation process to countries outside the European Union which have provided lower production costs. Traditional industry has disappeared from the European economy and has been replaced by the corporate industry which, while making huge profits in Europe, speculates on the weaknesses of developing countries. In the face of this trend, the European Union must protect its industrial activity by ensuring fair competition, financing the modernisation process and taking responsibility for the future of European employees in the industry. The main solution for increasing competitiveness is to develop the industry of the future by actively financing research and technological development.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on 30 August the Commission adopted a decision that Apple’s tax benefits in Ireland are illegal State aid. I am thankful for the European Parliament’s interest in this case and happy to be here today to inform you about the decision. It is an honour.  This decision follows an in-depth investigation into two tax rulings that Ireland had issued to Apple. We concluded that they gave Apple a selective advantage over other companies, artificially reducing Apple’s tax burden over two decades. This is illegal under EU State aid rules. Apple now has to pay the unpaid tax of up to EUR 13 billion plus interest.  Member States cannot give unfair tax benefits and thereby selectively favour certain companies. EU State aid rules keep the level playing field in the single market and ensure that companies can compete on equal terms, thus protecting European taxpayers.  The State aid decision on Apple does not call into question Ireland’s general tax system or its corporate tax rate. The investigation concerned two Irish tax rulings from 1991 and 2007. They gave selective tax treatment to two Irish companies in the Apple group. The ruling endorsed an internal allocation of profits within Apple Sales International between its head office and branch. The bulk of the company’s profits were allocated to the company’s head office. The thing was that Apple Sales International’s head office had no employees, no premises and no real economic activity. It existed only on paper. Therefore, there was no factual or economic justification for allocating almost all of the company’s profits to the head office.  Under the Irish tax law applicable at the time, the head office was not subject to tax in Ireland or anywhere else. The rulings therefore allowed Apple Sales International to pay very little tax on its profits. In fact, the effective tax rate for Apple Sales International was as little as 0.005% in 2014. This means that Apple paid less than EUR 50 in tax for every million euros in profits, giving it a significant advantage over other businesses in breach of State aid rules.  To restore fair competition the decision now orders the recovery of Apple’s unpaid taxes back to 2003. It is for the Irish tax authorities to calculate the exact amount. We estimate that it could be as much as EUR 13 billion plus interest. Apple and Ireland have announced that they will appeal, and they of course have the right to do so. We have a robust decision and will defend it in court. Once agreed by Ireland, we will publish our decision for all to see, and I hope that this can happen as fast as possible.  The published information may also be relevant to tax authorities in other jurisdictions. This is because Apple decided to record most of its profits from European sales in Ireland. This is not an issue for the EU State aid rules, but as soon as the decision is published, tax authorities will be able to read across the information provided by Apple in Ireland and in their jurisdiction, and of course assess whether this updated information is relevant under national tax rules. In addition, if the US tax authorities consider that Apple should have paid a higher contribution for research and development to its US parent, it could lead to a higher taxable amount in the US.  Looking ahead, the goal is that all companies, big or small, should pay taxes where they generate their profits. To that end, the EU, the US and the international partners as such must work together, and significant steps have already been taken by the OECD and endorsed by the G20. In the EU, under the responsibility of my colleagues Valdis Dombrovskis and Pierre Moscovici, we are pursuing a strategy towards fair taxation and greater transparency. Firstly, European tax authorities will next year start to exchange information on tax rulings, a real change for the better. But we should go even further. Transparency is very important in an open, democratic society. It is important that basic tax information on multinational companies becomes public. The public should see the number of employees, what activities a company has in each country, what profits they generate and what taxes they pay. This is the objective of the Commission proposal on country-by-country public reporting.  These reforms and even-handed enforcement of our competition rules contribute to a fairer investment environment, and a single market where  companies can compete on merit, as reflected in the quality of their products, prices, and the services they can provide, and not on the basis of their tax arrangements. A single market of more than 500 million potential customers: that alone is a very good reason for companies to invest, and it is a top priority for the Juncker Commission to make Europe even more attractive for investment for the benefit of all European citizens.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, we need to be aware that economic recovery is beginning to be a reality, but much remains to be done, because many European citizens are still having a hard time. But, without a doubt, whether economic recovery is a reality, it is thanks to the efforts of millions of European citizens. And in this context, these citizens, whom we have asked for many efforts, do not understand that large multinationals do not participate in this collective effort. On the contrary: unfortunately, they have the opposite perception. On the other hand, in this context I believe that the citizens of Europe should be grateful for the effort and forceful effort with which Commissioner Vestager has acted in the Apple case. Because, without a doubt, actions like this contribute to European citizens seeing us as part of the solution and not as part of the problem. Dear colleagues, we must say loud and clear that the party is over; it is true that multinationals contribute to growth and job creation, but they cannot have privileges that European citizens do not have. We must move towards fiscal union. A fundamental first step, without a doubt, is the consolidated common basis of corporation tax. That does not mean the same taxes, but means the same rules and, as the Commissioner said, more transparency. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is also important to stress that the countries affected by this case must claim their proportionate share of taxes. My country, Spain, has already done so and I hope that all countries will be in this initiative.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, Commissioner, congratulations, you are liberal, I am a socialist, you defend free and undistorted competition with determination and I congratulate you, I thank you. We are all drugged, intoxicated with these machines and yet we are glad that you have so severely condemned this company which in a way amuses us, it attracts us, it drugs us and then it blurs us. You have restored the order of things, but there is still a long way to go. And I see that today in Ireland things are finally moving. The Minister of Finance has just eliminated a tax benefit for vulture funds in the area of real estate loans. Would he be suspicious of you? You have advanced economic thinking because you put black and white what I said to Commissioner Charlie McCreevy many years ago. A tax benefit is state aid, when it is done under conditions that distort competition, such as the regime that is applied to Apple in Ireland.  But we have to go further and, Commissioner, you have on your table an issue to which I attach great importance. It's probably the next one. This is the McDonald's case, in which not only will you be able to shake up the tax rules, but you will also be able to establish a basis for true social harmonization and an effective fight against social dumping. Again, I look forward to you with the same determination, regardless of the Member State in question, which in this case is another Member State, Luxembourg. Finally, I would like to thank you, Commissioner, because to all those Eurosceptics, here or elsewhere, who explain to us that the European Commission is just a bureaucracy, you have shown that, while the Member States have not wanted tax harmonisation without unanimity, well, where the Commission has real power to act, it is at the heart of the interests of citizens by fighting against tax dumping and by allowing the restoration of tax justice. Thank you, keep going and you'll have our support.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Commissioner, it takes courage to tackle an iconic giant and multinational like Apple. My admiration for that. You have also received a lot of criticism for it, including from your predecessor Neelie Kroes. It is true that the Commission should not be concerned with tax policy. That is a sovereign competence of the Member States. I believe that the European Commission's attempt to implement such a tax policy and to introduce European taxes is absolutely out of the question. There is no support for this among the people of Europe. What does exist and for which you have our full support is for what you have just done. We must dare to tackle illegal state aid granted to selected companies, because in a free market consumers are in charge. Consumers choose which products they buy, what services they want. They decide what and how much is produced. They determine whether a company makes a profit or a loss. It is not up to politicians to determine who the winners and who the losers are. It is not up to companies, not even the big companies to obtain special advantages with convenient lobbying. It is good that you are making it clear that large multinationals do not have more rights than smaller companies. Finally, as you yourself have pointed out, it is not for this Parliament to make the final judgment. That will be up to the European Court of Justice. I look forward very much to your defence in that regard and to that judgment.  (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Loones, it is really music to my ears to hear you praise the Commission. I note that it is a party comrade of yours, if I can use that term, who is the minister of finance in Belgium, and if you are so happy with this ruling of the Commission, do you not think it is normal for Belgium to question its share of the profits that have left its territory to go to Ireland without being taxed? I note that Belgium is not showing an overflowing energy to recover its fair share of taxes not paid by Apple.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer. – No, I think we have no lessons to be learned in this regard, Mr Lamberts, when I see what Johan Van Overtveldt, our Minister of Finance, has already achieved, for example on transparency. When it comes to sharing rulings, Minister Van Overtveldt is ahead of what the European Union is doing. That's where we set an example. That's where we pull the cart. At the same time, I think there are indeed questions to be asked about how far we go back in time. In this respect, Mrs Neelie Kroes has opened a legitimate debate, which we must address. We have also seen this in a judgment that has been passed on to the Belgian Government in connection with the rulings for profit. I think we need to enter into this debate because you are really at the interface between fiscal policy and fair competition.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam Commissioner, when I was a little girl in the 1970s, there was a popular television series: The Man of 6 Million. I am pleased to say now that you have far surpassed that, because that tough man has now been surpassed by a tough woman: the Commissioner of 13 billion. That 13 billion is, of course, an astronomical amount, especially if you relate that to the fact that it is not paying enough tax by only one company. When I saw the press release describing your approach, I really had to read it again. Did I read that it said: 0.005 percent in 2014? That is, of course, a ridiculously low amount. We'd all like that. We want, of course, that everyone pays a fair contribution to tax. All of us, large and small companies, but certainly also the multinationals. The 13 billion is already being fought hard, because Ireland could of course make good use of that money itself. Other Member States where Apple products have been sold are also keen to claim them. The United States is already saying that a large part must come to them. I fear that it will be a long time before this is clarified. You yourself have already indicated that, I believe, the Commission has had three years of preparation to get this matter on the fores in the spotlight. I am a little afraid that, with Ireland and Apple taking the case to court, it will take years before we finally get clarity. I would therefore urge anyone involved to provide information, whatever, as soon as possible. Because we all want clarity on this matter as soon as possible. For us politicians, this case shows once again that we have to work really hard to simplify our tax systems and make it more transparent, because it is now simply too complicated and that is why it is taking far too long. (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
