text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the question; it’s really a pleasure to hear so much support for the sort of policies we’ve been working for here in the public debate, but sometimes we haven’t had so much support from other groups in in our committee work. Particularly on full public country—by—country reporting, we’ve been fighting for this for quite a long time, so I’d be very pleased to hear if Cora’s group have now decided to support that. So, could I ask: will ALDE be supporting full public country—by—country reporting?

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. – It is very clear to us that transparency is the most important weapon. We are still looking closely at the requested impact assessment, but we have at least seen that country-by-country reporting has not caused problems for the banks, where this obligation already applies.

name: Matt Carthy
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I’ve stood in this Chamber on countless occasions to defend the rights of national parliaments to set their own tax rates, and I do so again today. Sinn Féin will always defend Ireland’s sovereignty, as we have on every occasion when it’s been attacked by the European Commission, including on taxation matters, but this ruling is not one of those occasions.  I’m sure you, Commissioner, and many of your fellow federalists in this room are scratching their heads wondering what’s happened to your best friends in the Irish political establishment. The people who the EU could always depend on. When the Commission said jump to a savage austerity agenda, they simply asked ‘how harsh?’. When the EU said EUR 64 billion and private bank debt should be placed on the shoulders of the Irish people or when you demanded new water or property taxes, your friends in Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil quickly capitulated. When you proposed trade deals with investment courts that would do more to undermine sovereignty than any Commission ruling, your Irish friends proudly say ‘we’ll champion that for you’.  But today, the Commission’s bodies in Ireland are fighting back. Not in the interests, though, of the Irish people or the Irish economy, but in the interests of the wealthiest corporations in the world and our global web of tax avoidance. This ruling has no effect whatsoever on our tax rate or our ability to attract inward investment or to create jobs. Any investors seeking to remain in, or come to, Ireland can be assured of a talented workforce and a 12.5% corporate tax rate that we will protect; they just won’t be assured any longer of sweetheart deals that would allow them to dodge billions of euros in tax. The announced appeal is morally wrong, politically dishonest and economically stupid. We have a housing and health crisis in Ireland. Many of our public services are savagely underfunded. EUR 13 billion, or even a fraction of it, could help solve those problems. Rather than spending Irish taxpayers’ money on this appeal, our government should instead be restoring our international reputation by ensuring that Ireland will never again be part of the international tax avoidance racket.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, I am very annoyed because, as an elected environmentalist, I am opposed to human cloning. And yet, when I see you, the desire comes to me to multiply the Margrethe Vestager. I would like more like you, so it is a rather difficult contradiction to resolve, because, perhaps better than anyone else in the Commission, you remember the very beginning of your order of mission to defend the european general interest and you do so brilliantly.  You are also right - and I am sure my friends at the GUE will be very happy to hear it - to Vladimir Ilitch Lenin who said that where there is will, there is a way - but since Angela Merkel has taken up this expression, it has obviously become much more ecumenical, if I may say so.  And so, I really admire your work, because if you do not pretend to write the tax law in Europe, you are doing what you can not to put an end to the tax war they are waging, but at least to deprive them of the most unacceptable weapons they use in this tax war and for that, I thank you. Nor can I help but contrast your attitude with that, as mentioned, of Neelie Kroes, who preceded you in the position you hold, which was to describe the judgment, without even knowing it, as unfair, but worse, with the attitude of governments - I am obviously thinking of the trio of tax havens called the Benelux, but of course the Irish government is on board too - who fail to resist the urge to say: "But we don't want this money, you, the shareholders of multinationals, keep it, we will pump our small taxpayers, we will pump out SMEs more and more, we will reduce the services of the state, because we do not want your money". I find that attitude to be simply unacceptable. I do not know what it will take for the heads of state and government and their finance minister to return to this primary mission of defending the public interest. And it is quite difficult to sum up the public interest in the 1% defence.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Apple case clearly demonstrates that state aid discipline is not the right rule for punishing a company, the State and those who have in any case carried out and encouraged this type of immoral practice, precisely because the very State that encouraged tax avoidance will be rewarded with the payment of taxes in arrears and no sanction will be applied to the multinational. So we need to work, and quickly, for discipline in this regard, so that there is fair treatment, and we also need to name countries that are not cooperative in putting down a proposal, because we have been talking about it for twenty years.  I have recently visited the TAXE Committee over the last two years: I have seen more tags in Luxembourg from companies that most likely adopt schemes similar to Those of Apple, that real jobs, real businesses and real activities, many tags even of banks, among other things, so very large interests that to touch will be very difficult.  However, we must cooperate at international level, have courage in this respect and name, especially in the Council, those who oppose a certain type of agreement and compromise on this. No compromises should be made: small and medium-sized enterprises are failing and paying taxes for large companies, and so we absolutely cannot continue in this situation, we must react and react quickly. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Valli, do you believe that taxation matters on an international scale should be solved – and can be solved – through the OECD BEPS process? Do you not believe that is the correct way that we are moving forward and that every country should sign up to that, both European and international? Also, do you think that profits that Apple made on products that were sold across the European Union should have been taxed in Ireland? Do you not think that those profits should been taxed elsewhere, and that Ireland certainly has taken tax on profits made in its own country? Do you not agree with those statements?

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. As I said in my speech, this system of sanctions, which gives the possibility of repaying taxes in that country, is not fair, because there have been abuses by Apple and Ireland against countries where real economic activity has taken place. Of course taxes should be paid there, so taxes must be paid where this activity is carried out. Trying to cooperate for this is in the common interest: politics must react in this direction, and so it is common sense that we must push and it is in that direction.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, it is time! With the $13 billion fine imposed on Apple, it was time for the European Union to become aware of the tax delinquency of multinationals and the collateral damage of your borderless economy in the WTO way.  It was time, in the world economic war, for the European Union to react to the LuxLeaks scandal, which directly implicates your President Juncker, an accomplice of multinationals at the expense of nations, a real economic crime against the peoples.  It was time to do the same thing as the US administration, which for decades has punished our large national companies for using the dollar, such as BNP Paribas, for example.  With $200 billion in cash, Apple, without faith or law, has organized a real corporate tax heist. In my country, France, Apple has paid only 56 million corporate taxes in ten years. It's insignificant. The European Union explains that these tax rulings are not illegal. They are not illegal, but they are immoral to taxpayers and businesses who have to go through hyper-taxes to make up for budget deficits. I say to you in advance, Mrs Vestager, the European Union will never see the colour of the EUR 13 billion. Moreover, to the fullest of absurdity, your tax gas plant - Ireland - does not want the amount of this fine. And it would never come to the idea that the states that are victims of these thugs could receive reimbursement for their tax shortfalls. In short, with you, the poacher also receives a bonus.  So we must not whine if citizens now vote for patriotic parties. It must be up to the sovereign states to act. This requires regulating trade through national borders. Marine Le Pen's France will do so through systematic tax adjustments to punish tax evasion by multinationals.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I admit that I have a little difficulty understanding your decision, which has not been published, even if the objective of ending the tax dumping enjoyed by certain multinationals is laudable.  A few questions: first, one wonders about the legal basis. What are the legal texts that are covered? This lack of publication of your decision greatly limits our analytical possibilities. Secondly, the Commission says it does not question the fact that Member States are free of their tax policy - very well - and that rates are set freely by the states - here, Ireland. It therefore does not directly attack tax dumping that Ireland would engage in at the expense of other European countries. The logical result is that distortions of competition are appreciated within the Irish market. But who are these competitors? Have they received a complaint from you? It doesn't seem. Thirdly, if Ireland is at fault, is it not inconsistent, as my colleague has said, to want to force the $13 billion to be forcibly allocated to ireland as a punishment, which it tells you it does not want? It's still strange. Fourthly, if, as the Commission suggests, the Member States have refrained from imposing Apple for its actual economic activities on their territory, is the responsibility not for this deficiency lies with those States and not with the society which has benefited publicly and peacefully with their benevolence? I would like to be sure that your legitimate objectives are compatible with the rule of law, non-retroactivity, that your action serves European interests well and not to repatriate profits and taxes to the United States, Europe would not win.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, congratulations on this courageous and correct decision that you, Commissioner, have taken. Let me be clear: this is not about Apple, but about aid granted by the State of Ireland. That is why I say very clearly to the American address: this is not an anti-American fight, but the struggle to ensure that everyone pays their taxes according to their performance in the country where profits are generated. After all, it is not our model in Europe that one can negotiate one's tax rates individually with the tax office. And I am very grateful to you for finding the right lever, even if it rewards those who are to be punished – the profiteer is the State of Ireland, which receives these unpaid taxes here – but it is the right lever, because it is precisely there that you have the power to act accordingly. Tax justice is one of the essential things in our society. If we find that the ordinary citizen, the salaried worker, the small and medium-sized entrepreneur has to pay the taxes set by the state, but all those who operate across borders, who work in many Member States, can negotiate their own tax rates, then we are on the wrong track. Exactly the opposite of what I have heard here from a few other speakers is true. That is why I can only encourage you to go further here. And I also say very clearly, because I was the rapporteur for the tax rulings: the fact that the Member States have refused to make these preliminary rulings available to the Commission shows that this business model should continue to exist. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Very simply put, Mr Ferber: it is the Treaties that allow nation states to keep their own taxes and not be allowed by the EU. But you promote the lever, as you suggest, of competition law being used to enable this Parliament and this European Union to take taxes off nation states. Do you not see that this lever is taxation of nation states by the EU, by the back door?

name: Markus Ferber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – The key question is this: is such a tax ruling to an individual company an eligible aid or not? And the European Union certainly has the competence to look into this. Incidentally, since 1957, since the European Union was in existence, the control of subsidies has been one of the core tasks of the European Commission, and it is therefore necessary to examine: is this a subsidy that can be approved? And if it is not eligible for authorisation, the Commission must intervene accordingly, and it has done so. I think this is the right approach, and that is why I welcome it. It does not affect the member states' right to tax.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the single market can only function correctly if businesses have the possibility to compete on equal terms. However, unfortunately, practice shows that there are always companies operating within the EU that will try to circumvent the rules to gain questionable advantages. The current case of Apple demonstrates this quite well. Here, I have to congratulate the Commission – and especially you, Commissioner Vestager – for taking a firm stance on this matter. Companies like Apple and those who provide selective terms to them must know that this behaviour is not tolerated within the EU anymore, and that they will eventually have to pay a price. It should also be highlighted that the European Union is not leading any kind of witch hunt against American corporations. They create many jobs in Europe and make important investments: that is true. However, all companies – no matter whether European or foreign – must understand that using unfair advantages that go against EU law can lead to serious consequences. I am delighted to see the deep determination of the Commission to create a system of fair taxation and greater transparency. At the same time, I call on the Member States to tackle the loopholes in their national laws that allow tax avoidance to take place and refrain from any harmful tax practices. Again, let us be honest, it takes two to tango. Today’s message goes not only to Apple and similar, but their proxies around the Member States’ governments, as in Hungary as well.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done I would like to begin by congratulating the Commissioner on the work you have done here – very well. But I would also like to say that there are three institutions in the dock here: Apple, which is being scolded enough for not paying its taxes, Ireland, because it has facilitated this type of tax avoidance, and, of course, over a long period of time, and finally, of course, the previous commissions, which also seem to have seen nothing for at least ten years and have done nothing. , although Mr Ferber has just rightly said that this would have been a core task.  Now, as far as Ireland is concerned, it must also be said, of course, that Ireland has benefited from the euro bailout and has received billions in loans there, over EUR 83 or 85 billion, even though it would obviously have only had to apply its own tax laws in order to increase its revenue. EUR 13 billion would have flowed from Apple alone if the Irish Government had been willing to apply the law which it should have applied under EU law. That, ladies and gentlemen, is the real scandal: that Ireland has rehabilitated itself here at the expense of the Community.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I support the principle of tax justice, so on that, I agree with the Commissioner. But the question we ask today is: can EU state aid rules influence or even determine the tax policy of sovereign Member States? I do not know the answer to that question, and, crucially, I do not know the implications of a positive answer. That is why we need clarity, and the European Court of Justice (ECJ) is the only institution to provide that clarity. A EUR 13 billion bauble has been dangled in front of Irish noses. Commissioner Moscovici said, ‘it is strange for the Irish to say “I do not want your EUR 13 billion” when they could have social programmes’. So, Commissioner, can you guarantee the EUR 13 billion to Ireland if the ECJ agrees with you? Or will other countries look for their share of that particular cake? Commissioner Moscovici has basically guaranteed that we can start drawing up plans for schools and hospitals and houses; many Irish politicians already have. Can you guarantee that, Commissioner?

name: Fabio De Masi (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Apple paid 0.005 percent tax on its profits in the EU in 2014. That's 50 euros for every million profits they make with these chic iPads. I therefore welcome the EU Commission's decision on Apple, also against the opposition of the US Government.  However, the Irish Government does not want the EUR 13 billion and is going to court. The same government that, with the troika, saved ailing banks and cut the people's last shirt. The same government, which now has to transfer EUR 280 million more to Brussels, because it created a fictitious growth rate of 26 percent with tax tricks, about which every ordinary Irishman laughs. Moreover, only the Irish colleagues in my group in the Irish Parliament voted against the Irish Government's complaint. But it is just as embarrassing when the Bavarian Finance Minister Söder of the CSU criticises the Commission when it does its job at Apple. No craftsman in Bavaria would dream of a tax rate like Apple even after 10 measures at Oktoberfest. That is why Mr Söder should finally investigate Apple in Bavaria. There is the money for investment in schools and hospitals, which we have not needed since the refugee crisis, and I am therefore pleased that Mr Ferber, who is a honourable Member, is explaining this to The Söder. However, state aid law is too complicated and, with around 20 EU officials, a fight against windmills. On the other hand, only brutal transparency – for example, in country-by-country reporting – and a tax on profits in the EU, where they are incurred, does not help where Apple and Co. have letterboxes. We also need minimum taxes for corporations.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mrs Vestager, you and your 18 employees in this field really deserve an order. They have done more to restore respect for the European Union in the eyes of many citizens than many before. You have valued principles that we talk about so often here in Europe more highly than the pressure that has been put on you. The pressure was palpable. When did the US Treasury Secretary tell you what to decide? And you have stood up – and that is right. And I can only tell you that there is a lot of frustration about Europe at the moment, and you have shown with this decision that many people who talk badly about Europe are wrong. Europe can jointly defend its interests more than anyone can. In this respect, there is clearly a price to be announced at some point. I just wonder: when will more staff be deployed to tackle more cases of this kind? It cannot be that we are just making a few examples.  We currently have exactly the same thing in the case of money laundering, where five poor people form a financial crime unit and sit in the basement of Dg JUSTICE. Can you not grant them asylum? I believe that they would be better off in your house and that they also need more staff.  Finally, the Member States should cooperate in order to obtain some of the tax revenue that you have given them on the tray now. Can the EU Commission not take an initiative to ensure that the countries there work together instead of working against each other in collecting these taxes?

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the manchineel tree is a tropical tree originating in North America. It is one of the most dangerous trees in the world. To eat its fruit is deadly. Its nickname is manzanilla de la muerte, or ‘little apple of death’. As part of the EU’s march to nation statehood, it needs to finance its over—ambitious policies: this Parliament, civil service, courts, foreign policy and, of course, the burgeoning EU army. To raise money, it must have taxes. The Apple tax ruling forms part of the EU’s long-standing plan – which includes VAT and the common consolidated corporation tax base – to take control of EU citizens’ taxes directly. The Apple tax ruling is an attack on the tax sovereignty of EU nation states by the back door, and the EU has weaponised EU competition law and, in particular, state aid rules to achieve this.  The ruling is a massive problem for those Europhiles and Conservative Ministers who believe we should stay in the single market or want even EEA status. Remaining in either will lead the UK to be part of the EU’s competition law, acquis and EU state aid rules. Either could lead to retrospective tax rulings and stop us from having an independent competitive tax policy. Just as the manzanilla tree is the little apple of death for those that eat its fruit, the EU is the big apple of death to prosperity and freedom.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I may be one of the lone voices here taking issue with the Commission's proposals, but I do so in the name of Ireland, and also with the support of the government, backed up by the Irish Parliament, which voted 93 votes to 36 to appeal this to the European Court. A decision which our GUE Sinn Féin representative described as ‘morally wrong’. Well, if it is morally wrong to defend the reputation of a country, what is morally right? We have been accused of illegal state aid, which we deny; Apple did not get a sweetheart deal. We also take issue with the use of competition law to undermine the sovereignty of a national state. In this instance, taxation is the competence of the Member States, and if  the sovereignty of other Member States was challenged, I think some speakers here would be taking a different line to what they have taken so far. We agree, of course, there are gaping loopholes in relation to tax law and these have to be closed, and are being closed, and we have been at the forefront in that regard, in OECD and on BEPS.  There is also of course envy that we have been so successful in attracting foreign direct investment to Ireland. But I can tell you this: if these companies leave Ireland they will not be going to Paris, they will not be going to Berlin, they will not be going anywhere else except Singapore and other places outside the European Union. We have an educated workforce, we have a great relationship with the United States, which no other country has, we are also a gateway to Europe – and that is why we have foreign direct investment.  Finally, I want to leave you with three points: we are not going to be the messenger boys for the European Union, gathering taxes which they say belong to other Member States. We are not going to be the punchbag for this European Commission when it is afraid to tackle the big states regarding the Stability and Growth Pact. Finally, we will see you in court, after which you will hopefully be eating humble pie, perhaps humble apple pie.   (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, I would like to inform Mr Kelly – or perhaps he is already aware – that as soon as this decision was out, the UK Tories were immediately saying ‘well, now that we are leaving the European Union to compete, here’s a great opportunity with Ireland on tax.’ I would like to ask him how he thinks it can possibly be for the benefit of European citizens that we all seek to become countries like Singapore that compete with each other. What exactly does he think the future is in that, and does he not understand that what Commissioner Vestager is doing is exactly defending us against that kind of race to the bottom?

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for your question; the answer is obvious, and I have referred to it. We have to establish a level playing field, we have to establish transparency, we have to have the same rules applying right across the European Union and globally, and that is what we’re trying to do. But we cannot, as the Commissioner is trying to do, apply these rules retroactively. That is a problem with this. Indeed, if we do establish a transparency and a fair corporation tax and tax reporting –which we want – then companies will stay in the European Union, but if we hound them like this they will leave. The British will be delighted to welcome them, as will Singapore, and the European Union, as well as Ireland and all the Member States, will suffer. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Kelly, you say that Apple will leave Ireland and that these jobs will not be going to France or Singapore. I know more than yourself. You probably heard Tim Cook, CEO of Apple, on RTE, Ireland’s national broadcaster, who said that the reason he was in Ireland was because of the people and the workers and not because of the tax. Do you not believe him? Do you not think we are talented enough to attract them anyway without becoming the scumbags of Europe?

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. –  Mr Flanagan, you speak well, but you do not listen very well. That is exactly what I said – these companies come to Ireland not because of corporation tax, primarily, but because of our well-educated workforce, our relationship with the United States, our command of the English language and our gateway to Europe. If they decide to leave Ireland – which hopefully they will not, and they have said they will not – the same attractions will not be found in any other Member State of the European Union: they will find places other than the European Union to locate, and that is the point.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: Madam President, it is always a pleasure to have you to chair these debates. Commissioner, thank you very much for the effective fight against the tax optimisation of multinationals that you are leading. Today it's Apple and Ireland. We could call them the evil lovers who are welded together and ready for anything, and even to commit the irreparable, since I think that what they really want is to undermine the European economy, all to avoid participating in the financing of our social model, be it accessible and quality health care, social protection, education for all , support for jobs, a sustainable economy or security for all of us. And unfortunately if it is not Apple or the other multinationals that contribute to it, well it is small and medium-sized enterprises and our citizens who have to overcome the incivility of multinationals, with the result of citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises who have to pay more taxes than they should. And all for the benefit of Apple, its shareholders, its executives and its American employees. And what is left for European countries? Very little, except the impression of financing the extravagant lifestyle of the firm with apple. You know, Commissioner, in 2014, the revenues of Apple's six most senior executives, all American, peaked at 133 million euros. But for Apple, the European Commission is seriously wrong, and the multinational does not intend to reimburse or change its practices. As for Ireland, it is the same speech, and worse, the government refuses to ask Apple to repay the 13 billion. This is not a unique case because, contrary to what my colleague Sander said a few months ago, after a conviction by the European Commission, the Belgian government has also refused to recover from the multinationals the reimbursement of the defrauded sums. We can see, therefore, that the Commission, on the one hand, is doing its job but that the Member States are not following this path. This has already been noted with the report on the rules against tax evasion by multinationals, when states decided not to follow Parliament's recommendations and to postpone the implementation of these measures until 2024. Commissioner, should we not think about allowing the European Union to recover these sums directly from multinationals. One could imagine going back to the European budget and dedicating them, for example, to the fight against tax evasion. Especially since another news has confirmed Apple's condemnation, it is the closure by Caterpillar of its only headquarters in Belgium, more than 5,000 layoffs. In this case, Caterpillar organized its tax evasion in Switzerland, not Ireland, it has to stop. We will of course be with you, Commissioner, to put an end to it.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, thank You Commissioner Vestager for the admirable work you are doing for fair competition. European competition needs a level playing field. If large international companies are able to operate almost tax-free, local businesses will not be helped second. Every euro that Apple has not paid has been left to other European companies. As Mr Juncker mentioned this morning in his speech, Europeanism means equal treatment, the same rights, the same responsibilities. This also applies to companies. If we want growth, if we want European success stories, our own Apples and Facebooks, we must guarantee our growth companies a fair opportunity to compete against international waste.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner Vestager, I would like to thank you for your support. Actually, we are discussing an old and well-known economic problem. The theory speaks of profit-seeking and rent-seeking, where profit-seeking is the diligent entrepreneur and rent-seeking is the lazy coupon cutter. Here are many examples that the Irish and Apple can use if they want to look in the mirror. Perhaps the most famous is the Silk Road. We know what happened when attempts were made to prevent the Mongol Empire from cutting too much of interest rates. Then Genghis Khan made action to counter this. It was quite a major disaster for the European countries as well. In this sense, Ireland is, so to speak, in this example. There's another story, too. The more biblical story is about the apple and Eve. The European story is about Margrethe and the apple. She took a piece out of the fruit of wisdom.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to Commissioner Vestager that global corporations of unprecedented size are making unprecedented profits but are avoiding paying taxes on those profits on an unprecedented scale, thus forcing an ever-increasing tax burden on small companies and on individual taxpayers in countries, rich and poor, right across the globe. Ireland should do the right thing and accept that it has been involved in behaviour that is not in keeping with those that sought so bravely to make our nation a reality. However, we should not change our ways because we are being told to do so by the Commission. We should do it because it is the right thing to do, in the same way that we should not borrow to burn as is demanded by another arm of this institution, the ECB. We should say ‘no way, we won’t pay’.  This morning, Mr Juncker said that this Commission is delivering on tax avoidance/evasion. I find it difficult to tell the difference. You, I believe, Commissioner, but your boss I don’t believe. Capo di tutt'i capi, the ‘godfather’, as they say in Italy. It is like Al Capone running for President of Italy on the basis that he will wipe out the mafia. Good luck, Commissioner Vestager, I look forward to the meeting with you and other Irish MEPs on 4 October. Hopefully, Fine Gael will have changed from their newfound scepticism, because it doesn’t suit their pocket.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate Commissioner Vestager on her courageous decision to demand that Apple pay the EUR 13 billion it owes in tax. This action has done much to increase the EU's standing with European citizens, not just warm words or vague ambitions, but concrete action that will positively affect people's livelihoods. Across our continent, we see the revival of nationalism as people feel out of control in a globalising world, yet it is not other countries that threaten our ability to act, but the global corporations that grow ever more powerful. I welcome the decision of the Commission to work for Europe's citizens and to contain the power of corporations and ensure that they pay the taxes they owe. But we also need to be clear about who the recovered tax belongs to, because this is not just about Ireland and Apple. When any country arranges a sweetheart deal for a company we all lose out. If  we are to reverse the damaging cuts to public services and to invest in such vital issues as mitigating climate change, then we need to keep up the pressure for tax justice.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: –  Madam President, tax fairness is about everybody paying their fair share, and I applaud you, Commissioner, for your work and for having the political steel to reach this decision – a big step in tackling corporate tax evasion.  It beggars belief that Apple only paid corporate tax at a measly the rate of 0.005% in 2014. I believe this decision is a clear message to multinationals which are cherry-picking in terms of tax avoidance. Let us not forget that Apple benefits from infrastructure in Ireland paid for by the Irish taxpayer and its staff use this infrastructure on a daily basis, but the Irish taxpayer does not get anything in return. We cannot have one rule for big multinationals and another one for SMEs, who are the main creators of jobs across the European Union. In my region in the West Midlands, one of the big issues raised with me by SMEs is that this type of sweetheart deal is massively unfair and one they felt that the EU should have tackled long ago. Now Apple’s CEO has threatened that this decision will impact on jobs and investment. I believe this is totally the wrong approach. As one of the largest companies in the world, Apple is promoting corporate social responsibility and I welcome this; however, would it not be better for them to pay their tax rather than cherrypicking again and paying for perhaps a bit of education here or a bit of housing there? Although 13 billion looks like a massive amount of money, to a company like Apple it is only peanuts in terms of their total balance.  Commissioner, the competition rules are a strong tool which should in the end benefit the consumer. Will there now be a focus on the prices of Apple products and the company’s strategies to erode interoperability, such as removal of headphones? Once again, I think this decision is a big step on the road towards tax justice.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Between 2003 and 2014, Apple benefited from a total of €13 billion in tax benefits, paying an effective tax of less than one percent of profits. Such generous tax privileges are not available and were not available to other companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises. I am not surprised, in this case, that the European Commission has concluded that there has been an infringement of eu competition rules by granting unlawful state aid.  Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Tax avoidance by companies is, of course, a common practice, but apple's case shows that large transnational corporations are able to influence the amount of tax they pay in host countries, and at the same time, as a result of these practices, Member States and their budgets lose tens of billions of euros of tax annually.  The European Parliament has always been of the view that taxes must be paid where profits are created. I therefore call on the Commission to step up its efforts to seal tax systems while ensuring non-discrimination in the Single European Market.

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the Commission’s Apple state-aid EUR 13 billion decision is a brazen attempt to usurp the primacy of nation state tax policy and is legally questionable. EU Member States have been rightly reluctant to cede autonomy over setting tax rates. It is, after all, a crucial mechanism for responding to their respective economic needs and for nations to be competitive globally. Commissioner Vestager has responded outrageously to this sovereign issue by attempting to use state aid measures to harmonise corporation taxes and to direct their collection. This is another EU power grab. It is a tax trespass, and tax breaks are not state aid.  Tax reform can only be achieved through international consensus by sovereign nation governments. Yes, global corporations must pay more in tax and fair taxes, but action must be taken at the G20 or OEC level, not by the EU. I stand with the sovereign Irish Government in challenging this decision. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – I would like to ask you: The loss of the Irish Treasury worth EUR 13 billion as a result of granting tax breaks must be condemned as unlawful by all European institutions. The unjustified method of internally allocating profits between two corporations wholly owned by Apple Group led to the distortion of competition in the market and the reduction to 0.005 per cent of corporation tax on the company's profits for 2014.  Don't you think that €13 billion could have helped Ireland in years when the country was in financial and economic crisis with minimal economic growth and indicators? And shouldn't such vicious practices be put to an end in the European Union?

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, Mr Nekov. I think there are two issues being confused here. The first issue: are big corporations paying too little tax? Absolutely right; they are. We have to raise tax for them. The second point: should the EU be overriding national sovereignty and misusing state aid competition rules to do so? No, it should not. Do not confuse the two. I think we all agree that Apple and other big corporations should pay more tax, but not this way.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE).
text: – Madam President. Thank you very much to Commissioner Vestager, as an MEP, as a representative of European civil society, as a member of the PANA Commission and as a mere citizen. And as a politician, because it's not an Irish issue, nor is it a subject of accountants. Thank you very much for giving the best news that Europe has had in recent months; for showing how more Europe is needed to have a playing field that truly protects citizens. Thank you very much and follow yourself.  I cannot fail to say that, of course, one of the great conceptual mistakes made has undoubtedly been the attempt to create a single market and a single currency without a minimum – without a minimum! – of fiscal cohesion. No homogenization, but a minimum. We pay for it now and it is true that we have to do it for nooks and crannies, but it is indispensable. And finally, Commissioner, do not forget that there are tax rulings waiting also for the opinion many months ago.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, let us honestly say, the real State of the Union speech was delivered a fortnight ago. By asking Apple to return 13 billion euros in unpaid taxes, Vestager dealt a blow to the tax impunity of multinationals. By going through this process and multiplying the investigations, we can put Europe back at the service of its citizens. But Ms Vestager went further by pushing Member States to launch their own investigations. It thus defeated the argument of the legality of tax optimization schemes. These schemes are illegal under EU competition rules, but they are also illegal under national tax laws. This is a scathing disavowal in defence of Mr Juncker and his Luxembourg heritage. Above all, it is a highlight of the reluctance of our governments to act. Yes, these are difficult investigations, and yes, it is even harder when, over the last fifteen years, the means of justice and the tax authorities have been reduced.

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you for having put me on the list. First of all, I would like to thank the Commissioner. She has shown courage. It has finally tackled an issue that governments have shied away from: unfair tax competition, tax avoid- and the fact that Internet companies coming from America make their sales here but do not pay taxes, with tricks that the Member States have allowed. It is not a question of the maximum tax rates – Mrs Vestager has said nothing at all about tax sovereignty – but of the fact that competition law has prohibited, since the creation of the European Union, of allowing individual companies to have unequal conditions of competition. And that was the case. I hold my Irish colleagues in high esteem. However, Mr Kelly, the training system in Ireland may be as good as it is not the quality of the workforce, but only the tax preferences in Ireland, which mean that ten of the ten largest internet companies in the world are based in Ireland, nine of the ten largest pharmaceutical companies are based in Ireland, eight of the world's ten largest biotech companies are based in Ireland. I was with the ITRE committee at Google – 4 000 jobs Google Dublin and 3 500 from abroad for three or four years. These are the realities. That is why Mrs Vestager has achieved more than many speeches here. I would like to encourage you to continue to prevent and take action on this competition.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the commission's decision to consider Apple's tax treatment illegal is a courageous and very important decision, not least because it relaunches the debate on this issue – as you are seeing and hearing – with some useful elements of deepening.  We have come to the paradox that in Europe the 'how' and 'if' paying taxes has become the fundamental factor of competition between countries, this has happened in past years. This condition must be completely overcome for the benefit of the system of small and medium-sized enterprises, but also in terms of loyalty and relations between individual citizens and their institutions. Of course, we cannot always proceed – although it is desirable – with surveys that concern the individual company. We need common rules.  The first, as has been mentioned, is that of a consolidated tax base for all European companies. The second is that of country-by-country reporting – I would like to point out to you in this regard the delay in discussing the proposal that you have made and also the resounding limitations of the proposal. The principle is there, but if the threshold is high, and therefore excludes the vast majority of companies, very little remains in the material translation of a principle. Finally, I would like to say that it is also necessary to have a directive for the protection of whistleblowers, who cannot be regarded as people hostile to their community, quite the contrary: they play an important role for their community.  It goes without saying, however, that this will not be possible unless we also open the major chapter in the amendment of the European Treaties in the meantime, because taxation must become a Union policy.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President. Thank you, Commissioner. I also want to thank you and congratulate you on the decision. I find it intolerable that the Court has been used. However, taking into account the Advocate General's opinion on the case of Banco Santander and trade funds, I think we can be optimistic and trust that he will give them reason. And so we hope so. Look, Commissioner, I think there are two great lessons from your bravery. The first is that I believe that the question of combating tax evasion is a matter of political will. You've proved it. If there is political will, it can be done. And the second lesson, which I think is very important, is that you can twist the arm of those governments that are reluctant to cooperate. You can, you've proved it. And I think that is important: in the legislative proposals they have presented to us on country - by-country reporting, in which they will now present on a common taxable basis, be courageous, give the battle to the Council! Sometimes they say 'no, the proposal has to be measured, because other hand the Council will knock it down on us'. Be brave. Pass that courage on to your colleagues, because they have Parliament behind them and they will have public opinion behind them, too.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this is a special case but not a surprising one. I must congratulate the Commission and Commissioner, in particular. From what I have seen, this is serious piece of work, regardless of the fact that the final say will come from the Court.  I would also like to congratulate Apple, which has helped us to raise awareness of these problems with people and, hopefully, support for our work. So we should keep going. State aid is a legitimate tool to deal with this issue, because it is a competition problem and not about attacking national tax systems. The second countries should keep closing the loopholes in their tax systems as, for example, Ireland has done recently. We should do our job too, as we did recently in the anti—tax avoidance directive.  Last but not least, let me say that, if we have the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB), the debate about who should attribute the profit from the sale of iPhones in the European Union will be irrelevant, so I hope we will go for that.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: May I congratulate Commissioner Verstager on this perhaps undisputed but very courageous approach? It is also desperately needed, because the practice of tax avoidance is morally corrupt if tax laws apply to everyone, but not everyone is equal to that same law. It is also economically damaging if the coffee house does not have to pay the same as Starbucks or if a local bookstore does not have to pay the same as Amazon. This is economically damaging and morally corrupt, and that deserves an approach. I believe that the approach adopted by the Commission is more than justified because we are looking at a level playing field so that everyone has the same opportunities. My Irish colleagues would like to say that they cannot persevere in the role of vigilante, freerider. I myself come from a country that has sometimes played, or seems to play, a dubious role in the practice of tax avoidance. To be honest, I think I'm going to fit the penance. I also hope to see from the Irish colleagues that penance because one country must not divert the costs to another, in the role of vigilante. Finally, I would like to draw the comparison with Neelie Kroes, Commissioner Verstager's predecessor. It has not taken this approach. In fact, it defends American companies. She has thus become the lackey of big money in the service of American business and I see a big difference between then and now.

name: Michel Reimon (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, you have received a great deal of praise for your work. I would like to add my full voice to this. But there was also praise, which irritated me greatly, namely from national finance ministers. Several congratulated you and then immediately announced that they would like to have some of the billions that the judgment represents. This can only be populism or a complete lack of understanding, because competition law has not established that taxpayers or national budgets would be penalised by too little taxes, but that other corporations would be disadvantaged in their competition if Apple pays too little tax. That is what this verdict says. The verdict was correct, but we should think about the other side. If national finance ministers suddenly want more money now, then we in the European Parliament should urge you, as the Commission, to finally have a common European tax base, that we do not have competition between these states, but cooperation on tax matters. If competition law is the lever for constantly pointing this out, then I am happy and happy about it, and we should continue in this regard. It is clear again today that there is a rift here in Parliament too – on the right those who want national taxes and, on the left, those who want to cooperate. We offer the support.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Madam President, President Juncker spoke this morning about the need for a political Commission. The danger of having a political Commission is that sometimes decisions are taken based on politics and not on law; decisions that are more about agenda-setting. In my view, there was a clear determination on this case to get Apple in the midst of this investigation, irrespective of the damage done to Ireland. The Apple case will not be decided here, it will be decided in the European courts and the right of Ireland to appeal this decision must be respected by all of us. Ireland makes no apology for attracting investment to our country. The multinational sector in Ireland employs many thousands of Irish people, and indeed people from the European Union. In Apple’s case 6 000 real Irish people are living and working in those communities. The European business environment will not be helped by reinventing competition rules for the US, or indeed for other businesses that come into Europe. Chancellor Merkel recently made this point about sending out mixed messages. My final remark is this: the Commission now asks Ireland to collect this back tax from Apple while, at the same time, encouraging other Member States to seek a portion of it. How is this logical?  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Hayes, you say that 6 000 jobs are at stake. How many people would have been saved and better treated in your hospitals in Ireland? How many people could go through education and have better job opportunities if your government had the opportunity for public investment and other measures with the money that you are saving that company and many other companies with whom you made these secret tax rulings at the expense of the taxpayers in Ireland, and in other countries, including mine?

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – The issue in relation to Apple and tax: it has paid fully its tax in Ireland. I think you are misinformed about that. The question is the tax liability it may owe to other Member States of the European Union. That is why the ruling has been made. As you rightly say, I asked the question: how are we supposed to be the international tax collector in a circumstance where this money may well be owed to other Member States? This money does not belong to Ireland, this money belongs to other Member States where profits have been made. That is why, from a legal perspective, irrespective of emotional arguments, we need to get clarity on that, to be absolutely certain where this money was made, who it belongs to, because in relation to Apple in Ireland, their taxes are fully paid to Ireland.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am glad, I am relieved, that the European Commission has had this far-reaching competence in state aid law since 1957! It is only thanks to this far-reaching competence that there is now a pleasing result from their side. The European Commission's Apple decision is one thing: it is long overdue, and it is, of course, correct. And I wish you every success in the further work, because it is not just an Irish case, but there is very, very much else that is also to come.  For decades, multinational corporations, such as Apple, like Amazon, like Starbucks and so on, have been shifting their profits to low-tax states or using patent boxes to artificially small. It is not only the global corporations, but the governments that ultimately participate in these tax arrangements. And in this respect, it is incomprehensible, indeed sick, that Ireland does not want to have the billions owed back.  What we need now is total taxation of corporations; companies should set out their activities, their profits and their costs per country. The consolidated profit and thus also the taxes due are to be divided between the individual countries. This would put an end to the problem of profit shifts. This is because profits are to be taxed where they are incurred.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President. Finally, Mrs Vestager, European citizens can be recognised in a decision from the European Commission. Thank you! But that should be normal, right? May the European Union, which the Commission, address, address the issues that a single State cannot or will not do. That is, too, that must be , first of all, Europe. In any event, the need to use the State aid route illustrates the extent to which we need new regulation, fiscal harmonisation and avoid increasing unfair tax competition between Member States. That's the point. And that's also our contradiction. We demand that certain countries reduce their public deficits, but we do not know how to prevent other countries from taking ownership of what their ordinary income should be. Ireland will be fined for taxes that Apple has not paid to France, Spain, Greece, Germany, and so on. One hundred billion tax avoidance, the Commission itself estimates, simultaneously with a huge, huge public investment gap across Europe. The Apple case is the tip of an iceberg that can sink Europe or is the first sign of the change of course Europe urgently needs.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – (I congratulate you very much, Commissioner Vestager, on the courageous decision to force Ireland to recover the billions it has saved Apple in taxes, and I ask you to continue to investigate and prevent such agreements between Member States and large companies, including in my country, Portugal. This decision helps reconcile the Union and the citizens who, with SMEs, have borne the burden of austerity and excessive tax burden, while large national and multinational companies exploit the opacity of financial and corporate systems to exempt profits from taxation. The Irish Government's behaviour in appealing the decision is shameful and immoral, depriving Irish taxpayers and other states so out of colossal public resources.   The truth is that, two years after the Luxleaks scandal, tax dumping in the European Union remains rampant and unpunished, calling into question the internal market and capturing governments to serve interests contrary to those of their citizens, their States and the Union. As the European Parliament recommended in reports from the TAXE and ECON committee, we need reforms of convergence and fiscal transparency, which continue to be irresponsibly blocked by European Union governments, hidden behind the unanimity rule. This is the case with the fourth revision of the Directive on administrative cooperation, which requires the automatic exchange of information between Member States on tax agreements, but does not allow any public scrutiny of such agreements. We must require Parliament and the Commission to demand all the means to call on the Member States to their responsibilities, for more tax justice – for tax justice in the European Union – so that we do not continue to serve the organised financial and tax crime industry. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Gomes, you describe the decision of the Irish Government, endorsed by the Irish Parliament by 93 votes to 36, to repeal this decision as ‘immoral’. Do you consider decisions taken democratically to be immoral, and can any decision we take here in the European Parliament by majority decision be regarded as immoral?

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, sometimes democratic decisions are immoral, like for instance the decision to endorse the invasion of Iraq. This is an immoral decision because it calls into question the internal market, it violates loyalty among Member States, it leads Member States into a race to the bottom and it defrauds our taxpayers, the citizens and the SMEs who pay 30% more tax in the EU than big multinationals. It is absolutely immoral and it is absolutely unsound economically.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Apple did and does pay its tax in Ireland on the basis of the corporate tax rate and its activities in Ireland. That has not, I think, been very clear in this debate and some people do not seem to understand it. But what is clear is that Ireland did not collect tax on Apple’s activities in other countries, on the sales of Apple products, or on value that may have been added through marketing or innovation. That was to be collected in other jurisdictions, so it should be obvious. That is why the Irish Government is appealing this decision and why the Irish Parliament has agreed with the Government’s decision. We need certainty and clarity, and I think that the right way to decide on this is in the European courts.  I guess that there are opportunities, and there will be opportunities, to deal with corporations on an international scale. The OECD BEPs programme is the only way for us to do that, with countries sharing information on activities in their own jurisdictions. I think that the Irish Government has committed to working in that area and it is what we should all be focusing on, both here in the EU and in the US, and indeed internationally.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Apple has paid taxes for the ridiculous sum of EUR 50 per million in profit, taking advantage of the Irish tax law on 'stateless companies' and using as a shield one without employees, premises and activities. Congratulations, Commissioner, on your determination and courage. But the damage is not only fiscal or free competition, it is also ethical damage. I am trying to take a different approach: I would ask you not to touch your mobile phone for the time of my speech. It will struggle, we are addicted. This involves taking responsibility on the part of Apple, Samsung, Google and Facebook, the companies most involved in the issues of legitimate competition, the right to privacy, the right to be forgotten, to treat the dissemination of multimedia content more carefully. The violation of these rules, far from being just an accounting fact, reaps defenceless victims, such as Tiziana these days in Italy. "Think different" we start to say it too.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, we have repeatedly stressed in this Chamber that multinational companies producing super profits escape through intra-group transactions and other practices, which allow them to conceal their profits. These practices must be harshly punished. In the European Union, losses due to corporate avoidance, through a transfer of profits, are estimated at EUR 50 to 70 billion per year. However, the attitude of the European Union and, in particular, the Commission on this major apple issue is ambivalent. Because, at the same time as it condemns Apple to pay the price of EUR 13 billion, and it is right to do so, it does nothing for the large multinational companies that are fleeing tax having settled fiscally either in the Netherlands or in Luxembourg, where we also had the well-known Luxleaks scandal. Why is OLAF, while set up to crack down on corruption and fraud within the Member States, do nothing to help combat tax evasion within the European Union? When will similar sanctions be taken against the German and French companies featured in the Panama Papers?

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: –  Madam President, one important point that we seem to be forgetting is that when we talk about competition law, state aid rules are in place for a reason. Because once a company receives government support, a tax exemption, it gains a competitive advantage over the others. Therefore, not only do the state aid rules need to remain the exception rather than the rule, they also need to be applied across the board. People seem to be discovering this point only because we have a good competition commissioner. Beyond this point, what I want to stress is that I do not think that tax competition is a problem. Tax complexity is a problem. As long as there are exemptions available within very complex systems then big companies will be able to abuse them, and use the exemptions that the others cannot use, thus avoiding paying the taxes that others have to pay.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I would like to convey the message of the British citizen Neil Holmes Of Apple, with whom I fully identify. Apple's message is simple: if its store burns down, it doesn't call the fire department, if its store is robbed, it doesn't call the police, it's not allowed to use public roads to transport goods, because if Apple isn't as much of a tax payer as the rest of us, it doesn't have the right to use the services that are paid for by our taxes.  We also punish our own citizens for non-payment of taxes by imprisonment and make dubious agreements with corporations. Mr Juncker forgot to mention how this is actually done today, but we must put an end to this practice, because otherwise we will not explain to anyone that we are doing Europe for citizens and not for corporations and their profits.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – In addition to very creative phones and electronics, Apple also obviously has very creative accountants. Like other large corporations, which of course are taking advantage of this pointless tax war between some countries, which, of course, are taking advantage of the benefit of multinationals.  That is why, of course, congratulations, Commissioner, and I think we could also advise Mr Juncker on how to present measures to combat tax avoidance more ambitiously. We, of course, need more ambitious tax reform, which will also prevent such cases for the future, and it is good that, for once, we have started concretely. I think also lists and transparency in tax evasion needs to be done, as well as a common consolidated corporate tax base.  Tax avoidance is expected to cost the European Commission around EUR 70 billion a year, which is absolutely too much.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: Madam President, Mrs Vestager, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. There is no question that it is wrong for Apple not to pay taxes on billions in profits. And without question, it is right for you to act. I think the whole of Parliament supports you, and it is right that you are just trying to collect these taxes. As you can see, you already have the tools to act today, and you also have the courage to do so. Now my question is to you, and I would appreciate your answer very much: why do you think it is necessary to hit the strands and at the same time to achieve harmonisation of tax bases? The tools already exist today. Since 1991, that is to say for 25 years, we have known about these specific tax arrangements that the Irish Government has concluded. All we should have done was act! And you don't have to harmonise taxes or the tax base right away.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. – I would like to express my support for the Commission's decision to consider Ireland's tax treatment of Apple as unlawful State aid, so that apple company will have to return to the Irish State the EUR 13 billion of unfairly obtained tax savings. The fight against fraud and tax avoidance, the absolute priority of the S&D Group and the PSOE, is not directed exclusively against individuals, but also against those Member States which facilitate it, for example through the granting of opaque tax rulings (tax rulings) to certain multinationals, which violates free competition within the framework of the internal market , in addition to attacking the most basic social justice, at a time when Member States face increased demand from public services in the face of rising poverty, inequality and unemployment.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – EU national budgets lose €70 billion a year as a result of tax avoidance by multinationals. Combating tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning is therefore a priority. Concrete measures have already been taken at European level with the aim of taxing profits where economic activity actually takes place. Measures that, at the same time, create greater transparency, increase the efficiency of the tax system and make the tax system fairer, thereby ensuring fair competition between multinational and smaller companies. These measures are in line with the OECD's 15-point action plan to combat profit reduction and profit shifting, the so-called BEPS initiative. The issue is also given priority at G20 level, and the OECD has only recently been mandated to draw up a single list of all tax havens by next year. These steps signal the correct course of action. On the other hand, the decision of the European Commission to declare a tax agreement between the Irish Government and the US company Apple, retroactively with in 2003, as illegal aid and to demand a tax repayment of EUR 13 billion, poses potential risks to trade relations between Europe and the USA. It goes without saying that tax arrangements must be subject to strict control by national tax authorities. It goes without saying that Europe must combat corporate tax evasion. However, not at the expense of legal and planning security.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – Our admiration for the multinational, global Apple company is very high. But this admiration does not prevent us from noting that profits of tens of billions of dollars, made in many European countries, have been channelled and reported in the name of a shell company, registered in Ireland, where a tax of one percentage and even lower was paid (Financial Times, September 14/2016). The European Commission has asked Ireland to recover more than $14 billion from Apple. We welcome this decision by the European Commission. Global multinational companies need to understand that the tax avoidance phase has ended in countries where revenue-generating and profit-generating activities are actually carried out.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – (20) We have recently been bombed by Apple's famous case, which has been condemned by the European Union's Directorate General for Competition, which obliges that multinational to return the whopping sum of EUR 13 billion to the Irish State for tax benefits wrongly received between 1991 and 2014. At a time when the majority of European peoples are increasingly discrediting the European institutions, this initiative by the Swedish Commissioner responsible for competition is seen as a ploy designed to show service, seeking to create another façade of social concern.  Through a tax ruling, "Apple Sales International" was taxed at 1% until 2004, and then rose to 0.005%. Of course, the situation is scandalous. However, it is worth asking what the authorities have been doing since 1991. And it is also worth mentioning another relevant aspect. It is clear that this case constitutes a theft of tax revenues to the countries where Apple has actually made the profits. On the part of the CFP, we have already questioned the European Commission, seeking to know what this value was by country and what is being done to compensate these countries, many of them punished as is ours by austerity policies.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this debate. Thank you to so many Members – Giegold, Lambert, Gomes, Cato Scott, Nunes, De Masi, Da Vito, Caputo, all of these colleagues, among others – for their support and encouragement, which are very much appreciated: the encouragement to do what we do, which is very basic – to enforce competition law and our State-aid rules so as to ensure fair competition.  A lot of you mentioned small and medium sized businesses. These are businesses who pay their taxes. These are businesses who contribute by taking apprentices. These are businesses where you do not find the same statistics – as I am quite sure that my colleague Pierre Moscovici has presented to you – as you see with multinationals in terms of tax burden and taxes being paid. If taxes are not being paid by some, then they have to be paid by others and that is why it is not fair competition when some Member States hand out selective benefits.  A lot of you have been asking about the rule of law and the legal basis. This goes back to the very beginning, because our founding fathers saw very clearly that you cannot have fairness and fair competition if rich Member States or decisive Member States hand out selective benefits to some companies which are not available to others. The courts have said very clearly that State aid can come in many forms – it can be a very cheap piece of land, a very favourable loan, a bundle of cash in your hand, a tax benefit. But State aid it is, because it lowers your costs and lower costs are a thing which is not available to your competitors.  Secondly, the court has also said very clearly, talking about SMEs, stand-alone businesses and multinationals, that when multinationals do what they of course need to do, intra-holding trading, then there should be a resemblance to market conditions. Because stand-alone companies, the small and medium-sized businesses who are on their own, they have to do their thing in the market. Therefore the court has several times committed to the fact that we should be fair and transparent.  This is also why, Mr Hayes, this cannot be a political decision. It is built on the rule of law, it is built on due process, and it will of course be tested by our courts because of the completely legitimate opportunity for Ireland to appeal. But the court will hear nothing about party politics or emotions or gut feelings. They want the facts of the case, the court practice, how the case has been decided previously, and that of course will be tested.  Talking about what guidance we can give, we have too little case practice now to make great guidelines, but we have started to give guidance and to discuss in our high-level State-aid forum how to make sure that Member States can work with this, because obviously it is the responsibility of the Member States to make sure that national tax legislation, which is 100% a national issue, is upheld at the same time as what we have decided in common in EU State-aid rules.  Bernd Lucke asked about why just now. Well, actually this is a very good example of why we need transparency because this case was only opened because of hearings in the US Senate. This was where data came out that enabled the Commission to get concerned that something may not be as it ought to be, that there was a risk of State aid being handed out.  Mr Kelly asked about retroactivity. No, this is exactly the way things are always dealt with. If a benefit is handed out as a selective benefit to a particular company, it has to be taken back. We do that with a 10-year perspective from the date we asked the first question. This tax ruling has been in place since 1998, but we do not go back the whole way. We do exactly as we used to do: maximum 10 years’ going back. It is not retroactivity. Not a single rule has been changed. The only secrecy here was the tax rulings and that is why unpaid taxes have to be paid, just as well as other selective benefits will have to be repaid if they are seen to be illegal State aid. Last but not least, State-aid control cannot change tax legislation. If tax legislation is to be changed, it is done by the front door. It is either in the national parliaments, as done in Ireland a couple of years ago where the double Irish was done away with; or it is by unanimity in the Council of Ministers, and we do that by the front door to propose to ministers to make things easier. I am talking about the common corporate consolidated tax base. Not only will this make it more tricky for people to escape or to aggressively plan their taxation, but also it will make it much easier for small and medium-sized companies because they do not need to hire advisers in order to explain to them what they should be taxed on if they are active in more than one country, maybe just a few.  Sven Giegold asked about resources. What we are doing right now is trying to empower Member States to take as many State-aid decisions as possible themselves within the framework of the Treaty. I think we are up to 80 or 90% now, which frees up resources for us to look at the more tricky cases where you have a true cross-border issue and where fair competition is at stake.  I also, lastly, thank you for the encouragement to work within the OECD and the G20, because obviously this is a global matter. And obviously the highly qualified work done in the OECD to prevent base erosion and profit shifting is a cornerstone of what we can do in the future, because this is for all of us, and a global tax alliance is being formed in these years in order to ensure fair taxation, where everyone participates in paying their fair share, not more and not less, and where all the companies who pay their taxes to see that we have fair competition and that we are willing to work for it. Thank you very much for a very qualified and encouraging debate.

name: Ska Keller
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me first thank our excellent shadows for the great cooperation we had on this relocation file and the earlier relocation files that we have had – and the ones that might probably also still come.  The relocation decision that was taken a little over a year ago was from my understanding a real paradigm shift. For the first time we saw that solidarity was implemented for real in the area of migration and asylum within the Member States, and that is really good. The relocation programme of course has also a lot of floss and a lot of problems. There are too few places overall available. There is an arbitrary threshold of 75% of recognition rate, which really does not correspond with reality. There is a lot of bureaucracy that has been dealt with and many other problems. But still I believe it is a ground-breaking programme.  But there is one thing, one thing that is really threatening this relocation programme and the success that we could have with it, and that is the unwillingness of Member States to really use it, to fill it with life.  To date, and these are figures this week from the Commission, we have just 3 677 refugees relocated from Greece and only 1 064 from Italy. Let us remember that overall there are 160 000 places, which as such is not so much, but the figures that have been relocated over the past year, the people behind the figures – that number is simply not enough, and that is the problem that we are having here: Member States are not pledging places or they are not fulfilling their promises and this is especially a problem for unaccompanied minors who can hardly find any place anywhere. This is what is really threatening the programme, and some Member States have not relocated even a single refugee. What more can we do about European solidarity, where is the spirit of our Lisbon Treaty? Where is the spirit of working together if Member States are not able and willing to relocate even very small numbers of refugees? We have already this week discussed in plenary the huge numbers that a country like Lebanon has to deal with, while we as European Union Member States are not able to do at least our bit of the share.  I think this really has to change, also because the unwillingness to relocate has very concrete consequences for the refugees who are stuck in Greece or in Italy. We are talking about children who are sleeping in unbearable conditions, children who are not able to go to school, people who are not receiving proper medical care, refugees who are completely left in a limbo and who don't know what tomorrow will bring or where they will end up. Those are the real consequences that we see and we really have to address those big problems. With the vote tomorrow in the European Parliament, I think we as a Parliament we can give a strong signal that we will stick to the relocation decision, that we are committed to it and do not want to see it watered down by places being taken away from the relocation programme while there are still thousands of refugees in Greece and Italy and more are arriving on a daily basis. We need to strengthen the instrument rather than weaken it. We need to make it faster, much, much faster, and for that we have proposals. We also need to include a group like the Afghans, who make up a big part of the refugees arriving and who are in dire need of protection.
