I believe we can, but also we should, make the relocation programme a success story; a success story for the European Union, but much more for each and every refugee who is affected and for all those families and children who are stuck in Italy and Greece – we must give them hope and a perspective and give them the protection that they need.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to say to Ms Keller that I fully agree with her. The picture is as you describe it, Ms Keller, but let me assure you: making relocation succeed is still the essence of our comprehensive migration policy. We will not forget or let go of this priority. Let me remind everyone, as the President did this morning, that solidarity is legally enshrined in the Treaties and these are unanimously agreed by the Member States. Our objective is that everyone shares this solidarity, but we are not here to punish anyone. Member States have agreed to regulate, and that is legally binding. They have to do it. As the guardian of the Treaties, the Commission is here to ensure that Member States face up to their responsibilities and I can assure you this is what they have been doing over recent months. With more than 50 000 people in Greece, and more than 125 000 arrivals already in Italy, this is not only the sensible thing to do, it is the truly European thing to do, because what happens in Greece and Italy today might also happen in other countries one day. Ultimately, the impact of the migration crisis is felt not only in the frontline Member States, but also in the rest of the European Union. What is happening in Italy has a direct impact on your country or on northern Europeans, and a European challenge requires a European answer. That answer is relocation. Even here in this House we disagree. Believe me, it is always a pleasure to be here and debate with you. You have repeatedly enriched my knowledge and my judgement and I want to express my gratitude for that. What matters is that we agree on the political goal and on the importance of the success of the relocation scheme, because relocation, as I said at the beginning, is the most tangible proof of European solidarity towards both the people in need of protection, and the over-burdened Member States. Better sharing of responsibility among Member States is not a pull factor: it is an indispensable tool at our disposal for managing the refugee crisis, and the migration challenge in general, more effectively. This is the essence of our comprehensive migration policy, as President Juncker stressed this morning. We have to be realistic: while Greece and Italy are making great efforts, they cannot shoulder the responsibility alone and host and protect entirely all the asylum seekers present on their territory. So all Member States have to step in and take their share of the responsibility. We should not forget what these people went through, risking their lives to reach safety. It is time that they were all welcomed in countries where protection is offered properly, in line with our legal and moral obligations. But most importantly, in the long term, we have to avoid these people undertaking such dangerous journeys, by bringing them to Europe safely and legally. That is what resettlement is about – and this task is already starting now. Let me turn now to this specific proposal. The purpose of the Commission proposal was to make it possible for Member States to use the 54 000 unallocated relocation places for resettlement and other forms of legal admission of Syrians from Turkey to the EU. This is the essence of our proposal. We cannot support amendments that change the essential purpose or substantially modify the main elements of the relocation procedure as provided for in Council Decision 2015/1601. Some of the amendments that you propose to the original Council Decision could, in principle, be acceptable for us. We believe, however, that now it is time to pull together all our efforts to ensure the smooth implementation of relocation commitments. So far, 4 741 migrants have been relocated from Italy and Greece. We all agree that it is not enough, but numbers have been steadily increasing. We therefore have to keep going. The Commission and the EU agencies work closely with all the Member States to define and implement efficient procedures allowing Member States of relocation to assess each application properly and to increase both the numbers and the speed of relocations. Just yesterday, a relocation forum took place in Greece and tomorrow a meeting with all Member States will take place in Italy to find a common solution in order to increase relocations there too. Our aim is to address, to the extent possible, the objectives behind some of your amendments. For example: shorter procedures, more regular pledges, European Asylum Support Office (EASO) regular updates on eligible nationalities, etcetera. As we are approaching the last year of implementation of the relocation schemes, further action is urgently needed to accelerate their implementation. At this point, I want to reiterate the need for Member States to respond to the EASO experts’ call. At the beginning of August, I sent a letter to all Member States to urge them to increase the number of migrants relocated. I can assure you that I use all opportunities in bilateral meetings and at all Justice and Home Affairs Councils to remind Member States that it is the moment to demonstrate solidarity. The same goes for resettlement, where Member States should have all the tools in hand for delivering on their commitments. So far, since 4 April 2016, 1 583 Syrians have been resettled from Turkey under the 1:1 mechanism. We will have to increase this figure urgently. Our proposal today will introduce flexibility to ensure that all Member States that invest in relocation or resettlement will receive the necessary technical and financial support from the EU. Relocation and resettlement should be among the top EU’s priorities in the months ahead, and they go hand in hand. These are the real humanitarian needs – and all the Member States should stop merely talking about them and start acting and delivering more.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this dossier, for which I had the pleasure and honour of representing my parliamentary group as shadow rapporteur, is in fact a passage from the EU-Turkey agreement signed in March 2016, a commitment that is being made today on time on the issue of promoting the resettlement in Europe of Syrians hosted in Turkey.  I believe that the text examined in committee is perfectly balanced, thanks to the sensitivity of the rapporteur, Mrs Keller, and the other shadow rapporteurs, especially in so far as it eliminates the possibility for Member States to deduct the number of Syrians resettled by Turkey from the number of refugees that the Member State had undertaken to host under the relocation agreements from Italy and Greece. , and in so far as it is hoped that relocations will affect, as the rapporteur, Mrs Keller, she also pointed out, not only syrians, but also Eritreans, Iraqis and Afghans, in order to make the relocation mechanism more effective. That is why I believe that this text must be absolutely approved. But let me make one further point: I believe that the EU-Turkey agreement was an obligatory choice that is producing excellent results on the subject of containing the Balkan route, if it is true, as it is true, that the landings in Greece have been reduced by 90%. I hope that Europe will also show the same determination and efficiency in containing the Mediterranean trade, where, at the same time, there has been an increase in inflows, as was physiological.  On the subject of relocations, which the Commissioner mentioned, to date the data we can record are not at all exciting: we are talking about 4 000 migrants relocated compared to the 66 000 who, according to the initial project of 6 000 migrants per month, had to be relocated in these months from the start of that journey. That is why I hope that we will be able to reverse course on this issue and that Europe will show that it is up to the challenge that history presents us with on this issue.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, before I begin, I would like to congratulate Mrs Keller on the excellent cooperation we have had. Today's debate gives us the opportunity to take stock of European refugee policy. In May 2015, we committed to moving 22,000 refugees from outbreaks of war in Europe, but only 8,000 were resettled. In September 2015 we committed to moving 160,000 refugees from frontline countries - Greece and Italy - but relocated only 5,000. You understand that if we were a trading company, all the planners and implementers would have been fired. But we are the ones who hold the fortunes of people in our hands. So what's going on? Why are the Commission and the Council planning, but the Member States not implementing? Today President Juncker stressed to us that solidarity is not necessary, it comes out of the heart. That's an interesting observation. If we were talking about the Stability Pact and national subsidies, would he have the same relaxed view? Not to blame, however, he has brought, as proof of European solidarity, the investments of the European Funds in the various countries.  I will fully agree with the balance he proposes. No solidarity, no investment. And if at first we were right to have the excuse that Greece is no longer cooperating, that does not exist either. All refugees have been registered. The data is being processed and already 7,751 people are waiting with suitcases and papers in their hands to relocate. But the European door does not open. The Commission is also asking us today for refugees resettled from war zones in the various states, under particular schemes such as humanitarian visas and work visas, to be considered as meeting obligations to frontline states, Greece and Italy. That is to say, to let those who are already in Europe overwin the crisis in Greece and Italy. We describe the defeat of European integration. The triumph of national policies at the expense of our common approach. This defeat is seen even more clearly in the eyes of 7,751 people who are unfortunately waiting without response.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am a great supporter of European solidarity, to which Commissioner Avramopoulos has come back so often, but I would like to say that solidarity is very far from arbitrariness and centralism, and at the same time always implies genuine grassroots participation, in this case individual states. Unfortunately, I must say very clearly that the relocation decision, the whole relocation programme, bears the hallmarks of a programme burdened with arbitrariness and centralism. He does not see the difference between refugees and migrants, he does not see that refugees in these areas want to go only to selected rich European countries, and he does not see the complex context of this situation, so I cannot support Mrs Keller's report, and I urge you to look for other real forms of European solidarity that will give the opportunity to actually resolve this issue. Stubbornly persuasive arbitrary relocation will not solve our problems. Solidarity has a name – I am in favour of a version that is far from arbitrariness and means the real complicity and voluntary ness of the Member States.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I, too, would like to thank the rapporteur, Ska Keller, and all the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation. And I think we've done something good. As we all know, the name of our debate today is not really correct, because we are actually discussing the first part of the famous EU-Turkey refugee deal.  The Commission wants to apply the agreed relocation quotas for the one-to-one scheme between Turkey and Greece, and that is where I see the problem. In my opinion, the resettlement of refugees must not be at the expense of the resettlement quotas that have already been decided upon. We need both. Member States that have agreed to the relocation initiative must finally fulfil the obligations that this has enduring, as the Commissioner rightly called for. This is necessary not only to protect refugees, but also to support the border states.  Just as Jean-Claude Juncker and Commissioner Avramopoulos are just beginning, I would like to call once again for solidarity as a fundamental principle of working together. So far, as we have heard, the number of people resettled by Greece and Italy is simply too small. The human suffering that this unnecessarily causes or is prolonged may, for some, fulfil its objective as a deterrent, but that is not the way in which EU policy must proceed. We must not operate on the backs of fundamental and human rights as a flagship democracy, which I hope we all want to be. If what has happened so far is the implementation of common solutions in refugee policy, then we need much more tailwinds for the much-needed common EU asylum and migration policy.  Finally, I have to put a question to the representatives of the people's and family parties. How do you actually feel about refugee policy with the otherwise so high-end good of the family and thus with family reunification?

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with Ska Keller's report on the Commission's proposal.  I would, however, like to draw attention to the legal basis of the proposal. This is not the first time that the Commission has tended to exclude Parliament on the pretext of the emergency linked to sudden influxes of refugees; the other example is the agreement with Turkey. For a long time, however, inflows have not been sudden, so there is no reason why Parliament should not be fully involved as a co-legislator.  I would therefore ask you to consider my amendment. It highlights that the legal basis of the proposal – Article 78(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union – should be replaced by Article 78(2), which involves Parliament in its own right. This seems to me to be a good way of putting an end to the un democratic state of emergency in the field of refugees.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, only just over 4 000 refugees out of the 160 000 envisaged have been relocated from Greece and Italy to date.  Non-compliance with the commitments made by the Member States for the redistribution of asylum seekers from Greece and Italy demonstrates the lack of political will to respect the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities laid down in Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. In these two countries with the first accession of the European Union, the reception system continues to have enormous problems.  The aim now is to sacrifice a proportion of the resettlement relocation provided for in the EU-Turkey agreement, further debasing the supposed internal solidarity between the Member States. This questionable and blackmailing agreement, the result of the desperate and unsuccessful attempt to stop the flow of migrants to Europe, must not allow relocation and resettlement to be implemented at the expense of each other.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Mr President, the proposal to introduce temporary international protection measures for Italy and Greece is another grand plan of the European Union which will not be implemented in practice. Why, how can it be implemented when all states, in panic, close their borders and refuse to accept the migrants who are theirs. Really, what about that famous and empty phrase "a Syrian from Greece to Turkey, a Syrian from Turkey to Europe"? The Syrians go from Greece to Turkey with the eyedropper. Turkey, however, is throwing illegal immigrants into Greece with the "bucket". After her election failure, Mrs Merkel threatened to send to Greece 400,000 migrants accepted by Germany, taking out the dublin II treaty under review. In other words, Greece should become a vast concentration camp for unhappy and desperate people. To make our country once again a scapegoat, a scapegoat upon which all the failures of the European Union's foreign policy will be loaded. Moreover, you, Commissioner, Mr Avramopoule, fantasize about the creation of a European Coast Guard and Border Guard to do what the failed FRONTEX did. In other words, to become the traffic warden of those who move illegally to Italy and Greece. Nice guards you envision, Commissioner. Apparently such guards were in the hands of The Givenalis when in the Senate of Rome he wondered: 'Quis custodiet ipsos custodes?', that is, 'Who will guard us from the guards'?

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (
text: PPE). Mr President, the rapporteur, Mrs Keller and her colleagues, deserve congratulations on this important initiative today. Nevertheless, the decision, the amendment of which we are discussing today, we know, ladies and gentlemen, that it is not working adequately, because the positions that are committed are inadequate and implementation is slow and difficult. Only 3% of the original migration target has been implemented. We referred to 4,740 people who have left, out of a total of 160,000 decided over a two-year period by Greece and Italy. In Greece today there are 60,000 people, 13,500 on the islands, who are already in a difficult position, unaccompanied minors and not about 2,500 who have not joined the families, while the Minister responsible referred to about 5,000 unidentified people. This situation also makes asylum procedures more difficult. Relocation, ladies and gentlemen, is a practical demonstration and a strengthening of solidarity and a fair distribution of responsibilities. But today, the Commission has launched infringement proceedings against Greece for improper compliance with asylum laws and reception conditions. However, those legal actions that need to be taken have not been taken. It is precisely in order to repay the equal to those Member States which do not agree to implement the decisions. The key, ladies and gentlemen, to managing this serious European problem lies in the political will and solidarity of the Member States of Europe which means, quite simply, the implementation of European decisions.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It was a year ago that there was intense discussion in this House about the distribution of refugees already in the EU. There was talk of relocation, of hotspots. A large proportion of the Member States were prepared to play their part at the time. A year has passed. Additional refugees have arrived, and it has not even come close to dividing up the 160 000 people that were mentioned at the time. Thousands of people are still stuck – in Italy, in Greece, somewhere in between on the Balkan route. They fall into the hands of criminal smugglers, who smuggle them through the internal European border fences – for a lot of money. What remains are those who cannot afford it, especially children, old and frail people. I visited several camps in northern Greece in August, and I don't get these pictures out of my head. The conditions are catastrophic. People are hopeless and the situation is explosive. I don't want to imagine what it all will look like in winter. We must put an end to this situation, in the interests of the people who do not deserve it, in the interests of security and stability and, above all, in the interests of Greece. The solidarity of the Greek people is exemplary, but it must also be recognised by other Member States. That is why the Member States must finally stop hesitating and stand by their commitments. However, administrative obstacles must also be overcome; often it is not a lack of will, but different administrative cultures. This shows once again the urgent need to promote the Europeanisation of the asylum system. There is no way around creating legal entry opportunities. That is the great challenge we have.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, I would like to remind you that the total number that the Council of the European Union has decided to relocate within the European Union, from Greece and Italy, is 160 000 refugees. According to the data available to the Commission, by 12 September 2016 a total of 1,064 persons from Italy and 3,677 persons from Greece had been relocated. That's 4,734 people in total. I would also remind you that Mr Avramopoulos had committed himself to 6,000 relocations per month from Greece. The Commission's report also stressed this in order to meet the two-year deadline for the completion of relocations. In addition, Mr Avramopoulos, in written and other oral statements, reserves the right of the Commission to impose sanctions on Member States that do not comply. There are now 60,000 refugees in Greece. Greece cannot afford other refugees and illegal immigrants. Relocation must finally be implemented. And let us not forget, as a icing on the cake in all this, we have Mr. de Maiziere from Germany who now wants to send back to Greece refugees who have already gone to Germany. You realize that this situation cannot continue. This cannot be tolerated, in particular, in a poor country, such as Greece. Urgent measures must be taken, Mr Avraboule, and the after-elections must be completed.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The EU, that is, the world's richest and most prosperous continent, chose in the spring to make itself available for blackmail by an increasingly authoritarian Turkish government through the so-called Turkey statement – not to be confused with agreements – instead of trying to solve the challenges of migration policy within the EU on its own. Recent times show with all the desirability that the whole idea of disposing of our own responsibility for the reception of refugees to a country like Turkey was a failed air castle, doomed to failure. Having heard the ministers of several countries say that similar agreements should be concluded with countries such as Nigeria and Libya, I hope that we will now, once and for all, leave this behind and take responsibility instead. Of course, we should cooperate with countries outside Europe, including on migration, but there should be no doubt that we must put our own systems in place in our own countries in order to help humanely and dignifiedly those who have the right to international protection. I think we should work forward together. We do not need more Turkey statements without a functioning European asylum policy, based on solidarity and shared responsibility.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, today we are discussing a marginal amendment to the current legal regime for the relocation of refugees between the Member States of the Union. We are missing that this legal regime does not apply in practice and that Greece and Italy are forced to deal with a pan-European problem alone. In Greece, 60,000 refugees have been trapped and the costs of their settlement and living are borne by the Greek state, which at the same time is being asked by the Union to meet the enormous burden of an exorbitant public debt. The current Council Decision provides for 50 000 relocations from Greece to the territory of the other Member States of the Union, but 3,000 have taken place because the States of destination are making various obstacles. All Member States must immediately welcome their own refugees. If Europe wants to continue to exist, it needs solidarity among its members.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as an Italian, I thank you for your closeness and for the constant presence you have shown in even the most difficult times on our territory. We are also close to you because of all the difficulties you have with the Member States, with the selfishness of the Member States. You see, solidarity can't just be one-way. Central Italy has recently been hit by an earthquake and therefore we have a duty first and then to help our Italians. I find it difficult when, in front of a person who has lost his home, who lost everything in an earthquake, we have to place it in a tent, because the other structures are occupied by illegal immigrants.  So this means that Europe, all the more so, must take responsibility for refugees and illegal immigrants, because in Italy we can no longer do it, we must think first of the Italians. We absolutely understand who is fleeing war and must be welcomed by the whole of Europe, but those who have arrived as illegal immigrants must return to their country. Are we voting for funds for the reconstruction of the African economy? Well, but if these countries do not take back their citizens, then stop the trade agreements. The same applies to the Member States: stop when they do not take in refugees with European funds.  My appeal, and I will end here, Commissioner, is that of your next visit to Como, of your next visit to Ventimiglia. Como is famous and known for its beauties. Well, now it goes down in history precisely because it is affected and is oversoed by refugees and illegal immigrants because they have closed their borders. Same in Ventimiglia. This is not Europe and we ask you to intervene. Parliament adopted a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Madam Member, I would also like to ask you a very honest question as a Hungarian politician. You and your other Italian colleagues, your Greek colleagues, are right to complain about European inaction during this debate, but how is this in practice? That the refugee in question is signalling to you that he or she would go on, and then you are trying to look, and there is no receptiveness, or how does this work in practice, so why is the number of resettled so low?

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: Answer to a blue card question. First of all, we, as Italy, have never allowed ourselves and would never think of building a wall, that is what we give to the concept of solidarity. We welcome and save people, but we ask for the same solidarity with Europe and the other Member States, otherwise they will not take European funds. You are in Europe, for better or for worse.

name: Anna Hedh (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The humanitarian crisis that has arisen after the war in Syria has now been going on for years. As a means of resolving the unsustainable situation that many refugees live under in Greece and Italy, the Commission proposed that asylum seekers be relocated to the other Member States. The governments themselves have agreed to this and recognised that we must help the thousands of people stuck in Greece and Italy. But in practice, solidarity stays there and very little happens. Until July this year, only 793 people have been relocated from Italy and 2 033 from Greece. This inactivity is shameful and totally unworthy of one of the richest regions in the world, as europe actually is. On top of all that, the Commission and the Council now have plans to water down the system. It has been proposed that refugees who have come directly to the other Member States should be able to be 'counted off' from their relocation quotas. If this happens, I think it will be the nail in the coffin for the entire relocation system.  I and my political group therefore support the rapporteur, Mr Keller's proposal. The Member States must wake up and do what they have promised – give people who have fled for their lives an opportunity and a better start in the other EU Member States. We must see solidarity, and we must think 'It could have been us'.

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR).
text: –  Mr President, I believe it is high time to wake up and admit that relocation of asylum seekers is not a solution to the refugee crisis in general or the specific troubles in Greece and Italy.  First,  relocation in any significant numbers is impossible because of the political pressure within Member States, especially in those Member States where all migrants want to be relocated. Second, migrants arrive in Greece and Italy because from there they can continue to their preferred destination, in other words, the more we relocate the more will be encouraged to cross the Mediterranean.  In short, we should help as many people as possible in camps until they can return home, instead of relocating a small fraction of them within Europe. Especially, we must not delegate the control of our external borders to a country like Turkey.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the refugee crisis has unequivocally demonstrated the weaknesses in the Common European Asylum System. The very large burden it placed on the shoulders of several so-called "first countries of arrival", the discrepancies in the interpretation of the rules at national level. The relocation mechanism to Italy and Greece is also slowly and unsatisfactory, and now the emergency temporary measures will also apply to the implementation of another exceptional instrument – the agreement with Turkey. All this only shows us that the current system is not sustainable and goes after events. The reform of the outdated Dublin system is a step in the right direction, but in order to find long-term solutions, we need as soon as possible the adoption of a common European response to migratory pressure, based on the full sharing of responsibilities without exceptions.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Commissioner Avramopoulos on the initiative and thanking Mrs Keller for the quality of the proposals she has put forward and improving the initial text. As Ska Keller pointed out, one thing is relocation, another is resettlement. We need both instruments to deal with the problem. But we have two big problems: one is a scale problem, the scale is manifestly insufficient, the second is a slow problem.  The image we are passing on to ourselves and the image we are passing on to the world is that we are not solving either problem, nor are we resolving the fundamental reforms we need, to better equip ourselves to receive this influx of people, nor are we responding effectively to the humanitarian emergency. I said once in this house that we failed! We have been slow and insufficient in the aid we have provided, we have let national selfishness overtake a duty that is not only moral, but is also dictated to us by international law, the Geneva Convention, which gives us the duty to welcome people fleeing war, hunger, death.  And so I really enjoyed hearing Commissioner Avramopoulos stress the need for solidarity and this is the fundamental issue of this debate, more pressure on the Member States in order to fulfil what is their obligation. That's what we're all going to do right now.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Since the agreements with Turkey on migration, very few people have crossed the Aegean Sea. A number of European heads of government are therefore satisfied that the influx of refugees into their country has decreased and looks away when it comes to the tens of thousands of refugees who are stuck in greece in appalling conditions and still arriving in Italy every day. Or worse, some of my colleagues here also think it is an appropriate way to deter other potential refugees from making the crossing from Turkey to Greece. But there are also thousands of unaccompanied children in this group in Greece. Children who have fled to Europe without their parents or whose parents have not survived the journey. Children who have been unceremoniously locked up after arriving in Greece without education, without legal assistance and without proper supervision. Children in a desperate situation because there seems to be no place for them in Europe. Of the promised redistribution of more than 66 000 refugees from Greece to the rest of Europe, less than 4 000 people have actually been transferred to another European country after a year. That is the same number that arrived on the Greek islands in one day less than a year ago. Why are these unaccompanied minors not given the highest priority in relocation? And what are our political leaders worth if they cannot ensure that Europe keeps its promises and cannot at least ensure that fundamental rights are protected for all, but especially for the most vulnerable, such as the unaccompanied children? As far as I am concerned, we are starting today to redistribute these young people to other Member States. Because my Europe does not abandon these children, but cares about them.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I have traveled very often for the last two years in refugee camps and meet people. And I have had the opportunity to speak, Commissioner, to people who declare themselves refugees, many of whom are economic migrants, about 80%. But let's admit there are refugees. And you know what they told me? They only told me three countries they wanted to be relocated to. One country is called Sweden, the other country is called Germany and the third country is called Great Britain. And Commissioner, if these people do not want to go to the Czech Republic, they do not want to go to Estonia, they do not want to go to Romania, how do we get these people there? How are we going to keep these people in this country?  I welcome the agreement with Turkey, I think it is very good, and I think we should help refugees. We are and must be in solidarity, but please do not invent stupidity as a compulsory distribution and do not punish someone for perhaps not wanting or cannot accept someone under the quota. After all, we see here that this mechanism is not working, and I believe that we need to think about the way in which it is enforced. And I don't think enforcing it is happy. Commissioner, please think again about my words.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, I would like to applaud the European Commission's proposal for application legislation to implement the realocaction of refugees. I believe that this proposal can help speed up the realocation of those who are actually refugees and need our help.  Ladies and gentlemen, I have been going through the draft report of the European Parliament very carefully by my colleague Ska Keller, and I could not believe with my own eyes how some of the amendments completely amend the commission's original proposal, so fundamentally that it cannot be accepted in its current form. While the Commission's proposal consisted in the possibility of including Syrian refugees resettled from Turkey in the real-life quota, the new proposal from the European Parliament does not take this into account. The Commissioner has already made himself clear and does not agree with this amendment. Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the European Parliament will adopt sensible legislation and the Commission will carry out its task.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we all know, the scale of migration has reached worrying levels, especially in the Member States of first entry. The relocation plan must therefore be implemented in order to react quickly to the difficult humanitarian situation in Greece and to prevent the deterioration of the situation in Italy, where the arrival of many migrants continues on a daily basis.  I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur for insisting on the need for the Member States to respect the commitments previously made in the field of relocation, by making the agreed posts available quickly until they reach a rate of around 6 000 relocations per month, while unfortunately we know to date that the Member States have made only 7% of the number of posts available. This situation is particularly serious, then, in relation to the situation of unaccompanied foreign minors who, on the contrary, should always have priority, and therefore again in this case.  It is essential for the European Union to manage the migration crisis by implementing solidarity measures in accordance with a system of responsibility shared by all Member States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, solidarity between Member States is the basis for solving this oversized problem that we face, but there is no solidarity. We have to tell ourses ourses ourses here. Italy and Greece bear a huge burden.  Without the help of all european union countries, we will not solve the problem. But I don't see that we're going to solve it that fast. We must stand both financially and politically and morally and in every other way behind Italy, behind Greece, behind all those people who are miserable and miserable and who are on the Greek islands or somewhere around Italy.  But we are talking about the consequences, and we need to talk about the cause, about the wars, about Syria and the war in Syria. Today, the U.S. and Russia are negotiating some new peace. And where's Mrs Mogherini? Mr Juncker said today, very clearly, that Mrs Mogherini must also sit at the negotiating table, as the consequences of the war are felt by Europe, not Russia or the US.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Unfortunately, the real situation, Mr Avramopoule, reflected in the daily lives of the citizens of Greece and Italy, due to illegal immigration, is far from clear from the findings of the political bodies and the rapporteurs of the reports. Simply put, those in Parliament and the Commission who deal with immigration issues are ineffective and trustworthy. Of course, the Greeks should know and expect nothing positive from a Minister who now makes the Commissioner. The teaching of the ancient Greeks was based on a basic principle: do not focus on the treatment of the problem, but investigate the causes of it. No matter how many reports we vote on, if we do not fight the causes of illegal and mass immigration and defend our national identity, status and heritage, we will end up with a de-European Islamic Union with only Sharia law. It is not racism to demonstrate the problem that is covered under the cloak of persecuted and human suffering. Racism is to force the violent integration of different ethnicities and cultures.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our group agrees with the Ska Keller report.  I appeal precisely so as not to confuse the instruments of internal and external solidarity. Mr Juncker also recalled this morning, during his State of the Union address, that solidarity is an important instrument and therefore called on all Member States to reduce their differences in the reception of refugees, particularly as regards minors, unaccompanied minors and women.  Today I am calling on all Member States to overcome their selfishness. All this must be done for the benefit of Italy and Greece, so as not to leave them alone. So today we must direct all our efforts to call on all Member States to implement solidarity between them.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by expressing my thanks to all of you for your contributions to this very interesting debate tonight.  I could not agree more with you on the need for Member States to relocate more and more asylum applicants, and in parallel on the need for more resettlement. We have invested a lot in making relocation and resettlement work in practice and we have started to see some good, positive results. However, our efforts must now significantly accelerate. As I told you, I have sent letters to the Ministers and I am planning direct communication with Ministers to encourage them to send a signal of commitment. I would like to see real progress ahead of the Justice and Home Affairs Council and, in particular, ahead of the October European Council. To conclude, I thank you for coming here and sharing your frustration about the lack of results. But here, in this Chamber, most of us agree: what is important is that you reach out to your governments and you urge them to pledge. What is equally important is to address European citizens directly about our values, about our own historical past, and about the need to show solidarity to those in need today. Dear Members of Parliament, do not limit yourselves to this Chamber. You know better than anyone else that it was never an easy task to implement our EU migration policy and that half of the victory will be the right communication. As always, I need and I count on your support. Since I was asked some questions by my Greek friends here I would like to shift to Greek now. Mr Kyrko, first of all I would like to thank you for the question. First of all the numbers. There are currently 4,741 refugees relocated from Greece and Italy. The total number of refugees who have relocated directly to Europe is close to 10,600. You're asking me if I'm satisfied. Of course I'm not satisfied and I've said it publicly many times, by the numbers at least, obviously not yet. However, progress is being made and procedures are accelerating. As far as financial aid is concerned, as Mr Chrysogonos mentioned earlier, Greece has received and continues to receive aid, both in the form of emergency funding and funds through the national programmes which absolutely must be absorbed. As I said earlier, speeding up and increasing relocations is the main topic of discussion with my counterparts in every bilateral contact and in every Home Affairs Council. I even sent a letter to that in early August. It is the Commission's priority and mine. As President Juncker stressed this morning, the concept of solidarity is legally binding on the Treaties. Well, yes, relocation has to work. Not just to relieve countries under strong pressure, such as Greece and Italy. Because, in fact, they are taking on a disproportionate burden, but because every other European country may at some point find itself in the same position. Above all, because at these crucial moments for the political future of Europe, everyone must rise to the occasion. This means that they must show solidarity and responsibility in practice and respect the decisions taken at European level. I repeat, in conclusion, that relocation remains a priority for the Commission and my own personally. Thank you for your attention.

name: Ska Keller
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the shadows, who have been so helpful in the whole process, and have also been enduring all these emergency procedures that the Commission has been giving us as a present, so to speak. But I would also like to thank the Commission, especially for the helpful numbers that we always get up—to—date. Thank you personally, Mr Commissioner, for your personal efforts in the whole story. I think they are very helpful. But I still do not agree with your latest proposal, because if you say – and indeed there were some bureaucratic problems in the beginning – that now things are starting to run more smoothly, why should we change the path? Those 54 000 places are urgently needed in Greece and Italy – people are still arriving on a daily basis. The numbers are not low, not at all. And resettlement: you said it is very important, and I guess most of us will agree, it’s extremely important. We should do it, but we should not do the one thing to the detriment of the other thing – we cannot calculate the numbers so that we take a bit from the big part and put it somewhere else and say the part wasn’t so big from the beginning. I think we should rather extend the programme and make sure that the Member States resettle people; it’s absolutely needed. But we should not do it to the disadvantage of the relocation program, which in itself is already very, very small. The European Union, I believe, can – and must – do more, and the vote tomorrow will be a vote to support the relocation program, so it’s full support for you and full support for the relocation. We need to put it together, and let’s not diminish the relocation numbers, which are already so small.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – Improving the return rate of persons not entitled to international protection is vital for maintaining the completeness of the EU's asylum system. The initiative to provide a European travel document for the return of third-country nationals who are in the EU illegally is to be welcomed. Europe and refugees have the same interest: that refugees can return to their home countries as soon as the root causes are eliminated. To do this, you don't have to bring them here and distribute them, you have to take the help there. The EP's report, rather than confined to the technical form of the EU-Turkey agreement, seeks to expand and speed up the scope of this misguided mechanism, which will only make the functioning of this already functioning system even more impossible.  We believe that in the hope of distribution, people smugglers will have to take more and more vulnerable migrants on their way to Europe, risking their lives. On the other hand, the experience of migrants moving from poorer, more modest EU countries to Germany or Sweden within days. Therefore, Hungary, together with other Member States, opposes the mandatory form of re-allocation on principle. Solidarity should not be limited to the allocation of migrants according to quotas, including efforts to protect Europe's external borders and humanitarian aid aimed at improving the living conditions of camps close to the home of refugees. The lack of clarification on the issue of migration also leads to a disruption of the application of the Schengen system, which threatens the entire European integration and internal market.

name: Laura Agea
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Thyssen, ladies and gentlemen of the shadow rapporteurs who have worked with me on this report, I welcome the presence of Commissioner Thyssen, but tonight I am going to speak to an empty chair, which is that of the Council, to which these indications are addressed or should be addressed, because then it is the Council that should, once we have heard our opinion, take this into account.  Last year we did so, we worked on what used to be a common vision of employment and social policies for the benefit of the citizens, and yet the Council was highly disinterested in them, spookyly pretended that we did not exist and did not represent 500 million citizens. In this case, I would like to thank my colleagues who, for the second time, wanted to resubmit the same recommendations with me, because in its spooping the Council simply wanted to go back to its initial positions.  We are here, for the second time , and perhaps we will do so next year or in two years' time, to ask to be heard as representatives of 500 million citizens, because we constantly interface with them, we know what their suffering is, because suffering is spoken of when we talk about the citizens of Europe: they are reduced to exhaust, they have no work , there are no social protections, there is no lack of employment protections and we are dearly 'bypassed' by the council's spat, by the presumption, by arrogance, which cares what we are saying and does exactly the opposite, with the clear and obvious result – because you see it all in your countries – that the objectives of the 2020 strategy to reduce poverty have tragically failed. We had to reduce poverty, and in fact we have reached 200 million poor citizens in Europe, an increase of 5 million poor people in recent years.  And instead of listening to us and understanding that there are essential and indispensable policies to help them, there is an empty chair, and they should be ashamed not to fill that chair and not to listen to what we have to say! Last year we gave many indications, this year they are exactly the same: social protections, employment policies with public investment to restart the economy, assistance, minimum income policies that guarantee support for poor families, minimum wage ... We had said a thousand important things, none of them were taken into account. Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for supporting me in this and thank you, Council, wherever you are.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur for her very constructive role in preparing, together with the co-rapporteurs and as she did last year, a comprehensive report which is largely in line with the Commission’s proposal. As you know, the Commission decided to maintain the guidelines adopted in 2015 for this year and the Council agrees with our approach. We consider that the employment guidelines adopted in 2015 are still valid and relevant in today’s economic and social context. The Commission regrets that your position was not taken into account by the Council when adopting its decision in 2015. Nevertheless, I would like to assure you that the Commission paid due consideration to the opinion expressed by Parliament and has tried to accommodate it in several ways. A good example in this respect is the emphasis we put on the role of the social partners. The European Parliament has stressed on several occasions the need to enhance the role of the social partners when talking about employment and social policies. In the guidelines adopted in March 2015 social partners are invited to play, for the first time, a prominent role. This reflects the position you have often taken and which we fully share. The Commission agrees with you on the importance of developing inclusive and integrated labour markets. This is highlighted in the annual growth survey and reflected in the employment guidelines. The Commission monitors progress in these areas in the context of the European Semester and has addressed recommendations to the Member States to push reforms forward where relevant. I am glad that the report emphasises the importance of employment and social considerations in the European Semester. In 2016 the Commission has considerably reinforced this dimension in the European Semester and we will continue to place employment and social issues at the core of the semester in the future. The inclusion of three new employment indicators in the Macroeconomic Imbalances Procedure (MIP) scoreboard is a concrete deliverable on the Commission’s commitment to strengthen its analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, as you recommend in your report. The indicators are included in order better to capture the employment and social dimension of imbalances and adjustment processes. As regards your recommendations on national minimum income schemes, the Commission is committed to promoting among Member States adequate income support, which is one of the pillars of the 2008 Commission recommendation on active inclusion. This has also already been reflected in the country-specific recommendations addressed to those Member States most concerned. The Commission also agrees with you on the importance of making progress towards achieving the Europe 2020 targets in the employment and social areas. This is one of the key elements that the Commission takes into consideration when deciding on country-specific recommendations within the European Semester. I am available, of course, if you have comments or questions.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I agree with rapporteur Laura Agea that the absence of the Council is inexplicable, especially on this subject. I remember Polish presidency of the 2011 European Parliament – the Council has always been represented by representatives Polish and has participated in almost all the debates. It is truly unacceptable that these standards, which have been introduced in Parliament, are not being respected today. Especially today. The European Parliament, in its institutional system, is the voice of citizens and seeks to represent their interests in the best possible way. In this regard, we are criticised for the fact that, with regard to the employment guidelines, the Council of the European Union has not taken into account the recommendations of the European Parliament in the past year. On behalf of the PPE Group, I would like to express my hope that this will not happen again in the future. In times of democratic deficits, we cannot afford to disregard the voice of Europeans.  Job creation remains a priority for the coming months. It requires investment in projects that facilitate business start-up, as well as the functioning of small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the main source of employment in the European Union. Another challenge is to improve the transition from education to the labour market, and this requires investing in the right skills that are needed. The problem of non-compliance with labour market requirements has been known for a long time, but we have still not been able to fully respond to it. The centre of our activities should be young people who are currently in an extremely difficult situation. We must also not forget about seniorcitizens, who are an indispensable part of the labour market in a situation of demographic decline, and of building a stable social security system for workers, based on seniority and developed rights. All these actions and investments, including expenditure incurred by Member States, should respect budgetary discipline. The fact that Europe is out of crisis today and that economic parameters are improving is due to austerity and rationalisation of expenditure. In this context, I would like to draw attention to today's words of Jean-Claud Juncker, who spoke of the fact that the Stability and Growth Pact cannot become a pact of flexibility. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – We know very well there is an important link between education and employment. Nevertheless, education is not a competence of the European Union. At the same time we heard President Juncker saying today that Europe should be more social. If so, we need more social policies and more policies in terms of education. Would the EPP agree about making education a competence of the European Union?

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – There is no need for education to be a competence of the European Union. It seems to me that the principle of subsidiarity is the most important principle and we should implement it even more in the European Union, especially now, because of the criticism we hear from our communities. One does not bother one another. Education does not have to be a competence of the European Union in order to be able to carry it out well. We implement social policy in Europe without these EU competences and implement it well. We can do the same with education.

name: Javi López
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, today the European Parliament aims to persist. That is what we are doing today with this report, having collaborated with our rapporteur, Laura Agea. To persist in our opinion and in our view on employment policies and to point out, in this case humiliatingly, with an empty chair , to denounce that the Council is unable to hear our opinion. The truth is that we thank you for having the complicity of the Commissioner and the Commission in this very important aspect. It is very important that our proposals were not heard last year, but that this year we continued without hearing the work that this House does. Because, of course, it is a lack of institutional respect and also calls into question some of the mechanisms we have between institutions to make decisions. The Council believes that things are going very well, that employment in Europe is very positive, that we are going in the right direction, that we have no problems and that our opinions and our view are both expendable. But if we look at the numbers, today we have an unemployment rate above 10% in the European Union. It is only necessary to point out some other areas of the world, such as the United States, with a minimum unemployment record below 5%, after the economic crisis has passed. And we have five million more people at risk of social exclusion. They have to listen to our opinion: better social protection and greater social protection networks, which we can have; more active employment policies, which obviously require investment; and, as we have done so far, to place our social indicators in the European Semester at the same level as macroeconomic indicators. The Commission has taken a very successful decision in this regard, pointing out three more social indicators. Because the labour market is changing: precarization, internal devaluation, lower wages, temporaryity and, also, workers who are poor today are problems in our labour market that need to be solved.

name: Amjad Bashir
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, in this report the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has added a long wish-list to the guidelines to Member States that talks a lot about a high level of employment and decent working conditions. Of course we all want this, everybody does, but the reality is that if we want any of these hopes and dreams to come true, if we want more jobs for our young people, serious labour market reforms are needed to make the workforce more flexible and help businesses to grow. In the UK, this process began in 2010 with the new Conservative Government and figures released today show that unemployment is now at 4.8%, with three quarters of new jobs in the past year being full-time work. But the main issue I want to raise here is an issue of competence. With this report the European Parliament is trying once again to have more and more say over policies. We firmly believe it should remain a competence of the Member States. As a group, we have long held the view that the sharing of good practice in this area is a good thing, but adding a long wish-list to what has already been agreed by the Member States is not the right approach. Let us look at what works well and help to share that experience for the good of all Member States, our citizens, and especially for our young people.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all can I thank the rapporteur, Laura Agea, for her constructive and important work on this proposal. This year the Council decided that the 2015 employment guidelines should be maintained for 2016. This means that they could, in fact, ignore the European Parliament twice because last year too our suggestions were effectively ignored. However, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, in an effort to ensure that did not happen, came forward with this document under the rapporteurship of Laura Agea. Our message to the Council this evening is we do not expect to be ignored for a second time, and I want to thank the Commission for its support on this matter. I am pleased to say that many of the ALDE Group priorities were included in this report and these include, first of all, the promotion of entrepreneurship, in particular youth entrepreneurship. This we believe can be achieved by, for example, introducing optional entrepreneurship courses at schools and colleges, and in the creation of student enterprises also. We asked for greater efforts to be made in ensuring a smooth transition from education and training to work, and one of the practical suggestions we put forward is to make it possible for young people to convert several months’ unemployment benefit, up front, into a start-up grant. Some of the other ALDE priorities that are included in the document are supporting the creation and the growth of micro, small and medium enterprises, and one way we can do that is to cut red tape and get rid of unnecessary bureaucracy. ALDE also supports the call for effective investment in high-level and inclusive education and, in particular, for vocational education. Finally, I want to say again that I agree that the rapporteur. Unless the Council takes our views on board, we are wasting our time here but worst of all, European citizens are being badly served.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I too would like to thank Mrs Laura Agea for her good work and for our good cooperation. Last year, the Council took no account of Parliament's report on employment guidelines. This year, we are discussing again in the same futile process, without the presence of the Council. In my view, this is yet another great example of the large democratic deficit that exists in the Union. The neoliberal policies of harsh austerity and memoranda imposed on the peoples show the final face of the Union. Deregulation of industrial relations, downward pressure on wages and labour rights, the dissolution of the social state and social dumping are imposed on the peoples in order for multinationals and large capital to benefit. Certainly, the targets of increasing employment to 75% by 2020 and raising the standard of living above the poverty line for our 20 million fellow human beings, reaffirmed in the report, are entirely in agreement with us. We can also participate in a debate on the minimum guaranteed income if this is in the interests of workers, in particular, the low and middle classes. However, despite all the good reports on workers' rights, we cannot support changes within the framework of the Stability Pact and the European Semester. We insist on the abolition of these tools, which impose unpopular policies of poverty and harsh austerity. That is why, as a GUE/NGL group, we will abstain from voting on the employment guidelines report.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would also like to add the voice of my Group to that of the rapporteur. This attitude on the part of the Council is an ongoing problem and it is not just about timetabling. It is a pity because there are a lot of good ideas in this work this evening. Our governments are generally short of good ideas. We can see this in the continuing high levels of unemployment in many of our countries – and, indeed, low levels do not always mean everything is perfect. I note that my British colleague totally forgot to mention the number of people who increasingly are on zero-hour contracts and, of course, that is a national competence and nothing to do with the European Union. It is hardly inclusive growth. They are also failing to tackle discrimination on the labour market, so talent and qualifications are going to waste. But I would also like to point out that we have a clear risk here of forgetting that we have to deal with the challenges of climate change, which figures as a clear goal of the 2020 strategy. I would like to thank our rapporteur and the committee for trying to rectify that in our opinion on the labour market guidelines.

name: Tim Aker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, our referendum on 23 June was a very British revolution. As I was watching the results come in, it was the working class areas, it was the traditional Labour areas that were coming in with massive votes to leave the European Union, and it was obvious why. It was obvious before the referendum was even called. You talk about employment policies, well let us look at the biggest issue that has faced the United Kingdom for several years now: that of uncontrolled, unfettered, mass immigration. Now I do not blame people wanting to get a better life for themselves and their family. If your minimum wage is GBP 1 an hour, and you have the ability to go to a country where the minimum wage is GBP 8 or 9 an hour, you would do that, and I do not blame people for doing that. The people I do blame are the politicians who forgot that they were public servants. They forgot that they had a responsibility to their constituents, who are their employers. As public servants they have to make sure that they do everything within their power to improve the lot of their employers, and they have not. It was the Governor of the Bank of England who sealed the deal for the referendum when he said that mass immigration had led to incredible wage compression. Wages had fallen, jobs had stagnated, and why? Because people were coming in, taking a minimum wage that was much above their own wage, but big business cottoned on to this. The government in allowing for in-work benefits meant that big employers did not have to increase wages because the taxpayer will top up the bill. Fortunately, with our Brexit, we have made sure that we can fix this problem and there is not a day that goes by when I do not thank the British people for giving us our freedom. But I also worry day after day, because those of you here who cling to the euro, who cling to free movement and the unreasonable policies of this Union, you are condemning your futures, your youth, to misery and unemployment. And when you get your referendums, which the people will actually force upon you, you will have to change, or your constituents will change you.

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – According to the European Commission, there are two major problems in the Netherlands. Because there are too few people with permanent appointments, the Commission says that the redundancy protection should be lifted. However, this will cost vulnerable workers their jobs. And because there are too many one-man companies, the Commission believes that they should be forced to close down with higher taxes. However, these one-man companies were set up by people who first lost their jobs due to the influx of cheap labour from the Eastern European Member States, and this has been encouraged by the Commission. I have asked Commissioner Thijssen questions on both counts. Not only did it spend three months formulating an answer, but it also found unemployment of 7% to be quite acceptable. She has not responded to follow-up questions on my part two months ago. Mr President, the Commissioner apparently cannot or will not answer questions about this and she does not understand the situation in the Netherlands. We can therefore miss this Commissioner as a toothache, as well as her recommendations.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, we are again talking about employment policies, about major projects through which the vast majority of the unemployed will finally find a decent job with which they can not only survive but live decently with all the meaning of the word. However, the Peoples of European Peoples are tired of constantly hearing wishful thinking and beautiful words because, in addition to our discussions, they also see the practical implementation of the Union's policies. You know the result: in Greece the policies of austerity and memoranda, with the blessings of the European Union, have led to an economic recession greater than that of the Second World War. They have led to a more than quadrupling of unemployment, which we are currently trying to find ways to combat. The policies imposed by the Union, the ideological obsessions and the clusters of a large proportion of European politicians have led to this result. Not only in Greece of the economic crisis, but throughout Europe the poor became poorer and the rich richer. One is the solution to all this: production. Only when production is reassessed in all the countries of Europe will we be able to combat unemployment. However, production cannot be achieved by Union policies and by the various preferential imports from third countries which directly hit European producers.

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: – Nixtieq nibda jiena wkoll billi nirringrazzja lil Laura għax-xogħol kbir illi għamlet biex illum nistgħu nitkellmu fuq dan id-dokument importanti flimkien max-Shadow Rapporteurs kollha. Għax jiena ngħid illi kien hemm sforz komuni fil-kumitat tax-xogħol u l-qasam soċjali biex illum għandna dan id-dokument importanti ħafna għaliex fl-aħħar mill-aħħar jitkellem fuq ix-xogħol, ix-xogħol illi naturally huwa importanti ħafna għal diversi setturi.  U minkejja li qed naraw irkupru ekonomiku, irridu niftakru li dan huwa fraġli ħafna. U rridu ngħidu wkoll li, minkejja illi qiegħda tiżdied ir-rata tal-impjiegi, but għadna lura ħafna, jiġifieri anke f'diversi reġjuni li għandna madwar l-Ewropa.  Jiena niskanta kif iqum jitkellem rappreżentant tal-EFDD, is-Sur Aker, li huwa ferħan illi issa pajjiżu ħa joħroġ mill-Unjoni Ewropea. Ma naħsibx li għandna bżonn nisimgħu lezzjonijiet mingħandu dwar kif se mmexxu minn issa 'l quddiem għaliex naħseb li l-unika preokupazzjoni li għandu jkollu hu issa hi, mingħajr is-suq internal tal-Unjoni Ewropea, kont qed nistennih jitkellem u jgħidilna dwar kif se joħolqu l-impjiegi fir-Renju Unit, issa li ddeċidew illi joħorġu mill-Unjoni Ewropea.  Imma kif ħa nkomplu mmexxu din l-Ewropa tagħna? Naħseb m'għandna bżonn nieħdu lezzjonijiet mingħand ħadd. Kif qal il-President Juncker dalgħodu, l-Ewropa se tibqa' għaddejja, l-Ewropa se tibqa' miexja, u l-Ewropa għandha quddiemha l-isfidi kif għandhom il-pajjiżi kollha tad-dinja.  Jiena light jiddispjaċini ħafna wkoll li m'hawnx il-Kunsill preżenti, kif qalet tajjeb Laura u dawk kollha li tkellmu qabli. Nieħu pjaċir but nisma' lill-Kummissarju illi qiegħda tagħmel ħilitha kollha magħna. U jiena naħseb qatt ma rajt, f'dawn it-tnax-il sena illi ili f'dan il-Parlament, Kummissarju illi huwa daqshekk dedikat ma' dan ix-xogħol, ma' dan il-qasam soċjali illi għalina huwa kruċjali.  Hija importanti l-istrateġija li għandna quddiemna tal-2020; huma importanti ħafna miżuri oħra li aħna adottajna u li għad irridu nadottaw fil-futur. U allura ma naqtgħux qalbna, inkomplu mexjin, u grazzi, sabiex ilkoll flimkien nimxu biex nagħmlu din l-Ewropa aħjar milli hi light.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I too would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the really good work they have done, as well as the Commission. It is clear that we have reached agreement here in Parliament, that we have worked together to consider how labour market policies in the Member States can be positively influenced. We have big problems. These cannot be resolved in Sunday speeches, but everyone must pull together. When it comes to combating unemployment, combating poverty and social exclusion, that must be a priority for us, but also for each individual Member State. And for that we need concrete measures in the field of employment and social policy. We also need help for people who live and work across borders. The transferability of pension rights and social rights must be guaranteed. We in Europe need to do better in this. These are things that we also experience in our daily work. The issue of education has also been raised.  We only win the battle for competitiveness in this world if we have the best minds. In other words, when it is important to invest in education, in education and training, for the future of Europe as a location, we must pull together. And we need minimum wages and social standards. We heard it this morning in the President of the Commission's speech: we need to get better at this, and the Member States must do their homework on this. That is why we also expect the Member States to listen to us. It is the concrete things that people here in Europe feel. Where they have problems, they expect concrete solutions. Everyone has to join in. In future, the Council should really listen to Parliament. We have good ideas. These are not wish lists that we have here, but very specific proposals on how we can make the situation in Europe in such a way that there is no loss of confidence, but that Europe is perceived as what we are trying to do here in Parliament: a Europe of people and a social Europe.

name: Czesław Hoc (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In employment policy, the main value must be man, employee. It is therefore appropriate to apply methods and measures which ensure optimal, equitable and humane management of human capital. In order for this to happen, it is necessary, inter alia, to promote and realistically encourage the unemployed to return to work and to create new jobs for young people. We must remember that 23 million people are unemployed in the 28 countries of the European Union and 4 610 000 are unemployed among those under the age of 25. We need to create equal opportunities in employment, including for people with disabilities, women, young people, etc. We must support entrepreneurship, even create a fashion for entrepreneurship, combat social exclusion, create a friendly model of adaptation for workers and employers. The current document does not exhaust all the elements of good employment practice and, moreover, interferes too much with the competences of the Member States.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, thank you, Commissioner. Please, Commissioner, please, Commission, be ambitious and focus on the problem of unemployment, because there is no social triple A to be defined. There isn't if there's not a quasi-full employment situation. It's the fundamental need. There is no society that breaks inequalities without a full-employment society, because unemployment is a brutal inequality factor. Please listen to the ideas and proposals proposed by Mrs Agea. There's work to be done. Don't let it be a marginal routine for you. Don't introduce us to the same thing every year, as if nothing had happened in a year. One more year of intolerable unemployment in European areas is much more dramatic.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Employment policy must remain the responsibility of the national parliaments. We have unemployment rates in the EU between 4% and 24%. The EU does not function as a template. A single EU employment policy must fail. What is right for Romania may hurt Sweden, and what is good for Greece may be wrong for France. People no longer like this uniform porridge, which is served to them and which we are constantly stirring here. The British stomach is particularly sensitive, but the Poles and Hungarians, as well as the Czechs and Slovaks, are already very bad, and the Austrians and Hungarians are also starting to feel bad. They are already quite green on the face. The porridge is stirred wrong, and if we keep forcing people to eat this porridge, then people will one day put this porridge in front of you .... Set. That's a pity for the porridge, because the recipe was good at times.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report If we follow the report we are discussing here, these guidelines for employment policies are, in the first place, a stillbirth – or rather, a miscarriage. In fact, they have a fundamental design flaw in the same important place, which also accompanies EU policy in so many other policy areas as an evil shadow. As long as European so-called guidelines for employment policies do not explicitly commit themselves to a policy of stopping immigration, effective border management and effective protection against illegal migration, all other labour market policies, however well-intentioned, will inevitably have to fizzle out ineffectively. We discussed the problem yesterday in connection with social dumping. Such dumping is only possible because, up to now, the influx of cheap labour from all over the world into European labour markets has not even been stopped, which inevitably drives down the price of labour in accordance with the principles of supply and demand. This main problem is not addressed in any syllable in your report. Instead, it talks about developing a skilled workforce, promoting job quality, lifelong learning and improving performance in general. But how can this be under such conditions?

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, welcome again to this House at this working session.  One of the common mistakes in policy-making in a given subject is the tendency to isolate that same matter.  In the specific case of employment, we have increased reasons for dealing with the issue in a global way, because it is closely related to economic development, people's skills, the potential of businesses and market needs, among others.  In order for the European guidelines for member states' employment policies to be effective, they must be appropriate to the common realities and objectives of the Union, but also to the specificities of each Member State. That is why I believe that they should be articulated in a balanced way with the country-specific recommendations arising from the European Semester process.  I would like to point out that in this year's report on the social and employment aspects of the European Semester, of which I was rapporteur, we introduced great innovation, increasing its social dimension. We have included three employment indicators in the macroeconomic imbalances procedure, namely the activity rate, youth employment and long-term unemployment, and called for in-depth analyses on the basis of these indicators, taking into account the proposal and implementation of further reforms in the economic, social and labour market fields. For Parliament, country-specific recommendations should take into account not only economic indicators but also, where appropriate, employment indicators. If we do not do this articulation, employment policies are empty, because they disjoint from reality.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Commissioner Thyssen, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Thyssen, for his excellent work. I am very pleased that you are with us today, because you are also working on a European skills development strategy. The link between the labour market and skills development and education is one of the most important points in the European Parliament's recommendations, which we have emphasised very much. As a social scientist, I would like to highlight another aspect. The digital revolution we are facing is already starting to create a new group that needs to be turned away. These are over 45s who are no longer very young, but also not very old. Studies show that their digital skills are falling sharply compared to those under 30 and just over 30. Retraining is particularly important here. In my own country, Estonia, the Ministry of Labour has started a preventive retraining programme to give those workers whose speciality is currently at risk of disappearance due to the digital revolution the opportunity to prepare well in advance to go along with time and find new skills. I hope that this aspect will be included in the recommendations that we are working on at the moment. I would also like to say that I am very embarrassed that the Presidency is not present.
