I hope that such things will not happen during the Estonian Presidency.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Manfred Weber, the chairman of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, said this morning that Europe stands for growth, for sustainability and for employment. The reality is that Europe, the European Union, especially the eurozone, is the sick man of the global economy. We have no growth; in some countries already. Employment has gone down. We have no investments compared to 2007. What is the reason for this? We keep doing the same thing: we formulate guidelines and set up funds from which money flows. Funds are nothing more than redistribution. No one has yet explained to me how redistribution will create jobs. Perhaps we now have more officials in the Commission, that may be the case. But it is a misconception to assume that more work will be done by setting up funds. Work is created in the market itself. We therefore need to change market conditions. And what really brings us forward is TTIP and CETA. An atmosphere of competition is important for job creation!

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Mr President, the findings of the employment report are revealing. Maintaining unemployment at alarming levels and increasing it, as Mr. Younger confessed this morning. Instead of a reduction, as was the target, of the officially poor, there was an increase of 5 million. A quarter of the Union's population, 120 million people, are directly threatened by poverty, while one in four children leave school. Instead of working conditions converging upwards, they converge everywhere downwards. What does the report propose? We also see this in Greece, where the evaluation of the third left-wing memorandum will also bring a further reduction in wages in the private sector, undermining collective agreements, and linking wages to productivity, as the European Social Standard says. Already unemployment benefit instead of the unemployed is given in hot money to employers. After all, unemployment is being used to give more to capital. Do you propose a tax cut for employers, and taxes, who will pay them? The people! So you're suggesting active aging, work to death? Propose - listen, listen - in 2016, the level of pension at the poverty line while for young people generalisation of work flexibility, mobility, i.e. migration. Finally, minimum guaranteed income that is not social sensitivity, but downward pressure of all wages. You can't explain, not why you didn't meet the targets, but the main one: why when so much wealth is produced does poverty widen so much? But why does the work of millions go into the pockets of only a few rich, less and less. Only a planned economy on the basis of meeting popular needs and all possibilities can provide a solution. This is up to the people to fight and overthrow this system.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE).
text: - Dear Colleagues, There are a number of forward-looking recommendations in the draft report. These include strengthening the commitment to public investment and seeking balanced employment policy guidelines for Member States. Goals are important, too. Especially in areas where the Hungary has made significant progress recently. For example, the increase in the activity rate, which has tripled since 2010, has increased much better and at a higher rate than, for example, in Italy. Or the issue of youth unemployment, where there are huge differences between Member States. Personally, I believe in making a living from work. I therefore consider it premature to introduce a general minimum income. In the fight against poverty, other instruments are also needed, such as reductions in overheads or employment subsidies linked to various tax incentives.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: – Thank you, Mr President, and thank you rapporteur Laura Agio for her work. Commissioner, dear colleagues, we really need to finally look reality in the eyes of how our people, the citizens of our European Union, live. And look, the number of people at risk of poverty and exclusion has increased by several million instead of the 2 million people we have ambitiously committed. The level of employment in some countries has not yet risen to pre-crisis levels. In some Member States, the proportion of young people who do not work or receive training is more than twenty per cent and twenty-three per cent of early school leavers. I am no longer talking about children living in poverty. In this context, it is indeed very difficult to see why the Council is ignoring the european Parliament's proposals on guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States. Maybe he thinks he can work alone, unfortunately he doesn't. Life and results are really poor, showing things next. I therefore strongly call on us to work together, both by the Council and the Commission and the European Parliament, because only in this way can we achieve concrete results in improving the lives of our people and creating quality jobs. Thanks!

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, the fight against unemployment is a particularly important part of the overall economic efforts of the Member States, as there is no more important objective than enabling all members of the community who are able and willing to work to survive from their work and feed their families. In order to achieve a higher level of employment, we need to better align the education system with the needs of the labour market and from the earliest days encourage children and young people to be creative and entrepreneurship.  In countries such as Croatia, many people who have skills, knowledge and ideas are discouraged from entering entrepreneurial ventures due to high levies and administrative burdens and this is something that urgently needs to change.  I am sorry that this report also enters the private sphere of citizens and shows a desire to regulate the sharing of family obligations. Politics must not interfere in family relations and I will never support such a thing.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the European Parliament will vote tomorrow to review the guidelines adopted in 2015, in order to find solutions to boost employment, improve skills, develop skills and combat poverty. Unfortunately, the Member States do little to ignore these guidelines, which they themselves adopt, let alone the opinion of the European Parliament. We now see the result, we still have 21 million unemployed in Europe.  So I am speaking today, less to you, Commissioner, who are doing an outstanding job, it must be stressed, than to the members of the Council to ask them whether they intend to finally apply these guidelines. I would like to ask them specifically on three points.  First, what have they done to drastically reduce the burden on wages and to facilitate hiring by companies? Secondly, Europe has given them EUR 6 billion to help unemployed and unse qualified young people find work, internships or training. Have these funds been used effectively? Finally, have they put in place the necessary training to deal with the digital and energy revolutions that will profoundly change the labour market and jobs?

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as enshrined in the Treaties of the European Union, the overarching objective of the internal market is to achieve full employment and social progress, that is, a decent job for each and every European citizen no matter which part of the Union he may belong to. This year, Parliament is once again calling on the Council to revise the guidelines addressing the necessary policies to achieve this fundamental contract with citizens to ensure an inclusive integrated labour market, decent working conditions and wages for an adequate living income by way of collective bargaining. Yet the Council has consistently chosen to ignore this pivotal request of Parliament, thus failing to live up to one of its basic responsibilities under Union law. Will the Council this time break with this irresponsible practice and undertake Parliament’s proposals, or not? I would like to turn to you, Madam Commissioner, joining the previous speaker and beg you to convey this message to the Council since they do not seem to find anything of interest to be here tonight.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, dear Marianne Thyssen, Madam rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, according to Eurostat, the European Union has two million fewer unemployed in March 2016 than in March 2015. So we can finally say that we are on the right track. However, we are still a long way from achieving our objectives and there are still very large disparities between Member States and different generations. I would like to highlight and highlight what this report brings to the guidelines for employment policies in the Member States.  Let's talk about training, which is the real root of the world of work. Let's move on from the education system to the business. From an early age, let's create real exchanges and bridges between the two, especially through internships and learning. Let us give our youth the desire to undertake, let us also stop investing in training and professional sectors that belong to the past. Let us develop lifelong training, because in a changing world, many professional careers call for multi-training. While respecting our social standards, it is imperative to reduce red tape at all levels and in all sectors. Of course, how not to address the issue of taxation. Today it weighs too much on work, let us together choose a tax less detrimental to jobs and growth. I will end by reminding the Member States of the need to make better use of the resources of the European Social Fund at their disposal.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, like many of my fellow Members, I am forced to highlight a deep sense of dissatisfaction of the European Parliament with the behaviour of the Member States.  The Treaty of Lisbon introduces a mechanism that must serve to coordinate the policies governing the functioning of the European labour market. The indications we have retabled improve the quality of this synergy and strengthen its content with ambitious but widely shared proposals in this House aimed at creating a more cohesive and integrated European labour market, reducing levels of unemployment and social exclusion, ensuring decent working conditions and introducing a proposal for a guaranteed minimum income scheme.  The Council's short-term mentality must be abandoned by supporting social Europe by a more Community method, one of the dimensions that must be strengthened in order to relaunch the process of European integration.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like thank the rapporteur for the work that has been done in bringing us to this point. There has been a lot of discussion and a lot of agreement. We all, of course, want to see full employment, we want to see quality employment and, naturally, we want to see workers treated with respect and valued for the contribution that they make to their particular employment. We have seen much social progress in the European Union since its establishment. I see it completely where I come from in Ireland, and I continually outline the benefits that have come, following our membership of the European Union, to those who are in employment. We also need to see that workers are respected and given adequate rest time and holiday time. Maternity leave has been very important. We are in the process of reviewing that now, and it is extremely important for females to keep them in the workforce. The whole issue of paternity leave is also very important and needs to be addressed. I am glad that we are moving somewhat in that area. With such high levels of unemployment among our young people, this is one of the tragedies of our generation. I really welcome the work that the Commissioner is doing in this area in continuing to support the Youth Guarantee and ensuring that young people are given proper employment and support in gaining the necessary skills required in today’s workplaces. This has been a very positive development and one of the real shining lights of the previous Parliament and this Parliament. I thank the Commissioner for her work in this area. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Clune, yes, you mentioned the social progress that was achieved and I truly agree with you. At the same time, you know, considering the ignorance of the Commission’s and the Council’s position on employment policies, would you not agree that it is against the spirit of the Treaties and the spirit of good cooperation between the EU institutions, and that we, the European Parliament, should take a strong position on this situation?

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Absolutely, and thank you for your question: Parliament should take a strong position on this situation. We do want to see that workers across Europe are given due recognition and are provided with the necessary support in the workplace that gives them the respect that they deserve. So I think the position Parliament is taking and the discussion we are having here really do underline our commitment to the workers of Europe.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank, not in form but in substance, the rapporteur, Laura Agea, who, together with her colleagues, has produced a report that precisely outlines the difficult employment and economic situation in Europe, outlining the critical issues but, at the same time, indicating paths, proposals and new priorities.  This report not only calls for the legitimate role of Parliament, but also makes it very clear that ordinary measures are insufficient, that it is time to integrate employment and social targets into macroeconomic procedures in a concrete and ambitious way, that it is time to incorporate appropriate forms of protection against the phenomena of social dumping, as demonstrated by the recent events in which many workers and businesses have been affected.  Last year the Council did not take account of Parliament's suggestions and this year it does not lay down well, because it is not even present. I appeal to the Commissioner, whom I thank for being here, to take up the lines and indications of this report, just as I hope, ladies and gentlemen, that Parliament, when drawing up its proposal for the reform of company law in the next few days, will take account of this report, because through this too Parliament can influence social, economic and employment policies.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, indeed, as I said earlier, we are talking about the labour market, we are talking about social policies. Even today, President Juncker mentioned these things. But we cannot talk about social policies, labour policies, without, indeed, having a role in what it means to implement these policies at national level. The Council's attitude, the way it treats us and the way member States, today's governments, refuse to implement common measures, demonstrates that we are far from finding solutions to these really important problems. I think it is important that, together with the Commission, we work on the ways in which, indeed, everything that the unemployment part, the part of the labour market, is resolved. For this we need a common effort, which must go beyond the European Skills Agenda, we need to go further in the sense of direct promotion with citizens, a coherent attitude and the introduction of social skills at European Union level.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Council has set some guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States of the Union, within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy, with the aim - supposedly - of smart sustainable and unrestricted growth. But at a time when the European Union is imposing policies of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment on the countries of the European South, these guidelines are turning into empty letter projects. Not only have the Member States of the Union not benefited from the supposed support for the Europe 2020 strategy, but, on the contrary, armies of unemployed people have been created throughout Europe. Social inequalities have been established and every day more and more citizens are being driven into poverty. Therefore, the development of employment in Europe so far shows that the employment policy guidelines will not produce the desired results, as long as the Member States remain attached to the harsh austerity policies that, as has been shown in Greece in Spain and Portugal, have created poverty and unemployment.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to propose a reflection to improve the outcome of these guidelines for coordinating European employment policy. The European economy is very diverse, and this variety of productive fabrics does not necessarily coincide with the maps of the Member States. If intelligent specialization works for innovation, the same principle must work to promote employment, because policies should not be applied in industrial areas as in agricultural regions or in places where the services sector predominates. In addition, some of the institutional instruments that are decisive for improving employability, such as education, are managed by regions. For these organisation and functional reasons, I insist that we define European standards to ensure the minimums that the labour market must raise across the Union and that we categorice employment policies to better meet the needs of each economy. This requires more participation for regions to be involved in design and execution more closely and therefore more successful than today. How about, Commissioner, this proposal? I look forward to your opinion.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this debate. As we all know, having a job or not having a job really makes the difference for many people in feeling part of the ‘ins’ or the ‘outs’. It is very important for society and for the economy, but also for individuals, to have employment. It is also important to have a good, and also a stable, policy framework for reforms in the employment and social fields. This is particularly relevant with regard to the implementation of the country—specific recommendations. As you stressed in your report this year, as well as last year, qualitative and social considerations must find their place throughout the employment guidelines. Your report is very ambitious and allows for an enriched reading of the text that is on the table. I hope that you will continue to support it since many of your recommendations are already covered not only in the employment guidelines but also in the Annual Growth Survey (AGS) and, more broadly, in the European Semester. I welcome the honest debate we had today and I am confident that we will have other opportunities to continue this exchange. We are looking forward to your feedback and input through all channels, either in the committees or in the plenary. The Commission always values your opinions and we try to reflect them in our proposals. Some Members of this House made reference to President Juncker’s assertion, in his speech this morning on the State of the Union, that Europe needs to be more social. Others said that we have to work on this together. I could not agree more. We are convinced – and I hope that you share this conviction with me – that the economic strengthening of the Union goes hand in hand with social policy, with the aim of improving people’s lives. This is the core of the European social model and a vital component of our social market economy.  What Europe needs is fair and balanced growth leading to the creation of jobs – decent jobs and quality jobs – as well as opportunities and protection for everyone throughout their lives. May I remind you that this Commission has already taken many concrete steps to make sure that we deserve a triple—A rating in social affairs. We have the European Semester, in which we have deepened the analysis of employment and social performance, including by adding three employment indicators to the scoreboard under the alert mechanism report underpinning the macroeconomic imbalance procedures. We have strengthened the role of the social partners at European and at national level. We have proposed recommendations to the Member States on the reintegration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. You supported this and I thank you again for that. We proposed – and you quickly accepted – the increase in pre-financing for the Youth Employment Initiative. I can announce to you that today we have decided, with the Commission, to adopt the proposal to add EUR 1 billion extra to the Youth Employment Initiative: EUR 1 billion that has to be matched by EUR 1 billion extra out of European Social Fund (ESF) money. This is to reinforce the Youth Guarantee strategy and to make it possible for Member States really to roll this out. We have also proposed the European Accessibility Act, currently under discussion in this House, which will help many disabled people to have more choices and to have better access to the labour market. We have the newly established European Platform – Mr Pirinski is still here – which will also help to combat undeclared work and change it into declared work and, by doing this, create better working conditions for people. We have the new EURES regulation which will make it easier for jobseekers to widen their job search into other Member States. We have also launched a New Start initiative, the new work—life balance initiative, together with Commissioner Jourová, which aims to address the challenges of work-life balance and to remove barriers to women’s participation in the labour market. Many of you, of course, made reference to the need for skills development, and we have also launched the Skills Agenda. We proposed some initiatives on 10 June 2016 and we will come forward with others soon. This is, of course, one of the most important initiatives on the Commission’s work programme of this year and will directly contribute to our promise to deliver on jobs, growth and fairness. We have better protection of occupational safety and health, and the Carcinogens and Mutagens Directive to which we have proposed amendments, and we will come forward with another batch of amendments. Last, but of course not least, we launched the broad consultation on the European pillar of social rights which, as you know, will entail the development of a reference framework that helps us to screen the social – and also employment – policy of the Member States and of the European Union. So a lot has been done and, of course, a lot still has to be done. Whether we have concrete results for our citizens – and you are right to say that we need concrete results – will also depend on us and whether we are capable of working together. If the social partners, Parliament, the Council of Ministers and the Commission all work together, we have the best possible chance of achieving those results. This is what people rightly expect from us, so I can only call on you to continue to work together in a constructive way. This debate was part of that and I thank you very much for it.

name: Laura Agea
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank all my fellow Members and rapporteurs who have worked with me and who have supported the commitment to resubmit the guidelines to the Council. I would like to thank Commissioner Thyssen, who has had respect for this Parliament, as she has always had, by participating, listening and listening, which the Council has denied us.  The world is changed by example and not by words. I believe that in this text, for two years now, we have been saying fine things, fine words. The task of making those words concrete and truly effective now rests with you, Commissioner, and you, the Commissioner, together with the Council. The Member States must take effective and immediate action to relieve the 120 million citizens who currently live below the poverty line, but also to give a better quality of life to all the people of the European Union, demonstrating that this European Union makes sense.  Today we are rebuilding or trying to rebuild Europe, but we are rebuilding it on its rubble, and that is clear and undeniable. We have a commitment, a fundamental task. It is true that we must be united and aware, but we must also put ourselves in a position to roll up our sleeves, have courage, face reality and decide that what we have to do must have done yesterday, we did not do it, we are starting to do it now with a specific commitment.  Take responsibility for finding a single point of those recommendations and tell the Council that that point must be implemented between now and six months, because we need to see concrete gestures that change reality.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Postal services in Europe make an important contribution to cohesion in the European Union. When I was able to negotiate the directive – the third postal directive – here in this House in 2007, it was very important to us that we achieve this territorial cohesion and economic cohesion well together. At that time, we had postal services that developed in a good direction. We had cross-border competition, we had new service providers within the Member States that had developed, new suppliers came onto the market, the supply has widened – everything went in a good direction. Of course, the digitalization of communication has also changed a lot in the 21st century. This cannot be ignored. However, we must also note, of course, that the postal services, which were very active on the European market ten years ago, have retreated back to their home countries. This is actually a development that we did not want to achieve. We really wanted to achieve more competition at European level. Let me give me a quote from Voltaire: "The post is the comforter of life, for it transforms absentees into present." So I can't think of a better advertisement for the post office than Voltaire gave here. We note that what we had been agreeing with each other since the 1990s – I would remind you here of former colleague Brian Simpson, who was the first rapporteur of the first Postal Directive in 1997 – that we have defined a universal service, because it has always been a great concern for us that not only the people in the conurbations receive a good postal service, but that it is also true that in remote regions – on the mountains, we have also been able to do so. , on the islands, in peripheral regions of the Member States, a high-quality postal service is available. Ten years later, however, we find that this is not guaranteed in all Member States. I was surprised to find that we have a Member State – a large Member State, by the way – which has defined for 25% of the population that daily delivery is not necessary. I think it is in all our interests that the universal service, as we have agreed with each other, should really take effect. In order to do this, it must be ensured that universal service providers also have the appropriate framework conditions. They are now found through the VAT exemption. I would also like to point out that all those who have universal service obligations are equipped with an instrument that their competitors do not have. That is why it is also in our interest for those who have the VAT privilege – that is, do not have to charge VAT on stamps – to also provide a rich range of services. This, too, is, of course, part of the universal service. Our aim is to create a level playing field for postal services, as it is so beautifully called in European terms, for small, large, niche and cross-border services. We want the supervisory authorities to ensure that this is ensured. We also want to strengthen the Commission to put more pressure on the national supervisory authorities to ensure that the obligations of the European directive are applied in all Member States. I would particularly like to thank my shadow rapporteurs for their very constructive cooperation. It's been a bit difficult because the team that negotiated in 2007 seems to have just left me. But we got it right together. I am now looking forward to the debate and hope that tomorrow we will send out a clear signal for a strong universal service for our citizens.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you for your own-initiative report and in particular the rapporteur, Mr Ferber, and the rapporteurs for the committee opinions, Ms Anderson and Mr Bach. Postal services are an important sector of the economy. In 2014, over 500 million parcels and 64 billion letters were sent in the EU, but the sector is changing. In that same year, the number of letters sent across the EU declined by nearly 4%. In some Member States the decline was much more severe. In Denmark, for instance, it fell by 14% and in Italy by over 9%. On the other hand, the number of parcels is growing rapidly, as a result of e-commerce.  Improving cross-border e-commerce is one the pillars of the Digital Single Market Strategy. I am very pleased that Parliament agrees with the need for better and more affordable cross-border parcel delivery services. I will come back to parcels, but first I want to say a bit more about the Postal Services Directive.  As you know, we adopted our Application Report on the Postal Services Directive at the end of last year. We concluded that close monitoring and further analysis of the market was needed, and we committed to publishing statistics each year. I am pleased to report that the latest EU postal statistics for the year 2014 were published on the Commission’s website in June. The Commission is also setting up an expert group on postal statistics. We are also working to automate the data collection process to reduce the administrative burden and to enable faster publication. The Postal Services Directive requires universal service providers to deliver both letters and parcels on five days each week, except in exceptional circumstances. But as citizens move to electronic forms of communication and the number of letters declines, delivering each day is becoming more expensive. For example, the price for a 20 g letter rose on average by 7.5% last year. The directive gives a degree of flexibility on how Member States may implement and apply the Directive. This allows them to adapt to the changing needs of users and maintain the sustainability of services. For example, fewer Member States now include bulk letter and newspaper or periodical services in the universal service obligation. And fewer Member States now require deliveries on six days each week instead of five. Universal service providers can be compensated for net costs they incur in providing universal services. This is important, but compensation should be limited to what is strictly necessary and should not distort competition. To help with the next cost calculation, in an annex to the Application Report we set out approaches to that calculation that have been found to be consistent with the Directive.  The draft own-initiative report recognises the fundamental role of independent regulators in the implementation of the Postal Services Directive. In 2010 we established the European Regulators Group for Postal Services to help and advise us and to share best practices between European regulators. We really appreciate the work of the Group on the implementation of the Postal Services Directive and on cross-border parcel delivery. The Group will also have an important role implementing that proposal for a regulation. Now I come back to parcel delivery. As you know, the proposal was adopted in May as part of a package of measures to improve cross-border e—commerce. It is a targeted proposal to drive change in areas where the market and competition have not worked. It complements our 2013 Roadmap and market-led innovation, such as a universal service providers programme to make their services interoperable and an information platform that is being part-funded through COSME. The Regulation proposes action in three key areas. First, it will give postal regulators information about all the parcel delivery companies who are established in that Member State, except for the smallest ones. This will make it easier for them to spot problems in the market. Second, it will make the prices that individuals and small businesses pay more transparent, and require regulators to assess the affordability of those prices. Third, it will require non-discriminatory third-party access to be offered to universal services providers’ cross-border networks.  The proposal should help citizens benefit from lower delivery prices and choose from a wider range of goods, especially in remote and peripheral areas. It should also help small e-retailers get a better deal and help them gain new customers. Parcel delivery companies, especially universal service providers, will also be able to benefit from a growing number of parcels. This can help to create or safeguard jobs, especially in remote and rural areas.  Finally, let me briefly mention employment, since this has been raised by Parliament. As noted in your opinion by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, the Postal Services Directive allows Member States to reflect working conditions in their authorisation procedures. That means that Member States and postal regulators can require that certain minimum standards are met. Thank you very much and I look forward to hearing your views and to a very productive debate.

name: Georges Bach
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank Mr Ferber for the report. Three points are important to me. Firstly, as Mr Ferber has already mentioned, this is to preserve universal service in its present form. Secondly, that the role of national regulators should be strengthened. And thirdly, that we keep an eye on the impact on employees. This sector is changing and this is, of course, having an impact on employees. The traditional providers have managed to retrain people. That was done pretty well. Unfortunately, we have to note that new forms of employment contracts have found their way into the postal sector. There are major differences in working conditions and precarious contracts: part-time and temporary work are increasing.  It is important to us, as the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, to ensure that workers continue to enjoy decent working conditions, good social security, health and safety at work, as well as adequate pay and working time. I would also like to highlight the good cooperation with the social partners and the objective that increasing competition in future will not be at the expense of workers.

name: Lucy Anderson
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, I would like to welcome this report on behalf of the Socialists and Democrats and thank Mr Ferber, and all of our colleagues in various committees, who have worked very hard on this report. I am glad to say that we have got a good result.  Recent years have seen significant changes to postal services in the EU alongside the rapid development of the parcel delivery sector, as has been said. The review of the Postal Services Directive is a welcome opportunity to assess these developments now and establish our priorities for the future of services in Europe. It is important to note at the outset that the Postal Services Review and the report that we will vote on tomorrow have both confirmed that the directive does not require the privatisation of a universal service provider. In fact, it stresses that EU citizens have a guaranteed right to affordable and regular postal delivery services and it makes clear that these rights need to be protected. So together we must ensure the long-term sustainability of the universal service obligation, protecting, as has also been said, minimum delivery standards while recognising that the current provisions do provide Member States with the necessary flexibility within the law in the application of the directive, according to particular geographical circumstances. I would urge you very much to welcome this report with me. Parliament’s report makes it clear that competition in the postal sector must develop in a way that enhances rather than impedes citizens’ basic rights. Greater consumer choice is to be welcomed, but we must ensure that this does not lead to cherry picking, particularly in relation to employment practices in the sector. It has been acknowledged in the report that liberalisation of the postal sector has led to substantial differences in working conditions and wages and the report also stresses that increasing competition should not lead to illegal social practices. The EU and the Member States must work together to protect fundamental workers’ rights across the sector irrespective of employment status. Now while this report deals primarily with the review of the Postal Services Directive, we know that online shopping is a major factor, and that has also been mentioned. So overall, this is a good report, and I would urge everyone to vote for it tomorrow.

name: Wim van de Camp
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. I too would like to thank first and foremost rapporteur Markus Ferber, but also the shadow rapporteurs of the Committee on Transport for the work they have done, as has Mr Dombrovskis, who is tonight allowed to replace the Commissioner for the Internal Market and is doing so in a very professional manner. It may be a little strange that in this digital world we are still talking about traditional mail delivery, but I have learned in recent months that the classic mail delivery and also the general service of De Post is extremely important for many people in Europe. I am not just talking about the elderly or people in less densely populated areas. In fact, everyone still has orders that expire by post. As the Commissioner said, this is followed by the package delivery directive. We all know that with e-commerce, this is a hugely growing issue. But now that I have the floor, I would like to ask you if you can find out how many implementing reports the European Parliament has dealt with at the moment. We are still faced with huge packages of initiative reports, but at the beginning of this period we agreed that the European Parliament would focus more on introducing and enforcing agreed legislation. There was a huge story by Jerzy Buzek about execution reports, but I have the impression that not much is happening yet and perhaps you and your department can deny that.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President. Yes, Mr Ferber, for once we were going to absolutely support the report, how well balanced it is, the Commission is going and snapping it, moving forward with a regulation with which we no longer agree so much. With this, we have found that your report , for which I congratulate you very much , is reading it in the light of that other Regulation, that of the package, which has been forward to it. I would therefore like to ask Mr Dombrovskis why, if you are aware, the pace of presentation has so fast-paced that you have missed deadlines, consultations with the sector and has not even deigned to wait to listen to this Parliament. I say that some reasons will have and certainly not the best. I must say that, of course, we do not agree with the equivalence that is made between postal services and parcel services and roaming. It has nothing to do with the telecommunications sector with postal services and parcel service. Secondly, I would also like to make it clear that on some of the issues we are going to come up with a head-on battle with the proposal you have made. However, I must thank Mr Ferber and his report for their full balance, and even that he has accepted all the amendments with which we were trying, again, to maintain cohesion and the defence of a universal postal service with decent jobs.

name: Jacqueline Foster
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to Marcus Ferber for his dedication in this long-standing directive. I was initially delighted when it looked as though we had reached a common conclusion after such a long time, but it is not quite there.  The Royal Mail means a great deal to all of us in the UK. Indeed, its origins date back to Henry VIII, the original Brexiteer. 1635, in the reign of King Charles I,  paved the way for a unified postal service across the UK and 1883 saw the introduction of our postman. So, as it stands, the current UK Postal Services Act 2011 goes further than the minimum obligations laid down for a universal service. A six-day a week provision is guaranteed with uniform prices and free services to blind and partially sighted people, which shows that we have fully met the requirements to date. Regrettably, due to the unwelcome inclusion of a social dimension we are unlikely to support the rapporteur in the vote tomorrow. The key reason for this is not that we do not support great opportunities and good working conditions, but the reference in paragraph 48 to the possible installation of tachographs on vehicles of less than 3.5 tons. It was only in 2014, following a lengthy battle to exclude vehicles of this weight, that that regulation was supported. Finally, Mr President, we now live in a world where most of us will be buying goods online and we expect a 24/7 service. Because of this, the advantages of SMEs and the rise of entrepreneurs in this business have been most welcome. I therefore cannot support your report, Mr Ferber, unless paragraph 48 is removed. And I do hope that that will be the case before the vote tomorrow.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I think that postal services are primarily a question of communication. I do not think that there is anything else that has changed as much in the last 20 years as communication. I wonder what the ratio was between the number of postcards sent last summer and the number of WhatsApp messages or pictures sent through Facebook. It has changed dramatically. If we look at the first directive of 1997 now it seems like history, and even if we look at the third directive of 2008 it is well overdue. I very much appreciate that our colleague, Mr Ferber, did not stick to the directive, but tried to look at not only what is happening today, but what will be happening tomorrow. I think that this is the way to go. We need to meet the expectations and demands of consumers, and we need essentially to keep up the pace.  For me, the way to do this is to have a solid regulatory environment in which we have high-quality universal services with a certain degree of flexibility, independent – and I stress independent – national authorities that monitor the situation on the market, a fair environment between the companies that have been on the market for a long time and the newcomers, between the universal services companies and the SMEs, and also a solid awareness of cross-border opportunities. This is the way to go, not protectionism, which I fear is being encountered in a number of Member States. For me, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the end; this is the start because we are well ahead and we are awaiting the next proposal, which the Vice-President has already spoken about: parcel delivery services. I am looking forward to that and I think that we should be bound by the principles on which we have agreed in this report. Thank you very much, Mr Ferber, for the cooperation we had on this report.

name: Tania González Peñas
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as in so many other sectors, the Commission has made great efforts to liberalise the postal services market. And, as in so many other sectors, the arguments underlying this strategy are to ensure accessibility throughout the Union, to ensure quality and reliability criteria or to boost dynamism and job creation. It is no surprise, as in so many other sectors, that these objectives have not been met; on the contrary, the effects on the States which have most intensively implemented the provisions of the Directive are precisely the opposite. On the one hand, the characteristics of the service, with an overall deterioration in quality, with recorded increases in complaints and complaints, especially those aimed at new operators. And with a specific worsening of the two notes characteristics of the public postal service: accessibility and universality; because new operators, private operators, concentrate their efforts on the most lucrative segments of the postal market to the detriment of services for small users; and because higher quality losses occur in less urban and worst-connected areas, increasing service inequality by geographic area. And, if we look at the labour consequences, we see a general drop in job creation, a reduction in average wages and an overwhelming deterioration in working conditions. In our group we wonder when the time will come for the European institutions to accept the evidence and abandon the repeated idea that liberalisation is the solution to everything. It's a failed idea. You have to bet on public services and quality employment.

name: Jill Evans
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Ferber, for the report and for including amendments from our Group as well, and the Greens/European Free Alliance will be supporting the report tomorrow. It is essential, of course, as other colleagues have said, to keep the universal service obligation to deliver and collect five times a week as a minimum. It is important too to allow enough flexibility for Member States to meet their own domestic needs, as well as ensuring that this service is sustainable. Post is one of the most valued public services, and has changed and developed a great deal in recent years as we have become more digital. I know from my own constituency in Wales how vital it is to ensure that there is no discrimination against people who live in rural or mountainous areas compared with people living in cities and towns. There has to be an equal service. The report highlights the importance of decent working conditions and wages for all postal workers, for more checks on rest times, improving driver and road safety. It also includes protection for consumers, and the need for easy recourse, particularly in the case of cross-border services and it aims at ensuring affordability and access for all, which must be a basic principle for all of our services.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support First of all, I would like to commend colleague Ferber for his work in drafting this report and for his susceptibility to my amendments. More importantly, I must also say that e-services and e-commercial services are becoming more common, but without classical postal services these services cannot function. Online shopping doesn't work without it.  It is therefore particularly necessary to provide postal services in remote, secluded and less densely populated regions. But we also need to retain flexibility, which is why I am pleased that the document we are discussing also takes into account local specificities and the scope of the long-term sustainability of the service, which is extremely important for the Member States.  In addition to domestic services, it is also very important to provide cross-border postal services at transparent and reasonable prices, while using the achievements of the present day, such as cross-border track and trace systems, which are still quite expensive in today's context.  Finally, it is important to think about the use of new technologies. Such an option is available, for example, in the delivery by drones, which, with the appropriate regulation, can be an effective alternative to classical delivery, especially in sparsely populated, remote regions.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the right to receive and communicate information is an important pillar of European policy. We need to ensure a universal postal service on affordable and high-quality terms, especially for the frequency of mail distribution and collection.  The most remote and sparsely populated areas deserve special mention, since the provision of the service in these places is essential for reasons of social cohesion. There is no denying the need to ensure, in exceptional circumstances, an adequate margin of flexibility to preserve the sustainability of the service, adapting it to the new needs of users and recent market developments. This is, however, provided that the role and function of universal service, characterised by the pre-eminence of the public interest, does not fail.  Of fundamental importance, then, is the strategic role that new digital technologies must play in this context, offering a fair balance between flexibility and the right to information.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: –Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. The postal services market in Europe is undergoing changes that result in a decrease in demand for basic services. Of course, this process must not mean giving up the obligation for the State to provide universal postal services, but some reflection on the scope and frequency of their provision is needed. Universal operators cannot compete effectively on the commercial services market when they bear the cost of providing services that are unnecessary for consumers' needs. The construction of the Single European Digital Market, particularly in the area of e-commerce, means that the market for parcels, especially those delivered across borders, requires certain regulations that will reduce costs and enable new eri actors in the small and medium-sized enterprises sector to enter the market. Full access to information such as the price of the service, delivery time and return cost is particularly important, which will allow consumers and traders to choose the best postal service.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur for his work. I welcome Parliament's draft report and share the view that postal services should be provided as a universal service to all Citizens of the Union. I believe that it should be possible to harmonise the definition of universal service and to assess the quality of service on the basis of minimum standards at European level.  In my country too, when the debate is hot, I would like to say that I do not believe that low population density constitutes an argument for reducing the frequency of distribution under the universal service obligation. Affordable and reliable delivery of postal consignments and parcels is an important basic service for all citizens, but also a lifeline for businesses across Europe. I hope that the structures will not be reformed in a problem-oriented way, but precisely in a solution-oriented way, and we will see that mail delivery is not a burden or an expense, but a key function of society that also builds territorial cohesion. Postmen are also the kind of backbone that should be appreciated, not just harassed.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to thank the rapporteur warmly for emphasising in his report the importance of universal service. Daily mail delivery is part of the quality of life, not only in the cities and where many people live, but also in the villages and in remote areas, where fewer people live. And the exceptions that are already in place today are very careful, and generosity is absolutely out of place.  I would remind you that the Member State from which I come – Italy – has made a provision that 20% of the population can be exempted from universal service. This means, for example, in my region that of the 116 municipalities, universal service is only guaranteed in around a handful of municipalities; everyone else is looking through their fingers and have to hope for a mail delivery every other day. Well, if the bill comes from the telephone service or the electricity bill a day later, that is not a problem, but when the daily newspaper arrives yesterday, it is indeed a problem. There is nothing older than the daily newspaper from the day before.  That is why we should be very careful with the universal service and oblige the postal services to carry out this service, this obligation. Finally, postal delivery is a public service and, as such, it should be dealt with.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I wanted to refer to that last sentence. Mail yes – this is part of a public service. Without access to the postal service group, the area, people are simply subject to the exclusion process, and this is what we would very much like to avoid. Let us remember that, in fact, what we are supposed to provide is geographical, economic and financial access to postal services. So we have to reckon with this, that some fixed costs have to be borne. And with this, of course, there are also requirements for quality. I would like to warn against expecting wild competition. In my country, the government introduced a solution a few years ago – the cheapest, please, information services from polish courts were implemented in a meat shop, with parsley, and of course the consequences afterwards were deply – just because it was a few pennies cheaper. I also stress the importance of good conditions for postal workers, and here I do not agree with your statement from the ECR.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I represent a very rural region and part of my region in Cornwall has levels of deprivation and isolation that are so severe that its half-a-million inhabitants qualify for maximum levels of funding support from the European Union. It is by any measure a sparsely populated and remote area, so postal services are vital and they are protected by the UK’s 2011 Postal Services Act. I am glad to see that this own-initiative report comes some way towards guaranteeing a similar universal service obligation throughout the rest of Europe, but let us recognise the difficulties and challenges presented by this obligation. Postal services providers have to be lean, flexible organisations able to adapt to changing circumstances, and changing and indeed falling demand. They do not need to have additional burdens placed upon them by regulation. So let us protect services for my constituents in Cornwall and reject the calls in this report for more rigid employment contracts, tachographs and other restrictive practices.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is about more than competition. It's about satisfied customers and that we act well. In order for us to have satisfied customers, we need employees who have decent working conditions. I would like to thank Georges Bach, who, as draftsman of the opinion in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, was able to reach a very broad agreement and who also put our positions in good place. I would also like to thank the Committee on Transport for incorporateing this social dimension into the report. This is because it is often apparent that competition is purely on the backs of workers. We are calling for fair working conditions, regardless of the form of employment, precisely because we also see that many self-employed, solo self-employed, also experience poor working conditions in subcontractor chains in this area. These massive problems should also lead us to use good social partner regulations to ensure good health and safety at work and good standards for the future.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: – Thanks to electronic communication, the number of letters sent is gradually decreasing, but Slovaks still send more than 200,000 letters per year. The trend in sending packages is the opposite. Their number is increasing, mainly due to the ever-evolving online shopping. It is therefore important that postal services are provided at affordable prices and are really accessible to all. In the Slovak Republic, however, prices for postal services have long been above the European Union average. For example, the price for sending a standard letter by first class is at the level of the Netherlands and higher than in Sweden, Ireland or Germany. I therefore consider any further price increase by the Slovak Post to be unacceptable. At the same time, I would like to appeal to all, and therefore both public and private, postal service providers to ensure wheelchair access to their buildings, mailboxes and websites. This will make it easier to use their services not only for people with disabilities, but also for the elderly or, for example, for parents with pushchairs.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, postal services offer a key task to developed service economies. It is a growing and innovative sector, which very often in the Member States demonstrates that public services can and remain competitive in an environment of fiscal austerity. It is important that, for the needs of citizens, minimum standards of convergence of postal services between Member States should be established. However, this does not mean that national regulatory authorities should be bypassed, as the Commission wishes. On the contrary, the quality of services can be assessed by consumers themselves through the process of a pan-European service evaluation network. Quality in postal services means keeping a delivery and delivery schedule on time. And all this can be done.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened with interest to the views expressed during this debate. It has shown the continuing importance of affordable, reliable and sustainable postal services across the EU, and it has underlined the role of postal operators in providing employment. As I said at the outset, the postal market is changing quickly across the EU. I can assure you the Commission is keeping a close eye on developments. I am pleased that, overall, Parliament agrees that there is a need for flexibility in the universal service obligation, within the boundaries set by the Postal Services Directive. I am also pleased that you agree that we need better and more affordable cross-border parcel delivery services. On some of the specific questions raised on this point let me underline the following. The Commission has listened to the European Parliament’s views following the adoption of the Commission’s parcel roadmap in 2013. The proposal for a regulation on cross-border parcel delivery was adopted in May 2016, as part of the Package on the digital single market measures to improve e—commerce. The proposal is not for price regulation like roaming price caps, so one should not draw parallels here and we need to look at parcels and postal services because both are used in e-commerce. Once again we are already discussing this regulation with the Council, and I am looking forward to working with the European Parliament on this as well.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, a heartfelt thank you to all those who took part in the debate – it has shown that it makes sense for us to have once again dealt with the postal services. The current directive had to be implemented in all Member States by 2013. The Commission has made a communication – it was also its legal obligation – on the implementation of the directive, and that is now Parliament's opinion on this implementation report. In this respect, it also makes sense. I very much regret that our British colleagues from the Conservative side are not only leaving the EU, but are also unable to vote in favour of this report. I would have been very happy to have her in the boat. I would like to draw the attention of the members of the GUE Group to this: I think we have different views on this. This is also reflected in the amendments, which my group will not support. And if you have different views, you have to look at how the votes turn out. In any case, I come from a region where we now have a well-established second service provider, which also supplies mountain areas and rural areas. All this works if the framework conditions are right – and the directive lays the foundations for creating framework conditions so that this can work. But we have also heard that it is not yet working in a number of regions. The report also asks the Commission to ensure that national regulators are properly monitored so that they fully implement European law. The last point I would like to make: we have, of course, already noted that the traditional postal service providers, through the World Postal Association, have tried to fight against this directive, particularly on the issue of charges for cross-border mail. When I think of the fact that, when I was elected here, a letter from my constituency to Brussels cost the same as a letter within my constituency, which is no longer the case today, it shows that the traditional postal service providers could still do a lot for a Europe that is growing together. I would be pleased if we could once again achieve a single tariff for the whole of the European Union.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. – Half of the Union's consumers shop online. And the numbers continue to grow in a global market where there are no borders. That is the reality around the world, except in the Canary Islands, where postal shipment of imports and exports is subject to payment of the so-called Single Customs Document (DUA), which curbs the purchases and sales of the islanders. This is a drag on the development of e-commerce in the Islands. The ultraperiphery cannot be an impediment to competitiveness in global trade. Removing barriers to e-commerce must be crucial to achieving a true digital single market, without excluding any region. It is imperative to seek solutions so that canaries are not penalized with "abusive intermediation extracosts" in postal mailing to and from the Archipelago, and are no longer discriminated against in the virtual market. The 'effective access' to the same commercial offer as Community citizens must be ensured, so that the Canary Islands enjoys the same conditions in the transit of goods as in any other Member State. Canary Islands cannot be left off the European Digital Single Market.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Madam President! Firstly, thank you to rapporteur Karas for a very good report on the financing of our small and medium-sized enterprises. I would also like to thank Commissioner Dombrovskis, who has been deeply involved in this issue. When we talk about the Capital Markets Union, there are, of course, some levers in the toolbox. I think we need to take the whole palette, because on top of the financial crisis it has become even more pronounced that small and medium-sized enterprises are finding it difficult to raise the capital that is needed. It is also what we are hearing from all the speakers tonight that we need to do more. Today we have heard that Juncker is increasing the entire investment plan. It is also good for small and medium-sized enterprises. Many people have already received funding from the first part of the package. What I would like to highlight this evening is also that the implementation of the Basel rules in Capital Requirements Directive IV has not made it easier for small and medium-sized enterprises to obtain bank financing and to obtain financing through mortgage bonds. Now we are faced with a revision of Capital Requirements Directive IV, we are in fact faced with stricter rules again from the Basel Committee, which means that we need to padded even more. If we compare European companies with American companies, the Americans are financed with corporate bonds, while in Europe we finance our small and medium-sized enterprises with bank and mortgage bonds. That is why we need to ensure that we get a proper solution when Dombrovskis now starts with Capital Requirements Directive V.
